I had been looking forward to eating here FOREVER. I had a friend come into town so I figured this would be a great spot to take them. Satisfying my desire while also showing them a good time. Win-Win. We had a Tuesday reservation and the place was pretty full even then. We were seated immediately and were soon brought some fresh bread which is usually one of my favorite parts of the meal and Cochon was no exception. The bread was so good. Our waitress, who we had a hard time getting in contact with all night came and told us the specials (Pork Belly and Soft Shelled Crab) so my date and I decided to go with that along with the oysters and pork cheeks. Here's what I'll say about the food at Cochon; It's edible. It wasn't amazing. It wasn't even especially memorable. It was mediocre at its best. The oysters and the bread were the highlight of the meal. I wouldn't say don't eat here but I will say that there are many other restaurants in the city that will give you better food for your buck. Cochon was just okay.

We came for drinks on a Saturday evening.  Super easy to get a table for 5.  We split the boudin balls, which were heavenly as can be!  Service was super friendly.  This is a great place for a yummy casual meal out in NOLA!

this place is nice. 
Service. Popular place. You need to wait to get seats. You cannot sit down until all your group are there, which means, there is no way that you send one guy ahead to keep a table for other lazy team members. The waiter we got is fine. We wanted to split the bill even, he said he cannot do it. He asked us to write down how much each person want to pay. So we have to write down name and bill amount on the receipt.  
Food. Food is good. I had pork belly and pork face. Both are very good.

Make the trip to the warehouse district. Don't leave NOLA without a visit to Cochon. First stop: Cochon Butcher next door to the restaurant to taste some unusual sausages. Deer sausage is delectable. Duck pastrami ultra tasty. 
Now go have some dinner at the restaurant. Appetizers : ribs, fried liver, cucumber salad. Ask for a side of fried pork rinds (not on the menu but a treat). 
Fried chicken main, braised beef short rib and the rabbit and dumplings...oh baby. Fried chicken comes with a side of watermelon and tomato salad. Nuff said. 
Great local craft beers. NOLA Blonde was a great sidekick to wash down those pork rinds. Chocolate Rice Pudding or Pineapple upside down cake with a side of sorbet...tremendous finish.

Unbelievable!  Every single thing that hit our table was fantastic. Superb!  Fine dining in shorts.  The ingredients were fresh and the meat was top notch.  I felt like in was eating in my grandmothers kitchen...with an interesting culinary twist.   Wow...just wow...

My favorite part of our trip to New Orleans has to be our visit to Cochon.  They describe themselves as cajun creole cuisine.  I describe it as "AWESOME" cuisine.

Ambiance and décor is clean lines, a bit modern, very clean and spacious looking restaurant. 

We, a party of 4, started with a hot brioche. HELLO!!!!!!!  I was already smiling.  We purchased a bottle of Pinot Noir while some had a cocktail or two and got underway... and did we ever!!!

We pretty much had it all.  Ribs, cucumber salad, boucherie plate, cochon and the brisket. When I tell you each was better than the next, I am not exaggerating.  I am not a big pork eater but this was easily the most satisfying pork meal of my life.  We even repeated the ribs and cucumber salad they were so good!  

For dessert we ordered a lemon poundcake with ice cream which was just great.  The chocolate cream pie with salted caramel & malted milk crumbles was the wifey's favorite.  My least favorite was the   strawberry pudding with lemon shortbread.

Lunch took just over 2 1/2 hours and that's the way it should be when eating pork.  It was just UNREAL!!!

We left New Orleans the next day. The couple we were with? They came back to Cochon before returning to S. Florida!!!

Hey Larry do you want to go back to New Orleans? Hey whomever you are... if it means another visit to Cochon... heck ya!!!!

This is by far THE best restaurant during our three-day stay. The environment is clean, modern, and inviting. The staffs are very friendly. Most importantly, the foods are outrageously good. I'm a food lover and a good cook myself. My first exposure to Cajun food was through a cooking book written by chef Paul so naturally the K-Paul's Restaurant was on top of my must-go places during my stay. The day before I finally went there but left feeling unimpressed. That experience filled me with certain doubts when I went to this restaurant this afternoon. Boy was I surprised! The wood fired oyster was so good I had to order one more plate. It is served on a bed of rock salts and the oysters are juicy and full of flavor. I normally prefer fresh raw oysters with little  spice added, but now I'm a convert. I will choose these cooked oysters over any raw ones without blinking. The fried alligator is very good too. The breading does not override all the flavor and preserves the unique texture of the meat quite well. Eat each piece with the fresh mint leave provided and you will enjoy a quite complex taste unlike typical fried stuff. The fisherman style fish is a masterpiece as well!

All in all, this is one of the few truly memorable dining experiences I've had in my life. It has been a few hours and I'm still in food coma. LOL.

This restaurant absolutely lived up to its reputation. It was incredible. We arrived about 30 to 45 minutes before closing and the only available seats were at the bar, I was somewhat disappointed to not be at a table. It was no fault of the restaurants that I arrived late at night without making a reservation though. The bartenders who served us were very knowledgeable about the menu and friendly. We even ordered one dish twice it was so good. I'm sorry I can't remember what it was though. 
We went to New Orleans for less than 24 hours on a last-minute getaway and had had only one night to eat dinner and we chose Cochon. It was a great choice and I would do it again. This is the sort of place where you expect the waiters to be "too cool for school" but I was very impressed with how they treated to unhip tourists.

Awesome! Fantastic staff. Great atmosphere. Crawford pie was excellent. The wood-fire oysters are to die for. The fried alligator was really good. And life doesn't get any better than sweet tea with rabbit and dumplings. Did I say AWESOME.  I came here because of all the reviews on yelp and they were spot on.

1300+ reviews, I'm pretty sure everything has been covered. 

Get reservations
Order the Mac n cheese (probably order two)
The ribs are excellent and have a kick.
Brisket is delicious along with a bite of the potato salad. 
The Lima beans are surprisingly good. 

After ordering all the desserts I can say with confidence that the chocolate peanut butter pie is something you will never forget. I was never able to prepare myself enough for that last bite. Never.

Wow. Wow. Wow. This place is amazing. Tonight was my first time here. I'm down here from Atlanta with the band I travel with and a local friend recommended this place. First off, right when you walk in the door you smack right between the eyes with the amazing smell of the kitchen. Followed by the great atmosphere and great hostesses. We had the oysters as our started and by far the best I've ever had. I had the rabbit and dumpling today and their use of fresh ingredients and herbs is very much loved by me! My meal was an A+ and I have no complaints about my meal or our waiter. He was great. Very knowledgable about the menu and great attitude. 

I wouldn't change a thing! Stop what you are doing and go there. Now. Like - Right now.

This was my favorite restaurant in NOLA. The fried alligator and rabbit dumplings were AMAZING. 

My grandpa gave the waiters a really difficult time and they were friendly, patient, and generous. 

Basically the definition of a 5 star restaurant.

Great food! The menu was a bit daunting at first, but take the leap and try it! The eggplant and shrimp dressing was amazing as well as the chocolate cake. My advice, though, would be to make a reservation before you go. We waited an hour for a table for 2 while many reservation-made guests zoomed past us to their tables. Great food; great service.

OMG! What can I say but excellent. Everything about Cachon was exceptional. We had the oyster appetizer which had a little bit of heat but not overwhelming. We split the Louisiana Cachon and portion was perfect for two people. The cachon had wonderful flavor and was moist. Waitstaff was extraordinary! Thank you for a great lunch and we will be back!

Before we left for vacation asked a few co workers where to eat in NOLA. One said we had to go to Cochon. One of the best recommendations we've every gotten. Contemporary atmosphere. Upscale. We were traveling with a group of 10 friends so we made reservations a few weeks in advance. Started off with appetizers and the Wood-Fired oysters were wonderful.  The Gulf fish was amazing and a number of us had creamy grits and they were awesome. 
If we lived nearby, we would be regulars.

Peche's sister restaurant that I dripped into for lunch during a downtown downpour. Grilled oysters, fried chicken livers, meatball and polenta--each small plate delectable. A bright, open space that I had largely to myself in the afternoon netherworld between late lunch and early dinner. The menu was so comprehensive I can easily see returning multiple time to sample everything.
We tried about 5 or 6 small plates and boucheries. All were amazing, especially the fried boudin and the fried liver. Plus, the atmosphere is great and the service too.

We had the fried alligator, rabbit dumplings, gumbo, Mac & cheese, & twice baked potato. The food was excellent, and our kids loved all of it! Portions aren't very big, but are extremely flavorful - so you want to savor all of it. The service was good, but the food was even better.

We went to Cochon this evening as the last dinner in NOLA. We could not pick the better place because everything was absolutely amazing! 
Crawfish pie, mushroom salad, and bread pudding. We'll dido mutely be back when we visit New Orleans again!

First let me say we are from this area. About 45 mins south of NOLA. I had seen the chef from Cochon on one of my favorite shows Chopped, so this place was on my bucket list of restaurants.

Atmosphere was nice. I liked the decor. Personally I am not a fan of banqet seating where the person next to me could eat off my plate. There are maybe 4 booths but none were available.

Apps/ Small Plates = Fried chicken livers & Boudin balls
You get 3 of each for I think it was $9 for each plate. They were good. Not like wow I want more though. We are from this area so we have eaten both many times. So maybe we are biased on those items.

Entrees = I got the gulf fish of the day which was redfish. My wife got the fried chicken that came with a watermelon & heirloom tomato salad.
Sigh..well...I love fish & when the waiter said they leave the skin on & make it crispy, I thought oh good because I like that. Well lets just say he failed to mention THEY LEAVE THE FRICKN SCALES ON!! Needless to say after a bite with a mouthful of scales, I was SO done. It made me sick to my stomach. The waiter was apologetic, saying thats how they cook it. I said Yea well we live down here too & people around here eat crispy skin when its on the fish but I didnt expect the fish to not be cleaned & descaled! He was kind of cavalier about it like Not my fault but continued to apologize. In the end, they took it off our bill which was great on their part. 
My wife said the chicken was fine. The BEST PART of the whole meal was the sweet yellow watermelon & heirloom cherry tomato salad. She added a small amount of the white vinegar on the table (nice touch by the way) that had a few peppers floating in it & a dash of salt and OMG , we both said we could have eaten a bowl of just that!

Everything is a la carte. My $28 fish only came with a pile of pickled onions. We did get the mac & cheese. I always try mac & cheeae when its on a menu. Not a fan of this one.

We didnt bother getting dessert. My wife wanted peach cobbler but the waiter said the chef took it off the menu for that night because " he didnt like how it was looking". So I guess of he thought it wasnt good for whatever reason, it was best he didnt serve it.

Instead we grabbed the heavenly & undeniably amazing cheesecake from Ruth's Chris steakhouse downstairs at our hotel.

So Id say it was an experience....one I dont care to repeat

The feeling of chewing & then realizing I had a mouthful of fish scales is permanently engrained in my mind.

I give this place five stars because it is a wonderful blend of the casual atmosphere and well executed regional food, taken to the next level.

Cocktails are always excellent.  Small plates are never a miss and tonight was no exception.  Boudin, pork cheek, fried livers with pepper jelly, wood fired oysters, mushro salad, the heirloom tomato salad, the charcuterie plate and the crawfish pie.  Unreal.  A shared oyster and bacon sandwich - again, epic.  It is one of the few places I eat fried oysters in the city - they are done to a turn - every.single.time

Reservations are now a must if you'reore than a party of two.  On many nights - no reservation - no eating... Irrespective of party size.

Thought it was over hyped, overpriced and very ordinary, in general. Not to mention, I found the staff pretty high handed and even rude. The fried alligator was just about decent but nothing to die for. The pork cheeks were over cooked and the oysters were the worst I've had in NOLA. Not recommended.

This establishment gets five stars and is a must try for anyone visiting New Orleans. Love love love the fried aligator & wood fire oyster roast. Highly recommend the pork cheeks & mushroom salad. For entrees we split smoked ham hock, catfish court bouillon (a bit of kick) Louisiana Couchon & short ribs. One dish was better than the next. The macaroni & cheese casserole was delicious too. The old fashion Couchon & Hey-Jack are lite & refreshing cocktails. After our late lunch, we went next door to the Cuchon Butcher for some bacon pralines & peanut butter pie. Stick to your ribs good.

We had the rabbit and dumplings, braised cheek and shrimp & eggplant casserole.  Both the rabbit and the casserole were fantastic!!!!!  I have had better cheek but it was all the way in DC.   

Rabbit - it was tender, juicy and the sauce was divine.  I wish the dumplings were a little more doughy but they were still great.  I would have never thought to order this there but everyone including the waiter suggested it.  A must to try.

Shrimp and eggplant - my God I have never wanted to eat so much eggplant in my life.  It was spicy with a very slight sweetness to it.  Oh I loved it.

Cheek - I have had cheek before where it just melted in my mouth.  This was a little dry for me.  I think it was overcooked but I didn't even enjoy the flavor.  Not sure where they were going with this.  

My advice, try the restaurant, get the rabbit and the casserole.  Adventure with a few other menu items but not the cheek.

We didn't have a wait because we had reservations.  Others were waiting for an hour if they did not have reservations.  

Good prices, good food and fun atmosphere!

I wanted to try the rabbit stew, so I dragged my wife down there to try.  This place is very crowded and it wasn't even prime dinner time yet.  We decided to eat at the crowded bar because we didn't want to wait forever.  The bartenders were very nice and their drinks were great.  I ordered the rabbit stew which was good, but my wife ordered the pork belly which was great.  She liked it so much that the next time she went to New Orleans she dragged all her friends along to eat there.

This place was definitely worth the price tag. I had the bacon and oyster sandwich with Mac and cheese. The bacon was thick and perfectly crispy, paired with the moist oysters it made the sandwich one of the best I've ever had. I'm not sure what cheese they used for the Mac but it was amazing, I wanted to lick the dish. I took one of the rolls and scraped everyday bit of cheese sauce. I also tried the fried alligator and the garlic aoli was much better than other dipping sauces I've had with gator, they're normally too spicy but this was great. I would definitely come back here. It would be nice to sit on the patio next time!

Months later the flavors of the dishes at Cochon are on my palate and am salivating. 

First,  the ambiance is open dining, nice Scandinavian looking wood benches, sleek and modern yet you feel the NOLA vibe here.  The hip wait staff are  friendly, accommodating and are definitely proud of their restaurant.  Cochon has a James Beard award which  I'm sure doesn't hurt.  I knew this was going to be a feast so instead of taking the rental car I walked with friends about a mile to Cochon. 

Now the cuisine.   What did I think?  Sleek simple flavors, genuine which is  a  stark contrast to bold Orleans flavors.  I am very impressed that there are options other than Emeril's dynasty of restaurants, the Brennan dynasty of restaurants, Arnaud's, Galatoire's,  Antoine's  and K-Pauls to savor flavors of the new , "Southern" New Orleans.  Think earthy, savory, spicy yet restrained, distinct and genuine.  

For starters, I had the ribs appetizer because honestly, if the totem for this restaurant is a pig, you bet your mint julep ima get me some porc.  I had a glass of red Zin with this slightly spicy dish, 3 ribs to an order, enough for 2, 2 going to the pork glutton.  I was tempted to sin but  I shared this with two others.  It was super scrummy, different, with surprising yet awakening flavors of fennel seed  BBQ spices, vinegar.   The spiced melon rind added savory contrast to the vinegar that gave me a lightbulb moment --- why aren't additions like this a standard in our culinary lexicon?    The ribs were served at room temperature  which  threw me off.   I expected something hot off the smoker , yet I quickly realized that by serving them at room temp,  all the flavors and condiments are showcased.    I tasted a barbecued rib that was so different so clean and spicily yummy from any BBQ i've had.  I was in heaven.

Then the crawfish gumbo.  Gumbo, how do I love thee?   I can have gumbo breakfast lunch and dinner.   It was definitely a familiar gumbo but was outstanding in the sense that  I could taste the crawfish tamale in the sauce.... the umami richness was there yet the aftertaste was seafood and green Earth in a bowl, just to die for.    If you're a gumbo fan, this can easily be a 2 bowl order but you wanna move on to the next course.   

Finally, the Main:   Louisiana cochon with turnips, cabbage, pickled peaches & cracklins.  This dish to me was the bomb of bombs.  If you ever craved a pork on porc stewed, fried, crispy, earthy, cooked low and slow, and sultry all on one plate, this was IT.   The almost provincial presentation of the dish reminded me of eating in a small restaurant in the country.  The glass of Pinot I ordered went super delish with this plate.   My brain immediately thought meat lasagne sans noodles, layers of slow cooked meat, with braised vegetables, simple yet profound.  The very light sauce reminded me that this dish was deceptively cooked for hours to create a complexity of tastes behind simple  techniques.  Was a bit stunned.  To add to the flavor bombs of  this experience, the dish is topped with a crackling, the crowning glory to the plate that made the most obscene statement to me-- this is a celebration of beautiful PORK from head to tail.  Dipped the crackling in banana peppers in vinegar (served table side).....  Awed, started to laugh, SMH.

I  capped my meal with a shaved Brussels sprouts salad with lemon vinaigrette and Parmesan shavings.   Never had raw brussel sprouts.  The toothy greens with a proper French lemon dressing and a minimal addition of sharp cheese was the lightest of salads I've had in a very very long time.    Awed, SMH.  Dining friends agreed, ditto.  

Too full and didn't  venture on to dessert but will next time.   

I've always admired the cuisines of New Orleans for nowhere in this great US of A  is a region steeped in classic French, Creole, Cajun cooking techniques and traditions.   The culinary ecosystem is changing in New Orleans.   Cochon pioneers  the  split from Creole/Cajun/French traditions and reminds us that the changing world of eating in New Orleans is leaning toward simple yet developed, still steeped in multi-cultural gastronomy traditions without forgetting the generational practices of Southern cooking.... LOVE IT.   I do.  

Coming back. 


Visits: 1

A bit of cosmopolitan polish in New Orleans. This place has a little bit of everything -- tweaked NawLins dishes, more exotic choices like liver or sweetbreads and safe picks like steak & fish. The booze follows suit safe or spunky--there are quality choices in every category.

Had a good smattering of everything for a large group dinner (reservations a good idea). Pork cheeks, gumbo, special of lamb shank all really fine tuned and very good.

Definitely a good hybrid to take foodie types & those who go opt to go safer.

They are diligent in keeping their menus updated online so you can easily see about the latest cracklin'.

We came here by accident since we were looking for cochon butcher. Nonetheless, we tried a few items and had some wine before heading over to the butcher. The wines by the glass were actually pretty good, the place was beautifully appointed, and the waitstaff were cool. We tried the braised pork cheek which I just loved and my husband dug the crawfish pie better.  The boy's mac and cheese casserole was just ok. This is a nice casual spot for a more refined lunch experience.

I was in New Orleans for business, and I was staying at the Marriott Convention Center, and this restaurant was a 5 minute walk away.  My wife and I went here twice....in a row, it was the good!
  The first night we were able to sit at "The Chef's Counter" which is an area that overlooks the wood burning oven, and a very hectic kitchen.  

The appetizers that I had (between both nights) were the Fried Alligator, and the oven-roasted oysters.  First the gator...YUM!  It was seasoned just right, and the chili-garlic mayonnaise that was drizzled lightly over the top really brought this dish together.  
Now for the oysters---heaven.  The compound butter that is put on these oysters is so delicious.  If you think you do not like Oysters (especially if they came from the Atlantic or Pacific Ocean), you need to try gulf oysters.  They are much more mellow, and not as briny as their cousins from the Atlantic.  An order is typically served with 6-8 oysters (depending on size), and this is so worth it!

My wife had the Heirloom Tomato Salad with toasted bread and farmer's cheese.  DO NOT pass by this small, yet scrumptious salad.  It starts out with a big piece of white bread (toasted perfectly), on top of that Cochon spreads a very simple pesto (without pinenuts!), and then spreads farmers cheese on top of that.  It is quickly fired in the oven, and then topped with fresh heirloom tomatoes that are dressed simply in olive oil.  My mouth still waters thinking about this dish, and it is only a piece of bread with tomatoes on it!!!!

For the entree, both nights, I had the Rabbit and Dumplings.  Words cannot describe how delicious this dish is.  It is like a chicken pot pie with tender pieces of rabbit served in a cast iron skillet, and topped with homemade biscuits.  I am well aware that New Orleans is hot and muggy, especially in the summer time, but this dish instantaneously brought me back to a snowy New England day.  I also did enjoy a side of their Mac and Cheese Casserole, and that was pretty good as well.  

My wife had the smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickle.  There was a spice that she was not too fond of, but since I married her, I was able to eat some of this dish.  While not my favorite, it was really delicious, and the watermelon pickle complimented this dish very nicely. 

I cannot wait to return back to New Orleans, and rest assured, this will be our first stop for dinner.

I was here over 4th of July weekend with a bachelor party for dinner. I had the Cochon which was delicious. Lots of good drinks and great service. Definitely worth checking out when you are in New Orleans.

Went yesterday for the first time. No complaints. Service was great, beer selection was incredible with good prices. We had fried alligator for the table which was so good we ordered another. I had the porchetta sandwich special which was incredible. The oyster and bacon sandwich was also great. Good fresh bread they brought in the beginning too. Gumbo had a dark roux which was delicious too.
Would recommend and I would go here again.

Must have just ordered the wrong item, shorts rib. It was horrible, mainly just fat and only one rib. The pigs feet were also nothing but bone and fat. However the alligator, oyster sides were excellent. The service was excellent. The Louisiana cochon signature dish was also excellent.  Also need to add crown royal to your bar.

Came here for my birthday(June 2014). I recently moved back since Katrina, 'had heard about this place and had even seen it featured on TV. I ordered crackling appetizer, oysters and their cochon plate. The cracklings were cold and dry very similar to the ones you get at a gas station. The oyster plate was OK but easily surpassed in New Orleans. "Not the best" to say the least. The cochon plate was good but not superb. They just serve you the meat but it would've been nice if the would've come with a side like fries, a salad or bunny bread atleast. I felt ripped off. Definitely a tourist trap. 
On a positive note, the place looked great. Very hip in a trendy part of town. Nicely designed with a great ambiance. I figured the must not want guests to linger around too long because the seats are flat hard benches similar to Hooters. You don't wanna bring Mom here for birthday or mother's day for sure. But definitely a place for a first date.(as long as she's not paying or if she's a discriminating diner)
My final impression was the food has good intentions but poorly executed.
To be completely fair. I will try the sandwich shop where I was told to go by friends. Hopefully management will be on top of things in the kitchen. 
Pork is good, but must be treated with love and respect. Not let it sit for days and serve it cold with syrup.

delish! it was too long ago to remember exactly what i had, but everyone at my table enjoyed their food. atmosphere feels lively and a bit loud. definitely not a romantic spot, feels more like a lunch vibe to me.

Five stars ***** if it were not for BRINN our server  Great food...wonderful setting.  We ordered four entrees and three appetizers.  Food was delicious...service from Brinn was just awful and not acceptable.

The food is incredible. Southern food done SO RIGHT!! 

The ambiance is casual but still feels nice. It was warm and cozy, but still cool and modern. The service wasn't bad, but I could feel the waitress, tall curly blond, wanting the night to be done. She was a little in attentive and wasn't very welcoming. I nitpick when it comes to service because I was once a server and I know what's expected. She's the reason I brought my stars from 5 to 4. 

The food, however, is incredible. I was a Cochon virgin, so I order their classic Cochon dish. 5 stars. Delicious. We got the oysters, boudin balls, Cochon and Mac n cheese. The oysters were incredible, such a bold flavor. The boudin balls weren't anything special. I think I could find them better in a hole in the wall, but still tasty. The Cochon was perfect; diverse textures, balanced flavors and left me wanting more. Omg yum. And the mac n cheese was great, soul warming and satisfying. For dessert we got the pineapple upside down cake. It was moist, packed with pineapples, and paired with a cherry sorbet, which is what sold me. 

Basically, I will be coming back. Enjoy!!

Yelpers you led me here! This is GREAT FOOD to share w your Best Friend! Fact is, now I know how food should taste after eating here. 

And then sadness hit me like a ton of bricks! All my life was a lie, what's been fed prior to me was not food. THIS IS FOOD!!

Because I don't know what is unleashed behind Couchon, but hurry up & get here.

See if you agree!

It's so worth the FOUR HOUR drive from Houston!

Small plates await in the hipsterville section of NOLA. Make reservations. Beg. Feed the parking meter outside. Go! And then return and feed the meter again.

This location is in a promo spot by the very cool WW2 Museum and get ready for this, the administrative headquarters for the kitchen spice, Slap Yo Mama. (Brilliant Cajun Blend that those in the know, use, swear by and don't actually slap their mothers after a tremendous meal by said Mom.)

If you are heading to NOLA, please take me! Couchon awaits!!

Honey! 
My meal was great! 
The swimming hole
The Mac and cheese
The alligator
And
The Cochon with turnip greens. 
I'm definitely happy we decided to eat here.

my first meal on my first visit to Nola.
It was lunch time and there was a nice crowd but not crowded.
I like the location of this restaurant and the décor-- servers were great...cordial but not over the top.
I had the liver & toast appetizer and the cochon with cabbage as main course.
the liver and toast had to much jelly, the sweet overpowered the  other flavors,use about half of the jell provided.

the cochon was a lot of meat, and the cabbage was a bit overcooked, I know that cooking veggies for a looong time is the southern way, but I think I would have liked them a little more raw.

I would go back here just to try the other dishes.

on my arrival day I was planning to eat all day and try other restaurants, but I had this meal at about 1230 and I was FULL for the rest of the day.
My meal was very good! Th oysters were large and tasty! Mac and cheese is to die for!

Good food---our usual appetizers for lunch were plenty, and we even had some to take home for later.  The "fried boudin"= boudin balls= good!  Beware of the spicy brown mustard...abit overwhelming! The mac and cheese casserole had an ingredient that was not identifiable, but the casserole was good and very filling.  The crawfish pie was excellent.  The pre-meal rolls hit the spot.  The service was good...not outstanding, but the staff was good and attentive.  Will we return again?  Not sure, but this place was something different, and we can say we have been there and eaten that.

Typically, I have a very broad taste for food. There are not many types of foods that I do not enjoy and usually I try to preserve this by using moderation. I don't frequent on particular type of restaurant to others for the type of food being served. I always enjoy restaurants that pay particular attention to quality of the food without distracting us with pretentious environments. Luckily, Cochon compliments my taste in food with my preferred atmosphere.
 
Conchon isn't really hard to find in comparison to a few other nice New Orleans dining options. Remember to look up when looking for the place; the sign is a little subdued (which fits the restaurant style). If you are anywhere near the tourist-populated areas this shouldn't be hard to find. I grabbed a really late lunch around 4 o'clock on a Saturday and didn't have to wait for a table. I stayed for a couple of hours and noticed that there was a wait when we left just before 7PM. I would imagine calling ahead is probably a good idea on busy nights. There is a bar available and tables outside; I would imagine waiting shouldn't be too painful with a drink.

The atmosphere is very casual but gives you the impression that it is intentional and not because they didn't have the option to make it less casual. Feel comfortable wearing a T-shirt and something to cover your feet. The atmosphere feels like it encourages you to have a conversation with the person you came with or met there. I think the atmosphere extended our conversation longer that it normally would have been. Expect a trendy talkative environment. I don't have kids but you may be able to get away with it on the weekends if you decided to. (Not sure what kid menu options would be available). 

The menu selection is appropriate; it a great option for foodies and people who just want something safe to eat. I went with a couple small plate and boucherie options as opposed to ordering entrees. I don't live in New Orleans so really wasn't excited about only trying one item. I ordered the woodfired oysters, chili glazed shrimp, fried boudin, smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickle, and a side of the smothered greens. I had an Abita S.O.S. and my fiancé had a MollyWop (hilarious name). Everything we had was excellent. I prefer my small plates to come out as each one is prepared because I like it hot. The oysters were still warmed but I want them as soon as they are finished. Please note that the chili glazed shrimp comes with the heads; their actually very good when forked with the body and a lemon circle. Don't forget to try one of the sides, some places don't pay as much attention to the quality of their sides as entrees. Conchon is not one of them, the side of smothered greens was exceptional.

Service at this place was pretty good. I prefer servers that are accommodating and not intrusive; this place definitely does a great job of walking that line. The price as expected was around $70 for two people. On average that would be about $35 each. 

Great experience and option if you are looking for New Orleans but open to another take on traditional items. Foodies and hungry people should enjoy this place. I will go back next time I am there.

You MUST make a reservation in advance! Cochon can get VERY packed. I came with a big group of friends and we ordered food for days. We all shared multiple orders of the wood fired oysters with chili garlic butter, rabbit & dumplings, fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise, boucherie plate, and more. I really enjoyed everything, and was intrigued by the rare meat selection. It was a very modern twist to cajun style dishes. The beers on tap were local and delicious! The restaurant was very clean, cozy, and modern. I would definitely go back!

This place is WAY over rated!!!!!!!!  The employees was not the nicest, the food was AHHH and the place is loud.  Oh  And hopefully you get to sit next to someone that smell good because it will be very warm and cozy.  NOT in a good way.

This place was a huge let down.  Someone being from Southwest Louisiana and hoping to experience that feel in New Orleans I left feeling really upset.  

First off the service is very very very confusing they claim to work in teams which means there are two servers to a table.  Well they started off by one taking the drink order then the other came and asked for the drink order.  I was fed up with the constant ask and ask again.  

Second the food.  Well like I said I am from Southwest Louisiana which the owner I found out is also.  Well I think he left that style of food there and decided to put a twist on it on his own nasty nasty nasty.  I feel you get very little for the high price. 

Also, they claim to be Cajun style food well no Cajun style I feel.

The bathroom was really dirty and waste basket full of paper towels and falling on the floor.

The manager came to the table and mentioned that it is really hard to find Cajun food in New Orleans well yeah not at COCHON.  Sorry go somewhere else.  

This was my first and last visit.  I will never recommend this establishment to anyone.

As a native of New Orleans and a regular back in the home town, it's often a challenge to find something I would consider exceptional in a city teaming with very good restaurants. Cochon is an outstanding pearl among the jewels of New Orleans cuisine. With the Oyster Roast starter and sharing the Duck Dumplings and Stew and the Louisiana Cochon, my daughter and I found a measure of food heaven! We shall return to finish working our way through the menu. And by the way, having not spared a morsel on the plate, we had to take the absolutely delicious peanut butter and chocolate pie to go.

This place was amazing! 

It's a little out of the way, but totally worth going to!

We started with the boucherie plate. I have no idea what was actually on this, and I'm not sure if I want to find out, but I loved all of it... Even the weird liver spread was good and I am not usually a liver person. My bf didn't love it all, but I'd definitely get this again.

Apparently the Mac and cheese casserole was great (said the bf).

Skip the cucumber and herbs in vinaigrette.. They are just ok.

The catfish courtbouillon was spot on! Is definitely recommend getting it! The flavors were incredible.

The Louisiana cochon was also a must-get since it's the namesake of both the restaurant and the state.. How can you go wrong?!
Any of their pork dishes are delicious, and their wait staff is fantastic. Loved the contemporary feel.

We had our very last meal in N.O here and it was great.  Their sweet tea was nice and sweet, and my meal was great.  I decided to try a]the craw fish pie with a side of greens.  It was pretty much an empanada stuffed with a filling similar to craw fish ettoufee.  the pastry was flaky and perfectly baked or fried, I am not even sure, but it was very good.  I tasted a bit of my friends macaroni and cheese, which was wonderful.  

After lunch, we also decided to order dessert, which was the Peanut Brittle homemade ice cream.  I have never had ice cream so incredibly creamy.  It was definitely homemade and the complete opposite of ice cream out of a carton.  We loved it so much.  We also realized that there was a butcher shop located right next door that was also affiliated with Cachon.  We stopped there after finishing up our ice cream so that my friend's mother could order a traditional Muffaletta sandwich to take on the plane. She was kind enough to give me a piece, and I was so glad because it was amazing. The Muffaletta is a round sandwich with different sorts of meat and topped with a sauce consisting of olives.  It was so good, it will be the first thing I eat if I ever make it back to New Orleans.
Fresh baked rolls are out of this world. Ham hock =  life changing. Next time, and every time I am in New Orleans, I will be making a stop here.

On a recommendation we came here for a birthday dinner. The reason I only gave them 4 stars instead of 5 is because not only did we tell them we were celebrating a birthday but we all had "look who is 40" T-shirts on and we were not given any restaurant acknowledgement. 

 Now for the food. We ordered all the appetizers and all the sides in order to get a taste of Cochon. Everything was wonderful the oysters, the crawfish pie, the eggplant casserole oh my it was all really great.

We ordered the sissy moonshine flight which included a vanilla nutmeg, a strawberry and a peach moonshine. Super yummy, and yes we are sissy girls so we tried the sissy shines.

Try this restaurant if you have the time' it is worth it!

This place has enough positive reviews and I'm high on this place too!!
The overall preparation...ingredients..and spice level were all to my personal tastes.
There's no many places I would go 5 chips on da ratings but count this one.

The food are streamlined and elevated takes on soul/down home foods and executed well. The menu is not grand in it's offerings: a good sign that everything on the menu is probably really strong and would like to repeat visits to sample dishes I did't try.

I had the oysters roasted/broiled with the chili butter sauce....great
The Chili glazed shrimp small gulf shrimp fried crispy with very thinly crispy lemon n onions in a crispy batter....with a drizzle of maybe some home made sweet chili sauce...the shrimp portion was not bountiful but somehow made it a more shareable /"try this" dish...still pretty good.
 
Also tried the spareribs with picked watermelon...like that a lot!! well executed ...familiar and not too untraditional ...cooked long...which is how these cuts of meet should be...
and the smoked ham hock with a light tasting medley of black eyed peas, cucumbers,cherry tomatoes was a pleasant compliment to the best take on a ham hock.!!

sides? 
mac and cheese was good but its not my thing: everyplace tries to have mac n cheese menus these days....
the smoked collards were some of the better i've eaten in any southern or bbq joint too...

drinks are solid as i could tell from one or two types of mixed drinks that the bar knows what they're doing....

nice modern open space but wood decor makes it clean and trendy but comfy and not pretentious ...thumbs up
Great southern experience for a CA boy. Had the alligator, fried oysters, fried shrimp, and pork cheeks. Delicious!

In short: this place was just alright.  It definitely does not warrant itself a 4 or 5.  

I tried the wood-fired oyster roast, fried alligator, smoked pork ribs, the cochon (main entree), pork cheeks, gumbo, and fried livers.

Oyster:  Really good flavor
Fried alligator: it is fried food with their red sauce that is pretty tasty and better with the mint.  
Smoked pork ribs: I don't like smoked stuff but this one actually grew on me.  I actually enjoyed it. It doesn't have a bitter after taste and the smoked flavor and smell is not strong at all.  It's the right balance.  Surprisingly, it was my favorite out of everything.
Cochon ($28) - it's like eating pork with a crapload of salt.  Seriously, I don't know if it's only that evening, but the chef was heavy handed on the salt. :/  Sheesh.  It was NOT worth the $28 even if you are a pork lover...and I AM a pork eater.  You aint' missing much. Save your money for the smaller plates.  
Pork cheeks - let's just say this...I remember it being sweet and unimpressive. Enough said.  
Gumbo - it was alright. Had better 'nuff said.
Fried livers - TOO MUCH batter. I mean it was like eating batter with a hint of liver. LOL...yeah no.

So folks, let's just say this. Their main entrees like like around $20 and up.  We sat next to a group of adults and we looked over and they did NOT even finish their food.  I mean, I don't care if people get full or they don't want to gain weight or whatever, but if you have really good food in front of you and you love food, you WILL finish 99% of your food.  Yeah...one guy ate only half. I think he brought it to go, but I can't be too sure. We left before they did.  

So for all the 5 ratings...yikes.  I'm surprised this place got 4 stars.  I should've tried their deli side instead.  Darn!

We really enjoyed our meal, but unfortunately it was after dining at numerous restaurants for the previous 3 days and our reservation was for 5PM and we just weren't that hungry.  What we had was amazing, just wish we had the appetite to try more.  We had the appetizer Cochon sampler and alligator bites and shared the main Cochon dish.  Great food, great service, nice modern atmoshpere.

During our meal, my friends and I determined we'd rather eat and drink here than have good sex.

We pretty much had one of everything and don't regret it at all.

Super cute place with unbelievable selection of food.
Had the Turkey w/ avocado and it was so refreshing for such a hot day.
Sister had the pork w/ pineapple special and it was out of this world.
Side of potato was delightful along w/ their cocktail.
Felt bad using half a whole bottle of their sweet potato hot sauce, but it was sooooo good! Coming back again.

Atmosphere:
 I was glad to find this gem in NOLA because it reminded me of the restaurant boom going on at home (Nashville). It didn't surround itself with that tourist ambiance you get with the French Quarter and that was nice change. We made a reservation ahead of time and arrived early but were seated instantly.

Service:
I think the wait staff was a bit confused on who was manning our table as we had two servers but we didn't mind - they worked very well together.

Food:
We started with cocktails before changing to wine. Our wine choice was a bit boring but the cocktails were great.

My girlfriend had the fried chicken and watermelon & tomato salad which was good but my oyster and bacon sandwich blew it out of the water. We shared a twice-baked potato which was delicious.

We had a slice of the chocolate peanut butter pie which is also a must try.

Overall:
If you haven't been I would highly suggest it whether you're on a business trip or having a date night. I'd recommend a reservation ahead of time just in case - but same day reservations weren't hard to make either.

We had reservations at 5pm on Wednesday since it was booked tight when we called to set reservations a month in advance.  They must be GOOD!   Got a call the morning of day we were coming to confirm... WOW THEY ARE REALLY GOOD,Must expect a packed house.
When we showed up, the place only had 3 other tables eating.....Hmmmm.  Okay, we look over the menu and decide to try the pork cheeks, fried alligator , crawfish balls  and fire roasted oysters  The alligator was good and plentiful, the the rest was so..so.   The  appetizers had good flavor but the  price was outrageous  for the quantity.  5 dinky oysters in big shells  was not worth the price.
An Arnold Palmer was good but no refills???  
I think the huge staff that assembled in front of the kitchen ( men in black aprons) looked like an assault  was planned for a rush of patrons that never came....justfunny as they must have retreated into the back during the 45 minutes we were there. Could be why their labor costs seems to affect the menu pricing......not worth it!

Amazing place, reminded me lots of the Atlanta food scene. Enjoyed the fried gator and  and the rabbit & dumplings for entree. Gator was delicious with a lemon aioli served with mint. Rabbit and dumplings was tender, almost the consistency of a stew, but a must try for any foodie out there. Staff was very friendly and knowledgeable, ask them for recommendations!

This place was just perfect for a casual date night. Great drinks, amazing fresh bread rolls and excellent alligator bites and grilled oysters. We did wish they had fresh oysters to order as well.

My husband ordered the fresh fish - which still had scales on the bottom of the fish when served. He was able to eat around them ok, but it grossed me out a little bit.

I had the catfish. It was full of flavor! I would definitely recommend this restaurant and would be back here on my next trip.

So Ive been back a handful of times since my last review and thought it was time to update. We've pretty much tried everything on the menu and nothing ever disappoints. Whats funny about most of the food is the first bite is usually underwhelming and youre worried you made a bad choice. Then something happens to your brain and you discover you love it and end up craving it. Ive brought friends who said the same thing. 
Whats also cool is their awesome ever changing drink menu. Its very rare that I see more than a couple drinks on a cocktail list that look appealing to me. Their mixologist, Hannah, is a genius. Plus the fact they make their own marachino cherries, bitters, purees, etc doesnt hurt either. The wait is usually long ( around an hour) so we ens up finding a seat at the bar hence the reason I know the bartenders name by heart;)  It is pricey but it is quality and also a cuisine you can find anywhere else in the city. Like my first review, its sophisticated comfort food.
This place was great! Reminds me of girl and the goat in chicago. The catfish, alligator and blueberry dessert were the highlights

We totally didn't fit in with the crowd...I think you have to have a minimum of three tattoos to enter. Our server was really cool, though, friendly, down to earth and genuinely enthusiastic about the menu. 

We had the fried alligator (it was good, but to be honest, I have had more flavorful) . The Louisiana cochon was AMAZING though perhaps a bit over salted. Drinks were superb, but beware their online menu is not up to date - they buy a lot of fresh ingredients and make their syrups from fresh fruit so it changes with the season.

A good find - low key, casual. I'd definitely go back.

So it was a bit of a let down. I've always like The Butcher attached to it so wanted to get the "Full Experience". The small plates were good. The beer selection was decent although the waiter was kind of a douche when I asked for a room temp glass. supposedly the chef has assigned this glass to either the beer or beer in general!? Wasn't really clear and it wasn't even a beer glass. When I said just grab whatever pint or mug or whatever ya got at the bar he came back with a HOT wet glass obviously fresh out of the dishwasher, but whatever. My main disappointment was that the entrees weren't that good or unique. I will be back, but probably not for a full sit down entree dinner with the fam. I'll just have drinks and snack on the eclectic starters and charcuterie.

Waited about 3 years to eat at this place (I'm from Houston). Reservations are hard to come by. Finally dined here on Saturday and the food was to die for. Started off with a Mime on a Bike and it was so refreshing and not too sweet. Gave me the giggles from drinking it too fast on an empty stomach, but I think it enhanced the flavors of the food. 
Smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickles: My fiance could have gotten on his knees to chant "I'm not worthy" because he ribs are awesome but this is like ribs to the nth power.
Fried alligator with chili garlic aoli: best fried alligator eaten, like popcorn chicken
Rabbit and dumplings: Perfectly seasoned and not too rich on the sauce. More like a pot pie than dumplings. Rabbit was so tender.
Braised Beef shoulder: I only had a bite of this but man was it tasty. The beef fell apart before it was forked. Melted in your mouth like butta.
Pineapple upside down cake with raspberry sorbet: a little odd combination but the tartness and summer freshness of the sorbet balanced the sweet and sticky pineapple cake. Yum!

Service was impeccable. At one point, I leaned over to hug my fiance and spilled most of his whisky and the waiter was gracious enough to refill it without an extra charge on our bill. What a great night!

Can't wait to come back to NOLA to try more of Cochon.

Great oysters: oysters are placed in a wood fire and grilled to perfection. 

Amazing Gumbo: This is my first original gumbo experience. The gumbo was very flavorful and delicious. 

Average couchon and pork shoulder.

In 2013 the wife and I took our anniversary trip to New Orleans. We saw this restaurant on tv and just had to try it. 
The food and service were excellent. 
The boudin balls are the greatest bite of food period. Everything we ate exceeded our expectations.

Such a highly rated place, but not good enough for me. Food was average, nothing spectacular. A basket full of delicious, soft bread with butter arrived first. I enjoyed every single bite. It was that good! Imagine the smirk on my face when another server (not our main server) dropped another basket on my table. But unfortunately it gets worse from here. Fried alligator appetizer came next and it tasted a little raw. Trust me, you don't want to know how horrendous that tastes like. It was like a combination of crispy raw alligator meat with sweet mayo. I can still tasted it in my mouth. Definitely a no no. Finally, rabbit and dumplings, the main dish. I took my first bite, and boy oh boy.... Why does it tastes raw again? Is it just my unlucky night, or do I decide to dine at the famous Cochon on one of its off nights? I tried to taste the biscuit on top of the rabbit meat and it was so soggy. Sorry, but I like my biscuit dry, crispy, and soft inside. Definitely another no no. What a disappointment! I would hate to rate such a highly rated place very low, but maybe I should consider giving Cochon another try soon. Hopefully, it is on their "on" night.

The food was so good!!! The service was really bad!!!!! I had a server that acted like he was too good to server us or was too busy to take care of us! There was even a waitress from another table who came by who saw us sitting waiting to get refilled and taken care of because this kid lacked hospitality skills. I would defiantly recommend the food. It was outstanding. The environment is very hipster hippie crowd. But nice and dim lighting during dinner hours.

They know what they're doing...every single individual, from the host that quickly appears and gives options, to the friendly attendant delivering water and bread (bread was a little late, but that's okay, it'd be a crime to fill up on bread with food this great), to the server who was quick but thorough and not in a rush to leave but not annoyingly looking to make friends. They're all disciplined, timely, and professional. The staff is indeed on par with the high end food. And the food is absolutely on the upper end of the spectrum. 

The crab gumbo was dark, rich and spiced just right, with a little kick. 

The grill fired oysters with garlic and Parmesan in the half shell were OUT OF THIS WORLD. Seriously a MUST and I've NEVER been a fan of oysters. 

The kitchen served a complimentary plate of hogs head cheese with flat crouton crackers and pickled tomatoes. Sliced like pâté, it's a combination of meats from a hogs head. Call it gourmet scrapple(?). It was artistic and I enjoyed it. 

The catfish courtbouillon (coo-bee-on) entree was perfectly prepared, stewed down tomatoes and peppers in a fish broth but the twist here is the jalapeño and mint. My catfish was delicious, a bit wormy (no harm, the fish was fully cooked, just unappetizing) but the server insisted they prepare a new dish. Very professional. Ends up I asked them to sample the replacement out to other guests as a compliment of the kitchen and take it off my bill. They apologetically agreed. 

I'm giving them five stars because overall that's what they deserve. You definitely get what you pay for at Cochon.

(Edit...the manager was very apologetic and insisted I have dessert on the house. Perfect ending. The pineapple upside down cake with raspberry ice cream atop warm pineapple was incredible.)

Hmmm.  There seems to be a trend in my re-visits of Cochan.
This time, I ate very little, sharing with my companion the oysters, a side of macaroni and cheese, and the special, and mushroom "stew" topped with crispy pork of some kind.  The stew, was tasty but left my companion with an upset stomach.  
NOT the desired effect of a good meal.
The macaroni and cheese was, IMHO, not worth eating.  I left it, full, and our server didn't bother to inquire as to why.  (to Cochan's credit, anther server came by and noticed it uneaten, asking if he could get me another small plate to replace it, which I declined. That move saved the 3-stars!)  The oysters were also...meh.  I wouldn't order them there again, when they are so good at other establishments all over the city.
Frankly, if it had  been my first time and I didn't know better, this was a 2-star experience.
So glad that this was on our main destination list. We just made our way down the menu, small plate after small plate, each one more flavorful than the last.
Been here a couple of times, and this is definitely a place to keep returning to!  If you like pork, you won't be disappointed!

In a town known for its food, we were lucky to dine at Cochon while taking a weekend trip to NOLA. To sum up: great service, food and atmosphere. We started with the fried alligator and the crawfish/ green tomato casserole for apps and then moved on to the lousiana cochon and rabbit/dumplings for our mains. If I had to rate everything in order it would be:

1. Lousiana Cochon
2. Crawfish/Green Tomato Casserole
3. Rabbit
4. Fried Alligator (not saying it was bad, just everything else was great)

Everything was very well seasoned (some a bit on the salty side, but not overwhelming) and the portions were just right. 

Will definitely have to visit again next time I'm in NOLA. 

Bring your appetite.

Ordered fried alligator, oysters, and ribs. All are very good! The small plates are really small! But we could try more dishes in this way. The ribs are too sweet for me. The fried alligator is very tender. The oyster is fresh and good, but not the best I have ever had. It's not as full as some reviews on yelp, still some tables available. Maybe it's because I went there on Wednesday 1pm. In general, it's still a good place to go.

Everything we tried was delicious, including the duck liver, rabbit and dumplings, cochon, crawfish pie, and the shrimp. Dessert was also wonderful, my favorite was the fresh peach cobbler with cinnamon ice cream! Service was very fast as was the food, and our server gave some good recommendations. My only complaint was that we had a reservation a week prior and when we got there had to stand outside for half an hour. Maybe they had forgot and didn't have something available? Overall would still recommend this as a great spot to bring friends or a date. 

P.s.- if you bring friends and they are serving the pigs head special, try it! It looked absolutely perfect for a party to share

My favorite part of NOLA!! 
This food will make you salivate as it comes out! Everything is made fresh and we had the privilege of sitting by the kitchen bar so we got to witness everything being prepared up close and come out of the brick oven right before our eyes. YUM!

We ended up having like a four-course meal because everything was so good. We even shared with our neighbors!!  

This is what we got and I cannot say one bad thing about any of it: Brussels Sprout salad (the name does NOT do it justice), Mac-n-Cheese Casserole (holy crap that's good), Wood-fire Oyster Roast (droooool), fried alligator (my bf loved this!), smoked pork ribs (my bf almost licked the plate), we tried the neighbors crawfish empanada (in exchange for alligator and mac n cheese) that was awesome, and I got a seasonal white fish (can't remember which) that came with greens and potatoes that was absolutely delicious. 

They also gave us this complimentary crawfish dip that was amazing!
Can you say FULL?
We were only in town for a few days but if I am ever back in the area, I'm going here FIRST!

Our group of 6 decided to order and share all of the small plates on the menu, a few sides, the rabbit dumplings and one of the specials (fried chicken sandwich).

All of the dishes were pretty good. My favorites were the wood fired oysters and the fried alligator. The one dish that we all agreed was table slammin' good was the fried chicken sandwich special. The chicken was super juicy and all the flavors within were perfect. Not sure if this is a special that they have regularly but it's definitely a must try if it's available!

order the boudin balls! 
the staff was amazing and friendly, the food was perfect and the restaurant had a great atmosphere.
1st time having grilled oysters and they were absolutely AMAZING! And the white gazpacho was so delicious, definitely going back to NOLA just to eat here again!!

If you dig on the pig, you'll love this place. 
Menu is southern- pork fusion that comes together really well.  
Very trendy, wood minimalist decor. 
Servers know what's up and what to get.

About two and a half weeks ago I started looking up restaurants to go to in New Orleans and this was consistently on the list of places to try.  "Cochon" in French means pork and Lily in any language just so happens to mean "loves pork" (disclaimer: may or may not be true).
Extremely great service and we didnt have to wait forever for our food. For small plates we ordered the pork cheek and crawfish with green tomatoes. Both were just perfect and out of this world. The pork cheek was incredibly tender! Who doesnt like pork?! 

Main entrees included oyster and bacon sandwich and Louisiana Cochon. The oyster sandwich was good but a bit plain so I would definitely suggest the Louisiana cochon. The more I think about the Louisiana cochon dish the more I wish I were eating it again.  The pork came out looking like a crab cake and I was afraid it was going to be dry.  Don't worry, it was magical as expected.  The angelic pork disk was surrounded by cabbage and topped with these little pieces of diced peaches.  On the very top of my pork tree sat the golden star of a pork cracklin'.  So beautiful I decided to write a haiku about it

Loved Lousinana Cochon 
It was so yummy 
Must go back to get some more... 

(why are you counting the syllables.  Lily doesn'lt lie) You may cry now.Had to get a four o'clock reservation two weeks in advance but so worth it.
Overpriced salty food & slow service.  Ordered the cochon & rabbit plates both were so salty we could only eat some of it.  Waiter was soooo slow.   Save your money & go somewhere else.
Fried alligator and boudin appetizers were quite tasty.  Skip the boucherie plate -- you'll fare better at the butcher/deli.

Cochon lives up to the hype. Their food is fantastic in a setting that reminds you of a different era.  The thoughtfulness that went into this menu shows in all phases of the meal.  The Rub is a great bourbon-based drink (don't let the vinegar scare you) and the remaining drinks are great.  We tried most of the menu as a table of ten and the rabbit dumplings and fried boudin stood out above the rest.  The peach cobbler was a great way to end the evening.  

I cannot wait to go back
everything on the menu is fantastic... although i would skip the alligator. its ok to try once, but honestly i think it was mehhhh. the peach cobbler was amazing though

Out of all the restaurants I visited during my trip, Cochon was the one I was looking most forward to.  My experience was more deserving of 3.5 stars, but there isn't that option, and it definitely was not a 4 star experience.  

The service was solid and helpful, offering suggestions and giving opinions upon the popular items and personal favorites.  The host was wonderful and quite welcoming, and also helpful when I was looking at the liquor selection at the bar.  The restaurant wasn't too busy during our time of visit, but we appreciated the time the server spent with us.  The problems were simply with attention and table maintenance, as we definitely could have used new sharing plates more often, and empty plates spent a good amount of time on the table.  The pace of the meal also left a bit to be desired.  The three of us decided to share all of the food so that we could taste more of the menu, but the pacing was non-existent.  Everything pretty much hit the table at once, instead of it being brought out at possibly two or three dishes at a time to share, we had five plates hit the table at once during the first delivery, then another two following very shortly after.  Thankfully, the server/s noticed that food covered the whole table and slowed down the next couple plates.  Pretty big oversight in my opinion, and definitely something that should be addressed, considering it is the food that suffers from just sitting on the table.  

On to some of the food!

Wood Fired Oysters - Delicious chili garlic butter sauce, but over half the oysters had shriveled inside the shell from being overcooked.  It was almost comical how small they looked inside the shell.  Definitely not a plate that should have left the kitchen.  

Mushroom Salad - I really liked this dish.  The bright acidity, the great contrast in textures, and that beautiful earthiness of the mushrooms... such a nice combination.  The beef jerky is such an interesting component of the dish.  Some bits are slightly crunchy, while others have that great chewiness jerky is known for, providing this great little dance with the texture of the mushrooms. It's kind of a juggling of the umami flavors that the jerky and mushroom imparts.  The lemon vinaigrette imparts a great finish to those lingering flavors and the dish works so well.  The salad seems so simple, but just has layers of flavor.

Gulf Shrimp with Artichokes and Mushrooms - Pretty darn tasty with the earthiness that the roasted artichokes and mushrooms added to the dish.  Nice croutons soaked up a bit of the sauce and provided some good texture to each bite.  My only criticism would be with the discrepancy in size of the shrimp, surely an issue with the supplier, but a chef definitely needs to notice when one of the three shrimp is almost half the size of the others.  Just something really simple and easily fixed, but overlooked in this kitchen.  

Fried Livers with Pepper Jelly and Toast - so disappointing.  The livers were fried to a literal crisp, offering very little flavor and just really providing overly crunchy texture.  I wouldn't be surprised if some of the pieces just turned out to be fried batter.  The pepper jelly was tasty, but there was far too much of it, maybe the chef was trying to save the terrible toast that was almost cracker crunchy with none of that wonderfully tender middle you find in well executed toast.  Why not just use crackers if you want it to be that crisp?  Probably just another mistake in quality control by the chef, but that seems to be a running theme for this dining experience. 

Smoked Pork Ribs - came slathered with sauce.  Definitely didn't compensate for the overly dry ribs.  Watermelon pickles were tasty and the smoke was noticeable on the ribs, but goodness... this dish really tipped the scale and was quite a disappointment.

Peach Cobbler - ended up being the only dessert we had, which was probably a mistake.  The peaches were nicely incorporated, with that nice brightness that you find with delicious peaches that haven't been canned and packed in syrup.  The wonderful crust was tasty, adding great texture without being overwhelmingly sweet, holding up well with the ice cream on top.  The cinnamon ice cream was just over the top.  Deliciously creamy with the definite taste of cinnamon without being too sweet.  Such a simple and great dessert.

We definitely could have done without some of the other dishes in order to get more of the desserts.

The other dishes we had were solid, but nothing stood out about them.  Kind of a good thing, because what stood out most about the meal is the errors found in half the dishes we received.  Just not enough attention to detail, and sub par quality and integrity of the dishes.  I'm definitely coming back to try more of the menu, but I couldn't help but be disappointed in how this should have been our best dining experience in New Orleans spoiled by all kinds of oversight.

Fried Boudin/Pickled Peppers.
Boucherie Plate.
Cucumbers & Herbs in Vinegar.
Arugula Salad/Crispy Hog Jowl/Strawberry Vinaigrette.
Oyster & Bacon Sandwich.
Pineapple Upside Down Cake.

Good eats!
:)

I will start with the only real negative of my review.  The SEATING hostess... OMG.. She was kind of Goth, but in a snooty way.  Couldn't have acted more bothered to seat us.  Barely spoke.  Covered in tattoos (not a problem, just giving a visual), and piercings and looked totally bored.  Come on owners.  Don't you watch what is going on??  
Ok. On to the food.  I had the grilled oysters with parmesan and garlic and they were delicious.  Served on a salt block.  Then I had the braised Pork Cheeks.  They were pretty fantastic.  I'm pretty much a fan of pork cheeks and these were some of the best. Little crispy on the edges and melt in your mouth in the middle. 

My wife and the gulf shrimp with artichokes.  It was also very delicious.  

Our waiter was efficient and cheerful.  
Other than the HUGE negative of the seating hostess, we really enjoyed ourselves.
The sear on the burger was great and the bun was excellent. One issue that is not very appetizing was watching the food being made and prepared without gloves on anyone's hands.
Very good atmosphere. Great wait staff and inventive and unique menu. Rabbit stew was fantastic. Alligator was good.
Best food I've had in years!  Love the atmosphere, and the staff was excellent!  Will the manager was an gracious host!  I will recommend it to anyone that visits Nola!

It is a nice restaurant. The employes are extremely nice and provided excellent service. The reason for the one star is the food. They had a pork chop special and I ordered it. It was very tasty and very tender however towards the end of my meal I did not feel to good. I spent the rest of the night hugging the toilet. I would not recommend the pork chops.

Great food.  We tried the braised pork cheeks, fried alligator, and rabbit and dumplings.  All of the food was awesome.  The service was a bit slow, but it was also jam packed.  Definitely worth checking out again.

My husband and I went because we saw it on bizarre foods America and it did not disappoint. We started with the oysters, my husband ordered the Cochon (waiter's reco), I had the rabbit and dumplings and we shared the chocolate peanut butter pie. I honestly think I am going to dream about the rabbit and dumplings and the pie. Both were "omg delicious". Will definitely be back here on our next trip.
Worth a visit, pig heaven, nice setup, wait wasn't to long. Food of a very high quality
it was like i ''fine-dining southern food'' place, i really liked the ribs they served, it was the best i had during my time in the states!
Had several dishes on previous visits and they were all very good.  This time I was in and out and had the oyster and bacon sandwich.  Excellent.  Will be back.
Pretty good food tried a little of evertything. If tou like pulled pork. Youll love cochon.

We ordered a range of small plates to eat. When we were seated we saw a few tables nearby get entrees delivered. The portions were huge. So we opted to run with the list of small plates. I'm glad we made that choice as we stuffed with the hand full of plates we tried.

Fried gator - Really good. I cannot believe this isn't a more widely consumed protein.

Wood Fired Oysters - each oyster had a great big dollop of buttery spicy goo. 

Cucumber salad - Delicious. I'm stealing their recipe. They dice up cucumber and dose with heavy vinegar. They then add mint and parsley. It's just a simple and refreshing salad. 

Pork Belly special - good but the portion size could have been a tad bigger. 

Pineapple upside down cake - meh

This restaurant could easily exist in SF (which could be considered a bad thing given NOLAs amazing options). I think they could improve by adding just a few more pork options on the menu.

Loved it and Cochon Butcher.  

My wife does not like seafood and even tried and liked one of my Wood Fired Oysters with Chili Garlic sauce.  She really loved the Mac N Cheese. The dessert was a peach cobbled ala mode, with a homemade cinnamon ice cream.  

I had the Smoked Ribs with pickled Watermelon, my wife and both enjoyed them, especially the pickled watermelon. It was our first Braised Pork Cheeks, very good.  Served with fried black eye peas.  

If you visit NOLA, you have to try this place, I recommend, try right before you leave, or you may eat every meal here

Delicious, inventive food in a gently chic atmosphere.  Everything we had was delicious, so perhaps this is a place where you can't go wrong. However, where I come from, after my first glance at the menu this place would be $$$ instead of $$, so be prepared if you're on a budget.

3 of us shared the following tapas style and it was plenty when you add in the complimentary melt-in-your-mouth rolls:

--fried alligator: best I've ever had because the sauce they made was a perfect pairing.
--boucherie plate: MUST try - they specialize in pork dishes (their namesake) so do yourself a favor. Comes with crazy spreadable pork and delish bread and butter pickles.
--rabbit dumplings: very good, but I'd try a different entree next time.
--eggplant and shrimp dressing: Mmmmm!!! If you love eggplant get this!

Dined at Cochon over Labor Day Weekend.

Had heard about Cochon for awhile and was very excited to finally try it.

My parents and I decided to order a bunch of items off the menu and share them, so as to try more dishes.

We ordered the Meat Pie with Spicy Mayonnaise, Fried Livers with Pepper Jelly & Toast, Smoked Pork Ribs with Watermelon Pickle, Braised Pork Cheeks with Fried Field Pea & Sorghum Salad & Grilled Eggplant and the Smothered Greens.

I also ordered The Rub to drink.

Everything was absolute dynamite!

The Rub - Michter's Rye, Apple Cider Vinegar, Angostura Bitters, Simple Syrup - I was really pleased with this cocktail; The Apple Cider Vinegar gave it just a hint of sweetness and also gave it this divine tang!

The Meat Pie was so flavorful and the mayonnaise really had a nice spice to it! I think the meat pie was my dad's favorite.

Fried Livers with Pepper Jelly & Toast - I ordered these for the table because Southern Living suggested this dish when it highlighted Cochon in its 100 Best Southern Restaurants. I enjoyed the livers a lot, but, thought the meat pie was the better of the two small plates we ordered. The pepper jelly had a nice kick to it and the toast elevated the dish

Smoked Pork Ribs with Watermelon Pickle - The Pork ribs were so tender; they practically melted in my mouth; the watermelon pickle I would have never thought to add to a slab of ribs and, lo and behold, it was dynamite!

Braised Pork Cheeks with Fried Field Pea & Sorghum Salad & Grilled Eggplant - I thought this dish was very complex and wasn't sure if I was going to enjoy it. I'm so glad we ordered it, because all the elements really worked exceptionally well together. The fried field pea added a nice crunch to the dish, while the eggplant gave it this nice smoky flavor.

Smothered Greens - Oh My Goodness Gracious! These things were a flavor explosion in your mouth; Greens are one of my favorites and I've had greens countless times.....I've never tasted greens like this!

The waitstaff was very attentive.

Definitely would return here!

So I ventured to this place after hearing all the hype when I was out partying on Bourbon Street.  How i remembered this recommendation still baffles me.  Anyway, I had the catfish courtbouillon and my friend had the pork cheeks. I was really hopeful and excited about what was to come but then the food came.  

Now I will say the presentation is amazing but the taste was a little meh.  The pork cheeks were tender and flavorful but then the BEPs on top were either fried or dried. Either way I don't think crispy BEPs are appetizing and I must say the catfish courtbouillon needed to have a roux base tomato sauce or some tomato paste added because it was so runny. Thicker sauce please!!!  I couldn't believe the catfish nuggets were fried because  after a while the fish becomes soggy sitting in the runny sauce.  Does that mean I was suppose to eat my food quickly? Don't you hate when your cereal gets soggy?  I've never had fried fish in my court bouillon, ever!  

We finished off our meal with upside down pineapple cake. Again it was meh but restaurant quality for sure. I might have given 4 stars if they had bread pudding with bourbon sauce on the menu. 

Depending on your appetite you might have to order a few dishes but be careful of the prices.  I did manage to check out Butcher which is back side of the restaurant.  I definitely recommend you experience butcher even if it's nothing more than passing thru.

wood fired oysters yum.
fried boudin with peppers     gasp
cucumber salad to cleanse palate
macaroni and cheese   indeed
creamy grits
and pork cheeks?  wow.

This place is craft! I love the food! The environment is good. I also like the fact they have quirky things like Bottled Cheerwine on the menu. The Rabbit Dumplings are killer! The greens are heaven and don't forget dessert.

All the food I ordered was on point & flavorful. I had the beef rib, twice-baked potato, and a pineapple-upside down cake. As a nice touch they brought a couple small bite items before the meal arrived
Quite frankly, one the most memorable and enjoyable meals that we have eaten. The service was excellent as well.

Great place. Things I ordered:

Small plate: fried alligator-- the best I've ever had. 

Entree: Louisiana cochon-- eat and every bite was amazing. 

I shall return. 

Tip: Don't sit by the back bar (where all the food comes out)-- you'll just want to eat everything. 

Tip 2: make reservations.

This was my third time eating at Cochon.   We took a 6pm super early reservation because that was our only option for the weekend.  My partner seemed a little surprised because I had talked the place up so much and it looks relatively casual.   As with the other visits the food was killer.   Highly seasoned pork based food is easy to like.    Cochon does it so well.   What i find specifically impressive is the fish and seafood dishes are as excellent as the piggy dishes.  We had the rib small plate which was great, perhaps a little sweet, nicely smoked, not dry and toothy enough to be enjoyable.  My partner had chili garlic oysters which he was very in to.  I had the gumbo which was a top lifetime gumbo (a subject I have been investing a lot of time on during my monthly NOLA visits and in my own kitchen).   He had a roasted local gulf fish served with an eggplant puree and a hold wheat berry and green salad that was killer.   Never able to say no to a real charcutterie plate and full from the ribs and gumbo I ordered the charcuterie place which was great punctuated but delicious and not gross head cheese and made awesome by great house cured pickles and good creole mustard.

If you can get a reservation go.  Amongst the many many many amazing places to eat in NOLA Cochon is worth your despite its Star Chefyness.

Our place to eat in culinary heaven after landing from Chicago and we didn't regret it. Everything that we had was flavorful and simply delicious; fried boudin, catfish courtbouillon, gumbo and the chocolate cake. Highly recommend this place!

Came here for lunch since it was probably easier to get a table than dinner time.  Service was good.  Food was great.  Not too far of a walk from the street cars...

wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter....definitely get...amazing
chicken & andouille gumbo....it was ok.
braised pork cheeks with fried field pea & sorghum salad & grilled eggplant...definitely try.  
smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickle...wasn't my cup of tea.
fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise....thought it was overrated....it was good, nothing bad.

OMFG!!!!! just go and eat!!!

i was concerned that a meal comprised of mostly pig was going to be greasy .. not at all!
we had a large table and ordered one of almost everything . the standouts were short ribs which had pickled watermelon cubes on it was the perfect combo of sweet crispy smoky and moist. the roasted cochon with turnips was mind blowingly tender and savory. the shrimp casserole was more flavorful than i thought shrimp could be. macaroni and cheese!!! the cucumber salad was sweet and crisp.. there was not a dull cullinary moment  at the table!. the service was good , knowledgeable about both beer and food and the specialty cocktails were great..a perfect evening!!

Here Piggy, Piggy, Piggy!!!  And I come running to the best homage to a Pig that I have ever had the pleasure to indulge in. 
Make your reservations be it lunch or dinner as throngs of people have discovered this alter to the Swine.
