Our table had lunch and got a sampling of the menu from beginning to end. If you think that pork ribs with watermelon pickle is strange-so did I. Now, I am a total convert. Although not porcine, the fried alligator tail has me drooling over a reptile I once only held in fear and repulsion. 
All I can say is go and enjoy a meal you'll
be wanting to have again and again.
Most delicious restaurant ever! Best alligator appetizer. Love this place. Would recommend to everyone who haven't tried.

While visiting NO, my friends and I had a fabulous dinner at Cochon. The food and drinks were amazing, especially the zucchini salad. The only reason I gave 4 stars instead of 5 was the service. Many different servers took care of us, but one in particular was just so surly. She was very pregnant so was likely uncomfortable, but she probably should have stayed home that day then. She was miserable to be around and never once smiled.

I would give almost three stars if I had the choice. Was really not impressed with anything I was served. Wood fired oysters were cooked great but flavor was lacking. As with all dishes it seems.  Braised pork cheeks was tender and eggplant was nice but the field pea sourgum salad doesn't go too crunchy. The ham hock again lacked flavor. The stew it was on was nice. The mac and cheese not sure why ppl were raving about it! Seriously id almost rather Kraft no joke. The rub drink was the only thing not disappointing. But for 80 plus dollars just for me. Not even close to worth it. After all that I tried and nothing was better than average or even exciting taste wise, Im not likely to go back.
I'm in New Orleans several times a year, and I make it a point to eat here while I'm in town.

I did like my mac & cheese here. I ate it all up. it just wasn't absolutely mindblowing though. I did like this place and it was a good time. I wish I had tried the gator bites. I'll probably be back next time I'm in the area to try them. also my mom's grits were good. and the beef thing she had. she kept raving about it.

In NOLA for a conference alone, I thought it would be a good opportunity to check out some of the hot spots for food.  I showed up at Cochon about 5:30 on a Saturday and it was already busy.  The hostess let me know a few spots were opening at the bar, so I made my way there, ordered a drink and let the bartender I was waiting for a seat.  My only issue with the visit is that even after I let the bartender know that, they made no effort to stop the people that jumped in front of me and took the seats I had been patiently waiting for.  I realize it's first come and first serve, but having been in the business many years myself, it irked me.  The bar staff was unfriendly, not very attentive and hard to get the attention of.  I'm glad I ended up at a table.  Once seated, the service was great.  For as busy as it was, they were organized and I never waited more than a reasonable time for food, drink or even my bill at the end.  I ordered the alligator for a starter and then the rabbit dumplings for my main.  Soooo good!! The dishes were cooked perfect and the flavors were spot on.  With so many great places to eat in NOLA, I don't know that I would come back here if only visiting for a couple days and were by myself.  When eating solo, I prefer a bar seat and friendly bar staff, but I would def recommend to people who are planning ahead and make a reservation.  The food is uniquely delicious!

Meaty, Meaty!  Creative menu choices and superbly prepared porcine menu.  If you want the whole range of how to prepare pork, this is the place to see it.  Wide range of small and large plate possibilities.  I had some of the best ribs I have had anywhere.  The atmosphere is chic, and packed with both locals and tourists.  Good drink menu as well.  I think the menu would be enhanced with more choice of greens:  a nice crunchy salad or vegetables would enhance the dining experience.  The contrast of texture and culture would enhance the meat items.  A more balanced menu would be an avenue for improvement.  The waiting staff was knowledgeable, helpful and professional.  Interesting dessert choices provided a nice finish.  I'd just like to see the all-meat menu balanced with some crunchy greens.  I think some nice herbal roasted vegetables would be a excellent compliment.

Good food, good ambience and excellent service.  A winner for sure in our books.  Had the fried alligator which was a tad salty but surely hits the spot.  We got the braised pork cheeks which we've not have anything like it and was delicious.  Even the basic max and cheese they got it right.  The gulf fish was done just right and was fresh. Definitely a place I be back again that it hey have it in Singapore :)

If I hadn't developed more health-consciousness, Cochon would be 5 stars all the way.  Unfortunately, years of salt reduction in my dishes (by myself and my mother) have rendered me too sensitive to such a rich-tasting Southern meal.

Arnold Palmer: 5 stars
Who knew that making an Arnold Palmer with freshly-squeezed lemons, with the juicy vesicles floating in it, made it such a different beast?

Bread: 5 stars
They served these glazed-brown-topped buns fresh from the oven, criminally soft piping white insides. Every time your fingers come away from the bread, they'll be glistening with oil.  Yummm.

Louisiana Cochon: 4.5 stars
This is pork shoulder moulded into a patty, pan-fried.  Looks deceptively dry but somehow magically oozes with juice.  So delicious.  Sits in a pool of stewed cabbage, turnip, cubes of sweet peach, and puffy cracklins.  Minus half a star only because it was so salty.

Smothered Greens: 2 stars
I was probably mistaken on what smothered greens should be, but I certainly wasn't expecting this sour, salty, spicy vat of oil-drenched, wholly unhealthy leaves topped with salty bacon.

Rabbit Dumplings: 4 stars
Tender, flavourful, standard, yummy.

Mac and Cheese: 5 stars
Delicious but really more like a 4.5 from me, as there was a bit too much cheese.  5 from my dining partner who is more of a Mac and cheese connoisseur.

I've eaten here before and enjoyed the food (though I found it all a bit overly salty), but this review is strictly about their hospitality, or lack thereof, with an experience I had last night.

A group of two friends and I called around 8:45 p.m. because we know their kitchen closes at 10. We asked how long the list was and if we would be able to get a table if we came right away. The hostess who answered said, "There are only seven people on the list right now," so we told her we would be coming down in 10 or 15 minutes. "Great, see you then," she said.

So, we rushed down there by car, and when we arrived ten minutes later around 8:55 and asked the hostess to please put our name on the list, she told us they could no longer seat any more walk-ins and we would have to try our luck sitting at the bar, which was completely full. We explained that we just called 10 minutes ago and someone (apparently this same hostess) encouraged us to come in. "I'm sorry," she said, "There's just nothing I can do at this point. We can't seat anyone else."

My problem is definitely not that they don't seat walk-ins after a certain time, as that's totally understandable for a busy restaurant. My problem is that the hostess should have communicated to us over the phone that there would be a risk of this happening if we drove there. Instead, she never mentioned there would be a possibility of them filling up and encouraged us to come down. So, obviously this qualifies as extremely poor customer service, and we were all understandably upset. Fortunately, we went around the corner to Peche, got our name on the list with a fairly lengthy wait but had a really great experience there.

This place was pretty amazing. Came at lunch and sat at the bar while on a business trip and the entire place was packed out...at lunch...on a weekday!

Had the gumbo which was thinner than I'm used to but really really good. Also had the pork cheeks with some bites of crunchy stuff mixed in. To top it off, I got a side of mac'n'cheese caserole which may be one of the most addicting things I've ever had. 

The bartender was efficient if not overly friendly.

For my 290th review I wanted to spew some verbal diarrhea on something I am very passionate about: The Food at COCHON.

I swear to god, Donald and Steve are murdering my taste buds over here! And it feels good.

Their 'we don't give a damn' approach to their menu is a breath of phresh air. Ill just go out and say it: Ill bathe in pig fat...on a table... at their restaurant.

Do I eat here weekly? Yea, so sue me. 
Do I spend too much money here? Highly likely.
Do other patrons look at me in disbelief when I order 2 of everything on the menu? Hopefully.

Literally everything on the menu is worth a chew. However, there are some clear shining stars (even though the menu changes often).

Chile Oysters - Order two and save some bread to soak up that glistening sauce.
Fried Livers w/ Pepper Jelly - Just order it you pusse'.
Braised Pork Cheeks - YES.
Oyster & Bacon Sandwich - Simple, satisfying and sublime. This has a place during any point of the meal and my in heart. Share it as a small plate (cut in fours), eat it as an entrée, as a side with dessert OR take it home and eat it in bed. 
Wonder why men get morning wood? It's likely from this sandwich. 
You can't go wrong. 
You just can't. 

The daily specials freaking piss me off sometimes too. 
I typically have this grandiose plan for what Im going to order (usually beginning my plan that morning or even the day before) and how Im going to float through the menu this time... then at the last minute, the waiter (or waitress) comes over and turns my world upside down with the Specials List. 
It always works. 
Every time. 
Im so weak. 

So long story short, eat here. 
The experience is transcendent. 
The drinks are strongly on point. 
The music is directly off my Pandora playlist. 
The smells will make you dizzy.
And Ill likely be there...if that doesn't put the cherry on top.

290th review, rant over. 
Davis out.
(Drops the mic)

Cochon means pig. I love pig. Therefore, I love Cochon. Yes, this seems about right.

The food is magnifique, the service is very warm, and the ambiance is upscale enough to bring in a hot date, yet laid back enough that you can wear flip flops (Don't wear flip flops on a hot date. That's not what I'm saying.)

I faintly remember getting into a disagreement right before our awesome waitress, Andrea, brought out bread to start. In that moment, our squabble became irrelevant. All that mattered now was how I would go about devouring these hot, sinful, buttered rolls. Between chews, I managed to order the wood-fired oysters, fried alligator, and braised pork cheeks to start.  The fried alligator reminded me too much of General Tso's chicken. Not because I'm Asian, but because they use a similar technique by frying the battered meat, then tossing it in sauce. This did not blow my mind, so skip the gator. The wood-fired oysters, on the other hand, made my eyes roll back so far I could see my backside. Alternating between eating the perfectly roasted oysters, taking the chili garlic butter straight to the head, and sopping up any remainder with that buttery roll - this was my 2nd favorite dish.The braised pork cheeks were no joke either. The cheek gently melted in my mouth, as good pork cheek should, and the fried field peas offered a great contrast in texture. I was embarrassed that during our game of "Guess That Food" I identified them as corn nuts.

After demolishing 3 starters, it was only right that I split the Louisiana cochon entree and a side of macaroni & cheese with my boyfriend. For the Louisiana cochon, they somehow form this stack/patty out of pulled pork shoulder, then pan sear it. I thought it was a bit dry and bland at first, until experiencing the whole ensemble together: stewed turnips cabbage, some kind of jus, and the cracklins. Holy hell, it was like a symphony conducted by Porky Pig himself. The Filipino in me couldn't help but douse my cracklins in the vinegar offered at the table. Try it, and thank me later. But that macaroni & cheese... it brought tears to my eyes. I immediately wanted to extend my trip in NOLA, and expand my waistline. The cheese is so potent and up-front. The sauce is a creamy molten decadence that can evoke feelings of love. They must have used some N'awlins black magic to make mac & cheese this perfect. This cheese masterpiece was the highlight of my whole trip to Louisiana.

They would like you to believe that they're called Cochon because of their expertise with pig... but really, it is because you will resemble a pig by the end of your meal. This is just fine by me. My only regrets are not saving any room to dine next door at Cochon Butcher, and not ordering two sides of mac. Expand your doorway Cochon, because as soon as the tourettes-like oinking subsides, I am trotting back to New Orleans just for you.

Cochon was the best restaurant I ate in when I visited New Orleans!! The wait was 45 minutes but SO worth it... Every single dish was delectable! The Fried Oysters, the Fried Boudin, and the Short Rib were my favorites.  They have a great menu and you can't go wrong with anything you choose from it. Definitely a must-eat in New Orleans and I personally can't wait to go back!

Had the Carolina style bbq pork sandwich. Comes with coleslaw on top. It was delicious. Shared a side of the duck pastrami sliders. They were good too - tasted like grilled cheese. Great atmosphere here. Definitely worth checking out if you are in town.

Cochon was the most recommended place to try on our trip to New Orleans, and it did not disappoint.   The cocktail list was nice, and the bartender was very sweet and helpful.  We started out with the pork cheeks and fried alligator.  Get the pork cheeks and skip the alligator.   The highlight of the meal was actually a special, and it was the pork shoulder served over puréed squash.  It was an insanely well prepared and perfectly cooked meal.  However, it was a special and I would be sad about not being able to get it if I returned.  I do think the place may be a bit over hyped, as I had a slightly better meal at cafe Amelie the next night.   For example, the bread they bring out at Cochon are these little dinner rolls that you can buy at a supermarket.   Overall, it was a good meal.  I would consider returning on my next trip to try a few more things.  If they have the pork shoulder special, GET IT.  I almost forgot - the Mac and cheese was also really good.  Heavy and delicious.
Absolute pig overload.    Cheeks, boudin, Headcheese (a first) and some weird pork pudding thing that you spread with a knife.    Sorry honey my cholesterol is up.
Wonderful place. Passionate about the food they make and serve. I highly recommend.

Great little cafe type of establishment. I had the gator appetizer the short rib salad special. Probably the next fried gator I've ever had. Although next time I would probably ask for light sauce or have it on the side. The fresh mint and herbs made the bites pop. Delicious. The short rib salad was tasty. But the meat had fantastic flavor but  was very fatty. So I had to cut away most of it. 
Friendly service, nice ambiance. Would definitely go back for a repeat visit the next time I'm in town

I had a "light" lunch of gator bites with a side of mac'n'cheese - both were absolutely fantastic.  Mac'n'cheese was really creamy, and also crunchy from the cast iron skillet.  Gator bites were perfectly cooked (tender for gator), crispy on the outside with a great sauce.  Also had good local beer, they had a few on tap.  I sat at the bar and bartenders were really cool - highly recommend this place.

Fine, delish food. Favorite dish was shrimp & eggplant dish--which was magically satisfying without tasting like either shrimp or eggplant. But you MUST order the apple beet salad which makes you want to frolic in a field from joy; it had a savory but ever so light vinagret bathing the slaw, julienned freshness!  Mac'n cheese and greens were ok, but predictable. The costly rabbit and dumplins, I could have done without. The place is clean, cool and collected w simple wood decor and perfect lighting.

We came to New Orleans for a weekend getaway with a group of friends. We were interested in a place to have dinner that was open after 10pm but not on Bourbon St. This place popped up and we all had low expectations. Don't doubt this place. Everything was absolutely amazing. My boyfriend and I had macaroni and cheese casserole, meat pie, ribs and a twice baked stuffed potato. Our friends had fried alligator, grilled oysters and shrimp and eggplant dressing. Standout items were definitely the dressing and the macaroni and cheese. My baked potato was stuffed with cheese, scallions and hot sauce. We all could not stop talking about this place. It is definitely at the top of my list for future visits.

I went in with high expectations and was fairly disappointed sadly. 
Alligator was ok but I think more of an acquired taste that we did not have. Could not fault the preparation etc.
Meat pie and twice baked potato were good as was the boudin. 
Ribs were completely over acidic for our liking. Again probably an acquired taste.
Food wise nothing was out of this world.
Service was not good. Reading the other reviews I would like to think this was a stroke of bad luck on our behalf. 20 minutes before drinks orders were taken after being seated . After we finished our first , our glasses sat for about 15 mins before another waitress took pity on us and took our order due to our server going completely AWOL. Sides came at the very end of the meal, when we were too full to eat them. Sad face

A visit to New Orleans is not complete until you've experienced a meal at Cochon.

I knew that this restaurant was going to be good the moment that I walked in and observed the pleased look on the patron's faces. 

My husband and I sat at the bar and were immediately greeted by the bartender as well as a new friend at the bar who raved about the food as he ordered a second round of ribs. 

Here's what we ordered:

- Wood-fired oysters were deliciously sweet and had just the right amount of spice.
- Braised pork cheek was ultra-tender and tasty. I really enjoyed the crunch of the fried field peas.
- Mushroom salad was light and fresh.
- Louisiana cochon with cracklins was delish I wish I could have asked for a bag of cracklins to go!
- We rounded out the meal with a moist and sweet but not too sweet pineapple upside down cake.

If we could have licked our plates we would have. We will definitely be back!

I cannot say enough wonderful things about this restaurant. Incredible food, excellent service and wonderful atmosphere!

My boyfriend and I recently visited new orleans from California basically to eat. We are total foodies and wanted to try the amazing food that New Orleans had to offer. So happy I stumbled across this place! We just wanted to walk around the city and soak everything in. We walked by this place and noticed it was packed so we decided to eat here. SOOOO happy we did. 

We got the alligator bites as an appetizer and holy cow. One of the best things I have ever ate in my ENTIRE LIFE. Cooked perfectly and the sauce they toss it in is excellent. We split the short rib with WHITE bbq sauce ( I know what?! Sooo good though) and the twice baked potato which was incredible. I'm low key upset we were staying in a hotel because I wanted to take home the left overs and reheat them!

The best part was the people there. It's off the beaten path so for the most part everyone is from the south, therefor everyone was sooooo nice. From the customers to the service. We actually ended up sitting next to a lovely couple that we chatted with through our whole meal. 

All in all this place is absolutely fantastic. Thank you for great food and a great experience!

Cochon was recommended to me by a few of my clients who had traveled to the Big Easy. Once I looked at the short yet delectable menu, we decided to give it a try.

First, we both enjoyed the rustic decor. Clean wood tables and chairs and decor that was not overabundant or hurtful on the eyes. The ambiance is very relaxed and homey. 

To start, I got the wood fired oysters. OMG. I could eat 10 orders of them. They come with this wonderful hot, buttery, spicy garlic sauce. It is amazing and addicting. If I had the money to blow, I would come in just for the Oysters. But alas, I decided to have some real food, so I went with the ham hock and spaetzle. I thought is would be spaetzle with some ham hock meat thrown in.

Oh no, this plate had an entire ham hock in all its glory center stage on my plate. While I was surprised at the meat portion (large), I do wish there was more spaetzle. It was different from what I am accustomed to. The spaetzle at Cohcon is more fried and crispy. It is still delicious. Even the brussel sprouts had a great cook and flavor. 

My partner had the rabbit and dumplings. It looked amazing, but I did not hav a chance to sample it; he at it before I had the chance.

Overall, I would go back to Cochon. I enjoyed that it was located a bit off the main drag, that the food had the flavor or NOLA, but with a twist.

Quick View
Value (food): 7 out of 10
Taste of food: 9 out of 10
Service: 8 out of 10
Phenomal food and fantastic cocktails. I stayed simple - oyster and bacon sandwich - but it was perfect. Excellent ingredients, and well balanced. The service was excellent as well!

Worth every recommendation. I had a few of the small bites. The boucherie plate was excellent and a perfect choice to try a few types of pork. Alligators bites were tasty treats too. 'Mime on a bike' was my favorite cocktail. Service was great, I commend their postive attitude through the rude tourists.

Terrific, super-pork-focused meals.  There really isn't anything for you here if you're not a pork eater, but if you ARE then you are in for a real treat in the form of well-executed traditional pork dishes (cured meat plates, cochon du lait) as well as more creative efforts (check the specials!).  A great place for a meat-focused occasion.

I was told that this is the spot to check out if I was to ever visit NOLA. It was honestly very disappointing and overpriced. Our waitress completely forgot about us. We had to ask for the same thing multiple times. The food that we got was in small portions, but not as great as I thought it would be. It's definitely exotic but I think I can definitely skip this place the next time I come back. I would say check out this place for the experience but I'm sure there are plenty of places you can go while in town.

Get everything on the menu and share! They know how to make great food and magic with all parts of the pig! A must if you are in N'awlins!

I can eat 10 dozen of those fire roasted oysters; truly amazing. It's that garlic butter that they put on those really fresh oysters; I would probably eat my arm if it's covered in that.

Never went back in! Tried! The faux redhead at the front podium she just tore menus and talked on the phone. Half the tables were empty. Wait staff and bus help milled  around as we stood there. Huh? Some staff smoked outside. I guess the girl at the front  was too cool for the room. I've eaten here several times before. OVER-RATED! Expen$ive. This place isn't exactly in the center of the action either Deadly mistake really for this town. Hot today gone tomorrow.,They should really clean up outside around their business too. The doors going into the kitchen area from outside are FILTHY.

Oh my!  Lived up to the hype and then some.  We were there on a Wednesday evening and they were booked solid with an hour wait but no waiting if you were willing to eat at the bar.  Not a problem, we had good conversation with our neighbor at the bar from Portland and the bartenders.  Started with the bertrand road cocktail which was light but flavorful.  Ordered the wood fired oysters in chili garlic sauce to share.  I'm not a spicy fan but I powered through these because the flavors were so good.  He had the Ham hock with spaetzle and brussel sprouts, I had their signature dish the Louisiana Cochon with turnip, cabbage and cracklings.  Cochon is slow roasted pork, pulled then made into a party and fried.  Both were excellent but the star was the ham hock.  At the bartender's suggestion he used a straw to even get the marrow out of the bone.  We split the pineapple upside down cake for dessert.  It came with raspberry sherbet and was divine.  I see repeat visits in our future whenever we're in town.

Amazing. No words to describe this experience. Alligator appetizer incredible. Pork chop special with apple sauce could inspire an artist. Mac and cheese side is to die for. Food coma ensued. But it was well worth it.

A little loud inside, but I'm used to that with restaurants these days. The atmosphere was lovely and trendy - proper lighting levels and handsome wood/natural stone juxtaposition. I had the soup du jour - carrot & apple - which was super tasty. I also had the fried pork belly appetizer, which was melt-in-my-mouth delicious.
I'll make this short...this is a must for dinner if you're in New Orleans. Great food and great service add up to a great experience. Pig is their thing, but there is not a bad dish on the menu.

I've never had a meal where I said "WOW!" like the one I had at Cochon.  Chef/Owner Stephen Stryjewski and his mates are raising the bar on N'awlins fare with Cochon!  Absolutely the best food in the city - and that's saying a lot!  Great food, great atmosphere!  I will refer Cochon to everyone I know.

In the words of a good friend: "You had me at Pig".

I am so glad I had reservations because at about 5:30 - this place was filled to the brim. I still chose a seat at the bar as I was waiting for my friend, but they have full service and Hanna and Miles are quite entertaining. I hope they liked us as much as we liked them.

I saw a few plates of the oysters come out, and knew they were the first thing I was ordering. The NOLA style seems to be wood-fired. These were outrageous; beautifully cleaned shells with large large large oysters grilled and covered in a balanced chili sauce. I am sure the butter helped temper the heat from the chilis, but they had some kick. Full disclosure, I did sop up every last bit of that sauce with their warmed french bread.

Next, we tried the boudin - which is a New Orleans style pork and rice sausage. Cochon removes the casings, rolls it in a little ball and deep-fried it. Then, they serve it with spicy brown mustard and pickled peppers. I loved these; if you are nervous about boudin - try it here first.

I was intrigued by the ribs because - well this place is called PIG. And, because of the pickled watermelon rinds. I liked these. The bbq sauce was a little thicker and sweeter than I was expecting, but the pickled melon helped cut it. These were fine. Well, more than fine since we quickly devoured them. I probably wouldn't order them again. It wasn't my favorite dish of the night; that award goes easily to the oysters.

I wasn't feeling many of the desserts - but we couldn't pass up the house made ice cream of the day - sour cream and brownie. The sour cream ice cream was incredibly creamy and had natural tartness that complemented the rich dark chocolate brownie chunks; almost an adult version of cookies and cream. Now for real, look at that adorable pig cookie. It was a thin crisp cookie smothered with cinnamon and sugar. I loved this cookie - it easily broke apart, but it wasn't super crumbly. It reminded me of a ginger snap or graham cracker consistency.

There are a ton of places in this amazing city to try - and we didn't get to many of the celebrity chef ones - but I'll definitely go back here on my next trip.

First review was deleted so here goes again...Food was very tasty but disappointed in our service. At the beginning of our meal, they kept our glasses topped off with wine. However, once our main meal was served we waited about 5-10 for one of our sides to be served. We then sat with our dirty dishes in front of us for quite awhile before anyone came to check on us. The most discouraging part was the champagne that got spilled on me and the guy next to me. I wasn't even asked if any got on me and no mention of it after it was cleaned up off the floor. Would have given a higher rating if our service would have been better!

Cochon is not what it could be. I've had better alligator in Texas. Way better fired boudain balls at damn near any gas station in Acadiana.  If they opened a satellite location in St Martinsville they would go broke in a week.  $10 for 3 boudain balls?  Really?  Since anthony bourdain came here this place is brimming with Yankees looking for true cajun or creole cooking.  You may find that here. But get ready to pay a kings ransom for the same fried stuff they serve any Chevron on I-10. Is it too late to catch a cab to the blue crab?

Crowded and you sit very close to other patrons. Food is good but price is a bit high for the quality and environment. Service is good. Probably will not return any time soon.

Still haven't returned!!!

L-O-V-E.

Pork cheeks and fried alligator are incredible. Pretty good service and a great atmosphere within the restaurant.

I was disappointed by Cochon after reading the reviews and eating there. We had the alligator- which was just okay. Dry and chewy, and a little bland. We also had the rabbit and dumplings- this was extremely salty, but had a good taste. But hard to eat because of the salt. Good environment and service, but the food did not live up to its standards.

Yum yum yum. Everything from my drink to my food was dee-lish. 

I had the spicy tequila cocktail listed on the menu and it was great. The bar tendress took care when making every drink. The interior of the restaurant was very trendy - I wanted to spend all night there. I ordered the Cochon (pronounced koh-shaun) and it was amazing. Furthermore, the portion size was perfect. Not too big, not too small. Definitely stop here if you are ever in the neighborhood. 

Deducting one star because it was a bit pricey and the staff was a bit snobby.

The food here is simply amazing! Started with a meat plate, which is well structured and delicious. Fried alligator and wood fired oysters followed and did not disappoint. We then shared the cochon entree and the ham hock. Ham hock was so savory! Lima beans weren't quite what I expected as they were slow cooked in a gravy. But the grits were dynamite. Finished it up with chocolate peanut butter pie and pineapple upside down cake. 

Service was ok. The place was jammin and we ended up eating the bar. The bartenders were too busy to be really attentive and they had people stacked up behind our chairs ordering drinks
Outstanding! Was a tad intimidated by the menu, but every plate was extremely flavorful and scrumptious! A pleasant surprise and our favorite (and not most expensive) meal in NOLA! Go!

Who knew pork could taste this good?

What to order:
Wood fired oysters. You'll want to keep that delicious bread handy. Cause your gonna wanna dunk that in the sauce when you've gobbled the oysters. (And anything else you can dunk, including your fingers).

Cochon. I mean how can pulled pork assembled into a patty then seared really taste that good? Because the chef is a magician. That's how.

Service:
Friendly, knowledgable.

Environment:
When I walked in some tattooed kid wAs lifting up his shirt so his friend could take a picture. Meh. Trendy and close-table kind of place but the food stands on its own so it's easy to overlook!

Reservations a must! I could only get us in at 5:30 and made it a week beforE. There was a full restaurant and a wait at 5:30! Crazy.
Cool atmosphere. Alligator was good with some spice. The gumbo and boudin was excellent. Rabbit and dumpling delicious! Cheesecake a must, take it to go at least!

Bon restaurant pour les états-unis, mais relativement cher.

Le "Louisiane cochon" est très bon.

Je déconseille l'alligator, il est servi pané (et donc très gras) dans une sauce type mayonnaise (elle est aussi très grasse) de faite impossible de découvrir/ressentir le moindre goût de l'alligator

I had the fried chicken livers with pepper jelly. Crispy , tasty. Also had the apple and beet salad. Perfect amount of food for lunch. Not too heavy. Service was quick. Try the crispin pear cider. Crisp and refreshing.

Once creative and edgy Cochon has become tired and touristy. The noise level is annoyingly loud & the hard wooden seats are very uncomfortable. The wayyy too cool and indifferent service is totally mailing it in. Most of our dishes came out lukewarm and they all seemed to be prepped & plated way before they were served, other than the gulf $32 gulf fish, all the dishes seemed wilted. The pork cheek was cold and tired, the hockey puck of cochon was flavorless. No reason to return. Message to management-RETRAIN YOUR APATHETIC STAFF

Porch cheeks - Mac and cheese 
Unbelievable  
You have to come sit and enjoy at the bar facing Stowe in the kitchen 
Also stop by next door for sandwich to go omg so good

Chuck Norris will find you if you skip on this one !!

Aaah-mazing food and impeccable service! Make a reservation a day in advance to make certain you get in. Don't sit outside if it's cool, they don't turn on the heaters-and if the food wasn't as great as it was I would have rated it a 3. The excuse was no batteries for the remote to turn on heaters, but hey, there's a gas station which probably sells batteries right across the street.

Visiting NOLA for a conference I arrived at Cochon solo hoping to grab some lunch at the bar. Being that it was 1:45pm the restaurant was very busy but it looked like a few bar seats would be opening up shortly so I waited. When one bar did open about :15 later I walked over but the bartender stopped me and said "there are other people waiting" and she was right there was a couple (2 ppl) waiting ahead of me, so I asked if I could get the next seat after them. Seeming very annoyed, she said yes and informed me that a few more spots should be opening up soon. I continued to wait and then watch another single woman, who arrived after me, walk up to the same empty stool that I was denied from, sit down, and be waited on! Not wanting to make a scene I continued to wait. The bartender then approached the couple also waiting and said "your next, just sneak in and grab a spot" making it very clear that I was not getting a seat anytime soon. So I left. Poor service!

I was excited about my first dining experiece at Cochon based on the positive reviews of past guests. However, I have to be honest and say the experience was a big disappointment. I ordered the pork hock  and my wife ordered the gulf fish. In my opinion the pork hock was nothing special when it comes to taste and preparation. The gulf fish was okay but for the price of $ 32, it could have been better in terms of flavor and presentation. More importantly, the service is inadequate as compared with other restaurants  around the area with similar price range.  The servers are not attentive to their guest in making sure everything is good with your table.  In summary, you would be wise to spend your money somewhere else if your looking for a more positive dining experience.

A pedicab driver recommended this place and she couldn't have been more correct. Authentic food, great portions, prices not bad for what you get, ambience awesome. We sat at bar/chefs table. Cool because we could see all the good being prepared. We had the oysters which were so great, I wanted a soup made out of their chili sauce. The chefs gave us a sampling of their head cheese and bread, which was a nice surprise and very tasty. We ordered the ham hock and the short rib, I can't even begin to tell you how good. The ham hock was my favorite, I love southern food, and this hock had so much meat and flavor and the combination with the Brussels sprouts was out of this world. The beef was great too, and I love their spaghetti squash, you could tell it was fresh, sautéed in garlic and butter. So of course we had to order the Mac and cheese too. Beyond Mac and cheese, this cheese took it to a whole new level. We finished with apple pie, not a huge fan of
Pie, but I would get this again for all that cinnamon and the yummy ice cream. This place is worth every penny and the wait if you choose not to sit at counter.

Once you are in the neighborhood you can already smell the smokey goodness.  Your mouth starts to water and your appetite is awakened.  Great menu, great service and overall a great experience!  We must have gone back 3 times this trip.

way overrated - we had pork cheeks and catfish, and they were not good. food was very sweet and generally disappointing. the expected cajun influence was lacking, and the cooking seemed more inspired by American Chinese food than local flavors

we ordered:
paneed pork cheeks - breading and sweet and sour-style sauce reminiscent of chicken balls. complete waste of one of the best cuts of pork

catfish courtbouillion - fish was ok, but sauce was too sweet and too salty

ambiance and prices standard Brooklyn-hipster, but without the good food to match

A very interesting and appealing place.  Ate here recently this fall.
Rabbit and Dumplings is probably the best entree on the menu, the short rib had incredible bark.

Pork cheeks were a letdown.  The pork cheek is to me the best bite of pork one can have, they lacked the luxurious tender texture it is supposed to have.  Good flavor though.  Fried alligator was quite worthy.  Reminded me of past plates of offal.   Loved the cucumber/vinegar app.  Great contrasting plate for the onslaught of tasty meats.  Beet salad was good not great, but really a gorgeous salad.

Beer menu needs improvement, not just on selections, but on providing more information to the diner about the beers offered.   The waitress(es) were both off their game on being able to explain these beers.   I know the SE has a relatively weak craft beer scene compared to other regions, but with the quality of food this  place has, it should have a better beer menu, especially since the food just calls out for it.

Really good vibe and great drinks.  The food was defintiely above average, though not exactly transcendent.  Service was attentive and the staff knew their stuff.  I'm not sure that I'd wait all day to go here, but we snagged a 2PM reservation which worked out well.   Hopefully, places like this will revitalize the surrounding neighborhood, which seems ripe for a Brooklyn style scene of nightlife, restaurant, shopping, etc.

Definitely fulfilled my puerko destiny at my namesake.

Parker house (?) rolls are bombawesome, and got their caraway sausage, shrimp/eggplant dressing (prolly my fav!), Louisiana cochon, and chocolate cake.

All great, but similar to really good, well thought out, new American cuisine anywhere else.

It took me three visits to get a seat at the bar in this local hotspot near the New Orleans Convention Center, but the meal that followed was well worth the wait. I was skeptical after the bartender steered me away from the restaurant's namesake dish, but the plate of Rabbit and Dumplings she recommended was absolutely delicious. Washed down with an outstanding local brew from their extensive selection, this meal was one of the culinary highlights of my visit to the Crescent City. My only regret was that I didn't have the chance to pay another visit before I left -- on my next trip to New Orleans, Cochon will be one of my first stops!

We were told a 30-45 min wait, but they found us a table faster. The menu seemed more eclectic than expected (spaetzle? sauerkraut?), but I ordered the Cajun options (gumbo and catfish courtbouillon). The food was superb! The techniques were elegant, and the seasonings incredibly flavorful.  As an appetizer, we had the alligator bites, and they too were well done.  My colleagues were similarly pleased, and we found out others had eaten there the same night, with the same results.  Even in the busy restaurant, the service was quite good, so we considered this a big win.

I super love this place.
I made a reservation with my friend for a late-ish dinner but we arrived about 45 minutes early. We thought they'd be able to seat us since it was such a late time for dinner but this place was packed on a random Tuesday night. We sat down at the bar and the bartender was so nice that we decided to eat there instead of waiting for our table. We ordered two drinks; I forgot what my friend got but I got The Jack, which I asked to be light since I hadn't eaten anything yet. It was so good, I barely tasted the alcohol and it had a nice tart spicy kick. On the recommendation of our seat neighbor, we ordered:
Pork cheeks appetizer: AMAZING. Pork cheek meat rolls up into a ball and broiled or something so it has a crispish skin, and accompanied by pickled julienned carrots and red onion. Perfect mix of acid, salt and fat.
Rabbit and dumplings: As the bartender said, it was like rabbit potpie. So good and homey and country-style, and the gravy was yumtastic.
Cochon with cracklin and braised cabbage: Very rich dish and a giant serving; the pork was pulled and perfectly done. I'm not a big meat eater anymore so this was a lot of meat for me and I felt the portion could have been smaller or it's better shared as an entree. But still very good. 
Also: the table bread was DELICIOUS. 
For dessert, we split the seasonal ice cream (apple-pear-caramel with a ginger snap cookie) and the peanut butter pie with our seat neighbor. The ice cream was very good and tasted like an apple pie. The PB pie was extremely rich and a huge portion: I had a few bites and it was like eating a can of light peanut butter. Wouldn't suggest this unless there's like 4 people sharing, because it's RICH. 

Service was great; atmosphere was great; decor was great. Really can't find any faults. We loved this place so much that the next day we walked from our hotel to Cochon Butcher around the corner for sandwiches to take on the plane home.

Trying to get a reservation here at a reasonable hour during a conference is like trying to spot a unicorn in the mystical forest. Nearly impossible.  

I had tried to walk in earlier without a reservation and was told the wait would be 45 minutes to an hour unless I wanted to sit at the bar (which was completely full as well), which I did not understand because 2/3 of the tables were EMPTY. I also didn't appreciate the attitude the hostess was giving everyone who was coming in without reservations. 

I ended up having lunch at the conference center and making reservation for 2:45PM on a Friday afternoon - awkward, I know - but it was the only slot available that fit my schedule, and I'm glad I did. When I returned, the hostess was much more pleasant, and I was seated quickly.

I had the fried alligator and gumbo, and thoroughly enjoyed both. The fried alligator is a must try! Especially if this is your first time in New Orleans and you are feeling adventurous! ;) Trust me, it is not as exotic as you may think. Yes, it does in fact taste like chewy chicken. I do think that the fried alligator appetizer should be shared (a little too much grease for one meal), but because I was dining on my own, I had it all to myself. :9 The gumbo is good - but doesn't merit much recognition. It is just as good as the one at the next restaurant over.

I had the cochon and it was amazing.  The pork was so flavorful and tender.  I am usually not a fan of root vegetables but the accompanying roasted vegs were soooo good.  Fun cocktails, good service.  We ate at Galatoire's, K-Paul, Commanders Palace, Emeril's and Dragos (among otherss!) during our week long food tour of NOLA and this was my favorite.  Loved it so much on our last day we grabbed sandwiches to eat on the plane from the casual Cochon Butcher and loved that as well.  Thank you John Besh.

Not that good, the fish was the highlight and the pork was dry. Bland in general. Heavy on the atmosphere and weak on the food. Too trendy IMO. Too many reviews rating the place too high. Solid three.

We came without a reservation on Friday night around 8p. The place was packed! There was a crowd outside the door waiting to be seated and we were told the wait would be 60-90 minutes. Okay, not ideal but they have a cool bar so we just decided to hang out and order food by the bar. Eventually some seats opened up too in the bar area and we were able to snag it. :)

We ordered
- Ribs with pepper jelly (3/5): wish the ribs were more "fall-off-the-bone"
- Fried alligator (5/5): definitely was surprised by this. i've never had alligator before so i wasn't sure what to expect. so much flavor and interesting texture.
- Fried boudin balls (5/5): the best thing i ate in nawlins. i love the crunchy exterior of the fried balls with the soft pork shreds on the inside with the subtle flavor of dirty rice.
- Bourbon cocktails: they have a really good selection of bourbon and house made bitters.
- Ciders: Great selection of ciders too. We ordered a Crispin pear cider, Samuel Smith, and an Original Sin from NY that I've never seen in California before. The Original Sin was really dry and refreshing to pair with our spicy cajun food.

Might not seem like a lot of food, but it was more than enough for my boyfriend and I. Cajun food can be kinda heavy but deliciousss.

Holy freak'n mother of all that is good in the world!

A must do when you're in New Orleans.
Definitely do the pork cheeks, smoked pork ribs, and the short rib.

Pork paradise. If you love pork, go there immediately. My friend's ribs looked amazing. My group really enjoyed the fried alligator - fun to try in New Orleans. Kinda like a cross between chicken and pork. I loved my woodfired oysters app - one of them was as big as my hand and the sauce really enhanced the dish. The mac and cheese and gooey and rich and a hefty portion - could easily serve as an entree. If you're planning to have it as a side, I hope you bring friends to share or are prepared to go into a heavy food coma. My friend's catfish courtbouillon was complex and flavorful. If you're feeling not pork, or something lighter, I'd definitely recommend that. 

In addition to some interesting cocktail options, they have a vast assortment of sodas including Cheerwine!

Service was fast and friendly.
The short rib arugula salad was so delicious! I would come here again next time I'm in NOLA. The service is good too. I enjoyed the entire experience.

Had lunch here today per the recommendation of a friend back in NYC. FINALLY A DELICIOUS MEAL IN New Orleans!!! They don't have the stereotypical dishes here but they are most definitely local and delicious. THE OYSTERS WERE SO GOOD WE ORDERED TWO MORE FOR DESSERT. The rabbit and Cochon entree were very hearty and comforting. The service was great and the restaurant was classy without being stuck up. Our waiter was so nice! So happy they were welcoming to our toddler. He loved the pig cheeks!

So good. First trip to New Orleans. First experience of southern cooking. Was so impressed with the collared greens and bacon, the Brussels sprouts, and the gumbo. Oh the gumbo. Out of this world, melt in your mouth chicken. And the pork was similarly mouth-watering. Had no idea what I was in for-they hit it out of the park.

Make reservations cause this place was pretty packed already at 6.

Plenty of cocktails, local beers, wine to choose from.

Came here with a party of 11 and was seated right on time. 

We shared some plates that were so freaking delicious: grits, Mac and cheese, and the fried alligator.  The boudin balls were a bit dry (there's a joke somewhere in that statement) which was a disappointment.

For my main entree I had the Cochon plate.  Although tasty, it wasn't anything uniquely amazing when compared to other nawlins restaurants. 

The atmosphere is trendy and fun but you can honestly get cheaper and tastier food at hole in wall places around town. 

Warning: they do not split checks so imagine having to do math after alcohol....and after the waitress promised she could at the beginning of the meal.

So good. First trip to New Orleans. First experience of southern cooking. Was so impressed with the collared greens and bacon, the brussels sprouts, and the gumbo. Oh the gumbo. Out of this world, melt in your mouth chicken. And the pork was similarly mouth-watering. Had no idea what I was in for-they hit it out of the park. I'm no expert in southern food and I acknowledge that eating his stuff every day could cause a coronary. But bit oh boy was this good! Highly recommended!
The alligator and grilled oysters are a must! Ive been eating oysters at a different place everyday on this trip and nothing comes close.

Every single dish was amazing. We had the gumbo, chicken livers on toast with pepper jelly, pork cheeks, pork belly special and country rid with apples and sauerkraut. 

The gumbo was tasty with turkey and kale. Different than the other gumbos we have had in Nola. The chicken livers are a must have. They are fried to perfection and on top a delightful little toast with pepper jelly. The jelly pulls the entire thing together and every bite was amazing. 

Highly recommend this place for a nice, delicious, not too expensive dinner. We will be back for sure!

Cochon isn't normally open on Sundays so we definitely lucked out. We arrived with a reservation but still had to wait as it was very crowded. 

I was with a great group of girls who were adventurous and willing to try anything.

Rabbit and dumplings, Lousiana Cochon with cracklings, Short ribs, Roasted oysters, Gumbo, Hot buttery rolls, & Shrimp. For Dessert, we shared Port, Apple pie and Butterscotch pudding.

Every dish was expertly prepared and we polished off everything down to the last bite. We tried not to fill up on the bread but ended up using it to sop up the sauces and gravies.

The table next to us got the special which was basically a whole fried pig. The 5 of them tackled it like a pro! It looked so good, especially the crispy skin. I had to resist the urge to lean over and stick my fork in for a bite. 

Bravo, Cochon! I would absolutely recommend this place to anyone in NOLA looking for a trendy spot with great food and an interesting mix of cocktails.

A chef at another restaurant recommend Cochon, so my husband and I decided to give it a try. Unfortunately, we were not impressed. 

Food: The menu item description was so intriguing and contained unique flavor pairings, so we ordered few apps and small plates. We were deceived! Flavor was bland, portion was okay, temperature of some items seemed cooler than expected, but visual presentation of each item was grand... 

Atmosphere: We did not have reservations (Mon night 8:30) but host immediately offered table or bar. We chose corner seats at bar. Bartender made great drinks but his attitude and personality was a bit dull. I guess the idea of serving guests was distracting his plans of cleaning spots off glassware. The gentleman from the kitchen that brought our food to us was amazing and explained each dish (while bartender/server continued to polish glassware). 

We left wondering how an amazing chef from another restaurant recommended this place. Maybe we just visited this place on a bad night (other reviews on yelp seem to give high ratings), but we won't go back to find out.

When I started planning my trip to New Orleans (I was going down for the American Public Health Association conference anyway, but I wanted to plan the personal trip portion of it), I wanted some real unique cajun food. I wanted something very different,  but very tasty and classy. I came to Yelp and saw Cochon was so positively rated, so I decided to give it a shot.
Wow - thank you for not letting me down, Yelp! Actually,  it's the opposite of letting me down....this place is my favorite restaurant I went to in New Orleans! I was lucky enough to go here for lunch and dinner on separate days.

For my dinner conmigo (I.e., party of 1), I came right after I got settled into the hotel to a bustling Friday evening.  I had a 9:30 reservation, but 9:50 rolled around and I was still tableless. The friendly, bearded manager was very attentive and offered me my beer of choice on the house (I ordered the clown shoes ipa....amazing!). For an appetizer, I ordered the fried livers small plate.  If you order this to share, order 2....because it is beyond delicious!  This plate is a perfect balance....a great fry on top of stiff toast and the perfect pepper jelly (for sweet and spice) and mint leaves. It was out of this world.

I had the highly rated rabbit and dumplings. I will admit that it was good but did not give me the "wow!" Unique factor I was looking for. Delicious,  but tasted ordinary to me.

For my lunch meeting, we ended up getting a better spread of what the menu had to offer. We ordered the fire grilled oysters to share, and it was the best oyster I ever had. It had the dreamiest, best smoky flavor you could imagine (great freshly charred aroma added to the experience). I had the pork loin sandwich special on a fresh brioce bun and it was delectable (I hate that word but I can't keep saying delicious over and over :) ). No one at the table had complaints....I do wish I ordered a side of the mac and cheese. My colleagues said it was amazing tasting.... another raved about the chili, and yet another loved her pork cheeks.

All in all, there is a reason why this place is 5 stars. It is amazing and out of this world.  Sure, it's usually overcrowded and you'll wait for a table even if you have a reservation,  but the food is undoubtedly worth it.
Vey eclectic menu. Great New Orleans flavor with a fresh and inventive twist. Not just Pork-centric items. My wife and son who do not eat pork had lots of choices. Very satisfying meal.

First off I'd like to say I was hesitant about ordering anything with the fact that this is a restaurant known for its pork and I do not eat pork products, poultry, etc. The server was rude and told me that I could not make any changes or substitutions as per the chef's request. I wanted to order the oyster & bacon sandwich with no bacon and extra oysters. He said I would have to get the bacon on the side and there are no extras. Sounds like a either a Nazi chef or a lazy server.
 
The oysters had a nice sauce on them. The shrimp and eggplant gratin was tasty, but unappetizing, too dark on top. The cortbouillon was tasty but a little too spicy. The mac & cheese did not taste homemade and was bland. 

We waited about 30 minutes between appetizers/small plates and entrees. Granted we were at a table of 7 for dinner, but I expected more from a restaurant that requires you to order everything upfront. Also the fact that we had to split our own check was a headache. Overall I love the atmosphere but was disappointed with the limited variety of menu options and wait time. Even my boyfriend who loves pork was disappointed to not see more dishes with bacon.

Right behind Cochon is the Butcher. Do yourself a favor and try the meats done in house! Chips, Pickels, Hot Sauce, Etc,

Very open casual feel in the restaurant. Garage doors open like your out back in someone's car garage. Some people are dressed up, but most are tshirts and jeans. Seems like a local hangout for Chefs or local foodies after hours too. 

I had Pimento and cheese app and Mortadella app special while at the bar. Both were yummy. 
Then I opted for the Muffaleta. Yes, I ate it all! With house made meats. Not the 14 inch dinner platter size everyone is used to, but an 8inch done right. Salted Carmel Eclaire. Get some! There's also a Unicorns head sticking out of the ice machine at bar.

Great experience on my first visit to this place. It is a very popular spot, very busy and very loud, and their reputation is well deserved. I had their flagship dish: Louisiana Cochon (suckling pig) and it was wonderful. Very tender and tasty meat, and the vegetables and apples that are part of the sauce make this dish a real winner. I'm looking forward to coming back and trying some of their other specialties.

We came here for lunch, but as brunch. They don't actually do brunch, but we didn't care. This was, in many ways, the best brunch I've ever had. I think it almost killed me. Here's why:

Smoked pork ribs - literally among the best ribs I've ever had. Perfect in every conceivable way. They fell off the bone when you so much as looked at them, and the rub was astoundingly good.
Gumbo - best gumbo we had in Nola. Now, this may indicate that we didn't choose our gumbo eating to the best of our ability, but DAMN it was good. So incredibly rich.
Rabbit & dumplings - damagingly filling, but so good you can't stop eating it.
Catfish - honestly, this was the only vaguely disappointing entry, but only by comparison with the rest. It was certainly the only vaguely healthy thing we ate.

And then, the cocktails. Because of course your first meal of the day should have 3 rounds of cocktails. And they were all excellent. Seriously excellent.

Service was also very good. I will definitely be returning.

Was back in November and had yet another excellent meal.  Some of the servers can be a bit goofy but the quality of the food and drinks was still grand.  Also, seeing one of the recent reviews... if you're not a pork eater... this probably is not a good choice for you.  If you like fish try Peche.

We had hands down the BEST meal of our short stay in NOLA at Cochon.  In fact, I'm writing this review at my dad's insistence, whose only gripe was that I didn't find it early enough for us to eat there twice during our 4 day trip to NOLA. Go figure.

After 3 straight days of eating fried catfish, fried shrimp, and mediocre gumbo, Cochon was as refreshing as a meal can get (while still being sinfully, sinfully good).  

We doubled down on the garlic chili oysters because garlic. *sigh*

There were 10 of us altogether, so we got to sample almost everything in the small plates and entree sections. Everything was a hit, but special mention definitely has to go to the rabbit and dumplings. AMAZING. 

If you're in NOLA for holiday, don't settle for touristy food. Make the trip out to Cochon early in your trip and go back to Cochon butcher next door for their small plates and muffaletta!

Make a reservation- this place was at full capacity at 6pm! That said, easily one of the best and most expensive meals I've had in New Orleans. 

I like to think of Cochon as upscale barbecue. I ordered alligator bites- great herb flavor mixed with aioli dressing. Very zesty without being terribly spicy. Also had the Louisiana Cochon and short rib dishes, preferred the Cochon with it's amazing cabbage side. The short rib was charred and tough unfortunately. There wasn't enough veg on either plate to suit me, way too much meat. Tried the peanut butter pie- to DIE for. I would come back any time just for the pie, seriously. Also tried a butterscotch root beer, intriguing but not to my taste. My one regret is not ordering the butterscotch pudding too.

Also, what is the deal with refusal to split checks? I was in New Orleans on a business trip and needed an itemized bill with only the items I ordered so I could expense it, but the manager acted like I was asking for some terribly vulgar service. And this was after I had CONFIRMED it was possible for Cochon to separate checks when I made my reservation earlier that day. Frustrating end to a great meal.

Service was perfect, not intrusive like some upscale places, staff very knowledgeable about menu and specials. Quick with recommendations, and my water glass was always full.
Great new trendy restaurant in the Warehouse District in New Orleans.  Fresh grilled fish was perfectly cooked and spiced. Service was excellent. Place is full very early, reservation a must.

We were disappointed . The chicken liver appetizer was dry and hard and not hot.The cucumbers were very acidic. Baked oysters were good, but not great. The Pork Cochon with cracklings, their signature dish with turnips and cabbage was ice cold and we had to send it back. The lima beans were good but also not hot. The desserts chocolate cake and butterscotch pudding were adequate but not spectacular. The bill was $ 98 and not worth it. The restaurant also was very loud.

I love this place. If you want to eat at the normal dining hour, a reservation is required. 

The livers and spicy jelly is wonderful. Alligator bites are also a great got to try item. All of the sides are large and made to share. Not one per person. 

The rabbit strew and the red fish (fish special regularly on menu) is also great. Any special of the day should be strongly considered. Pretty good bottle of wine prices also.

Fantastic!!!! If you are anywhere near this place you should eat here. Food is fantastic. Wait staff is exceptional. I had the rabbit and dumplings my wife had the cochon both were amazing. Without a doubt try the alligator bites in spicy mayonnaise it is incredible.

Really recommend this place if you are in the area and want to have a meal made with ingredients you usually eat but with a flavor from another level! 
Don't forget to order the baked oyster, the sauce is sooo good!

Everything I had was wonderful! Started with the fried alligator, pretty good. Then for main course I had the smoked ham hock with brussel sprouts, which was spectacular. But the best part was the peanut butter pie.... A dream!

ugh... why did we not go to the butcher instead?  why did we have to eat at the regular cochon?!?!  damn it.  the pork belly sandwich looked so so so BOMB.

luckily we found parking behind the place, but that was like the best thing about this place... that and the mac and cheese.  i got the alligator, pork cheeks, rabbit dumplings, and the macaroni & cheese casserole.

braised pork cheeks with grits, grapefruit & toasted almonds $12
the pork cheeks were good, but not worth the price.  it was extremely tiny and 
fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise $12
DO NOT GET THIS.  it was hard and EXTREMELY salty.  i had to keep drinking water to wash down the dish.  it was so bad, i didn't even finish it.  what a waste.
rabbit & dumplings $23
it was little chunks of rabbit with 4 tiny biscuits.  i don't know what country they are referring to when they say dumplings, but when i hear that word i automatically assume that the rabbits would be stuffed inside some sort of flour.  nope.  it was literally tiny biscuits.  the rabbit meat was soaked with some strong herbal flavor.    
macaroni & cheese casserole $7.
if anything, i should have got 2 of these instead.  hot and cheesy, just the way i like it. 

all this for about 60 bucks on lunch.  meh, i could have gone else where and ate 2x the food for the same price.  

the table next to us also got the fried alligator, and the face they were making was very similar to mine when chomping down on the fried alligator bites.  not delicious.  lol.

My absolute favorite restaurant in New Orleans. GO. You must go (but make a reservation ahead of time!). And when you go - order the shrimp and eggplant dressing, meat pie, wood-fired oysters and chocolate peanut butter pie. Recommend ordering several different things and eating family-style, best way to get a bite of everything. Also, the cocktails are amazing.
Stupid good. If you don't have the fire smoked oysters while here, I will be forced to excommunicate you from my life.

OMG, i wish I lived in NOLA. Everything we got was so tasty.  I wish i wore stretchy pants so I could have eaten more!

We started with fried alligator and meat pie.  I loved the meat pie, especially with the spicy mayo.

We then shared the cochon and mac & cheese. I wasn't a fan of the cracklins but the cochon was delicious and the mac& cheese was super creamy.

I would definitely recommend Cochon for all carnivores!

Enjoyed my dinner but service could have been better. We sat for awhile before anyone even acknowledged us. The waitress seemed like she didn't want to be bothered and really didn't want to give recommendations. We had to go to the bar on two occasions to get additional drinks during our dinner. The food was very good and the Mac & Cheese was so creamy and good. We hit several restaurants during our weekend trip and I would rate this one as second best. 

If the service was better I would have rated it a 4 out of 5 stars. I always leave no less than 20% tip but just couldn't do it this time because the service was so bad!

I don't know if I found anything "amazing" when I ate lunch at Cochon. I had the ham hock with brussel sprouts. The ham hock was very tender and not too salty; however, it didn't really stand out as a "must recommend" or something to order again. 

The service was great though.

I went there on a friend's recommendation.  It did not disappoint.  Casual spot with minimalist decor but a reservation is definitely suggested for dinner. Went midweek at 6PM and it was already full.

Had the wood fired oysters, boudin balls, braised pork cheeks, and roasted pork belly and liked them in that order. The oysters were average (lemon helped) but not Cochon's forte.  The fried boudin balls were crunchy outside, firm inside and  well spiced.  Where Cochon shined, as it should, were the pork dishes.  The braised pork cheeks were tender and the combination of the creamy grits and grapefruit provided a good textural contrast.  Reminiscent of a fusion dish and a pleasant surprise.  The roast pork belly was the best dish. Skin was crispy and the meat melted in your mouth. It was served with roasted beets, caramelized onions, and chard which seemed almost superfluous.  In fact, the dish probably could have skipped one of these and still been great.

BAD EXPERIENCE! We came here with high expectations after a number of recommendations and was disappointed. 

The pork cheeks were cold and the ribs rubbery. 

Their signature dish - Cochon was flavorless, dry and stringy/chewy. The smoked ham hock was better but still lacking. 

As others have said, the service is spotty and we found the staff a bit disorganized. 

The best part of this restaurant is the free warm rolls and matches.

I adore the layout and decor of Cochon: small and intimate with bar seating right in front of the kitchen (highly recommend for someone going alone or in a pair). 

The food was generally tasty, but only the gumbo was exceptional. The duck with dumplings was good, but heavy, and the pork cheeks and grits were decent. However, i did enjoy the experience as a whole and the service was excellent. 

Overall, an above average meal which did not meet the hype and prices.

Outstanding!

We found cochone by yelp -on a Saturday they were booked till 10:30 so we could not get reservations 
It was a 40 min wait but well worth it- 
we were seated at the chef's table and watched the kitchen in action - it was fun!


We had the alligator, the cochone and the rabbit. Everything was delicious. Fast service with a smile!

Definitely will be back!

Ate there at least 8 times during my time working in NOLA.  Bestie loved the rabbit and dumplings, and I loved the roasted fish.  The Shrimp and eggplant dressing is a must have.  Try and sit at the kitchen bar, and watch the show.

It was just okay. The fried livers were delicious but the pepper jelly (of which there was far too much) was overwhelming. That was ALL you could taste. The boudin balls were amazing-- by far the best thing we had.  The pork cheeks were tender but under seasoned and the redfish, while tasty, was RIDICULOUSLY expensive!  The price along with the slightly arrogant vibe from the staff made the experience a let down.
We loved this place. The food was the best we've had in New Orleans. Its not close to the majority of the tourist stuff but worth the walk. Make sure to get a reservation cause it gets packed.

I had seen this restaurant on a few lists and was eager to try during my next visit to NOLA. While it was decent, Cochon wasn't anything to write home about, and I wouldn't come back. First, for a Southern, Cajun/Creole restaurant in New Orleans -- even a modern one -- the portions were disappointingly small, except maybe the sides. Second and most importantly, their staple dish - their cochon entree (pork in French), was dry! Maybe it was an off night, but it was such a bummer.

Apps:
-fried alligator: good, but a little too salty
-pork cheeks: was just ok, but puny portion that was definitely not shareable for more than 2 people (literally you each get 1 bite).

Entrees:
-cochon: like a pulled pork patty, on top of cabbage and other things. supposed to be the main delight but the pork was DRY! 
-rabbit and dumplings - i actually really liked this, but my father-in-law was disappointed in the portion size; you don't get a lot of rabbit

Sides:
-Lima beans: good
-Mac n cheese: solid

We skipped dessert. Was worth a try but would rather visit my reliable NOLA favorites next time.

According to these yelp reviews, the human palate is a miracle and will appreciate tiny portions of finely cooked cuisine served in fancy ass geometrically shaped containers.  Pretentious assholes.

I don't know, maybe my palate is missing something.  But am the type of person who don't give a shitty jack about atmosphere, and service (unless they are deplorable), or what kind of fucking shape and colors the serving dishes come in.  I know a good thing when I put it in my mouth.  And yes fuckers, size matters.  Eating at Cochon is like sucking on a finely shaped dick, the size of your pinky, wrapped in very nice briefs, and paying top dollar for it.  NO THANKS.  

My friend ordered the beef rib for like $20 and guess what came out?  A SINGLE FUCKING RIB.  What the fuck is this??  American Psycho?  Want to cut it into the shape of stars while you're at it?  Anything tastes amazing when there's just two fucking bites of it and you're STARVING!!  Don't make the mistake of coming here and paying for a fancy ass meal then ending up at a poboy shop actually eating something meaningful.

I don't have the vocabulary to adequately describe how fantastic this restaurant is, so I'll just describe how the night went down. 

Since our trip to NOLA was last minute,  we couldn't make any reservations,  but we've been lucky enough to be able to find seats at the bar everywhere and Cochon was no exception. We made friends with a couple who looked like they were leaving and as soon as they got up,  we were already parked in their seats giving them hugs goodbye and good luck in the Sugar Bowl!  

The bartenders were wonderful and their food suggestions were spot on.  I can't think of the last time I had better Mac and cheese! In total we ordered the rabbit dumplings,  gumbo, Mac, shrimp stuffing, the ham hock, and butterscotch pudding.  EVERYTHING was amazing!  

Drink suggestion : Hey,  Jack.  The first sip is by far the best, it's tangy without much sweetness,  and has a spicy afternoon that is exactly what you want.

We stopped by to grab some sandwiches to go. They use some choice meats for the sandwiches. Even their Cajun dog was delicious! They are a bit pricey, but you do get what you pay for. Don't forget to pick up a bag of their homemade chips too. Can't speak to the dinner service or meal size that other reviewers have pointed out. if you are in need of a great sandwich, head here.

There are two different restaurants under this name, one next to the other.  This is a more formal restaurant and the other one (the butcher) serves sandwiches. 
The food here is not great and a little bit pricy. The pork checks were the best thing we ordered, and the alligator was interesting an very well fried. 
There are way too many tables and you end up sitting awkwardly close to the other tables. 
Next time we will try the butcher.

So we effed up and ate here instead of the butcher which is where we were intending. Little did I know that if I walked my ass around the corner we would have found it.  

I would have been really pissed if this meal sucked but it didn't.  We shared several things.  The fried alligator I loved.  Loved the sauce its tossed in and it's not over fried.  Tried head cheese for the first time. Still not sure how I feel about it... The broiled oysters were ok.  Very messy and pretty greasy.  Acmes oysters are better.  My Bacon and Oyster sandwich was so simple but so delicious.  I would order than again any day.

Good food. Poor service.

We really enjoyed our dishes and would have ordered far more drinks had the server came around again. I'm glad I tried this place once, but I won't be returning. I don't care for trendy restaurants that have this "I'm so hot right now so poor service is okay" attitude. Having been in the service industry for 6+ years, I know what it takes to deliver good service to a table and I can't even describe how far from good service our experience was.

Expectation vs reality didn't connect. Vibe/decor are amazing. Food left me wanting. 

Alligator app - well breaded and fried. Best item we had. 

Cochon - pulled pork in a patty, pan seared, dried out, smothered in au jus. Didn't have much flavor outside the jus. 

Mac and cheese is a beautiful creation but lacked salt/cheese flavor. It was awesomely gooey though. 

Finished a few bites but didn't ask for a to go box. 

Drink wise they have an awesome setup including some moonshines. 

Go for drinks/apps...

We went here on a Saturday night. It was really busy even about an hour before closing. We were seated in less than 5 minutes, though, which was very nice of the host to take care of us so quickly. There were 4 of us dining together and we ordered the meat pie (different but good!), liver (nice sweet flavor), oyster (I liked the sauce they put on it), country rib (tender but smaller portion than I expected), and the catfish courtboullion (it was okay--my least favorite of everything that we ordered). It was a fancy take on Southern food which was something different for me to try.

MY GAWD. Some of the best food I've had IN. MY. LIFE. 

Wood-fired Oysters with Chili Garlic Butter
Literally tears of joy. This is most delicious way to eat oysters. I would have this every day if I could.

Catfish Courtbouillon
May this dish live on forever. I don't usually eat catfish, but this me speechless. It was stupendous. One of the best things I've ever had in my life. Mind blown.

Braised Pork Cheeks with Grits
Good, a little dry but mushrooms were great, grits were creamy. The above items outshine everything else.

Macaroni & Cheese
Gooey, rich, and perfect.

Great decor, atmosphere, service was friendly. Food did take awhile to come out but they made sure to ply us with plenty of bread and beverages so wasn't too terrible.
A great place to have a lite lunch. The alligator was amazing... And our waiter gave us excellent service.
Great pork and seafood menu. The alligator dumplings was an eclectic touch. Too bad for chicken loves - not a single item.

Cochon. It's the New Orleans proxy of the "it" restaurant in your city that you've come to know so well. It's trendy (everyone wants to eat there). Yet casual (jeans and a t-shirt, a-ok). The ambiance is always bustling. Reservations, if any exist, are hard to come by. Have you dined here before? No? Let me walk you through the menu. There's shared small plates involved. A couple entree options the size of your bicep. Plus craft beer, for sure a full craft menu. Though there's a $2 can of PBR, or High Life, or something of that ilk. Described as something like "American Lager." 

The common complaints? Service staff is a little pretentious. They know where they work is the bomb. That's okay. Treat the place with respect, and you'll win them over. The portions are too small. And/or the plates are too expensive. That's okay. Make food good. Use first-rate ingredients. If you don't like it, go to Krystal Burger. The food sucks. Can't help you there. I award your taste buds no points, and may God have mercy on your soul.

So, Cochon. Scroll through my photo documentation and drool at your heart's content. We had a big party, and thus were free and merry to order exponentially. I believe we ordered 10 plates in all (for 7 adults and 2 kids), which promptly required the waitress to question whether we ordered enough. At that point, I was concerned about my life choices. But after the lunch, we were more than sufficiently full.

Highlight 1: I got the table to sample alligator. Cochon's fried gator is dang tasty, with a wonderful chili-garlic mayo that's only subtly spicy. Of the remaining small plates, the mushrooms were overtly soupy, and the soaked cornbread that came with the shrimp had to be eaten immediately, lest it get soggy. On the flipside, I loved the simple pan-roasted shrimp, and the carrot-cauliflower salad was refreshingly healthy in a meat-laden meal.

Highlight 2: All right, the good stuff. Ipso facto, the "cochon." Cochon's braised pork cheeks get most of the swine love, but I went crazy for the smoked pork ribs, the best ribs I've eaten this side of Pappy's in St. Louis. The ribs are sweet and tangy with a bit of an Asian punch. Don't get me wrong, the pork cheeks were amazing as well. The grapefruit bits were rivaled only by the inspired pomegranate seeds atop the ham hock, though the winner amongst accoutrements had to have been the ham's underlying sweet potato puree.

Highlight 3: I debated heavily between the gulf fish and the catfish courtboullion, eventually opting for the former. I likely wouldn't have gone wrong either way, but that fish was simply, expertly, and perfectly cooked. The oyster-bacon is a beast of a sandwich.

As far as ordering goes, I recommend heavily leaning on the boucherie and entrees sections. The small plates are fine, but as long as you're in New Orleans, and as long as you're in as fine an establishment as Cochon, the sole purpose of your trip should be to loosen the belt buckle by a notch. Get the good stuff. Enjoy.

OMG the best place in all of NOLA!!!  the service is great but the food speaks for itself.  It's amazing.  We order the fried alligator and the boudin I couldn't tell you which was better because both we so freaking amazing we almost licked the plates.  HAHA  I ordered the special of the day which was a steak sandwich and the fried oyster and bacon sammie.  Both we really really good.  The only thing was that the oyster bacon sandwich bread was a little soggy.

My southern themed restaurant in New Orleans! The best chargrilled oysters in town...even over Crazy Lobster & Dragos. Fried alligator is divine. Do Not pass up the short ribs with pickled watermelon rind! Mac n' cheese is a must. Not an entree will disappoint!

I went out with a bunch of other friends and ordered the rabbit & dumplings (23) which was surprisingly delicious. It's served on a hot plate with rabbit meat mixed in to the dish and the dumpling is made of bread as opposed to the traditional Asian style. I was very and quite happily surprised.

Cochon was amazing.
We visited from out of town on a Saturday. No reservations available, so you can walk in and wait to sit outside or at the chefs table. Bar is first come first served. We were estimated to have a seat in 30 minutes, it was more like 45 minutes or so.
We had the shrimp and cornbread app, my husband had the rabbit and dumplings and I had the short ribs.
