I also ordered a Manhattan that I asked for up and in a rocks glass-- I received a nearly brimming rocks glass- I got my money's worth, and then some. Everything was flavorful and very good. The short ribs came on a potato risotto. I liked this side, but might have preferred something with a different texture- crispy potatoes or something to balance the softness of the short rib and its beet topping. We ended our meal with the butterscotch pudding-- rich and wonderful to share. Please note, if you sit at the chefs table: the head cheese is not cheese, it's the head of the pig! Enjoy

In short: an orgasmic meal that will blow your mind with impeccable service. 

In long: Props to John and Denisse for their amazing attention. The cocktails were mind blowing and delicious. The food, oh god the food. The oysters, the pork cheeks, the cochon, the rabbit, all of it. Amazing. 

If you don't come to this place, you are doing yourself a disservice. 

Do it.

I enjoyed every bit of this dinner. Atmosphere was fun and typical of a good New Orleans spot. 

Food really was amazing. We had the short rib that just melted in your mouth. Our friend had the ham hock and she said it was one of the best things she's ever eaten. The food is just really well cooked and of a high quality. 

Cocktails were good. Will definitely be going back.
I died and went to heaven.  A more expensive, sit down version of Cochon Butcher.
Incredible food and outstanding quality. The staff are very helpful and I'm always impressed on how clean everything is. Slow roasted pork rib was one of the best meals I have ever had.

The best restaurant in New Orleans?  It has my vote.

We had a reservation for 7 people at 8pm this past Saturday as part of my buddy's bachelor party but our table wasn't ready until 830 or so.  This was not the fault of the Cochon team as the party before us basically put up tents to camp out.  Nevertheless, the manager, John, and his team went out of their to make up for this minor hiccup.  They brought us complimentary shots while we waited and surprised us with an amazing charcuterie board .

The cocktails were amazing.  I will try (and fail) to recreate the Delta Burke for months to come.  
All of the small plates were out of this world, but the wood-fired oysters were the star. The rabbit, cochon, alligator and pork cheeks  were all knock-outs.

We ate very well (and often) over the past few days but Cochon was in a league of its own for both food and service.

Pig cheeks!! My favorite! On some type of cream cheese grits. I wish I could eat every day for breakfast. Also ribs.  Smoky deliciousness. Also the cochon with turnips yum. Had three pork dishes bc after all it's cochon!!  This town really made a food impression on me. So glad walked a lot so only gained 1 lb. I wanna go back.

The only reservation available for a party of three on a Friday night was 4:30! But given how everyone raves we decided to go.
Delicious.  Excellent service.
Red snapper was a special and our table loved it.
Pork cheeks amazing.
Roasted oysters fabulous.
Fried shrimp heads - crunchy. Salty. Yummy.

Dinner at Cochon was an absolute delight! I came here with 8 friends for dinner on the first night of my bachelorette party weekend, and we couldn't have chosen a better place. Coming from DC, the menu prices seemed very reasonable and I felt like the portions were great for sharing. We ate so many things, but my favorite shared plates were the wood-fired oysters with chili butter, meat pie, the macaroni and cheese, and the chocolate peanut butter which was DIVINE. I had the oyster and bacon sandwich for my entree which was also delicious. 

The atmosphere was fun, buzzing, and not formal at all, perfect for a loud group of girls! Our waitress was friendly and quick to bring more bottles of wine. The only misstep was that our appetizers came all at once but we didn't have plates. It took several minutes trying to get someone's attention to finally bring over appetizer plates. Besides that,  it was really a lovely evening!

I cannot even put into accurate words how amazing this was. As my dinner companion said .. I feel like I've been taken to church. 
And let me say I've spent a week eating amazing meals but this was hands down the best... Best tasting, best service., best everything.  Vincent took care of our group and all our questions, gave great guidance and recommendations and we felt like there was a team of people taking care of us. 

We all shared items, favorites were pork ribs, ham hock, collard greens, pork chop special, and creamy grits and the soup. And the oysters... Seriously get the oysters

Cochon swept me off my feet!  Went with friend and we shared the alligator w chili aioli, wood fired oysters w chili butter, smoked pork ribs w watermelon pickle, braised pork cheeks w grits and pickled cucumbers.  It was one of the most amazing meals I have had.  You must stop here if you are in NOLA!
Food was fantastic and French wine was delightful. We shared numerous appetizers and sides which were all great. Desserts are made onsite and well done.

A decent meal but disappointing considering all of the 5-star ratings it was given on this site. The absolute best part about the evening were the Grilled Oysters and the Fried Chicken Livers on the appetizer menu and the Mac and Cheese as a side. The rest of the food was tasty comfort food, fancied on the plate but nothing to really write home about. I would go back again which is why it gets 3-stars from me but the reason it goes no higher are these:

1. Reservations are tight and I was only able to get one at 5 pm on a weeknight so I jumped at it. When I called to see if I could add a person to my party I was given a fairly hard time about it (excuse me for trying to increase your business). Eventually I was told that they could accommodate 1 more person on my reservation after I felt like I had to sell a kidney to get it done. On arrival, the restaurant was occupied by 4 customers. That's right, 4. And it stayed that way for a good 2 hours. Now I understand that staffing and turning tables is a tricky science but I don't understand why you would give me a hard time about adding 1 person to my table at 5 pm in the afternoon when the place was completely empty and remained that way for 2 hours. I felt like they were allergic to wanting to fill the place up upon opening.

2. We were told that the Fried Chicken Livers came with 3 to an order. I asked if they could add 1 more to the plate to accommodate the number of people at the table and just charge us extra for the additional liver. The kitchen refused so we ended up having to order an additional full order and had too many. Is it too difficult to fry up 1 chicken liver? We were willing to pay for it and were not asking to change the recipe. 

In the end, it really was the lack of customer-centric service that drags this place down for me. I have no doubt that the kitchen is skilled and that Donald Link is a big name in the hospitality industry in this area but I think they could really benefit from focusing on how their no-can-do attitude portrays itself to the consumer.

My friends either love this place or hate it so I was excited to see what I thought.
I was impressed! However, I love meat. This is def the place to go if you love meat. It also has a great laid back feel and not stuffy like many fine dinning places. 

We started with the fried alligator and it was nice and a little spicy. I enjoyed the sauce a lot. Pour some homemade hot sauce on your plate if you like extra spicy. 

I had the Cochon plate. It was perfect and very meaty. The cooked cabbage and cracklings were also cooked perfectly. 

Andrew had the fried oyster and bacon sandwich which I enjoyed more than my Cochon! The bacon is so thick and made in house. There was a sauce on it that was to die for. 

Pop in next door for a slice of the Elvis kingcake. You won't be disappointed :)

Interesting variety of cocktails, and decent size wine list. The mac & cheese on the side was A+ as was our service. I got one of the delicious salads to cancel the mac & cheese ;-) I was in for lunch and it was quite busy! I will be back again...
Delicious lunch. Oysters were so good. Staff were great and didn't make us feel rushed

This place was DELICIOUS.  We went for a late lunch after sightseeing in the city and there was no one else dining at the time.  The service was a little strange, we had 4 different people taking care of our table, each seemingly with a different job.  I would have preferred just one waiter/waitress who took care of the entire service experience.  

The food, however, was amazing.  We had the fried alligator to start, which had a great sauce on it and was the perfect size to share.  We also had the pork ribs which were potentially life changing, and the mac and cheese.  SO GOOD.  SO SO GOOD.  My fiancee had the ham hock, which was cooked perfectly.  For dessert we had the cochon mess, which was a custard with strawberries and pistachios.  

I would absolutely recommend this place to anyone coming to NOLA.

This place is RIDICULOUS! In town for a meeting and came to the restaurant with a group of 8 discerning colleagues. They were all somewhat skeptical of my choice but not one of us put one thing on our mouths that was anything less than spectacular. The oysters, the chicken fried pork shoulder, the fish, all the desserts...EVERYTHING was amazing!

Cochon is so popular and it can be a challenge getting a table if you are not good at planning in advance. I am a macaroni and cheese addict and Cochon has one of the best in the city. I honestly would travel for miles to get to that cheesy heaven. The grits is my second favorite side. The fried alligator is a good sharing appetizer and if you aren't used to eating alligator the texture is on the tough side. The sauce that comes with the alligator is what takes the dish from great to excellent. The boudin balls (3 to an order) were great and another good split if you cut them in half. The paneed pork cheeks with creole cream cheese grits & dried figs was something that really jumped off the menu to me, but ended up being my least favorite out of four. The chocolate peanut butter pie is the best dessert. A big stand out for Cochon is their bartenders. They really know how to work their magic and really mix some outstanding cocktails.

Amazing!  Just delicious.  I highly recommend this place.  Our party enjoyed the pork cheeks and wood grilled oysters for an appetizer.  I had the gulf fish (red fish) for dinner and the mac and cheese casserole, which was awesome.  Two of my friends had the rabbit and dumplings which was very hearty and filled them up.   For dessert, definitely get the peanut butter chocolate pie.

I was really looking forward to the fried oyster and bacon sandwich. It was good but I wasn't blown away. I'm not a fan of a lot of bread on my sandwich ie poboys and muffelettas but this was served on 2 pieces of toast. I was expecting a better presentation. But the mac and cheese was amazing and the lima beans had a great flavor with a little kick.  The place itself was much more casual than I expected but no draw backs there. Our waiter, Mark, was very good. Overall--good experience.

Best food we had in New Orleans. My boyfriend had the Louisiana Cochon, which was perfect! Soft, juicy and very well seasoned. Oh, we had the fried alligator to start and the garlic chilli mayo with parsley and mint was fantastic. I had the Catfish Courtbouillon, which was perfectly cooked and seasoned. Could be a bit milder though, but really good.
Wow!! Fantastic! Everything here was outstanding. Pork cheeks, hamhock, lamb sirloin, Mac and Cheese, and the Cochon!! Wonderful! Would recommend this place 100 times over. A must try!

I love the ambiance of this restaurant. It was full of people so thank goodness we made reservations. It was busy yet I didn't have to shout at my girlfriends to be heard. 

The service was great. Our waitress was extremely friendly and helpful. She gave us her recommendations. 

We shared entrees and appetizers which was great because I got to try a bit of everything.

For appetizers and sides we had the fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise,
twice-baked stuffed potato, carrot salad. 

For entrees we tried the Louisiana Cochon with turnips, cabbage & cracklins and the Rabbit with Dumplings. I enjoyed both dishes and I could have eaten the pig dish all by myself. It was so flavorful and delicious. I loved the giant pillowy dumplings on top of the rabbit dish. It complimented the pot pie-like rabbit filling perfectly.

For dessert we had the German Chocolate Cake. It had coconut on the ganache so my sister avoided it but the rest of enjoyed it. I found the cake too sweet so it was not something I could eat by myself. It was good but I was done after a few bites.

The standouts of the night were definitely the entrees. 

Overall, it was a great meal and the next time I come I want to try their roasted pig's head that I saw some tables enjoy. We were  full from happy hour so didn't get a chance this time.

Just delicious. The staff was nice and knowledgable and our servers recommendations were spot on. I really don't think you can go wrong with anything you order. I had the hamhock with sweet potatoes and Brussels sprouts. It was a generous portion and paired well with the bottle of wine we ordered.

Time to revolt!  The peanut butter pie is no longer on the menu, although it is still offered over at Butcher.

Fantastic meal(s) all around, from the alligator appetizer, the cochon main and assorted appetizers.

My only real complaint is the $4.00 Mexicola, which only costs $.75 at Costco and should not cost more than $2.00 - $2.50 at any restaurant, no matter how popular it is.

Was visiting New Orleans for a work conference and was looking forward to the meal based on the rave reviews. I thought it was meh. My coworkers enjoyed it a lot. The alligator was probably the best thing we had. I am not a fan of oysters but they loved it. We also had another rather unsharable appetizer that had a soft boiled egg and goat cheese... But I hate goat cheese so that was not a winner. I got the Cochon as my entree and sent it back. I couldn't put my finger on what grossed me out. It was kind of dry and too salty. The Mac and cheese was okay, a but too gooey for me. I like more of the southern style, more dry version with breadcrumbs on top. I sampled the fish and it was ok. Not spectacular. The butterscotch pudding was tasty and coworkers loved the German chocolate cake.

Wow. So tasty. Good service. Fantastic selection of craft cocktails. As your mom said, eat your greens. Seriously, we've been here a handful of times and the veggie sides are stellar. Best to make a reservation.

This place is the empire of pork! The cocktails here are wonderful and service is friendly and very attentive. We had the braised cheeks which had wonderful flavor and the ribs - my god these are amazing! Perfect balance of smoke, sweet (almost a bit of a laquer on the ribs) and they are fall off the bone moist and good. We ordered their signature dish the cochon au lait and sadly this disappointed (in spit of rave reviews). We had to send it back as it was just so mealy and dry (as if it had been reheated). We dined here on New Years Day and perhaps it was tough to purvey new supply. Regardless, the restaurant manager was very gracious about this and sent it back and removed it from our check. We ordered extra crackling which were like pork rinds on flavor steroids - SOOO WORTH IT! We also had the mac and cheese with it which hit the spot. We'd definitely go back again in spite of our entree blip.

South of the French Quarter, away from the glitz and camp of the tourist hot-spots, lies the wonderful Cochon. After a day of parades, rowdy crowds, hail storms of tacky beads and doubloons, Cochon feels like an oasis of civility and class. 

Cochon means "pig" so the menu features pork belly, ham, ham hock, but the food is creole and southern in direction. The chefs are also doing craft meats and charcuterie. Begin your escape at Cochon at the bar with a wonderful cocktail and charcuterie plate. 

A couple of wonderful notes on the charcuterie plate. They served a couple of chorizos with wonderfully smokey, paprika flavor. The flavors are very traditionally Spanish. They put pig's headcheese, a pate, in the selection. Just fantastic. 

For cocktails, the Delta Burke is a refreshing sweet, herby bourbon concoction. Terrific. Their beer and wine list will not let the serious eater down. Get a bottle of the "Tramp Stamp." A cheerful bar staff keeps you well libationed. 

I got the beef spareribs. They were served with a fermented beats. The sweetness of beats played off of the delicious smokey meat in a truly remarkable way. It was such a terrific combination. Unexpected but so, so good. 

A few notes on price and availability. We were able to get a table for two on a Saturday night, a week before Mardi Gras with no reservation and a half hour wait. Dinner with drinks and dessert was $90, a remarkable bargain. Ten blocks north, two cocktails at a nice place will run you $30. 

A stellar experience. An amazing bargain. I left feeling recharged.

Dinner at Cochon. Wonderful experience. Had the Alligator (a must try), the pork cheeks (really a great dish), rabbit and dumplings (good but not out of this world) and the pineapple desert ( delish!) 
If you are at the convention center- this is a must stop. Have to try the Cochon Butcher next time.
great service and nice place.

Nice to go to a good dinner that does not require a dress code.  I went with a large group so some of the dishes I had just a few bites of because we were sharing, but overall, everything was delicious.  The server was very nice and we got our food in good time.

wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter - a must get if you like oysters. Plump and fresh with great flavour
fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise - tried it just to try alligator...nothing special.  Tasted like a cross between chicken and squid, kind of a chewier chicken.
paneed pork cheeks with creole cream cheese grits & dried figs - I only got a bite of this, but the little that I ate was delicious
fried boudin with pickled peppers - great flavours with lots of depth
oven-roasted gulf fish "fisherman's style" - it was ok, I didn't realize that they kept the scales on the skin. I really like fish skin that is slightly burnt so I put the entire skin in my mouth and I ended up with a mouth full of scales
rabbit & dumplings - I liked this dish a lot, it was total comfort food.  Nice earthy flavours
beef short rib with potato risotto & fermented beets - it was a little chewier than expected but still very good
macaroni & cheese casserole - tasted great, but surprised they didn't put bacon in it
smothered greens - i think this was the only vegetable that I had on my trip...it was refreshing
butterscotch pudding - I liked this a lot, it was nice and creamy and thick.  But my friends thought it was too thick.  I thought it was just fine.
Strawberry Mess (can't remember the name) - it came out much larger than expected, and it was nice and light.  It had strawberries in a yogurt cream with pieces of meringue.  A nice light dessert after such a huge dinner

One of the most talked about restaurants in NOLA.  I arrived on a Monday night and found a packed house. Lots of people sitting, dining and drinking the Monday blues away; I was glad that I made reservations. 
My date had the fish and I had the rabbit. Then we took on the German chocolate cake... All said and done, not bad. I was expecting a more upscale/fancier place but this joint is totally casual. Service was good although, somewhat aloof. -The food was great!  Oh so great... and reasonably priced too! 

Looking forward to another visit.

Cochon has amazing chicken liver & pork cheeks. The bread there is dangerously delicious. The ham hock is priceless. Their charcuterie is fun & the Mac & cheese was delicious. No complaints, all love.

As this was the first restaurant we stepped into at New Orleans, Cochon set a really high standard for the rest of the trip. The atmosphere was very classy and elegant with a lot of wood tones. After waiting for a bit, we were seated in the corner of the restaurant at the booth, which was perfect for our party of 7. We ordered a ton of food... even double orders on some of the dishes. For appetizers, we started out with:

Wood Fired Oysters with chili garlic butter ($14)- this was the most AMAZING dish of the night. seriously. The chili garlic butter sauce was kind of cajun style... It was so flavorful, and eating the oysters with the hot juice was the best. We ordered more because we couldn't get enough! 5/5

Meat pie with spicy mayo ($9)- Again another amazing dish so we ordered another one... the meat pie was nice and crispy on the outside and the inside was very hearty and the meat was delicious. Another favorite dish from the menu. 5/5

Pan roasted shrimp with cornbread and country butter ham ($14)- This dish tastes exactly like the description. The shrimp was well done and the cornbread surprisingly went well with the shrimp. 3/5

Fried Alligator with chili garlic mayo ($12)- Wow. After seeing everyone rave about this dish, I finally understand why. This dish with the seasoning and everything combined was perfection. The alligator was the perfect amount of chewy, and the fried part was delicious. 5/5 

Fried poached Egg with pickled kohlrabi & goat cream cheese ($11)- Who even thinks about frying a poached egg? It' was actually really good... On top of that, I dont even like goat cheese, but it was a great subtle compliment. 4/5

Fried sausage special- We didnt even order this dish, but we took it anyways. It was another solid dish, and the string beans was a nice complement. 4/5

Paneed pork cheeks with creole cream cheese grits and dried figs ($12)- This dish was great. The pork was very tender, and the grits went well with pork cheek. So many combinations here that I have never tried, and all were delicious. 5/5

Carrot, cauliflower and raisin salad with curry mayo and pecans ($10)- A light and refreshing dish compared to everything else. The server recommended this, and I would as well. 4/5

On to the entrees...

Braised ham hock with sweet potato puree, brussels sporuts & pomegranate ($26)- This was the best ham I have ever had. The ham was so succulent and juicy and tender... Need I say more? 5/5

Louisiana cochon with turnips, cabbage & crackins ($24)- Another fantastic pork dish.. the cochon is basically their specialty pulled pork dish. the crackins also added a nice texture. 4/5

Rabbit & Dumplings ($23)- This was another great entree. I love rabbits and dumplings, and Cochon knows how to to make their food. The gravy was thick and rich, and the biscuit was hot and fluffy. The rabbit was hearty, and this plate overall was delicious. 5/5

Beef short rib with potato risotto & fermented beets ($27)- The short rib was so tender- we didnt even need a knife to cut the meat.  The fat made it flavorful, and the potato risotto was yummy. 4/5

For dessert, we got the king king ice cream and the cochon mess. The king king ice cream was very interesting.. we weren't used to the very rich and too sweet flavor. Didn't really like it. The ice cream was very thick.. it didn't even melt the whole time it was on the table. The cochon mess on the other hand, was fantastic. It is a mix of meringue cream and the baked meringue, so you get soft and crispy at the same time as well as other toppings. Yum. 

The drinks here were also very good (I dont remember what I ordered). Overall, the best dinner I had at New Orleans! Love how the chefs here have a totally different perspective on food than in LA- I know that I will not find this cajun/ creole infused food in Los Angeles. I will miss this; hopefully I'll be back one day!

I realize 5 stars is high praise but I've been here 3 times and each has been better than the last. The fried livers and pepper jelly is an out of this world taste experience and tonight I had the redfish on the "half-shell" which may have been the best piece of fish I ever ate. The Cochon Mess was a great desert which topped off a near perfect dinner.

This was the first place I ate in New Orleans. I landed at the airport, checked in to the hotel, and then went straight to Cochon. Didn't pass go, didn't collect $200.

Internet research prior to my New Orleans trip dictated that this place was an absolute must and it turned out to be true. Everything on the internet is true. Cochon was great and it definitely set the culinary tone for the remainder of the trip.

The food was phenomenal. The fried alligator for an appetizer is a great choice, especially if you're not from New Orleans. As a Seattleite (an area far away from any alligator population) it was my first time eating gator and Cochon definitely made me want to eat it more. After that, I made a point to keep an eye out for Alligator on all future menus (I may or may not have contemplated stealing a few alligators and shipping them back to Seattle to live on the Puget Sound, but  I didn't because I'm not a biologist and I'm sure there are legitimate reasons why they aren't already in Seattle...). And the chili garlic aioli... ermahgerd. So good. I would use it instead of body wash every day, provided I could refrain from shoveling it in my face while I was showering.

I ordered the Louisiana cochon for dinner and it did not disappoint. Smoky and delicious. The cracklins were a nice textural porky piece that complemented the cochon very well. 

I know Cochon didn't get popular because of its cocktail program, but the reason they lose a star is because I wasn't impressed with the cocktail selection or execution. They're definitely trying to craft unique drinks here, but in my opinion, the cocktails quite obviously pale in comparison to the food. They do have a fairly impressive beer selection though, so pick your poison. I would try the cocktails again, but I would probably get a beer first. Beer probably complements their food menu better anyway.

Get a reservation. Show up hungry. Enjoy. Well worth a visit. I'll definitely be back on my next trip!

Cochon has a classy yet casual atmosphere to it. The alligator bites were as good as can be. I've never had alligator before but the sauce it was tossed with gave it a good flavor. The texture of the bites varied with some pieces being chewier and others being more tender. 

I am a mac and cheese aficionado so I fell in love with the mac and cheese here. It had a creamy yet not heavy consistency in its cheese sauce. I felt as if I could eat their mac and cheese all day. 

I actually wanted to try Cochon Butcher but ended up here instead by mistake. But it was not a mistake that I regret at all.

Wow, what a restaurant. This was our best meal in New Orleans. It was a hideously hot day and we stepped in and sat next to the kitchen. The smooth running kitchen itself says a lot and the care that was going in on a busy afternoon showed that these people know their stuff.

I had the catfish courtboullion and it is a dish that contains flavors that I haven't found anywhere else. It was tangy and spicy and delicious because it was well balanced. We also had the oven roasted gulf fish - also cooked to perfection.

If you visit New Orleans then go here. Enough said.

Yes if you're thinking about eating here don't second guess yourself, its away from the tourist traps in the French Quarter.......the baked redfish is to die for, the eggplant with shrimp and the mac/cheese OMG it's so good I ordered another to take home.

If you want to splurge on one pricey dinner in NOLA this is the place.  All the food here is amazing!  This place is classy, but you can go in jeans!  We had the alligator and mac n cheese casserole as appetizers and the rabbit and dumplings and pork belly special for our main course.  All were amazing!  This is a must if you are visiting NOLA.  We also heard from a local at Cochon Butcher you can sit and order small plates, which would be great to taste a variety of this amazing chef's food!

I wanted to try Cochon Butcher for lunch, and tried several times during my visit. Unfortunately everyone else in the city - or least the near vicinity - seemed to have the same idea. By the time I got near enough to see the line, I had already thought better of it. 

So on the third day we 'settled' for an early Friday lunch at Cochon. Showing up right as they opened at 11am allowed us to be one of the first tables seated, though the place quickly filled up. Our small outdoor table on a temperate day made for a good casual lunch.

Our server wasn't the most enthusiastic, but hey we all have those days. She was still pleasant, but I think wasn't in the mood to explain menu items to some of our more 'inexperienced' diners. Maybe the fact that I was also geeking out over the plethora of pork made everyone else's attitude seem more subdued also. Who knows. But it was Friday, I was at Cochon with nowhere to be, and a world of pork at my fingertips, ripe for ordering. 

At the risk of starting to sound like an alcoholic in the desert, once again I bemoaned the fact that I wasn't drinking as I perused the cocktail, beer and cider list before settling for an arnold palmer.

Food-wise, it was clearly unique. To satisfy my pig craving, we started with the boucherie plate. If you're not familiar with the term - as I wasn't - it's a cajun term often applied to a communal butchering. As far as it applies to the plate though, think charcuterie. 

Beautifully executed bits of rillette, pate, cured meats and terrine with ground mustard, toasts, house pickled vegetables (including beets!) Good to share a few starting bites, or to make a meal out of for one. 

For my entree, I selected the Oyster & Bacon Sandwich. Fried oysters, house-made bacon, toasted bread and mayo. Obviously it was divine. I'd revisit Cochon without hesitation.

This place takes reservations and has better grilled oysters than Acme Oyster House. That is all you really have to know. They were a little spicy, served while the soup in the oyster was still bubbling, and all around delicious. We were tempted to stop here one last time before leaving New Orleans, just for these oysters. It's not in the touristy area but honestly it's not that far and definitely worth a detour.
I truly loved this place. The ribs were fabulous. I want the recipe for the Cochon Mess dessert as it was light and so tasty. We will definitely return when in NOLA.
What kind of pork would you like? It's all good here.

Really good food. Get the grits-- soooo good. We also got the ham hock, some Brussels, a couple salads and the stuffing. All were delicious. Interior of restaurant was nice but nothing special. Chairs were really strange and not very comfortable but not a huge deal.

this was, by far, the biggest let down among all the places we ate at while we were in nola over the weekend. not that the food was terrible, i think we were just expecting too much because of all these 5 star reviews. 

atmosphere: agree with one of the reviewers that it feels losangeles-ish, in its hipster vibe. nothing wrong with it except it was so hot inside when we were there. hopefully it's not like that all the time. 

service: not quite attentive and our server didn't even give us bread nor did she mention what the specials for the day were. she also didn't come back to refill our water, even after we got our check. 

drinks: got the strawberry lager and that was just ok. husband got the cosmic ipa and he liked it. 

food: Louisiana cochon, the main dish of the house, was perplexing to me. i didn't really know what to make of it. coming from someone who will eat almost anything, i found this dish underwhelming. the flavor was one tone, and there wasn't really a wow factor. again, it wasn't bad, just not good either. AND, the pork was dry. the pork cheeks w grits was a better dish, imo. the only saving grace of that meal. 

overall, the food was ok but i wouldn't go back. the service was so lackluster compared to other places we ate at. there's plenty of other fantastic restaurants in nola that are definitely more worthy your time.

Best meal we had in NOLA by far!!!  

After all the seafoody places and food we had I was in dire need of some meat grubbing. Thankfully Cochon was a few minutes walk from our hotel (Hilton Garden Inn) so we decided to try our luck there on a Saturday night around 8pm. Now we were VERY lucky because when we got there there were 2 seats at the bar but the restaurant itself was PACKED! To get a table they estimated a 2 hour wait time (what the huh??) but told us the bar is full service. So yea - make reservations well in advance!

The bar itself is comfy - plenty of space and great service so don't suffer through a long wait if you can get a bar seat (go ahead and hover - do your thang to get a seat). 

We enjoyed the rabbit stew, pork cheeks, smoked mussels and the ham hock. Yes, their namesake is Cochon but the bartender suggested if we were going to go pork to get the ham hock. Thank God we listened to her bc the ham hock was divine! Smokey, tender, and absolutely delicious. Get this. Please! The rabbit stew was my personal favorite overall though - so homey and filling. It looks like a small dish but it felt like a never ending pot of delish. I was dipping the complimentary bread all up in that stew! And our starters - the smoked mussels and pork cheeks - yes yes yes! If I wasn't pregnant I would have inhaled about 30 of those mussels....honey, are you reading this?? Get me this, replicate this recipe, air ship this over bc I neeeeeed this. Well I need this whole meal all over again - so let's trade. Baby for this meal. Good deal? I think so.

Came to Cochon for lunch- had to come back the next day to try some of the other options. The ribs with pickled watermelon - superb. The fried alligator was perfect. Rabbit and dumplings were cooked in the wood oven, the best rabbit I've ever had.

I sat by open kitchen and watched the line whip up hundreds of covers. It was impressive. This restaurant handles some serious traffic. 

Cocktails were unique. The Chartreuse cocktail included home-brewed fig bitters and rose syrup... Mmmmm. Great service, great atmosphere.

The food was good but not AMAZING, especially for all the hype.  I am not a fan of small plates either... But what I had was good (fried gator and rabbit and dumpling stew).  I feel like I had better food else where on the trip.  I am glad we tried it out, but probably wouldn't go again if I was back in the area.

My friend got the oysters and almost died. Her eyes rolled to the back of her head. She says they are the best she has ever had. Chili garlic butter. 

Had the grits. Not a fan. Eh

Smothered greens - pretty good. A bitter sweet kind of taste.  Hard to explain. Would get again

The bread - yummmmm!!

Sweetened iced tea - yummmmm!!!!

Leaning towards 3.5 stars.

The GF and I had been a talking bout coming here for a while.  I tried to get in here a couple times but they were full..  Finally planned it out, and did the whole reservation in advance thing.  Got there, everything was fine.

I started off with a couple of "The Rub" cocktails, and they were delish.  We each had the turkey gumbo which was very tasty.

The best part of the meal were the pork cheeks, they were yummy, tender, delicious, all that.

My GF had the ham hock for the main course and I had the meat pie.  Both were good, though I thought both were very salty.

We had a fine experience, I really have nothing negative to say, but there was nothing particularly memorable either.  Meaning, there is a long-list of very high quality restaurants in New Orleans, and I don't think this place lives up to the hype...  or difficulty to get in...

I would go there again, but wouldn't make it a priority. I would go to Coquette, Herbsaint, La Petite, Peche, ...  then Cochon would be further down the list.
Great ambiance, delicious drinks. Wood fire oysters are amazing. Make sure to ask for bread for dipping in the oyster drippings...
Good food, good service! Alligator had good sauce but you lost the flavor of the 'gator.
These are not oysters I had a few years ago. They rocked. These are small and over run with spices.

Hadn't been here in years. Would it live up to our memories? Answer a resounding YES. Brought a couple bottles from my cellar to celebrate with another couple. Asked our waiter (Vince) to bring out dishes to go with them. Excellent choices and service. Pork cheeks are ridiculous! Mac and cheese? These aren't your moms. Wish I had grown up eating these. Best hogs head cheese in town. Smoked pork ribs meaty,juicy,delicious.Not a bad dish or choice. Everything excellent. Price? $240 for 4. Worth every penny!

This was a great late lunch. 

Incredible wood fired oysters as everyone mentions, make sure to drink the juice in the shell. Also had the ham hock. Great smoky flavor balanced with sweetness from purée and the slightly bitter shaved Brussels. 

A perfect two course lunch.

Came here during Mardi Gras weekend for a friend's informal birthday dinner with about eight people. They sat us at a long table off by the front door - the restaurant itself was pretty packed but we were rather secluded - probably because they anticipated us being rather loud in the larger group.

The rolls here are AMAZING! I had four pieces from the basket - warm, buttery, flakey, soft. Wanted to ask for more but then I would have had WAY too much bread. 

I ordered the pork cheeks as recommended by the waitstaff - it was listed under the smaller plate section but the presentation and portion size was enough for someone not too hungry. Loved the arugula salad on top which was light and refreshing. I shared the fried alligator plate which was nice and crispy yet meaty. 

Great food and environment! Would definitely recommend.

I came during Mardi Gras week and arrived about 30 minutes before the restaurant closed, but the hostess was very accommodating. She recommended that I wait for a seat at the Chef's counter so I obliged; it was totally worth it because I got to see the action in the kitchen from my seat as I enjoyed my cocktail and waited for my food to arrive. I immediately took a liking to the dynamic of the kitchen staff - they were fun to watch and speak with. It's always a joy to see the inner workings of a restaurant and experiencing how my food is prepared before it gets to me adds to the overall impression of the meal. 

I ordered the fried gator and boudin balls to start. The gator was favorite bite of food of the night. It was succulent and reminiscent of dark meat pork and fitting considering the name Cochon adorns the building. The textures were great - crispy yet soft; tender with just enough chew. The remoulade was well balanced and did not overpower the natural flavor of the gator. It was dang tasty! The boudin balls were just okay for me. They were perfectly fried and crisp without being greasy, but the flavor profile just didn't do it for me. I had a certain expectation from boudin especially with Butcher next door. I wanted it to be meaty with a hint of offal and instead got a pastrami fritter of sorts. Good, just not what I expected. The pickled banana peppers that came with it were fantastic!

Considering it was my first time at Cochon, I decided to try their namesake: the Louisiana cochon. As much as I wanted to love this dish, I didn't enjoy it as much as I hoped I would. The entire dish, each component rather, was well seasoned and delicious. It's just that it was overly salty when eaten altogether. They were just shutting down the kitchen as I received my entree so I didn't want to make a fuss. Given that, I would still come back to Cochon to try this dish once more, but only after I get my hands on that short rib dish I originally wanted to order!  I'll give the restaurant 4 stars for the service, decor and that gator dish! The food is definitely delicious; i just came at an off period during service.
Unique menu. After a week of Cajun butter and cayenne I was looking for something a bit different. Had the rabbit and dumpling stew. Was fantastic

Worth the hype!

It's tiresome when everyone says you "just have to go there" but Cochon lived up to the hype!  

My companion and I had the roasted shrimp, the meat pie, the short ribs, and the twice baked potato.  Everything was delicious and the service was great.  The atmosphere was lively and just a tiny bit loud, decor was light and rustic.

Worth the hype!

Just got back from a trip from Nawlins and easily the highlight was my meal at Cochon. I've been wanting to get to the restaurant for a few years but never was able to get a reservation in time. Luckily, this time was different and got a table for six at a very reasonable time (6:30 pm). 

The meal was excellent. Started off with a Tramp Stamp (which sadly is unavailable where I live) before switching to wine. For appetizers the table shared the fried alligator (delicious), chicken livers (had a sweet jelly which was a nice touch), ribs (oh yeah) and the wood fired oysters. The oysters had a red garlic sauce that added to the taste but made it messy to eat. All four were a nice way to start the meal. 

Also, I need to mention the rolls. Order up on those!

For dinner, I went with the ham hock where the meat fell right off the bone. Not a big fan of brussel sprouts but these did not seem so bad. I was also able to try the Louisana cochon (think pulled pork cooked like a crab cake) which might have been better than my meal and also the rabbit and dumplings. That had a nice homey stew taste to it though it did not look heavy on rabbit. For sides, we went with the mac and cheese (awesome) and the double baked potato. The potato was by far the "worst" part of the meal as it was only good. But there's no way I am knocking any starts off for that.

Definitely hit this place up when you are in Nawlins.

In town for a trade show and made a reservation based on reading about Cochon in a few different magazines. Maybe my expectations were too high but I felt the food was good but not spectacular. The atmosphere and vibe was solid. Great energy and the service. 
We enjoyed our appetizers ( everyone likes some alligator every now and then) but the main courses were flat. I tend to order chef specials and on this night I ordered a pork loin  on dirty rice.The pork was over cooked and consequently a bit dry. My guest both ordered a trout special and while they enjoyed the meal they both felt it could have been better. Based on the reputation and service I would give Cochon another shot but in the very competitive NOLA market they need to get better.

Stopped in for a quick bite.  The crowd was a mix of locals and others checking out the scene.  I felt like I was in DC or NYC with a little New Orleans sprinkled in.  
I only had the Boucherie plate and a beer.  Porky goodness with a cold Bayou Teche LA 31 Biere Noire.  I would return.  Gets crowded so prepare accordingly.

Heard about it as the best restaurant in New Orleans.  Thought it was hyperbole, and was wrong.

Best food experience in a city known for food.  My fiance and I enjoyed everything we had.  Especially the wonderful craft cocktail selection and the knowledgeable staff.

To prep for the following morning's adventures to Jean Lefitte's Swamp tour, I trekked to Cochon to have their fried alligator in a chili garlic mayonnaise. 

They make their own rolls (delicious) and they give you a couple as an appetizer (with butter of course--- this city is all about their breads and butter).

The kitchen hooks you up with a cone of AMAZING chicharrones, or cracklin's 'round these parts, that was so reminiscent of the cloudy chicharrones that 4505 Meats used to make (I've had recent batches, and it's no longer the same! ::sadface::), served with a cane syrup-type dipping sauce (with or without the sauce, the cracklin's were on point).

The alligator had a hint of chewiness, but still tender. The breading and chili mayo were good.  I enjoyed it.
I also had the fried livers, served on top of baby toasts and pepper jelly. These were also enjoyable.
They have this chili infused vinegar that was a great condiment to my fried appetizers.

I sat next to the area where they expedite the dishes, which was sensory overload. The chefs in the back were all eye candy. I wish I had another cone of cracklin's with cane sugar.

I'd come back here to try their smoked hamhock and the rabbit n' dumplings.

I had my 21st birthday here and the environment was the ideal setting and the food was just what I expected, satisfyingly good and happily full. I really wanted to give them a five star review but I couldn't because of how long it took to get seated. I made reservations for 9PM and my party of six and I arrived on time. We were not seated until 40 minutes later, 20 minutes before the kitchen was about to close, because the only table that could seat seven was occupied. I understand that they had no control over their customers' stay, but they should have been more time aware of our reservation and the party before. The hostess was kind enough to serve us spiced moonshine on the house and try to seat us immediately after the part before left. 

Now for the food. For the appetizer we had fried alligator tails and it was good, but not anything special. The wood-fired oysters was spiced perfectly and I wished I ordered more. I had the special which was pork loin with dirty rice. It reminded me of a traditional Korean BBQ and the rice was seasoned nicely, not too salty but just enough to compliment the pork loin. I also had the ribs with watermelon sauce and I give it too thumbs up. The watermelon sauce actually brought out the juices of the ribs. We also ordered the rabbit and dumpling and normally I don't like rabbit because I find it to gamey, but this rabbit just fell apart in your mouth and whatever thick broth it was cooked in made it mouthwatering. For dessert I had the German chocolate cake and I was wondering if I could have some more right now! It was not overly sweet and the coconut just added to the texture and another dimension of sweetness. 

Overall, my experience here was lovely other than the wait time. But hey, it's all about the food.

We had wanted to try Cochon for some time, and it did not disappoint. This farm to table restaurant is full of creativity, exploration of tastes, and fun. Like many establishments in the Warehouse District, the restaurant has given new life to an old brick building and reinvigorated its classic Nawlins character. Underneath the classic sign hanging over the sidewalk are trees planted in containers and tables beckoning passersby to stop for a moment and experience an outstanding taste sensation. The inside has bare red brick walls, eclectic artwork with black and white photos of farms, wood floors, a wooden bar, and open floor plan with visibility into the kitchen and the wood-fired oven. Everything about it has a contemporary, tasteful look and feel. The young staff is attentive and professional, and exudes the energy of a team that sincerely cares about high quality food and fine dining. We ordered an appetizer (oysters), a small plate (grilled shrimp), a salad, and one entrée (Louisiana cochon). Everything was excellent, but we decided the taste of the shrimp dish topped everything else. The various ingredients made for an incredible flavor profile with not one ingredient standing out or overpowering the others. It just blended perfectly and would not have been the same without each one of the ingredients. I've looked for this dish on the Internet and have not found it, although Chef Link apparently makes several variations of it. That's the thing with a creative chef - the menus vary frequently.  By the way, the cracklins are a must have and add a nice texture to the cochon. 
 
Meal: lunch, weekend
Order: Wood fired oysters with chili garlic butter, Louisiana cochon (roast pork shoulder) with turnips, cabbage, and cracklins, grilled shrimp with pickled cabbage, carrots, cauliflower in  a white cream sauce with a little cayenne pepper for kick, mixed green salad with fried cheese, rolls made with lard, butterscotch pudding, black coffee
With Tin Roof Brewery Perfect Tin Amber and Wollywop (cathead honeysuckle vodka, campari, peach bitters, lemon san Pellegrino) 
Ratings: (1=terrible, 2=pretty bad, 3=bad, 4=just okay, 5=good, 6=very good, 7=excellent)
Food: taste-7; presentation-6
Service: speed-6; friendliness-6; attentiveness-6
Ambiance: comfort-6; look-6
Price: 5
Overall: 6

Pretty busy so I don't think we got the proper 'Cochon' service. Service wasn't bad at all, just not as friendly and attentive as past restaurant experiences. 

Food also came - entree, drink, then appetizer. I think they may have forgotten about it, but no worries. I understand it's super busy and these things happen. When the appetizer did finally come out, it was incorrect but it was quickly corrected.

Got the Smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickle and they were very tart, acidic, not really tasty. Very unique grill taste. I'm not a fan of the 'grill mark' taste so I could be biased. The bread was great (4). Small like the sweet Hawaiian bread, but not sweet.

Atmosphere is very cool. They played old school hip hop on a Monday. The tables and chairs are wood and there is a brick accent wall. You can also sit at the rear bar in front of the open kitchen. Pretty cool. There is also a bat immediately to the right when you come in next to a waiting area. 

Overall, ok experience. Maybe I'll try some other dishes on another visit. Looking over at other tables, I could see some tasty looking food.

Fantastic meal in New Orleans. Reservation was hard to come by-the only thing available 2 months out was 5pm on a Friday night, so make sure to plan ahead, or just get there early and grab a seat at the bar or hope for a table. 

Compared to other popular restaurants in New Orleans, Cochon has a more laid-back vibe and that was one of the things we loved about it. It's always fun to get a little dressed up, but it's also nice to have a great meal somewhere that's just a little more low-key. Our server offered great recommendations and was very attentive. We loved Cochon and would love to return next time we're in New Orleans.

We ordered:

*Wood-Fired Oysters-absolute MUST! My husband does not like raw oysters but he LOVED these! We seriously considered coming back the next day and sitting at the bar and just ordering these!

*Fried Alligator-ok, but I was quite as excited about these as I thought I would be. It could basically be any kind of meat just heavily breaded and smothered in a spicy sauce. 

*Fried Boudin-good, but very rich.

*Braised Ham Hock-Delicious! Great smokey flavor that went perfectly with the sweet potato puree, brussels sprouts, and pomegranate.

*Butterscotch Pudding-Yum! We don't usually order pudding but our server immediately recommended this when we asked about desserts so we went with it and we were definitely not disappointed.

Outstanding service.
A tasty meal- had to do some Google question-asking about some of the cooking terms!
We had the pork cheeks (tenderest ever) -and the grits are fine ground for an amazing texture- and we had the the court-bullion catfish, which is served with rice. The rabbit was recommended, but I wasn't ready for that...

Admittedly it was a short experience. Reception was hosted here after the conference let out I was attending.

Appetizers and drinks only, but a fair amount! 
The theme was certainly goat cheese on a flat bread with topping. Bruschetta on the base was fabulous, and the pork belly was equally tantalizing. Drinks accompanied these perfectly.

Perhaps the star of the night was the very good deviled eggs which included a shrimp! It added a texture that was sorely missing from the mix and was honestly something terribly delicious that I want much more of.

I have no doubt the offerings further in the menu excite. We also accompanied this with a full assortment of seafood, including a fabulous whitefish cevice and freshly shucked oysters. Excellent throughout.

Convenient to WWII Museum.  The rabbit & dumplings were absolutely delicious.  The rabbit & dumplings were light & full of flavor. The shrimp & egg gumbo was also full of flavor.  The boudin balls have a crisp, outer layer.  This was the perfect meal for a rainy day.

Great place for drinks and dinner with friends.  Had appetizers pork check and oysters. Great oysters. For Main course I have the grilled fish an my friends got the short rib. They said the short rib was salty. My fish was good.

One of the best places I've ever eaten. You can't go wrong here. It's a little pricey, but very much worth it! Make sure to get a reservation (we didn't know we needed them there). If you don't have one, there is seating at the bar or at a bar facing into the kitchen. We sat at the kitchen which we really enjoyed watching everything be prepared. One of the cooks even gave a few recommendations on his favorites.

Best baked oysters in the world - order double. Perfect place to have good conversation, but so so service. Entrees great, but oddly enough I would skip the Cochon. Maybe they should rename it The Baked Oyster.

I had one more day in NOLA and of course it was raining so what else could we do besides go and eat more amazing NOLA food. On my previous visit my hubby and I went to Cochon butcher since Cochon was super busy so on this last visit I knew that I had to give it a shot. Atmosphere is super casual, perfect for some lunch time snacks. 

We weren't starving but knew that we had to try some of their staple dishes per the servers recommendations. They give out complimentary rolls and butter so just do yourself a favor and have them, they are soft, warm and buttery, it doesn't get much better than that. As an appetizer we had to try the fried alligator bites in the spicy chipotle sauce and I was so proud of myself for finally trying alligator because that is a little strange I must say. It was surprisingly good, reminded me of a tougher shrimp and the sauce was spot on, so it didn't matter if it was shrimp, calamari or even alligator, you can fry and dip just about anything in that sauce. We then got a few orders of the smoked oysters also in their spicy sauce. Get these as well as they are delicious, plump and full of flavor. I still prefer the char grilled ones at Acme but these are still really good. Then we got a few more orders of their smoked ribs per everyone's suggestions and my mom says that they are the best ribs she's ever had in her life. They were my favorite thing there and come on we had to get some porky stuff since we're at a pigs place. These ribs literally fell off the bone and had so much freaking flavor, I just couldn't stop eating them.

I really wanted to try their chocolate peanut butter pie but we were so full at this point that we decided to wait for another visit in the future. Everything here is great, the atmosphere, the service and especially the food. I will definitely come back here and Cochon butcher in the future.

Completely disgusting! City of NOLA shut off water for well over an hour and employees are allowed back in the kitchen after only using hand sanitizer after using the bathroom. Think about it disgusting! The employees agreed, however the greedy owners decided to stay  open.  When I complained to manager she had a huge smile on her face. Told me the city health inspector had just been in to approve them staying open.  She did not care. Waited all day to come have a late lunch here and left after realizing just how disgusting people can actually be.
For sure the best meal we had in New Orleans. This was the highlight of our trip... Great service and again great drinks. This is a must visit.

Omg the Mac and cheese is bomb.com.  Not too cheesy and just the right touch.  I also got the Turkey Sandwich and usually it would be a sandwich that's bland, but this was deliciously flavored and was filling.

Oh, I also LOVE the Sweet Potato Habanero hot sauce.
Fantastic, had the alligator and bean soup to start and ended with the rabbits and dumplings. My daughter had the redfish. We will definitely be back.

The food is great but if you want seperate checks, you need to tell your server before hand or you are stuck calculating how much each person pays including tip... as a server myself, this is ridiculous. It is a servers job to ask about seperate checks or if one person is paying. It is also their job to calculate how much every person pays... not the customers. The manager is also bad at handling these types of situations. She was so passive agressive. Also, they switched servers on us mid-way through. There was no apology or guilt or acknowledgement of their wrong. As a server, I am appalled by their "customer service". I should of read the bad reviews because they all mention the bad service.
This is one of the best meals I have EVER eaten!  Paneed pork cheeks with Creole cream cheese grits and dried figs.  There wasn't enough bread to sop up my plate!

I fell in Love here.  With the food and my company.  

"They are known for their Bloody Mary, you should try it." 
"Um it is 11am"
"So."

LOVE HIM.  Totally sipped on that.  

Our server was so attentive.  Went through the menu.  The  grasp on what was about to happen could not be captured.  I totaaaaaaalllllllly had potato salad as an app haha.    Then, wait for it, pork, pig, lardon, greatness hit the table.  I had to tell the Love of my Life I would return to the conversation shortly as I excused my my knife.  It stayed clean the entire meal.  I took the back side of my fork and just lightly pressed until the foliation of evidence unveiled drippings unknown to mortals.  I cannot even express the pressed in parts that touched the sweet potatoes, some had brussel sprouts, some had pomegrante seeds.   He got a sammich.  Anyway, back to me.  

My Life is Complete.

Oh and the decor is spot on.  Light woods and cramped tables that allowed us to share breathing air with an actor on one side and an author on the other.  Super Groovy NOLA is.   Excited to be more and more part of this City.  See you in a few weeks.
Highly recommend this restaurant! MUST try the rabbit&dumplings, the fried alligator and oyster are so good too.

This review is way overdue! I visited in June 2014. After a long afternoon of walking around NOLA in the humidity and much needed thunder storms to relieve said humidity, my boss and I were hungry and came across Cochon. The place was modern yet still felt very welcoming. We were seated at a bar top right by the kitchen so that we could watch the chefs in action (we're food scientists so we couldn't resist). The server and chefs were so nice and they gave us some homemade headcheese as an appetizer. It was impressive, but I'm not a huge fan of gelled formed meat. I generally don't eat fried food, but I decided that since I was in the south, I would splurge. I ordered fried chicken with watermelon salad and mac'n'cheese. Sadly, I was disappointed with the chicken- the skin was so thick and fatty and although the outer layer was crispy, the chicken overall was just not that flavorful :( The watermelon salad was delish as was teh mac'n'cheese (so creamy and crispy on the top layer!).

Food: I was in town for the Rock n' Roll Marathon and was looking for a light lunch. After looking through the menu, I ended up ordering the pork cheeks, fried alligator, and a Radical Rye IPA. Everything was very good including the beer. Everybody always wants to know what alligator tastes like. Well, it has the texture of chicken but a little taste of fish... so it's a combination of fish and chicken. I kept the meal light and simple as I didn't want to eat too heavy or get too adventurous the day before running a marathon. I would definitely love to come back here to try other items on their menu.

Service: Service was decent and the food was brought out in a timely manner. But it was as if I had the word tourist tattooed on my forehead and she wanted me to order more food. Ok, that was my fault for bringing all of my bags with me to eat. I should've dumped my stuff at my hotel first before coming here to eat.

Location: There's a Cochon Butcher, which was more of a sandwich shop, and the restaurant setting Cochon, down at the corner. You'll know what I'm talking about when you get there. I came across Cochon Butcher first and it was packed, so I got a table at Cochon.
Loved their gumbo with deviled egg (amazing flavor combination), grilled oysters (best in NO so far), bbq ribs (like candy), and butterscotch pudding!! Wonderful service too!! Thank you Cochon!!

I came to Cochon with a group of 4 to have dinner during our first night in NOLA.  Before we left for the trip, I tried making an online reservation and the only time available was 3pm.  I decided to call and see if they could do anything better, and I was offered 5pm and 9pm, so definitely call if you have trouble getting a reservation.

We started with cocktails and a spare rib appetizer.  The cocktails were excellent and the rib was fantastic.  Coming from the Northeast, I'm not used to vinegar based BBQ sauce, so this was new to me.  I don't know if I prefer the vinegar base, but it's a really tasty alternative to tomato based sauces.  

For the main course, I had the Louisiana Cochon.  I really enjoyed this meal.  It came with a few veggies and, oddly enough, a couple of pork rinds on top.  I don't eat pork rinds, but I gave them a try with the pork and I really enjoyed the salty crunch that the rinds added.  My only issue with this dish was that the meat was a tad dry, but hardly enough to be a true problem.

We opted for a liquid dessert and got a sweet moonshine flight.  I've never had moonshine, but I know now that it's as strong as I've heard.  I'm glad it was shared because it would've knocked me out.

I originally came across Cochon by accident and was glad that I did. I ordered the Oyster and Bacon Sandwich (without the bacon)- because I like oysters and somehow I thought it would be low fat.

Ha!!! It was about a billion calories but soooooo good.  I was tempted to go back later that day and get it again.

I have gone back a few more time and have never been disappointed with anything that I've ordered. This place has a great vibe and the wines are pretty good and pair well with the food.

However, I recommend making a reservation if you can.  There is often a long wait to get in -- but with food this good, that's only to be expected.

Cochon is the eighth wonder of the culinary world. We ordered five small dishes, in order to try as many things as possible. Each dish was MAGNIFICENT. 

We started out with the shrimp gumbo with deviled egg (how could we NOT try that!?!?). It was so flavorful, and the egg and scallions added a simple yet powerful KAPOW! 

The cucumbers in vinaigrette with herbs were both cool and refreshing yet had a spicy kick. I'm salivating just recalling this meal!!

The barbecue ribs were melt-in-your-mouth delish. The alligator bites were tasty and savory. The oysters were grilled to perfection and were swimming in a savory garlic butter. 

For dessert we had butterscotch pudding which was so rich, creamy, and flavorful. 

In addition to the food being heavenly, the staff was friendly and attentive. So sad we live hundreds of miles away. So glad we were able to experience the deliciousness. Run, don't walk here. And make a reservation if you're going for dinner, to avoid the inevitable lines.

I was here for lunch on a Tuesday afternoon (the week before Mardi Gras, 2015). Due to some confusion, we had to split our party into 2 groups (2 of us at 12:30, the other 3 at 1:45ish). Unfortunately, this affected our service. Our waitresses were bothered by the separation - talking behind our backs (as if we didn't notice). This was very unprofessional, to say the least. Too bad this put a damper on our experience because the food was excellent. We ordered a few small plates, along with the cochon entree. The pineapple upside-down cake with pomegranate ice cream was incredible. I accompained this with a nice coffee. We didn't have any wine or cocktails due to it being a work day. I will definitely give this place a chance again, as I am sure our servers will be better.

Overall: 3.3 / B

Unfortunately Cochon did not live up to its great reviews. Our waitress was not very friendly, and when we asked to sit in a booth, she said it was only for large parties. However, several minutes later a couple was seated there. Then we asked for a second helping of bread- usually readily brought to your table without asking at nice restaurants, she never did. When I asked her about it she said she said it was coming.  Our check was brought to us before we ever received any second helping of bread! The waitress never mentioned the bread as she quickly took our check away and wished us good night. I guess we wouldn't have been so desperate for more bread had the portions been more plentiful, and I would not have complained about the tiny portions had the prices not been so extravagant. As far as the food itself, the only two meals that were very good were the chacuterie small plate and the cochon entree. But with the bad service, small portions and over-the-top prices, I would not bother to go back there again. If you want to pay that kind of money go to a finer, truly upscale restaurant; one that will deliver great service and great food not just upscale prices.

SO SO SO GOOD-

started out with the shrimp and oyster appetizers- both were out of this world. 

then onto the gumbo and carrot salad- also phenomenal.

then entrees- red fish and the cochon- we had to stop ourselves from finishing our plates- and the grits- BEST GRITS IVE EVER HAD!

The only let down was the lemon meringue- not my fave, but i'm not a huge fan of lemon desserts - bf had the german chocolate cake and said it was pretty good.

WILL BE BACK NEXT TIME I'M IN TOWN!!!

As always, the food at Cochon was incredible today. Unfortunately, the service at both the hostess stand and the table service was awful.  We arrived early for our reservation, but waited about 70 minutes, 40 minutes longer than walk-ins that arrived after us because we were skipped over by the three hostesses. When I went up to check that we were on the list, after a number of walk-ins were seated before us, the lead one/manager told me that we were in the system and we were next. After another four groups were sat over another 20 minutes, I was told it was because she was setting us up with an inside table, even though most people sat, were sat inside, and she never asked whether we wanted to sit inside our out. After we were finally sat, or server promptly delivered water and forgot about us for 15 minutes. We eventually were able to order and the food arrived promptly and was incredible. We had the bouchon plate, fried poached egg with kohlrabi, pork cheeks, grits, greens, and LA cochon with cabbage and cracklins. The food was as incredible as it always is at Cochon. Getting drink refills and the check paid were as inefficient as the hostess stand. With all of the waiting, our quick lunch took over 2.5 hours, and would have been much longer, but the kitchen cranked the food out quickly. As great as the food was, the service killed the experience though. There are too many great options in the great city of New Orleans to return for service like this. The only person who showed great service was the server's assistant. He actually rang our check, after seeing our waitress pass by us so many times. He should have been serving and the server should have been delivering bread and refilling water.

My favorite of the night was the petite stack of smoked pork ribs with pickled watermelon and a sweet glaze. Pork cheek terrine was beautifully cooked, tender and crisped at the corners for a close second place. Smoked ham hock was flavorful, if scarce on the crisped brussels sprouts. The nuggets of fried alligator ended up being the most generously portioned dish, without much flavor beyond the aioli. Thin brown crust graced the tops of the plush mound of Parker house rolls. Rabbit & dumplings were rustic and thickened just enough, though I personally would have been happier with smaller dumplings and more rabbit. Pork tongue was surprisingly under-seasoned, but still not as disappointing as the simple braised beef. Desserts were okay: fudge strawberry ice cream was rich and subtle on fruit, the strawberry pocket pie evoked nostalgic strawberry shortcake notes, and the pineapple upside-down cake was moist with a pretty shell.

Three and a half stars. Pork items are executed stronger than other proteins, as to be expected. Hearty food with conservative portions, chic interior and a bustling dining room. Signage at night makes this restaurant stand out like a Vegas church of pig. Future hit list: crawfish pie, fried shrimp heads with roasted chili sauce, fried livers with pepper jelly & toast, fried boudin with pickled peppers, shrimp & deviled egg gumbo, Louisiana cochon, smothered greens, creamy grits, Delta Burke, the Rub.

Amazing!! I visited on a late afternoon weekend recently, and scored a table outside. The hostesses did a great job considering the high number of walk-ins. Service was prompt, but not super friendly. The food was absolutely incredible - bacon and oyster sandwich, grilled shrimp with pickled cauliflower, and a ribs special were all perfectly done.

We made a reservation and still had to wait over 20 minutes, plus it was miserably hot in there, but it was worth it once the food started coming out. They were out of the pork cheeks, which was disappointing, but our server was great and directed us towards some other awesome things. The wood fired oysters were one of the best things I ate in NOLA. Ridiculously good. I didn't want to share with my boyfriend.
The best meal I've had in a long time!! Wood fired oysters were perfectly seasoned.  Braised ribs were tender,  no knife needed.  Wait can be kind of long but absolutely worth it.

When I knew I was coming to Nola, I looked on Yelp for restaurants. And this place was one of the most reviewed places there. Over 1700 reviews I had to check it out. I heard this place gets pretty busy so we decided to come mid afternoon. The place was really nice, clean with a wodden homey look. Theres seating outside, and the place had a great vibe. As soon as you walk in you smell that strong BBQ smoked pork smell and its awesome. The staff are great. The menu is not that large but its got everything you need, including some great drinks, I had the Betrand Rd! I was told if you go to Nola you have to try the Boudin. We got them here and, wow, they are like pork cutlets with rice that comes with some spicy mustard, Amazing! Next we got an order of the Aligator tail! Those little tenders that taste like chicken was sooo good. The spicy garlic aioli was one of the BEST SAUCES I have ever tasted in my life!! With a side of some rich Mac n chesse the meal was perfect. My sister and I shared those three things and it was perfect. Decent portions, a little pricier then the rest of Nola food, but well worth it. This spot pretty muched sumed up Nola food for me, flavorful, exotic, but rich and homey. Out of all the spots I went to in Nola this was my favorite hands down, wish there was one in Chicago!

Service was surprisingly horrible.  Asked for non alcoholic cocktail and was told that they don't make them.  

Food was excellent but they bring food to table when it's ready not all at once.  One person at our table of 6 had to wait a while before her food arrived.  When we politely inquired, our server was rude about the delay 

A little too much attitude for my blood.  Was very disappointed, but we all know what eventually happens when service is an afterthought...

After a visit to the National World War II Museum, my friends and I decided to stop for some dinner at Cochon. Having already been to Cochon Butcher, which was delicious, I was excited to give the food at the actual restaurant a try.

I got the Crispin Hard Apple Cider to start, which came with the cutest little cup to pour into. So light and refreshing, it was a great way to unwind after walking around all day in New Orleans. My two friends and I decided to share the Boucherie Plate, which came with a generous amount of meat. Served with toasty bread and pickles, I was pretty much in cold cut heaven. 

My entree decision was an easy one, as I've heard rave reviews about the Louisiana Cochon. While it was indeed tasty, I was expecting it to be even tastier. Served with turnips, cabbage + cracklins, the pork cochon was smoky and tasty. I think mine might have been a tad bit under seasoned, but I still enjoyed it nonetheless. I thought the cracklins gave the dish a nice texture, while the turnips gave it a nice touch of acidity. 

We shared the Peach Cobbler for dessert, which was perfectly sweet and crumbly. I honestly feel like it's the crumble that makes a cobbler and this one did not disappoint. Loved that it was peach instead of the traditional apple as well.

Rabbit and dumplings. Get them.

Gator bites. Get them.

Cochon. Go there.

Went here for lunch and it was some of the best pork I've ever had.  However, I feel the place is a bit overpriced and the lack of value keeps me from rating it the full 5 stars.  I think you are almost better off at the more laid back Butcher next door if you're trying to get your fill.  But in a city full of amazing food, you can't go wrong here.
We are very impressed! Everything is unique. Even the salads and twice baked potato were delicious. I would recommend the ribs and the boucherie plate.
Excellent!
Favorite must have is the roasted oysters. Daily specials always please as well. If it's available, I highly recommend the beef hash. Wonderful space and staff - reservations recommended.

I can't believe I haven't reviewed Cochon. People come thousands of miles to visit me here in beautiful New Orleans, and you want to know the only consistent thing in those visits? Cochon. No other restaurants make my MUST list. I have favorites. I have so-goods. There is only ONE must. That is Cochon. Go there....and thank me later. I love you all. Trust me.

The noise is crazy, but go in expecting it. Your welcome.

If you don't make it to Cochon, go to Cochon Butcher and get a Cuban. Thank me later.

Cochon provides a perfect example of a restaurant where you simply can not make up your mind because you will literally want to try everything on the menu. And this can be particularly vexing here because what they offer is largely heavy, country style food that will make you want to roll over and take a nap immediately once you finish a plate. I will say that I would have been happy ordering 3 plates of the wood-fired oysters and just calling it a day. Those were simply amazing. We also ordered the gator, the crawfish pie, a side of lima beans, and the rabbit and dumplings. The Rabbit with dumplings was a homerun dish as well. I really enjoyed the gator too, but the crawfish pie was not very interesting. We're visitors to New Orleans so I now understand that crawfish pie is kind of like street food here, but this was something that had intrigued me so much but then delivered so little. What I pictured in my mind and what arrived were far off so I'd say pass on this one. At the end of the day, we experienced some great food in a vibrant setting and I would love to go back.

Far from the FQ - gotta take a cab and hunt for one for the return trip. And although you ask the waitstaff to call one while you are paying your bill, they don't.  Annoying.  I guess once they get your money they don't care about the rest of your experience there?  The food is ok - spicy so be warned. I also got SUPER sick after (had the boudin, veal, and mac n cheese) so I'm not sure what did me in but overall from the sickness to the customer service, I won't be returning.
The food is amazing, I sat at the chefs counter which was a great experiment. They gave me complimentary head cheese. This was a first for me and it was really good. The Mac and cheese was amazing.
Awesome menu, great atmosphere, the moon pie put me in a sugar coma. Would be five stars except for the distresses signals the waittress put off by having to talk with us

There is so much to praise about this place but their Grilled Oysters were out of control (better than Acme and Drago's). Do not leave w/o trying them! Other than that, the Louisiana Cochon with cabbage and turnips is wonderful, the St Bertrand cocktail is addictive and the butterscotch pudding will make it virtually impossible to care about anything anyone is saying to you at the time you are eating it.

They seated us right away and I now realize why. The service was mediocre and the food was not great. I had the Cochon and it was just really salty. The Mac n cheese side was bland and not incredibly tasty. 
   I don't often dislike everything about my meal but this time I really did. Oh wait , the bread was good. I paid a lot of money for good bread!

I think it has great food here but not exceeding my other dining experience in local restaurants. I heard of this places reputation and came here with very high expectation. Especially I love GW FINS and heard Cochon is comparable to GW FINS. We ordered many appetizers here - fried alligator tail, shrimp&egg gumbo, wood fried oysters, boudin, and pig cheeks. Almost all are too salty for us :( also, I feel some foods are tasty regardless of its salty taste because the raw materials themselves taste good, not because they cook them better or have better recipes.
It was ok not great service. Drinks were not refilled no one checked up on us.  Really overpriced for what your getting.  Good was good not amazing nothing was so delicious I'd come back.

Excellent service, wonderfully unique selection. The shrimp and eggplant dressing is delicious! Our servers were so attentive. The restaurant was too dim for my taste. Overall the decor is as unique and interesting as the menu.

It was my first alligator meat experience, and I enjoyed their fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise dish. The meat almost tasted like chicken but on a tougher side. The chili garlic mayo sauce definitely complimented the flavors. I also ordered panned pork cheeks and it was very moist and tender, except the size of the dish was  pretty small. My friend ordered the fisherman's style fish and the fish still had scales which I was never a big fan of. I thought it was also lacking for flavors that I expect from a creole restaurant. The waiter also took a long time to order our drinks, refill our waters and get us the check. The place is also pretty noisy. Overall, my experience there was just A-OK. We heard many good things about the place, but if your traveling to NOLA it wouldn't be something I highly recommend. If you happen to be in the area, then I would say sit at the bar to check out this alligator meat appetizer with a glass of wine.

I have been here so many times, I have eaten everything on the menu. It's all amazing! My favorites are the Cochon and the rabbit and dumplings, but everything is just wonderful! Great service and ambience and delicious cocktails! One of my favorite places in New Orleans!
