Not my kind of restaurant. I am sure certain foods are considered gourmet  for others. But seriously to have as a special fir the evening  a pigs head. My dinner companions ordered ir and ate it. I guess  at 60.00 you better eat it. On a brighter side I did go vegan for the night. Their side dishes  of vegtables were nicely done. I could not find anythibg else to order without thinking about the  pugs head.

Do not miss Cochon when in New Orleans !! We were a party of 4 and ordered  the wood- fired oysters, rabbit-dumplings and the catfish. The ambiance is very comfy and the food super delicious. It was a great way to unwind after walking around all day in New Orleans.

I need to go back here to give a more accurate assessment of the food.  I went here after three days of heavy eating and moderate drinking.  Neither my wife and I were in the mood to eat this type of food, but I felt obligated to try this place in light of the great reviews and its proximity to my hotel.  

Despite having my fill of rich food, the little bit I was able to put down was stellar.  I started with the pork rib with watermelon pickle and the smoked hamhock.  The ribs were good and the pickles were awesome (sweet and sour, but not overpowering).  The smoked hamhock tasted as good as it looked.  

Another highlight was the overall vibe.  In simple terms, this place is cool.  It is a casual eatery, with great food, cocktails and beer.  My only suggestion would be to go here earlier in your trip, and with a group so you can try as many items as possible.

Oh MAN, this place is worth the hype. I went with two friends and we ordered a bunch of dishes to share:

-Louisiana cochon: Tasty, especially the cracklins it comes with, but it was way too salty for our taste. Not sure if that's just the way the dish is or if something went wrong with our particular order. I'm not docking points for this because we brought it up to the server, who offered to take it back and make us another one, but we declined.

-Crawfish pie (it's like an empanada): My friends really liked this but I didn't care for it, possibly because I don't like crawfish (it was my first time eating crawfish so I'm not sure).

-Grits: ORDER THIS. None of us were grits fans, but this side dish won us over, probably due to the insanely tasty amount of cream and butter in it.

-Oyster and bacon sandwich: Delicious! The bacon was thick, crisp and flavorful -- no wimpy Oscar Meyer bacon here. The breading on the fried oysters was also thick and crunchy, and the oysters inside were creamy.

-Pineapple upside down cake: Good, but I only had a small bite of my friend's order, so I can't speak much to it.

-Butterscotch pudding: My other friend and I both ordered it, and when we took that first bite we almost died right then and there at the table. Days later, we are still talking about it. This simple dessert is the most memorable thing we consumed on my entire trip to NOLA. I would shiv someone in a second for another serving.
I can't say enough great things about this place! They have the best oysters in New Orleans by far!  The pork ribs were amazing also.

Even after a day of walking, we didn't regret for a second our decision to follow the Yelp reviews down to Couchon after getting off the Creole Queen. The key to traveling with a 13-year-old boy is keeping his blood sugar up, so a 4:00 snack seemed like a great idea . He devoured short ribs with watermelon pickles and a huge, delicious wedge of German chocolate cake (I couldn't say no to my perennial birthday favorite, considering it was a mere two days from my birthday!) I had the oysters with chili garlic butter. beause, chili garlic butter! And they made me Drunk Arnold Palmers, which they called by some other golfer's name, one apparently known for his drinking. Whatever,  it was all amazing, the best meal we have had yet this week! Service was pleasant and quick, and no judging my kid for having rib sauce all over his face. Win! Go there NOW!

I'm writing this review based on my visit a month ago.  Given the stellar reviews that other Yelpers have written about Cochon since then, I think that my 5-star rating, although dated, still holds weight.  

Every time my girlfriend and I visit a city, we plan our Food Marathons to a "T." While we were researching New Orleans, Cochon consistently came up in our queries of places to try out.  It's funny.  I took French for 8 years from Middle School up until college, and I had no idea what "cochon" meant until I looked at the menu and noticed all the delightful pork dishes.  Fail #1. What's funnier is that we chose to go to this place on a Friday during the lent.  We're Roman Catholics.  Roman Catholics don't eat meat on Fridays during Lent.  We knew this going in, but we still wanted to try some of their other dishes.  Fail #1.5.

No, we didn't get to try the smoked pork ribs, nor did we get to try the rabbit and dumplings, or braised beef short rib, etc, etc, etc.  But we did get the wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter, the fried alligator with chili garlic mayo, and the grilled shrimp with roasted cabbage, pickled cauliflower, and jalapeno mayo.  All this, along with some local craft beers and ciders, made for an awesome dining experience.  Let's just say these three appetizers alone were the highlight of our trip.   

Not only that, but our waitress was SUPER accommodating to our religious needs, recommending other seafood dishes like catfish courtbouillon, and the oven-roasted gulf fish.  We were quite full, having sampled some other dishes from Cafe Amelie an hour earlier (Food Marathon, remember?), but we certainly appreciated the effort!  I can only imagine how tasty Cochon's staple dishes are.  Can't wait to go back!

I have been want to go to Cochon ever since it open and somehow never managed to get there. I was at the convention center for a seminar and have a couple hours between courses, and when I Yelped for restaurants it came up. So I said perfect. And it was!!!
  I sat at the chefs bar which is right in front of the wood burning oven where I got to see the creations being made. Service was prompt and quick efficient and all servers seem very knowledgeable of the menu.
   I start off with their fire roasted oysters. Now in the land "everyone has their own charbroiled oyster dish", what could they possibly do to it to improve upon it.. Well they did. It was amazing. Absolutely no comparison to what we think of as charbroiled oysters. The sauce is light and exquisite the oyster difficult but tender. A must-have. 
     I then had the ham hock which was brined then smoked than braised. Spectacular doesn't quite cut it  Will absolutely be going again and highly recommending it.
I love you guys but please bring back the mushroom salad. I have dreams about it.....i miss it...i want it back!!!

The fried gator bites were incredible!
I was amazed by the salad with fried cheese as well as the veggie curry soup. The flavors of each dish were complex and full of unique flavor. I can't wait to come back to town again!

Love the pork! Definitely a go to if we ever come back to New Orleans, the only downside is it always has a long line and the outside reeks of garbage.. But it's worth the wait once i got inside and tasted their food

How is it possible that this place doesn't hold a solid 5 star rating? I wish I could give it a 6. 

This place might be among the best restaurants I've ever dined at. When Ursula took Ariel's voice she took a job in Cochon's kitchen and served it up with their Oysters. They are truly amazing. Whatever slurpy goodness was in that blessèd shell was a gift. 

The portions, even for small plates are enormous. We ate more than any one human being should for a meal. 

Everything about this place was perfect. The server was smart and sassy, not unlike Jack Black in High Fidelity.

The cocktails were all delicious, well crafted, well poured, tasty and reasonable.

Ham Hock!

If there is one place you dine in New Orleans for dinner, this should be it.

I tried at least 5 or 6 menu items during my visit and although they were all good the rabbit livers with spicy jelly was an absolute show stopper!

We dined outside on the patio and stayed posted there eating and people watching for hours.  The overall experience was incredible!.

This was recommended to me by my taxi driver and hotel concierge. I'm a first time visitor to NOLA and wanted to ensure to pick a good place to eat.  They seated me right away, and I got to sit at the bar watching the chefs, which was unique.  The food was good, unique, and prepared well.  I had the chili ginger oysters and the Louisiana pork house special.  I wasn't impressed with the friendliness of the servers - they switched servers in the middle and didn't tell me and didn't really seem pleased to help answer my questions about the menu.  At one point I saw the two servers I had standing, smiling, and talking and looking at me out of the corner of their eye.  Whether or not they were talking about me is irrelevant - I don't care - it's just the feeling of not being welcome as a newcomer.

My favorite place to eat in New Orleans. The food is ridiculous! I was in the big easy for mardi grass and the one place I couldn't miss on this trip as my favorite restaurant.
The rabbit and dumplings are great!
BB
We visited Cochon on special orders from Guy Fiery (on the show, not in person, unfortunately), and loved it! The Louisiana Cochon is to die for. Really. Die. For. A must have.

I'd give six stars if I could. I went here based on Yelp reviews. I was by myself but ate at the food bar, which felt like the best seat in the house. I was mesmerized by the open kitchen. I was facing the wood burning oven--the heart of the action. I had a perfect view of the food prep, which was sheer poetry. It's remarkable how something can be simultaneously frenzied and calming. The cliché "well oiled machine" comes to mind. I felt like I should be paying extra just to watch. 

And then there's the food...I had the short rib with horseradish potato salad ($27 I think)--a perfect pairing. The kitchen sent me a complimentary plate of head cheese with crostini, Dijon mustard and thin pickle slices. My first reaction was, "wow! how nice!" My second reaction was "crap. Now I have to eat it. I'm not much of a head cheese fan." Or wasn't until now. Now I am confident that I would love anything on the menu. And after watching just about everything on the menu being prepared, I think the oysters look great, the rabbit as well, and of course, the mac and cheese. The fish wouldn't be at the top of my list, although I'm sure it's good. I was too full to try dessert.

I popped in seeking shelter during a rain storm, I mean flash flood! ;)

I had a couple of appys, the alligator and the liver. Both were exceptional. The alligator wasn't chewy like most other places. The liver was nice and light textured, not dense like most.

I'm miserably sad after eating here. Sad only because I won't be seeing this menu again anytime soon back home. Just a little of everything might be better than a lot of something. Mufaletta, brisket, pastrami, roasted turkey, whatever butcher style you like, even a beef jerky topped with some sweet potato habanero hot sauce. Be here or be square my friends, you'll feel like your Nola adventure is complete.

Best meal ever! We ordered the majority of the menu granted but everything was awesomeness sprinkled with the big O! I made reservations 2 weeks out considering French Quarter Festival-and we sat outside and it was grand!!!! Favorite bite-Chargrilled oysters...phew. I've only got pics of dinner cause yeah...I was in euphoria. Holy Cochon Batman!
Can't even explain how good the oysters are!!! Just ridiculous, whether you like oysters or not. Great place, try as much as you can handle. Sigh!!

The flavors of the food at cochon jump off the plates. I went with a group of 8 people and was able to enjoy most of the food on the menu. The Louisiana Cochon is live for, the strawberry glazed pigs feet special was downright amazing.

Great staff and good food. You absolutely must try the gumbo. It was the best we had in New Orleans... Portion was a little smaller than I would've liked ;)... The shrimp was just average. I really liked the combination of shrimp with cauliflower etc but the shrimp was a little tough. The pork cheek made up for what the shrimp lacked- it was amazing!!

It was 7 of us at the dinner.. We had rabbit dumpling, ham hock, alligator fried and some extra dishes,, everything was great!! Was amazingggg... The server was nice..! Til we found cockroach flew around and landed in our in our table.. In front of my food!! Yepppp!!! I screamed and jumped!!! It was a huge one!! Very disgusting! I lost my appetite instantly..!  Not hungry anymore! Even though they over me to order a new one.. But couldn't do it! That cockroach just ruin our nite! 
Even though they comp most of our bills, and offer free dessert... I wouldn't take any chance.. Turn out someone already post a pic on yelp with cockroach crawling on their wall..
They really need to get this problem taking care of!! It's veryyyyyyyy disturbing, unbelievable disgusting to see cockroach flaying around your table and then landed and crawled around your table! 
Sorry management... Nothing against the food not your employees.. But this cockroach problem is very unacceptable.

I ordered 3 different things because I just HAD to try them all.  I tried boudin balls for the first time. They are an interesting dish and I didn't finish them all because I was busy eating everything else. But they are definitely worth trying. I also ordered the crawfish pie. If you order any appetizer or aren't as hungry, order that. It's delicious!!! I also ordered a shrimp appetizer. I don't remember what it was called but it was really good.

Delicious southern cooking and excellent service!  We had the fried gator (which was seasoned well), shrimp appetizer (very nice!), mixed green salad, short ribs (meet fell apart) with some amazing horse radish potato salad, colored greens, butterscotch pudding and pineapple upside down desert.  You must check this place out!

I saw Cochon and its butcher shop in the back on multiple Must-Try lists for NOLA, so of course we had to try it. I didn't know the difference between the restaurant and sandwich shop when we stopped in Saturday morning for brunch at 11, but that's ok as both come highly recommended. If you want higher-end plates, definitely go to the restaurant; if you want fresh butcher selection (cheaper) sandwiches and hearty sandwiches, go with the butcher shop in the back. We started with the fried alligator, which wasn't too gamy like often described. I had the braised pork cheeks and he had the rabbit dumplings. We've never had either dish prepared in the Cochon way- my mouth is watering just thinking about them! Brunch for two w/o drinks will run you about $50. Will definitely try the butcher shop next time.
Really enjoyed their wine list and cocktail list. Though their rabbit and dumplings dish was phenomenal. Got the Molly Wops cocktail and it's very tart - which I like in a cocktail.

Great restaurant while in NOLA. The fried aligator was amazing. Also try the chicken and sausage gumbo.  
My main entree was the pork cheeks which did not disappoint. All around great place to eat.

Heard good stuff about this place so made reservations at Cochon before arriving in nawlins.  Definitely has a nice atmosphere and is a trendy place to grab dinner.  The menu is a bit eclectic and features quite a few distinct items - but overall neither myself nor the wife were impressed.  I had the rabbit and she had the cochon - presentation was nice but taste was completely average.  Felt my dish was a bit too salty, and my wife said a good pulled pork would beat out hers any day.  One thing we both enjoyed though - the alligator appetizer was pretty freakin delicious and we recommend giving it a try if you drop by.
Went here with a group of friends. Wow! Great food. Loved everything I tried - pork cheeks, gulf fish, short ribs, grits, and the oysters. Wow!

Cochon was highly recommended by a few friends who had been to NOLA before and when I looked at Yelp reviews, there were an additional 1700+ reviews with a solid 4-star rating, so I definitely knew I had to get reservations here for me and my girlfriends. Cochon wasn't on Opentable, so I just called the restaurant. I called 2 weeks before our trip and was able to get a Saturday evening reservation for 4 for either 6 PM or 9 PM - I chose the latter. 

When we arrived, the place was packed and we had to wait about 10 minutes until a table opened up. The place had a very laid back vibe with the décor and lighting. Their music was awesome; playing 90's R&B and Hip-hop. My friends and I forgot we were in New Orleans for a second since Cochon had a very NYC/Brooklyn-y feel. The service was great; our glasses were never empty! Staff could have been friendlier but they were just really busy and we felt it but our waitress did help point out which dishes could be made Gluten-free for my friend. 

I ordered the Louisiana Cochon w/ Turnips, Cabbage, & Cracklins ($24). The Pork was tender and super-flavorful. There was some sauce which the turnips and cabbage were bathed in and the cracklins were on top, which ensured that they'd remain crunchy. Whenever I took a bite, I'd try to get a little bit of the protein, veggies, and cracklins which created a great balance of textures and flavors. My girlsfriends tried my pork and thought it was really good as well! 2 of my friends had the Smoked Pork Ribs and my other friend had the Gulf fish which was Gluten-free. Everyone thoroughly enjoyed their dishes and I tasted everyone's and they were all good! 

I'd definitely recommend this place!

I went with the recommended selections of my bartender - Oh Em Gee!

Easily the most perfect Gumbo I've EVER had!

The smoked oysters and pork cheeks were incredible. 

I will be back and work my way through this amazing menu complemented by a nice wine, beer and cocktail menu. 

Great restaurant. A must if you are in NOLA!

The Fried crocodile was good, but everything else was just average. 

The receptionist and the guy that looks like Bart Simpson with a beard weren't really the nicest of the staff (saw them glancing at customers and then laughing). Place is definitely overrated and overpriced. Better off going to Acme's Oysterhouse, Katie's, or Atchafalaya! (now that's a restaurant worthy of the hype).

We are locals and tried Cochon's for the first time. The food was average at best and the service was poor. The restaurant wasn't busy, and we had to stop and ask a staff member who was servicing our table. Once our order was placed we never saw our waitress again, and no one returned to ask if we needed drink refills or to inquire about any other service needed. My husband asked to substitute the meat accompaniment due to a restricted diet. He was told that wasn't possible but that he could purchase something else. We eat out frequently and have never been to a restaurant that did not try to accommodate him. The result was an average portion of beef short rib at a cost of $27.00. Since this wasn't enough food he ordered a $7.00 vegetable. We will not be returning nor will we recommend to our friends who visit the city.

A solid dinner experience though based on how much everyone raved, it didn't live up to that experience. Certain dishes, like the wood-fired oyster appetizer, were phenomenal; other items were just ok. Didn't blow my mind... or taste buds. 

What did? The Catdaddy moonshine, something I'd never had ordered if not for the recommendation of a friend whose tastes I trusted. And I wasn't steered wrong. It was smooth, slightly sweet with big caramel-vanilla flavor. I'd go back just for that!

The Fried crocodile was good, but everything else was just average. 

The receptionist and the guy that looks like Bart Simpson with a beard weren't really the nicest of the staff (saw them glancing at customers and then laughing). Place is definitely overrated and overpriced. Better off going to Acme's Oysterhouse or Katie's.

Alligator fried w spicy mayo

turkey - kale - gumbo

Shaved mushrooms

Pork cheeks

Mac n cheese

Homemade lemonade palmer

I now know what my last meal request would be.


This is a modern take on some old classis.
Are you looking for the hot trendy new restaurant that all you'll be telling your friends about?
This is my favorite hands down place to go eat when I'm in Nola and the bang for your buck is out of this world. 5 Star rustic dinning! 

Just remember to come hungry, because you'll want to order everything.
Great food with personality. Good service as well. Will be back and choose some different items. Oysters were great, bodim good, gumbo very good. Alligator was ok.

Excellent experience.   The chef sent over a little lagniappe of boucheri as we were sitting at the chefs bar and enjoying the scene behind the bar.  For starters my friend and I shared the oyster roast and the goat stuffed biscuits.   Oh how I wish this was a main dish and there would be more goat.  I'm still dreaming of that dish.  For the main portion we shared the daily plate: soft shell crab.  This was the best ssc I have ever had.  The mac n cheese was ok,  not too cheesy in flavor but could have used more spice.  The smothered greens-should not be missed.  Cocktails were nice I enjoyed the blueberry gin cocktail and have been craving one since.

Wonderful place with great casual atmosphere and great comfort food.  Definitely come hungry you will not be disappointed.  A very mixed clientele easy going and relaxing with a very friendly neighborly appeal.   Loved it.  Food was great and stick to your ribs type food with that Cajun twist.

We went for my birthday dinner and ordered almost one of everything. Loved the alligator and cochon the most. I typically don't like eggplant but the shrimp casserole with eggplant was to die for. The rabbit could have been more tender but the flavor was still nice.

Loved the beer and cocktail list too.

So Good!!  Can't miss this place!  This has become a must for any visit to New Orleans.  Make your dinner reservation well in advance.  Can usually get in for lunch at opening, but make reservations just in case!!

The wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter was the best cooked oyster dish I have ever had! But then the Gumbo was so salty! My wife eat it all but still, it was soooo salty!  And then we had louisiana cochon with turnips, cabbage & cracklins $24.  Again, a little bit to the salty side. Cochon was very dry, cabbage does taste OK.  Overall, I would give 2 stars, but with that Oyster, I give a three,

We hit this place since we were in the area. I have to admit I was highly dubious once I saw the quasi industrial decor and the abundance of hipsters. Lots of skinny leg pants and beards. But we loved everything. I had the Crawfish Pie that was amazing and the Louisiana Cochon with Turnips and Cracklings. Crazy good. Wifey had the Braised Beef Short Rib and says was some of the best she has ever had.  Would definitely recommend. Great place, Hipsters aside.

Place has highs and lows. Like most places in New Orleans the front of house staff is inept. We waited 20 minutes past our reservation because the two women were too busy chatting and not doing their job, so they forgot about us and began seating people who just walked in. Finally after pointing it out to the manager (who didn't even apologize) we wait another 10 minutes and are finally seated. Big fail. The food is pretty solid and the wait staff was good, but still pretty slow and unaware. Highlights on food the chicken livers with mint and jelly. Very balanced and tasty. The rabbit and dumplings was pure comfort. And the grits are solid. The pork cheek was dry and overcooked. The the greens were pretty average. Fix the service and this place would be 4 stars.
Yummy and fun foods! Smaller portions, but not bad. Pricier. Definitely worth a visit! Nice open setting restaurant. Bar.

Eating at Cochon was a great experience and I would definitely recommend it to someone who wanted to get a modern take on some very satisfying southern cuisine. 

We made a reservation for Monday night at 8.30, which was a good idea since it was certainly poppin'! Service was attentive and friendly. We started with the crawfish pie and paneed pork cheeks appetizers. They were both delicious, but I mainly had the crawfish pie which was a deliciously seasoned crawfish empanada.

I had the rabbit and dumplings entree which was so deliciously seasoned, flavored, and delicious. The dumplings were very doughy, almost like soaked biscuits, so order if you like it that style. My friend had the Louisiana cochon with turnips, cabbage, and cracklins which she also thought was flavored nicely, especially the turnips. We had to skip dessert because we were so full.

Standout cocktail of the night? The Rub. It was out of this world. Overall, it was a great vibe, great lighting, great restaurant for people watching. They were playing great music as well. it's fairly easy for a tourist to get to, it's near the WWII museum.

My first time but not my last,  casual but with class. Started with corn custard and crab salad, the delicate flavorful custard paired with the vinaigrette tang of the crab was a marriage of flavors created in heaven. I was lucky enough to have the oysters with chili garlic butter sent and they were fantastic plump and flavorful.  My entree was the smoked ham hock with field peas and spring onions.  The meat of the hock was moist and falling off the bone the onions although sweet still had that onion bite. Service was excellent and manager Daniel (know him from Windsor Court but don't remember his last name) was on top of it all.  Was my first time but plan to return

Flippin Amazing! 

We were greeted upon arrival here with smiling faces. I have heard so much about Cochon from those who've traveled to New Orleans, so I knew I had to come here. 

I ordered the Delta Burke ($10) via the recommendation of the waiter and it was really good and tasty. My mom and aunt each ordered a glass of Sauvignon Blanc and thought it was good. 

For our entrées, my aunt and mom each ordered the red fish and a side of baked mashed potatoes. Obviously I had some of their meal and I have to say it was beyond good! The flavors of the fish were perfectly blended and complimented each other so well. The mashed potato sides were also excellent. The fish was pricey at $32 a piece, but it's worth it if you're touring New Orleans.

I had the special of the night which was the fried soft shell crab. I don't feel it was worth $27 alone, but it was pretty damn good. 

Our server was nice and attentive. And the staff was friendly. I would love to come back here before my stay in NOLA ends or when I come back to the city in the future. Cochon is a must if you're coming to New Orleans!!

We had a trip planned to New Orleans for a wedding and were very excited to score a reservation at Cochon.  We've heard lots of great things about it and have been looking forward to eating here for a while.

Pros:  
- Service was excellent, attentive and never over-bearing.  There was a slight mistake with our order, and the server was quick to fix it and made it right.  The restaurant puts a lot of time into training their staff and it shows.

- Rabbit & Dumplings:  Simply one of the best rustic dishes I've ever had.  The seasoning was perfect, rabbit was tender and flavorful, and the dumplings floating on top were insane.  There are tons of good reviews for it here but you simply have to try it.

- Boucherie plate:  Excellent.  The "porkhead" terrine and pork rillet were our favorite and I could have eaten way more of both!

- Beer / Wine:  Great selection of local craft beers and a great reasonably priced wine menu.

Cons:
- We can't get another reservation tomorrow!

My first taste of gator.  I am now an addict.  Unfortunately, there are no gators in AZ that I can eat...  Went in for lunch and our taste buds were blown away.  Gator, short ribs, gator!  Go.  Eat.  Enjoy.  Best gator in NOLA!

Food was superb. Angie our waitress was the worst.  Took half our order,  then had her own lunch across from us. Had to have the manager, Will, put things back on track.  Only to have Angie return with her fake sarcastic politeness. Although,  it seemed Angie did try to minagate the collateral damage by providing 3 free drinks on the house as a peace offering.   Only 2 of the 3 people drank Angies drink. This 2 people feel ill shortly after leaving, providing a nice evening of vomiting.  Thanks Angie. BTW  food still tasted good on it's way back up.

My friends and I shared all the items on the small plates section of their menu and we were not disappointed! The oysters are a must-have, richly seasoned with butter garlic and cajun spices!  We did try to eat there again, almost impossible without a reservation and may take up to two hours if clears at all.  Yumm!

This was, without a doubt, my favorite place to eat when I traveled to NOLA this January. 

The oysters are out of control good. I tried oysters at MANY places, Cochon had the best! 

The best, Jerry! The best! 

You walk into the place and you can just smell all the delicious meat and the bourbon you are going to be drinking and you cannot wait for the hostess to bring you to your table. 

It is definitely worth the trip to NOLA just to visit this place. 

Enjoy!!

Loved everything about it. The atmosphere is very cool and the food was outrageous.
Started with the grilled shrimp small plate, delicious. I got the garden salad, due to diet restrictions, but it was one of the most delicious salads I've had, dressed perfectly. My mom got the green been smoked drum salad, the drum was smoked to perfection. Got a good balance of the smokiness and the fairly mild fish taste. We also shared the eggplant and shrimp dressing side. It seems there was more eggplant than shrimp but it was still good nonetheless. 
I love a good Arnold Palmer and this was without a doubt the best one I've ever had. Their homemade lemonade and fresh iced tea is the perfect combination on a beautiful warm day outside.

Cochon is one of the best restaurant experiences I've ever had. It sits comftrably inbetween casual and fine dining to where there isn't a dresscode but the waiters are highly trained and knowledgeable the food presentation is gorgious and there's the little things like silverware replacement after each course and a hot towel for your saucy rib fingers. Myself, my Dad and a friend decided to crush as much of the menu as we could. We all ordered something different and we spared no expense. We ordered enough food to feed a party double our size. We were in town for Jazz Fest and I had been studying the menu for months. It lived up to the hype. 


We started off with WOOD FIRED OYSTERS W/ CHILI GARLIC BUTTER and CRAWFISH PIE. These were the best oysters I've ever had. The chili garlic butter was insanely flavorful and rich. Crawfish pie is classic New Orleans and was also incredible! Next came the GRILLED SHRIMP W/ROASTED CABBAGE, PICKLED CAULIFLOWER & JALEPENO MAYO, SMOKED PORK RIBS W/ WATERMELON PICKLES and CORN CUSTARD W/SPRING ONION SABISE & CRAB SALAD. The shrimp dish was pretty different, the combined ingredients complimented each other very well. The same goes for the corn custard with crab salad. Very rich and unique and beautifully plated. But the highlight of the entire meal came with my ribs. Hands down best ribs I have ever had! The sauce was perfect! Incredible BBQ sauce, nice and spicey but not too spicey. My mouth is watering as I type this.

We ain't done yet! Finally came the final course. My father had the RABBIT AND DUMPLINGS with LIMA BEANS, I had the LOUISIANA COCHON W/ TURNIPS, CABBAGE & CRACKLINS with MACARONI AND CHEESE and my friend slowed it down a bit with FRIED ALLIGATOR W/ CHILI GARLIC MAYO and SMOTHERED GREENS. My Cochon was glorious! A giant lump of pork sat on a bed of cooked cabbage and broth surrounded by cracklins (AKA pork rinds) and sprinkled with tiny cubes of turnips. When you touch the cochon with your fork it crumbles in to juicy pulled pork. When you get a little bit of all of the items on your fork at once it is pure euphoria! Their signature dish is out of this world! The crunch of the cracklins really set it off. The rabbit and dumplings was delicious and my Dad loved it. Which was surprising because he's not one to try new things but I made him cause we're in New Orleans! The gator was great. Not so different from the gator I'm used to but the sauce set it apart from the usual ole gator tail. The sides were also all fantastic! Obviously you can't go wrong with Mac n cheese. It was incredible! I'm not a big lima  bean fan but even they were good. It was almost more of a split pea soup tasting caserole than just your regular lima bean.  Couldnt complain about The callerd greens either. 

There is a long list of restaurants I want to get to in the Crescent City. I have a lot to go yet but I'm not sure if this experience can be topped. Maybe it's cause its just right up my alley. I love it's food and style. There is also the Cochon Butcher next door. It's run by the same company and is more of a sandwich shop and bar... and butcher. It is also super awesome (check out my review) I can't wait to get back to NoLa and try some of the other exciting grub from both Cochon and Butcher. I need to move there so I can eat this incredible food more than just once a year. This city and it's food, music and culture is pure nirvana for me. Now I gotta find something to eat that will satisfy the hunger writing this review has caused. Damn you Yelp!

Best restaurant overall on the trip from apps to dessert. We went to a couple fine dining splurge for dinner and overall this was the best experience. Loved the oyster app. With chili butter as well as the grilled shrimp with roasted cabbage, Soft shell crab special salad was great as was my husband's shaved pork sandwich special. Butterscotch pudding and German chocolate cake homey and satisfying. The bread is great and warm and lovely for sopping up the chili butter. The strawberry pie is refreshing but not fresh strawberries in sight more of and ice cream pie with Graham cracker crust. Make a reservation or prepare to wait.

Ribs were tough to me.
Mac and cheese winner!!
Cucumbers salad with mint(way to vinegary for my taste)
Lima beans wonderful favor( more meat in this dish than beans)
The pork cheeks and the lightly roasted veggies salad with tarragon were the best part of my meal.  
Lovely space near the warehouse area.

Not only was the food fantastic here, the service was terrific. Even though it was packed, our server spent time with my girlfriend and me giving us his recommendations on food and drinks. We sat right near the kitchen and watched the chefs prepare some amazing looking meals. The biggest let down was not being able to try everything because it all looked so good.

I really enjoyed this restaurant! 6 girlfriends and I came out to New Orleans to celebrate a girlfriend's bachelorette party. Stopping by this place was such a good decision! We ate the oysters, the ribs, the gumbo, the collards, mac n' cheese, and fried alligator. It was ALL really delicious. A word to the wise, everything is a bit spicy. It feels like a constant buzz. It's a very light spiciness though. But if you don't like spicy, then this might not be your speed. Otherwise, this is an awesome way to spend a night out with your friends.

I had some high expectations. Saw it in travel channel. And some lists. Also just the food I had yesterday everything blew my mind. But the dishes here were pretty mediocre. Only thing different were the roasted oysters with their mayo base sauce. 

1- barefoot in the grass cocktail : the best part of my bf's meal
2- cucumber mint salad : extremely vinegary and spicy.. Only got vinegar lovers 
3- roasted oysters: good. I guess I'm not THAT Big of a ouster fan to have LOVED it. But the size of the oysters were massive easily the biggest oysters I've seen. 
4- fisherman fish: huge portion. Very bland. Just paprika sprinkled on top. With pickled onions as a side. If your into simply eats. Which I am. I enjoyed it. But the price was fancy dining prices. Which I don't think was worth it. 
5- pork cheeks: they were good. Super tender. The corn and scallions mix thing was more memorable than the actual meat. Portion is extremely small. Cause it's not a main entree 
6- Icecream flavor of the day : blueberry coconuts. Very subtle taste. Not too creamy. I liked it a lot. 

The complimentary bread was awesome. Soft butter! Yay! - don't you hate it when they give you hard butter and it's impossible to spread on your bread. Yeah. I hate that. 

Service was great

Interior reminds me a lot of cookshop NYC if you've been. Very laid back vibe. But every guy is still in button ups. 

Overall tho I wouldn't go back.

Right from the start the staff was rude. We showed up with 12 people and all I was told was that we may have trouble accommodating. If you sit at the table then you'll have to leave by one was the quote from the redheaded hostess. Then we had some special requests and the waiter Jesse was quite rude. He likes to roll his eyes at us for every request.I had to have the manager switch our server due to his very poor attitude. The food was good, but I would avoid this restaurant since the staff and waitstaff is obviously under trained and not used to dealing with special request.they made a very positive food experience into one where I regretted coming to this restaurant despite it's good reviews on yelp.

This highly recommended restaurant fell completely short of ALL expectations.  Let me preface this with the 45 minute wait for oysters and gumbo (my other appetizers took almost an hour).  The cochon was dry, the ham hock and beef short rib were overdone.  Mac and cheese was fine however nothing to rave about.  The food was mediocre, service sub par.  Our food runner had a stronger presence than my waiter.  The strong point of this restaurant was definitely the bar; cocktails were done nicely.  If anything,  come here for the chargrilled oysters.  Those were fabulous!!  
FOOD - 2 stars
SERVICE - 2 stars
BAR - 4 stars

Great food, terrible service. We had the rabbit and dumplings and the short ribs. The rabbit was outstanding - flavor, consistency, and aroma. Short ribs were good but slightly overdone. Still very good. Service was very poor. Our server ignored our table for very extended periods of time, she was no courteous at all, and our order was delayed without explanation. The manager later apologized but it made for a very poor experience. Still worth it for the food.

The food was phenomenal!  They were out of the crab cakes, so they brought us a tray of oysters on the house. Alligator with the sauce was outstanding. Management was great. I'd definitely recommend this restaurant to anyone. Also, it was walking distance from our hotel near Bourbon Street. Can't wait to go back.

I give the food 4 stars, but the service 3. 

This was my first stop on my New Orleans business trip and my coworker and I stopped in during a late lunch break. We were seated immediately, probably because it was about 2:30pm, Saturday. It took a long while before a server came to our table to go over the menu, then to come back again to take our order, but we ended up going with the fried alligator, rabbit and dumplings, and cochon. The fried alligator was great! It was smothered in a chili chipotle aioli that gave it great flavor! The bigger pieces were a little chewy, so I preferred the smaller bites. I tried a bite from my coworker's cochon dish and thought it was pretty good too! My rabbit and dumplings dish was almost like a chicken pot pie. Slightly heavy on the Rosemary and pepper, but the overload on carrots gave it some sweetness. It was good, but i don't know if I'd order it again, I'd want to try all their other things! After finishing our meal, it took us so long before we could get a server to get us the check. I think the manager noticed me constantly looking around for our two servers - who were both just chatting by the bar - so she went and grabbed them both and pointed to our table to signal that we needed them. I'm glad the manager noticed us, otherwise we probably would have waited 30 min before getting our check! If I'm back in the area with people that have never been to New Orleans, I'd probably take them back, but for myself, I'd rather try some other establishments.

This place will set you back, but it's worth it. They also deal well with groups, which we needed with 9 people.

They are very proud that they butcher the pig on site and use it all.

My adventurous wife has headcheese and other more normal cuts. I had ribs and Mac and cheese. Both were great. Bring friends so you can share.

I wanted so badly to give this place five stars because the food was absolutely amazing. However, our waiter was one of the rudest, snottiest little snobs that I have had the misfortune to come across as a diner. First of all, he practically ignored us, I assume either because we are a biracial couple or because we are young (both my fiance and I are 21.) However, that does not mean we weren't spending money or weren't worth his time! I had to lean in to hear what the chef's special was when he told the table next to us, as he never told us, and that's actually what we ended up ordering. He also did not bring us bread, and when I noticed all of the other tables received bread I had to ask a different waiter to bring some out. I then ordered an Angry Orchard apple ale and he spent the LONGEST time staring at my ID, then back at me, then holding it up to my face, when the ID picture looks just like me because it IS me. Frankly it was embarrassing and rude as hell. Then, after practically being ignored through our whole dinner, I ordered the chocolate cake and when I saw it had nuts in it, I told him I was unaware it had nuts in it and didn't want it as they make me ill, but would still pay for it. He rudely said, "Well, the menu says it's German chocolate cake, and German chocolate cake is known for having nuts and coconut in it." Excuse my ignorance, Sassypants. All that aside, the chef's special that we ordered that night was the pork shank with corn, snap peas, and chanterelle mushrooms in a lemon sauce and it was absolutely HEAVENLY. The pork just fell off the bone, tender and delectable. We also got alligator as an appetizer that was delicious. Overall, I wish I could say we had a good experience here but it was ruined by our waiter. Really disappointing, especially when we spent upwards of $100 for a meal for two.  If you're young or a mixed couple don't come here unless you want to have a waiter who needs a major attitude adjustment turn his nose up at you.

Just down the road from ww2 museum, I highly recommend Cochon.  Came here for lunch, ordered 5 small plates for the four of us.  Each one amazing.  Pay it a visit...you will thank me.  Revision...actually it was 6 plates..oh and 1 desert.  Sorry they have great drinks too.

We tried Saturday brunch at Cochon, and it was very good.  The stand-out was the fried livers with pepper jelly and the butterscotch pudding, and the Louisiana cochon (a pork dish) came in a close second.  We also tried the fried alligator, which was OK, but I think it was a little bit too drenched in the spicy aioli sauce.  Service was alright, but, during those peak hours, I really think they need more servers.

Overall, it was good but not my favorite brunch.

Food was amazing and service was wonderful! 

We got a few small plates instead of a big meal, it was perfect. The magnolia beer is really fun beer they serve. 

Must make reservations, unless you are okay with sitting at the bar or chief's table!

Cochon reminds me a lot of the restaurants I've been to in Chicago (namely The Publican, as they are both pork-centric). We went to Cochon on our last night in NOLA and decided to keep it light. Our server was very cool with us being lame and only ordering a few things. 

The beer/cocktail list was very impressive (I don't do wine so I couldn't tell you how that list was). There was a hefeweizen on the list that my husband had never tried (those are his favourite types of beer) and when he went to order it, our server was very frank and told him that he wouldn't like it. The fact that he was a hefe freak like my husband was pretty cool. Hubs opted for something else, Beir de Garde, maybe? I got this lemon ginger beer thing that was pretty outstanding.

We had the wood-fired oysters (heavenly) and the fried alligator (also good, albeit a bit chewy). We also split a strawberry pie which was also delicious. Personally, I prefer Cochon Butcher but this is a nice place to take a date. The decor was also pretty cool - like wooden beach furniture but indoors.

We were disappointed with our inattentive service and the meal. We waited 20 minutes past our reservation ( on a Tuesday night- not a weekend). When we were finally seated, it was 15-20 minutes before anyone showed up with menus. Another 15 minutes for water. Our waitress was indifferent when she finally showed up and didn't offer much help with the menu. Her service was the worst I have had in a long time. We ordered several small plates and gumbo but nothing to recommend. Same with entrees and sides. I would not return here but would instead go around the corner to Butcher- similar food by same owners but at lower prices in a fun setting.
And if you want a delicious meal with outstanding service, head to Peche, a block away.

This following review is set to the music of "Les Poissons" sung by the mad chef in Disney's The Little Mermaid:

     "Les cochons, les cochons,
     How I love les cochons!
     Love to chop and to serve little pigs.

     First I cut off their heads 
     Then I pull out their bones 
     Ah, mais oui, ca c'est 
     toujours delish!

     Les cochons, les cochons 
     Hee-hee-hee, haw-haw-haw 
     With the cleaver I hack them in two!

     I pull out what's inside 
     And I serve it up fried 
     God, I love little piggies, don't you...?!?"

We love Restaurant Cochon THAT MUCH, too...  

The sausage boudin balls were among the best things either of us has EVER eaten.  The charcuterie plate was very good.  The seasoned roast pork shoulder was outstanding.

Cochon was strongly recommended to us by a chef friend who studied in NOLA under Emeril.  He said "I would go to Cochon for breakfast, lunch and dinner, then get up tomorrow and do it all over again!"

Yea. That...

Worth the hype. Had the alligator starter (generous portion, delicious) and boucherie sampler (included pig face, rillettes, head cheese -- totally divine). Entrees were the rabbit (rich, with perfect dumplings), the namesake cochon (perfect) and a special pork chop (smoky flavorful, and reasonably priced, but tough -- not a highlight). We got seated here right away for lunch after seeing a tough line at Butcher around the corner. Service was impeccable.

This place was great! My fiance and I ate an early dinner there without a reservation. They sat us right away and we tried several dishes. Each one was awesome! The ribs with watermelon were perfect. I also thought that it was very deserving of the price as well. We ate at several different restaurants in the area and this one was the best! 
If and when we return... We will be coming back. Also the best part (I know it is weird, but I loved it...they gave us warm cloths to wipe off your fingers from the ribs. AWESOME!)
Suggestion from my fiance- more scotch options!!!

Great lunch started with the grilled shrimp with roasted cabbage,  pickled cauliflower and a hint of jalapeno, the contrast of the still warm shrimp and the room temperature cabbage and cauliflower with the spice of the jalapeno is a perfect match. My entree today was the fish special a still moist roasted drum fillet with fresh corn, soy beans and cherry tomato was excellent the corn and soy beans still al dente. The manager instead of sitting in an office is expediting the food so that everything is out in a timely manner, the staff is friendly and efficient giving the place a very relaxing atmosphere

We took a taxi from the French Quarter to this unassuming appearing restaurant.  The staff are pretty friendly. There is a warm wonderful aroma from the wood fire oven. Excellent bourbon selection with a very kind bar tender.  The gumbo (unfortunately riddled with scallions on top-I am not sure why chefs do that) was super delicious with its smokey flavor and viscous texture from the okra.  The fried alligator in a tangy sauce was very good. The boucherie was also very good.  The pork dish was delicious. My only criticism is the pork and the alligator were heavy on the sodium.  The butterscotch pudding was super good, super thick.

I came here a few years ago with my husband so if my memory serves me correct I belive it was a great experience. 

I remember it was walking distance from our hotel which was great, but it wasnt in an over populated area like the French Quarter. 

We tried the fried alligator bites. They were crunchy and good. I think the sauce was a garlic aoli sauce which was also great. 

What made our experience wonderful was the bartender. We sat at the bar because we didnt have a reservation for lunch  although i dont remember it being crowded. The bartender was so cool and friendly towards us. He actually offered us some homemade jalapeño tequilla to try which my husband loved. I dont like jalapeño but it did taste legitimately like jalapeño.  It was dope cause he pulled it out of a secret sash with no label or anything. Totally a house made concoction.

We had an awesome meal here outside last night. Friendly host and a great server who steered us in the right direction on the menu including some absurdly good wood fired oysters. Solid booze and great dessert as well!

So, the hubs and I had a somewhat random plan of attack for our culinary tour of NOLA this weekend. Which made it no surprise that our roundabout morning led us to Cochon. Pretty sure it was Bourdain that piqued our interest in this spot first and hubs' love of everything Meat, second. After the light sprinkle of rain and super long wait at Mother's sent us over to a yummy brewery in the Business District to ponder our journey of the day, a cool bartender there recommended Cochon while we were looking at Yelp for lunch...Thank you, Carrie, for saving us from our derailment...The fresh mint and pickled onion on the alligator tail...***sigh***
Sweet hot pepper jelly with the fried livers...
Corn and sugar snap peas on the pork cheeks...
The savory herbed wonder of the Rabbit and Dumplings sings...Hallelujah!! (Btw- doesn't hurt that the music playing is on Point. Think Terence Trent D'Arby Wishing Well). 
Not to mention the incredible "Delta Burke" bourbon cocktail that so perfectly accompanies every bite...if you don't visit Cochon while in New Orleans for a mouthful of orgasmic euphoria, you can't sit with us! Cochon, we are soulmates

Came here for lunch and we just had 2 small plates and a side and were completely stuffed. We ordered the crawfish pie, fried alligator and Mac & cheese casserole. All of it was amazing. The fried alligator was lightly breaded and tossed in a chili sauce but it wasn't too hot, reminded me of a Thai chili sauce. The crawfish pie was like having a thick gumbo in a perfectly fried pastie. The mac & cheese was so creamy and cheesy...SO DELICIOUS!!!
Oh my goodness, I am in love. The food was outstanding and ambiance is right there with it in an emerging neighborhood. I would highly recommend to anyone wanting the best of the best!

I was very happy with my meal at Cochon. The fried alligator and pork cheeks were superb. We were seated at the chef's counter which wasn't the most pleasant place to sit, but I didn't mind it. At the end of our meal, however, when we asked to split the check (for a table of 2), I was told that they don't split checks. I understand some restaurants do this for simplicity, but I didn't feel I was asking for much. Without putting up a fuss, they did end up splitting the check for me but it did rub me the wrong way.
Excellent dining experience. Delightful, creative food. Excellent service. Highly recommend to anyone visiting New Orleans. Look forward to returning!
Very good food. I liked the appetizers we got. The combinations were different but tasted good together.

recommend: oysters as I'm sure plenty of people recommend as well.  (Edit) Had dinner here last night and the service is awful. Our waiter Vince looks at us like we're an inconvenience. Hasn't checked in on us since he took our order. (Edit: he checked on us once when we were halfway through the entree.  Still not the same attentiveness he gave other tables.  The Cochon was saltier than I remembered and my boyfriend's short rib was also salty). I moved out of NOLA 3 years ago but I lived in the warehouse apartments across the street.  I ate here a number of times and used to take all my visiting friends here. Safe to say that I came here full of hope. Sadly the manager also hasn't checked on us either even when he was just sitting in the front when the rush died down. Our waiter spoke of specials to the table next to us but didn't share the wisdom with us. Oh wells I came here knowing what I wanted. Cochon and Fire roasted oysters. It saddens me that Vince, the manager, and the salty food ruined this experience. I feel I've been very patient during our hour and a half wait (even though we expected an hour originally we sat waiting knowing the food is worth the wait) and then to be greeted with a server who seemed like he lost the lottery when we sat down is pretty disheartening.  Also I had to ask for bread twice. The first time he said it was coming out of the oven and the second time I asked the server who brought the oysters.  She came right back with them. Vince didn't even care if we got the bread or not. Clearly he just wanted us to leave. Never planning on coming back. 

Thank you to the Cochon staff for reminding me that not everyone in Nola is nice and that  I think unhospitable people shouldn't be in the restaurant business.

The food was A-MAZING! We got the braised cheeks as an appetizer and it was sweet yet spicy. It was unlike anything I have ever tasted and the pork was so tender it just fell apart as you ate it. The rabbit and dumplings was amazing too. 

Seriously some of the best food I have ever tasted. Small portions but great food.
Worst I've got for my trip in New Orleans. The only good thing is the alligator tail is not too bad.

We had a gut-busting, delicious lunch here, though it was so rich we needed an afternoon nap to recover!

The braised pork cheeks were delicious, though we preferred the battered fried alligator with its delicious aioli for its more challenging texture and flavors. For entrees, we ordered the Louisiana cochon with turnips, cabbage, and cracklins, and the ham hock. Both were meaty, savory, and full of great flavors -- and the portion size was right.

Service was friendly and attentive, and this restaurant looks as if it would be comfortable in a lot of hip cities across the US -- but it feels right at home in New Orleans.

The Sommelier Daniel is incredible. 

The food is incredible. 

Walk. 
Drive. 
Cab. 
Whatever, just come here. 

Eat. 
Joke. 
Love it like I did!

I've been dying to come here and finally got my chance for a bachelor party, no reservations, on a Friday night. We drank and ate appetizers at the bar and then were seated outside. To start, the boudin was insanely good, best I've had. And the charcuterie board was quite delicious. For the mains we ordered short rib, rabbit and dumpling, smoked ham hock, and the cochon. I heard the short rib ruled; I tried the other 3 with the cochon my favorite and ham my least, although all were very good. Also had the crawfish pie and fried alligator and both were demolished, with a slight nod to the crawfish pie. Yes, I will return; we almost did the very next night!

Great lunch again, started with pickled shrimp with squash, radish and a roasted tomato sauce,  petfect on a warm day. Entree was an excellent pan seared drum with corn grits, wild mushroom and kale an excellent daily special.  Again service was very good and food fresh and perfectly prepared.

First of all the waitstaff was amazing; super friendly and very helpful. We were also allowed to sit on the patio with our dog, who got all the love in the world which was awesome. The gazpacho was decent, my husband had a pork appetizer I can't remember the name of, and that was also just ok. The Gulf Fish for dinner was outstanding; it's probably their most expensive item, but it was delicious and cooked to perfection. My husband had the catfish, which he said was just okay, but I think all in all it was a nice meal and experience. I guess my only issue were the prices; I didn't think our dinner should've cost over $100 but hey, that's just nit-picking (we didn't have any alcoholic drinks, either).

Best meal in N.O., by far. We had gulf fish, alligator, gumbo, smoked ham hock (!), and pork cheeks. Each better than the last. The ham hock was my personal favorite. super smoky. (And they dealt with our schedule malfunction without a hitch.) The real deal.

This place really is all that. 
The service was great, the food was fabulous and the atmosphere casual and inviting. 
We had the Boudin Balls, the Chargrilled Oysters, the Shrimp app, gumbo and the amazing fish served fisherman style. That was the real standout dish. 
I am looking forward to coming back again next time I am home.

Food was actually really good but service was horrible! The waitress didn't wait until everyone in our party ordered drinks before she walked away. She also dropped a plate of dirty silverware on one of the girls and didn't apologize and then said "we have no capability of splitting up the items into individual bills". Unfortunately would not eat here again which is disappointing because the food was good!

This place is great. Fantastic drinks, hey jack cocktail is very tasty and nice reasonably priced wines. We had jumbo and a cold soup sprcial to start and the drum fish special as a main.  The special was great and cheaper than most menu items!  What really made lunch special was Terrance, our waiter,  he made the specials come alive when he described them.

A foodie's bucketlist item. If you don't mind exchanging bad service for excellent food, you must come here. Once.

Food: 5 stars
Delicious flavors and manageable portions. The shrimp & eggplant dressing (a side) was delicious. When I first looked at the menu, I wasn't excited by any of the offerings. But everything we ordered was excellent.

Atmosphere: 5 stars
Chic, clean, crowded but not packed. The fire stove in the kitchen area, the dimly lit dining area, and the wooden furnishings made it feel like home.

Service: 1 star
Our waitress forgot to give us bread and was simply bizarre. After 45 minutes, we still had no food. When we calmly asked the waitress if it would be much longer, she snapped at us to chill out. Maybe she was having a bad moment, because she was overly sweet once our food was delivered.

So for Cochon, I had pretty high hopes. I was expecting excellent food, which for the the most part, was accurate, but the service was really appalling for a place with so much hype. 

The evening started out pretty well, the restaurant is situated on a corner and was buzzing with people when we got there. There seemed to be a long wait both inside and outside of the restaurant. I really liked the decor inside, good mood lighting and a fairly open kitchen area with a wood fire oven.

Once we were seated, we ordered water, which came really quickly. Other than that, it seemed like service took forever. Our waitress mostly ignored us after we asked questions about the menu items and seemed to mostly stay in a corner doing nothing. When we asked about the free bread, we had to ask someone else as we hadn't seen our waitress in about 20-25 min. It definitely was good bread when we tried it....but by that time, we were starving.

After we ordered, we basically waited another 40 min for our food. When we asked our waitress about it, she said, "guys guys calm down" and gave us quite a bit of attitude. 

The food: it was good, I ordered the oven-baked oysters with garlic butter, which many people raved about.  It was good, but not as amazing as I thought it was going to be, especially for $14. 

The shrimp & eggplant dressing was really really good, a little salty, but otherwise probably my favorite dish of the night. The mac and cheese was good too, but I'm not a big fan of cheese in general. 

I also ordered the eggplant and farro salad, which again was good but nothing extraordinary, I did really enjoy the grilled eggplant though.

The catfish dish was pretty good as well, I would recommend it if you came here.

Overall, the food was pretty good, but the service was awful, and I would give it between 2.5-3 stars. If we weren't starving by the time we got our food,  I would've given this place 4 stars.

Oh well, good atmosphere and company!

Excellent lunch Thursday,  started with fried alligator with chili garlic mayo that was perfect. They use the tenderloin an not tough the mayo has the perfect amount of spice so it doesn't kill your taste buds. For my entree i had rabbit and dumplings that was very good, the dumplings had a nice brown and a little crispy top from the broiler and the carrots and such were still al dente . Angie again did a great job serving always a pleasure to see her.

Delicious! Stopped in while traveling, this place is right down from the convention center and right around the corner from the Hilton Garden Inn. Traveling alone, I've no qualms about dining out alone, so I nabbed a seat at the bar where you get get full menu service.

I started with the "hey, Jack" a lovely concoction with a slightly sweet side and a bit of a kick. Just what I was looking for!

It was kind of late so I went for the grilled oysters and gumbo so as to not eat too heavy. I prefer shrimp gumbo but this chicken gumbo was delicious. Chicken and sausage was generous and it was filled of classic spices. It would be awesome if it had shrimp and crab instead. The oysters wet absolutely awesome. I would come back for these again and again, grilled with cheese and served hot over rock salt. I tilted them up and was begging for more. 

Sorry, I skipped dessert but several people at the bar were licking their plates clean! 

Atmosphere was a dressy casual vibe although you could easily walk in here in jeans or shorts.

Overall: definitely recommended!!

Man... those rabbit dumplings are no joke. I have no idea how they keep the dumplings from getting soggy in that rich and delicious sauce but they stay bready and soft. The flavors are really excellent.
I have to get the Boucherie Plate every time but I secretly just want a plate of that head cheese and whatever potted meat they're serving at the time. Also, I have a well-documented loathing of pickles but I have to admit, Cochon's homemade pickles are the perfect accouterments for the plate. I would have never tried them but my friend who feels the same way about pickles as I do (pickles are cucumbers soaked in evil!)  convinced me to try them.
My only critiques are that the tables are rather close together which always leads to an awkward ass in your face at some point. Also, the restaurant can be quite loud when busy as the acoustics aren't great. You know what though? I'll still go there any day of the week!

I will always take friends and family here from out of town because I know it will be a slam dunk every time. Always had excellent service and food here, never a let down. Great craft cocktails as well.

Solid lunch or dinner for a casual or upscale night out. Highly recommend!

So so good! Incredible New Orleans flavor, great local beer selection, and friendly service. We went for lunch and shared a variety of small plates (4 for 3 people was plenty). We got the oysters (best thing I ate in the whole trip), gumbo, alligator bites, and crawfish pie. Everything had a wonderful slightly spicy flavor (especially the alligator, which had a delicious creamy chili sauce), so just keep that in mind if you don't like spicy food. Must go! Even our local friends love it.

Just great food!!!

The oysters (i am admittedly a Yankee) were the best I've ever had!!!  We did 3 apps and 2 entrees and every dish blew us away.  Layout of the restaurant is stellar, simultaneously informal but upscale.  Picnic table-styled tableus amidst a more elegant interior.  Cocktails are exceptional too. 

The only reason this place gets 4 stars (and admittedly im service industry and nit-picking on what other people will prolly never notice) is due to the (presumed) shift manager with the big nose and glasses.  Younger guy.  Giving your servers heavy pours of wine to swirl and "try" is one thing.  Buying shots while taking a shot with servicd industry folks from another establishment is a red flag.  Letting your servers drink shots & beer under your nose at the bar expo station where customers can clearly see it is pretty dissapointing.  Given it was the end of the night, but it takes away from the feel of the establishment 

**DISCLAIMER**
Im from Ohio, where drinking laws/ideology  are drastically different!  Maybe this is how everyone in NO operates.  Still, im an out of towner, as many patrons in sure are, and its a cause for concern.  

Still, with my extensive critiquing done, this place is a must visit, cool spot outside the quarter!  GET THE OYSTERS!!  Kitchen kicks ass, vibe of the restaurant is great, hostesses went above and beyond.  Very impressed by this joint, and is a wonderful alternative to Emeril's!!

Must visit in NOLA

Best restaurant my wife and I have ever been to! We were here for 5 days and we decided to have dinner here every night! Great drinks and even more amazing food! This will be one of the things we miss most about leaving New Orleans, going back home to Santa Clara CA and oh how depressing life will be without this gem!!

Went with my wife and kids and was very pleased.  Ordered the alligator sausage, oysters, pepper dish and gumbo to start and all dishes were nicely flavored, loved the spices on the oysters.  For entrees we had the ham steak, beef rib, cochon, and rabbit.  Never had ham that good, pork incredible but would have liked more than one crackling, beef rib cooked to perfection and rabbit dish very nice.  All dishes had small but nice addition of some vegetables done very well.   Okra side dish was tasty and Mac and cheese was very good.  We Ended with butterscotch pudding and pineapple upside cake which were incredible.  Service was excellent and in my opinion just an overall great dining experience.

Wow this place did not disappoint and the atmosphere is trendy. Try the rabbit with dumplings, it has a kick of spice with aroma of thyme and celery. The presentation is rustic with a small cast iron pan. Also tasty was their wood fired oysters (I am sad a half order only had 5 )...the chili and mashed garlic on top are makes these irrestible. A good side to try are the creamy grits, however I recommend pairing the grits wit a faro salad since the grits with rabbit a dumplings will leave you so full. 

I will return next time in NOLA.

A unique twist on some traditional New Orleans flavored here. Pork themed restaurant so expect lost of meat including the best tender and flavorful BBQ pork cheeks finished with fried kale. They have some comfort veggie items as well like some Lima beans and macaroni and cheese baked with a crispy crust. If you're looking for a modern update to some good comfort good this is a must try. Beware of peak hours, come on the early side of lunch (like before 12:30) to avoid a wait.

Awesome place. Stopped in for lunch today and the food was awesome. Great oysters and boudin appetizer!! Was also very impressed with the crab salad, just wish the portion was bigger!! Always great food and good service. Definitely want to go back and try the rabbit dumplings!

I came in around 2:30pm and noticed that while not packed, the restaurant was maybe half full. The host kindly offered a table, the bar, or the chef's bar. I sat at the chef's bar, being a party of only one person and not intending to drink.

I ordered a lemonade, the okra and tomato stew as my starter, and two sides for my entree: the mac & cheese and lima beans. The lemonade was listed as homemade, but wasn't anything special. The okra and tomato stew was excellent with a lot of flavor! It was a special that day, so definitely try it if you have the chance. The kitchen also sent me an appetizer with crostini, sweet pickles, pickled beets, and a kind of meat aspic. This also was very tasty--a good balance of flavors. The mac & cheese  was a bigger portion than I expected, but was also flavorful and unique in that it had onions inside of the dish. The lima beans were rich and cooked well, though there seemed to more pork than beans in the dish! I also ordered the butterscotch pudding for dessert as recommended by the server, which was also perfect, because it wasn't too sweet, but also plenty rich. It came with a pecan cookie, which I thought was a nice touch.

As for the service, I understand that as a party of one that it's not a priority for the server to constantly check on me. However, I was a little disappointed that the server only asked how things were once the entire (3 course) meal. And I noticed that her section seemed to be full the entire time I was there, though about half of the restaurant was unoccupied--making her seem extremely busy and thus harder to get a hold of.

Further, the foodrunners brought my two entree dishes before my appetizers were cleared. (When I ordered I clarified that I wanted the appetizers as *starters* and then the side dishes as entrees.) This became a little overwhelming to have four plates in front of me. And no one offered to bring me a clean share plate--which I remedied by using one that came underneath one of the dishes. The bussers didn't ever clear away my dishes until I set them aside after a while of not using them. After finishing dessert, I ended up eying the manager to give me the check.

Overall, this seems like a very busy place, for good reason--the food is awesome. The service is okay, but not perfect. I think if you're alone you might be better off at the bar, which is a shame, because seeing the open kitchen was pretty cool.

Ok, heard a lot of great reviews about this place so I had to try it out.   

1st, when I travel, it is mostly with a bunch of people so being able to feed a group of people is important.    Cochon's staff were right on point.  In and at tables fast, waiter greeted you within 2 min of seating and away were going!!!

With a group we tried EVERYTHING!!!!  Beef and pork ribs, gator, rabbit, red fish, shrimp, gumbo, Mac and cheese, loaded grits, twice baked potatoes, and the oysters.   Oooooh myyyyyy. 

The food was amazing, good portions, flavorful, and yummy in my tummy!!!

Staff was great and knowledgable of the menu and very out going!!! 

I strongly recommend this place for dinner or lunch, large groups or small.  Prices are great and the food is banging.
The wood fire oyster is a must try!

BLUF:  Obvious recommendation for a must go place when people are in town.  This place never disappoints.

I have been here a few times but the most recent might have been the best.  My lady and I are trying to avoid glutten because we are trendy annoying yuppies.  The waiter humored us and walked us through all of our menu questions with grace.  We sat outside because inside is usually always crowded and you need a reservation.  Great staff and atmosphere so feel free to sit anywhere and be happy.

I got the Cochon with was pulled pork only lightly dusted in flower and fried.  It sat over some onions and maybe some other veggie but topped with a couple pieces of pickled peaches.  It was off the chain.  Huge huge fan.  

My lady got the short ribs which i beileve came with mushrooms and other veggies.  her's was great too.  

We wish we could have gotten cocktails because in the past they have been great.  

Whenever we suggest places for people to eat in NOLA we always throw out Cochon because we KNOW it will be a hit.
Soooooooo good. One of the best meals if my life! I would definitely recommend this restaurant. It is also very close to the WWII Museum and was easy to find.

Food here is very good, as most say in the ratings.  The prices are outrageous!!!  The $$ is deceptive...as the normal lunch/dinner portions are smaller than what most places give for appetizers. So for 3 people, two draft beers, the bill was over 20/each. EXTREMELY Disappointed !!!!

When I arrived I felt like I had arrived at a cattle trough...  The seating is plain hard and you are eating on top of each other.  Not a place to go if you are hoping to have intimate conversation.  Seating was quick because of our reservations, less than five minutes.  Must start with the oysters (***** stars) probably the best I have ever tasted.  Sad that there were only 6.  Try the gator bites if you are looking for a meat candy experience.(**** stats). A bit minty but well fried and lightly drizzled with just enough sauce that you could try their hot sauce on it or better yet dip it in the oyster sauce!!!

Whatever you do get the grits as a side (***** stars) unbelievable. The Mac and cheese is very cheddary and has a cheddar fish cracker aftertaste (**** stars) and the greens are perfectly cooked but not memorable (*** stars). Overall a excellent dining experience with a chic club/bar feel to it.  

Maybe at dinner it's a little more quite but for a late lunch it was what we were looking for.

For a party of two the best seating tends to be against the from of the house wall.  A bit close for comfort.

This restaurant was our top pic for the weekend and eight of us found it highly over rated. Food was good but the atmosphere was NOT. Our waitress was sarcastic and rude. We were over charged for drinks after waiting a LONG time for drinks. She was poor at her job and unapologetic. 

Locals told us it was hype. We should've listened and spent our evening with friends in a better restaurant.
Gumbo and coshon pork with pineapple upside down cake.  Wonderful place outside the tourist area. Excellent food and vibe.

We ordered catfish and short ribs. Excellent!
For a truly incredible experience, order the fish and ribs served on the side and pair the ribs with the catfish sauce, delicious! They have their own bakery on the 3rd floor so check out the desert list. Will definitely recommend to others.

I had a great lunch! I had the alligator appetizer, fresh fish, and the oyster and bacon sandwich. It was all very good; the oyster and bacon sandwich was my favorite. However, the waiter did not stop by our table throughout the meal to check on us and see if we needed anything or refills. He also took a while whenever doing something like taking care of our check. The food was amazing but the service was slow; but worth a stop if you like good seafood.

I loved everything about Cochon . The name (French for pork,  and also their signature dish), the atmosphere(relaxed,  yet cool), and most importantly the food! 

Alligator bites were nice and tender and the accompanying Chipotle mayo had just enough of a quick to keep things interesting. Boudin was sweet and melty. Cucumber salad brought the acidity and freshness missing in so many meals this side of the Atlantic. 

The standout dish though? The rib. They were SO GOOD!! Melt-in-the-mouth, sticky without being sickly,  and that pickled watermelon on top 

I'm not sure when I'll be back in New Orleans,  but next time I am,  I'll definitely put a return trip to Cochon at the very top of my to-do list!

Two words...pork perfection.  Absolutely one of the best restaurants I've ever eaten in AND it had such a laid back chill vibe to compared to the usual high end hipster snootiness you find at typical places with a well known chef.  Came with a group of 6 on a busy Friday night.  Reservation was for 7:45, we got there early and were able to enjoy a cocktail at the bar prior to being seated.  The cocktails were well made and balanced and tasty.  We split a bunch of small plates, the fired boudin...a delicious ball of breaded well seasoned loose boudin sausage set off by the acid from the pickled peppers.  The pork cheeks were melt in your mouth tender and sublime.  My buddy said the smoked ham hock dish was fantastic.  Everyone in our group cleaned the plates.  We split greens, mac and cheese and grits.  Sounds like simple southern fair but all was done with great attention to detail and the shining example of what soul cooking should be.  My entree was the Louisiana cochon.  A fantastically cooked piece of pork.  Nothing over worked or ridiculous, just a high quality piece of pork cooked perfectly.  The meat was laying on a bed of braised turnips and cabbage in a nice vinegar sauce that cut through the richness of the pork.  And oh yeah...perfect cracklins to top off the whole deal.  Butterscotch pudding was rich and flavorful and the bourbon they suggested to go with it just worked to end the meal.  Our server was excellent, attentive, knowledgeable, fun but not overbearing or intrusive.  Just a fantastic experience and restaurant.

Well haven't been there in a few years. Went tonite service sucks and food to salty. Shrimp and eggplant dressing was to salty. I'm not to happy with tonight. Will go some where else next time. Not worth it to me. To many other good places to eat in the city better then this place

After eating here I can see why this place is on many best 10 lists. The oysters are fantastic, fried alligator also. Rabbit and dumplings was equal  to or better than the many other rabbit dishes I've had around the world (France, Italy, Australia, at home many many times - sorry Mum) and the fish main also great.  There was a 40 minute wait for a table but we were able to eat at the bar without the wait. Seats were hard but we had a good view of other dishes and chatted to the New York based Italian couple sitting next to us who had a bunch of dishes different to ours who concurred with our sentiments. Service was great. Def go here at least once if in NOLA?
Great food and service.  Dont miss the ham hock and the butterscotch pudding

This place is stupid delicious. I love the fried alligator with the garlic aioli and basil... but so does everyone else. The same sentiment applies with the oysters. The rabbit and dumplings dish was so comforting and rich. I wasn't super in love with the ham hock with the field peas and chanterelles, but it was still very good. I am not a lover of ham hock though, but I felt like I needed to order something really piggy at Cochon because ... Cochon. The pork cheeks were really tender, but it wasn't super memorable as others have suggested. It was good, but it also just tasted like a roast. It was also a touch salty. The grits were amazeballs and soooooo creamy, and I would probably marry the German chocolate cake with chocolate ganache.
