Oh, and everything is even better if you start the meal with a sazerac or two!

We ate here with the family when passing through town. I will admit this is not the greatest place for kids but sometimes who really cares?  

We had about 6 plates in a tapas kind of fashion. I can not really say anything that has not been said in 1600 reviews but everything was over the top good.   Our waitress was extremely slammed and managed to give us perfect service. 

I have another dozen things on the menu to try the next time we visit.

Cochon was one of my favorite dining experiences during our trip to New Orleans. I didn't realize we were in good company (i.e. Anthony Bourdain had eaten here before until after the fact) but even not knowing that, Cochon was a delicious experience. 

It's a small restaurant so reservations are highly recommended. This particular night, it was very busy so again recommendations are a plus. They serve things small plates style which makes it a good place for sharing and for groups. When we arrived, we were greeted and seated immediately because of our reservation. We decided to get alligator bites to share (we figured we should try them since we were in New Orleans). We then ordered drinks and our food. I can tell you what I ordered, I ordered mac and cheese to share with my sister and chicken and andouille sausage gumbo as well as a cocktail called Barefoot in the Grass. While we waited, our server brought out warm fresh bread for us which was delicious. Then our drinks came; whoever was working bar that night was on point. My drink tasted so smooth and I could not taste the alcohol which is a sign of a well made drink in my opinion. Especially considering that this drink had gin and I couldn't taste it? Well done. 

Then the food came: the alligator bites were tasty and reminded me a lot of calamari. The gumbo was a good size portion and delicious. Just the right amount of spices and flavor for me. But the mac and cheese was the star of my meal. It was so good! I love a good mac and cheese and this was amazing. Creamy, baked to perfection, just awesome. 

Though they were busy, our waiter was attentive and we didn't feel neglected. We didn't feel rushed either which I appreciated. They are strict about splitting checks (they only allow up to for payments) so plan accordingly. Overall an awesome dining experience and one I highly recommend trying when going to New Orleans.

Stopped on our way to the WWII Museum for lunch.  We had an enjoyable dining experience.  The atmosphere is fantastic as we enjoyed listening to some Soundgarden, Nirvana and other grunge artists playing through the speakers.  Waiters were very friendly and knowledgeable.  We shared the alligator appetizer which was delicious.  The Pork Chops were seasoned just right and melted in your mouth.  A must stop for anyone in NOLA.

Wow, wow, wow! Loved it so much! I took my wife and 4 kids on a trip through town and we all absolutely loved it! We ordered 9 different items and ate family style. Everything from the baloney to the alligator was absolutely amazing. My wife, a true cheese fanatic said that the Mac and cheese was the best she had ever had! Well done! We will be back:)
Was here during the NOLA Jazz Fest and loved it! Food & service were fantastic! Fresh ingredients, innovative and delicious! Portions were a good size and priced well! A must!

After seeing these great reviews, I had to give this place a try. My family was in New Orleans for a day, so we stopped by. The things I ordered were all highly recommended by Yelp.

They said the wait would be almost 2 hours. Thankfully it was less, more like 1 hour. Still really long, though, for what we got. I'll start by saying the alligator bites were our favorite. Unique with great seasoning and sauce. Definitely recommended. The rest? Well..

The oysters were pretty good, but the taste was nothing super special in my opinion. Very juicy. The rabbit stew was as expected, hot and thick but not bursting with any flavor in particular. Rather bland comfort food. Pork cheeks had great texture but also not strong on taste. The Louisiana cochun was too similar to the pork cheeks.

Everything was overpriced in my opinion, as I've had much better tasting and better-for-you food at all sorts of cheaper restaurants. Not worth the wait. Although I saw an order of mac and cheese go by... wish we ordered that instead of the fancy stuff.

Great lunch, again,  started with new shrimp dish the shrimp are still warm and accented with peas,not from a can, julienned ham and shrimp broth. Main course was one of the specials seared pork tenderloin with saurkraut, potatoes and pork jus all were excellent and fresh as usual service was very good as always .

Definitely overhyped to be considered a top spot in New Orleans.  I tried a little bit of everything and nothing impressed and had quite a hefty bill to pay.  I had the crawfish pie and pot pie and definitely had better elsewhere.  Not worth the walk from canal or poydras...

Believe the hype. This place is everything I heard it would be and more. My table of 6 tried almost everything on the menu and nothing disappointed. 

We had the fried alligator, wood-fired oysters with chili sauce, ham hock, the Cochon, meat pie, braised pork cheeks, pork ribs, gumbo, rabbit stew, lima beans, macaroni & cheese, grits, collard greens. Everything was expertly prepared. The service was exceptional and attentive. Our waiter (I think his name was Wyatt) was funny and knowledgeable and engaging. Even the music was outstanding. It was a fun mix of 90s R&B and hip-hop. It was such a fun place. Even the decor was light & airy and welcoming. It was very refreshing for a place with such a high-brow menu has such a down-to-earth vibe to it. It was a great combination!  I highly recommend it!!!
The wood grilled oysters are life changing. Great place.

Great alternative to the Acme Oyster House, if not better and without the wait. I ended up at Cochon because the line for Acme was outrageous and I pulled this place up on Yelp as an alternative. The oysters were easily some of the best I've ever had. We ordered the wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter and they were absolutely delicious and full of flavor. The oyster & bacon sandwich was also really tasty and was big enough to split. The rabbit & dumplings is another great dish, the rabbit was incredibly tender and truly complimented the light dumplings. They also have a unique cocktail menu and a full bar, perfect for sitting at while you wait for your table and far better than standing outside in a long line at Acme.

My friend and I ordered the Oven Roasted Gulf Fish (Red fish) and the beef short ribs. Both dishes were delicious. The fish was fresh and the beef was very tender. The dishes was well thought out, every ingredient amplified the flavor of the fish and beef. It was so good, I almost cried.

Wonderful meal! We were going to try to go to their sister restaurant and visit the butcher but due to the heat walked in here. Best decision ever! I loved the chicken liver with pepper jelly on toast, but lets be real the wood oven oysters with chili oil and garlic were hands down out of this world.

Every week I go and every week I say it can't get any better but it does. Started with the Crab Salad with Corn custard, radish and fresh dill a variation of what I had the first time different but essentially the same and just as good, this is something they do a lot so when you return weekly like I do you can have something you had before but the presentation and some minute changes make a dish basically the same but different. My entree was a fantastic grilled Flank Steak with real fried potatoes and grilled red onion, pear tomatoes that were then tossed with fresh Basil. As usual everything is fresh and service is great.

Cochon is a very good restaurant.  While in NOLA we had the opportunity to dine at Peche, Cochon, and Cochon Butcher.  We liked them all.

The most memorable dishes were the Rabbit and Dumplings and the Fire Roasted Oysters with Chili Aioli on it.

The Rabbit and Dumplings were very savory.  It was comforting and had great flavor.  The dumplings were flavorful and had a great texture.  It kind of taste like grandma's one from the Dirty South!

The oyster had a nice smokey flavor and were cooked perfectly.  

Overall this is a nice place to go.  We enjoyed Peche more, but this place is solid!

We made a reservation, which I recommend. We split the wood fired oysters. They were decent, I'm not huge on oysters but I ate them. My husband enjoyed them and he isn't a huge fan oysters either, but got them because of so many good reviews. We split the beef rib. It was falling apart with the touch of a fork, just perfect. We also got the Mac & cheese. It was amazing. We were happy with our selections and would go back. I highly recommend this place.

Hands down, a great find! If you want to eat at the restaurant make a reservation fast!! Behind the actual restaurant is their Boucher shop where you can also get food. I recommend taking the time to dine in. Great atmosphere and food. Try the Mac N Cheese for a side dish! :)

Food is great, staff is great (I sat at the bar, was served by Myles) drinks are great, desserts are great. Made it a point to come here after being recommended by a true southerner. Not pricey unless you're ordering massive amounts of entrees and drinks . I'm an apps and drinks kinda girl so if you're in town make it a point to stop here.
FYI- new to this pic taking on yelp so it didn't post but if you're a fan of sweets, for the love of God get the butterscotch pudding!
Food was very good. Alligator appetizer was the best item. Somewhat small portions.

Beautiful atmosphere, great food, and a cool location. Came here on a recent visit to New Orleans. My husband ordered the special that evening, which was a slow cooked pork neck. It was delicious and absolutely full of flavor tender and soft. I didn't have a very big appetite so I just had a side salad and an order of alligator.  It came with a sauce that had mixed reviews from our table.  I liked it, others didn't. Service was good, and I am very strongly likely to return here on my next trip to New Orleans.

We saved this place for our last night in NOLA since we had heard such great reviews from people we know and on-line. What a disappointment! The food was nothing special. Our server was nice, but totally stoned. The only thing we liked were the pan-seared shrimp. The oysters were ok, but we left considerable amounts of both the fish and the signature cochon dishes on our plates. No one asked why. On a positive note, the wine list was pretty good. Definitely over-rated and overpriced.

As first time visitors to the city, my aunt and I decided to give Cochon a try after hearing and seeing good things. I had the Louisiana cochon, and she had the gumbo. We shared the fried livers appetizer, and for dessert, the pineapple upside down cake. Not being used to Cajun/Creole cuisine, I think my aunt's gumbo was a little on the salty side for her but she enjoyed the flavors. In fact, we both enjoyed how each dish was distinct in flavor, and texture. The cracklings on the cochon with the cabbage added interest and variety to the dish, and we both loved the pineapple upside down cake, a great balance of sweetness, tart, and lightness.

This place is definitely worth a try. Even just for how the dishes are all prepared in different ways that isn't stuffy, or unapproachable. Thanks for a good meal!

Food is a solid 4.  Service from our lady was a 1, I'll round that up tho as the other dudes were legit and kind of filled in for her after a little while.  I would try it again and hope for better staff, but it's hard rating this as a 3 so we're calling it a 2..Service makes or breaks and while the good was awesome, she just left a bad impression..

(((After dining elsewhere in NOLA the same week I cannot reason returning... The service was on such an opposite end of the spectrum compared to every other spot we tried..)))

Service left something to be desired for sure, as we didn't get any explanation of specials, the menu, etc.. Nor were we really allowed to drink to the extent we'd hoped which is just sad...

First round of drinks very slow to arrive(like 20 minutes slow...), finally said something what was a few moments before our first course arrived and received the drinks.  Our waitress was totally Mia all night and while it was busy at 8pm when we got there, her lack of interest showed.

Other wait staff helping her were awesome, but man talk about resting b@&$) face.. Maybe we did something wrong, wait.. No we didn't...

Fried alligator and crab salad, both were awesome.  2nd drink ordered, which took another 18 minutes. Apology was offered at least this time and drink compd by her male counterpart.

Mains arrive, rabbit and dumplings and beef short rib, both delicious.  Wife not at table at first, so he held hers in the kitchen till she returned.  Homegirl returns to offer wife a second drink as she's finishing tho, shitty timing... 5, 10 minutes sooner would have been more appropriate and she would have had another drink... As one would enjoy while they start their main, but alas it wasn't meant to be.

Finally, we had the fried banana split to finish which was delicious.  All around a good experience with the food, but her service or lack there of was totally abysmal..

So to sum it up, food was awesome, but the service complete crap.  Pretty pathetic and quite a disappointment given the reviews..

Neat place, stopped in there to have a beer and some dinner around 5. Next time I will wait and how hen I am in a cocktails kind of mood. They looked incredible. We sat @ the bar and the bartenders were very knowledgeable about the product and friendly. The fried alligator I felt was a little tough (but it is gator) their boudin balls and Mac n cheese do not disappoint .

Favorite thing was the ambience and the 90's R&B playing that I hadn't heard in a while. 

Negative.... Bar stools were not comfortable.

From the oysters to the actual Cochon, the bold flavor blew us away! What a meal
Our boy also enjoyed it - we were glad to have a cool place with great food that we could also bring him.

This was the restaurant that provided me the best meal during my last trip to NOLA. Unbelievable. Just speechless on how good this place was. Only ordered from the small plates, but it was enough to fill me up. Firstly, the drink selection was impeccable. The salad arugula salad with blueberries, fresh cheese & cornbread croutons was the perfect summer blend and was light and refreshing.The fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise was the most notable appetizer and was phenomenal, perfectly spicy. The pan roasted gulf shrimp with country ham, english peas and tarragon was incredibly fresh and delicious. Can't wait to come back.

If you go to one restaurant in New Orleans, make Cochon the one. It was by far my favorite restaurant. And that's saying something when you're there for 6 days and eating out for every meal. 

I would recommend choosing one or two appetizers depending on the group and 4 to 6 appetizers and sides. They will give you such a well rounded tasting of the food. 

The rabbit with dumplings was to die for. So delicious. Their Mac and Cheese is something worth coming back for. The dressing was something totally new to me, but essentially it's cornbread with every delicious Cajun ingredient you can imagine. 

Finally, the bar provided a wonderful selection
of craft beer and cocktails. Personally I find the Old Fashioned to be tasty enough to order twice.
The rabbit and dumplings are really delicious. It's one of those dishes that contain subtle hints of magic flavors that are hard to name.. Complex but home cooked

Mmmmm.  Whilst the menu is quite limited, we were able to find interesting and delicious choices - the ham hock is sinfully unctuous, and the crab salad small but beautifully composed and flavorful.  Sides of greens and cucumber salad were tasty, and my husband devoured the pineapple upside down cake in about 10 seconds.  Service was fair - a bit disconnected until it came time for the check.  Still - one of our better restaurant choices in NOLA.

Eclectic menu and it's really, really good. Pork cheeks were flavorful and brought to a whole other level thanks to the garnish. Gumbo was impactful with the right amount of spice. Paired that with the spicy Monstre cocktail and it was perfect. Chose to follow with the lemon wheat. Now I am full, happy, and conflicted on whether or not I try someplace new with my next day in NoLa or come back here, lol. Highly recommend. Inviting atmosphere and staff had great suggestions.
The food was great. I tried alligator meat for the first time and I'm so glad I tried this! And the line was long, so you should make reservations or go early! And everyone was so nice :)

This place is very good, no doubt. However, the hype does not live up to the reality. Oyster app was good, not brilliant. Rib app was good, not brilliant, braised short ribs were good, not brilliant, collard greens were good, not brilliant...

I think that to entry level foodies this will be a great experience but when you get down to the pure science and art of cuisine this place is good, not brilliant.

With that said, I certainly recommend it. There is almost nothing that will fall flat (except maybe the fried alligator; fast food quality).

Cochin Butcher is a much better, albeit far more casual, incarnation of the company's moniker.

I was pretty excited to go here, and we ended up ordering the Louisiana Cochon, gumbo and butterscotch pudding to share. 

Louisiana Cochon - the meat was incredibly tender and flavorful, but what it was cooked in, particularly the peaches? Not as much 

Gumbo - my least favorite of the gumbos that we had on this trip, it had an incredibly strong, one-dimensional flavor, that tasted like... bbq sauce. 

Butterscotch pudding - the highlight of our meal; it was delicious, it was silky smooth. It was definitely too much for one person, but between the three of us, it was the perfect amount. so decadent. if you go here, do not miss this!

If you're in the city and you're looking for a sit down seafood place, this is a must try. Its one of the most tasty meals I've ever had. Our group got oysters, rabbit dumplings, and these fried alligator balls. The oysters tasted so fresh and this is coming from someone who doesn't really enjoy oysters much. The rabbit dumplings had spectacular flavor with the soup broth. My favorite part of the dinner was the alligator. It tasted exactly like chicken. The texture, the flavor, the scent was just like chicken. They cooked it perfectly as most places can overcook alligator and make it tough and dry.

I was first here shortly after it opened.  I was not eating red meat (Don't eat it now either) but this place was fantastic.  I had the alligator and crab cakes.  Fantastic.

A year ago, I went here with the wife - she loved it.  We also fell in love with their sister operation next door, The Butcher.... (More on them and the duck pastrami - which is to die for - in a review on The Butcher).

We tend to sit at the bar, and while it is a small one, the service is outstanding.

I will be back every time we visit NOLA.

Went here specifically to try their boudin - chef Chris Cosentino of Incanto fame in SF says it is the best he has ever had. We had a late afternoon pork-fest snack of the fried boudin, the boucherie platter which is their charcuterie plate of house made cured meats and pate, and the shaved pig salad. All of the various pork products are of high quality and super tasty. The boudin was creamy and flavorful. There are about a dozen craft beers on the menu from LA which pair well with the menu. FYI, all of the cold cuts and sausages can be purchased next door at the Cochon Butcher.

Alright, so as it turns out most of my NOLA places get 5 starts because the food in New Orleans is SO. DAMN. GOOD. But, believe me when I say, Cochon is my favorite of all the restaurants I went to there. It's menu is filled with heavenly pork goodness that would challenge a vegetarian to resist. EVERYTHING was great. The Louisiana Cochon might have changed my life, and the macaroni and cheese casserole keeps me awake at night thinking about it way out here in California, where I can't get it whenever I want. I miss you Cochon :.(

I couldn't wait to finally get a reservation to go here! Sadly I was disappointed... :(

We got the Ham hock with golden rice, field peas and pickled peppers! The ham hock was great, but the rice and peas, yuck! It tasted like there was a bunch of salt dumped in it. 

We also ordered the fried liver, which I normally don't eat fried food. It was pretty good. 

We ordered the boucherie plate which had Hog Head cheese which was awful, also had salami, mortedella which was less them paper thin. 

Not a place for someone that eats low carb and doesn't eat fried food. Highly over rated.

Place is crowded, seats are too close together and very loud music. 

I felt that the chef was not very good at "marrying" the flavors.

Excellent. Artisan menu with rather fanciful presentations. Bar seating at the kitchen too so you can watch. Their wine pour are a little skimpy and the staff is not quite as attentive as they could be. ( don't wait to get the check if you have someplace to be)

I've been to NOLA many times, and this is the first time I've discovered Cochon. Seriously, this is the best food I've ever had. Our table shared items from about half of the menu, and everything was amazing. My main dish was the Louisiana Cochon, and I can't stop craving all of the different flavors. Casual and not too expensive, which I also love. My sincere compliments to the chef(s). Everyone should try this place!!

Four stars for the food. It was tasty, but wasn't outstanding by any means. My favorite dish was probably the fried boudin (we ordered 7 dishes based on yelp recommendations). 

What brings it down a star was the service. Was very awkward having two servers that were not on the same page...they didn't have utensils ready and came by to take multiple drink orders. The most awkward situatiin was when one of them came by to signal us to leave when the other server never gave me my credit card back. 

Was very excited to dine here but left with unmet expectations.

Stopped in for lunch here after receiving several recommendations from different people. When we got there it was fairly empty, but by the time our food arrived, the place was packed! On a Tuesday. Good feelings before I even took a bite! I ordered the catfish courtbouillon and it was fabulous!! My colleague had the oyster bacon sandwich, which she was also thrilled with. The ambience was nice. No complaints with the service. Actually just thinking about that catfish is making me want to go back! Something tells me nothing on this menu would disappoint.

After leaving the WWII museum, my parents and I wanted to grab a quick bite to eat. We stumbled upon this place and ran on in. 

The food was pretty average, especially for the price. Three of us bought the small plates only and the bill was still $100. My dad got the alligator and said it was good, but my mom struck out with the ribs and watermelon pickle, while I didn't do any better with the boucherie. We had them keep the bread coming because we tried to fill up on that-so on that note, the service was good. The guy was very friendly and everyone seemed to be checking in on us pretty regularly. 

I probably wouldn't come back here, but my parentals would. But I won't say give it a shot, but they might.

This place is a must go while in New Orleans!  I don't typically give 5 stars but this place is well deserved of 5 stars..  The setting is a trending hip place and crowd in the quickly rising warehouse district.  Small bar but very good drinks! Especially the Old Fashions.  Get one!!  

Started off with the heirloom tomato salad.  At least 4/5 different types of tomatoes that were all outstanding .  A must!!  For my app I tried the oysters that were cooked in a nice chili spicy chili sauce.  Not over powering just right.  Outstanding!

My main course was the rabbit with dumplings.  WOW!!  Comes out in a little cast iron skillet with the dumplings baked on top.  Exceeded my expectations!  

I will return when I come back to the Big Easy!!

Really really cool spot and the food is outstanding . Sat at the bar because it was soooo busy and we called too late to get a reservation. Had a bunch of small plates and our favorites were the chicken livers and the pork ribs . Staff are so friendly and helpful in making selections . And it is noisy but if you can hear it listen to the soundtrack playing in the background .. Amazing !
Very short, off the wall menu. Over rated and over priced. We were looking for Cajun, this is definitely not traditional Cajun.

If you are a pork lover, this is Nirvana.  While in NOLA I had lunch there twice.  Once in the dining room and the next day at the butcher shop next door.  Food at both places was excellent. Dining room was a little noisy.  My only complaint was that my waiter in the dining room had dirty hands and fingernails.  Very unappetizing.

I regret that I have only been to Cochon once. I have, after all, been in the state more than once, and so where is my excuse? Well, not knowing, perhaps, though it shall be remedied in the future.

I like familiar things at times, and fancy things as well, adventure and reliability both in full measure. The menu at Cochon offered me both [with the added bonus that, as a party of five, we got to try most everything we could have wanted] and I enjoyed every bite. I even liked the head cheese, which I admit to having been rather wary of, initially. Such a spot is not without its flaws, of course. The place was incredibly crowded, and I might argue there wasn't really enough room for the entire party at our table, nor for everything we ordered, though the waiters did a fine job of trading things in and out as we finished dishes and more arrived. Overall, however, the meal was quite pleasant, and a splendid way to cap out a day to remember.

STUPID GOOD. 
My friend and I arrived and decided to share five small plates. They started us with the wood-fired oysters and fried blue crab claws. Delicious. 
We had our doubts that it would be possible for the next three dishes for live to the high bar set by the first two. WE WERE WRONG. The alligator was awesome. The tomato braised pork cheeks were some of the most tender & flavorful meat that I've ever sampled. The fried liver (and I usually don't like liver) was a so-close second. 
If you're in New Orleans don't miss this spot. Super close to the WW2 museum.

Friend and I shared a few plates of food and they were all pretty good. This restaurant is very meat heavy and the food was a tad too heavy for the hot weather we were experiencing during our trip. Yes, I know summer in NOLA is expected to be hot! Food was a little heavy with the heat we were experiencing but we enjoyed ourselves nonetheless. We had the tomato braised pork cheeks, which were super tender and had tons of flavor. The Louisiana cochon with cabbage was good but my favorite part of this dish was the cabbage! I'm not a huge cabbage fan so you can imagine how great the cabbage had to be in order for me to like it! We also tried the smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickle. Pickle was delicious and went very well with the ribs. I would say the ribs was my favorite dish of the three!

Oh the glorious gluttony! Oh me, oh my, you haven't truly feasted until you venture to New Orleans and venture into Cochon!

We arrived there on a Friday shortly before 5pm and there were only a handful of patrons dining (everyone was either rushing from work to get home or stuck in traffic trying to leave town). With more than ample seating, reservations were not needed and we were seated immediately in a booth. (Also, casual attire was perfectly fine despite the upscale ambiance. I love dining in this area because of the more relaxed dress codes at many dining establishments.)

Our friendly, attentive server took our orders and then brought a bucket of complimentary mini golden, buttery, toasted, soft, and delectable dinner rolls. For appetizers, wood-fired oysters drenched in chili garlic butter rocked my world! Seriously, the perfectly roasted oysters were meant to be eaten slowly so that each bite could be savored. Those buttery dinner rolls were put to good use as I soaked up every drop of the chili garlic butter. The next appetizer was the fried blue crab claws in lemon brown butter. The seasoned breading + fresh crab claws + lemon brown butter was a great medley of texture and flavor. I've had had crab claw appetizers countless times but never have they been uniquely fried as these were. Cochon has thoroughly spoiled me with their fried crab claw appetizer. Try them and your world will never be the same.

Obviously, when dining at Cochon, you order cochon! For the entree, we decided to share the Louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklins, and pickled peaches, along with a side of the twice-baked stuffed potato. Again, the chefs have created an excellent dish with the harmonious medley of textures and flavors. The cochon was crispy on the outside, but tender, tasty and moist on the inside. The cochon was served atop a cabbage-pickled peach mixture that paired well with the meat. The delicious twice-baked stuffed potato was comfort food, which enhanced the flavorful cochon. For the crunch factor, the cracklins laid proudly on top of the cochon, beckoning you to come in closer for a bite. That crunch factor sealed the deal for our meal!

With it being another hot summer day, we chose the coconut angel food cake, with lemon peach sorbet and coconut macaroon. The cake was fluffy and not too sweet and paired well with the fruity sorbet. The coconut flavor was subtle and not overwhelming. After such a heavy meal, this light dessert was quite refreshingly welcomed by our palates.

When in NOLA, Cochon is definitely a must (and over 1900 reviews to prove it)! I love how incredibly talented the chefs are at Cochon and their use of fresh, seasonal ingredients in their perfectly executed dishes. Hurry up and get started on your culinary dining adventure at Cochon because of their stellar service and fantabulously incredi-mazing food!
Tried the boudin balls, oysters and fried alligator for appetizers along with pulled pork sandwich ham hock and pork ribs main course everything was amazingly delicious.
Fun vibe and helpful servers.  Grilled oysters were wonderful ad was the short rib.  It had a wonderful broth with a few peanuts as well.  The couchon signature dish and crab claws were a bit salty.

Our first visit to Cochon was shortly after its opening. We were floored with the simplicity and the complexity wrapped into most every dish. These seemed like hometown recipes. The presentation however is far from the food mom made. That is what sets Cochon apart from the food served at thousands of family tables across America.

Since opening, we have returned multiple times and we have been satisfied in equal measure. This visit we tried to determine if we've ever ordered the same thing twice. We can't honestly remember doing so.  The reason is the ever-increasing quality we always expect from the folks at Cochon. Boy, we like this place!

My husband and I had lunch at Cochon with another couple yesterday, and it was excellent. We got the wood-fired oysters, the alligator and the pork cheeks as appetizers, and each was better than the last. The food was a little heavy for August in New Orleans but it was worth it. The service was average, but the food and cocktails were superior.

Solid 4 out of 5. 

We had an amazing food tour through NOLA over a 4 day weekend and Cochon was the final stop. Compared to the other locations we visited this was probably the least successful all around but did serve me one of my favorite dishes. That fact and the good service and affordable prices are what earned it the 4th star. 

We tried the alligator and gulf shrimp appetizers. I'm not sure why everyone was raving about the alligator, yes the sauce is tasty but just like any other time I've had alligator it's a tough and chewy and sometimes overwhelmingly fishy meal so I honestly would skip it. The shrimp was also just ok for our tasting but in their defense we had eaten at commanders palace the night before and the cookery there is 2nd to none. 

With that being said you absolutely have to get the Louisiana Cochon entrée. It is seriously delicious. They cook pork shoulder and break it down with a pulled pork approach. They then create a sort of pulled pork patty and coat it what seemed to be a dry rub and cook it to a whole other level. It is super tender and juicy on the inside with a completely different texture and flavor on the outside. It reminded me of everything good about breakfast sausage with its flavor profile so there must have been some sage in the spices. SO GOOD! This dish should be a must for anyone's first visit and then go on rotation for every other visit. Seriously one of the best dishes we had all trip. 

Based on that alone give it a look and see for yourself.

After already spending a few days in NOLA gorging myself to death, I still proclaim that Cochon gave me one of the best meals of my life! 

I came here with my family who are all pretty picky eaters and wanted something special and 'quintessentially New Orleans'. For appetizers, we started off with the FRIED LIVER, PORK CHEEKS, and SMOKED PORK RIBS. I have never ever liked liver in my life, but the FRIED LIVER was so delicious! Each morsel of liver was perfectly fried and placed on a buttered piece of bread. Although the bread and liver were delicious, what tied this dish together was the sweet jam that was spread between the bread and liver. The SMOKED RIBS were delicious, but nothing really that special. The PORK CHEEKS were the highlight of the meal. I had never had pork cheeks before, but this dish will make me seek out pork cheeks in the future. Each piece had the right amount of seasoning and was incredibly tender -- i'm drooling right now just thinking about it.

For the entree, we all shared a HAM HOCK. There was a good amount of meat in the dish and like all ham hocks, the dish was very tender. Lastly, for dessert, we chose an ANGEL FOOD CAKE and some kind of banana, coconut cake that I forgot the name of. My mom, who never eats dessert, polished off the Angel Food Cake.

TL;DR Get the LIVERS and PORK CHEEKS for sure!

I went all over New Orleans and this place was a block away from my hotel suite. Lol.  The restaurant was very airy and nice.  They seat you immediately and the server ask you can they start you off with something to drink.   They serve you soft rolls (they may be called somethings else) with creamy butter while you wait for your meal.

I ordered the salad of the day, which had apples and pears cut up on it. Yum.  A small plate of crocodile meat with garlic mayonnaise.. That was yummy too.  The alcoholic drinks I order was refreshing but very low alcohol content.  (Next time I am going hardcore.)  The offer dessert but I declined due to I was comfortable full , but I am sure it was delicious.

Easily the best meal I have ever had! I got a cold-blooded cocktail, which was unreal!  We got the fried alligator, and being from New Jersey, I've never experienced something so delicious. Ever. It's got a great kick to it, and the plate itself is just enough. I got the Cochon as an entree, and OMG! Not only did the meat just melt in your mouth, it didn't take a lot for it to just pull apart! The plate was appealing as it was served with fried pig skin( to die for), the pickled peaches were my favorite. Looking at the other tables who had gotten dessert, it looked even more amazing! The atmosphere was cozy, the song playlist was a lot of upbeat 90s rap throwbacks which I enjoyed, and the smoky oaky smells were my favorite. No wonder this place is Zagat rated, it delivers as promised!

We had walked by this restaurant the last time we were in New Orleans and wanted to try, but ran out of time. We made sure to make it in...and it was well worth it! We had the fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise, rabbit and dumplings, wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter, the Louisiana cochon with turnips, cabbage & cracklins, and macaroni & cheese casserole. We were able to share everything and get a good sampling. Everytime we tried a dish it became our favorite. We will be back!

I couldn't find anything wrong with this place. We went on an early Saturday evening and were immediately seated despite no reservation. Every worker we interacted with was extremely attentive, polite, and professional. The meat was tender, the vegetables fresh, and the drinks delicious. The 90's hip hop music playing in the background was an added plus. Overall, it was a well spent Saturday evening and we'll definitely be back.

The food was very well done. My husband loved his beef shoulder. It was very tender. The only issue is the menu is very limited. Twice baked potato was very tasty. My vegetarian was able to eat the mac and cheese.

One of my all-time favorites in NO.  Awesome oysters with the garlic butter.  The ham hock fell off the bone.  Such a good restaurant.  Much better service than Peche.  
I'd come back here for breakfast, lunch and dinner.  Can't wait to return.

Our first place to eat in culinary heaven after landing from Chicago and we didn't regret it. Everything that we had was flavorful and simply delicious; fried boudin, catfish courtbouillon, gumbo and the chocolate cake. Highly recommend this place!

Great vibe, excellent food.  I went to celebrate a birthday with 15 friends.  They were awesome and accommodating, even though it was totally last minute.  All the dishes were great.  Service was excellent.  All the small plates and appetizers were amazing - we ordered 3 helpings of the oysters!

Came here for dinner one night without a reservation and we were sat right away, good start! I really enjoyed the laid back atmosphere, there is no dress code and I was in flip flops and didn't feel out of place. 

To start with we had the fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise (best alligator appetizer I have had) and the boudin balls (pretty good). 

For my entree I had the Louisiana Cochon with cabbage, cracklins, and pickled peaches (supposed to be a signature dish, but I thought it didn't live up to the hype). Perhaps it may have been because it was served a little cold (We sat near the kitchen and I could see it just sitting under a heat lamp for at least 5-7 minutes). On a more positive note my wife had the rabbit & dumplings and it was SOOOOOO delicious!!!!! The rabbit was cooked perfectly and the dumplings were fluffy and light with excellent flavor. I would highly recommend this dish! My friend had the pork chop special of the day which he thoroughly enjoyed. Overall, a pretty good experience and we will be back in the future.

The special of the day was the pork chop & all of us agreed it was the best pork chop we had ever tasted. Those of us who did not order this wished that we did! The fried alligator was interesting. Sort of like chicken but a little chewier. I'd go back!

I can see how people like this place.  It is laid out well, offers many Cajun/creole style dishes, and has a very nice atmosphere inside.  They even sat a group of four of us without reservations right away on a Thursday night around 7:30.  

That being said, Cochon was not for me.  The portions were real tiny, and the food that I had was not very flavorful. Our table also had two servers switching on and off, which was a bit strange.  Finally, I was irked that they charged for water.  Admittedly I have not eaten at many restaurants that do and should have been more on top of it, but our server(s) could have communicated that a bit better before we ordered a bunch of (what turned out to be) really expensive water.

I'm pretty sure I'm in the minority, but there was just something about this place that I did not like.  It seemed like they were trying to be high-end, but cheap at the same time. Not a fan.
Very good grits and redfish on a half shell. Wasn't thrilled about the oysters though. Hubby love the rabbit dumplingss.

We chose this place because we wanted Cajun/Creole and seafood options, and it was also super close to our hotel. It ended up being fantastic, the menu had great options, and the staff was friendly. It was a great experience and also affordable.

I loved these place. I have this friend that grew up here and he told me what to order. It was typical Cajun food. I had boudin , crawfish pie and even alligator. It was delicious. Cochon dish was spectacular!! Is a must!! Don't forget to order the upside down  pineapple cake.

What an amazing restaurant! As a visitor/tourist you definitely need to wait her know some one or do your research to find this gem! Possibly one of the best atmospheres to eat of the whole trip! Very modern and appealing to a crowd in their 20-40s looking for a great vibe and a great meal!

Unfortunately, after a late lunch, and wising up on not filling up before a night of drinking...we chose to order appetizers for the table. I believe we ordered almost every one (including 2 Mac and Cheeses) which were all EXCELLENT!!

I would come back and recommend to any one I know visiting in the future!!!

A great dinner place. We had no reservation and no wait eating here during the week. The food, cocktails, and service was spot on. We ordered the pork ribs, boudin balls, fried alligator and for dessert, the hummingbird cake. The pork ribs and boudin balls were my favorite of the night.

The hummingbird cake was on the dry side.

You MUST visit!!

We had a reservation and only waited 8-10 minutes to be seated. The night we went NoLa was experiencing a day of off/on thunderstorms so we couldn't wait outside for our table. 

For appetizers we had the fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise (amaze) and the tomato braised pork cheeks. Our server had accidentally put in an order of oysters instead of the pork cheeks so when the runner brought us the oysters instead we were a little confused. He apologized, the server apologized and the floor manager came to apologize. Crazy good customer service!! We were not even angry (or upset!) and they were apologizing like they had just set us on fire. Some of the reviews said that they had poor service but I can't even imagine that. There was an ample amount of servers and runners all circulating the floor. We never had to ask for a refill of a drink (water or alcoholic -- ooh I HAD THE LEMONADE! get that!!) and they were quick to fill our bread. SOFT, BUTTERY, DELICIOUS DINNER ROLLS.

I had the rabbit & dumplings and the boy had the cochon. Both were delicious. The rabbit had a little too much rosemary for me but very good nonetheless.  We shared the mac & cheese casserole and the twice-baked stuffed potato. WE FINISHED ALL OF IT.

For dessert (yes we forced ourselves to have dessert), we shared the fried banana split. 

This restaurant is not "hype". This is the real deal!
foodie paradise. Beautiful ambience with real hip hop filling the air. Creative menu. Great service. Great drinks and elite bourbon selection. Everything we ate was superb.

This is one of the top 10 places in New Orleans.  I didn't have a reservation but was able to immediately sit at the bar and have dinner.  The wait was about an hour for a table.  The bartenders were amazing and very attentive.  I had the beef brisket which was so tender and tasty.  The mac and cheese was the BEST I have ever had.  For dessert I had the upside down pineapple cake with coconut sherbet.  I highly recommend this place unbelievable!

We came for lunch and had:
gator with spicy aoili
crawfish pie
shortribs
cochon with crackings

The small plates of gator and crawfish pie outshined the larger plates. Not the larger plates were bad, quite the contrary, I just felt that they were blander than the flavor-packed small plates and needed some sort of sauce.

Still a good meal but I recommend ordering a bunch of small plates and going to town.

Good selection of local beers.
Funnily enough - what stood out was the char-grilled oysters. Everything else was good - but not as memorable. Great place but you definitely need to make reservations - especially for dinner.
Paneed pork cheeks were not good as rated. The garnishes did not compliment the meat at all. I only liked the creamy grits and the ribs, which were okay.

If you're in the Big Easy, you know there are hundreds of great places to eat, but it's not complete until you try Cochon.  Never had such great, unique comfort food.  Smoked ham hock on field peas with pickled pepper rings!  Warm fried okra salad.  Always surprised by how much of a treat it is to eat different food than I normally eat and how delicious it is. Give this place a try, you will be rewarded with an experience that will make you return again.

We had a fantastic dinner here last Saturday night at Cochon!

To start we had the oysters and fried boudin. Both were divine. The oysters were some of the best I had while in NOLA. The boudin reminded me of the country-style pate I used to eat in France. It was like a memory on a plate. 

DH had the hamhock, which he LOVED and I had the Louisiana chochon, which I thoroughly enjoyed as well. 

We tried the hummingbird cake for dessert, which was nice, but I think we were too full by that point to fully enjoy it's carrot-cake like texture and cream cheese frosting. 

The service was fine and the space is modern. The atmosphere is laid back and you won't be out of place in casual clothes, although many were dressed up as well.

Loved this place! They serve you these delicious dinner rolls while you wait for your meal. I got the wood fired oysters with chili garlic butter which may have even the BEST OYSTERS I had all week in NoLa! Then I also had the fried alligator which was a first for me. It tastes almost like chicken but a little chewier. I actually really enjoyed them and they serve them with chili garlic mayo which compliments them perfectly! I walked in during the lunch rush but they still had a few tables left. Ideally I would make a reservation.

First time at Cochon very nice place . The garlic Oysters were small but very tasty. The gumbo was some of the best I ever had . My wife had the Brisket over top of grits with gravy topped with shaved pepper salad. Next time I want to try the Oyster & Bacon sandwich.

30 minue wait during White Linen night... I'd say thats pretty darn good!

We dined outside, but I did a walk through to check out the rest of the place.  Pretty neat!

I had the pork cheek and one of the moonshines (I forget which!) and it was fabulous!  My boyfriend had the couchon and cracklins.  He thought it was great, but the portion size was very small (to which I agree). We were entertaining friends from out of town- they enjoyed it as well.

Great drink selection.  

I'm ready to go next door to try Cochon Butcher next!

Really really neat stuff. Cool atmosphere. Wait staff was great. Ask to try the head cheese so you can mark it off your list. Past that get whatever variation of pork you are in the mood 4. Again very cool place
Wonderful as always!!! A great experience from the cocktails to the appetizers to the entrees. The oysters and boucherie plate never fail!

One of my clients who is a chef recommended I go here, so of course I had to listen. I ate two appetizers: the meat pie and the gumbo, and then ate the fish of the day entree, and then shared the buttermilk panna cotta. Also, I tried other people's dishes, including the ribs and the cochon.  I had a hard time walking afterward, but I have no regrets! Everything was amazing, including the unique sides that came with the dishes; the ribs came with pickled watermelon and the fish came with pickled onions! 

The service was impeccable; the server was never difficult to get a hold of, and he was super attentive the whole time. (Off topic, but he looked like a cross between the mixed martial arts fighter, TJ Dillashaw, and Shia LeBeouf). I really think restaurants that have food runners and people refilling water and drinks allows the wait staff to function far more efficiently.

I'll be returning when I go back to New Orleans.

Usually I shy away from writing my own review for places that have a million already (like Cochon does). But I had such an amazing experience here I felt the need to put it on paper.

I was in New Orleans for a good friends bachelorette party and we wanted a nice dinner for our last night. We made reservations for 9pm (which was pretty much all they had left). We walked in about 10 minutes before our reservation and they promptly ushered us to our table.

Service was perfect from the beginning. We had 2 different people waiting on us and they were both so nice and informative. Cocktails were on point. The Cold Blooded was my favorite but the Delta Burke was also great.

Dinner. What DIDN'T we order? We all wanted to try pretty much everything so we did a family style meal. Let me see if I can remember everything we ordered. Gulf shrimp, fried boudin, paneed pork cheeks, grilled okra salad, rabbit and dumplings, brisket and grits, oven-roasted gulf fish, wood-fired eggplant, mac and cheese, greens, and shrimp and eggplant dressing. We did pretty good.

I think the stand outs were definitely the fried boudin, over roasted gulf fish (we commonly referred to it as "crack fish" because we were immediately addicted) and the greens (probably the best greens I have ever had. We were also all addicted to their delicious hot sauce and all bought a bottle when we left. 

Our experience here was so great and such a perfect end to our trip. Highly recomended!

This was one of the best stops to eat on our week long trip. Between the great staff and delicious food, it was worth the price. This is an "A la carte" type establishment so prepare to order the additional side dish.

Food prepare very well and presented in cast iron dishes to keep them warm. We had the Rabbit dumplings and the Chicken fried pork loin. The rabbit was very well but the pork loin was too salty. The side dishes were the Mac and Cheese and the Shrimp and eggplant dressing. Both were very tasty and well seasoned.

The appetizer was the pork cheeks. It was so tender it melted in your mouth. Although we had some extra ingredients in the dressing, parchment paper, the staff was apologetic and offer to immediately replace the dish.

Arrive early or make a reservation. It is worth the price and the wait.

Upon our arrival the waiters were very friendly and seated us right away. They were very accomodating since we were sitting by a window they came and let the blinds down so the sun wasn't in our face. 

Our waiter was super nice and very friendly. He was super informative as well. I ordered the pork cheeks and it was not what I thought. It was super small and not as tasty as I wanted. It was good but not great. My husband got the brisket and grits and he also thought it was good not great. 

We also got drinks. I loved my drink, cold blooded and my husband loved his drink, some beer. 

Two friendly British women next to us let us try their fried aligator. It was sooooo good! I recommend getting that.

The place was super packed so lots of people like it.

With the amazing reviews on Yelp, decided to give this place a first shot right after I landed in NOLA! And I have to say, I was not disappointed. Though the location of it looked shady on the outside, once you are inside, the ambience of it, was simply amazing! I would have to say their mashed potato was my favorite. The next on the list would be alligator appetizer, and the chili sauce that came with it. The entree & the dessert, was pretty decent! Definitely visit this place when you are in town.

My first review! Didn't expect it to be 5 stars, but here we are. We went here with a group of 6 last night, everything was perfection! 

Start with that we walked in 15 minutes early for our 9pm reservation and were seated immediately...awesome. We had two wonderfully attentive servers. The drinks were delivered to the right position points and we always love that. Cocktails were fantastic! My friends had the cold blooded and it was soooo good! Nice little spice on the back.

The food!!!! Perfect! We had the alligator, the ribs, the gumbo, the greens, the mac n cheese, the twice baked potatoes, the oysters, the pulled pork, and the catfish. I can't even describe how decisions every single bite of everything was...order it all! 

Lastly, the service! I mean, it was so great. My friend was ready to have a little drink at the end of the meal and normally drinks tequila. Our amazing server (can't remember her name at the moment) suggested that she have the moonshine. She was nervous, but the the sever said boldly "do you trust me?" My friend said I do. And she said "trust me girl!" Well my friend trusted her and was absolutely not disappointed. This service really just made our experience so much more perfect. Amazing all around, kudos to Cochon

Went here for lunch on a Wednesday and the place was buzzing (which is always a good sign).  We were in a rush because we had a flight to catch.  But I'm soooo glad we squeezed this in.  The service was fast enough that we got all of our food and was out of there in time.

Once we looked at the menu, the hardest part was choosing what to get because we literally wanted EVERYTHING.  We ended up getting the wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter ($14), smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickle ($14), tomato braised pork cheeks with hoe cake & pumpkin seeds ($12), louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklins & pickled peaches ($24), and macaroni & cheese casserole ($7).  Yes, we were hungry, and yes, we finished it ALL!  My favorite was the wood fired oysters, the mere mention of which makes me salivate.  But everything was exceptional.

The service was great.  The staff was very attentive.  Surprisingly this was one of our cheaper meals in New Orleans given how good the food is. All in all a great experience and I will definitely be going back.

This was our first meal in NOLA and though it wasn't the strongest, the impression it left us was pleasant. I mean come on, first time eating FRIED ALLIGATOR ($12) has got to be memorable in anyone's book. That said, these chicken-like meat are somewhat chewy but not by any means in a jaw-breaking way. There was no gaminess detected thanks to the generous slathering of chili garlic mayo which I found very tasty. Is it worth trying? Absolutely.

The PORK CHEEKS ($12) was my favorite dish here. It's shredded meat, breaded, and then pan-fried on a skillet. Three of these round shaped babies are all you get on a small plate topped with mushrooms and fried lemons as they sit on a bed of eggplant caviar. One bite of everything together was a burst of flavor in my mouth. It was rich, it was scrumptious, it was heavenly. For this alone, I get why the restaurant is called Cochon (pig in French).

Our main course was another pork dish, of course. We decided on the SMOKED HAM HOCK ($26) served with wonderful pickled peppers on top and an earthy mix of gold rice and field peas underneath it. I enjoyed the smokiness of the meat but it wasn't as tender as I hoped it would be. I have to be honest this dish did not wow me as I expected it to. 

The restaurant itself was warm and inviting especially with a waitstaff embodying that Southern hospitality. It's very casual with an open kitchen that's viewable from the dining room and a bar for those who are there mainly for libations. Reservations are allowed though we didn't really need it at 4PM on a Saturday. I doubt that's the case for dinner time. Not bad for meal #1 on our trip!

We came here for dinner on a Saturday night.  We tried many things at this restaurant.  Our recommedation: get the oysters, alligator, rabbit and dumplings. 

Fire wood oysters - everyone's favorite appetizer at our table.  Just heaven. 

Fried alligator - awesome, crunchy, flavorful.

Pork Cheeks - tender meat, delicious sauce. Note: really small plate.

Cochon main plate - this was good, but we didn't think it was out of the park.

Pork Hock - the meat fell apart from the bone, but I think some sauce is needed, felt like the meat was lacking moisture.  Also, the dish was lukewarm upon arrival. Would have preferred it to be hotter. 

Beef brisket - alright,  but not memorable.  My husband was actually disappointed,  the flavors were rather bland. Meh.

Rabbit and dumpling - this was definitely the table's favorite.  Flavors were savory with thyme. The rabbit meat was delicious and distinctive.  

Hummingbird cake - good, creamy

Banana split - the better dessert of the three

Chocolate chess pie - hits the spot for chocolate cravings.

Beer Perish - my friend said it was good.

Crispin pear cider - refreshing 

Summary : phenomenal apps. Mediocre nothing special mains with the exception of the awesome rabbit and dumplings.  Desserts good .

We were told it would be a 45 min to an hour wait. During this time, we saw 2 tables on the patio sit there empty for 20 minutes a piece. The hostesses were acting like they could pick and choose who they "allowed" to eat at their restaurant. 

Due to the extremely horrible, "I'm better than you" attitude from the hostess, we decided to leave and go down the street to another restaurant. When we went in to give the courtesy of knowing we were leaving, the hostess acted like she couldn't even find our name on the list. 

From listening to another group talking, two guys had come in a week before dressed the same way they were then and didn't get a table. Tonight, however, they were with some women and had no problem being seated. 

I wonder what Chef Link would say if he knew his staff was treating customers this way. Word of mouth is huge in the restaurant business.

Cochon is a very popular restaurant in New Orleans.  The food is good, but you don't get a lot for your money.  It is a very hipster trendy place that cures a lot of their own meats.  I appreciate their sourcing of local foods, but I wish the servings were bigger, especially knowing how much they cost.  This place is also very hard to get a reservation.  Not sure if they don't like Open Table, but you usually can't get a reservation using Open Table after 5pm.

Really interesting menus. I went with 4 small plates and it was to much to finish.
The fried oysters are fantastic. 
The fried boudin was really good as well
The alligator was a solid choice.
The worst of the bunch was the ribs. It is an interesting combo of pickled flavor and heat. A couple of the seemed a little dry and the others had been cooked perfectly. It wasn't bad, just not the best. 
This place is great, especially if you don't want the noise of the French Quarter. 
I will come back here, 100%

Made lunch reservations for my birthday. Food was great. Pork cheeks and pork chop special were very tasty. 
I was only dissapointed by the service. Our waitress was very sweet and nice. She even added a birthday candle to our dessert. Almost every other employee, however, from the hostess to the bartenders and cooks (they have an open air kitchen) avoided eye contact, and didn't smile. The vibe didn't feel welcoming or warm. It instead felt pretentious. My second glass of white wine sat at the bar for 15 minutes until one of the 3 bartenders decided to finally bring it to our table. 

I would still recommend going for the food, especially if you love pork, just don't be surprised by the lackluster service.
Everything was great. The cocktails, soft shell crab, and the service. My first time here and I would definitely come back !

4.5 stars: another great meal @Cochon. We have sampled many different stuff from craft cocktails to apps to large plates to dessert. So far every single one of them was good to great. Their kitchen must have some real talents. Thank you chefs! You passionate chefs make the world a better place. 

Reservation is a must, even on a weekday. 

If you are a Vegan/ Vegetarian you will be missing out on the best dining experience here.

Atmosphere is casual upscale, and it can get pretty loud as they do get busy.

Although their service staff has been efficient, they are not the most friendly bunch. I find they generally lack the special touch that elevates good dining experience to excellent. Perhaps Southern hospitality, or at least some humanly charm would be nice. With the restaurants' reputation and food this good... especially at the price point, one would expect the whole experience to be amazing.

One thing that bugged me on our last visit was the fact our server brought out a bottle of wine with incorrect vintage (different from what is listed on the menu) and failed to inform us about it. It may be a small detail but I would have chosen something different had I known the bottle doesn't come in the vintage(s) I wanted. 
I wish he'd politely inquire if the different vintage would be okay, instead of just presenting it abruptly in his uninterested attitude. Or the wine list should list the correct vintage in the first place.
Maybe they need more training/ education, or maybe just needs to CARE.   

Overall, the dinner was delicious so we are happy. Good bourbons on the menu which is a plus.

The worse service ever! Had to send salad back because too salty! I know I know! Why order a salad at Cochon but I had just eaten and was meeting a group of friends& family from out of town and wasn't that hungry but they were so with that being said the waitress took forever and then brought food before cocktails & Bevs were delivered and then they auctioned off the food which took 5 guys to auction all the food so a lot of over talking and confusion then another 39 minuets for them to get our check right which still had the salad I returned which no one asked if I wanted to have remade or order something else! It was disappointing and frustrating which took from them being able to seat others standing around forever waiting. The food is good but not great and extremely overpriced! Too bad this placed turned so touristy & crappy! I'll never go back!

Again back in the Warehouse District after more gallery hopping and the Ogden museum... We came at lunch and snagged a table for a late lunch snack.  I wanted to try the Boudin balls and was not disappointed.  Then the pork cheeks were amazing!  Definitely get that.  Finally, the arugula salad was perfect to cut the richness of this snack.  Next time I plan on trying their butcher shop around the corner!

The gator frites are spectacular. The aioli really seals the deal. The frites are in large enough bites that you really get a good idea of the gator texture.

The mac n cheese is very creamy without being overly rich. 

The rabbit and dumplings are a bit disappointing. Instead of dumplings i got 4 dumpling sized biscuits. The rabbit is very tender. The broth is flavorful but not wildly phenomenal.

With no reservation, we had a 30-40 minute wait, which passed quickly as we chatted with other customers and eye-balled the treats that were emanating from the kitchen. When our turn came up, we were seated at bar-style seating that faced the kitchen. That was like winning the seating lottery. I LOVE to watch the cooks and the dishes, so my spot facing the wood-fired oven was THE BEST spot in the house. Our server was a local fellow who was welcoming and joyful, and happy to make suggestions. Cochon is a restaurant whose specialty is "small plates," appetizer-sized portions that are fun to share. We chose a mix of tastes - roasted oysters, smoked ribs, smothered greens, and grits with a twist (the addition of roasted vegetables and a soft cooked egg). Our server also brought us a little present - a sampling of the head cheese. We loved sampling the interesting taste and texture combinations. We swooned over the oysters, which had a garlic and spicy creole kick to them. We could have eaten a few dozen of them. They were outstanding. The head cheese (smokey and velvety textured) was accompanied by thinly sliced homemade pickles and buttered toast squares - and this, too was a standout. The ribs were smokey thoughout and chewy, the sauce a little sweeter than I like, but still delicious. The grits / vegetable / egg combination was an interesting contrast to our other choices - and a nice counterbalance to the ribs. The greens were flavorful with shards of smoked pork - the only negative is that I hit some grit in them in one bite, otherwise they were excellent. Cochon made dining out fun and entertaining. We sensed that this place was definitely "hot" and "in," and we add our thumbs up. Like its sister restaurant, the deli Cochon Butcher next door, it is a couple of blocks down Higgins St. from the National WWII Museum. Well worth a stop, and if there is a wait to be seated, it is worth the wait.

Every time we go to NOLA we have to try a new restaurant. After hearing a reservation is almost necessary for this place, we tried to see if we could get a table by walk in. We went after the lunch rush and got right in. Words cannot express how amazing our experience was. Everything was perfect. My husband ordered the brisket and grits topped with a pepper salad, while I ordered the duck and dumplings. We began our order with oysters and boudin balls. We couldn't walk after, but this place is too perfect to pass up. Service was friendly and the managers came by to check on our experience. If this place is out of your way, make time. It's worth the trip and any money spent here.

I was most pleased to have gotten a last minute reservation for the weekend we were in town. Very glad we chose this place beautiful food, excellent service and lovely modern interior. After a bit much creole in the days preceding and following this meal, it remained a breath of fresh air. Southern without a doubt, but much more care with the flavors. We had a lovely app special of a chile crusted fried rib with a nice mint-herb salad, the Cochon w/braised cabbage and turnips, the brisket and slow roasted grits with a pepper salad and a side of the greens. Everything was fantastic, the pork was flavored perfectly (tho a bit dry), but melded very well with tasty cabbage and turnips. The brisket was dead on perfect, the grits creamy and the pepper salad added just the right acid note and interesting way to bring in strong hints of Rosemary. Sadly no dessert, as we had already partaken in beignets as our pre-pre-app as our reservation was on the late side. Can't wait to return one day!

Totally UN-impressed Cochon guys, sorry. I came from Baton Rouge to eat here after reading raves about it for years. I don't think I have been this disappointed in a meal in years.  If this is what passes for good food in New Orleans, then it's not the food city it's cracked up to be. I had the Louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklins & pickled peaches and for $24 for the tiny portion (and it was NOT a small plate item--although it sure should be one) it should have been fantastic considering the reputation of this establishment.  It was totally underwhelming and if I hadn't been starving to death due to not eating all day, I might have given this a 2 star review since hunger is the best spice--but even that couldn't help this flavorless room temperature mess.  The 1 spoonful of cabbage that was purported to contain pickled peaches and cracklins had 3 fingernail size pieces of cracklins that were so rock hard that I was afraid to eat them because I feared breaking a tooth--and I have strong teeth.  The cabbage mix was cold and when I asked if it was supposed to be cold (and this was after waiting FORTY-FIVE MINUTES ON A TUESDAY) they said "uh no...." and snatched the plate and returned with slightly warmed veggies and I couldn't find a piece of peach anywhere in it, so it was like eating red cabbage at a German joint.  Here's a hint:  I like my food HOT guys. The also forgot to heat the "cochon" which was a small ball of shredded pork like a shredded pork crab cake, the meat was room temperature and was beyond pathetic. I could have done this in a crock pot at home and it would have been a LOT better.  It was apparently premade and stored in the fridge until I ordered it and they apparently consider browning the top and bottom to be adequate to reheat the meat.  It had zero flavor other than some mild heat but it was terrible and this whole mess was criminally overpriced along with being cold and flavorless.  I had to be in the city on other business and have wanted to eat here for years, so it was extremely disappointing to discover that this has got the be the most over-rated and over-priced place in America.  The service was indifferent at best and I would NEVER come back here again.  City Pork and City Pork and Brasserie in Baton Rouge are light-years superior to this albeit similarly overpriced.  I went next door to Cochon Butcher to see if the food there was any better....you can read that review next. (Spoiler Alert: It was terrible too).
Factor in the horrible lack of parking and you can figure out the rest--the only place to park without walking forever is $10 for "0-8" hours.  I left my car with a valet at a different restaurant for $5 tip and walked a block.

I had fried alligator and cochon. The gator was AWESOME!!!!! But the cochon was a little salty for me.... I even didn't finish it because it was salty.

The service was good, but they didn't accept separate checks unless you are four or more.

We had planned eating a three course dinner but after evaluating the menu we decided to go the small plate route. The decision was filling, budget friendly and did I mention filling!? 

Get the gator. Each bite is delicious, savoury and just the right amount of heat. Speaking of heat, the mac and cheese is a great way to neutralize the heat. We also had the roasted oysters and the bouchrie plate. Everything was yummy from start to finish. 

The waitstaff was a team. This was annoying. We really liked our secondary waiter, but our primary was less than exceptional. Overall a great experience. Make a reservation so you can avoid the long wait.

Cochon was delicious. I had the Louisiana Cochon. It was very tender. The greens were good but the best were the oysters. They had a spicy sauce on them making them unlike I've had before.  It was great. The atmosphere was perfect. Very lively and fun.

CoChon's is a great place for something different with New Orleans flavor. The wood fired oysters, shrimp and eggplant casserole are a must. People who don't like eggplant will like this spicy dish. Top it off with the apple & fig Crostotata....yummy!

I have to say, I was blown away. My wife and I are down in the area for a conference and we came because of the great reviews. I have to say, we were not disappointed! 

When we arrived at 5:30pm on a Thursday night they were so full with patrons and reservations that we had to sit outside with our party of 2.5. 

The waitress was a bit busy and so the only reason I went to a 4 stars was because of the slower service... If I could have done 4.5 I would have been there! 

The food was absolutely incredible and the beer was cool and refreshing. I would gladly return for another visit!

Stumbled upon this during a recent trip to New Orleans. Convenient location from the convention center. The food here was delicious. I tried the fried alligator, couchon and ribs. The alligator is highly recommended and tasted like chicken. Wish I had a chance to come back and eat more of it. The scenery was nice and prices were fair. Would recommend.

Our first place for dinner in NOLA and we had a good time. After drinks we had ordered a few dishes to try - Fried alligator tasted like calamari but more dry; pork cheeks were a bit on the salty side but very flavorful. The eggplant puree that came with it had a great kick; oyster and bacon sandwich was good which you don't really expect from a combination like this. Certainly unique as I've never had anything like this, simple. For dessert, highly recommend the hummingbird cake! Service was amazing. Great dining experience. Make reservations!!

Came here to see what the hype was about. We only ordered appetizers because it was 3pm and we weren't really hungry.

**FRIED ALLIGATOR - best thing about Cochon. I never had alligator before but I love it! Interesting texture for sure..the chili garlic mayonnaise? to die for! I don't even like mayo but this sauce was amazinggg. I kind of wish we ordered 4 of these instead of ordering the other dishes appetizers.

*PORK CHEEK - second best appetizer - really tender pork

Chicken and andouille gumbo - do NOT get. It was SO SALTY! My first time eating gumbo and I was very disappointed :(

Gulf shrimp - Comes with ONLY 4 pieces of shrimp for $16?! Not worth it

Maybe I'd come back to try their entrees and definitely the fried alligator otherwise I didn't care too much for this restaurant
Just ordered a bottle of Zin for $50 and got a white wine glass. When I asked for a red wine glass I was told they were only for wines over $85.00.  Are you kidding me.

It's as good as people brag it to be.  The Staff and service were spectacular and we sat in the rear watching the kitchen in action.  The crew work their asses off and it's an amazing efficient and orchestrated kitchen that puts tremendous effort pride and skill into their food.  Just go and appreciate it for yourself.  
We tried the gator bites which were good but overshadowed by the boudin, the ham hock entre, the oysters and mac cheese.   The food is filling and it's worth trying several things on the menu.  We will definitely be back for this gem. 

We showed up at noon on a Thursday and it got busy quickly.  Recommend getting a reservation if you plan to go.  Enjoy!!!

So I have heard so many good things of this place and when my friend came to visit from DC and happened to stay in the hotel closed to this place, I quickly suggested here so we can catch up with each other tonight before she flies out tomorrow.

The place was crowded for a Monday night which is okay because it just proved that this place is popular and I just couldn't wait to try their food. The wait was about 30 minutes and the hostess was very nice, so we were fine.

We were seated at the last table outside of the restaurant almost in front of the entrance of the law firm upstairs?! It was actually good because it was quiet and kinda isolated from the crowds.  Also, sitting in front of a building like that kinda created a trendy atmosphere for us, so we were pretty happy about it.

The server came and greeted us. She was nice but seemed to be not personable. She just kinda stood there and almost wanted us to order right away. I told her that it was our first time there (as an ice breaker), and asked if she could recommend anything to us. Then, she actually sighed.... Yes, sighed.... And told us her favorite few dishes: Louisiana Cochon and the fish dish (don't remember the name of the dish). The way she described the dishes was kinda robotic...

Anyway, we decided to order two appetizers: Wood fried oysters and Fried alligator, and two entrees: The fish dish and the Louisiana Cochon (braised pork shoulder with cracklings, cabbages and pickled peaches. 

The appetizers were very good. The bread was great! However, the entrees came out when we were still eating our appetizers and the guy who brought the entrees to us attempted to take our appetizers away while we were still enjoying them. He apologized and said that he didn't see us still eating them.  Anyway, no biggie. The entrees were just not as good as I expected. The fish smelled awfully fishy when it got to our table and the pork shoulder... It was tough and dry. We could not even finish the entrees. The worst part, three servers and a hostess were continuously checking on us. At first, we thought that they were just being nice asking if we needed anything but then, after three times of constantly interrupting our conversations, I realized that the reason they were doing so was to wanting us to leave so they can turnover the table as they were getting more crowded. 

Well, we decided to do so and still left a generous tip but seriously, this place is very disappointing. I just think that it's very rude to treat customers this way. Maybe this is just one of the touristy place that they don't care what locals think but to be honest, if the service was a little better, I would come back for appetizers and even bring few more friends to give it another go, but now, I just don't think I will come back again.... 

I gave it two stars because of the nice seating and the nice hostess!
The rabbit and dumplings is one the best meals I have ever had. Service and ambience great also.

Amazing, simply amazing.  I came here entirely by accident and on a whim and it's like a gift from God that this is where my face was stuffed with the best lunch I've ever had.  Pick anything on the menu, it'll be delicious.  I had the fried livers, pork cheeks, and this baked eggplant dish with olive oil.  Take the hot sauce on the table and put it on EVERYTHING because it's just that good (and not that hot!).  The bread that they serve you is crack, eat it all and dip it in everything.

For dessert I had the chocolate chess pie, a MUST!  Then after you're done feasting, go around the corner to their butcher shop and buy a bunch of beef jerky to go because it's the best beef jerky in the entire world.

family style with 6 people.

wood-fired oyster roast
pork cheek terrine with spring onions & blistered tomato vinaigrette
meat pie
roasted beet & arugula salad with tarragon yogurt dressing
rabbit & dumplings
eggplant & shrimp dressing

Cocktail: Hey, Jill

Definitely great food. Lively atmosphere. Went here for lunch with the hobby. Fried Alligator  must. We order the days special, pork chop. And the the famous rabbit & dumpling. Both was delicious. Portion reasonable. But well worth it once u taste the flavor a that comes from the dishes.

Good things about this place, cocktails are fantastic!!! The main course was really good! I had the Cochon with cabbage and my husband has the rabbit with dumplings! Both were great!!!! 

Bad things, the apps were awful and over cooked! The service is some of the worst that I have had ever experienced in New Orleans!!!

I wouldn't go back when there is much better places to eat where you are treated well!!!

2000th review? Crazy.

This was a highly-anticipated meal during my trip to New Orleans. Having watched a number of documentaries that feature Cochon, Donald Link, and Stephen Stryjewski, I was eager to give it a try. A buddy of mine recently got engaged, so we all went out to Cochon to celebrate for lunch. We were seated right away, and having scoped the menu beforehand, we were ready to order right away as well. We were also greeted with some very warm, fluffy brioche buns, with super-soft, yet dense butter, and a little bit of finishing kosher salt. 

We went pretty much all out and got the wood-fired oysters in chili butter, fried alligator in chili mayo, mac and cheese casserole, pork knuckles, Louisiana cochon (pulled pork), and the beef brisket.
