Hoo boy. Absolutely everything was delicious. My favorites were the oysters and pork knuckles, mostly because of how unique they were. The chili butter with the meat of the oysters was very interesting, but very delicious. The pork knuckles were like disks of pork meat, fried and battered with pickled veggies and mint on top. Pretty killer. Everything else was great too, it was just those two dishes that really stood out. The mac & cheese casserole was super creamy and decadent, the super densely-packed cochon was pretty much melt-in-your-mouth, and the fried alligator was just excellent and had great contrasting flavors. In all, the meal was incredibly rich and hearty, so let it be known that a meal at Cochon is not for the faint of heart, or should I say the high in cholesterol, heh. 

Waitstaff was a bit aloof , and it took awhile to get our orders actually in, but after that, the drink and water refills came by pretty frequently. The prices in general are slightly more expensive than most restaurants in the area, but the quality is all very good, so you can be assured that you're receiving a great meal.

I would definitely recommend this place for date night, or just bro brunch. Note that there aren't really any TVs in here, so you can't catch the Saints/LSU game, but you can try to schedule your meal around those times and then get to the bar as fast as you can, haha. I will definitely be back to try their other dishes and cocktails, or if I'm just feeling a really good meal in New Orleans.
Amazing food and service!! A most try if you are in New Orleans. The oyster and the alligator where out of this world and the drinks are unique.

Open, airy and bustling place lets you know that serious food and cocktails await. Of course the name means pork so keep that in mind (I don't eat it). Hoppin on a Friday afternoon and all indoor and outdoor tables full. With that being said only waited about 15 min to sit for 2 of us. Enjoy your wait at the bar. Interesting cocktails and plenty of local beer both on tap and bottled. 
Server was competent but seemed nervous or hyped on too much caffeine. Downside...  our wait for 3 small plates was a little long. Luckily I'm on holiday and the company was good. Started with the roasted oysters, delicious and plump with a flavorful sauce. I added some spice to mine, can't resist house made hot sauces. My date had the redfish special. Deliciously light and flavorful boned whole fish. 
I had the richly flavored fried chicken liver with pepper jelly as well as the okra salad. All good, filling and delicious. Would like to try the butcher next time.

We had a lovely lunch here today.   Only one snafu.  I called to get directions as we were visiting from out of town.  I had looked at a map and figured I could take the St Charles Street car.   The lady at the front desk told me that was the wrong direction. So I grabbed an uber.  When I left I found the street car just 3-4 blocks from the restaurant.   So my only complaint is that the hostess did not know their location or bother to ask someone who might know.  She seemed annoyed to help.  Other than that a great meal and wait staff.
Sat night full house at 9pm. Young crowd, loud and lively.  Great bar service and excellent meal. Server average.  Had bbq oysters, chicken livers, meat pie, fried alligator, redfish.

Maybe I'm spoiled since Tampa is a great foodie's paradise, but I thought everything here was just ok. Nothing remarkable or memorable, but not bad either. 

We ordered a shot of the apple pie moonshine and it will definitely put hair on your chest. Great taste to it though. 

For our food, we ordered a bunch of small plates, with the best one being the meat pie....think empanada. 

Besides that, the meat platter was just ok and the gumbo looked soupy. 

Would I return?  Probably not since there are way more options in NOLA to try first.

This gem of a restaurant is a must visit. You cannot go wrong!

Highly recommend ordering several appetizers and sides so you get to enjoy the amazing variety this fine establishment has to offer. 

This restaurant should be on anyone's must visit list of New Orleans restaurants.

Cochon is one of my favorite restaurants in New Orleans.  I have been there many times; both for dinner and for drinks after work.I have yet to have a bad experience at Cochon.

Their specialty cocktail list changes periodically.  I normally go for the bourbon cocktails and they have all been very good.  Wish I could remember the names of them and what was in them so I could make them at home.  They have a very good selection of craft beers to choose from.  Probably their best thing though is their selection of bourbons, whiskeys, and scotches.

I always start off my meal with, or have a snack after work, the fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise.  They are very light battered so the batter is not overbearing.  The sauce over them is very good and the garnish they use adds a nice bit of bitterness.

I've also gotten the fried boudin balls a couple of times and I can say I'll definitely order them again at some point.

The heirloom tomato salad with sunflower seeds & cucumber vinaigrette is probably one of the best salads that I have ever eaten!  It's the perfect balance of fresh sweet tomatoes, salty sunflower seeds, and a lightly sour and bitter vinaigrette.

Probably my favorite thing on the menu though is the rabbit & dumplings.  It's just perfect!  Something so good cannot be describes in a manner so you'll just have to try it yourself.  And if you think that you don't like rabbit you are very WRONG.

If you like spicy go here.

Awesome service, great vibe, amazing alligator fritters and they even have a butterscotch rootbeer.

Amazing!

This place was pretty good.  We went for a work function and it's a little pricey for me to ever venture on my own.  The food was pretty good, and maybe I'm just more of a burger and fries kind of gal because everyone raved about this place, locals and tourists alike.  A friend of mine had the rabbit and dumplings and she thought it was fantastic, I had the short rib and while it was incredibly tender, I thought it was actually lacking in flavor.

Wonderful Restaurant, serving Pig meat in every possible incantation, superior service, great noisy ambience, Sadly parking is not great, on street, but uber over & no problem. The specialty cocktail ist is impressive 7 a way above average wine list, But the Star is the food & pork offered in numerous manners, I cant recommend a  single Pork dish because they are all Spectacular , but we ordered 2x the Cajun shrimp because it was so good.

Literally one of the best meals of my life. Recommended to us by a local uber driver. No reservation on a Thursday evening at 8pm, we had an hour wait. Full restaurant, great ambiance. I had soup of the day, and my husband the Cochon. Both were excellent. I was not expecting a soup to have me so thrilled for a meal! Portions on the smaller side. The only slight disappointment of our experience was our distracted and unattentive waiter. All else wonderful.

We started with the wood fired oysters,  they were good but two pieces of shells made it into the oyster,  that took away  from the dish. I then had the fried oyster sandwich which was very good. Finished with the apple fig crustada and that was the highlight of the day, absolutely delicious.

To avoid those long wait times at Cochon (easily over 1h during the busy times), definitely use Open Table or call ahead to make a reservation. You may get some real oddball times for dinner (our choices happened to be either 5pm or 9pm, with nothing in between) but at least you'll get seated within a reasonable time. I think the reputation for Cochon exceeds itself. You can get more authentic Creole food elsewhere for much lower prices. 

However, if you decide to brave the long wait times, I highly recommend the fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise. For those who haven't tried alligator before, it's a stringier version of chicken but Cochon brings out the tenderness of each piece. The real highlight, however, is the mayonnaise. Spicy, creamy, and delicious - you can also try it with the wood-fired oysters if you decide that reptiles just aren't your thing. Although the Louisiana cochon (think pulled pork) with cabbage, cracklins (pork rinds), and pickled peaches is supposed to be their signature dish, I didn't think it was anything amazing. If you're planning on sampling a bunch of appetizers, the small plates (boucherie) will be the perfect size for one person. Both the smoked pork ribs and the pork cheeks were decent, but again, nothing to rave about.

Final verdict: for tourists with limited amount of time to sample all of NOLA's delicious cuisine, Cochon can certainly be skipped.

Amazingly delicious. Best place to eat if you're trapped at the convention center. Tried to eat at the Butcher but the line was too long and that made me happy. I was with colleagues and everyone raved about their food.

My wife and I have been wanting to try Cochon for quite some time and finally got an opportunity. And usually when you build something up in your mind, it mainly disappoints... but not this time!!

I have family down in New Orleans, so I frequent the city often. But when we are there for those reasons, our time is taken up with family things or Mardi Gras parades!! So on a trip down that was a bit more relaxed, we planned and executed a trip to Cochon.

Since this was a lunch trip, we were seated pretty immediately. They ambience is classy but casual. And even though we went at about 2 PM, it was still pretty crowded. Always a good sign. Our waiter was attentive and informative. Never an empty glass so with that, I could never complain about the service.

Now the food is my only complaint. How can you choose just one thing when there are so many delicious choices?!? Simply not fair. And to add to that, the pan fried pork loin sandwich with roasted brussel sprouts. So what did what any reasonable people would do, and chose two thing we both liked and split it! Since that sandwich sticks out in my mind so well, you know that was one of the items chosen. The other was the rabbit and dumplings. The sandwich was incredible! Perfectly cooked but not greasy. The bread was fresh and light and came topped with an incredible slaw that complimented the pork so well. The rabbit and dumplings were a little different than I expected. It was more like a creamy rabbit stew with carrots and potatoes. It had four biscuit halves on top that served as more of the "dumpling" than anything. I do wish it had a little more rabbit in it. But that sauce it was served in was so good, it made up for anything else missing. Overall, this was an amazing experience that will keep bringing us back for years to come!

Came to see what the hype was all about. Went during lunch, so there wasn't really a line. But parking did suck, just wish they had their own private parking, instead it was street parking in a busy location. Sat outside because the weather was so beautiful out, and it was cool to people watch while waiting for the food. Service was decent, not attentive or slow. Ended up ordering oysters and fried alligator. Must say, as a first timer for eating an alligator, it was good. Didn't know what to expect, thought it would be rubbery, but it was different and interesting, tasted more like chicken! As for the oysters, they were good as well. Had a lot of flavoring and juice. Overall experience was excellent. Would recommend this place to anyone that has time in NOLA. Just remember, this place can also be quite pricey, depending how much is ordered.

Fantastic fried alligator! The gumbo was on the salty side but I pretty much always think gumbo is too salty. 

The rabbit stew tasted funny to me but I think that was a matter of preference. The Mac and cheese was spot on!

This place was really a let down.  Service was absolutely appalling, music choice was hip hop/rap horrible,  and the whole restaurant was so deafeningly loud my party could not hear each other or carry on a conversation.  I had been looking forward to this dinner and coming across country from Seattle,  I expected an incredible meal experience.  The dishes were good, especially the pork.  We never really knew which server was ours.  Anthony Bourdain reviewed this place and really enjoyed it but he must have gone when he was there alone.  I can't stress enough how overrated this place is - not worth the positive reviews AT All - don't go!
Good food, well priced, but a little confusing dealing with wait team and the order was messed up, but the staff proactively took measures to make things right!

This place is a longtime favorite. We no longer live in Nola but still have a condo in town so we are back at least once a year. This is one of our first stops every time. Love the Cochon pineapple upside down cake rolls eggplant catfish .....really everything is delicious. Last time we were there someone in my party said their pork was s little dry. Not only did they remake dish immediately but they gave everyone at table comped desserts. That is Nola hospitality

Had a few cocktails and the boucherie plate, it was delicious; the tartan, headcheese...everything.  I told the bartender I had an egg allergy and he substituted one of the meats for summer sausage....love Chef Link everything he cranks out is amazingly fresh and consistent

Modern Cajun should be a thing in every city because Cochon delights and tantalizes with its unique creations. A breakdown:

Wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter: Amazing sauce
Fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise: Good for those looking to try gator without knowing they're eating gator
Chicken & andouille gumbo: A bit too salty
Catfish courtbouillon: Tender and flavorful, easily my favorite
Smoked ham hock with gold rice, field peas & pickled peppers: Not bad, but not my favorite. I found the ham overcooked
Twice-baked stuffed potato: Twice-baked deliciousness
Hummingbird Cake with bourbon anglaise: Amazeballs of sweetness

Drinks? Get the Cold Blooded (vodka, basil, lime, habanero bitters, blood orange, San Pellegrino) to refresh yourself. Service is a bit hit and miss, the only downside to an otherwise fantastic meal experience.

Discovered this place from Yelp. The reviews are accurate. This place is excellent. First time I tried fried alligator, it was awesome. The menu is seasonal so some of the items you see featured here may not be on the menu.

I really enjoyed the selection of root beers.

Wood-fired oysters. Arugula salad, shaved pig's head & capers w/ tomato vinaigrette. Paneed pork cheeks with mushrooms & lemon. Smoked hock with peas and rice. Cochon with cabbage, cracklins & peaches. 

And I'm supposed to choose?

But because I was already waiting for my Uber, I went just with wood-fired oysters.. and oh. my.  Stuff them into my mouth!  I was trying to exercise restraint but all four? five? of them popped right down the throat.  Smoky, plump, juicy with just the right flavoring enough to season but not disturb the natural flavors of them oysters themselves - these were oysters grilled to perfection. 

This is unfortunately the only thing I had the time to taste here, but I know I'll be back the next time I'm in NOLA!

Terrible parking - just Uber there!

FYI, we are not from New Orleans. We're not even from an East coast state. Were from Las Vegas. Soo.. this is a western suburb girl reviewing southern local food!

We wanted cajun/creole food and have already been to ACME and Drago's. We wanted to try something new, so we found ourselves at Cochon! 

The restaurant looked promising, it was bustling with people. We didnt realize how popular it was until the hostess asked if we had a reservation. We didn't. So we gave her our name and hung out at the bar.

We tried some local beer.. Abita strawberry brew or something like that. Nice and light but I'm not a beer person.. then the hostess came to seat us!

We tried the fried alligator which tasted like chicken calamari if you can imagine it! It was sweet tangy but some pieces a good chew to it. Overall good though.

We also tried the deviled egg gumbo. It had a rich smoky flavor to it.. it was good.. but I don't like when gumbo is smoky. Not sure if that's offensive or anything but... yeah.

The beef brisket with horseradish potato was good. Very tender, nice flavor, but not salty enough in my opinion. 

And the best thing on the menu.. definitely had to be the wood-fried oysters. Soo delicious. I was expecting it to be similar to the charboiled oysters from Drago's but it was entirely different. There was yummy salty flavorful salty garlic oil. My only thing against them was that it only came with 6 tiny oysters!

Yum!

We were in NOLA for the Krewe of Boo weekend. Basically, H and I walked alongside the parade route to get from our hotel to Cochon, which was a lot of fun.

We had to wait for a few minutes before our table was ready (which was fine, but also kind of annoying considering we'd made a reservation). I ordered a Crispin cider (which came out in a gigantic bottle - yes, I finished all 22 oz. on my own) while H opted for her classic gin martini.

We decided to share five small plates. We got the fried alligator, the boudin balls, pork cheeks, grits, and slow-cooked shrimp. Everything was delicious. The fried alligator had fennel and mint mixed in, which was a pleasant surprise that brightened up the heavy, fried breading. The alligator itself was tossed in a spicy sauce, which I thought was delicious and though a few pieces were kind of chewy, I'm glad I can say I've eaten gator. The boudin was awesome and definitely something I want to try more of. The pork cheeks were super tender and probably the star of the meal. The shrimp was spiced well, though the portion size was a little underwhelming, and the grits served as a nice carb to help balance out our protein-laden meal.

Overall, the food was superb and the staff were really accommodating and kind. I had actually called ahead to ask if it would be weird that we were in costume (since we had planned on walking down to the Monster Mash after our meal) and the hostess responded, "Uh, this is New Orleans. Anything you wear is fine."

Can I give this place 6 stars? There is absolutely nothing bad on the menu. Hell, there isn't even anything mediocre on the menu. Every.single.dish we tried was exceptional. It was so good, we went back the very next day.

As a Texan, it shames me to admit that the best ribs I've ever had were from Louisiana. The smoked pork ribs were...perfection. Just a little bit crispy with a wonderful sauce - vinegar based? Likewise, the fried liver, gumbo, mushroom salad, and smoked ham hock were all incredible. 

Service was friendly, affable and shockingly quick. Both days we went, Cochon was packed, yet all of our plates arrived minutes after we ordered. You won't get out of here inexpensively, but that's mostly because the menu seems to order itself. I found myself sounding like a child reciting their Christmas list to Santa; "I want this, and this, and this, and one of these..."

Just go to Cochon, it's incredible.
Had an unbelievable rabbit and dumplings. Table mates had pork cheek and white bean "salad" and an oyster and bacon sandwich. All were delicious. I'll be back.

It needs to be mentioned that a mediocre restaurant in New Orleans is likely a 5 star rating in most other cities because the level of food execution is so high here.  Thus, a 5 star rating in N.O. Is reaching outer worldly limits.  Cochon deserves a 5 star rating.  The oyster and bacon sandwich was sinfully delicious.  Plump, deep fried oysters, ultra thick cut bacon, shredded lettuce and sliced green pickled tomatoes lie between two butter grilled slices of house baked white bread.  Sort of a bastard child from a BLT, grilled cheese & oyster poboy.  The turkey and kale gumbo was an interesting take on this traditional soup.

Food is good, the service is just terrible.  We were pretty much ignored the entire time.  We didn't get bread like all the other tables around us and when we asked about it, it took until the end of the meal to finally come.  Several other tables that arrived after us and got the same amount of food as us left well before us.  When we got the bill, we told the server we were in a rush and he still took his time.  This place has such potential if they could be timely

Food was good but not great, especially for the price. The side of Lima beans, cooked with bacon, was our favorite item.  The redfish broiled fisherman a style was delicious. The chess pie was very disappointing, as was the pork chop special. Service was mediocre at best.

If you love oysters, I'd recommend the oyster and bacon sandwich - it's the best 20 dollars you'll ever spend, in my opinion.  They used to list a certain cocktail that went with it very well, but ask the bartender and I'm sure they'll suggest a drink to pair perfectly with it.  Other must try's (if you're into the same foods):  the wood fired oysters with chili garlic butter, pork cheeks and catfish,  The meat pie seemed to be a favored dish, but I never tried.  It always looked so good, maybe next time I'm back for a visit.

Now this place had some fantastic food. The wait was a lil rediculus 1.5 hr for a table, but shows how food this place is. We ended up at the bar before the hostess texted us for a table. Ordered drinks and some gator to start, gator was a lil chewy but good. I ordered the Louisiana cochon, which was flavor intense. I was blown away. Service was very good and staff was on there game. Highly recommended.

We made a reservation for a Monday dinner, and were seated promptly despite the place being pretty packed.  Great service.  I had their speciality pork chop which was fantastic.  Menu is not huge: maybe 5 or 6 choices for each course.  Small plates are good for sharing.  Cocktails were excellent.  Place has a bit of the Brooklyn hipster vibe.

This was the worst dining experience I had in New Orleans by far. We were immediately greeted and sat. Our waiter brought us water to drink, and then went M.I.A. for the next 15-20 minutes. Then he took our drink order. Drinks came and he disappeared yet again for another 20 minutes before taking our food order. We had the alligator appetizer, Mac and cheese casserole, boucherie plate, and the pork cheeks. If there was anything good about this place, it's that the food was excellent. However, we ended up waiting 45 minutes for our food. Normally, I would've thought they maybe they were just running behind or under-staffed that night. But that wasn't the case. Other tables around us were receiving much faster service. In fact, I counted 10 tables that were served and seating new groups while we just sat there mostly ignored. We also never got the complimentary rolls with our meal (which they provided other tables quickly) until I had to ask for it when our food came out. Our water was refilled only once throughout the entire time we were there. I found it funny that the only time they were quick on anything was when it came to the check. The food was also rather pricey for what we got, but I can't complain about the quality. 

We spent around 90 minutes in this place being absolutely ignored by the serving staff. As we were running late for a tour by that point, I didn't get a chance to speak to their management about our treatment. This was one of the worst dining experiences I've ever had in my life, and ended our New Orleans trip on a very sour note.

Great appetizers, main dishes and desserts.  Atmosphere great with a variety of customers.  Service was excellent.  Mainly pork based dishes as you'd expected but enough sides dishes and soups that the vegetarian in our party was well fed.

One of the biggest food snobs I've ever met told me that the rabbit and dumplings from here were the best meal he's *ever* had.  So, of course, I had to make a special trip here on my visit to New Orleans.  I decided rabbit is delicious, I just have to not think of cute little bunnies.  It was seriously one of the best dishes ever.  It was a tad spicy, and I'm a wimp with spiciness, but I didn't care.  The mac n cheese casserole was also great, as was the pork cheek.  Definitely recommend a visit if you are anywhere near the New Orleans area.  Oh, and make reservations at least days in advance.

This is our last night in New Orleans and we wanted something special.  It's Monday night.  We tried to make a reservation and they gave us 10 pm slot which was the last sitting.  We came here at 9:30 pm and waited for 15 mins to be seated.  We ordered the wood fired oyster, smoked pork rib, ham hock and cauliflower as side dish. All of them were perfect!!  What a great ending for our New Orleans vacation!

We visit NOLA once a year and ate here during our last visit.

Upon arrival we were checked in and asked to wait at the bar just left of where you walk in. The bar was crowded, it was mid week about 530pm. As we were ordering our cocktail the hostess came by to seat us but saw we were just about to have our cocktails - she said no rush and that she would be back shortly. We liked that. 

A few minutes later the hostess returned and we were seated in the center of the dining room. We noted that there was an open kitchen at the back and thought that might be nice to sit at next time. The place is a large dining area with an open kitchen at one end and the bar alongside. Tables are wooden type picnic style with comfortable seats and there were a few large parties around us. A bit loud - ok with us.

Our server was a jovial fellow who was happy to elaborate about the chef, the food and himself. All good. 

We ordered a handful of appetizers. We usually do this at our first visit to a restaurant as it give us a chance to sample the chef's offerings and also test the server and serving line. The pork cheek was great as was the alligator. There were no appetizers we did not enjoy. For our main we got the pork shoulder - only one between us. It was fabulous the meat fell from the bone and the flavoring was perfect. We had a few beers with the meal. Service was very good.

It was cold at our table. We understand that on a warm evening the a/c will be cranked. But it seemed as if we were right under a vent. Shortly after we were seated I had a word with the hostess who came by our table and immediately lowered the a/c. It was quite comfortable afterwards.

This is a good place and a good value as well. I do not understand the comments about price being high. We thought the pricing was spot on and a very good value. There are plenty of places in NOLA where you can spend much more and get much less.

We will likely come back to dine here next spring.

We give the place an "A". 

Mark & Nancy.

Maybe my wife and I had high expectations because of all the high reviews we read about this place. We ordered the grilled oysters, alligator in chili aoli sauce, bbq ribs, pork cheeks and beans and the grits. They were all tapas or small plate sizes. Overall, the food was alright but comparing the food we had here to the other places we went to in NOLA, the food seemed a little bland or not enough seasoning. But we would still come here again since the service was great

I'm remarkably disappointed thus far. If I'd have know that a reservation time didn't mean anything to the restaurant then I'd have gone to one of the other many fantastic alternatives. It gets two stars because I did manage to fight my way to the bar for a reasonably tasty bourbon-based cocktail, but honestly, there is plenty of good food to be had in the neighborhood without being ignored for those willing to flirt with the hostess.

Had an awesome dinner here with friends.  I am currently following a vegan diet, which can be difficult when dining with a large group.  The chef made a special vegan meal for me that was amazing!  Service was great as well!

Great atmosphere, amazing staff, appetizers were delicious boudin balls and meat pie a must! Cocktails were fantastic! Fridays guys (Miles was great!!!) behind the bar were helpful,  happy, and attentive!!
This is a great place. especially if your a fan of meat. You can do no wrong regardless of your order. Everything is fantastic. Not cheap, but not expensive either. Let your server help you order.

Dined alone last night (as I'm here for work), so I was seated right at the kitchen bar. It was so exciting watching the chefs prepare the food in their wood-fire oven and the aroma just made me hungry. Beware that your clothes and hair will smell like wood fire. 

Appetizer: I started with the fried liver on toast garnished with pepper jelly, mint leaves and onion. It seems like they were small piece of fried pate on toast (and I love pate). However, the pepper jelly was overly sweet and took away from the taste of the liver. I was a bit disappointed with this dish, but I nonetheless I ate it all. I probably won't order it again.

For entree: I had the rabbit & dumplings. That is one popular dish as I see the chef prepare batches at a time over and over again. It was delicious! There was a bit of a kick to it, and I can definitely taste the ginger needed because of the natural gamey flavor that the rabbit meat gives off. The rabbit meat was tender just like really good chicken meat. The "dumplings" were very light, pillowy, little breads. Definitely the ultimate comfort food for winter. I also ordered the shrimp & eggplant dressing that tasted much better as leftovers (as I had it boxed up for next day's lunch). 

The customers next to me had ordered 2 of the wood-fire broiled oysters. It was good. The garlic chili vinegar was delicious and I loved dipping my bread into it. I wish there were more of the sauce. Oysters weren't bad, but I definitely prefer raw oysters. 

Dessert: I had the coconut lime sherbert and it was the perfect ending to dinner. 2 scoops. It was light and citrus flavor. They even served it with a sugar cookie in the shape of a pig. Delicious.

Very disappointed given the reviews I've read on Yelp.  Maybe I ordered the wrong thing.  Short wait despite our reservations.  Very nice and modern restaurant in a restored brick building.  The mixed green salad was OK.  I had the louisiana cochon, which is the special of the place.  It was just OK.  I tried the fish special which was OK.  The mac and cheese was good.  I should have gone conservative and had the gumbo.  Chocolate Chess Pie was good.  

Maybe I ordered the wrong thing.  Service was fine.  Super busy restaurant.

Came here for my cousin's bachelorette dinner.  We had reservations for 15 and got seated immediately.

Anyway. I ordered the catfish courtbouillon and the wood-fired oyster roast.  I didn't care too much for the catfish but the oysters were sooo GOOD.  I just wanted to eat that all night.  Too bad they only give you 5 oysters ):  

I wasn't brave enough to try the fried alligator but some of my friends tried and it and they said it tastes just like chicken but better?!  Whatever that means.

I wanted to give this place 4 stars but the host was pretty much being rude and wanted us to leave since we were there a little over closing.  Truth is, we were pretty much done eating just waiting to get our credit cards back so we can sign and leave the place.  

So yeah, 3 stars.  I don't think I would come here ever again.

Given the reviews, we had high hopes for Cochon. Starting with the wood fired oysters, I found them bland and overly saturated with butter. I preferred the Acme ones. My sis and I both ordered the louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklins & pickled peaches $24. I like my food hot and this was lukewarm at best. The cracklin was yummy, but again not even warm. The pork was tasty but would have benefited from an up in temperature. All in all, not impressed with this dish. We ordered 2 coffees and a pineapple upside down cake. Our coffee came immediately but the cake took 10 minutes which defeated the purpose of having coffee with our dessert. What I really disliked about Cochon was the speed with which our experience unfolded:  break neck speed. Our plates from the appetizer had not even been completely cleared when another server appeared with the lukewarm entrees. The coffee and dessert was poorly timed and the absolute worst part of all of this was the placement of the bill on our table while we were finishing the pineapple upside cake (which was ok but nothing spectacular, by the way.) I didn't request the bill and I find it incredibly rude to have the bill placed on my table while I'm still eating, unless of course I'm sitting at a counter in a coffee shop/diner. This is especially true in a restaurant where the combined bill with tip  $140. It is obvious Cochon is supremely interested in turning the tables over and not providing the diner with an experience warranting a repeat visit. My final comment is this: Both my sister and I spent half the night in the bathroom with stomach aches and digestive "episodes," something that can only be attributed to the food at Cochon. A friend in New Orleans shared she had heard of others having a similar gastrointestinal postscript after dining at Cochon. I cannot recommend this restaurant.

Doing a little traveling with some friends before we leave for deployment. We happened to stumble upon this lovely place. Ribs were nothing special, the tuna and gumbo were delicious!!!! Full recommendation of the fried alligator. The service was superb. 
After we left we did a little research and saw that normally you need a reservation- we went around 2-230 ish- no wait. Completely in love w the menu and the area

My lunch here was lovely. I sat at the bar and the atmosphere is very comfortable but still trendy. I had the alligator bites and the mac and cheese - both were very yummy. I'd definitely go back for a big dinner option next time.

Cool space; the semi open kitchen fills the large dining room with a tantalizing aroma as you enter. The menu is incredible; unique and so many amazing sounding dishes. Definitely hearty, comfort food - recommend arriving hungry! Portions were larger than expected and prices are quite the bargain considering the quality and quantity. My wife and I ordered the fried alligator, smoked pork ribs, rabbit & dumplings and an oyster and bacon sandwich. The pork ribs were absolutely fantastic; tender, juicy, flavorful - among the best ribs I have consumed anywhere! The rabbit and dumplings were like a gourmet, deconstructed pot pie. The garlic chili sauce for the fried alligator tasty, possessed a kiss of heat and balanced the slight gaminess of the gator. The only miss was the sandwich; the oysters somehow seemed to have become water logged and had an unpleasant texture and off taste. Service was adequate,  though not so good as to enhance the dining experience. Definitely a venue I'd like to return to next time I am in NOLA to partake in more of the menu and possibly check out next door sister venue, Cochon Butcher.

Cochon is one of those staples that you just cannot miss. This is one of the most important restaurants that serve up great New Orleans cuisine at it's finest. 

The wood-fired oysters are a must. The chili garlic butter is out of this world. These oysters are charred to perfection and have the smokey taste from the process being grilled. The garlic butter is melted throughout the oyster and is addicting!! I swear I can just pour all that butter into all my seafood platters and it'll do the job.

The alligator bites were amazing too! These were the best gator bites I've had in N.O. The texture is much tender and is fried to perfection and not that mushy breaded texture. This is crispy and golden. The dipping sauce of the chili garlic goes great too! So make sure you get two things here: Wood-fired oysters & gator bites!

It was a bit of a miss for us: food was good but the service was miserable.  We were in town for our honeymoon and made reservations for Cochon at the recommendation of a friend.  We ate the day before at Cochon Butcher and really enjoyed both the food and service.  We had the wood-fired oysters, Louisiana cochon and rabbit & dumplings.  The beer that we ordered when we first sat down showed up late and flat.  The oysters were drowning in sauce and completely smothered the oyster...my non-seafood eating wife tried one and really liked it exactly because she couldn't taste the oyster.  The cochon was good, and I liked the rabbit and dumplings as well.  We flagged down a server and ordered the 2nd round of beers and waited and waited...it finally showed up as our dishes were being cleared.  Oh I almost forgot, someone from Cochon kept calling and hanging up without leaving a voicemail to confirm our reservation.  I will not eat here again.
Loved it.  Crab bisque was the soup of he day...perfect.  Mac & cheese, fried alligator & oysters were awesome.

While in New Orleans for work, a colleague and I decided to visit Cochon. I had heard great things and wanted to try it out. 

When we arrived, the hostess told us it would be a 20 minute wait. She offered the alternative of either sitting outside or at the bar. However, I didn't want either of those options, so we elected to wait. I was surprised, because there were at least 4 empty tables in the restaurant. The hostess said those were for reservations.

After about 30 minutes, we were again offered a table outside or a seat at the bar. They also said they might be able to seat us sooner at the chefs table. However, I wanted a more relaxed dining experience. They then told us we could eat at cochon butcher next door. But we had already waited for a while, so we decided to stay.

15 minutes later, we were seated (the moral: make a reservation). 

The server came by shortly. He didn't volunteer much information, until we started asking specific questions about items on the menu.

We ordered the shrimp appetizer, which was incredible.

I ordered the cochon, which was also very good. It has a sweet sauce, which I enjoyed.

My colleague ordered the catfish, which she loved. She said she would come back again to order that.

We also ordered a side of smothered greens, which was underwhelming. We didn't finish them. 

Over all, the food was really great. However, the service is just not up to par.

#We split a bunch of different things. And the #Grits and #Collard Greens are some of the best I've ever had. So good. I didn't care for the #Cochon pork entree. But #Grits and #Greens well made up for it. Those are like six-star items. The Cochon pork was like 3. So I'll give this a five.

Food was delicious and service was great. I recommend making reservations if you are planning to go for dinner.  

If you love ribs. You won't be disappointed. Some of the best ever!  The wood-fired menu is simple and amazing!
The place to be for good meat. We tried the fried alligator and were positively surprised. Really nice chic minimalistic place.

Must try when visiting Nola. Nola cuisine can get as fancy or cheap depending on your budget. For my first night here, I decided to try something more upscale. We made a reservation and got seated right away after being 15 minutes late. My favorite thing is the bread!!!! It was similar to a sweet roll and was so steamy and soft. The fried alligator was lightly battered with a creamy spicy sauce and the rabbit n dumplings were also a favorite. Rabbit tastes more like turkey than chicken. The fried pork cheeks, gumbo, and oyster n bacon sandwich were tasty as well! For a group of 3 we paid $150 for the bill with a drinks. Don't forget to grab some free match boxes on your way out!

I don't understand why this place has attracted so much attention. The restaurant is quite noisy at dinner time even from a casual dinning standard. We had fried alligator for appetizer, which was fun for us first/timer. The taste was great, but could be better with less dressing. For entrees, we had Cochon's signature pork cracklings with pickled cabbage and fried oyster sandwich. Neither was impressive. The former was simply a huge dump of tasteless pulled pork sitting on pickled cabbage, surrounded by pieces of fried pork skin. The three ingredients did't even fuse with each other at all. The fried oysters were pretty good but unfortunately, the sandwich was over-dressed again.
Excellent restaurant with extremely creative dishes, reasonably priced given the quality. Order as many as "small plates" as possible to let your taste buds to have an exciting experience.

All I can say is OH MY GOODNESS that was delish! We are completely stuffed also; good thing we can walk it off! We started off with the alligator bites and moved to the boudin balls, grits, mac and cheese, and greens. Everything was equally as good as the next and then came the pork ribblets.... we're  seriously going into a food coma after this meal! For me this is the best food we've devoured all trip! 5 Stars Cochon!

This was our first stop during our New Orleans trip. It was really delicious! We had the "Hey Jill" cocktail, the gulf shrimp appetizer, and the Louisiana Cochon for dinner. The Mac n cheese is out of this world! We had a reservation. It might be a good idea to make one before you come. Definitely recommend.

The theme of our dinner was, "Oh boy, that's salty." 

We ordered the gumbo, the baked oysters, and the fried alligators to share between the two of us. The alligator meat was TOUGH. Like, I need to chew twenty extra seconds to swallow this  tough. I think the kitchen tried to play up the batter and I could taste a little kick, but the alligator meat itself wasn't tenderized enough (is that even possible?). I think if the alligator was pounded out and served as a katsu, it might have been better? We didn't finish this dish.
The gumbo was served with wilted kale, but it was so salty that the taste of kale, let alone any other ingredient, was lost. We probably had half of the bowl between the two of us. 

We were very excited about the baked oysters because we sat by the kitchen and saw them prepare this. The oysters themselves are quite fresh... if you can get over the salt-content of the sauce. I think oysters are too delicate to hold their own against a sauce like that. That sauce would have been better on wild rice or gnocchi. But definitely, not oysters.

Three stars though for the delicious, buttery dinner rolls and the amuse bouche on the house.

"Deliciousness" was the theme. The food is simply wow. Favorites: 

- Wood fired oysters, great texture and flavor.
- Fried livers with pepper jelly and toast, had never had fried liver but it was delicious! The jelly and mint on top made it. Total package plate. We ordered another.
- Mac and cheese, prepare for richness.
- Fried cauliflower, wow.

Also: mimosas plus mimosas TO GO. And great service. Thanks, Angie!

Highly recommended!!

Absolutely delicious food!  Cochon does a great job of mixing the flavors and style of New Orleans food with skilled cooking.  The oysters and aligator bite apps were delicious.  Roasted Fish fisherman's style was perfectly cooked and seasoned.  The pork cheeks were also tasty.  The mac and cheese is not to be missed, and the eggplant and shrimp dressing was creative and fantastic as well!  I thought the dessert menu was slightly disappointing - nothing that made me think I must try it, but they did have a lot of variety.  My only reason for giving four stars rather than five is that while the staff was very professional and efficient, I didn't see anyone who really came across as striving to deliver an outstanding experience to the customers.  They got the job done very well, but i got the feeling that they saw the people at each table as a commodity to be moved along rather than guests in a restaurant they were hosting.

A great friend of mine, Jim Estelette, suddenly passed away the day after Thanksgiving.  I promptly drove from Huntsville, Alabama to New Iberia, La to bury a unbelievably dear friend.   On the way back, I stopped in New Orleans at Cochon's restaurant.   I explained to the waitress why I was in New Orleans.    I told her, in broad generalities, what types of foods I  liked and that I was stopping in to have a Cajun/Creole meal in honor of my friend.   I asked her to select my wine, appetizer, soup and entree based on my likes.   She was so understanding and did a spectacular job of making sure my dining experience was truly fantastic.   The food was amazing and the wine was paired to perfection.    I will definitely be back.
Go... just GO! 'Nuff said. Oh and plllllllllllllllllllllease open a Cochon's in Austin!!!

Loved the food! I can't believe I forgot to review this place. I was in a hurry and ordered a cup of gumbo the eggplant dressing and the smothered greens!  Absolutely Delicious! It was so good I packed it up and took it on the plane. Reheated the next day and hubby could not believe how tasty it was! Not only would I return but I have recommended it to others.

One word :delicious
If you're willing to pay a little bit more than usually, it's really worth it!
I got the alligator bites and a side potato, and that was awesome! ($12 for alligator and $7 for the potato without tips and taxes)
I red on a lot of websites that they had the best gator bites of NOLA. I don't know if it's the best because it's the only one I tried, but that was very good.

The restaurant itself is also very nice.

We ate here last night and had a superlative dining experience. Simply amazing.

I started with an appetizer portion of the pork ribs with barbecue sauce and pickled watermelon rind. The watermelon was cut into tiny pieces and effectively became part of the sauce. That made for a balance of salty, sweet, smokey, and slightly tart. I could have made an entire meal of just that sauce! LOVED it!

Next, my wife and I split a pork shank that had been slowly braised for hours. To call it fall-off-the-bone tender would be an understatement. Soft and tender, but still plenty moist as well.

We and our dining partners also had a couple of sides including the creamy grits.

Oh, and I got us a bottle of a southern Rhône wine (Gigondas) to wash down the meal, which it did nicely. The wine list itself, while just one (two-sided) page, certainly had enough for pretty much anyone to find something nice, without breaking the bank.

The ambiance was lively, but not so loud we couldn't talk. People all around were friendly, talking, and laughing. The settings were comfortable, but not pretentious or otherwise off-putting. The wait staff were attentive, knowledgeable, prompt, and friendly. One of our guests found her meal to be too cool for her liking. They quickly corrected the problem and removed her meal from our bill.

I'd be hard pressed to think of things that Cochon should be doing better. The food, ambiance, service, etc., were all spot on. I'd not only come back on our future trips, but I'm happy to declare this a "MUST GO" ever time we're in town. (Geaux Saints!)

I should add that I'd made our reservations using OpenTable. Our table was ready on time -- 5 minutes early, even. I did notice a few walk-ins were being told their wait would exceed an hour, but that's their fault for not making reservations.

Fabulous, all around!!! I'd give them 6 stars if I could.

Food here is delicious. I'm a fan of fish, and the redfish is good, but I wouldn't spend that kind of money again on it. GET THE ALLIGATOR, it's the best I've ever had. The pork is great and the rabbit dumplings amazing also. Finally, the signature cocktails are worth the $. This location is convenient if you're at the convention center and if you can use Open Table to get a reservation, I would definitely suggest you do so.

This place is awesome!! The food is terrific and the service is too. We sat at the bar at the more casual area. Ordered the bbq pork sandwich which was delicious, the Brussels sprouts, Mac n cheese. For dessert it was a bacon praline and a apple walnut pocket pie. We also ordered a couple of their signature drinks that were delish! We were getting so sick of the usual seafood and sauce, Cochon did not disappoint and was amazing bbq.
I would highly recommend it.
Great atmosphere, delicious food.  This was by far the best food we had in New Orleans.

Cochon is one of my favorite restos in  New Orleans when it comes to good Cajun authenticity and is a totem for modern Southern cooking.  Sure there are new delicious and inventive dining that can be experienced at R'evolution & GWFins for example, my  visit here was rewarded with great comfort food, unencumbered, original but modern.   I love it here.  The vibe at Couchon is comfortable, user friendly and the smells from the kitchen make my day fantastic.  

This visit, I tried other items on the menu:

1)  Fried alligator with chili aioli and mint.  This dish was meaty, hearty, lean and deliciously 'gatory' with a crisp crust.   If you haven't had alligator, the flesh is hearty very lean with a consistency between swordfish and chicken breast.   The aioli gave it that tease factor, the mint sent it to the level of sophisticated dishes in Thai cookery.  Sprinkle that with the pepper/vinegar served tableside and you smile.  You just do--  it's really super good.

2)  Rabbit and dumplings.  This beautiful Southern serving came on a cast iron skillet, hot off the oven with browned biscuits, the pan had a rich country white gravy with  bold fresh herbs, thyme, maybe oregano, veggies, nicely done  'chickeny tasting' rabbit meat.  Definitely soul food albeit  a little salty.  Again, I wonder if the chef or person who made this dish smokes cigarettes.

3)  Fig Tarte with Marcarpone Ice Cream---  Geesh God Almighty, how does a Southern resto make a genius Italian-ish dessert.  It was...nicely crusty brioche with figs and apples straight from the oven to table with a genius scoop of mascarpone ice cream.  It was, bite after bite a very satisfying dessert.

**Minus one star.  While the service was attentive and friendly, the chef who made the Rabbit and dumplings overpoured the NaCl or they smoke.   Smokers oversalt  food.  I have this constant problem in Europe and Asia and can tell immediately if the chef is a smoker.    I sent it back and the resto was good enough to comp me.  Chefs who smoke should have a non-smoker taste their food/sauce right after the first seasoning.

Because the food at Cochon is so delicious and inventively good, the service totally fine; I will return.  

Visits:  3

Tip:  Remind your waitperson to make sure your plate is not salty.  Love the vinegar/pepper bottles on tables.  This condiment is perfect on fried plates like the alligator, even the ribs appetizer. They have great cocktails here :))

Really one of the best dining experiences in New Orleans. If you love southern comfort food you'll love this pace and their wine selection. Service is impeccable and their small plates are perfect for sharing. Loved every minute of it!

One of the best food places you can eat in the US.  Been several times.  I have been to banquets upstairs, and the banquet food is tremendous.  Consistently changing menu is always on point, wine well chosen, and the cocktails are mixed expertly.  You cannot go wrong here.

Fun place with great food.  One of the best Bloody Mary's I've ever had and with quite a kick.  The food was Cajun with a nouveau twist and everything paired very well.   The gumbo was quite tasty as was the mac and cheese casserole.  Service was attentive and the atmosphere very upscale and pleasant.   Everyone seemed to enjoy their food and glad we ventured over from the French Quarter.

Definitely worth the 2 minute walk from the convention center.  Yes Cochon Butcher is next door and you can get quick sandwiches.  But if you have more than an hour to kill, I'd recommend going next door to Cochon and sitting at the bar for lunch.  Best thing we ordered were the wood fire grilled oysters.  The garlic sauce doused over the plump oysters was really delicious and I've decided they have my favorite NOLA oysters.  The boudin balls were good, but could be crispier like the ones at Toup's Meatery.  Mac and cheese was quite good, very cheesy and classic.  The pork cheek was delicious with super tender meat and a nice flavor.  It's a shame there are only like 3 pieces hidden underneath all the beans.  I didn't care much for the beans so spent a good amount of time hunting through the beans for a forkful of meat.

Overated, I can't believe the hype and high ratings. One of the most expensive and disappointing meals I have ever had. I'm guessing the herd mentality makes people pile into this joint. We came as a small group and tried about half the menu after reading all the high reviews. I left hungry with food on the table.  Service was mediocre, and the place was mighty expensive. The alligator tail was almost good, but 2nd piece I had was not cooked. I have eaten great food all over the country and all over the world ( and most was a lot cheaper) , but this one was one the biggest let downs I have encountered.

This is one my favorite places in NOLA to eat for that southern style fare. Super professional staff and a nice atmosphere coupled with an amazingly eclectic menu just makes it a perfect for place for lunch or a nice dinner.  Their dishes overwhelm the tastebuds with matched flavors that you might not expect like liver fried livers and pepper jelly or boudin balls and pickled peppers.  The rabbit n dumplings just feels like home and oyster n bacon sandwich although a little small is fat with flavor.  I was lucky enough to get the Ahi Tuna Salad on the day they put it on their Facebook page and it was again a perfect mix of flavors with the tuna done just right.  I recommend it to all my friends and colleagues when they come to visit. Reservations recommended.
Wood Fired oysters... Spicy, savory, Incredible. In fact didn't even bother to order anything else.

This place is a must try at least once.  I had the smoked ham hock and banana pudding. The ham hock was very tender and juicy. I finished my meal off with a delicious banana pudding. I will be back for more.

Overwhelmingly underwhelming and overtly disappointing. 

-Service was fine but not very welcoming or attentive; indifferent would be most accurate.

-Fried Alligator was cooked perfectly in texture but overpowered by the slathering of aioli rendering the crust soggy and masking the delicate alligator flavor.

-Louisiana Cochon was incredibly disappointing. Each component in the dish was too heavily salted. The pork itself a bit dry and the cabbage and pickled turnips overcooked as if the dish were made earlier in the week and reheated in the microwave.

My expectations were high, the service was great the food was average. Our bread was like toast when it arrived at the table. I suspect it sat under a heat lamp for too long. The gator appetizer tasted more of mayo than anything else. Under seasoned. Isn't this New Orleans?!? Don't get the fried liver. Stick with something simple. The cook staff can handle that I'm sure. This place need some TLC from the head chef!

me: I'll have the Horny Goat with Rabbit and Dumplings. brother: the blonde and catfish...waiter "so the Horny goat and a blonde with the rabbit....Okay that sounds weird." 

We loved this place. two people ordered the catfish and all four of us were eating it. The boucherie plate was a great starter. I wanted more meat in my rabbit in dumplings. the server was hilarious. We will come back next time we are in town.

Surprisingly fulfilling.  I started out with the baked oyster with chilli sauce (my favorite) the oyster were fresh tasting and the sauce was garlicky and spicy but at a well balanced ratio. The ingredients were not overwhelming just delightful. I also had the fried alligator, least favorite because the meat is too tough. Luckily the batter was tasteful. Then as an entrée I had the rabbit & dumpling and mac n cheese as a side. The rabbit meat is so soft and mixed in with the gravy sauce and vegetables is delectable. The mac n cheese is delicious too.  Finishing up my dining experience with the apple & fig crostata with Mascarpone ice cream.

Walked in with no reservations and sat us immediately ...probably because its off season, Wednesday evening, and it was raining.
Came here for the gator bites, which were great. The real showstopper though was the smoked ribs with watermelon pickle.
As a vegetarian going to a restaurant named Cochon, this place is pretty darn good. Last time we went I remember the Mac and cheese being amazing. Everyone I talk to has loved this restaurant.

Not worth the $$ money we paid for.  The ambience was great, but the food was so-so  The suggested special - pork chops (16$); had a good smoked flavor, but it was rubbery. The turkey, black Eyed pea and kale gumbo (8$) was tasty,  my wife liked it,  but it was an appetizer.  Fried alligator (12$) wasn't good, compared to other places we have tried in the past. Mac n Cheese (7$) was good,  had rich cheese in it. We went on a Saturday during lunch time.  Overall,  the food was so-so and not worth the money we spent for. 
The ambience was good,

Have to say, really disappointed!!! The starters are ok but the Louisiana Cochon is really bad. Very over salted and the pork is just too dry. The service isn't impressive either. Overall a bad experience.

Phenomenal!!!!!!! 

Visiting New Orleans and came across this place and decided to give it a try because of the reviews! 

I've never tried alligator before nor did it ever cross my mind, but I said screw it I'm trying it for the first time. SO GLAD THAT I TRIED IT AT COCHON FOR THE FIRST TIME. It tastes like chicken to be honest and I would definitely eat it again. Been drooling over the alligator at Cochon since I left Nola! 

The grilled broccoli salad was amazing. Not too soaked in dressing and you can actually taste the grilled flavors in it. For a dish so simple it was great! 

Mac and cheese casserole was good! Beef brisket entree was good, but the winner of the night was the alligator and broccoli salad!

We love this restaurant! We have yet to have a bad meal. On our last visit I ate the rabbit with dumplings. Although I think the herbs could have been toned down, it was still very good. Sometimes a hint of flavor is enough. 

Jean had a pork dish with cracklings on top. I liked it a lot but it is rich. 

Try the grilled oysters and the chicken livers. Don't forget to dunk your homemade hot rolls in the sauce from the oysters. 

This restaurant is a must try if you are visiting NOLA. One of our favorites.

Beware. Our server Andrea added in an additional tip to the amount we authorized to pay. We did not authorize that amount. She was very rude and barely paid attention to us. The restaurant was not busy at the time and servers were just standing around and we did not get great service. 

The food was good and unique. However, the service overshadowed the good food.
Loved their rabbit dumplings.... It reminds you of a good chicken pot pie.. Must have when in NOLA..

Highlights: 1) Reserve a spot before you show up or be prepared to wait for at least an hour.
2) On the house breads are really good.

This place is a bit overpriced for what they offer.
Appetizers portions are barely good for one person.
- wood-fired oysters:  good.
- gulf shrimp, potatoes: All you get is 4-5 shrimps and may be 2 small pieces of potatoes. Not worth the price.
- catfish courtbouillon: Loved it. Its a fair portion compared to others I ordered.
- rabbit & dumplings: I am still not convinced it had rabbit meat. Other than that it was pretty above average.

Ambience:3/5 
Food: 3.5/5
Service: 4/5

BOTH COCHON AND BUTCHER ARE OVERRATED!!!
Had ribs at Cochon with a cocktail that has grapefruit San Pellegrino with my husband. The ribs were dry, sauce was nothing special, complimentary pork skin with syrupy sauce was nasty and had bad smell to it. Oh, when I asked more of San Pellegrino in my cocktail to make it lighter, the waitress said "oh, then you should order a can of San Pellegrino." Really? And it took forever almost 25 mins to get a check and get it back after we were done eating. My waitress was busy throwing jokes with other customers when I was literally staring at her from about 4 feet away. Nobody came to fill out our water, staffs were just walking around taking orders with no aftercare, and I had to almost yell at one of the staff to get an attention to get my check. Awful and very unpleasant!

And then we moved over to Butcher with disappointment from Cochon. My hubby ordered Carolina BBQ sandwich, I order pork belly one, and an order of boudin. The BBQ sandwich was again nothing special, the pork belly sandwich was cold and so disgusting from dripping grease and unseasoned pickled cucumber between the bread. Boudin was just okay as well. I can't believe how this place got so many good reviews when I think they deserve only 2 stars. 

Overall I feel like I wasted anout 50 bucks for the food that is not even worth 20 bucks. Staffs were not helpful, the food was mediocre, and overall experience was just disaster! 
What? Best sandwich place in NOLA? I rather go to Subway and order meatball sub or something, rather than coming here, wait for half an hour for nothing, and end up getting overpriced & overrated food. Ewww!
Stupidly good. Not sure what else to say other than the best place I've eaten in NOLA.!

This was the first place we ate at during our trip to NOLA, and all in all pretty good.

I made reservations at 8pm... And we waited and waited and weren't able to be seated until 9:15ish.   It was a little upsetting since I did make reservations... And we stood right outside the door so there was no way I missed my name. I think they literally just forgot us. To try and make up for the long wait they gave us complimentary moonshine shots, so a star for that! However we were STARVING by the time we sat down, and we had to hurry because last call was at 9:30!

Everyone's favorite dish was the fried alligator... YUM!!! I wish we ordered more!!! We also got the rabbit and dumplings, cochon (obviously), oysters (yum!!), and boudin (groups 2nd favorite). Could've done without the rabbit and dumplings, but everything else was tasty!

Wish the wait wasn't so bad, but I appreciate how they tried to make up for it. Also wish we weren't seated so close to last call so we could've ordered more fried alligator!! It's a must try!!

Very flavorful and great service. The Beef Brisket was one of the top 3 plates I had in the city, excellent flavor and soft texture. The pork ribs were also good. Make reservations if going there on a weekend.

Delicious meal!  We couldn't get reservations for 11 for dinner but was lucky enough to get a table for lunch once they opened.  We thought we will leave some room and go to butcher next door and get more food but left so full and satisfied, we couldn't possibly fit another bite in.  We ordered the most delicious oysters, the alligator meat, the rabbit and dumplings which I didn't have but group raved about it!  The ribs, the Pork cheek, double potatoes, fried cauliflower, beets were all so good!

We came for lunch, it seemed like there was no separate lunch menus so prices were still as high as they would be for dinner but it was less crowded which was great. They had amazing service, incredible food and some of the best mixed drinks we've ever had.

5 stars for dinner except for the hummingbird cake, which has no hummingbird parts inside (but seriously don't get it- mine was stale and unflavorful). Get everything else though! Especially the baked oysters and fried gator (which was not awkward at all to eat even after going on a swamp tour earlier in the day and holding a cute baby gator). Hostess that night had her act together and was on top of the wait list, even coming over to us several times to apologize for the long wait time.
Very trendy. Very select menu - mostly pork items. The Mac and cheese was to die for!

Holy Jesus- best meal of 2015. We're from the Bay Area and eat at San Francisco spots as well as high end Napa and Sonoma restaurants. The food we had here outshines most things we've had...EVER. 

Alligator- delicious.

Mac and cheese- top of the percentile, but even the best mac n' cheese is nothing to make a trip thousands of miles for IMO. 

Ham hocks - essence of all that is good with pork, pickled greens are insane as part of this dish. 

Beef- the spices are unique and make this dish my husband and I's top pick. All the things were top notch but this blew us away. 

Note- don't think cocktails are anything to write home about, but that is not why you come here so who cares? Get some to complete the ambiance but don't put too much weight on them. 

Didn't have dessert, which looked quite good, - or the ribs or oysters or a few other things people mentioned but for 2 people it was more food than our belt or waist bands could handle, so take that with a grain of salt (just do what you feel, hoping you'll have the same high satisfaction with whatever you choose). 

Cheers. 
Be hungry, order with your eyes and be excited to eat at this amazing, fantastic food.

Prepared to wait at least an hour if not more. At least they lit you sit at the bar while you wait, but I'm not much for drinking so that's irrelevant to me. 

Touring NOLA so I wanted to try out popular local stuff like the fried alligator and rabbit dumplings. Also tried the cochon, because that's their name so why not. 

The highlight for me was the alligator coating... Crispy and bright acid flavors. It was almost like a buffalo boneless chicken... Except it's alligator. The meat is a bit like chicken, just chewier. 

I did not see what was so special about the rabbit & dumplings or the cochon. The dumplings seemed out of place to mix with an OK pot pie. Cochon was also insignificant, just a basic pulled pork formed into a patty. 

We did, however, like the complimentary buttered dinner rolls. Better than other places, and you can help yourself to seconds for free ish...

Giving this place one star because I can't go any lower. 
Were quoted 20 minute wait, actually ended up waiting over 45. 
Went to the bar for a nice bottle of Champagne, when our named was called we were offered a seat at the Chef's counter. Chef's counter!!! We could've had lunch at the bar 40 minutes ago. 
Ordered the char grilled oysters and they were cold in the middle, second order came and they were cold again. 
Going by our appetizers, we canceled our entrees, did not want to take a chance on luke warm entrees. 
The manager came by with a very insincere apology. 
It's sad we couldn't eat at a reputable establishment and did not get treated accordingly.  

The bartenders were very nice, but we will probably not be going back.

Decided to run over for lunch during our day at the WWII Museum. I should have made a reservation, but totally forgot! (You gotta remember to do that - the line was crazy!)

I had the special of the day - the fried fish sandwich with nice vinegar-y slaw. My husband had the Broccoli salad and black eyed pea gumbo. He loved it.

The temperature had dropped the day we were there - we stupidly said yes to the outside seating. Don't do it. The heaters don't do a thing. So, we were kind of racing to get out of there because we were freezing in the wind.

Make reservations - seriously!

Not impressed at all with this place. It did not live up to its reputation at all! And we chose to come here over Commanders Palace... Big mistake. We were quoted a 20 minute wait time for a table of 2 and waited over 40. Now I know it's technically a Holiday so I tried to give them the benefit of the doubt. Plus I'm in the industry and I know what it's like to quote a particular wait time and have it go over because guest just sit at tables longer than expected. But with that said a little sincerity and an apology would have gone a long way. But we received neither from her. Just an excuse and a promise that we would still be able to eat even thought they were closing extremely early. The hostess did however offer us a seat at the chefs counter after about anther 10 minutes of waiting but we were already sitting at the bar and could have eaten there a long time before that. And I like eating at a table and drinking at the bar.  Plus the bar is boring. You're just looking at a wall of liquor bottles inattentive bartenders. We ordered the grilled oysters to start but they were lukewarm at best. The shells were hot though. I'll give them that.  We sent those back and received another order. But those were also lukewarm. When we informed the bartender that they weren't up to par she immediately notified what looked like a manager. But all that Manager did was bring us a basket of bread that was already advertised as complimentary. When we decided we had had enough and canceled our order, another Manager showed up offering no apology and very little concern for our situation and looked more annoyed that he had to talk to us and offered us more excuses. He just promised that our next course would be better. But judging by the apps. We didn't want to take a chance that our entrees would be as sub par as the oysters. All in all I will never go back and am very disappointed in this Donald Link concept. I've heard so many good things about his cooking and his reputation for creating great southern inspired dishes but it looks like all he cares about now is the money and not the product he stamps his name on. We are actually rethinking visiting his other concepts now because of this really bad visit. We did however enjoy our $100 bottle of Champagne.

I went here with the wife and parents. As expected there were many patrons, even at 2:30pm. 

We ordered the alligator and oysters, which tasted delicious. Then we waited for over 30 minutes for the entree. All the entrees had great presentation and were delectable. We then waited for ~30 minutes for the check. I would say I have definitely had better tasting pulled pork, fish, duck, and hock at lower prices and shorter waits. We didn't order any drinks; I think the experience would have been better if we had.

We came here around 3 with no reservation. We didn't have to wait too long for a seat. I checked out the butcher spot around the corner - that is always another good option if you do not want to wait long. Known for their smoked meats, I didn't see a ton of options in the menu, but definitely enough. Get the oysters. They came with an amazing smoky sauce. We only came for appetizers, but I had food envy seeing plates served to other tables.... Lots of delicious options. Also, they have a number of whiskey taster options.
Loved the food here!! The best is shrimp and eggplant. The kids loved the Mac and cheese casserole!!
Get the oysters in chili oil. Made to perfection. Not under and not rubbery, just perfect and the staff rocks to boot! Luv u!

We came to this place 2 1/2 years ago and loved it! We came to NOLA again this year for NYE and we're lucky to score a reservation and sit again at the chef's counter. Our delicious meal
proves that Cochon has high standards for consistency. Still a FANTASTIC meal, and watching the kitchen work is a hell
If a show! We had the boudin and short ribs for app. WOW! The Cochon dish and the Beef were outstanding, and the shrimp with eggplant dressing is to die for. Their pineapple upside down cake was out dessert 2 1/2 years ago and we had it again. Truly a gem! Small, prefect ending to our meal. Before we left we spoke to the Chef and his staff to thank them. They were very nice to us.  This place is amazing. Make your reservation, and come!

Tip: make a reservation in advance. This place is a bit of a mad house. Probably because the food is amazing. Complimentary fresh rolls were so good we asked for more, but the waitress took forever getting them and ended up packing them in a box for us as we paid the check. We got the fried alligator because when else would we have alligator?? But other than the novelty, we found the meet to be kind of gamey and tough. The fried liver was good, but a TINY portion. What was much better were the wood fired oysters. I could have finished all of them by myself. We also tried the pork cheeks (yummy but small), ham hock (which ended up being a sizable portion of meat), and the boudin (sausage) which was unique and tasty. They DO provide high chairs, but I think bringing our 1 year old out to this restaurant for dinner was a bit ambitious on our part. More of a date place or for young, trendy singles.

We have six ppl and we ordered all different dishes...all were really good. pork cheeks, knuckles, ribs..wood fired oyster, fried alligator, and rabbit and dumplings! highly recommend a large group of ppl and order everything to share!

I made reservation and we were quickly seated on time. We had two servers and the guy was good but the girl was lacking. She hardly came around to check up on us. They also chip out on our free bread. I would have gave them 5 stars. 


Broccoli salad (5/5) - One of the best salad
Char grilled oysters (4/5) - It's more raw than char grilled, but still good. 
Louisiana Cochon (4/5)
Mac and cheese (4/5)
Spicy ginger ale (4/5) 
Bacon and oyster sandwich (3/5) 
Fried pate liver (3.5/5)
Pork ribs (5/5) - it's so good!

Over all, great food but service was lacking.

We came for lunch, it seemed like there was no separate lunch menus so prices were still as high as they would be for dinner but it was less crowded which was great. They had amazing service, incredible food and some of the best mixed drinks we've ever had! We highly recommend the rabbit with dumplings, it was very rich and tasted like a pot-pie. Also the wicked garden mixed drink was a favorite in our group, it tasted like an alcoholic version of a fresh squeezed vegetable juice - very refreshing! Any of the "couchon", or pork dishes are of course what they are known for and many of the words on the menu we had to google to see what they were! We will definitely come back next time we are in town!

This is easily one of the prettier restaurants in NOLA and is slightly off the route from the craziness of Bourbon St. The service was excellent and really made us feel at home and that our presence was a wonderful thing. We sat at the chef's counter and the chef did an amazing job in telling us what was good and what he would avoid on the menu. I always appreciate honesty vs. "everything is excellent". It makes me trust their recommendations even more.

The macaroni and cheese casserole was delicious. I ate most of this myself. I loved that the top layer was crusted and somewhat burned. It gave much more texture to the dish.

The paneed pork cheeks didn't have much flavor despite the delightful pile of creamy sauce beneath it. However, I actually felt that this lack of flavor was very intentional. I was left savoring, slowly chewing, and experiencing the texture of the cheeks as each bite nearly melted in my mouth without resistance.

The rabbit and dumpling dish felt like soup for the soul. It felt like mom's healing chicken soup but a bit creamier with more substance. I liked it but didn't think it was worth $23. There's hardly much rabbit meat but the dumplings were good.

This bloody mary probably had more kick and vodka than any bloody mary I've had in NOLA. It makes me now doubt that other locations aren't trying hard enough.

Don't waste a bite on the complimentary olives. They were a bit strange but it was a nice gesture!

The food is so delicious every plate we got was good!! Staff was quick and service was great! Except that we had 2 servers 1 guy and 1 girl. The guy was extremely nice the girl just needed to put on more of a smile and appear welcoming. She looked so sad!!

Came here for a late lunch, and while the place wasn't fully packed, there was still quite a wait which was disappointing.  The actual location is quite nice and the restaurant itself is very vibrant, well decorated, bright and clean.  After finally getting to our table we noticed that service was quite spotty, as it seems like a good majority of the staff was getting lunch or eating at the time.

We started off and ordered some specialty sodas for our drinks, my girlfriend and I tried the butterscotch root beer and the bourbon cream soda both of which were very delicious, which was followed up with complimentary rolls.  We then ordered the fried alligator which tasted great especially with the mayo sauce.  We then ordered the ribs with watermelon pickle, which was a little too overpowering.  The sauce itself was strong and the increased sourness from the pickle was just too much.  We then ended our meal with the cochon, which was alright, it didn't really blow me away, as most of the flavor was the cabbage and peaches although the cracklins added some nice texture.

They definitely have some good points and treasured moments, but at the same time there were time when the experience fell through, hence the average review.

[This is probably the only time I'll do this, so please forgive the complete lapse in character, but...] 

Yaaaaasssss. 

That's just how Cochon makes me feel. This is my kind of restaurant. Everything is superb (food, service, vibe, booze), and the overall effect forms up (like Voltron) into one of my favorite places to eat, in one of my favorite towns to eat. I don't make that statement lightly.

Last time we came in we didn't have a reservation because I'm a dimwitted ignoramus (stop your protests, it's true). The hostess said, "We don't have any tables available, and there's nothing at the bar...would you be OK sitting at the Chef's Counter?"

Wait, what? That's the best thing that ever happened. Hostess, you're making dreams come true.

So for our entire meal, we sat in front of that wood-burning oven and watched and smelled as mouthwatering plate after mouthwatering plate was finished and sent over to be expedited, all the while wondering why the hell we didn't order whatever happened to be walking by (the rabbit is foremost among these dishes, and the first thing I'm ordering when I come back in).

Speaking of which, order the oysters. Slathered in chili-butter and wood-fired (like everything else), nothing smells better than these, and not much tastes better. Other things I absolutely adore about this place:

1. They sent a full order of hogshead cheese to us, on the house. (I'd like to believe I'm special, but everyone else got it too.) I'm a sucker for lagniappe, and a HUGE sucker for lagniappe that also happens to be charcuterie of the highest quality.

2. Just about everything in this place is so very, very porky. As is fitting when the name on the door is Cochon. That hogshead cheese, the ribs, the pork cheeks (essentially a cassoulet that is perfect in cold weather), even the grilled broccoli salad (incredible) was porky as hell. I also appreciate the acid-forward flavors; the ribs especially are quite vinegary, and I loved it.

3. The details matter. Everything from the music playing to the bread is carefully thought out, and it all fits. With regard to the bread (perfect little buttery dinner rolls), we thought we'd missed out, or our waiter hated us. It just turned out that they only serve the bread to you when it's hot and fresh out of the oven...the way bread should be.

The only thing I don't appreciate:

They kept trying to clear my wife's plate while she was in the bathroom. I realize you thought we were single diners because she's entirely out of my league.
