And I'm sure it looked like she'd left and it was time to take away her food...but it hurts that everyone on your staff came to the same conclusion that I don't look like someone who has a date. Accurate, but it hurts..

In the end, Cochon is all about hearty, unfussy, stick-to-your-ribs, absolutely fucking delicious food that I ate entirely too much of (which is OK because I'm putting on a layer of fat for winter). Pair that with a rye or bourbon cocktail, and I'm a happy, happy man.

Let my daughter know that I was in New Orleans. I let her know what I wanted to eat and we yelped this establishment. This location is in a trendier area it seemed. Not hard to find off the 10. Staff was friendly and we were seated right away. We were there on a Wednesday at about 2:30pm. We had the fried alligator which was tasty, Mac and cheese which was tasty also. Ordered the boudin sausage (balls?), sorry can't remember exactly what they were called. They were a bit gamey but I've never had it so this could be something I'm not used to. Overall nice atmosphere, nice staff and good food.

My friends and I were in Nola for a conference and had time to explore the city and their food scene. I was tasked to find a dinner place that reflected Nola cuisine and I found Cochon. Needless to say, my friends and I were blown away by the food. There is nothing on their menu that you could go wrong with and we left the restaurant full and happy. I wanted to give a small shoutout to their salads which they somehow made refreshing, delicious, and healthy all at the same time. Cochon was definitely my most favorite place in Nola and I can't wait to come back!

So I picked this place because it was walking distance from our hotel and had good reviews.  Boy did that pay off!  The food here is great.  It's been a while since my visit, so I don't remember exactly what we had, there was only one dish that I didn't like, which was a rabbit pot pie type of dish, out of the 5-7 things that we ate.  The atmosphere is laid back.

Our server seemed very distracted and seemed confused at first if we were going to by her responsibility or not, but this really didn't distract from the great evening that we had here.  Would definitely return.

I'm catching up on reviews I should've written months ago.  We were here in March 2015. 

We had to wait 15-20 minutes for a table as we didn't have reservations and we did arrive during the lunch hour, so considering that, the wait wasn't bad.

We had the wood-fired oysters, the oyster and bacon sandwich, the macaroni and cheese casserole, and the shrimp and eggplant dressing.  There was a common theme among all of the items:  super salty.  I don't mean salty in that "someone added a bit too much for my taste" way; I mean salty in that "I may've gotten a less salty taste had I licked a salt lick" way.  We preferred the oysters at Acme and the oyster po boy at SoBou, and since we ate at Cochon after having tried the others, these just seemed average.

Our waiter was standoffish and acted a bit as if we were imposing on him being there during the end of the lunch rush.  I don't want, need, or expect wait staff to act like my new best friend, but I do expect professional and polite behavior.  It took some time for the check to arrive and to get our non-alcoholic drinks refilled.

All in all, there are so many great places to eat in New Orleans, I recommend seeking out other replaces for similar food.
One of the best meals we had in New Orleans.  Food was perfectly cooked and they had great cocktails as well.

If you happen to be in NOLA this is the best spot to go for a good time, great food, and an awesome crew! We sat at the bar and this night became the highlight of our trip, tons of fun and a great atmosphere. The bartenders were by far the best we have ever had, especially Jeremy who provided us attentive service! When we make another trip back to the southern city... I sure know where I'm headed to first!!
Went here with a group of friends. Took a while to seat us but other than that everything was great. Good food and good service. Highly recommend. Alligator was on point. Sucess!

Very creative dishes and cocktails with lots of flavor! If you like meat/pork dishes this will be heaven. If you're more of a casual meat eater (like me) some of the flavors got repetitive. The ambiance is low key and hipster. We had two waiters help us. One was great, the other left much to be desired. Recommended.

Food was good, service was spotty. The waitress Amanda literally did not try to help us as much as the other waiter with braids whose name I did not catch.

I had the pork ribs, Fried alligator, and turkey Gumbo. Overall, it was good, but not great. A lot of it felt quite salty, although the free dinner rolls balanced the flavor a decent amount. The flavor was pretty good if it wasn't for the overwhelming saltiness. Service was really the reason for it to drop from a 4 to a 3 star. Please make sure that certain waitresses actually try to serve the customer.

Service was bad. The server was not friendly, didn't have patience for questions regarding  the menu and just had a bad attitude (restaurant was not that busy). I really hate going to a pricey restaurant for a person to ruin what should be a good time. If it was cheap I would not complain. Waters took a long time to arrive and we never got the complimentary bread. I think no one at the special "chef's table" gets the bread. Avoid that area, it's not so special. They may have noticed my discontent and brought me complimentary fried caulliflower...wow that's a punishment. Caulliflower. Food was ok. The Mac and cheese was the best, which is sad. The menu is limited.

Amazing restaurant, we went with a group of 3 and shared the wood fired oysters, fried alligator, watermelon ribs, Louisiana Cochon, Mac and cheese, and topped it off with a chocolate chess pie.  The wood fired oysters were probably the best of all of these, they were a full of flavor with a garlic kick.  The fried alligator was also good.  The ribs were a little of the sweet side, but still tasted amazing.  The Cochon was also really good, it didn't looked like pulled pork at first but when you break it down its basically pulled pork.  The Mac and cheese was nice and cheesy and really good as well.  The desert really topped it off, it was a great mix of chocolate and praline.  The cocktails weren't a hit, but still 5 stars for the food, just stick to the whiskey straight and you should be fine.

Overall this is a great place. Small but unique menu. Went with 3 co-workers, so we shared small plates to get started. Alligator, pork cheek, meat plate, and off the menu special carpaccio. Cheeks and carpaccio where to die for. Meat plate was really good, but not much nothing outstanding. The alligator was not good. Tough and way too spicy. Had to put it down as to not over power the rest of the meal. I got the catfish courbollion and eggplant/shrimp side. courbollion was really good. Big portion. Side was amazing. Cooworkers got the off the menu special pork chop. Had a very nice flavor, but lacked any sear. Can't hold a candle to Perry's in Houston. We started with beers and the wait staff never approached us to order a second round. They did however keep our waters full. Took awhile to get the bill also. Solid place, but due to a few missteps, couldn't give it a 5. I would definitely come back.
Very good food! Tried the ribs, macaroni, and oysters. The oysters were amazing and the sauce is breathtaking! Macaroni was just ok and the ribs were great but not hot enough (temp wise).

Ok I'm here again!!! It's tough to get away from the crowds of people and find a genuinely great restaurants/ Bar. I ordered the porkChop again. I love it.  Love this place. Be nice to the staff there are spurts where the restaurant gets hopping and you might have to Waite but the Waite is worth it. Great food great staff and we'll run. Try it for yourself!!!

Great experience all around-helpful friendly staff and great food. I ordered the Cochon-amazing. I am not normally a pork person, but this may have been the best pork dish I have ever had.

Places like this make me miss living in the South. Try getting a James Beard award winning chef's signature dish any where in the North for $23! And if you are looking for a great lunch sandwich go next door to Cochon Butcher.

Great staff that offered wonderful recommendations. The four of us ordered the fried alligator, fried cauliflower, mac n cheese, the gulf shrimps and the catfish. The lime cilantro alligator was good, we just didn't like the actual texture of the meat, but glad we tried it. All the other dishes were great, especially the catfish. It was smothered in creamy sauce with rice over it, yummmms. We went there after the WWII museum, about a 5 min walk. The perfect way to end the afternoon!

The restaurant is extremely popular. Make reservations. There is a bar to wait at for a table if you walk in or have to wait for tables to be cleared.

My wife and I went for dinner at Cushon on Sat Jan 23 2016. Had seen it rated on the internet as a top 10 place to dine in New Orleans.

Our first time in New Orleans & the first time to Cushon.

The service was a bit rushed and not all that friendly. The bench and chairs were not all that comfortable.

We asked our server for before dinner cocktail recommendations - for a vodka drinker and a rum drinker.

Per his recommendation - my wife had a COLD BLOODED vodka cocktail - it had an interesting spice flavor and subtle heat to it. Very interesting and quite different than her usual martinis.

I had an ABOUT THYME rum cocktail. It was interesting but not all that memorable,

The buns that were included with the meal were very tasty.

The SMOKED PORK RIBS WITH WATERMELON PICKLE was excellent and a good sized portion to share as an appetizer.

The HAM HOCK WITH SWEET POTATOES was very good and a large portion. Maybe a little over done.

The special that night was a PORCHETTA that sounded so good - but was just average in flavor and overall experience. Just way too much pork fat left on the plate after trimming what even I would eat.

We shared a side order of BROCCOLI BACON AND a SAUCE that was very good. We were glad to have a few more vegetables and so tasty ...

We shared a HUMMINGBIRD desert which is a banana bread knock off of carrot cake. The nuts were very much like carrot cake and the creme fresh icing was similar to the cream cheese icing on carrot cake - but much lighter. A very tasty desert.

Everyone seemed to be having a good time. We had a nice conversation with the couple sitting next to us.

The restaurant is a bit noisy - making conversation more strained than usual.

A good meal out after a busy day driving to and visiting a couple of Plantations. It seemed too expensive for the lasting flavor and experience impact. Maybe we were just too tired.

We just happened to run into the last 3/4 of a Mardi Gras parade on the 12 minute walk back to our hotel. Lots of fun loving people on the streets.

A restaurant that can never be wrong to recommend to a meat lover. Terrific pork cheeks. Super tender and juicy meat with black pepper and onions. Some creamy grits added to the heavy seasoning while slices of turnips refreshed your mouth. Fried alligator was good. I sat at the chef counter and hoped I could order every dish they prepared hahaha.
Wow! Just had the ribs. Hubby had pork chop. Beet salad,broccoli salad Mac and cheese for kids. All out of this world yummy!

My first experience with Cochon was during an event catered by them. I remember very clearly how delicious the Shrimp and Grits were... years later. My second experience with them was just as delicious. I brought my sister here when she was visiting me at school and we sat at the bar by the kitchen. The food was amazing!

I brought my entire family with me for my graduation dinner and we couldn't have been happier with the choice! There wasn't a single thing the waiter recommended that we didn't love. Everything from the pre-dinner cocktails to the desserts were amazing. 

Cochon is somewhere I recommend to all my friends visiting the city. Their butcher next door is also great!

The atmosphere walking in off the main drag was warm and welcoming. We had a reservation for a group celebrating my bachelorette. Yahoo! They had a nice selection of drinks to start off with. Think small plates shared with friends for this kind of feast. Believe me, it is a feast. The mac and cheese will be sure to make even the most finicky eaters swoon. Some of those finicky eaters even found themselves gorging into plates of fried alligator with just the right amount of heat to remind you of the Cajun and Creole this area is known for. The smoked ribs didn't really do it for me, but everyone else liked them. Sorry, I happen to be a smoke snob.  If you don't know what fried boudin is, you should probably try that too. A salad and soup were also shared among friends, but everything else stood out so much more. I would like to end this with a HUGE thank you to the staff there that night. They handled us rowdy girls quite well and the food was great.

We had a simply Superb dining experience here.  The food was beyond delicious and creatively prepared with an attention to detail that blew us away.  I cannot rave enough -- you must try it for yourself!

Pig tongue pastrami, cheeks, ham hocks, wood-fired oysters, pork ribs, chicken livers, Boudin, and alligator. Can't pick a favorite!

Cochon is a fairly casual place where you can have a feast!  We went for my 30th birthday in August of 2015 and it was fantastic.  I love that you can get the odd cuts here.  I know some people are apprehensive about jowls and cheeks and tongue, but gather some courage and try it, because you won't regret it!
Friendly, knowledgeable staff, amazing food and good eating ambiance.  Shrimp and grits were amazing.

Probably the best restaurant that ive ever been to. Started off with the fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise, and it was delicious. my fiance doesn't normally eat alligator and she loved it as well. I also ordered the smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickle and it had the perfect smoke to it and the watermelon pickle added a nice vinegar to counter the slight smoke. Definitely hope to come back!

Went in based n the Yelp reviews...I should have known better and looked at the other comments.  WORST SERVICE EVER!!!.  Come on Mike, at least act like you want to earn your tips.  Its not my fault that you are over forty and still a server.  Your attitude showed and you have been there for years according to management.  I guess this gives you the right to treat people based on your menopausal moments.  We were seated right in the corner where the Sun Does Shine...**tip asked to be moved from that location if they try to sit you there.  In fact that should be the workers lunch table.  We saw management eating also....Ok so for those of you who don't care about service....Food was good...we had to ask a lot of questions because the menu was hard to understand.  It is small portions so order some sides....and yes they have fresh bread and yes we kept asking for more...but a table of 7 and they only bring you one basket....we saw the other tables getting one basket also with only 2 at the table...Maybe Magic Mike was pissed at this also...So my table mates said do not tip...I tipped because Mike's first impression affects everyone..and that is not fair to the other servers who really work hard.  Next time we should have just stop across the street at the Ugly Dog Saloon & BBQ

Very busy dinner spot.

Took a while for us to get seated (with reservation). It seems like the table they put us in wasn't meant for a group of 8, but they put us there anyway, tight fit for 8 guys!

The dinner itself was good:

wood fired Oysters: Had a nice seasoning, didn't taste fishy

Fried alligator: good bites, had a nice kick to it

Ribs: Order this as the main meal, because the other options didn't sound appetizing to me. They were really good

Fried Boudin (in spanish we call these quipes): These tasted very good, I could eat a whole bowl of these things!

Cochon: some friends ordered this, they said it was ok, but nothing special

They have an extensive alcohol menu, some good bourbons in there. We were all pretty stuffed after the meal, so no dessert. 

Overall, a nice place for a group or special ocasion. They have some seats facing the kitchen if you like that sort of thing, cool concept.

The large mussels were the star of the show. The magic is in the sauce, which offers a flavorful slightly spicy -perfect sprinkle of chili flakes - not overwhelming sauce. 

Fear not if you've never eaten alligator. It's basically somewhere between chicken and squid, slightly rubbery and plain. It is after all part land and part water creature (so my friend says, haha). The zesty mayo sauce and strands of cooked onions -also smothered in the sauce - enhance this crispy dish. The dish could use more sauce to dip on the side. Other than that, it's a thumbs up in my book. 

My friend and I dropped in on a Saturday (on Mardi Gras weekend)  ~8pm and the wait was ~30 minutes. Service and atmosphere was great.

Cochon- time to eat gastropub NOLA style. We came for dinner on a Friday and after of a day of trying to grab bites at some of the top spots in NOLA we weren't super hungry, so we split a few small plates. I easily made a reservation online prior to my trip to NOLA and I would recommend that for anyone looking to check out this spot.

The plates we shared: wood fired oysters in chili butter,  pork cheeks, and fried alligator with chili garlic mayo. Holy piglet- everything was amazing! The three items were small but great for two people to share. We sat at a small table but I saw seating at a chefs counter which looked really awesome. 

If I lived in NOLA I feel like I'd eat here all the time. Lucky for my waist I am several hundred miles away, I still can't wait to go back.

Best in town I saw.
Inventive current takes honoring the cuisine.
Drinks, apps, service, entrees -- all unbeatable. The price wasn't too bad for a New Yorker either. That rabbit and dumplings... And those fucking rolls. What a fat kid I was with those.  Why go to some antebellum food museum when they give you the local food in a flavorful fresh and creative way? Do it.

Cochon was definitely worth checking out. Tons of great small plate options & no frills atmosphere. The grilled broccoli was an unexpected favorite. Just wish they still had some fried alligator left when we got there, but that's what happens when you make a last minute reservation.

Sooooo the place is nice but the food is lacking in flavor 
The alligator and Mac Nf cheese was amazing 
Other than that everything was just ok
Amazing. Had the oysters and crocodile- delicious! Then the broccoli salad and pork belly.

I went to New Orleans last weekend for Mardi Gras, so I made sure to book a reservation at Cochon beforehand. Their dinner reservations were booked (not surprising), so be sure to book weeks in advance! Instead, I booked a table for 2:30pm and had a late lunch.

For our meal, my boyfriend and I split the wood-fired oysters with garlic chili butter, rabbit and dumplings, ham hock, and mac and cheese casserole. I'm not a fan of raw oysters, but I loved these. The sauce was delicious! The rabbit and dumplings were good, but I wouldn't get them again. The ham hock and mac and cheese were AWESOME. 

The service was also pretty good. Our server started out kinda meh, but seemed to lighten up by the end of the meal. The food was brought out and cleaned up by other servers and bussers, which was nice.

Definitely a must-have stop if you only have a weekend in town!

Came in for a Friday lunch with my fiancé and future father in law. We had a reservation, though it wasn't too crowded at 11:30. Expect to pay full dinner prices at lunch as it doesn't appear they have a separate lunch menu. We started with the smoked ribs, which were really yummy. My fiancé got the soup of the day, which was a smoked chicken and mushroom and she thought it was delicious. 

For entrées, I had the Cochon with a side of Mac n cheese. It was good, though the Mac lacked seasoning. My fiancé got the special ham sandwich of the day with roasted Brussel sprouts. The sprouts were awesome, though the ham was more like roast pork. The father in law had the rabbit and dumplings which he seemed to enjoy, but said the dumplings were biscuits and not dumplings. 

For dessert, I got the chocolate chess pie which was decent but nothing is dream about and he had the pineapple upside down cake, which can he enjoyed. 

The service was attentive and friendly.

I came in for lunch with my dad and my fiancé- it was a great experience! The service was wonderful, the decor comfortable, the food delicious. I would recommend this restaurant to anyone! We started with the smoked ribs with pickled watermelon- yum. I also had the soup of the day- a spicy chicken and mushroom. It was so good, I've been talking about it all day! My dad got the rabbit and dumplings, Lima beans and pineapple upside down cake- he said it was delicious. My fiancé got the Cochon, macaroni and cheese and chess pie- he ate every bite! I got one of the daily specials- a smoked ham sandwich with gravy and onions and provolone on French with fried Brussels sprouts. It was so good! I will def be back!
The food is amazing & service is good. Staffs r very friendly and mindful!! (Folding your napkins while you are away from your seat) I just love the gulf fish, super yummy!

It's not that it's bad, it's just that it was ok. I've been here twice, thinking the first time was just an off night for the cook or maybe my taster was off, but it was the same as the first, just ok. I'm surprised so many people like this place where as I personally think my husbands (similar) dishes taste better!
Twice baked potato and smoked ribs are a-maz-ing. Fried alligator is something you have to try. Think of fatty chicken.

Just visited Cochon for the first time tonight. We made reservations about a week before arriving in NOLA based on other reviews we'd read, but it didn't seem that busy on a Monday night at 8:00. We were seated quickly and greeted by our friendly and helpful server who explained the main features of the menu and gave us suggestions. We ordered the fried alligator and wood fired oysters as starters. They were both good, but the oysters were really awesome, and I don't even normally like oysters! We ordered the pork cheeks and mac and cheese for sides, and we ordered the cochon as an entree. Our favorite of the three was the pork cheeks. So tender, and the spices on them were perfect. We were super impressed with the service and quality of our meal at Cochon! Highly recommend it to everyone, and we'll be back again!

Really nice atmosphere. The cocktails were really good. We had a great waiter, who was very energetic and funny.
I enjoyed the oyster appetizer the most.  They had a nice chili too them. The mac n cheese was good too. I had the cochon, and thought it was good, but I wouldn't order it again. The crackling on it was fantastic though!
Also has the special ice cream of the night, which was strawberry shortcake - awesome!

We didn't have reservations but landed there during the busy lunch hour and found a place at the bar. Our bartender was awesome! He was training someone and making drinks for the entire restaurant all while remaining attentive to us. The wood-fired oysters are a treat! I could drink the sauce they use. I felt like I was cheating on NOLA by getting the ribs - false! So good! I can't wait to come back to eat the rest of the menu.
I love the desert here. It is so amazing. They have a great pastry chef. I will be back for that desert!! Thank you for everything the service was wonderful here.
Finally went awesome Duck and dumplings delish wife had oyster and bacon sandwich she loved it. Great service, great atmosphere will be back!

This place was really good.  We ordered the wood fired oysters and fried alligator for appetizers.  And the Louisiana Cochon as our entree.  Everything was really good and we would definitely come here again.

I would consider Cochon to be Southern New; that is, a modern take on mostly southern and Cajun food. The restaurant has a tapas style and ambiance with its extensive wine selection, bouchiere platter (similar to a charcuterie board), and tapas dishes. 

We were first served complimentary corn bread which was the best corn bread I had in New Orleans. It was buttery and grainy. The top was baked to crisp.

For appetizer, we shared the alligator bites. It was prepared such that you could taste the difference between gator and other meats. The meat itself was a bit tough at first; however it immediately softens up once you break through it on the first bite. The gator bites were topped with slightly pickled white onions and a fresh herb. I also liked the chili garlic mayo which was mild and creamy.

For our main courses, we shared the Louisiana Cochon and the Rabbit & Dumplings. I recommend both dishes. The two were very hearty, earthy, and plentifully seasoned.

The cochon was pulled pork formed together as a patty and stove fried. The pork was still succulent, yet it now had a crispier outer layer providing a textural contrast. The cochon patty was platted over slow cooked cabbage and turnips. The ingredients married together well. It also had a few small cubes of apple which added a little sweetness to an earthy and savory dish.

The Rabbit and Dumplings was an interesting take on Sheppard's Pie. Instead of having a pie crust at the top, there were four small biscuits placed throughout the dish. The rabbit was soft and tender. It was best preparation of rabbit that I've had. All in all. this dish was extremely filling. 

The service was attentive and knowledgeable. I liked the offerings of local and craft beers.

I would rate it four and a half stars.

Yet again, one of the best meals I have ever had.

Started with a cocktail. We both had an Amite Smash (a bourbon cocktail). It was wonderful.

For our small plate we had the boudin. Cooked to perfection, and delightfully spicy. Dipped in the mustard and it took on a whole new character. Fantastic.

We had the off-special special, a shank. Perfectly done. Absolutely melted in your mouth. I have never had any meat this tender and flavorful. It is not hyperbole for me to say the meat fell off the bone.

The special was on top of some of the most creamy/buttery grits I've had. I don't eat grits very often, but I enjoyed these very much. Combined with the pork ... it was just heaven.

Service: perfectly attentive. When they came by to ask how we liked the special ... I just laughed ... it was so good.

I try very hard to eat at Cochon (and the butcher, too) every time I'm able to visit New Orleans.

Be aware:
1. you have to plan ahead to get a reservation, worth doing
2. can get busy, and a little loud, which isn't their fault, there are just sometimes loud people
Incredible! Amazing! Wish I had more days in NOLA so I could come back and work my way through the menu. Everything looks good!

Prior to arriving to New Orleans, we looked this restaurant up and we made a reservation based on the raving reviews. Very trendy restaurant whose servers and customer service deserves a thumbs up.!!!! We arrived early and they deff accommodated us even tough they were busy. The food was good but not amazing. We had the rabbit stew as an entree and for appetizers we had the brucherie plate which were both ok. Not amazing and that is why this restaurant only gets a 3 star. Sitting by the kitchen bar was really cool. I would reccomened this place for a random dinner in town but I wouldn't do it as a tourist in town for an amazing New Orleans experience

The pork cheeks are amazing
The couchon pork is really good
Very nice place, very good service

I have had several of the best meals I've ever eaten, at Cochon. I've eaten there several times and it is always a delight. After trying several of the entrees, I typically just go with the appetizers, mac & cheese, gumbo, and the charcuterie plate. Their fried Boudin is the best I've ever had.
Holy shit, I could barely walk after, sat by the kitchen and saw the madness go down! will be back for more innovative eats next time I am in town.

3.5 stars. It's a great romantic spot. Boyfriend and I sat by the chefs window and watched them work away, cooking all these great dishes. By the end of the meal I felt like I ordered the wrong food though.
The fried alligator was good, tasted like... Chicken but a little tougher. Loved the sauce that came with it. They gave us head cheese on the house. Which I was very excited about! First time having and it was interesting! Loved the pickles and bit of toast with it. On to the mains... The fish my boyfriend got was very delicate and flavorful, but light. The cochon I got was however dry but it did well with some of the acidic cabbage. I was really excited by crackling but I thought I almost broke a teeth on my first piece.

Great food - terrible service.  Didn't get seated for a 730 reservation until 800 and then barely saw our waiter. 

Wood fired oysters and catfish courtbouillon absolutely divine.

OMG!! I'm so glad I went here on my trip to New Orleans. I made reservations for lunch. I suggest you make reservations when you go because it gets crowded pretty quick. Anyways, for starters I had the chargrilled oysters and the fried alligator. I FELT LIKE I WAS IN HEAVEN! The chargrilled oysters were cooked to perfection. Not too overcooked and you still tasted the freshness of the oysters when you bite into it. It was my first time eating alligator and I must say... it tasted like popcorn chicken. Lol, it's not a bad thing, but it was a little pricey ($14). Our server Jake was friendly and knowledgeable. The staff in general was on point! They refilled our waters without us asking and everyone had a smile on their faces. I suggest you try these two appetizers when you go! I also got an entree, but I didn't like it as much, so I don't remember exactly what it was or what was in it lol.
Attentive staff, fantastic spin on classic Southern dishes with a modern twist, and fun atmosphere. Great for big groups!

It is a beautiful, cozy restaurant located in the Garden District. It was pretty crowded on a Wednesday night and I would highly recommend making reservations. 

The meal started off with fresh, warm bread and butter and a couple of craft beers. They have an excellent craft beer and wine list. The food was pretty darn good as well! The Broccoli, Kale, and Bacon salad was a good pairing especially with the creamy buttermilk salad dressing. I would say that if you are going for a fresh, citrus-y salad then do not choose this one. The Rabbit and Dumplings is a lovely comfort dish with a nice twist on chicken pot pie. There are biscuits on top of a thick gravy with plenty of rabbit in it as well (I've never had rabbit before and it tastes like a game-y chicken, fyi). The Mac and Cheese is a melt-in-your-mouth small plate but also very filling. 

Overall, great experience-would definitely recommend if you are in New Orleans!

I was there for a convention. There were dozens of recommendations from friends back home and locals. I decided to try this place first. I loved the food so
Much and wanted so much to try other dishes on the menu, I went back. (I basically used another meal opportunity for this place instead of another restaurant on the recommended list I had!)

The spice, sauce were superb!

The first time, I ordered an entree. The second time I went with two colleagues.  We ordered all five small plates plus the ribs with pickled watermelon. Delicious!

I found it to be so-so for the price. The food is good but I honestly prefer it's more affordable sibling, Butcher, better all around. 
The food is great, but pricey and predictable. I also had a reservation and the hostess still called walk ins before us.   So minus a star for that.
Great lunch atmosphere and environment!   Music and crowded.   Recommend the gumbo, fried alligators and pork.  Make reservations.  If you have to wait walk across the street to Ugly Dog for a drink.

Amazing food! Hands down, one of the best meals I have ever had. Went with a group of 4 and tried a bunch of different things. The chili oysters are incredible. We ended up getting 2 orders and had it not been for the fact that we wanted to try other food, we would have gotten 3. The fried alligator comes with an awesome sauce and is not greasy at all. Pork cheeks were super tender and flavorful. All of this comes with super flavorful sauces to dip the yeasty bread in.

For entrees we all shared the fisherman style fish. The fish was super fresh and seasoned perfectly. The rabbit and dumplings were stick on your ribs, homestyle deliciousness. Lastly the cochcon entree was good. The cabbage and turnip side to the Cochon dish, with the cracklins, pull the whole dish together. I would get any of these dishes again. 

They were out of the mac n cheese but the lima beans side was amazing and savory. 

We shared the chess pie for dessert. Super rich and pretty good. It didn't compare to all of the amazing savory food we had, however, maybe the other desserts are more outta this world.

The only reason I don't give this a 5 is the service is not super stellar. Reservations were at 9 and we were right on time. However, we did not have our cocktails in front of us until 9:40. The waitress was also kind of hard to flag down. It was totally packed, and I get that, but for the price point, the service probably should be better. Also, the bathroom seemed more like the bathroom at a bar than a nice restaurant. 

So, food is a total 5! Definitely go check it out! Just expect the service to be more of a 3.

Thursday I sat on the patio, it was beautiful, never have I seen better service. My waiter was named Dave and he truly made the experience. My boyfriend and I shared the oysters, the fried alligator, and the unbelievable hamhock. We didn't even know where to begin, but Dave guided us through the menu and made us feel very comfortable and special. It was a very important day for us and he made everything flawless. You can get good food anywhere, but you can't get this kind of service. Hands down, amazing. Thanks so much Dave and Cochon kitchen. Will DEFINITELY be back again.

A friend & I ate here on our last night in NOLA  back in October. 

Popular spot, it was packed even on a  Monday night. Reservations are highly recommended!

Ambiance is cozy, modern/rustic, lively atmosphere, very high energy.

Service was efficient though staff could have been friendlier (smiles don't cost a dime).

Food is amazing! I had the gator bites....absolutely delicious, and a salad, very fresh. My friend ordered two of the pork dishes, pork cheeks and something else & she was in hog heaven....literally. A must try in NOLA.

Wish I took some photos, but we were starving and just dug in. Was in town for a work convention, and stayed at an Airbnb a block from here, came for cocktails and some food, with friends from work, I had the Mac and cheese and the pork belly, both of these were mouth watering and amazingly good! 

The last day I came back for lunch next door and had the Mac and cheese again with the pork belly sandwich, so delicious! Definitely check this place out if you're in Nola!

Must check this place if you're in town! love this place! everything was so delicious!! Make sure you rsvp because this place will get packed! The service could use alittle work though, our server was barely around, but our guy server was on point! not sure if they tip pooled there or he was helping her out because she was lacking. But overall i would definitely come back here.

3.5 stars bumped down as the experience overall just fell short of expectations especially after all the praise and accolades I came across.

While the interior was certainly spacious and inviting with extensive use of lighter wood throughout, things progressively went downhill from there with regards to service.  One server introduced himself to us at the beginning only to have another take our drink orders...that required nearly another 15 minutes to just fill two glasses of wine.  Clearly disorganized and seeing a number of them, for the lack of a better term, dicking around in the background left a sour taste.

My friend and I went with the highly popular wood-fired oysters along with the signature Louisiana cochon and oven-roasted redfish.  The oysters were packed with flavor from the chili garlic butter and piping hot, well worth a try.  The pork turned out to basically be a large mound of pulled pork crisped around the edges.  It paired well with the accompanying cabbage and honestly, it needed it as the parts closer to the edges were borderline dry.  Conversely, our redfish was perfectly roasted and seasoned well.

All the food taken together was certainly quite tasty, but they were very simplistic and lacking in any kind of creativity compared to some of the top restaurants we came across throughout NOLA.  Prices could've been better as well given the execution and the service has plenty of room for improvement.

My favorite southern themed restaurant in New Orleans! The best chargrilled oysters in town...even over Crazy Lobster & Dragos. Fried alligator is divine. Do Not pass up the short ribs with pickled watermelon rind! Mac n' cheese is a Must. Not an entree will disappoint!!

Great place to try fine southern food. I tried the fried alligator, liver, pork cheeks, and the boucherie plate.
Best plate was pork cheeks: tender and seasoning is great, palatable to most tastes.
Recommend pork cheeks and alligator. Alligator was a little chewy (expected) but flavors were great. 
Liver was good also and interesting. 
Boucherie had pate and head cheese that were great, but the rest of it was just ok.

The food here is some of the best I've tasted.  I had the ham hocks with sweet potatoes, and my dining partner had a beef stew of some sort that I can't remember.  They were both equally tasty and incredibly filling.  We also had their charcuterie board which was fantastic.  Bloody Mary's are spicy upon request.  
The only thing that I don't give a high rating on is the hostess, and one of our servers, which is why I gave an overall of 4 stars.  The hostess was unfriendly and busy talking to another (hostess?).  We did not feel welcomed into the restaurant at all.  The female server was less that friendly, barely smiled, but alas the saving grace, the male server who had a smile on his face and was eager to answer any questions we had.  BTW, I'm a 55 year old woman so I guarantee he wasn't flirting. Wish I could've gotten all their names. Would've been more helpful to this review.

Two of our dishes were excellent and the others were pretty mediocre. We loved the wood oven oysters and the pork cheeks. I could have eaten a whole plate of the oysters myself! We also ordered the oven roasted fish and some cake our waiter was raving about (think banana bread/carrot cake). The fish was cooked perfectly, but honestly  was hard to appreciate having been served with no sides. We could have ordered our own sides but nothing sounded like it would pair well with the fish. And the cake had the potential to be good, but it was served so cold that it was hard to taste the banana pudding and that also made the cake feel dry. Our waiter was really nice but the overall service was really slow- we waited awhile to get our drinks and the dishes took for ever to come out as well. It was also freezing in the restaurant so our appetizers got cold really quickly. Not sure I'd come back.

Cochon Butcher is highly rated so I had to go!  This place is on the side of a building - some other restaurant in front - so confusing.  The meat was sliced thin, olive spread was just that - nothing super special.  The seeded toasted bun was good.  Overall I could have used some more layers of flavors, but still a great sandwich - so you won't be disappointed.   The house chips were crispy and salted well.  The cookies are soft and quickly satisfies your sweet tooth.    This is not walking distance from the quarter.

A New Orleans favorite. We've been a few times, and our last time was with a party of eight. The service could not have been better, and the food was expectedly-outstanding. Cocktails and delicious. 

We ordered many small plates, including roasted oysters crawfish pies and fried chicken livers with pepper jelly. The lovers are among my favorite things anywhere in the city. Soups and salads were also good.

I had the cochon with turnips, cabbage, pickled turnips & cracklins. Other-worldy. Truly a signature dish and something I could eat daily. the side of lima beans is one of my favorite sides anywhere. My wife ordered the rabbit & dumplings and loved it. I got to eat a bit of it as well. Rich, creamy and delicious. I only wish that I had access to the pot. I could eat my weight in this.

This was our final meal in town, and it was a good note to end on. Fried alligator is well done with a really tasty sauce. It's chewy of course, but that's expected with alligator. Arugula strawberry salad was pretty good for something green. Gulf fish is simple and really high quality, good tasting without too much seasoning. Rabbit and Dumplings is quite good, though in fairness the taste and experience is more or less like a chicken pot pie. The dumplings are really more like fully cooked biscuits forming the top of the pot pie. Still, it was good. The place was very busy, but service was pretty quick. Quite a lot of good beers in bottles, and a few good ones on tap.

Unless you're either vegetarian/vegan, a health freak, or simply just some bland-food-eating weirdo, you're going to be faced with some tough choices when that sheet of paper with "Cochon" printed at the top is placed in front of you after you get seated.  You might be plain bewildered, or even discombobulated.  See, you're going to scan that menu and want to order EVERY last damn item on the menu.   Trying to decide what to omit is going to be a painful process.

A week or so later, I'm still regretting stuff I didn't get to try.

And yet, because my wife had suffered a nasty case of food poisoning a couple of night before, we went a little easy on the throttle when it came to fully sampling the porktastic greatness in which Cochon specializes.

The first thing we ordered was the best:  the onion braised pork cheeks (served w/with grits, radish & crushed herbs).  It's not all that much food for twelve dollars, but this is some of the most concentrated pork flavor you're going to get.  Hugely delicious.  We ordered the boucherie plate, which apparently is a Cajun term that refers to communal butchering of hogs.  As a plate at Cochon, it basically means charcuterie.  Here, the sausage items seemed best, along with an excellent bit of hogshead cheese.  The cured ham was good, but maybe too subtle to stand up to some of the other pork items.  Same deal with the rillettes:  smooth and creamy, but not very bold flavor.  There were a few pickles (tomatoes and cucumber) as well, which were a super-tangy contrast to the pork.  In addition, we ordered the cucumbers and herbs in vinegar off of the "soup and salad" section of the menu:  It was so vibrant, bright, and simple a dish as to suggest that Donald Link could open a damn good vegetarian restaurant if he wanted to.  (And that's probably a mild form of blasphemy to some when it comes to this guy.)

For entrees, we got the rabbit & dumplings and oven-roasted fish (which I'm pretty sure was redfish).  The rabbit & dumplings is basically the best rabbit pot pie you've never had (until now).  But I have to say that, by the end of it. it's flavors and textures were coming off as slightly one-dimensional, if bold and tasty.  The fish dish was fine, but did not compare to what we had at Peche a night later.

So regrets:  As I glanced at tables around me, I was already feeling them.  The fellas next to us had the ham hock and cochon entrees, which were making the rabbit and fish seem a bit light and conservative.  But across the way, a foursome had ordered one of the specials, which was a half pig's face.  That looked like just about the greatest thing ever, and the first time we'd seen it in a restaurant since a visit to Au Pied du Cochon in Montreal a few years back.

The table on our other side, with eight or ten folks was celebrating a birthday and sharing a bunch of items.  That really seems like the ideal way to go at Cochon, if you have that many folks who can join you and can score a reservation far enough in advance.

Ambience-wise, Cochon is a raving, cacophonous madhouse, and it's not for everybody.  (And this was a Monday night!)  The restaurant's look--lots of wood and concrete, a sharp modern look--is pretty common these days, but not so much in New Orleans when Cochon opened a decade ago.  Tables are mashed close together, and, when you walk in, the front of the house seems to be totally disorganized.  But the staff was excellent:  Despite the appearance of chaos, they ran a smooth show the whole way through; servers took time time to answer questions about the menu over the din.  

Excellent list of various types of alcohol (esp. bourbon)!

Not a perfect restaurant (as suggested by some of the above commentary), but with enough distinctiveness and highs to warrant this score.

Do you enjoy food? Are you visiting NOLA and want a taste of the new age modern food boom cultivating in this beautiful and uniquely divine city of art, music, and indulgence of fantastic food? Do you want to slightly avoid the touristy insanity that may come about in the French quarter? If yes, then this place is just for you! 

This was the last real meal I had before leaving my visit in NOLA and boy, did it really leave a lasting impression on me. I came about this place only through its great reviews on Yelp and decided to make an advanced reservation. I highly recommend doing it weeks in advance as I only had late options when I looked into it-- but this could have been due to the fact it was around the New Year holiday. 

Alas, we found ourselves in a very modern/hip/casual venue which made us fear it might be too "hipster" and and just a hype but then we ordered a variety of the appetizer / small plates and basically had an out of body experience realizing how quick we were to judge a book by its cover. Everything was fantastic... I have to even admit the oysters were better than the Acme oysters... That's right I said such blasphemy. Though, it's a different kind of preparation-- I still would say I would line up for these oysters than the ones anywhere near the heart of the French Quarter. To top it off, we had apple and fig for dessert and basically died again. 

All in all, I loved the food and I also enjoyed seeing the somewhat up and coming modernity of NOLA. though some might argue against its growth killing the culture. However, I'd like to think this place thrives due to the fact that it pays homage to the NOLA culture which cultivates the idea of growing from the roots to disrupt the norm and create beauty, delicious forbidden-fruit level beauty, out of it. 

I pray I will return to this place in the future!

Dinner at Cochon was the best meal I had in New Orleans over the course of a 4-day visit, and all of my companions agree. The service was attentive throughout our meal. For reference, we also dined at an Emeril restaurant, a James Beard award-winning restaurant, and a James Beard nominated restaurant. The wood-fired oysters were truly memorable: briny and smoky, with the perfect amount of kick. Man, we should've ordered a second round. The ham hock, so tender it just slid off the bone, was a favorite entree, even with people who "aren't really into ham." I was worried about our vegetarian friend, but Cochon prepared a beautiful entree for her. We all loved the twice-baked potato. Finally, I would like to commend the person who curates the music selection (a nice selection of indie/alternative rock) there. Not only was my belly happy, my ears were, too.

Oh Cochon, how I miss thee!

I had many fun memories from my trip to NOLA, but my favorite food experience belongs to Cochon. Boo and I managed to book a hotel within walking distance from the restaurant, so we casually walked in a little after lunch time. Despite not having reservations and the place being pretty busy, we were seated within a few minutes.The interior is clean and bright, yet welcoming. I like the brick and wood design. 

While we waited on the entrees, we devoured some delicious rolls. These were soft and buttery with the right hint of sweetness. For my main course, I got the Ham Hock. Surprisingly I've never had pork on a bone outside of ribs. My curiosity was rewarded with some deliciousness! The meat was super savory, and the accompanying sweet potato, pickled greens, and black eyed peas were fantastic. The bitterness of the greens, the sweetness of the potatoes, the different textures-- it was exactly the balanced meal you would want in a high end restaurant. No wonder Bourdain recommended this place. I really wish I could verbalize it better, but this meal was one of the best things I've ever had! I even got a T-shirt from the adjacent store to commemorate my experience. 

Whether you're a local or a tourist dropping by for a weekend like I was, PLEASE make it a point to try Cochon. (Probably wise to make a reservation in advance).

My experience:

Some friendly staff.
Extremely slow service.
Food was ok but I've had better elsewhere in New Orleans.
Didn't reach anywhere near my expectations.

Highly recommend eating here! Love the casual atmosphere. When we arrived, they got our reservation wrong and we had to wait a couple minutes for them to figure out our table, but it wasn't too bad. It's super busy so make sure you call in ahead. 

The food was scrumptious -- we started with the shrimp & deviled egg gumbo (a must!) and fried alligator (tasty and had nice texture, but a bit overdressed. Probably would've been better with the sauce on the side). 

The pork cheeks were also perfectly cooked and had great flavor. The meat pulled apart easily. The star of the night was the rabbit & dumplings. The flavor really sank into every part of the dish, especially the carrots! The sauce was amazing and we ate up every last drop with some bread. 

I also had a bite of my friend's hazelnut pudding -- so good. if I weren't so full, I would've ordered one for myself.

Yas, queen. It lives up to the hype. Visiting and tired of the same cajun and creole foods everywhere? Grab some modern eats that includes fresh vegetables. Great atmosphere even though it's always packed. Recommend, son!
I don't get why people come here. The food is salty and uninspired the servers are rude and slow. My friend got food poisoning, so we won't be giving it another shot. Just no.

It was so amazing. Heard from a friend to try it. We walked in and were seated right a way. The menu was simple and easy to pick what we wanted. I had the Mac n cheese baked and it was to die for. I also went for the deviled egg gumbo very good. Coffee was also very good. Service great. Plenty to help. You have to try this if your in New Orleans.

Decided to visit this place after seeing it on one of the Bourdain shows.  Recently remodeled and expanded, the place has a hip industrial vibe well suited for the Warehouse District near the Quarter.  It is a short 15 minute walk from the Canal Street but if you are walking at night stay on Tchoupitoulas.  The side streets are not well traveled.

The focus is on meat and if you're going to a restaurant called Cochon you better try some pork.  The meat preparations were unusual, not your normal pork chop or loin.  The food is what you would expect at a fine restaurant.  We ordered entrees but if I were to go back,  I would order a number of their small plates. People were raving about the pork cheeks, the salad with pork belly and the collard greens were excellent.

They don't have a children's menu but they do have a Mac and Cheese on the menu.  The restaurant is really not geared for children and there were very few in the restaurant but if your child is adventurous you will be fine.  Dress is casual, any where from jeans to business fits in.

This place is very popular and reservations are a must during dinner hours.

By the way, they have a casual sandwich restaurant next door.

I still find myself dreaming of the oysters. Everything at Cochon is incredible, from the cocktails to the appetizers to the main courses. This was, by far, our best meal in New Orleans. I'd highly recommend both the Louisiana cochon and the fish -- and, of course, the oysters. The amazing oysters...

I came here with my boyfriend and his sister. We were a little disappointed with the service - while the server was nice, the service was slow. We waited 45 minutes for our appetizer and about 2 hours (overall) for our main entrees. We thought it had something to do with the fact that we were sitting outside, but the wait time felt excessive. This put a damper on the overall meal, especially as we had to rush through our entrees when a thunderstorm came and we were not moved inside to enjoy a dry meal. 

But for the food: 

Complimentary Bread: Fresh and not too soft or too crispy. Nice medium. 
Fried Boudin with Pickled Peppers Appetizer: This may have been the tastiest dish of the entire night. Easily the best boudin I've ever had and the dipping sauce they included added a nice punch of spice.

- Boyfriend had the rabbit and dumplings - the flavors were tasty and savory and it was a nice, hearty meal.
- Boyfriend's Sister had the Catfish Courtbouillon - she practically licked the bowl, she liked it so much.
- I had the Hamhock and it came with sweet potatoes and black-eyed peas and pickled greens. This dish had a really interesting array of flavors and every bite tasted different. I rather enjoyed it - the pork was tender and tasty and balanced well with the sweet potatoes.

The food is great, but the service is slow. Expect some tasty bites, but expect to wait a while for them to come. I'd make reservations next time to secure a seat inside and probably bring some snacks in my purse.
Went to this place on my birthday while in New Orleans for work. Good food, but we waited an hour and a half to be seated when we were told they'd be a 30 minute wait. Very unlikely I'll be back.

I was too full from lunch to really enjoy a full dinner, but my mother said it was the best meal she has had in NOLA so far. My boys loved the pork ribs and my wife enjoyed the fried livers and pork cheeks. I really liked the crawfish pie. The only disappointment was the lemon poppyseed cake. It had way too much poppyseed and was dry. The service was very good and the ambience of the restaurant is great.

Cochon was the very first place I tried in New Orleans, and this place did not disappoint. I had things that I have never had before, I definitely got fatter. 

*Fried Alligator - Definitely something I would think of ordering, but in actuality, takes like chicken. It tastes great with a hot sauce. 

**Oysters - Fried oyster also a tasty option. They were not that memorable compared to the other NOLA things I have had. 

***Pork Roast - THis thing was a huge monster of a pork piece and it was very sweet and tasty. I believe this was a special, and we had the opportunity of having it. It was great for a party and I loved all of it. THank you.

Over priced,  mediocre at best.   Had the fried alligator which had a nice creamy,  flavorful sauce.   The darkened oysters were the smallest oysters I have seen and a sad excuse for an appetizer.  The catfish was way overpriced at $19 and lacked any flavor.   I had to add salt and pepper just to get some taste to it.  
Servers seem to enjoy chatting next to the register compared to actually serving customers. 
I definitely would not recommend this place unless you have time and money to waste.  
The one thing this place is atmosphere, but I wouldn't dine here just for that.

Amazing food here! We came here on our last night in New Orleans and are so glad we did. It was honestly one of the best meals we had in the city. The dishes were so unique and flavorful. We ordered the fried alligator (sauce on the side), pickled cucumbers, pork cheeks and rabbit with dumplings. The fried alligator was pretty good- had a chewy texture and we were glad we had the sauce on the side so we could really taste the alligator itself. The fresh herbs and pickled onions with the alligator made the dish very tasty. The pickled cucumbers were flavorful with a good tang to the vinaigrette, perfect contrast to the richness of the rabbit. The pork cheeks were tender and also very good. For the rabbit, it was like a rabbit pot pie- a rich stew of rabbit with carrots and a white root vegetable- not a lot of rabbit meat itself, but very good. The dumplings were like soft biscuits on the top- a nice accompaniment to the dish. For the two of us, this was plenty of food so we were not craving dessert. Our waitress at the restaurant was not particularly attentive-we waited a while for her to take our orders and she seemed to be gone for a large portion of the time we were there (we were constantly waiting for her), but thankfully the food came out in a timely manner. The food, however, was delicious and we would definitely come back.

Excellent.  Very accomodating, especially since we brought in 3 young children.  The fried alligator nuggets were spicy and delicious.  My rosé was dry and refreshing. My 5-year-old devoured the crawfish pie--the one bite I got was phenomenal.  The service was impeccable, and the decor was spacious and modern.

Not a very good neighbor they take up all the sidewalk with tables and chairs. Bikes located to everything on the other side of street. Workers taken breaks on the other side of street. Leaving cigs butts, drink cup and food containers all over. Never clean the sidewalks.  Then today they took over the sidewalk to paint some wood. Couldn't walk dogs because a trap on sidewalk full of paint with roller and pan. They don't care about the people who leave here. No star!!!!!

Good food, prices are a bit steep though. We had the ribs for the appetizer and they were awesome (we loved the watermelon salsa), rabbit with dumplings (ordered it because it was highly recommended in previous reviews-super heavy, decent flavor, but definitely felt overpriced at 23$), ham hock (lots of meat, pretty rich, reasonable price). I had the cold blooded cocktail which may be my favorite drink of our trip, definitely recommend!

Overall, good food, fun atmosphere, prices are pretty steep!

First complaint: The hostess told me we'll wait 10-15 minutes and we ended up waiting for almost 40 minutes. Please find a better way to estimate the wait time. 

Second complaint: This place tries to be a "trendy" new American restaurant with a high price tag and just does not live up to that ambition. The menu is not descriptive enough nor is the waitstaff good at explaining what to expect. Moreover, there is not enough diversity in the menu. You end up wanting to try maybe one of the entrees or the appetziers, but nothing else. 

That being said, the wood-fired oysters are great. We ended up getting two orders of these. But honestly, having five oysters per plate, rather than a round number, a half dozen? Cheap move. 

But everything else we ordered was just not up to par, especially if you consider the price tag attached to them. 

The pork cheek was underseasoned (read: tasteless). Even though the cook was great, the plate was just not enjoyable. In contrast, the BBQ ribs were overseasoned. The cook was spot on, but the whole dish was just smothered in really hearty, rich sauce. 

For dessert, we had the chocolate pudding. It was just about as good as the ones I have made at home. Not impressive. 

I would skip this place, especially as someone coming from San Francisco. It was a big letdown.

Oh my God, this place will change the way you look at oysters. This was by far the best meal I had in New Orleans, and my only regret was that it's not open on Sunday, so I couldn't go back for a return visit before my weekend ended.

PROS:

- Wood-fired oysters. Just get them. After thinking that Acme had some fantastic grilled oysters, I had my mind blown with these. The way that they cook the oysters perfectly preserve the delicate meatiness of the oyster, but enhances it with a special kick of spices. It was so good we sopped up the juice with our bread afterwards.
- The rabbit and dumplings were like a much better version of a chicken pot pie -- cooked to perfection
- Even the rolls were amazing! Fluffy, light, the way that rolls are supposed to be but never are.

CONS:

- I liked the fried alligator, but to be honest I felt like it was a little too expected. There wasn't anything particularly special about it.
- Service is a little hit or miss. Sometimes the server stopped at our table every 5 minutes, sometimes we would try to flag him down and couldn't find him at all.

Overall, a fantastic experience. Thanks NOLA!
Went here for dinner two nights ago. Wasn't impressed but the food was yummy . I recommend the macaroni casserole and the ribs

Wow, where do we start? 

I got a seat next to the kitchen and watch the beautiful rock symphony that is kitchen work. Since I'm in town to get around a bunch of food and drink spots, I gotta go with some "only in NOLA" fare, which meant the alligator bites and the cochon. 

First off they bring delicious hot yeast rolls which I believe are sourdough. I eateds two. I did not anticipate the complimentary "amuse boche" head cheese, if I did I would have probably stuck to one roll. The headcheese was quite excellent. Not too fatty but fatty enough to make it a marvelous, savory spread onto toast bits. Think vietnamese head cheese but a lot richer. It was accompanied with mustard and sweet pickles, which is like c'mon, are we trying to channel banh mi here? (The answer is yes.) 

Now the alligator bites- wow-e, fantastic! Never had alligator before, but it was surprisingly mild. It's like if fish, chicken, and frog had a baby it would taste like this. The batter was nice and crispy. The sauce quite frankly tasted like sriracha mayo which I am not hating on. The parsley and sliced raw white onion cut up the richness with some aromatic, sweet punches. 

Now for the crowning dish, the cochon. Omg. The cochon. This cochon will probably make Cochon my #2 favorite restaurant in the world. Tender, succulent pork packed into a a cake, pan seared, served on top of beautifully perfectly braised cabbage, big pieces of cracklin, and pickled turnip pieces. Flavor and texture perfection. I don't even like pork! The cabbage really was the star here though, I have never had better cabbage in my life. It was so flavorful and tender without falling apart. the flavor married well with the pork. Funny enough once again, it channeled some asian dishes- braised cabbage and pork is a Chinese staple and the sweet and sour element is often found in our cuisine.

Great atmosphere and excellent service. The food was good but nothing that really stood out, except their grilled oysters. We ordered it twice! The butter sauce they put on it is really good. Try this place if you must, but you're not missing much if you didn't.

Visited Nawlin' this past weekend for my friend's bachelorette bash, and we ate dinner here before going back to NYC. I have visited NOLA once before, but have never eaten at Cochon. My friend recommended that we all must eat here because it was super delicious. I have read the wonderful reviews prior to eating here, and did not have much expectation. But man oh man, this is hands down the best meal I had in NOLA! Everything was mind blowing that we all had to order seconds! Now I know why Cochon was inducted into the Nations Restaurant News Hall of Fame and was listed in The New York Times as one of the top 3 restaurants that counts. 

We were a party of 10, and reservations were made weeks ago. The decor was lovely, and the staff was so attentive, friendly and wonderful. But most importantly, the foods were outstanding! The foods we ordered to share were:

Wood-fired Oysters w/ Chili Garlic Butter ($14) -- This was my most favorite. It was so delicious that we all got 4 orders of this. This is a must order! You won't regret.

Fried Alligator w/ Chili Garlic Mayo ($12) -- I have eaten alligator meat in Thailand once by mistake (someone lied to me and said it was chicken), and I got so disgusted ever since that I vowed not to eat it ever again. Well, I may have eaten my word because I ate that fried alligator ball & it was so damn delicious! That sauce was so amazing. The alligator tasted like chicken & squid. Delish!

Fried Livers w/ Pepper Jelly & Toast ($8) - I didn't eat this b/c I don't eat organ meats, but my friends loved it very much that this was also reordered.

Fried Boudin w/ Pickled Peppers ($9) - This was my 2nd most favorite! Tasty, Savory & Crunchy. The dijon mustard sauce complemented the boudin so well. We also reordered this because it was so damn good!

Onions Braised Pork Cheeks w/ Grits, Radish & Crushed Herbs ($12) - This was very tender and tasty. The group loved it so much, it was also reordered.

Ham Hock w/ Sweet Potatoes, Picked Greens & Black Eyed Peas ($26) - The ham was so tender & the sweet potatoe pureed complemented the ham so well (like a sweet & salty combo). We liked it but it wasn't our most favorite.

Louisiana Cochon w/ Cabbage, Cracklins & Picked Turnips ($24) - This is another must order! Since the restaurant is named "Cochon", this entree must be ordered. It was so tender, tasty, and we loved it so much we ordered seconds!

Oven-roasted Gulf Fish ($32) - Fish was tender and meaty, but it was a bit lacking in flavor. I wouldn't order this again.

Mac & Cheese Casserole ($7) - One of the best mac & cheese I have ever eaten. This is also a must order. We ordered seconds! YUM!

Coconut Snowball w/ coconut cream & meringue ($8) - Couldn't leave w/o ordering desserts. I was so shocked that their desserts were that good. This is a must order! I have never eaten something so unique like this, and it was so tasty (not overwhelmingly sweet). It was also so fluffy. Damn good! This was my top dessert out of the 3.

Pineapple Upside down cake w/ coconut lime sherbet ($8) - This was also delicious, and not overwhelmingly sweet (b/c pineapple upside down cakes can be too sweet). This one was my 2nd fav out of the 3 desserts we tried.

Chocolate Hazelnut Pudding ($8) - For big chocolate lovers, you would like this very much. It was very rich, smooth, and tasty (not too sweet). It was very tasty, but not my most favorite b/c I don't really like pudding textured foods that much. But I would recommend chocolate lovers to get this.

In conclusion, I highly recommend Cochon to anyone visiting NOLA. This is a must eat place. After eating here, I can't stop preaching to other people on how delicious it was. Wish they would open a shop in NYC one day...if not I guess I have to save my vacation days and come back to Nawlin' again.

Sweet Jesus was this place amazing. The food knocked my socks off!!! Their ribs are to die for and so is the Mac and cheese.... My only let down was the service but I feel like our waiter was stretched thin and did the best he could. If you can get kitchen side seating, take it. Those guys rock!

Food was great. Very well placed and decorative. You are paying extra bucks for artistry. Ambiance is somewhat lacking. 
   Complaint would be, that what appears to be vegetables with an entree turn out to be a garnish. The menu is technically a la Carte for everything. Sides are alacarte . 
Service was acceptable, but they did give us the wrong check. We had to correct that. 
  The place is clean, even the restrooms.

Amazing meal! Everything we tried was great. You know it's going to be good once you walk in because it smells so darn good in there. Menu does change but I would trust anything in the menu. My friend and I tried the wood-fired oysters that was cooked to perfection and not over cooked! We also had the Mac and cheese as an app instead of a side, it was very creamy and not too heavy. Then for entrees first we had the pork cheek, we both had never had the cheek before it was so tender and the sauce with the grits was a great combination. Also we had the Louisiana Cochon, also very tasty, we felt it had a stew type of vibe and the cabbage had a nice kick of spice. All the flavors in the dishes were on point! The decor is beat too.

Amazing spot! Loved the chill, elegant but casual atmosphere and decor that reminds me of a classier stylized warehouse. The service was on spot, water refilled just when we needed, never interrupted at the wrong times (aka when my mouth is full of food), really great recommendations from our waiter Josh. We ordered two appetizers, one meat and one entree and one dessert, maybe a bit too much for our stomachs but it was really good. Some challah looking bread with butter was brought in the beginning - and if the bread is good, I'm sure the food will be amazing! The "wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter $12" was legit the best oysters I have ever had. The light sauce on top was heavenly savory and tasted like it was my first bite every time. The "fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise $11" was amazing in taste but the texture of the gator was a bit tougher than I would've liked it. For meat, our "smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickle $12" was amazing! So stewed down that we accidentally bit in the bone. Super sweet but maybe a bit dry. Watermelon pickle was an interesting little garnish. Then we had "louisiana cochon with turnips, cabbage & cracklins $23"

I came here with my colleagues and we had about a 15 minute wait for a table around 6:30 pm which was perfect because it started to get pretty packed after we arrived. The food was delicious! We started with the oysters and the alligator - both were delicious!! My colleagues had the ham hock and the cochon, both were delicious! I had the goldfish fisherman style, which is the fish filleted with the skin on one side. The fish was fresh and flavorful, perfectly cooked. For dessert we had the coconut snowball-which was a vanilla cake with cream in between and covered in coconut flakes. We also had the hazelnut pudding. Take a recommendation and order both and eat them together, it's pure perfection! Come here, you won't be disappointed! A+!

I was pretty disappointed. The food was incredibly good but the price and the portions were totally unreasonable. The fried alligator and the oysters were delicious, there were so many flavors but together it was $26 and I didn't feel full at all after my meal. 

For my entree, I got the rabbit and gravy. It was pretty good, not amazing and certainly not worth the $23 that I spent on it. The size of the entree was also incredibly small, and there were probably 5 very small pieces of rabbit. I won't be recommending this place to my friends. If you do come here for food, just get be oysters for a taste. Don't spend $20 on a meal that won't even fill you up. 

The atmosphere of the restaurant was really nice. I liked the decor. The service though was terrible. The waitress took forever to get us our water, take our order, and bring us our food. I was incredibly disappointed in the service for the restaurant. Overall, not satisfied even if the food is good.

If I could give this 10 stars, I would!  I have had the best meal of my life here!
The management makes anything possible, as long as you ask prior to your visit; they are a great staff!
Kudos to the chef, and don't forget to order the oysters!

Oh my good lord have mercy!!! Hands-down the best place for food in New Orleans. At first I was skeptical due to the prices, but the food was beyond worth it. The lunch entree of the day was marinated pork with dirty rice and a green salad with a sour vinaigrette. Phenomenal!! I started with some oven-fired oysters and I couldn't ask for anything more. I wasn't sure what to expect, and I am no expert on food, but I am an expert on what I like and I very much liked this meal. Well-rounded with flavor that melded together perfectly. I would recommend this place to anyone who simply wants to chill and enjoy a perfectly cooked meal with a significant other or a small group of friends.

Intimate setting.
Great food.
Unique combinations.
Perfect proportions.
Do it.

Two stars for service! Terrible waitstaff service!! Our second time and while the food is amazing (pork cheeks, yummy) We were forgotten about, our drink order was wrong, and I got the impression we were putting them out. Hostess station seated us in promptly at the chef bar. The kitchen ran smoothly and they were very engaging when we had questions about the menu (server nowhere to be found, then bothered by my questions).  Check comes and a "no charge" for an amuse bouche is on itemized receipt, our counter parts each received one... if it wasn't the second time within a year I might just not go back, as there are many acclaimed restaurants to choose from. I hope the problem gets solved soon.

Memorable! 

Stopped here for some appetizers and drinks. We had the pork ribs (delicious and tender), fried crocodile with aioli (surprisingly like chicken but also very tasty) and the fried boudin (my least favorite of the three, but my boyfriend really enjoyed this one). The drinks were also well done. Would return for the ribs alone! :)
Truly amazing food and not touristy at all.  Sat at the bar and had the Boudin fritters and pork special of the night.  Both were to die for.  Wish I was in town longer for a second visit.

Loved. Loved. This place. The vibe the decor the food and the drinks. My fav place in New Orleans so far!  My Italian husband also loved the mushroom risotto which is a big deal. If I ever come back to NOLA or have to recommend a place to anyone this will definitely be it!

This one pains me. It really does. I went to school in New Orleans. And when I get back, there's really only one thing I want to do. Eat. The last time I was here I wanted to get to Cochon. But couldn't. This time - just before Easter - I was here with my wife and two daughters. We were lucky to get an early reservation and we were psyched. The entire experience was kind of weird. New Orleans is known for its hospitality and easy spirit. The vibe here felt contrived. The food was great. It really was. From warm yeast raised rolls to the rabbit stew. Well done. But from the beginning, we felt like something was off. Our server never smiled, though she was cordial. There was definitely an attitude lurking (let's get it straight, this is Cochon, not Commander's). And then one of the server helpers (bus lady) - after attempting to clear my plate too early, spilled an entire glass of ice water into my lap. It wasn't a splash. It was a deluge. I was soaked and cold. And I laughed it off. And did my best to move on. The helper said sorry. But our server never returned. Not once. Never to say sorry, to see how we were doing, to ask if she could help. She walked by our table several times and wouldn't make eye contact. Maybe she was embarrassed. But it almost felt like she "gave up on us." As if, "well they're a lost cause so I'll move on to other customers." In fact, the helper who spilled the water was now relegated to finishing the service. She was now taking our dessert orders, etc. As if, "you screwed that one up so you take them now." It was weird. The manager came over and apologized - but only after he realize our dessert order was taking so long. They said the Chef wasn't happy with the presentation and wanted to do it over. Bullshit. Come on. What would you expect for all of this inconvenience? A comped entree? A comped dessert? A comped meal? Well, they offered a comped glass of wine. Seriously? I didn't ask for anything, and the bill came back with a comped glass of wine. I didn't want to make a scene...I was with my kids. But I felt as if I were the one who inconvenienced them. Not the other way around.  Ultimately they settled on comped desserts (which they should have done anyway given we waited 20 minutes for them) and a comped 2 glasses of wine. It is amazing what bad service can do to ruin a great meal. We won't be back. And I'd recommend you try it only if you think you won't have a glass of ice water spilled into your crotch and only if you're willing to feel like you're dining there at their pleasure, not yours.

I stopped in for a quick lunch and I may have just ordered wing but I had high hopes and the flavors just didn't quite hit them. The cocktail that I start d with was tasty. I had the BBQ Oysters, the Boudin Balls, and the Alligator bites.  I was advised that they were small plates and I could eat them myself but this was not the case. They were full appetizers and it looked a little ridiculous on my table. Also it was way too much food. The alligator had a good flavor but it was extremely chewy. I have had alligator before so this was not a first experience with its texture. The boudin balls were good but way too big and filling. Wish they were a quarter of the size. The BBQ oysters were good. Nice flavor and texture. Over all given the menu and the reviews I think this place is better than the experience I had but not sure I will be back to try it out.

This place was phenomenal.  It had been on our radar for over a year (we don't live in NOLA) and on a crazy rainy Tuesday night we got in with no reservation.  Ordered a few plates for the table to share, every dish had such standout flavor making every bite worth it.  Only downside is that even their mac n cheese had some spice in it making it hard to find something for a kiddo to eat.  
Service was good. Beers were great. Atmosphere easy.

We went for lunch on our first day in Nola. We got three appetizers: alligator meat, gumbo with deviled egg, and fried liver with jelly pepper and toast. Everything tasted delicious! Probably my most favorite gumbo i've tasted (they put lots of okra, love that!) 

For entree we shared a special of the day; grilled red fish (i think). It literally melt in my mouth, the meat was so freSh and delicious. The skin was still on, gave it the needed crunchiness. 

Im still drooling thinking about Cochon

So good my lady and I ate here twice during our stay in New Orleans! The gator tail bites were amazing, the mac & cheese was to die for, and the meat selection.... Is there a drool button?? I'll tell you this we had to stop here before going to the airport and it was the best way to end the trip and would do it all over again

This place was certified el fuego. The cocktails had me doing all sorts of impressive calisthenics across the refurbished wood bar. Take your lady here to remind her you aren't a total scumbag (it's not your fault you occasionally follow thots on Insta my G). Flex on.

The table had fried oysters as an app. Not sure what kind of contract you have to make with the Dark Lord to procure giant multiple oysters per each shell, coupled with straight SINFUL chili garlic butter sauce for your restaurant, but I wholly agree that whoever's soul was signed away for it was well worth the price.
