I myself ordered the namesake. The meat was so tender and succulent I swear it must've been braised in sow tears. The fritters were on some Funyuns-of-the-gods level-type ish. My girl's oyster and bacon sandwich had me passive aggressively resenting her later for not bringing home leftovers.

The only negative was the large and loud table of basic frat daddy brotoypes who were seated next to us and unable to maintain their composure post 2-3 Bud Light Limes. They were obnoxious and insisted on interacting with me and my party despite us repeatedly politely declining their company. Normally this offense is grounds for docking of a star or two but our waitress seemed even more tired of their ish than we were and ended up verbally slapping them down to size quicker than a single mother at Chuck E. Cheese on her last nerve.

Go here my G.

We took another trip back to NOLA and this time brought our friends with us. This was #1 on our places to go. If I could give this restaurant 100 stars, I would. Can't think of one negative thing (well, except that the amazing peanut butter pie is no longer served) (seriously almost cried over it, lol).
Everyone in our party of 6 was amazed with their meal. The food is seriously so so so good. We had 2 excellent waiters. One had dark hair and a beard and the other sorta looked like Keegan Michael Key. They were both seriously awesome. They even called a cab for us at the end of our meal, we were well taken care of. 
This time I had the pulled pork. So good! We ordered the char grilled oysters too, excellent. I had some of my husbands rabbit dumpling, amazing. Everyone's food looked great. 
Our friends were so impressed and we were happy to be able to take them to such a special place. We will never skip Cochon any time we return to NOLA. Love it!

I loved this place. Out of all the places we ate during our 10 days in New Orleans, this was my favorite. The environment was casual and the food was amazing. 

Favorite items ordered by the group: 

- fire roasted oysters (I am not a huge oyster fan, but these were delicious)
- short rib
- eggplant casserole

This place gets very busy and reservations fill up weeks in advance, so plan in advance.

We, a party of four, ordered cocktails and just about 2/3 of the menu...hands down one the best meals I've had in the U.S.!!!

Cocktails on point!
Food on point!
Service was the best one could ask for!

This is a top notch - professional - fun/cozy - no pretentious just rad f'n food!!

Wish they were in San Francisco

Although I am not one to give bad reviews, I actually created a Yelp account just to review this place. Came in with some friends while I was in town visiting family. Firstly, I'm not sure if they were just unusually busy but there was considerable confusion at the hostess stand, and she barely looked up to acknowledge our party. 

After being seated, the server took her sweet time to approach our table, she seemed much more concerned about laughing with her friends at the bar or at the register. Overall very snotty, as she was above our questions despite the fact that it was our first visit. I wish I had paid better attention to her name (I only remember that it started with an "A") as I probably should've spoken to management about her. I've never before felt as if I was being judged by a server simply for inquiring about the menu and wine selection. 

The food was ok, terribly overpriced for the quality and quantity, which was disappointing as I had high hopes after seeing this place featured on the travel channel and numerous websites. 

The pathetic service by far overshadowed the entire visit, and sadly we will not return. The "best of New Orleans" lists should be revised.

Decided to stop in while in NO based on Bourdain's positive review of this place... well, we were blown away by their food! Every single thing we ordered was absolutely delicious! Our whole group loved the place and the food.

If you've never been, this place is a must!

A super duper strong 4 star. We loved everything about Cochon. The food was good, service was good, and the drinks were good. 

We especially loved the meat board.

This place came highly recommended from a friend, and was absolutely the best meal of my trip to New Orleans! Cute little restaurant in a beautiful neighborhood, away from the touristy-ness of the French Quarter and Canal Street. 

My boyfriend and I opted to split a bunch of small plates rather than ordering entrees, and we were delighted with everything we tried. The highlight of the meal however, was 100% the wood fired oysters in chili garlic butter. The oysters literally melted in your mouth, and oh my god, that butter. I wanted to pour it over everything. The boudin balls were also good, although I do think I've had better throughout the city. We also tried the cucumber salad - simple, yet refreshing and spicy - as well as the mac n cheese, super cheesy and actually flavorful. We ended the meal with the pineapple upside cake with lime coconut sorbet which was awesome, and was a perfect end to the meal. 

From start to finish, everything from service, to food, to drinks, was perfected. Highly recommend to everyone visiting or living in the area. You really can't get a better bang for your buck - two cocktails, a whole lot of delicious food, and a dessert later, we still managed to get out of there for well under $100, tip included!

Fabulous!    Crawfish Pie....Mac'n Cheese. ...Red Fish...the best!    Busy!  Get reservations! 
First time ever where we did NOT need  tartar sauce!!  And easy on the pocket book!

Fried alligator was fun - nothing crazy but we got it just to say we did.  Cocktail menu was fresh.  Habanero Bitters! 

Everyone love their entrees.....Pork, rabbit, ham hock.....plates were locked clean. 

It's crowded. Loud. Casual but full of tourists. 

The food was 4 but we had poor poor service. We ended up with free appetizers and drinks because they were forgotten and we had to ask. :(
Delicious!! We had almost everything on the menu, the service was top notch! The drinks were amazing! This is definitely a must if you are in NOLA!
One of the best meals I had in New Orleans. Great food with great service. I tried alligator for the first time here and it was delicious! Great cocktails as well!!

I had a business dinner with a party of 7. Overpriced hipster restaurant with mediocre food at best. For appetizer I had the pork cheeks which wasn't that bad. However, my main course dish rabbit dumplings was bland, heavy on the carrots and potatoes with little to no rabbit. What rabbit that I could find was very tough. 

Bar menu was lacking and desert was a pass since dinner was such a disappointment.

If I had a better experience, I would have picked up the check on this one...decided to turn it over to the one who recommended the restaurant. That will teach him!

The Wood Fired Oysters are game changing , not to mention they're filled with chili butter. 

Came here as a couple of tourists looking for some alligator (I know so typical) ended up stepping into one of the tastiest dining experiences yet! 

The alligator was amazing! Probably more so because the sauce that was slathered over top was some kind of spicy heavenly concoction. But the meat was very light and delicious. 

We also ordered a turkey gumbo that was being offered at the time. Again delicious, had a slow creeping smokey heat to it. (If you couldn't tell I love spice) 

Not much to say about the oysters other than we wish we could've ordered more. Truly mouth watering. 

Lastly we got a side salad of arugula, broccolini I believe, radish and cranberry dressed with a light and sweet sauce, another win in our book.

Only gripe is the portion size but it's to be expected when you have chefs that really know what they're doing in the kitchen.

Slightly over-hyped for me. I came in really wanting to like this place, and the drinks were definitely great, and so was the service, but my main dish, the louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklins & pickled turnips, was so salty, I couldn't finish it. The pork was just too much, and even with the pickled turnips and kimchi type cabbage, it still wasn't enough to balance out the flavors, so I had to order a lemonade on top of it and ended up not finishing my meal.

Luckily having such a big group, we got to try a few different things. Their alligator appetizer was pretty good, so were the ribs, but I left with too much of a salty taste in my mouth. And no espresso/coffee either to wash it all down.

I've wanted to try this place for the longest time but it never worked out on my visits to New Orleans.  I finally had the perfect opportunity with two friends coming in from Europe.  I luckily got a reservation for four under short notice and couldn't have been happier.  

Sadly, I have to say this place is incredibly over-hyped. The drinks are great along with the service and atmosphere.  However, most of our meals were a huge disappointment including our fried alligator appetizer (which may have just been off that night).  The mac and cheese was quite good at least.  

I'm writing this review a couple months after dining here and I had to look at the menu on the website to even remember what I had because it was so forgettable.  I'm actually getting a little mad just remembering the night.  From what it looks like, I had the ham hock with sweet potatoes, pickled greens, and black eyed peas.  It was incredibly salty and just didn't really hit the mark on any aspect you would expect from a restaurant this well reviewed and admired.

Thankfully, the rest of the food on the trip was on point so I could at least make it up to my friends for bringing them here.

Mainly based on the reviews from some fine people here, I headed over to Cochon on a Wednesday night during a visit with my son.  We sat at the bar in front of the open kitchen and it was quite a treat.

Service was outstanding led by Ryan and team.  The entire staff was integral to the experience and was thoroughly well versed on the menu items.  The selections were enough to get a spin on some local dishes but limited enough to know they were focused on all of them.

So let's get to the food.  Fried Alligator had a wonderful coating and served in scrumptious sauce.  We moved on to the pork belly and boudin and they were great interpretations.  The star of the night was the Cochon.  Lovely shredded pieces of pork with cabbage and cracklings.  A mixture of flavor and texture that was utterly unctuous.

File under honorable mention the complimentary head cheese plate.  This dish can cover the gamut from really bad to what I had at Cochon.  It was well balanced between luscious pieces of the most flavorful pork and a texture that supported all that flavor.  

This was a gastric experience that I was grateful to share with my foodie son.  Thanks to the entire team for making a memorable night for us!

After hearing and seeing (Bourdain episode) so much hype about this place my expectations were so high. I even came here for my bday dinner no less. Sadly it was a very lackluster and annoying experience. My first impression of the place is that it's absurdly loud. Absurdly. You can't even speak with your dining partners, you have to yell. This applies to the waitstaff as well. And that's only when they're available. Could someone please tell Mr. Link to hire more waitstaff?? These people are ran ragged trying to serve the entire dining room, I counted about 4 of them that night. What is the rationale to having so few waitstaff on the floor? It's not as though they are saving money. So strange and disappointing. This would never fly in NYC, people would laugh you out of the city. 
        Onto the eating...... So, we were served by various waitstaff throughout the evening. None of them could hear us, nor we them. Orders had to be repeated at a yell. Their beer list appears wonderful, sadly the waitress couldn't tell me the first thing about their rotating tap list. When I ordered a rare local IPA in a magnum bottle she brought out a shot glass and flung the beer into it. Absurd. There was no beer, just a shot glass of foam. A shot glass. Completely full of foam. Yes, and I paid $15 for that bottle. Again, absurd. To the food.....
        We ordered starters- boudin and the oysters. The boudin wouldn't be a starter for a child, disappointment. The oysters on the other hand, whoa. My God, the food of the evening and perhaps the one saving grace. They were delicious, it was the taste of the sea with smoke. A genius dish. Our mains were the Rabbit and dumplings and Louisiana Cochon. Neither were very good. The Cochon was a salty overkill and the Rabbits tasted of cloying fall spices- mace, thyme, and whatever else they put in the roux. Weird, and again disappointing. Dessert didn't offer much better, chocolate pudding was well, plain old chocolate pudding. And the pineapple upside down cake, I could honestly make it just as well. Nothing you can't get in other restaurants way better. 
       After tip it was a $180 meal. That was more than Atchafalya, Brennan's, or the Upperline. All three of those were by far better meals. Do yourself a favor, look for better food. This city abounds with it. Cochon doesn't.

The best restaurant of all I visited during my stay in new Orleans

Chargrilled oysters
Watermelon pickeled coated ribs
Rabbit
Aligator
The list goes on
Had the oysters and short rib for appetizers. Dinner was the pork shoulder dish and a salad. Snow Ball and lemon pie for dessert.

Absolutely amazing! We loved this place so much, we returned for more. It's a short walk from French Quarter, which you will be grateful for once you leave over satisfied. 
We had the Woodfired Oysters, which for someone who doesn't like Oysters to start with, was the best plate we had in New Orleans. We also ordered a few small plates and shared them, Louisiana Cochon was a must at a restaurant named after it and didn't disappoint. (even at the Jazz Fest stuffed in a Po-boy)! Their cocktail menu and desserts were inventive.
Just go, you won't be dissapointed.

We had a very underwhelming experience here several weeks ago. We arrived on a Thursday night with no reservation based on a recommendation from our hotel up the street. We were given an estimated wait time of 35-40 minutes. After being offered a table outside (where it had been lightly raining off and on) which we declined, we were finally seated 90 minutes later in the back room of the restaurant. The entire time we were waiting we got nothing but attitude from the hostess who seemed to think that she was doing us a favor by seating us at all. When we were seated, our waiter was very empathetic to the fact we had been waiting so long and did his best to expedite our dinner. Sadly, after all of that waiting, the food just did not live up to our expectations. The ribs and shrimp were delicious, but the cochon was plain disappointing. I was expecting something with a lot more of a unique flavor, but all I got was a very salty dish. Doubtful that we will be back on our next visit to town.
Amazing. As always. Today the ribs made me want to drive to Memphis and slap some sense into them

Very solid - I had the Louisiana Cochon and the mac and cheese and tried one of their specialty drinks. The Cochon was smokey and delicious. Like to get back and try the fried oyster and bacon sandwich

This place is regarded as one of the finest restaurants in New Orleans and it does not disappoint. 

We had a party of 12 and tried to expand it to 20. I had to make a reservation almost 45 days in advance just to get a table and when we tried to expand, there was no chance. We had a 9 PM reservation on a Monday night so we only had a hour to order and think about dessert before the kitchen closed.

We were all there and ready at 9 PM and so was our table. The restaurant was hoping and there were no free tables in my sight, but the hostess lead us through the dining room took a sharp left turn and there was a back dining room I hadn't seen! With a table waiting for us.

As we looked at the menu and ordered drinks, more friends showed up. I started getting a little nervous, because when I called to expand our reservation, they were pretty strict on not letting us have more than 12 people. But the waiter and hostess were SOOO friendly and nice! They accommodated my late comers (six People!!) and made us all feel comfortable and welcome!  I should add that we had all been drinking and the staff was patient with our drunkenness!

We shared all the small plates and boucherie. What stood out to me was the wood-fired oyster and the fried alligator, who knew? 

For dinner I had the Louisiana Cochon which was amazing. I did get to try cat fish, gulf fish and beef creole daube. Everything was truly delicious!  Also, get the mac and cheese side!!

When the check came I was the one who organized the paying. I collected the cash and credit cards and made sure the bill was covered. The waiter, and I am sorry for not remembering his name, was so gracious and pleasant through out our experience there and he really made our night by just laughing with us and making us feel like we were not as big a pain as I thought we were.

Thanks to everyone there for making it a wonderful dinner!

I had the Louisiana Couchon - pulled pork shoulder formed into a patty, dusted with flour and seared and served over a bed of cabbage. Smokey and delicious. The Mac and cheese is creamy and delicious as a side.

Amazing. Just delicious, great service and atmosphere. Definitely lived up to its name and I'm so happy about it. I had the oysters and pork cheeks (just dropped in for a snack) and both were so rich and full of flavor and depth. I'm salivating now. I should go back.

The place is always super packed, so we went to the bar &  ordered drinks & food. The bar service was NOT the best,  they were slammed & not paying attention to the customers. We also ordered food which was pretty amazing but it was cold. We couldn't get the bartenders attention, so it was an okay experience. Maybe next time we can sit at a table & get a better service.
Pretty amazing place, serious takes on meat and side dishes. A fine restaurant in a town full of them, yet a standout. Not for the faint of wallet I must warn you. You may want to try everything.

Great restaurant. The worst customer service I've ever experienced. I have no idea who they think they are and why they think they can talk to people the way they do. I almost felt like they loved to talk to people with a rude demeanor and were proud to turn people away. With so many choices in NOLA why would I ever come here again?

First time visitor to the restaurant, I heard/read a lot of great reviews so I wanted to check it out during my visit to New Orleans.

The food was excellent.  We ordered the oysters, the cheeks, and boudin balls to start.  All very tasty - GF thought the cheeks were her favs and mine was the boudin.  We then got the gumbo - one of the better, if not the best we had during our time in NO.  We decided to finish by splitting the ham hock.  Falling off the bone, this was super tender.  I was a bit iffy on the broth that it's cooked in - seemed to lack something, and looking at the other photos, it was a bit different that particular day, but overall the dish was still quite nice.

For drinks, we got the bourbon/strawberry cocktail.  Super delicious and would highly recommend it.

Service was great, food was delicious and we're glad this was our last meal before hopping on the plane back home.

***Cochon resto is not the sandwich place- that is Cochon Butcher- we screwed that up. 

Fabulous food, unfriendly and rather absent staff. I was so excited to check this place out after a long day of conferencing; the second you walk through the door it smelled heavenly, I immediately expressed how much go I was
Looking forward to the meal and hostesses looked at me like I was a weirdo, and the waitress took 15 minutes to take our app order after we sat down, who also wasn't the friendliest. 

Doesn't matter though- the food was incredible. Started with the cucumber salad and a mixed green one with roasted peanuts which was super smokey and delicious. Each of us ordered and shared entrees, the Ham hock was one of the tastiest things I've ever had- melted in your mouth and fell right off the bone. The rabbit was a big let down- could barely taste or find any pieces in the very hearty stew. The beef creole was good but not too many pieces of steak. We also God Mac n cheese and smothered greens which were both sensational. I had been looking for a great southern collards dish all week and this didn't disappoint. Drinks were a tad sweet for my taste but overall great business/lunch/dinner spot aside from the service hiccups.

I was visiting New Orleans and after reading multiple reviews about this restaurant, I decided to visit. I had the oyster bacon sandwich and fried alligator. The alligator was lacking a little bit of salt and the oyster sandwich tasted just like any other. The ambiance of the restaurant was brilliant but I would definitely not go back to this restaurant if I visited NOLA again!

My friends wanted to try this restaurant after seeing it on an Anthony Bourdain episode. We came on a Thursday night and the wait was 2 hours long but we stuck with it because we really wanted to try it. Verdict? Too over-hyped for me.

The food was ridiculously salty here. EVERY.SINGLE.DISH.

Smoked Ham Hock 2/5 - Over cooked and dry. Salty.

Louisiana Cochon 3/5 - If I had to pick one dish I actually enjoyed at this restaurant, this would be it. However, it is still pretty average. Nothing very special about it. The meat was tender but the flavors were lacking. Salty

Wood-fired Oysters w/ Chili Garlic Butter 2/5 - Tasteless. Can't even taste the chili garlic butter. Tasted like half cooked oysters. Salty

Rabbit & Dumplings 2/5 - Nothing special. Salty.

Fried Livers 1/5 - I'm normally an intestine girl but the way that this was prepared had nothing to offer besides the fried batter on the outside. Nothing special. Salty.

Mixed Greens Salad 2/5 - Salty. How the eff do you make a salad salty?!!?

The restaurant is loud as fuck inside. You almost have to scream when talking in order for your party to hear you. The service was definitely a miss for our server was only around when we flagged him down and he never once offered to fill up our waters until we asked. Ummm.. hello? Are we invisible to you?

For a restaurant that's so "popular" it sucks! Save your money and go elsewhere. If I wanted my meal to be extra salty I can always eat a can of salt at home. Don't waste your time.
Pork cheeks were AMAZING.  Soft and succulent and meaty with every bite.  Pork cheeks has moved up to the number 1 spot above pork belly on my favorite part from a pig list.

This place was fantastic, servers did their job, whilst being a little understaffed, everything that came out of the kitchen was delicious. Big kudos to the chefs as it really was a delight. Alligator 10/10. Pork ribs 10/10. Boudin 11/10! Fantastic atmosphere. 

I would say however that first impressions leave a mark, and unfortunately I could not enjoy everything written in my first paragraph until about an hour in as the host (bigger girl wearing black spandex top, for identification purposes only) left a rather undesirable taste in my mouth. And not only mine but after some small talk with nearby tables seemed we all shared this opinion. This individual made it her job to be rude and add comment where it is not required, and was extremely unprofessional in the way she treated us at the door. Basically the way she looked and spoke to you broadcast that she did not really care to be there or to make you feel welcome. 

I wanted to leave a note saying please do not tip out this hostess. But did not feel that was the best place to voice it. Hence coming to Yelp. 

Hopefully they can remove her from her current post and put her to wash dishes. Or get her a job at McDonald's where they teach people how to welcome you properly. Well a McDonald's welcome would have been appreciated in this instance... Too bad can't give this place 4 3/4 stars as it is a 5 if you removed the host. 

Will be back next time I visit New Orleans as the food is amazing. However may call ahead first and ask who is standing at the door. 

Davide

It's hard to see what the hype is all about.  The food is OK, but based on the reviews and reputation I had expected more.  I started with the gumbo and fried chicken livers.  The gumbo portion was small, and while flavorful I found it to be thin.  I've had much better gumbo in NOLA.  The fried chicken livers were excellent but drowning in hot jelly.  And again, the portion size was small.  Undeterred, I ordered the ribs with watermelon pickle.  The ribs were done perfectly, but ruined because they were drowning in sauce.  Which is a shame because the watermelon pickle was an excellent addition but completely lost in the sauce. So overall, underwhelming.  In addition, the bar area is small and the bar staff a bit aloof - not engaging at all. In conclusion, go if you must but there are far better eating options in town.

Got there for lunch after hesitating between the restaurant and the sandwich place next door. We got the cochon de lait, fried alligator and fried boudin. All of them were A-MA-ZING! Will definitely be back next time I'm in NOLA.

Visited NOLA for the second weekend of Jazz fest 2016.  We read a lot of reviews on Cochon and knew we had to eat here.  It lived up to all the hype - super casual but GOOD. Everything about the place is good - service, the food, the drinks and the carefree/fun atmosphere of the restaurant and the others dining during Jazz fest.  If you have one night in NOLA this is the place I'd eat if I were you.
Excellent atmosphere and great cocktails.  We are wood fire oysters and alligator for appetizers and they were just right.

Hands down the best meal we had in NOLA. THEEE BEST. 

Ever had a meal where every single thing you tried was delicious? Cochon was one of those meals. 

You can only make reservations over the phone. I'm so glad we did, because the place was packed. We got lucky and scored some seats at the chef's counter where we were up close and personal with all of the action. It's seriously so mesmerizing, watching them pump out dish after dish after dish.  

The stuff we had the pleasure of ordering:
+ Wood fired oysters with chili garlic butter ($14) - there's a reason why everyone raves about these. We weren't going to order these at first because it seemed pricey, but they are soOOo worth it.
+  Fried alligator ($12) - Shawn C. liked this a lot.
+ Onion braised pork cheeks ($12) - same note as above, I tried the grits and liked that, though!
+ Catfish courtbouillon ($19) - really flavorful, huge portion
+ Upside down pineapple cake with lime sorbet ($8) - seriously SOOOO freckin' good. The warm cake is TO DIE FOR.

Oh yeah, the complimentary bread is pretty damn good. I'd usually skip the bread basket, but not here. Gimme the damn bread!!

I asked Shawn C. if we could come back the next day for lunch, it was a serious question, he said we should try something else. It's okay, Cochon. I'll be back for you one day.

Love this place! Haven't had Cajun food in over 10 years and the girl at the front desk of my hotel recommended this place. I came back twice because I wanted to try all their dishes. LOL. The wood fire grilled oysters in chili butter sauce is a MUST have. So delicious.  Until next time...if I have another business meeting in NOLA, I will definitely be back.

This place was fantastic. Great food and great service. Gumbo 9/10
Mac and cheese 9/10
Beers 10/10
Fun attractive people 8/10

I could hardly believe the crowd gathered at Cochon on a Monday night at 8:30 PM!  I guess the New Orleans food scene is a lot more serious than what we have going on in Denver (wah, wah).  We waited 45-minutes but were repaid by some seriously flavorful food.  Yeah it's loud, yeah it's not cheap but yeah it's worth it.  I had the ham hock and shared a side of mac and cheese with my husband and while the macaroni wasn't the best I've ever had, the ham hock dish more than made up for any cheese shortcomings.  Delightfully salty, fall off the bone tender and the deliciously complemented by the black eyed peas, greens and sweet potatoes.  I was extremely satisfied by everything we ate.

It's not often that food is revelatory.  We ordered the special, ribs on a lettuce wrap, and the pork was beyond perfect, complimented by spicy sauce and chili-roasted peanuts.  Each bite was close-your-eyes-to-savor-the-flavor good.  We had the shaved Brussel sprout salad, mac and cheese and boudin balls, all of which were delicious.  We had the pineapple upside down cake because of the picture and the bottom was crispy, the cake was dense, the pineapple tender, the caramel sauce a perfect compliment and the lime coconut ice cream set everything off perfectly.  

I've been hearing about Cochon for several years, but this was my first visit, and man, am I glad I went!  This will be a must-do for every future NOLA trip!

OMFG the oysters are incredible! Orgasmic!  I now know why they say oysters are an aphrodisiac...because whomever coined that ate oysters at Cochon!

The group of people I was with insisted we come to Cochon for oysters.  I was skeptical, how good can oysters really be?  We came around 9:00pm on a Thursday and it was packed and we couldn't get seated for 1.5 hours.  My friends insisted it was worth the wait, so we put our name on the list and went down the street for some drinks.  About an hour and half later, Cochon texted that our table was ready. Props already for having the texting system in place, I really like that.

So we sat outside, which was lovely.  Our waitress was very personable and funny and the service was fantastic.  We ordered a bunch of the wood fired oysters, which were really out of this world.  So much so that we ordered more.  I also got a salad too, which was very nice.  Others in my group got the oyster and bacon sandwich, which they said was fantastic.

So overall, Cochon is worth the wait and the oysters are a must.  I'm still dreaming of them.  I will definitely come here again when back in New Orleans.

Absolutely one of my favorite meals in New Orleans.  I came here for dinner and it was really loud so expect to yell across the table.  They have an extensive whiskey collection (including flights!) but I opted for a cocktail.  The COLD BLOODED made with vodka (which I subbed out for gin), basil, lime, habanero bitters and blood orange, was excellent.  I fell in love with their starter bread, which were these amazing hot Parker house rolls.  I asked to take the rest of my rolls home and my server instead packed a fresh batch for me.  Yay!

I was dining solo, so I couldn't finish everything, but I just had to try their much-hyped FRIED ALLIGATOR.  These breaded and fried chunks of alligator were fantastic though they were tossed in a bit too much chili garlic mayo sauce for my taste.  The bites with mint were the best.  For my entree, I got the CATFISH COURTBOUILLON.  So good!  It's filets of catfish stewed in a delicious sauce and served with rice.

Great food.  Great service.

My friends from Philadelphia love this place and refuse to eat anywhere else when they come to town. In their opinion, "This is the best food we have ever had." And that's coming from a guy who doesn't like pork about a restaurant known for pork. My opinion differs a little from that; I would go so far as to say "best", but the food is excellent. Its not an all-pork menu, they cater to those who prefer the other white meat (chicken) and the fish eaters, but I would avoid bringing a vegetarian or vegan here. 
My personal OVERALL experience from my most recent dinner could have been better. First of all, they charge you $25 PER PERSON for no shows on reservations or cancellations within 48 hours, apparently lots of places are doing that now. We arrived on time for our reservation, and the hostess advised us that our table wasn't ready yet, directed us to the bar, and promised to grab us when the table was ready. So, we ordered drinks, all of which were perfect and refreshing. I recommend the Blonde Redhead cocktail! But after 30 minutes, we still hadn't been retrieved by the hostess. It took us asking again if our table was ready, and it was. Either our timing was right on, or they forgot about us. The restaurant was abuzz but not insanely busy.
Our server was kind of awkward, he was just kind of quirky and slow and fumbly, like you'd expect in New Orleans, I suppose.
We ordered: 
Woodfired Oysters - AMAZING! 
Smoked Ribs - AMAZING!
Fried Alligator - anything fried is usually good-GOOD! 
Ham Hock - YUM! Tastes like Ham!
Louisiana Cochon - Meh. This was my meal and it was very dry. 
Rabbit & Dumplings - SO GREAT!
Amberjack Fish Special - AMAZING!
I was disappointed in my dish as its the namesake dish for crying out loud, it should have been the best one on the table. Its not enough to deter me, though. Next time, I will order the oysters and ribs all for myself!

Came here with a large group and they split us up which was a good thing, the pork shoulder and roasted oysters is all you have to order also duck dumplings were excellent....stuck to small plates and it was the best decision, service was quick and waiter was refilling our beer without hesitation.

Beautiful restaurant with a rustic yet contemporary feel! This was our first meal we had when visiting Nola, and I'm more than happy it was this place that introduced us to the authentic Cajun flavors that New Orleans had to offer.

We started with the fried alligator and the wood-fired oysters. Having never had alligator before, we didn't really know what to expect. The alligator bites were drenched in this delicious chili garlic mayo, but still retained a slight crisp on the outside. It didn't taste as "gamey" as I expected, but it was still very meaty and hearty. I'd describe the texture as a chewier version of chicken breast. The wood-fired oysters were amazing. They were dressed in chili garlic butter and came out piping hot. Definitely one of my favorites of our meal. A little after the appetizers were served, we were given a sample of the boucherie plate as a compliment from the kitchen. It came with really good hogs head cheese with a side of pickles and a mustard. 

For our entrees, I went with the rabbit and dumplings, and my boyfriend went with their oven-roasted gulf fish. My rabbit and dumplings were served in a cast iron skillet and had about six "dumplings" in it. The dumplings were more like biscuits honestly. The stew was everything you imagine Southern cajun food to be - bold, hearty, and soul-warming with tons of flavor. It was a great dish to start off my Nola adventures with. I can't comment too much on the fish my boyfriend had since I had just a bite, but it was a really generous portion and well-seasoned. 

I'd suggest Cochon to anyone who decides to visit Nola. It is a great restaurant, and the food will not disappoint.
If I could give fractional stars I'd probably go 4.5.  Food kicks ass, nice bar selection, open and pleasant atmosphere.  Great place overall.

Incredible food. End of a long day of business/conference travel. Saddled up to bar exhausted. Sat down bar tenders poured a perfect old fashioned and were all smiles. After old fashioned everything was as good or better than previous dish/drink. Met a fellow ex-pat Australian at bar a a lovel couple from SC. Left Cochan having thrown off the dementors that had been on my back all day. Love this place.

Cochon is a delicious restaurant in the Warehouse District of New Orleans.  This place gets a little crowded, so if you can make a reservation, you may want to opt to do so.  

The atmosphere is pleasant and hip. There is some outside dining in front of the restaurant.  

The food was very good.  We tried the gumbo, the alligator, bread, pineapple upside down cake with coconut lime sherbet, and shrimp with artichokes, mushrooms and peas.  Our favorite was the gator, which had a nice spicy sauce, which didn't overpower the flavor of the meat.  The ribs with pickled watermelon was moist and the meat was falling off the bone, but there was too much sauce for my liking.  The shrimp mixture was yummy.  The house bread was served warm with a light crunch of the crust from the toasting of it.   My favorite part of the meal was the pineapple upside down cake with coconut lime sherbet.  I could have eaten several of them.  Our waitress suggested it and she couldn't have been more on the money.  

Overall, we had a wonderful evening at Cochon and the food was great.

I still think about this food and it's been five years since I was there. If you were in New Orleans, it is worth making a reservation at this restaurant. You will not regret it!  Be super hungry when you get there and order tons of plates. Everyone that goes to New Orleans, I recommend they go here and they rave about it for months. Enjoy!!

This place brings a high level of uniqueness to dishes featuring pork. We ordered the pork cheeks, ham hock, and smoked ribs with watermelon pickles. All in all fantastic. Recommend adding a dash of their homemade vinegar to the ham hock to really bring out the flavor. Wood fire grilled oysters are also fantastic. We had them to start. If you're looking for a good offering of meat dishes as a break from all the seafood this is the place to go. They also have a fish entree for those that want to take full advantage of the seafood NOLA has to offer.

Really good foodI would have given 5 stars if not for the inattentive/snippy bar service.  If you sit at the bar you do not get the bread.  I got the meat pie and Mac n cheese and it was all very good.

My friends got the catfish eggplant shrimp and pork cheek all of which I tasted and was very good!

Superlative
I will always come back.
My first experience a decade ago was with their lemon pie. This is the uniform favorite of most hotel and restaurant folks in the city.

This place is amazing. So glad we chose to try it out this trip. This place will be a must stop each time were in town. The oysters were heaven I m still thinking about them. The ham hock flavor was insane. You can't go wrong there

Anyone will find something to order here. It's absolutely divine! I recommend this place to everyone. Definitely get the oysters as part of your appetizer order, it's amazing. I have been opposed to oysters before coming here. My godmother had to persuade me to try it and I'm glad she did. The staff is accommodating and very very eager to assist you regardless of how busy they are. I love them, you will too!

Off of the three dishes that we ordered, I'd say two of them are a must try!
 **wood fired oysters with chili garlic butter
 **fried alligator with chili garlic mayo
Both of these were extremely flavorful and delicious. DEFINITELY eat the alligator with the mint leaves and onion that was served as a garnish... that gave even MORE flavor and depth! 

We were soooo disappointed in the cochon entree. For our third dish, we were debating between the pork cheeks, pork ribs, catfish courtbuillon and the cochon. We thought that we should at least get the dish that the restaurant is named after--that'll be safe one, right? NO. The dish was quite strange to me... overly SALTY, unbelievably dry and unappetizingly chewy! What a huge regret. Skip on the cochon!!!

Floor staff/service was good, the hostesses were decent. 
Get the oysters and the alligator! 
Oh, and make reservations!
Everything about this restaurant is awesome . Beautifully built ( all woods and brick). The food are delicious .

the Mac and cheese was amazing! very well seasoned and light. The alligator had just the right amount of spice and the mint leaves really added a lot to it. The cucumbers and herbs had a spicy kick to it that completed its deliciousness. I would highly recommend going here!

We came in for lunch on a weekday. Since it was first time, we decided to try a bunch of stuff. We got the fried alligator, ribs, crawfish pie and cochon. The fried alligator had a good sauce, it reminded me of general tso chicken! The ribs were too saucy for me. The crawfish pie was solo good. There was a lot of crawfish in the filling and the pie crust was crispy. It came with a relish but I didn't eat it. The cochon is pulled pork formed into a patty with cabbage and radish. I really enjoyed the cabbage and radish. It's a little pricey for lunch for was very enjoyable. The restaurant is about 30min walk from Jackson square in French quarter.

The atmosphere is nice.   I ordered the oysters, macaroni and cheese,  and the lemon dessert cake.  I loved the first 2 but the dessert was mediocre .   Their bread is delicious too.  I also ordered a cocktail which was good and strong and those are 2 things you definitely look for in a drink.  I would definitely return to try the pork cheeks

Severely disappointed. I can make a better pork dinner and I am not a chef. Pork cheeks were tender but no better than any pork tenderloin I have ever made in my pressure cooker. Shrimp and eggplant dressing was slightly fishy tasting and that's about all I can say for it. The Cochon dinner plate - boring, nothing special. The best thing about our meal here was meeting and chatting with the nice couple at the table next to us. Too many other good places in NOLA - don't wast your time here.

This cool place has a creative, delicious, and healthy menu, not to mention a good drinks list as well.  Staff was attentive and knowledgeable.  Sit at the Chef's bar if you're solo or in a couple.  Don't pass up the opportunity to eat here!

I'm not very adventurous with food so I stick with the Mac and cheese. It was $7.00 and came with a nice bowl of bread rolls. I was full and it was delicious. I did have a gin and bitters drink. I forgot the name of it already but it had a mint leaf in it. Nice atmosphere.

We originally wanted to try Peche but it was booked with a two hour wait so they sent us to Cochon. It was yummy! We got the cucumber salad with vinegar - YUM! The Louisiana Cochon because, why not? Fried alligator was good, tasted like fried calamari :) we also had the wood fire grilled oysters which were dressed with some of the best spices ever! These oysters are also very big, my friend compared it to a testicle. Get it! Haha! We have reservations for Peche tonight! (They are sister restaurants)

Busy Friday night, sat down at 10:30pm. Great whiskey neat before dinner, went with Michters rye and bourbon by excellent suggestion from the bartender. Food was awesome. Ordered the boucheron plate for an app (outstanding mixed charcuterie plate), and ham hock and rabbit dumplings for the entree. Awesome falloff the bone Hamhock and very flavorful rabbit, though not very meaty entree. We got the boucheron comped because there was a beard hair in it (which is why only four stars lol).  Overall wonderful food, great service and would go back again.

Interesting casual, hip, restaurant. Really enjoyed the service and new dishes.

Ordered:
- fried alligator in a great spicy sauce. Alligator was nicely cooked with a lovely onion to balance out the richness of the sauce
- rabbit and dumplings were swimming in a lovely stew. Dumplings were nice and moist and rabbit was nicely cooked. 
- rolls were heavenly. Worth a trip back to get a few baskets of rolls.
- boudins had a great consistency. Slightly salty for my taste but loved the mustard and pickled onion accompaniments.

Had a great cocktail - blood of my people - with a good kick.

Would be back to try more.

My family and I were visiting NOLA for the first time from NJ. We were staying in the Warehouse district and wanted to find a great restaurant besides the famed Commanders Palace to head to for my dads 60th birthday dinner. I found Cochon on Yelp and with over 1k reviews and at least 4 stars I thought we found a fabulous place. 

As with our arrival there, seeing the crowd was very hip and youngish (30s). Reservations to get in (which I did make). I also made them to note it was a birthday celebration on my reservation* 

The oysters were great. The fried alligator was delicious. Otherwise everything else was mediocre at best. Reviews on crappy service are true. And also, nothing made to note that it was a 60th birthday celebration for my father. What a waste. I think the mass amounts of reviews were more so for the ambience and feel for this place - otherwise, food was meh.

I've been to Cochon three times during three trips to New Orleans in the past two years. From the first visit, the food has called to me, beckoning me not only to return to New Orleans, but to this restaurant to re-infuse with the flavors that I love. 

My first time at Cochon was a lunch. I was sat at the bar in front of the kitchen and I got to watch the guys cranking out food in cast iron pans and their wood-fired oven. It was spectacular. And the flavors of the food were unparalleled. The crawfish pie was awesome. The gumbo was the best I tasted in the city. For me, the biggest disappointment that trip was that I couldn't bring my wife there for dinner as we ran out of time.

I returned to New Orleans three months later for a work event. During that trip, a colleague and I went to dinner at Cochon. Again, the food, the service, everything was spectacular. The waitress had quit working in New York to come down and work for a time at Cochon. We had the gumbo (incredible again), and the alligator dish as my colleague wanted to try that. While it was probably the best alligator that I've had, it felt more like a check mark on a tourist list, but my colleague was happy. And then came the rabbit and dumplings -- such incredible flavor we were scraping the cast iron pan to get any last remnants we could. Again, an awesome experience.

So it was with some excitement that we booked Cochon again last night. This time, my wife and I on vacation. I was finally going to bring her to the restaurant that, for a period of time, had us planning our wedding here in New Orleans. We had actually considered having the reception at Calcasieu, the private space above Cochon, simply based on my experiences with the food. Perhaps that helps describe how enamored I was with the food at Cochon. Needless to say, we were excited to finally visit together.

Unfortunately, our experience was not the awesome experience we'd hoped for. First, the restaurant was crowded, perhaps some conference or other event was in town, creating a larger crowd than you might expect for a Monday night. Twenty minutes after our reservation time, we were seated. Recently they've expanded the dining room at Cochon, so we were brought into the larger back room dining area that had lots of seats. and a number of empty tables. Overall, it looked as though they were attempting to manage when people were sat in order to avoid overwhelming the kitchen. 

The food started out great. The crawfish pie was as exceptional as I remember it. The boucherie plate was spectacular. My wife loved it. And when rolls arrived, they were as good as you could imagine dinner rolls being. Somewhere late into our small plates, we placed an order for gumbo and an entree of the rabbit & dumplings. It was shortly after this, that our waiter must have started his second job at one of Donald Link's other restaurants. We sat. And we sat. I ran out of beer. At one point, a woman in a dress who looked like she might have a second job as a hostess came by, refilled our water and asked about my empty beer. Then took my wine order. My wife and I soon found ourselves on the crossword app on our phone. Some time after my wine arrived, our original waiter came back by and told us there had been an error and somehow they lost our order. He then speculated that we'd ordered something different and we re-placed our correct order. The two women at the table next to us -- a similar experience. Although the waiter did apologize to us and the other four tables around us, we were surprised that none of us received a visit from the restaurant manager. 

Now the problem with service issues like this is that, when the food does arrive, you start to question your palate. The gumbo, while still the best that I had in New Orleans this trip, tasted slightly burned to my wife. And the rabbit and dumplings, while quite good, tasted a bit less peppery than I remember. My wife loved it and there was pepper at the table, but the service had already stomped our buzz. We wrapped up, and eventually managed to wrangle our check from our waiter. I grabbed my card, ready to pay, and we watched our waiter go by twice without picking it up. Finally, I turned from my wife and sat, looking bored and facing to the side and staring at the restaurant manager in the corridor between the two dining rooms. Eventually, this was enough to prompt them to pick up the card and process the transaction. 

In short, this is another service review and your mileage may vary. If I was in town again, I would probably try and go to Cochon again -- the food is that good -- but our experience with the service has certainly given us pause. I'll also say that I'm going home without the same craving to return that I once had. You could say that, after years of using Yelp, I was so scarred by this experience that I felt the need to write my first Yelp review.

High ratings from so many people I was building myself up for an awesome amazing blow my mind experience!! It's was meh, over priced and poor service. Oysters were good. Compared to Commanders Palace this place was just ok for about the same price and poor service. My reco - skip Cochon and eat at Commanders, you won't be disappointed.
Fantastic food and cocktails, would recommend the fried alligator and baked oysters for appetizers.

4.50 stars.  Cochon is one of the most heavily reviewed and highly rated destinations in New Orleans and for good reason.  Aside from sporting a trendy look with great wood paneling and exterior brick as well as nifty indoor balcony seating overlooking the restaurant, the cuisine is stellar as well.  Start with glorious bites of alligator drowned in a thick mayonnaise based sauce featuring notes of chili and garlic or maybe the house boudin balls (essentially, a deep fried pork and rice ball) for a Cajun treat to start.  Or, for those seeking a more seasonal treat, we also enjoyed a wonderful pork cheek dish paired with tender slivers of yellow squash, English peas, and green onions.   

There are a number of excellent choices for dinner though one would be hard pressed to beat the beef short rib over corn grits.  The tender short rib absolutely melts in the mouth and pairs perfectly with the grits.  While I only sampled the rabbit and dumplings, the meat was exquisite and this warm hearty dish would make a lovely choice especially for a cold day.  The catfish courtbouillon also impressed with a flavorful base subtly adding layers to an already nuanced preparation.  

Don't miss out on dessert either (I think we ended up trying all of them).  While the pineapple upside down cake was absolutely devoured by our party, I was perhaps most partial to a rather decadent chocolate hazelnut pudding.  

At least on this visit, Cochon ended up being my favorite overall meal (even besting general favorite Jacques-Imo's).  Even with all the places I've yet to visit in this city, I would be hard pressed to pass up a subsequent visit.

We picked out Cochon as one of our must-eat's in NoLA based on the high and positive reviews and we were not disappointed one bit. My sister and I came with our stomachs pretty stuffed from the previous restaurant we were at..... but still managed to demolish all the yummy food we ordered. 

The must haves: wood fired oysters with chili garlic butter AND the smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickle. The oysters was top-notch and the sauce was just bangin'. It's one of those dishes where you already know you can order another one before it's even finished haha it's just that good. The smoked pork ribs was nothing like I have ever tried. The ribs were soooo nicely done with a good amount of watermelon pickle as garnishment on top.  

The eh: we had the fried alligator bites since it was considered one of the more popular dishes to try, but it wasn't really our favorite. Maybe its the texture of alligator meat but it was rather chewy for us. It was for sure real appetizing to the eye, but personally I'd skip this one next time.  

As for dessert, if you aren't stuffed yet from your entrees- please save some room for chocolate hazelnut pudding. IT IS THAT DELICIOUS! Pudding has never been my type for dessert but this is an absolute game changer. The texture of the pudding plus hazelnut being a weakness of mine.... mm mm mmmmmmmmm. All in all, I'd come back in a heartbeat for the smoked ribs, wood fired oysters and my now all-time favorite chocolate hazelnut pudding :)

There was NOTHING bad about this place. From the ridiculous over ordering of apps, to the delivery of every single dessert on the menu to our table... none of the six of us were upset by the night. 

The grilled oysters - just silly. The charcuterie tray... amazing spread. Just everything was delicious. 

Of course, knowing the pastry chef (who is awesome) didn't hurt... so we get a special delivery of two trays to end the meal. It was, literally, every single dessert on the menu. We weren't even going to order a dessert... then we just killed it. Didn't leave a crumb. 

Really an amazing meal.

Scrumptious.  I loved everything I inhaled here.  I was dining solo, so it really wasn't too much - I had the pork cheeks and gumbo and it was just delicious.  I wanted to come back with friends later in the week, but without a reservation, we had no luck.  I will definitely come back next time I'm in town.

While the food is amazing, service and atmosphere don't quite reach that level.  Starting with the food - menu descriptions do not do justice to the flavor on the plate. We started with a special small plate - pulled pork on polenta.   We fought over last bite - polenta pancake was crispy on outside, creamy inside...covered with some of the best pulled pork I have ever had in a wonderful sauce that I cannot call BBQ because it was so far above that description.  Then main courses again far beyond the description.  My Louisiana Cochon was a party in the mouth.  I kept wanting to steal creamy grits off my companion's plate under his no-fork-required short rib.  Blueberry pie with ice cream gave a lovely sweet finish to the meal!

Now the not so good.  Service was just adequate.  I should not have to ask for water refill.  Nor have to ask twice for a glass of wine. Maybe our waitress was having a bod day, as I don't think she smiled once and showed impatience with our questions on unfamiliar menu terms.  While the room is a visually appealing space, it is loud! It wasn't even full on an early Thursday evening, but still hard to hear the waitress as she told us the specials. 

Go for the food but don't expect a holistic dining experience to match the flavor on your plate.

We finally made our way to Cochon on a spur of the moment date night and surprisingly enough we were able to be sat at the bar without a wait on a busy Saturday night. The hostesses were very good and let me see the bar before I agreed to sit there. The waitstaff was thorough and they brought out a complimentary hogshead cheese from the chef. The cooks at the wood-fire oven were also very friendly, talking to us about the dishes while still giving us the privacy that we wanted. We ordered the ribs, which were crispy on the outside but still tender with tons of flavor!!! We also got the cucumbers and herbs salad as well as an order of cracklin. I ate almost the whole order of cracklin and needed more! So we immediately ordered another! There is not many cracklin that tops the cracklin at jazzfest, if any. And this, my friends, is a close contender. I definitely recommended eating at the chef's bar/table for a date night or at a table with a group! I loved the rustic atmosphere and casual but sophisticated decor. My only regret is not ordering the wood-fired oysters because,damn,did they smell good!!!

I didn't even eat here. I came in, and got sat by the front desk. I was trying to meet a group of friends, but assumed they left cause I couldn't find them. Prior to receiving any food or water (or ordering, for that matter), I realized that they were at the Cochran Butcher, so I let the hostess know.

She was a shorter blonde lady with semi wavy hair. She just rolled her eyes and didn't say anything. 

So rude and not accommodating at all.

Yeah ok BOOM.

This place has game.  Good lord.  Sat at the bar (1st come 1st served) for a complete meal.  Everything was knock your socks off good.

I had the grilled oysters to start. Excellent although my heart belongs to Felix's. Then I had the cochon, and I found my happy place.

Wife had a daily special, a roasted half chicken.  Good lord how do they do that?!!?  I must figure it out.  With the exception of one lunch of Bresse chicken in France 16 years ago (a moment of silence please) this was the best and most memorable chicken ever consumed.

Almost creamy tender.  I'm guessing some combination of brine and buttermilk before roasting, but this merits investigation.

Strong hipster vibe on the staff (ink and creative facial hair) which is fine.

Wine list is what I like - lots of choices and variety, but one page, not a book.
The food was really good! Cocktails and service not so much. We were seated thirty minutes after our reservation, and were mostly forgotten about.

This place was bumpin when I went on a Thursday night. The lines were long, but you can grab a drink at the bar while you wait. Try the cold blooded- it has habanero bitters. We got seated after about 15-20 minutes. I tried the louisiana cochon and it was delicious!! Also tried their oysters with chili garlic butter, which were good too. I just wish they served it as a half dozen instead of only 5 pieces. The prices are a little on the higher end of Yelp's two $$ ($20-$32). The other thing I can complain about is the name of the restaurant - Cochon, which makes me think of pork. But there's only like three pork dishes on their menu, so the name is a little misleading..

The food was great here! Specifically the fried alligator appetizer. Bomb. I had the beef short rib for my main course. It was very tender with great flavor. For dessert, we had the blueberry pie with cream cheese ice cream. That was amazing as well! Service was good. I would definitely come back here.
Although the food was good...bartenders were extremely unfriendly! Won't go back...definitely won't recommend! Mood killer!

This restaurant was a HUGE disappointment.   We started with a  Sangiovese wine that was way overpriced and the label didn't indicate it was actually  Sangiovese.   The waitress recommended the roast chicken dish special, it arrived quickly and appeared to be delicious.  However,  as we began to to cut into the meat,  it was bloody!  The parts that were edible  were tough and not meaty,  obviously an inferior product.   Worst yet, they had the audacity to charge  $30 for that repulsive dish!  Think twice about visiting this mass production hole.

We came in for a quick snack and tried the boucherie plate, chicken and andouille gumbo and end up getting the fried livers with pepper jelly & toast and also a special of the day, smoked pork on cornbread. Thank you Sean O, you were a delight.

I went a year ago and still fantasize about Cochon. Literally the best food to ever touch my lips. I sound like I'm exaggerating but the food was so wonderful. I'm confused by some of the bad reviews because everything was cooked to PERFECTION. Maybe an off night? The food was so amazing it trumps any bad service (but our service was great). 

There was four of us and we ordered a lot.
The oysters, Mac and cheese, alligator, and Louisiana cochon were some of the most satisfying, different flavors I've ever had. 
But the absolute best food was the ham hock and beans which was fall apart amazing goodness, and the rabbit and dumplings was the most amazing flavor I've EVER had enter my mouth. 
Also the cherry they put on our dessert was like none I've ever had. 
We ate our way through NOLA and Cochon was the best restaurant. Which is saying a lot. We left amazed, I'm sure the waiters thought we were crazy.

Serving sizes are small, and entree sizes are expensive. I'd recommend maybe a lunch here as you'll be more willing to fork out the money for more food. I had the boiled oysters and they were some of the best (and the cleanest-no sand!) I also had a blueberry arugula salad that was alright. Gluten-free options are available here but are limiting.

There are so many great menu choices. I sampled just about everything my family ordered and the standouts were the fried alligator in that wonderful spicy mayo and the rabbit and dumplings. Never had rabbit before and that dish blew me away. The mac n cheese was something to behold. The blueberry pie was piping hot and delicious as well. Great ambiance and great service.

Cochon was very okay, but perhaps if we had a better waiter, our experience would be different.

-he didn't tell us the specials
-rarely checked in with us
-sucked

We ordered the following:

-wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter ($14): good, but EXTREMELY decadent. Maybe a little too much even.

-boucherie plate ($16): this was a nice medley of cured meats. Unfortunately, there was no explanation to any of the cured treats, but everything was delicious.

-smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickle ($14): good, but not memorable.

-louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklings, and picked turnips ($24): pork stewed in very muted flavors. I know this was the recommended dish, but there was something lacking about the dish.

I dunno. I wasn't jaded about my dining experience despite the lack of attention from our waiter, but I didn't think what we order was that good. No memorable flavor combinations. No interesting combinations. Everything was very safe and I get it. 

Hey, come here. It's an institution, it's fun, and just kinda off the beaten path if you're looking for that.
I choose the obvious, cochon, I came back twice, it was incredible, even now my wife and I would like to go back to NOLA just to try cocoon at Cochon and the Acme's oysters

Lovely restaurant with excellent staff. The wood fired oysters were phenomenal, like jaw dropping amazing. Oysters were so creamy and the chili sauce gave it a kick. One of my favorite oyster experiences in NOLA! I also tried the fried alligator, first timer! Didn't let me down, really great appetizer. The fried boudin were okay but didn't meat my expectations. I think I would rather try Cochon Butcher since they have more small eats to try. This one is pricier too.

We made reservations approximately 3 months in advance for a large bachelorette party. We were the first reservation of the day. We did have to wait a little while so they could arrange a table for us. While we waited we asked the bartenders for waters because it was about a 20-minute walk. They were honestly a little reluctant to give us waters and even said "you know you are going to get waters at the table," which I thought was a little rude considering we had to wait for our table and there was no one else in the restaurant so they weren't busy. Anyway, after we were seated we were promptly greeted by our waiter who was a saint. We asked him about 100 questions about the menu and his preferences and we were all amazed at how easily and perfectly he described the menu items. I'm always impressed with waiters who get everyone's order correct in a large party and this guy was perfect! I wish I remembered his name but he was one of the best waiters I've ever had. Food wise: our meals were excellent!! Mac n cheese was best I've ever had. Ham hoc was awesome too.

When we were planning out our group trip to NOLA, Cochon was always one of the restaurants we said we absolutely had to go to. So we booked it for my birthday dinner, and it was worth it all.

First of all, the restaurant is gigantic. I didn't even realize there was a whole back section (and an upstairs). We sat in the back with about a dozen other groups.

Started out with some whiskey because their selection was top-notch.

For food, we had just about everything and shared it family-style:

-Fried livers with pepper jelly and toast
-Pork cheeks with grilled squash and peas
-Louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklins and pickled peaches
-Short rib with tomato, squash, pickled okra over slow roasted grits
-Boucherie plate with pate, pickled veggies and their version of a Slim Jim
-Fried alligator with chili garlic mayo
-Wood fired oysters with chili garlic butter
-Rabbit & dumplings
-Mac and cheese
-Creamy grits

Yes, you should believe the hype. The wood fired oysters are every bit as delicious as people say. Big and meaty, with a nice kick.

The fried alligator was definitely worth trying (my first foray with gator). It was deep fried to the point where the cliche "tastes like chicken" applied, but nonetheless excellent.

The short rib was excellent, and I love pickled veggies on anything. It was served atop slow roasted grits, which was a great combination.

The pork cheeks were also a winner. You can't go to a restaurant named cochon and not get pig. We also did their namesake dish, the Louisiana cochon. The cracklins and cabbage together made for an interesting contrast between crispy and tender.

Honestly, there wasn't anything I wasn't a fan of. Of course, at the end of the meal, my friends ordered me a key lime pie and they got half the restaurant to sing "happy birthday" to me. It wasn't the last time this happened either...

But in any case, if you can snag a reservation for Cochon, definitely stop by. It'll be one of the more meat-forward meals, and it'll be very memorable.
Sat at the "kitchen counter" in front of the wood oven. Appetizer (alligator) was good and entrees (rabbit dumpling and cochon) were outstanding. Worth the walk and the wait.

Cochon lived up to its hype!!  Terrific meal at a trendy spot in the warehouse district.  Service was friendly and efficient and very accommodating to our daughter.  Bartender was a delight to watch as he used many fresh herbs and fruits in his cocktails and we had a perfect birds eye view of his cool creations.  We started with the bouchrie plate served on a cutting board with pickled veggies and light brioche toast and an assortment of hams, sausage, pate and a delicious homemade mustard.  After tasting this I wish we had time to visit the butcher shop next door.  We also had a cucumber with herb salad which was refreshing and herbaceous with large bites of mint and parsley dressed with a tangy chili vinegar.  Entrees were short ribs with grits and gulf Drum fish served with pickled onion.  The fish was the BEST I've ever had!  It was sizzling and moist and served on the skin with flakiness that was easy to eat and cooked perfectly.  Our daughter had the wood oven baked macaroni and cheese casserole which was devoured.  It was decadent with white cheddar and Swiss cheese and a hint of onion and cayenne.  We finished off my birthday dinner with pineapple upside down cake with coconut lime sherbet.  Total tag $136 and worth it!  It was fun and upbeat without feeling rushed and great for large or small parties.
Great place .... Good food and atmosphere.  A bit expensive and don't think you'll catch a game score, not a tv in the place but you go here for food not games!

We're huge Bourdain fans so this place was on the list for our trip to New Orleans. It's a bit out of the way in the Warehouse District, but it really isn't that far from Canal St. We walked it fairly quickly. We were pleasantly surprised there was no wait-we purposely went early around 5pm and the place was only about 1/4 full. Nicely done new-rustic-urban interior with a wide open feel. We already knew what was on the menu before we arrived, so we quickly ordered Alligator Bites (spicy and delicious) the shrimp appetizer (it was just ok in my opinion) and I had the mac n cheese casserole-so good but hard to finish, despite it's smallish size. My husband had the rabbit and dumplings and said it was delicious. We didn't partake in the fine whiskey selection as we were already nursing a hangover from the night before. Overall, it was really good. It was spendy 2/3 of what we ordered were appetizers. It was on our list, so we went. We'd go back and actually order some pork next time.

What a great way to start my NOLA trip! The restaurant is open and inviting, the food is delicious and the staff is so friendly!  Be sure to try the Louisiana crab rice and the Cochon - you will not be disappointed!!!
Terrin, our server was the most knowledgeable server I have ever had at any restaurant. Great service!

Delicious!!!! Food was great all around. We decided to just try a few of the appetizers they were are so great.  Service was good, our server was very helpful and gave great suggestions on appetizers!

This food was truly fantastic. Nouveau Cajun style. Be prepared for 45 minute to 1 hour waits but the tables outside makes that bearable. The seasoning in the food was fantastic. Like bed the rabbit and noodles, catfish and short ribs. The fried alligator for appetizer was delicious with the Cajun aoli spread. But service can be slow.
Most go here for supper, but there lunch specials are really good. There is normally never a wait during the day which is also nice. The alligator bites are fresh and does not taste to fishy.

This place is so good, we came twice in one week. I had the chance to sample the wood fired oysters, chicken livers, alligator, boudin, oyster and bacon sandwich, catfish courtboullion, mac and cheese, pork ribs... I can't even remember if that's all. Everything was really fantastic. I had a blonde redhead (I think that was the name) which was a strawberry cocktail that was super refreshing. However, they serve it with muddled strawberries in the glass, which is visually pleasing but logistically challenging. The strawberries block your straw. After the first one I ask for it to be served strained, and it was much better.

I came here to eat last May when I was meeting a friend for a Vacation weekend in New Orleans. We went here just because it was something I had found on Yelp. From the outside, this place looks dull in the old building it's located it, but once you enter its a different world. I remember it standing out to me because the food came out and looked pretty and it was delicious. I had the Fried Alligator  and my friend got a soup of some kind. We had a few drinks which were also very good and different. I definitely recommend this for something tasteful and fancy. Great for dates

Great food, but a very frustrating reservation/check in service. We made reservations online, but were told by the staff that their online system is glitchy & we didn't have reservations. So we put our names in & then changed our number to text with the hostess bc my phone was dying. They said no problem, but then an hour passed & they never texted us. When I asked the hostess, she said, oh-we couldn't delete out your first number. Arghh. Good thing the rabbit dumplings were worth the frustration.

This was my favorite restaurant when I visited NOLA on Memorial Day weekend. I made reservation 2 weeks prior and still only got a table at 9PM for 4 people. When we got there we still waited almost 40mins to be seated. It was packed and crowded. I guess everyone else loved Cochon just as much. We did a family style to share so I can try a little bit of everything. We got their famous wood fired oysters. Oh man that was so meaty, juicy and well flavored. The fried alligator with garlic mayonnaise was surprisingly good. I've not had good alligator before so I was so surprised how good it was and the garlic mayonnaise was perfect with it. The boucherie platter of cured meat made in house was probably my least favorite. It wasn't the best I've had but not the worst. The rabbit and dumplings were also very good. The rabbit meat was great, it wasn't dry like most places and there was a lot of flavor. My other favorite dish here is the gumbo. I hated gumbo prior to this trip. Gumbo always tasted too earthy like dirt for me. The gumbo here is so good. Must get it. 

Actually everything here is good. Must come here if you're in NOLA.

Well, the place lives up to the hype. Though we were told it was an upscale place, you definitely do not need a blazer here...just a collared shirt will do. The setting looks like it was made for yuppies...er..hipster millenials. There was a very Restoration Hardware meets farmer's market feel to the place. The boucherie plate was very tasty, loaded with various charcuterie...it was, however, marred by something that looked (and tasted) like Underwood devilled ham...uggh. I had the special short ribs...so tender yet popped under the broiled for nicely crisped edges. This came on a bed of creamy grits...yummy. My daughter had the most luxurious and decadent macaroni and cheese...it was one of the few non-Kraft varieties she would actually eat. She absolutely devoured this version. My wife had the grilled drum special...this was grilled skin-on over a wood fire and was amazing. Service was friendly and attentive throughout...that is until the end. Now we had been there about 80 min, and we weren't really lingering. However, we ordered desert which was then brought out at the same time our check was plopped down on the table next to it...the waitress did say "no hurry". Really? Because that's exactly the message we get when you plop down an unsolicited check.

(Review based on 2.5 stars)

Located on a corner with street parking (metered, 2 hour limit).

My husband and I came by here for an early dinner around 5:05 pm last Wednesday. We were seated by the hostess at a table. After we were given water and menus, we ended up getting:

Complementary Rolls- Deliciously warm rolls (4) served with whipped butter (but the rolls tasted perfect without the butter). We got a refill on these rolls while we waited for our food to be brought out.

Crawfish Pie, $13 prior to tax- This pie was delicious, but smaller than I was expecting. This is a hand held pie (for $13, I thought I was getting a pot pie type of pie) and the shell was deep fried. The filling of crawfish, stewed carrots and tomatoes made for a perfect appetizer. This pie came with a small side of spicy relish, which was pretty good. 

Roasted Eggplant, Cherry Tomato & Peanut Vinaigrette Salad, $9 prior to tax- I loved this salad, even though it was rather small. The roasted eggplant was made perfectly and the cherry tomatoes and mint leaves added so much depth and flavor. The peanut vinaigrette salad dressing was light. 

Chicken & Andouille Gumbo, $8 prior to tax- This gumbo was also kind of on the small side, but I liked the shredded chicken in the soup. The andouille sausage was good and I liked the rice in this gumbo. But I didn't think this gumbo was as good as gumbo that I have had during our vacation. 

Louisiana Cochon With Cabbage, Cracklins & Pickled Peaches, $24 prior to tax- This pork dish was a little bland. But the pork was soft and tender. Wasn't a fan of the cracklins (fried pork skin) though, it was missing flavor. The pickled peach was really good and made for a sweet like relish/ salsa. Without the pickled peach, this dish would truly be a waste.
-----------------------------
(Total= $59.40 after tax, prior to tip)

Service was pretty poor by our server. It seems that this restaurant is really pushing alcohol drinks (as we saw our server tried to promote their drinks to other tables and the hostess seating us also suggested drinks with our meal). After we told our server that we were fine when asked if we wanted any drinks, she said 'so you are not going to order anything else beside water?'. I thought that was pretty rude. 

Anyways, when I had asked our server about the chicken andouille gumbo before ordering it, she seemed annoyed with my questions. She also seemed a little annoyed with me when I asked her about the crawfish pie too. 

Although she did take away some of our dirty dishes towards the end of the meal and also refilled our water glass once, I still thought she provided some poor service. The other employee (I would have to guess that she was equivalent of a bus boy since she only refilled our water, brought us another refill of the dinner rolls and took way the dirty dishes) helping us was very friendly and attentive. 

So the 2.5 star rating that I am awarding this restaurant is for the poor and rude service and also for the bland dish we had. 

I wouldn't come here and would have preferred to try their Cochon Butcher around the corner instead (you can just go pass their kitchen through the restaurant).

Fried GATOR here I come! We came for this and boy was it delicious. Fried, fluffy, but the meat was a little tough. Amazing sauce. The gumbo was mediocre. The biggest downer was the staff. We were super excited to end our New Orleans trip with the revered Cochon, but the staff were a bit grumpy and disinterested which always makes for a less fun time. Service is key folks.

The smell when you walk in the door sets the stage for an amazing meal. Loved almost everything we tried ... but the crawfish pie was my favorite (so good we ordered a second one!). Also enjoyed the alligator bites, the chicken and sausage gumbo, the ribs and the mac & cheese. The only disappointment was the boudin balls, which we all thought tasted a bit like the canned corn beef hash. Overall it was an excellent meal!

WOW!!!. Sat at the bar and had a killer old fashioned ... Their potbelly Old Fashion that's on the menu was a Perfect cocktail. Miles is a great bartender and his recommendations for dinner were PERFECT. I ordered the wood fired oysters that were singularly the best oysters I've ever eaten. Make sure you ask for some bread to soak up the butter left in the shells. He recommended the Ham Hock for dinner ... It was amazing. Fall off the bone tender and the spring onions and chili's on top were perfect compliments. I would recommend this place to anyone. My only problem was that there was so much on the menu I wanted, one entree just teased me. Need to come back!
The food and the service were outstanding!  We had multiple menu items and everything was super tasty. The staff was especially attentive.

It was an okay meal, but not the exceptional meal I expected from everything I'd heard. My favorite part of the meal was the gator bites we had to start. The wood-fired oysters were oily and not that great. I had the Louisiana cochon and it was good, but nothing I'd need to have again.
Love it!  The Sweet Breads rock!  Joseph provided fantastic service.  Best place we have eaten on our trip.

WOWOWOW. That meal just left my mouth in amazement! Louisiana has the best food in the country and Couchon just put an exclamation mark on it! We had the experience of sitting at the chefs table. A front row seat to watch "Mr. Manager" and his Team create pure AWESOMENESS! BIG PROPS to the wood oven team. These 2 are the hardest working wood oven ninjas in New Orleans. The Ham hock was my favorite.
