I had the smoked ribs with pickled watermelon. I'm a huge rib lover but my biggest beef with Cochon is the fact that the ribs were NOT TENDER. They didn't fall off the bone at all. In fact, they were chewy :(. I ruined a brand new white cashmere sweater eating these and they weren't even worth it.

That said, I would definitely come back to Cochon next time and try more dishes. And I'll definitely be trying the butcher shop next time as well.

Don't get me wrong. The food is ok. The best thing I ate were the rolls they bring to the table. I ate two different things. They both were decidedly different. One seafood item and one meat. They tasted the same. Identical when they shouldn't have. The flavor profile had no differentiation. I think this effect becomes common when a restaurant uses a single "spice blend" to season most dishes. It shows a lack of attention to the item being prepared. Great chefs bring singular attention to each dish. Alas, this place was just cranking out the food. The service was fine. A teeny bit slow. I think that's my last visit. As it's decidedly a tourist place now. You'll do better elsewhere.
Delicious food, solid beer selection. Make sure to also check out Cochon Butcher around the corner!

Solid and well done. Spicy food no matter what you order, but really solid. Best piece of fish I can remember in years (red fish). Gator was excellent and my companions loved the Lima beans. 
Ribs were almost too spicy but solid. The brisket Was almost too tender to eat. Just awesome. 
Wait staff was excellent. 
Overall a lovely experience.

Delicious food! We had brisket, ribs, potato salad and macaroni and cheese. Everything was great. The brisket was so tender and juicy! Very good portions, excellent customer service, fresh food and really quick too. The location was nice. I really enjoyed eating here.

Review from July 2015.

Make reservations! Located in the up and coming Warehouse District, this restaurant is a bit more expensive, but well worth it. A 20 minute walk from the French quarter will take you by Harrods's ($50 on black?) and Emeril's New Orleans (if you win on black). Not great for big groups, but intimate and super friendly (typical southern hospitality)!  Portions are on the smaller side but each is unique (not all are easily shareable).  Everything we had was great; fried alligator, rabbit,  dumplings, oysters, braised pork cheeks, grits, cheesecake,

Recommendation: gnarly barley radical rye p.a + fried alligator + rabbit & dumplings + bourbon flight + the Cuba cigar that you smuggled through customs (if only....;)

Cochon is a place I always visit first when I come to New Orleans. In the past it's made me feel comfortable, relaxed and glad I was in town. Best of all the food is always very very good.  It's been a while since I've visited and in that time they have expanded the restaurant considerably. I'm not sure on size but to me the warehouse expansion seems more than double the footprint from the original restaurant - this isn't scientific though so I could be wrong. 

At any rate, my experience this last weekend was pretty disappointing. It's too bad too because the food is awesome still. Don't get me started of the tastiness of the fried alligator or wood fired oysters. It seems to me that through expanding so large they've lost a lot the magic of what they used to be and now the place is a money maker. The warehouse is too loud, dark and most of all COLD. So cold that every waitress/waiter were wearing hoodies and a few tables around us had to ask that they turn on the heat. You have to understand if you haven't gone that this is polar opposite of how you'd feel if you went to the old Cochon. Don't get me wrong, accidents happen and as soon as a few tables asked about the heat they took care of it but should multiple tables need to ask? I guess this was a taste of how service has changed here because it didn't stop there. 

The overall menu doesn't change too much, a few things here and there but that's totally fine as it's beyond tasty. However, when you go out of the way to clip a specials menu to the main menu you'd think there would be some explanation. Tri-tip reads interesting but at $80 seems pricey. On my way out I saw one in the pass and it was clearly a family style serving. I might have been interested in that or the goat neck had I known this. I also don't think it's appropriate after serving drinks to immediate ask if we're ready to order entrees, then ask every.. single.. time... you return to the table after if we are ready to order entrees. I'm all for trying to turn a table but I think a Beard level establishment should do it in a subtle way that the guests don't feel like they're being pushed out. Never would have experienced this at the old Cochon. 

It's weird, I'm more sad about this recent visit than pissed or whatever. I feel like this is a breakup or something. We've just grown apart. I just don't understand the need to totally change the mojo of a place just to make more money. Gold digging girls driving me crazy I can't take it no mo.

Welcome to New Orleans! This was a solid choice to kick off our visit and first meal there. 'Cochon' is French for 'pig', and what an aptly named restaurant because we sure waddled out of there!

FOOD (4.5 stars):
------------------
Everything was outstanding, even beginning with our first choice of the **wood-fired oysters with chili butter**. The sauce was perfect with just a mild kick to it, and the oysters were meaty but not chewy. 

From the boucherie, we went for the **pork cheek country captain with raisins, turnips, & almonds** which had a unique flavor and were deliciously tender.

Because of the namesake, we had to order the **louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklins, & pickled turnips**. Now, the South is big on their cracklins and turnips, so expect to see them on many dishes. That pig sure was juicy and enjoyable.

For sides, we got the **macaroni & cheese casserole** and **smothered greens**. The mac & cheese was cooked perfectly! And any southern meal could always use some greens.

SERVICE (3 stars):
-------------------
To our great surprise and disappointment, our server was strangely cold. Not the warm Southern hospitality we were expecting. Maybe because it was during Mardi Gras week and everyone is just exhausted during that time, but still. It put a damper on our festive mood. Also we noticed that the busboys and other tables' servers were super friendly and greeted us warmly, so I don't know why our server couldn't put on a smile. Don't you know that bigger smiles = bigger tips?

AMBIANCE/DECOR (4 stars):
-----------------------------
We appreciated the open airy feeling of the interior due to the wood paneling. It's nice to dine in a space that is light and not claustrophobic. The vibe is very warm and is conducive to socializing. Great group spot!

TIP: Make reservations during Mardi Gras week! We didn't know any better, but we got really lucky on timing. 

DATE TIP: You and your Cochon companion might feel stuffed on the way out. But they say the way to a person's heart is through their stomach!

The mac and cheese is an absolute must. It was creamy, flavorful and even had a very slight kick to it. The turkey sandwich was pretty good, but the aioli was slightly underwhelming. I think if there had just been more aioli on the sandwich, it would have been better. Still a good sandwich and many others I want to try based on the orders I saw coming out of the kitchen. I asked for a recommendation for a local beer and the man behind the counter obliged. I want to go back to try a different sandwich and will get the mac and cheese every.single.time.
Friendly weight staff, great drinks, and solid food. We loved the broiled oysters, macaroni and cheese (for our daughter), crawfish empanadas, ribs, the cochon, and banana pudding.

The happy hour may be the best deal in town. My cocktail was nice. I must have forgotten what gulf oysters were like because I remember them being amazing. They were still lovely, tender, fresh and clean. But they seem to lack brininess and sweetness when raw. However, when fried, these oysters were absolute perfection.

Came here for lunch on Monday morning and everything was incredible. Our waitress went through almost the entire menu with us with such eloquence that I almost ordered one of everything. The fried alligator (my first gator experience) blew my mind. The crawfish pie was amazing. The oyster and bacon sandwich was huge and something I would never expect to be so delicious. We finished off with the upside-down pineapple cake which was the perfect sweet ending to our meal. I would recommend Cochon to absolutely everyone.

Everything here was good! We ordered a ton of food for our group of 8. Even with a reservation, you'll be waiting. I think service could have been more attentive. We did have to get up to ask for things.

Some of my favorites: fried alligator, rabbit and dumplings, THE BREAD, and the mac and cheese 

Onto dessert, I really wanted to try the ice cream sandwich trio but they had ran out. After hearing that, I asked our server before dinner if he could save me a chocolate hazelnut pudding before hand because they sell out. And he said yes! By the end of the meal, he said they had sold it to another table by accident. They offered all of their desserts on the menu that they had. It was a nice gesture but the pineapple upside down cake was okay, sorbet was okay, and the peanut butter dessert was okay. My favorite dessert we had was the Dutch apple pie!

Their dishes had a great southern food influence to it. It's a must try when in NOLA.

Cochon is a large and boisterous restaurant.  The service was excellent with the servers working in pairs.  The cocktail menu is well constructed although it was strange that they could not serve the bourbon cocktail that I wanted because they were out of Cynar.  The food was inventive.  The fried boudin with pickled peppers was delicious.  The mustard was particularly outstanding.  The smoked pork ribs were more heavily sauced than I typically like but own me over.  The watermelon pickle was a great accompaniment.  I wish there were more.   The desert menu was well prepared.  The german chocolate cake was moist with ample frosting.  Cochon was be a great place to meet friends for drinks and snacks.

Great meat-centric restaurant right outside of French Quarter! Many locals told us to stop here during our vacation and I'm glad we did. However, there are 2 restaurants with this name: Cochon on one side and Cochon Butcher (their more casual sandwich shop - that DOES have a killer muffuletta). Cochon takes reservations and is available on OpenTable. There's also plenty of street parking around the streets.

My boyfriend and I enjoyed boudin balls, rabbit dumplings, mac & cheese, and I had the fried oyster and bacon sandwich. The boudin balls were delicious with just enough spice and a great texture to it. We loved the rabbit dumplings as they were light enough with great rich flavor. The mac and cheese was my favorite as it was served au gratin and is amazing with Cochon's in-house hot sauce added to it. Unfortunately, I wasn't much of a fan of my oyster and bacon sandwich. It was too much crunch and breading for me to truly taste everything cohesively. They have a great bourbon selection with all fair prices.

I only give this place a 4 as I wasn't as happy with my meal but overall, everything else was great and service was awesome here too. I'd definitely go back for my next trip down to the Big Easy!
Food is out of this world . Had the pig cochon which was great and also had oysters straight fire
Love this place.  Food is consistently good.  The rabbit is my favorite.  Be sure to save room for dessert.

First visit here during Mardi Gras, we come every year, and it was recommended by our many local friends. 
In a town where oyster dishes are king we found the king of kings in the wood fired baked oysters. Though l don't understand why they serve an odd number 5???
Had a little problem with the brisket entree but it was quickly and professionally resolved by the server and on duty manager.
We will definitely visit again next year!!!

Came here for brunch after the WWII Museum (less than 5 min walk) during Mardi Gras weekend and was super surprised we didn't have to wait. 

The food was average and I say this place is overrated.  In my opinion, the star is next door at Cochon Butcher. Below are my thoughts on some items at Cochon:

-Fried Boudin: this was amaze balls and was the only highlight as this app exploded with goodness

-Alligator Appetizer: try this if you haven't eaten alligator before. It's a bit chewy and has texture similar to chicken with a bit of fishiness to it 

-Hamhock: a big disappointment, this dish was recommended to me by two servers. There wasn't too much meat, was pricey ($25+ for lunch) and just didn't taste good

-Ribs: coming from Atlanta, I'll say these ribs were unique as they were watermelon pickled. They are far from fall off the bone or tasty though..

Service was subpar as we had 2-3 servers and outside the hostess, the servers took awhile and didn't seem to enjoy working there. Overall, I wouldn't come back for the food. Drinks may be a different case as the atmosphere is pretty swanky.

My wife recommended this place froma visit she had six years ago.  While the flavors of the mean were great, $29 for a couple slices of brisket is over the top.  I have a bbq place back home that would blow this place out of the water.  I thinkk the food is over priced, but still tasty.  I think the hype is too trendy.

Probabaly my favorite place ever! I was cooped up in college station for way too long so this lovely place definitely blew me out of the water. They met all of my expectations for them from reading their reviews from news articles and their menu. We got the whiskey flight, the cochon and the chili shrimp. Everything was delicious and very well seasoned and thought out. The chili shrimp gave us about 5 or 6 whole shrimps, shell and head still on, in a lovely Sweet chili sauce reminiscent of Asian cuisine. The Cochon was a buttery melt in your mouth pork dish over a simple cabbage mound. Even their rolls were beautifully soft and sweet. The place wasn't too busy when we got there at 11 but when we left at 12 it got super busy and for good reason!

Today is my 5th day in New Orleans. We came to this place to have a break during our day tour in WWII museum. We saw this place with a really nice patio outside. But, they refuse to open patio seating to other guests when there were several more tables still available. At the beginning, we're told we can seat outside after the tale is being cleaned, but they look just fine. Later the story became that in order to seat there, we need to wait 30 mins. After a while, we were told there may be reservations made on these tables, they need to check. After so called checking, we're told these tables were closed to customers. So we end up seating inside, which is not a big deal, although that was my first time to experience such unprofessional service at a restaurant. Our server, she was  wry pushy on drinks, and later even on dishes. We weren't hungry, so just ordered some appetizer dishes (apparently she wasn't happy about that). She got an attitude and not showing up after ordering until our meal is finished and we were ready for our bill. Finally, she had a smile on her face when she brought the check back. Unfortunately, I didn't undertip her, because the dishes are tasty.

Ate here today with my family. We got the alligator bites with the sauce on the side. They were fresh and not chewy like some places make them. I got the rabbit and dumplings. It was very good, even my wife that has tried rabbit in the past (and didn't like it) said it was very good. She got the fried boudin. They were also excellent. We got the grits and mac and cheese for sides. Both were creamy and very favorable. The wait staff was very attentive to us. Only negative would be price. Typical small plates with large price tag. For our meal with drinks for 3 was over $70 before tip. The restaurant was very clean. Even the glass cups look so clean they looked brand new. They have a beautiful wood fired oven where most of the food is cooked. All in all great food and good experience for our first visit.

I had a wonderful experience on my first visit. Stellar food and service in a comfy atmosphere. If you are in the area, this place is a must. Their Mac and cheese casserole blew me away. Be sure to save room for dessert!

After visiting the Butcher in 2014 and having one of the best meals during our last trip to New Orleans I was excited to go to the place that started it all. However, I think I let my expectations get the better of me. 

We had a 7:45 reservation. We walked from the French Quarter and arrived early, and since there really isn't a good place to have a drink and wait, we went in 15 minutes early just to check in and hang at the bar. Once we got through the front door, madness ensued. 

It. Was. Packed. 

Thank the spirit we had a reservation as a ton of people were standing around, looking lost and confused with no where to go. No seats, no defined waiting area. Some of the dining tables were right next to the front. I can only imagine how distracting it would be to sit at one of these tables as you see concerned patrons and restless kids standing around for an eternity. 

The hostess said they were running on time. Great! After checking in I was very clear with the hostess that my husband and I would be at the bar because the "waiting area" was so crowded and I was pretty parched from our walk. The bartender made my husband a great Negroni, I just wanted water. And we waited. And waited. And waited. 

15 minutes after our reservation time I did what I never do: I checked back in with the hostess, at which point she said she was waiting for us to seat us. Are you kidding me? You know my name, phone number, email.... you never said I should come back... when I was waiting to get her attention I saw her make a note for another patron: "bro dude with beanie". He didn't look much like a "bro" to me, but what do I know? Maybe if they took numbers or names instead of focusing on subjective adjectives and articles of clothing that can easily be removed they'll have better luck. I was just glad to get seated, but then kept being super distracted by the chaos of the front door. That ish needs to get sorted out, asap. 

The boudin balls, beet salad, and brisket were amazing. Catfish court bouillon was finished in 5 bites.

This place was a great experience. My party of four started with the fried whole shrimp and alligator. I got the rabbit and dumplings and my friends got the catfish courtbullion, the crawfish pie, gumbo, twice backed potato, eggplant side, and the greens. This isn't your typical fried food joint - there is hardly any breading so it's more of a tempura. Everything was really good, but I think that the rabbit and dumplings was the real winner. The main dishes were medium sized portions but some of the appetizers were quite small considering the price. I will definitely return, however. 

During conferences, this place is going to be PACKED. Make reservations or face multi-hour waits. 

Just a tip: the heaters outside aren't very good. We were shivering outside even though we were sitting right under one. Bring a sweater!

Order anything on this menu and you won't go wrong. My friends and I have tried dozens of things on our visits here and can't find anything that isn't fantastic. Great service and I love the vibe of the space. It is in my top five go-to spots in NOLA. I can't say enough great things.
Had a great time at Cochon. Food was amazing but definitely get a reservation- place is hopping.
This place is amazing, the oyster is the best, a little spicy  but deli, I prove ribs, alligator, oyster everything is awesome  ...

This is the best meal I've had in NOLA, and I've been to many of the greats like Antoine's, Bayona, etc. They're slaying over at Cochon. We watched a clip on Eater, and since my babe loves all things barbecue, we wanted to drop in for a meal. Surprisingly, we ended up eating everything BUT the pork entree which people raved about on Eater. 

The space is awesome, with a handful of tables outdoors, and an excellent bar stocked with a vast array of Bourbon. My babe ordered a $30 Buffalo Trace Antique Collection (Stagg) Bourbon which he said was really hard to find. He took a lot of pleasure in sniffing and sipping upon it. Me? Well, I'm a cheap date. I ordered an old fashioned with Rye whiskey. I chose the Michter's which was only a $13 cocktail. Still, it was our last night, and we wanted to have an indulgent send-off.

We put our names down for a table, and the wait was 45 minutes, but the bar has open seating. So, we ended up timing it perfectly when a couple vacated two spots for us at the bar. We opted to stay at the bar because it was lively, and gave our table away.

We started with the fried Boudin, and it was excellent. The Dijon mustard and pickled onions were perfect accompaniments. I also wanted to try the shrimp and deviled egg jambalaya. I had jambalaya the night before from Oceana, but it didn't not hit the spot, and it definitely was not spicy. Thankfully, Cochon's was expertly rendered because it had a heat that was subtle but present.  
It also had the signature dark roux which to me signals authentic Cajun flavorings. The deviled egg actually worked to quell some of the spice. 

Meanwhile, I ogled a fish dish that someone else nearby was eating. I asked her if it was good, and she couldn't say enough nice things about it, so I literally ordered the same meal as her, even down to the macaroni and cheese side dish that she had chosen. This method worked out. I'm usually hesitant to order a whole fish, skin-on, but this one was blackened and cooked perfectly and didn't have a single stray bone left behind. It was delicious, and I ate the whole thing like a #champ. 

The mac and cheese is next level, but it also filled me up. Like so much so that it was both my side dish and my dessert. Haha.

My sweetheart had the rabbit stew, and every bite I stole was impressive. They use biscuits for dumplings, the broth is thicker like a gravy, and the meat was plentiful and tasty and very tender.

All-in-all, we had a great night at Cochon. Many thanks to the expert bartenders who were also our servers. We appreciated his knowledgeable and talented they were. I also love supporting a local business that is trying to be both Cajun and Southern because these two genres make for an excellent hybrid.

I went in with a group of 7 people for a late lunch (around 3pm), and it was still quite busy. They had us sat within 15 minutes. We had two servers helping us out which was nice.

We ordered all of our food, and it came within 20 minutes except for a salad my friend had ordered. Eventually, he got the salad, but it had meat on it (he was a vegetarian and had asked for no meat). When he pointed this out to the waiter, he insisted it was not meat, but instead fresh cheddar. At that point, we got another server to help us out and get him a new salad. In my opinion, they should not have charged him for the salad, but they still did!!!! We were ready to get out of there by the time we finally got the salad, so we didn't complain.

Splitting checks is always difficult for large groups, but they weren't very helpful here. I wouldn't recommend coming here if you need separate checks (we were in town on business and needed to pay individually to get reimbursed).

Highlight: the oyster & bacon sandwich. Although it wasn't much of a sandwich because the bread was SOOOOOO soggy that I had to deconstruct it and eat it with a fork. However, the fried oysters were delicious. Also a great selection of beer!

After asking about the vegan options, the server offered to have the chef create an entree for me.  The chef made me a fantastic vegan roasted cauliflower entree with black-eyed peas puree, spicy carrots, and a citrus-fennel salad. They were very accommodating and it was absolutely delicious!
Great service and great food. Must get the fried alligator bites and banana pudding. Everything in between is also delicious!

Very disappointed in how classless the hostess (poka-dotted shirt)  is at this restaurant. I rarely leave negative reviews and it takes a lot to get under my skin. 

We were thrilled to try this restaurant out seeing that it came recommended. We understand that at times there will be a wait but we do not deserve to be spoken to with an attitude like no other and bothered by asking a few questions. Gosh forbid if you have to use some actual brain cells to be professional and polite. When we pay, I believe we pay for your pay check? 

Just straight up rude and even had the nerve to tell me to book a reservation for another night. Hello Mic-fly we came to restaurant to eat that night.

I would recommend hiring a new hostess asap!!

Enjoyed our dinner here, but don't think it quite lived up to the reputation. Service was great. Our waitress was super helpful and sweet. The food was good but not as spectacular as we were expecting. Some dishes were overly salted and nothing special. As other reviewers have mentioned they were out of some of the desserts, which was disappointing. Rabbit and dumplings was delicious. Twice baked potato was really tasty!

Just about everything on this menu sounded amazing! We settled on a few small items each and loved everything! The oysters are not to be missed, maybe the tastiest I've ever had in my life! The mac n cheese casserole and devlied egg gumbo were also great. The only annoying thing was with the open kitchen they have you could see your food just sitting up there under the heater oven as you were hungry and just wanted to go grab it. It was comfortable and cool in there with good air conditioning. Also, we were too exhausted from five days in NOLA already, but the cocktails looked very impressive as well.

First night in town, and we stumbled upon Cochon when the restaurant we planned to have dinner at had just closed for the night. Lucky mistake. Service and food were all top notch at Cohon. Tasty cocktails too!

I didn't think this restaurant was that great. I was excited to try it with the reviews being so positive. 
 We had a reservation and still stood awkwardly by the crammed hostess for 15-20 minutes while other parties continued to get seated. 
  The prices were good, but the food was nothing spectacular. The service was poor in that we had two different servers taking care of us and yet our drinks went empty for quite some time on multiple occasions. We wanted to order more dishes and deserts but continued to wait on a server to visit us. One would have thought with so many dishes and drinks being ordered we would have had great service. 
  The music was so loud we could not hold a conversations because everyone around us was yelling as well in order to hear one another. 
  We won't be visiting this restaurant on future trips to New Orleans.

Have the wood fired oysters, you won't regret it. Best in town! 
the service is excellent and the food amazing. Stop by Butcher, they adjacent sandwich shop to buy pickled veggies and other goodies. They also have the best Moscow mule in town!
Great restaurant with great service. Order the beet salad and also the macaroni and cheese.
We thought the food was really good and very unique. The creamy grits are to die for. You have to eat those.

Had lunch here because of the Yelp reviews. My first visit to New Orleans. I had the oysters and ribs (ribs recommended by server). It was a good meal but I can't say it wowed me.  Again, good meal but I have had better. It is a very modern, airy place (and smells delicious).

I misunderstood this place and was even more confused going out. I went in expecting a fine dining experience, when really this is more of a contemporary fusion of local cajun/creole, BBQ, gastropub, etc. like I said, a bit confused on exactly what that wanted to be. Had the food and service all been amazing, this would have quickly faded to "no big deal;" but, not to be. 

We had early 5:3.. Hostess was pleasant and reserved  table was ready when we arrived. A nice detail. But service went downhill from there. We could hear about half of what our waiter was saying and he was constantly referring to his order book for details on the day's specials which he had not yet memorized

We got our cocktail orders in and I was excited to take a dive into the local cuisine. We ordered  gator bites and roasted oysters with hot chili oil. Man, these local oysters are huge! I usually eat my oysters raw and haven' had gator in over 30 years; so not being an expert, I can't really compare or contrast; but would say they were very good; but amazing or memorable. After dropping off the apps, we were told the bread for the table was still not ready in the kitchen. 

For the main course, I had the beef brisket and my wife the Cachon (Pulled pork shoulder shaped  into a patty and seasoned on the outside with a spicy dry rub). Oddly though, as our waiter was taking his now 2nd smoke break just outside the door by our table, they brought our main course plates while we  were still halfway through our appetizers and cocktails. The asst manager apologized for the timing but just left it at that. No wine orders were taken and, why? We still had half our cocktails left. The overwhelming flavor on the brisket was salt.  Really not much more of interest beyond that. And, oddly, served only with a cold and average potato salad. The Cachon was surprisingly dry which is not what I expect from pork shoulder; but maybe that is how Cachon is supposed to be. Our bread arrived about  1/2 way into the main course.  Odd for sure, but, must say, possibly worth the wait?!

Never did get a wine order in as the timing was just not right, but did order dessert. The German chocolate cake we shared was amazing! Maybe the best I have ever had. Unfortunately, they didn't take a coffee order at the time and by the time I could  put it in, I did not get it until ¾ of the way through the cake. And, when they did bring it, they forgot the sugar. He never did come back with it and I asked them to take the coffee off of my tab. 

Overall, with so many great restaurant choices in NOLA, I'm not sure this makes the "must" or even "should" list for me.

It's out of the way from the French Quarter, but worth the trip.  Everything we got was really tasty.  Started with boudin, pork cheeks, and crawfish pie.  Could have eaten 3 of each, but the cheeks were my favorite.  Then split the rabbit stew, which we could not make it through, not for lack of trying.

They really have a service issue at this restaurant. We were seated close to our reservation time of 830 but it went downhill from there. They tried to tag team us with servers, we suspected that our first one was very inexperienced , maybe her first night. She knew very little about the menu, which probably led us to make the wrong choices for dinner. The pork rib app and brisket were poorly done. You can get better at the airport in Dallas. Am sure the bread was great but couldn't get any after several requests. We gave up after that and put it down to a poor dining experience.
With all the great places to eat in Nola pass this one up.

Loved the food and were happy to quickly get seated at the chef's table; we love watching the kitchen in action. (Especially since the crew had great camaraderie on a busy Saturday night.) I sadly didn't order the porchetta, one of the specials of the evening, but the sous chef was kind enough to give us a taste after we spent most of our meal drooling over it from our bar stools. Recommend the grilled oysters, ribs and the mac n' cheese!
Great, amazing food!  Friendly and helpful staff. The crawfish bisque was deep, rich, and spicy!  The whisky and German chocolate cake was a crowning dessert to a great meal.
Love the boudin balls. The fried chicken livers with pepper jelly. The gumbo and deviled egg was good. So was the rabbit and dumplings.

I looked forward to going to Cochon when i read the reviews about it.  I have been there 3 times.  Overall I was disappointed in the food but I may not have ordered their best dishes like their oysters.  The hostess and waitstaff were below average and the restaurant was loud.  I did not care for the ambiance.  My wife ordered boudin and thought that it was very good.
I decided to buy a sampling of most of the products that you can take home; I was expecting to find a good source for certain products.  For example I compared their andouille sausage with several other brands in a blind taste test and was disappointed that the results showed only average results.I can't figure it out

What a wonderful place to get some vittles for your stay in New Orleans. Try the Cajun Pastrami, the terrine and just about anything else in the case. Great people are there helping you figure out what to take out (or eat in). There is a lovely bar with great service and high tops for casual lunches. Next door, Butcher, is more of a sit down with the same great foods and reputation. Love these two places and go stock up every time we leave town to bring back samples to savor. Until the next trip...

Great food, atmosphere, and service. Everything we ordered was on point. Staff worked together and seemed to be having fun while they were working which is always nice to see. Definitely order the alligator as an appetizer

Our dish (rabbit) was pretty good. The prices are high, and we found out afterwards that other tables were served bread, guess since we aren't regulars, our waitress didn't bother? 

So for stars:

Prices - high (2*)
Service - bleh (2*)
Food - good (4*

Average - 3stars.

My favorite spot for delicious comfort food. The Ham hock is my go to dish, but if the pork shoulder is on special then get that. Drinks are always tasty and service is great. Call ahead because without a reservation it will be hard to get in.

I had a lovely dinner at Cochon for my brother's birthday. We made a reservation a day or two before for 8:30pm and actually tried to come earlier since we had some extra time but weren't able to be seated until the reserved time. Not a big deal since there was a bar across the street we waited at.

The food and drinks at Cochon perfectly matched our palette - bold flavors, depth, unique combinations. We got quite a few things but here were the memorable moments:

- Wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter ($14) - we fell in love with wood-fired oysters at Felix's the night before so we wanted to see how Cochon did theirs. These were great as well, with some Asian flare and sweetness - but I think we all preferred Felix's simple, indulgent, charred-forward flavor.

- Rabbit & dumplings ($23) - Cochon's take on Chicken & Dumplings, and this was a favorite of our table. It tasted so homey and comforting, like it had been stewing for hours. I couldn't get enough of this.

- Shrimp & deviled egg gumbo ($8) - Loved this take on gumbo, because it felt nostalgic to our Chinese heritage with there being notes of fermented shrimp paste. It just added a lot of depth and umami.

I can't remember the name of the cocktail I had, but it was so good that I had probably 5 of them. It had passion fruit, which I love and was probably reminiscent of a hurricane and maybe had mezcal. But if you want a perfect drink on a hot day, keep ordering the drink that has passion fruit.

Huge Plus: the bathrooms have amazing acoustics. I was snapping some Adele karaoke clips and it was major.

The great: Make a reservation, get seated promptly. Loved the waiting area which is a blank space in between the hostess space and the bar. It was really smart and eliminates the crowd standing by the door waiting to be seated. Service was amazing. The only hiccup is we asked for more bread, because the bread is yeasty perfection and we had to ask like 3 different times. We didn't get it until we were almost done our entrees. 

So what did we eat: A table of five people so for appetizers we got the Oysters, Crawfish Pie, and Alligator bites. The oysters are note worthy and live up to the hype, the crawfisg pie had amazing flavor. I didn't try the alligator but it looked good. 

Entrees: Three of us had the Catfish Courtbuillon, one person had the Rabbit and Dumplings, and another had the Louisiana Cochon. The Courtbouillons were extremely salty. Two of us tried to muster through because the flavor of the dish was amazing but the salt was very overpowering. A lady came around, like seriously I have no idea where she came from, and asked me how the dish was. I said mine was too salty, actually all of us did, but one of us had already powered through the dish and two of us sent it back (the woman first offered to correct it with out us even asking to send it back) as the lady assured us they would fix it. First, the remake came out super fast. Impressive. Still a smidge salty but less salty than the first and much more tolerable. The dish is really good but be mindful of the salt. The catfish was cooked and seasoned to perfection. Somewhere the broth seems if the put a extra pinch of salt in the dish it consume the flavor with salt. To the managers credit, hence the four stars, she explained they were training new cooks and it was very possible that someone was unknowingly heavy handed with the salt. I mean, I am one for transparency and flaw acceptance, it could save the world alot of turmoil if more people did it, lol. I really appreciated her candor and her willingness to remedy the issue immediately and she did it with a huge smile. Amazing customer service. 

I would definitely try it again. I tried Cochon Butcher earlier the same day for lunch.

Extremely disappointed. Smoked pork ribs were covered in a BBQ sauce that was so spicy we could not eat them (the menu does not describe them as spicy). Smothered greens and beef brisket were so salty we could not eat them. The only part of our meal that we could eat was the grits and mac & cheese casserole, which were both very good.

Place was ok...the bread and butter was really good..so warm and gooey. We got the cochon and the ham hock which really wasnt my thing. The best part of the cochon for me was the cabbage and pork skin...my friend ordered the rib and pickled watermelon and it was amazing..:by small so u should get a side. All the appetizers (alligator, oysters, and mac and cheese) were amazing .

Louisiana cochon, smoked ham and the braised cheek appetizer were super delicious. The wine list is not that impressive and our server was not quite so knowledgeable to help make a selection. Not so many places are open for "late" dinner in NOLA, so this is an added advantage. Our reservation was for 9:30 and we were immediately seated.

It was my first time coming to this restaurant and I was so disappointed with the food. Service was great, music playing in the background was great, but I don't think I will ever be back. We ordered the oysters as an appetizer  . They were amazing but I feel a little overpriced. My boyfriend and I split the beef brisket and potato salad along with the macaroni and the food was just so bland! My best friend and her boyfriend ended up getting some alligator appetizer, the dumplings, and some pork dish. If anything the dumplings were OK. Pork was bland. Not flavorful at all! Nothing had enough flavor .I don't understand. I have had better food for a better price at hole in the wall places in Nola. I don't mind paying for food if it tastes amazing but this was so bland. The best things on the menu are the alligator dish and the oysters. Oh yes and whoever the dj was picking the playlist! (Sad,but true) You're better off going to the pork place down the street. Don't waste your money. You're in Nola, there are so many better options.

TLDR - Great place to get lunch or dinner in a laid back atmosphere. Feels upscale but relaxed and well worth checking out if you're in the area. I don't know if this is really quintessential Cajun cuisine but it was pretty delicious. More like 4.25 or 4.5 stars than  4.


The Long Version 

I came here during Mardi Gras with a group of friends and this place was well reviewed and close to our living accommodations. The night before I went to their Butcher shop right next door and it blew me away (read the review on that to hear more high praise or just stop reading and go!). 

When we arrived the place was pretty full but we were able to quickly get a table outside and the weather was beautiful although still hot. The service was great, we were given waters quickly and I started off with an Arnold Palmer which looked better than it tasted. For starters we went with hush puppies and fried gator tail which came out relatively quick and tasted pretty great. There was a bit too much sauce on the tail for my liking but other than that - no complaints.

For my main I went with the ribs and they were pretty good. They weren't fall off the bone sadly but the flavor profile was outstanding, I'd recommended them no problem. The portion size was pretty healthy too and could easily be shared with one other along with a side. 

Speaking of sides, the Mac and Cheese is not to be missed. I ordered some at the butcher shop the night before and again here. Usually I'm not very big on Mac and Cheese but this one was unreal. The pasta was cooked perfectly and the cheese didn't make me feel overly full with every bite (well not at first, it is hot cheese and carbs after all). Every bite I took was phenomenal and I can confidently say it was the best take on the dish I've had in my life and that includes the attempts with truffle (Why Steakhouses? Truffles or their oils don't make everything better). I even ended up leaving some ribs on the plate to finish the Mac and Cheese, it was that good. Long story short, get the Mac and Cheese - you won't regret it.

Overall this place was great, not perfect (aside from the Mac and Cheese which is a gift from the Gods), but I'd come back here. The atmosphere, service, and food make this place worth a stop. If you're with a group, try to split dishes as they are big and heavy. I was a hungover gluttonous fool and ordered/horded too much... Opps...

Really enjoyed my meal at Cochon!  This place was recommended seemingly everywhere -- other people I knew who'd visited NOLA, articles, and so on -- so I was super excited to check it out on a recent visit to NOLA.

I made a reservation about a week in advance for 9:15pm.  We arrived a bit early and it was busy, so we weren't able to be seated until a little after 9:15 (which was a bit of a struggle as we were approaching hangry by this point in the night, but understandable!).  

The space is surprisingly large inside, with ample seating in the main area and upstairs.  The restaurant has a modern, upscale-ish/trendy sort of feel.  Service was great.

The highlight was, of course, the food!  Standout items were the crawfish pie, which was basically like a big empanada full of crawfish and other delicious things and had a great flavor; the boudin balls; the macaroni and cheese (which was almost impossibly creamy and flavorful, so good!  A must-try!) and the banana pudding dessert, which packed a TON of flavor and had warm cookies/cake/something amazing mixed in with the pudding.  I had the Catfish Courtbuillon for my entree, which was delicious and flavorful (and a welcome lighter alternative to some of the more rich food we had ordered) as well.

Prices were pretty reasonable given the trendiness of the atmosphere and the reputation of the place -- for 1 drink, 2 appetizers, 3 entrees and a dessert shared among 3 people we came in at about $40/pp.

Great meal and cocktails at Cochon. Hit this our first night in NOLA and it didn't disappoint.  

Some highlights included the alligator bites, crawfish pie, cochon, wood fired oysters, pork cheeks. 

Great ambiance and friendly service.

This place is AMAZING! Everything that we had was perfect. The woodfire oysters were wonderful with the perfect amount of heat. The rabbit and dumplings were packed with flavor and the brisket was so tender you could eat it with a spoon. Get the Mac and cheese, it's crispy top and edges were a great balance to the creamy center below and the banana pudding was delightful as well. My favorite place to eat here.

If I could spend the rest of my life in one place, it would be Cochon. This Cajun/Creole oasis on Tchoupitoulas Street is absolute heaven for anyone who knows anything about food, or just likes to taste things that are yummy. It does not deserve anything less than 5 stars, and I'd give it 6 if I could. I guarantee you that my descriptions don't do justice to the orgasmic eating experience that is Cochon.

The bar is very classy and serves a variety of cocktails in addition to their beers on tap, in cans and bottles, and a great wine selection. The ambiance is exactly what you're looking for no matter what you're looking for. It's classy without being stuffy and casual at the same time without being divey. I don't really have a word that quite encompasses the feel except for perfect.

All of that aside, you're here for the FOOD, so let's get to it.

Wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter ($14) - undeniably the best $14 you'll ever spend. I had a ton of wood-fired oysters on my trip and none even held a candle to holding a candle to these. They are perfectly cooked and swimming in this chili garlic butter that I want all of my food to be drenched in for the rest of eternity

Fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise ($12) - this is the one thing that might be better than the oysters. They're crispy on the outside and soft and juicy on the inside..perfectly fried in all the right ways. I'm a huge fan of all aiolis/mayonnaises, and this is one of the best I've ever had. They pair perfectly together and throw a veritable party in your mouth. I don't mean a high-school kegger in your friends backyard, I mean the parties people who win the Oscars go to after dropping off their gold statues.

Smoked beef brisket with horseradish potato salad ($29) - wow was this perfectly done. My mouth is watering just thinking about this and I just knocked back 4 bowls of cereal (don't ask). This is how brisket should take. I don't know how long they smoked it for, but they nailed it. You didn't need a knife to cut the brisket, it practically fell apart as the juices oozed out elegantly onto my plate and subsequently onto my lap (through no fault of the waiter's or restaurant's, it was all on me). The potato salad was a perfect pair and I'd highly recommend you try one of my patented "perfect bites" which is when you get a little bit of everything on you fork and devour accordingly.

Seriously, I could write a book on this place because I have volumes to say about every dish and the 4 of us ate quite a bit of food. I would fly back to New Orleans just to eat here and then leave. Seriously. Hmm maybe I will. Let's check Travelocity.

Cory was so amazing! Currently here at 10pm Monday April 10th. Our waitress wasn't bad, she just was quite. Cory came to our table and entertained us and had such an amazing personality. She was talkative, cute, and made such a difference in our experience. Food was amazing too!!

Host stand literally couldn't deal. Y'all need to chill and little and smile more because both times I e been in yall looked real stressed. Breathe honey! 

Service was slow to start but had major Bling

Terren (sp?) was incredibly knowledgeable of menu, as was his asst. Mike. Both gentlemen helped us make decisions we were very happy with. 

Beet salad was super lit. Mom loved it. Beets roasted perfectly, still had a nice bite and paired with the citrus and whipped feta smoothly. Very well executed simple ingredients that spoke for themselves. Nice crunch of the salty pepitas. 

Wine wascab. Grenache. Zin. 

Also  enjoyed the gumbo. Perfectly balanced seasoning. Maybe on the salty side for some but BOMB for us. Hatas gonna hate. 

The stewed rabbit with dumplings was so flavorful, packed with herbs and fresh veg. Tender cooked rabbit. Loved it, thanks for the recommendation guys!

Loud atmosphere. Wood. brick. Wood burning stove super sexy. Back of house was also sexy and well seasoned. 

Thanks y'all!

food was just ok. drinks good. service is slow but friendly. i've had better ribs in Nashville. don't quite understand what the James Beard award was for? 
would not really go back unless at someone else's tab

HIGHLY recommend the wood-fired oysters to start. I would say I generally like oysters and seafood, but I could eat a dozen of these in seconds. AMAZING. Our table also really enjoyed the gator bites and boudin balls for appetizers. Clean plates all around. I'd also recommend my entree - the fish plate. It was one of the more expensive dishes ($32) but it was worth it. I did get a side of mac n cheese which was nothing to write home about but was not bad by any means. We paid about $200 for 4 plates, 3 apps, and 4 drinks. Would definitely recommend and would come back again.
Our meal at Cochon was one of the highlights of our trip. Rabbit stew, brisket special, alligator app and cocktails were all super tasty. Make a reservation for dinner weeks in advance.

Nearly empty on a weekday lunch. We meant to go to the Butcher next door, not this more formal restaurant. Unfortunately, we didn't realize this until after we ate. Oops. 

Our server was nice, but we noticed that some tables were offered complimentary bread, which we never received. And $9 for a pint of beer?

Their tri-tip sandwich was okay, not great. The meat was undercooked and way too chewy. The boudin fritters (only three little balls) weren't hot enough. 

Go to the Butcher around the corner instead of here.

Went here on recommendation, and very glad we did.  Well off the beaten tourist path, but still walkable from our place in central business district. And an easy walk from WWII Museum. Delicious local food -- we shared small plates of oysters, gator bits, greens, and mac & cheese and had plenty to go around for 6 adults. Tasty cocktails, too.   Unpretentious setting, clean & cozy, with friendly & helpful wait staff -- all in all, a great mid-day food outing.
Best beef brisket and horseradish potato salad I have ever had in my life - period. It was amazing enough to make me actually write a review. That's HUGE!!!!

Very good with potential to have many good meals here ... everything was delicious ... a bit nore corporate than boucherie but everything was consistently good

Alligator bites? Yes
Mac and cheese? Perfect

... even great rye whiskey selection

Okay. I'm sorry yelp.  I just looked through the pictures for Cochon and it doesn't look like anyone has captured any pictures of the meal I had, and I was too inebriated to do it myself, so I will do my best to explain what I ate.

A FIVE POUND PORK PORTERHOUSE

This thing served six people, with leftovers.  It was slow smoked to medium/medium well.  It was amazing.  Delicious flavor, super soft pork, and the perfect way to put yourself into a meat coma.  I was stuffed by the end, I felt like I could barely move.  

I tried some of the sides with my mountain of meat as well.  The macaroni and cheese was pretty great, and I tend to be picky about mac and cheese.  Lot's of cheese, these weren't "milk noodles."  The creamy grits were also very good.  The smothered greens were good, but there was a bit too much cream in there for me.  

An excellent meal.
Just right. Nice space, great flavor, good cocktails, not over the top rich. DO GET THE GRITS! Whoa, they are divine.

Everything was really good. We had wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter, pork cheek country captain, and Louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklings, and pickled turnips. Also, daughter had Mac and cheese and Lima beans. Very delicious!  The server was very nice and helped us understand the menu since it was our first visit.  Next time we'll check out their sister restaurant Cochon Butcher.

We came here upon friends' recommendations. Boy so happy we did! We sat outside on an beautiful April night. I ordered a Hurricane and it was delicious!!! Quality cocktail! We ordered wood fired oysters - so delicious- fired shrimp is to die for! And crawfish pie was also really good. Service was good and fast while indoors was packed. This is a very good place. Don't miss it.

This place rocks, they do a great job on all of their dishes! Another hot spot that you should try to get to when visiting or a local. They have made quite a name for themselves and this is a hot spot to get into.

We tried a lot of their menu, can't remember everything but we had 4 people order a ton of stuff and dessert. I know we loved it all, very impressive to see menu start to finish be so good. All four of us gave two thumbs up.

Great local find!! Food was perfect tonight!! Alligator tail and beef ribs with pickled watermelon to start off with. Shared rabbit dumplings, brisket and ham hock. Mac n cheese is to die for!  Collards were awesome. Finished the meal off with banana pudding and my favorite German chocolate cake(with a tall glass of milk). Wished we had places like this back home. Great atmosphere and wonderful service. You won't be disappointed!!

This place was delicious and very trendy.  The food was a too salty for our taste, but still excellent.  I had the rabbit stew, which also came out extremely hot.  The ambiance was not very comfortable - the chairs and table were simple (on trend) but our neighbors were very close to us, and it was very loud and difficult to have a conversation across the table.  We were there for a long weekend from Tallahassee, so the glimpse of civilization was just what we wanted.

I was here with friends over the holidays and just now getting around to writing a review.  I have recommended this place to everyone i know.  It is quite simply one of the best places i have ever been.  If you are a meat eater, this is the place to go.  They also have a great selection of beers and cocktails.  Their mac n chees and short ribs are off the chain according to my friends.  I had the brisket which was fantastic.  They also brought out this bread which was stellar.  I think it has been featured on the travel channel but it lives up to the hype.  I would go back in a heartbeat.  It is near the business district and not in the quarter but don't let that stop you.  You won't be disappointed in the food or the service!

Delicious! New Orleans classics kicked up a notch. The red snapper was my favorite and the pork didn't disappoint. The charbroiled oysters had good flavor but a little undercooked to my liking. We didn't make reservations so we're seated at the chef's booth and enjoyed the view of the kitchen.

Cochon was my favorite place to eat on my trip to the big easy. We ate here twice in 3 days. 
It has a great ambiance without seeming pretentious. The decor is clean and cool. It really works and you feel cozy in it. 
The menu is pretty simple and easy to understand. Small, medium and large plates basically make up the whole menu. I didn't get everything in the menu but if I did I'm sure I would find it amazing. It's not a BBQ restaurant but you have to try the ribs. They are the best I ever had. Mac n cheese is also to die for and don't be afraid to try the alligator.
walked in a on a wkday night and there was a bit of a wait..luckily there was space at the bar..loved the mac and cheese and alligator bites!

We had the gumbo (was a bit on the salty side), pork cheeks (really good), and rabbit and dumplings (best one out of everything we had). For dessert we had the banana pudding, which was a bit too sweet but very flavorful.

Make sure you get the complimentary bread, that's the best!

This place is awesome! The bourbon list is expansive and the menu amazing. Everyone at our table changed their minds numerous times before ordering because the food sounded so good. We ordered the smoked brisket, pork cheeks, Louisiana Cochon and ribs. Each had great flavor as all shared our meals with each other. The German chocolate cake was good, but the meals were the best part of our experience. Good food with good friends, what more can you ask for!
There is nothing I can add but OMG this is the real deal. I have eaten at both restaurants. I have never been disappointed and can't wait to come back.

Absolutely not over-rated! 

Food was subtle and elegantly flavored and prepared, bar is excellent. Drink a little slow in coming but at peak hours on a Friday night during Jazz Fest. Dinner service was friendly and timely.

Went for lunch before the crowd and got lucky with a table. The items on the menu are definitely unique. Not vegetarian friendly and not your typical meats. There's alligator, pork, gumbo, real New Orleans dining. Ordered the gulf fish, which was pretty tasty --- tasted very fresh, but was a bit over salted. The drinks were wonderful, the dessert was amazing. All in all a memorable and good dining experience.
Overrated in my opinion. Food was just ok (ribs and Cochon were favored of the dishes we tried). Dessert was just ok (German Chocolate was the best of the options we tried).  Service was pretty good.

The ambience was great.  I tried the roast, and it was good.  The shrimp salad sandwich was excellent.  Our server was excellent.  And I forgot my credit card at the restaurant, and they saved it for me :).

Loved this place so much. This was the first restaurant we tried and we almost went twice during our stay in New Orleans! Perfect for a fancy-ish lunch. Service was great, super friendly waiter!  Everything we ordered on the menu was delicious!
The food was fantastic, great atmosphere!  Make sure you have a reservation or you'll be on a very long waiting list.

Cochon mean "pig" in French. Surely the name implies their expertise with the pork dishes. My advise is to pick the strangest dish or the one you can't pronounce, they will open your eyes to the new enjoyable experience. We love the food, ambient and courtesy of serving staff.

We were extremely hungry when we got here and were let down by the portion size and quality for the price. Entrees are $30ish so if you're not looking to break the bank, you have to stick with the $7 apps. There were 7 of us and we ordered about 12 items from the menu. We all agreed that none of it was better than average. We would have been ok with it if the prices weren't so high, but to leave with a full belly you'll need to spend at least $20 per person.  Lastly, beware that Yelp lists this as Cajun/Creole food. You'll be let down if that what you're in the mood for. There are only about 25 choices on the menu and most are more in line with barbecue or tapas.
Food was outstanding. The kitchen staff worked as a team and the product is the result.

We went on a recommendation by my brother-in-law. I love homemade dinner rolls and he mentioned they made great dinner rolls.  
We were there on the early side about 5:30 so it was not crowded and the noise level was minimal. This place is connected with a butchery, we however did not order from the meat dishes with the ecxception of their gumbo which had chicken and sausage.
Our food and our service were both fair. Our actual server did not offer the specials for the evening until we asked and she was rarely around for questions or requests.
I ordered the wood fired oysters with chili garlic butter which the server highly recommended. 
I found them to be fresh but not prepared to my liking. Even though the oysters were cooked, they came out luke warm. The chili garlic butter did not have any zip to it in fact it was rather bland and overly greasy.
The gumbo was was the right consistency but the meats in it were far too smokey. Towards the last quarter of the bowl, the gumbo was so smokey it was inedible. My husbands grilled redfish was nicely prepared but nothing special about it and quite pricey for a small piece of fish without much served with it. We didn't even stay for dessert.

Make sure to make a reservation, there was a wait out the door 45 mins before closing. The food was excellent -- best oysters I've ever had. The mac and cheese, mushroom salad and crawfish bread were also tasty.

Incredible! I travel for work and often enjoy taking the opportunity to find new places to eat by myself. Everything was perfect here.... the service, the cocktails, and the food. I had the oysters, followed by the braised ham hock, and finished with a piece of German chocolate cake. I will come back here for sure.

A friend had recommended this place and I was excited to try it but it was kind of a letdown.

For a 1 pm lunch for two people I was not expecting a 20 minute wait, and then once we were sat it took about 10 minutes for the server to even greet us - not cool. 

The food also took a long time (~25 min).

I had the fried alligator and mac and cheese. The mac and cheese was veryyyyy good but heavy. The fried alligator was served in a spicy mayo with mint leaves - not gonna lie, if it weren't for the mint and mayo I probably would have hated the fried alligator but I wanted to try it to at least say I tried it. The meat is tough and chewy and the fried batter around it does not help the texture. 

All in all, wish we would have gone to Butcher instead (a sister restaurant right next door). The reviews there are a better anyways.

If you are in NOLA and spending long days at the convention center like I was recently, check this place out for dinner. It is bright and open with a great bar super bartenders and an extensive collection of brown Liquors.  I tried something I have never eaten before, pork cheeks. Amazing! This place gets crowded so either make a reservation or be prepared to wait a little bit. Well worth it.

Loved this place. Had a little bit of everything. Ribs were fantastic, brisket was great, spicy alligator, chili smoked oysters were incredible. I had the drink called The Rub which had rye whiskey, bitters and apple cider vinegar. Was sure how that would turn out but really liked it. Will go here again next
We literally had the hardest time getting the bread. We're probably going to get black listed for getting three rollls

2 blocks across the street from conference center, great food

We were a petty of two and got 4 dishes to share: oysters, alligator, pork cheeks, and mac and cheese--all delicious and the four dishes combined were the perfect amount of food for two.

Get the alligator. That was our favorite.

The oysters have an oily spicy sauce here and they went really well for adding some flavor to the Mac and cheese.

For nonalcoholic drinkers, they have a rose elderflower lemonade (in a bottle)!

Wow! The food is delicious and filling. The place was packed on arrival. We got the oysters, mushroom salad, pig cheeks, brisket and horseradish potato salad, and a side of mac n cheese. We loved it all!! It was the perfect southern comfort meal for our trip.

Went here for dinner with a large group after making a 7pm weekend reservation months in advance, and we were not disappointed. The service was quick and friendly, and the vibe is low-key (not pretentious) while still nice. I had the fish and really enjoyed it - no knife needed, tender off the bone and quite tasty. The mac n cheese side was billed as "to die for," and it was amazing. I only had a bite, but I could see that being a full dinner given how rich it was! The oysters as an appetizer were delicious. I also tried the beet salad, which was perfection. Our waiter suggested a round of apple pie shots for our bachelorette instead of dessert, and they were delicious (but I probably would have rather tried the dessert). I would recommend Cochon to anyone looking for a relaxed but high-quality dinner experience in New Orleans. Definitely can't eat it every day - the food is definitely Southern and heavy - but good for special occasions.

Quick service at the butcher service deli. Had the pastrami and rye and wish it had more of the sauerkraut to even out the meat portion. I also had the mac and cheese and it was a very small portion for what they charged. Overall very tasty.

I have been to the sandwich shop at cochon a few times during a work conference (it is walking distance to the convention center). A delicious lunch spot. Today we went to the restaurant. The oysters are amazing. I wanted 2 more rolls to sop up the spicy, buttery sauce. We also had the crawfish pie. Very tasty as well. We shared an entree recommended by our waitress - the cochon. It was sort of like a ball of meat. Delicious. Served with a tangy cabbage mixture. We tried the chili vinegar on it (which was sitting on the table with another hot sauce), and it was fantastic. I would definitely go back.

This place is GOOD!!!!! The oysters were delicious, the rabbit on point, the brisket with horseradish mashed potatoes was fenomenal and the sandwich special (on Tuesday) was excellent. Service is outstanding and fast. Friendly ambient. We will come back for sure

Nice and cute restaurant. Reasonably priced with great service. Had the market fish that was absolutely delicious. The Cajun cucumber with mint salad was a but odd at first but grew on me. I would definitely get it again.

The food is awesome. But the hostess was rude and unaccommodating. Very pretentious. I will miss the food but I will never be back. We had several meals here while we were in town. We were stopping in one more time before we left but just walked out after the way we were treated. Not a great way to treat convention visitors
Tried 9 different dishes with our group and all I can say is DAMN!!!!  Really, this was an outstanding experience all the way around!!

We had an amazing dinner here. I was especially impressed by the service. Our waitress Rema was great to us, and even gave us her personalized recommendations for brunch spots in the area. 

She went out of her way to really think through good options for what we were looking for (authentic off the tourist track spot that would not be too busy on Mother's Day -- hard!!). Thank you Rema.

This was recommended by pretty much everyone. You will need to take a cab if coming from French Quarter but it's so worth it. Get a reservation! Instead of doing entrees we did a lot of smaller plates. The ribs were the smokiest I had ever had. The mac and cheese is a must get.  We will go back for sure to get the stuff we didn't try this time.

Just went through the appetizers and they were just great! If you've never tried alligator this is where you should have it first. The oysters and the shrimps are a good complement to get you through the night

I loved this restaurant! The decor & ambiance  was really nice and the food was delicious. I tried their alligator bites, spare ribs (meat fell right off the bone), mac n cheese and the fried oyster blt. I wish I had room to try their desserts. Definitely would return!

We came here as a party of 6. The service was good but the food was just a little above average. I read a ton of reviews raving about the food here and I just don't agree. We had the grilled oysters, pork cheeks, rabbit and dumplings, fried alligator, pork ribs, and the whole trout that was a special for the night.  I enjoyed the grilled oysters, they were very good but that's about it. Everything else was decent but nothing to rave about. Maybe it was because of the high expectations, but everything was just.. ok. I probably wouldn't go back and wouldn't recommend it. But if I was forced to go back I wouldn't hate it.

Get the mac and cheese, it was great. The catfish and the beef brisket were alright, but not really stand out. The brisket comes with a horseradish potato salad, which I did not think paired well with the brisket. The brisket had a sweeter smoked flavor and I thought the horse radish overpowered that. Our waitress was nice and was trying, but looked CLEARLY exhausted and was dealing with other more "needy" tables unfortunately.

We went to Cochon on a Friday night while visiting New Orleans after reading several reviews and references to the restaurant.  It was thoroughly disappointing.  Cochon is supposed to represent the new wave of cajun/creole restaurants in NOLA.  It probably does just that but new wave is not necessarily better than the "old guard."  The menu is somewhat limited, the portions are very small and there was an excessive amount of salt on all four of our dishes.  The acoustics were horrible to the extent that we had trouble hearing each other and the seating was hard wooden chairs that were generally uncomfortable.  Our group didn't fit into the millennial demographic and it appeared that 80-90% of the guests were millennials and that the restaurant might be attractive to that group because it is trendy and has developed a buzz around its brief existence.  Would never return.

This place was by far our favorite restaurant in NOLA!! The BBQ ribs had a serious spice to it. It was amazing! However, the best thing I tasted during our entire trip was the rabbit ravioli. It was a rabbit stew with biscuits ok too. The flavor was so hearty and delicious! My fiancé kept trying to eat my dish because I ordered better this time haha!! The service was also superb! The price point wasn't bad! For two people, appetizers and dinner and two drinks each (include a top shelf bourbon pour) was only $100.

My dad and I ate in Cochon based on the reviews here but I have to say Cochon was overrated. It is soooo cold dining in here. Food was generally too salty to appreciate ( for Chinese people at least)
Oyster was good but not surprisingly amazing as other spots in NOLA. Pork cheek was great. Squash salad was also salty and lack of textual in some ways. 
Chicken Gumbo was ...well.. just edible. 
There are too many other choices in NOLA for a dining in but we definitely won't be back again.
Now I have to find somewhere else to eat a decent lunch! 

But good thing is the waitress was friendly and helpful. 
Thanks.
Upscale decor and dining in comparison to most of NOLA. Mostly cajun dishes reimagined such as the namesake, Cochon. Other foods include crawfish meat pies or deep fried alligator.

Cochon is officially my favorite restaurant in Nola !  Came here for a conference early May and I had been Cochon twice in 4 days :) 

The food, the service, the vibe, I enjoyed it all!

After days back in NYC I still dream of the wood fired oysters with chili butter . It taste just as good as how it sounds! Prob some of the best and biggest oysters I ever had! The only ones that could match this size and juicy level are the ones from the Irish Sea.These bad boys are so big and plum, buttery, bursting of flavors. Go with a Kentucky rye. That is how I roll :) 

Do make reservation or come early. It gets crowded every night!

Giving this place 4 stars for their ribs which were some of the best I've had and for their grilled oysters with chili oil. So delicious!! And our waitress and staff were very nice and attentive! Definitely worth checking out!

Great date spot and cocktails to add. Make reservations! We came on a Saturday at 715 after making reservations that morning and it was packed. The chargrilled Oysters and ribs are what we saw mentioned most in reviews so we started with the ribs... were from Texas and have tried a many rib/BBQ sauce, so we might have had too much to compare to when we thought they were "just good, not great." Still had their own flare with pickled watermelon relish. For entrees, we had the rabbit dumplings and fried oyster sandwich. Both stellar but the oyster sandwich was sooooo flavorful. A little heavy on the sauces but def the most memorable of our experience at Cochon.

We didn't mind, but some might have been seriously turned off by how long the process took. Slow to take our order but we got the appetiZer in right away, so again... didn't mind.

Delicious food and fantastic service! Waitress was so friendly as well as the rest of the staff. Place was so clean! Open kitchen and great atmosphere.

We had the garlic, chilli butter baked oysters- freaking delicious! And the fried boudin balls - life changing amazing party for your mouth! Also had the shaved mushroom salad with fried lemon and jerky, which was so light and flacor packed. Last we started with the Boucherie plate that had chefs choice of homemade meats - the pork pate was to died for. Honestly best meal, service and place - must go in NOLA! Enjoy

Everything was amazing! Super cool laid back spot with a casual vibe and excellent food. The only issue that we ran into was while they have lots of bourbon and whisky selections, my mom had a hard time finding a drink that didn't taste boozy and strong. My husband and I however enjoyed our strong boozy drinks thoroughly!

There was nothing me and my friends tried that wasn't absolutely outstanding. We ordered every appetizer and I can't say enough about the oysters, ribs, meat pie, and fried livers. The main course was a 2lb wagyu beef cut. Good lord, it was beautiful. Waitress was fantastic, knew what she was talking about. My brother had chef's roulette and was served a whole fish which was just nice. We ate at 4 of the top restaurants in the city and we'd take this place any day of the week, and was half the price of the others!

I don't know what other people think but this restaurant is really stupid! Friends and I entered this restaurant and none of the waiter or waitress welcome us. After we sitting down few minutes later, the waiter realized and came to us to ask what for drinks (there were just three tables occupied at that moment). After he served us drinks, none of them came to us again for order even we waved to them! Soooooooooooo fuxking stupid! I won't enter it again. Eventually we left this restaurant without ordering. 永远不要进去 sb饭店

Nope my memory did not deceive me... upon second visit I learned... Cochon is the goods. I came here with my wife for a trip to New Orleans celebrating 3 years together and I knew right away I wanted my favorite meal of my previous trip (Cochon) to be one our list of places to visit. The staff there all seem incredibly friendly, fun and knowledgable about their product. They brought out delicious fresh bread with butter which I struggled to avoid (I wanted to enjoy my meal!). We started with their "Boucherie Plate" which is their Charcuterie plate with all sorts of delicious meat goods. While on vacation we tend to be even more adventurous so things like meats from pigs face suddenly don't sound as "wild". All of the meat on the plate was delicious and beautifully "plated" (yeah I went there). For main dishes my wife ordered the Rabbit & Dumplings (Her first time eating rabbit (I tasted hers so it was mine too!)) and she absolutely loved it. I had the same thing I ordered my previous visit (Louisiana Cochon
With turnips, cabbage & cracklins) and it was as delicious as I remember. I would absolutely return a third time. This remains one of my favorite restaurants in the country!
Great service! The gumbo was perfectly spiced, the fried alligator was amazing with fresh basil and onions, and the grilled oysters were totally yummy.
Walked in off the street for dinner. Such great service. Smells so good. Great mix of cajun and pork offerings. Open bar that overlooks the kitchen to boot!

Our goal when visiting NOLA is always about food. We were excited to give Cochon a try and were able to obtain a 10 pm reservation. Wait staff was friendly knowledgeable. Great cocktail, beer, and wine selection. 

The MVP of the meal was the wood fired oysters with chili garlic butter. We ate them with the fresh homemade bread. Several of the dishes (brisket and ham hock) were too salty!  I was intrigued by the horseradish potato salad that came with the brisket, but found it to be underwhelming. The "fisherman's style" baked fish was was light and delicious! The mushroom salad was an interesting/good flavor combination, but I probably wouldn't order again. The roasted carrots from the special tasted like a campfire- yum! The oyster and bacon sandwich was like a NOLA BLT! Highly recommend!

As I sit in Cochon and continue to eat and drink I can't contain my excitement to review this great restaurant and bar. Cochon has a trendy atmosphere with minimalist industrial decor that has become very popular within the last few years. The bartender, Wyatt, is fantastic and truly great at making drinks and feeling out how much he should talk to his customers. He gave terrific recommendations on beer and food.

I had the alligator small plate to start. I have had alligator tail several times, but this was a different cut that was much better. The spicy aoli was amazing and the meat was very tender. I had the Louisiana Cochon as my entree because when in Cochon, eat Cochon. It was the most well seasoned and delicious meat I have had in a long time, and they some how managed to elevate cabbage to a hole new level. Pork crackling added great texture as well. Awesome-sauce. I was going to stop, but I couldn't so I ordered dessert. I had the spicy peanut chocolate pudding pie, which was as good as it sounds. Perfect finish to a terrific meal. 

The great part is that I didn't even mean to eat at Cochon! Serendipitously, I ended up here after a long search for Cochon 'Butcher' that took me on a long trek through the streets. After Google Maps failed me once, I ended up at Cochon, but not the butcher side that was next door. I was in the mood for a muffaletta, but decided to stay since the butcher closed in 15min and I had already ordered a drink. A little pricey, but worth it. Best meal I have had in NOLA so far.

Eh...

I think I was expecting more because I'd received recommendations from friends, magazines, and Yelpers, it I thought it was overrated,

Before I get to the food, the waiter was great. Unfortunately, you can tell the restaurant is trying to turn people around quickly. I get that, but it ruins the experience when a host is walking about and noting your progress on an iPad every five minutes. That's not an exaggeration. I think it's part of the restaurant's training because we also went to Pesce where they did the same. I get that you have to do it, but at least practice some subtlety.

Ok, the food. We started with the oysters. I'm from New England where they pride themselves on their oysters and I have to say NOLA has New England beat if you like meatier oysters. I didn't even know people grilled them because I'm just used to shuckin' and slurpin'! We ordered the crawfish empanada because we wanted to try crawfish in New Orleans. It was good, but I wouldn't order it again and we didn't finish it.

We also ordered the boudin, which reviews recommended and they were definitely right. When you google boudin, it looks like an uncooked sausage so we were a bit skeptical, but that's not at all what they brought out. The fried ball of meat was delicious and I highly recommend it to anyone going.

Next up were the ribs. The meat fell right off the bone and had a complex mix of spices that I really enjoyed. My wife found it to be rather spicy so if you're not into spice, you should probably shy away from this dish. Last, but most certainly not least was the mac and cheese. We ordered it hoping for the pancetta mac and cheese at the Cochon Butcher, but pancetta wasn't on the menu. The mac and cheese was still a very satisfying side dish.
