It was well portioned with a perfect balance of cheese and cream.

Overall it was good, but we probably wouldn't go back. I would be open to trying the butcher, but wouldn't pay to have someone timing how quickly I can eat their delicious food.

Every time I come to NOLA, I make it a point to stop at this place. The food is unreal here and I haven't had anything remotely close to tasting bad since the first time I came here a few years back. I would highly recommend the pork cheeks and brisket dinner.

Wow. Wow. Wow. 

In a city of sea food and daiquiris, Cochon is THE stand out with the smoked meats and spirits. This is my favorite part of southern cooking and man every bite and sip we had was unforgettable. 

We ordered the pork ribs with watermelon salsa and whiskey flight. The sauce was tangy and spicy and the meat was tender, smoky, juicy, fall off the bone. The watermelon bites were a surprising but refreshing addition. I loved the pepper sauce they have the tables - the one with real red peppers soaking in a vinegar solution. Sharp taste that adds a great kick. So good I even put it on the bread. 

The whiskey pairings were great with the meat and showcased a diverse selection of flavors. Good serving size too. We came during an off meal time - around 3PM and were seated immediately. Next time I'm back in Nola, Cochon is first on my list.

Year in and year out this place executes at the highest culinary level. The bar is deep in whiskies and a bit lighter on other choices, but pretty much everything on the menu other than the pineapple upside down cake is a wow. The baked oysters are off the hook, but then again, I've never had a bad meal here in years. Always inventing, they are one of those rare places where you come to pleasantly expect the unexpected and are rewarded with artistry and improvisation that is culinary Jazz. The staff in the front of the house is quite level and gracious, the one area where the restaurant has improved over the years. The bar is a whiskey lovers' dream, although it is deep in other beverages and wines too. Reservations are a must!

The menu is diverse and celebrates authentic New Orleans fare. We sampled several menu items. Our servers, Terran and Tim were especially attentive and pleasant. Stay away from the chain restaurants and 'tourist traps'. Treat yourself to an amazing dining experience.

Oysters. So good we ordered another plate immediately after we ate the last one. 
Mac and cheese... my mom who refuses to eat it ate half my portion. The collard greens were perfectly tender with the right amount of sour.

Honestly though, the ham bone/shank plate did not live up to the hype of the many reviews. It was good, not great.
Food while great was pricey for a lunch. 2 apps, 1 soup, 2 sides, 1 entree and dessert (no drinks) not including tip was nearly $100.

I think I stand with a few other reviewers in that this place is a bit overrated or has possibly gotten to hip for its britches.  We went on recommendations from yelp and friends.  I'm not even sure I ever know who was waiting on us as we had a few people stopping by.  While this can be nice at times, it led to confusion about the bottle of wine we ordered (they almost opened one twice the price of what we ordered), who had what dishes, etc.  Additionally, we had some friends very generously pay for part of the meal ahead of time as a birthday treat.  This should have been made known to us as the very beginning so we didn't over-order and also so we didn't accidentally assume it was the restaurant treating us so well.  While we were told of one thing that was coming, we were not told of another.  So it was embarrassing when I tried to tell the waiter we didn't order something only to have him correct me.  We asked the waiter about the special.  His response was that his notes said the same thing as the menu.  Ok.  Not helpful.  A good restaurant gives tastes to the staff so that they can accurately describe and SELL the daily specials or even the more pricey menu items.  Food was good but I I was just not blown away by the service.  Also young girls doing drugs in the bathroom, hogging the stall, and then crying when they dropped said drugs?...not super classy.

O M G .. wow I loved this place !!! I'd give  10 stars if I could.. my favorite thing was the lima beans (I call them butter beans ) but they call them lima anyway they taste like they are made with LOVE.. lol we also had the best BANANA PUDDING EVER it's served warm with this delightful meringue topping.. I literally licked the bowl.. lol. This place is a MUST go... 
OMG THE CRAWFISH PIE changed my life.. lol please please please eat it..  I could go on and on..but if your reading this you're probably on your way now.. enjoy . Omg wait the ROLLS .. don't forget the perfect little yeast rolls.. omg now I  want to go back. Lol

First of all, they served the best bread - warm, buttery and just simply delicious. Besides that, we ordered oysters, fried alligators and the signature Louisiana cochon with cabbage. All of them were super delightful. The only meh dish we had was the grilled shrimp with chowchow. But overall it was a great experience. We really enjoyed the open space and great natural lighting.
Cheese masoroni is a little salty but still good. Fried alligator tastes like chicken. Rabbit and dumpling tastes OK, beef is not bad but potato salad is sour, a little strange.

Ugh...  I had such great expectations and was so disappointed.  Two drinks ordered as we arrived, one came before the meal one after.  Food arrived.  It was good, but not spectacular.  We were going to oder a second side, but nobody ever came to check on us.

Would you like some pig with your pork? How about a side of pork ribs with your ham hock entree. Well Cochon will make that happen. The name says it all! What can I say about Cochon that hasn't already been said. The smoked pork ribs were out of bounds. Sinfully good. The level of crispy smoke they get on these ribs is off the charts. My fingers legitimately smelled smokey the morning after. Like someone's scent who you slept with the night before. Before I get more inappropriate, just take my word for it and go here.

SIIIIIIIIIIGH! This place is hard to rate. I wouldn't take anything from anyone that gives Cochon a 5-star rating, and I wouldn't hate on anyone that gave it a 1- or 2-star rating. It was very ok, which not a bad thing. It was just VERY VERY ok. 

The ambiance is great...very chic and sexy. The service was pretty good. I always appreciate when the servers are around, but not all in my grill. The whiskey, cocktail, and beer lists are great. Even the menu options were pretty solid and well rounded. I'm just so conflicted over the taste of everything.

My sister ordered oysters as an appetizer and catfish and rice as her entree. I ordered smoked brisket and horseradish potato salad and the macaroni side. I didn't want to eat both the potato salad and the mac n cheese, but all the reviews said the mac and cheese was legit, so I ordered that too. The oysters came out, and I will concur with EVERYONE that said they were amazing. They really were great. Our entrees came out shortly after we finished the oysters. I was initially pleasantly surprised by how soft the brisket was when I went to cut it up. HOWEVER...I soon realized that there was a lot of fat in the brisket. I know...I know. Fat?! On brisket?!?! No sh*t! I eat A LOT of brisket, so I know the routine...I know the deal. This was an inordinate amount of fatty brisket, but like the fat kid that I am, I ate it all anyway. I was starving.  (My sister and I drove from Atlanta today and i'd only eaten a breakfast sandwich at Dunkin Donuts and some Haribo gummy bears all day!). The horseradish potato salad was really good though! Next up was my mac and cheese, and it was ok. VERY VERY ok. Even though i was full after eating my fat boy brisket, if the mac and cheese had been great, I would've eaten every bite of it. I had about 5 bites and then threw in the towel. My sister let me taste a bit of her catfish and it wasn't bad. It was slightly above VERY ok, but slightly below good. I could taste the salt in it, which isn't difficult for me since I rarely cook with salt or eat salty foods, but I think it was what an average would consider the right amount of salt. 

Anyway...I'd actually come back. In fact, this place deserves several chances, and I'd be inclined to update my review once I do come back. However, for now I'll have to give it a 3-star rating.

This wasn't a authentic cajun experience, but the food and service was great. The wood fire grilled oysters are a must, if you like oysters. I absolutely loved them. My husband had the catfish and really enjoyed it. We ended our meal with a pineapple upside down cake, and I must say, its the best one I've ever had.

While in New Orleans, one place we knew we wanted to dine was either Cochon or Cochon Butcher. We ended up going with Cochon for a slightly more classy meal. We arrived for our reservation and were seated within minutes with a lovely server. 

After looking over the menu, we agreed most of the starters and sides sounded better to us than any of the mains so we settled on a smorgasbord of smaller dishes paired with some local brews. Cochon had 8 local beers on tap ranging from $7-9 per pint. I had the Strawberry Canebrake from Parish Brewing which was a fabulous Louisiana beer with generous hits of strawberry - solid fruity beer for the hot NOLA weather and very sessionable at 5%.

We had the:
Wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter $14 - I'm allergic to shellfish but my dining partner said this was bomb!
Pork cheek country captain with raisins, turnips & almonds $12 - Such a pretty dish but tasty to boot! The combination of all the ingredients gave it such good balance between flavors and textures.
Macaroni & cheese casserole $7 - Creamy, southern style mac & cheese that came in a generous portion.
Smothered greens $7 - Neither of us loved this dish and I would definitely skip it on my next go around at Cochon.
Fried boudin with pickled peppers $9 - Deep fried goodness filled with everything nice! A slight kick to them but in a very good way.

Overall, we had a pleasant experience though it didn't knock my socks off. Solid food & beer, excellent service and very accommodating to us. Not that it has any bearing on my review, but we mentioned we had a birthday and nada. Despite everything being good, I think I'm good on Cochon because it was just plain ol' good - not great. However, I absolutely want to try Cochon Butcher next time I'm down in New Orleans.

SLAP! YO! MAMA! GOOD!

     I recently had the privilege to travel through NOLA for about a week. The prime reason for the destination outside of Jazz Fest was food. We had reservations booked at all the big ones (Commanders Palace, Brennans for brunch, Irenes, Mr. B's) among others. The food was amazing everywhere, but my wife and I discussed our favorite places the other day, and mine was without a doubt cochon. 
     For starters, the smell of the building alone is BBQ heaven. It smells like oak wood, smoke and meat. Ahhhhh just thinking about the smell now is putting me on cloud 9. As a group, we started off with the crawfish pie, wood-fired oysters, cucumbers and herbs in vinegar and the mac and cheese. My personal favorite was the oysters. I don't know if I've had tastier grilled oysters anywhere... and damn I do love me some oysters. The crawfish pie was also amazing and unlike anything I've ever had. We order 2 for a table of 6 and we could have easily ordered 2 more. The cucumbers and herbs were simple and refreshing. The mac and cheese was lethal. I urge you not to order and eat it before your main course or you may find yourself full and unable to eat more. I didn't have that problem but some of party did. It is damn good. Creamy cheesy heaven. 
     I went with the pork cheeks for my main course. It was simple and rustic but incredibly complex at the same time. The flavors were amazing and the pork cheek melted in your mouth. The rest of our table tried the rabbit and dumplings, 3 order of cochon with cabbage and one order of the brisket. We were all incredibly satisfied. We are a loud group and aside from silverware scraping plates and peoples lips smacking there wasn't a lot of other noise or talking. The Food was amazing and the atmosphere only added to it. I enjoyed all of the food in NOLA, but Cochon, ya'll stole my heart!

#flavortrain approved and 2 hands on the belly

Wonderful menu! Have the mac and cheese. It's absolutely amazing! Seriously, some of the best I've ever had. I had the ribs, and they were tasty, yet very spicey! All around awesome experience. Great service too!

If I'm going to eat at just one restaurant during future travels to New Orleans, it's going to be Cochon! Every part of our experience was truly worthy of five stars.

We arrived on a Thursday night without reservations and found that the wait would be about 45 minutes, but the hostesses were extremely kind to fit us in and recommended we go to Butcher (still part of Cochon but more casual, two doors down from the restaurant) for small bites and drinks while we waited. It was a great suggestion that we followed before returning when we received a text that we could be seated. 

The ambiance of the restaurant is warm and modern. It's a welcome change from the busyness of the town. The menu is small but  works in their favor, because the food was unforgettable! We tried several thing from the menu, but our favorites were the grilled oysters (so good we got two plates), the pork cheek (so tender and flavorful), the mac and cheese (rich and creamy), the red fish (huge portion), and the collard greens (perfectly cooked). Our waitress Colleen was especially helpful to our group and made sure our experience was superb. 

One of the best parts of traveling to New Orleans is the incredible food, and Cochon exceeded my expectations. We will be returning!
This is one of my top ten restaurants that i wanted to try.It defined did not disappoint.the food was delicious and servers where very helpful.

Went here on a dinner "date" with my two year old son and we had a first class meal. The service was attentive and helpful with the menu, which had a lot of local cuisine options, both elevated/innovative and just quality takes of traditional dishes. We had the gumbo, the rabbit and dumplings, and the pineapple cake. All wonderful. The bill without tax or tip was $46 with beverage and that seemed very reasonable given the environment, service, and excellence of the food. They were accommodating of my son,  who shared the meal with me adding a little rice rice from the kitchen. Love. Ice restaurants that don't mind kids! Our visit was after a trip to one of the museums (the Ogden, by the WWII museum) and it was a perfect way to spent a few hours in town on a very rainy day.
The actual restaurant and the butcher shop have incredible food. A true NOLA gem in the warehouse district!

We came to this place by accident - we noticed after we ordered our food. But I am so happy I stayed. The food was delicious. The chili oysters were incredible. This was our first spot to eat at when arriving to NOLA. 
the prices were a bit high for the portion of the dish. not sure if it's normal NOLA prices or not. 
Anyway - good place even if we came across it by mistake. 
I would def. go back to get some of those amazing oysters!

Upon entering we were approached by the hostess and what looked to be a manager or waitress and asked with evident contempt "Are you sure you want to eat here? Perhaps the bakery around the corner?" We had a large party of 13 and I'm sure after the sweltering head we were a bit ragged but this was beyond embarrassing. The disdain was dripping from her mouth! We left .... there's a good BBQ place across the street. They were happy to take lots of our money. The food was good too!
I really love this restaurant! It's nice and airy and the atmosphere is great! I had the twice smoked ham hock today. It was amazing. You can't go wrong with this place. Never had a bad meal here.

Still my favorite restaurant I've been to in New Orleans. The drinks, apps, entrees, and desserts were all great. I had The Hurricane cocktail which was fantastic. The ribs, grilled shrimp, crawfish pie, and wood fired oysters were our favorite appetizers. I ordered the rabbit and dumplings entree which was delicious. I tried the cochon and the ham hock which were also great. I was pretty trashed by the time dessert rolled around so take this with a grain of salt but they were quite tasty. Can't wait to come back next time

The flavors of Cochon completely crushed by the small portions, high prices and braggadocios staff.  This was late lunch and my companion and I were hungry.  This was not my first experience at Cochon.  I already knew the food was delicious and practically everything is made by hand.   But this time I was hit with a huge lunch bill - 1 appetizer, two plates and dessert = $100+ dollars and two people who left hungry.  We should have not had to go out to dinner that night.... that late lunch should have lasted and we only required a few tapas to get us through.  Not this time.  We left Cochon hungry.  That's why we had dessert at Lunch because the portions for our meat plate and signature dish were small.  The crackling in my plate was soggy, but the desserts we fantastic - my pineapple upside-down cake was great, but again not large enough to fill my tummy.  The appetizer was $15 for 5 char-grilled oysters in garlic and chilli oil.  Only two of the oysters were decent size, the rest were tiny.  We only drank water, no booze.

We're not fat, grotesque, nor are we gluttons.  We expect to eat a meal and leave satisfied.  
My companion and I did not feel that way after our departure.

Staff was nice but constantly walking around to empty plates saying "that must have been so good, that plate is clean."  The plate was clean because there was hardly enough on it to start to fill us up.  And we later started looking around at tables who got bread before the meal and realized we never got bread or anything for the table before our meal. Staff left no room for criticism.  Multiple waiters bragged about the food to us and left no room for us to say "we're still hungry."  

For the fine flavors, I'm willing to give this place another chance.  For the tiny portions on main course meals (not just "small plates") - shame on you.  I'll wait for someone else to offer to pay for the next meal and try again.

Went for dinner on a Saturday night. Very large and busy restaurant. 

Overall service. Below average; waiter had to be reminded 3 times before delivering a bottle of water and all in all felt rushy and not very interested in helping. Transactional. 

Food. Oysters, some were shuck incorrectly. The shell parts were in my mouth. Unpleasant. Tomato salad. Confusing to palat. Sloppy in its plating. Weak in its balance of the ingredients. Ham hock. Was supposed to be the star. Found it to be average close to overcooked and dry.

Would not repeat.

My wife & I came to Cochon on our first night visiting New Orleans. It was such a good experience we returned for our last night as well. 

We arrived on a Saturday night, we couldn't get a table so instead we sat at the bar. Our bartenders were excellent, the cocktails were amazingly strong and delicious, and the food was insanely good. We had a little bit of everything: oysters, fried alligator, Mac and cheese, and their bbq ribs. 

Our second night was on a Tuesday, we were seated right away and we were able to enjoy the restaurant at a slower pace. The food was once again excellent, we had their pot roast special along with more oysters and alligator, we also tried their gumbo and I enjoyed a whiskey flight. Service was once again excellent. 

I couldn't have a stronger recommendation for this restaurant, please do yourself the favor and check it out if you're in the area.

Wood fired oysters are really good! The 2 best things ...heirloom tomatoes with buttermilk and crab vinaigrette and the Louisiana cochon with cabbage and cracklins and pickled peaches ... we had two orders of each :) awesome place and really great service!!
Funky & hip! Excellent food & service! Ordered the Cochon dish & beet soup & loved both!
One of my friends that was originally with me on the first visit recently went back to NOLA... and he went to Cochon EVERY night for dinner! ...yes, it's that good... :D

One of my favorite places when I'm dining with others. Last stop served up a great bowl of gumbo, a fantastic  Boucherie charcuterie plate, Louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklins & pickled peaches,grilled shrimp with chow-chow , mac & cheese and collard greens., No room for dessert, but thankfully Cochon The Butcher next door had plenty of bacon pralines to take home.

I'm so happy that we were highly recommended to come here, this restaurant was the best meal of the entire trip!!! We came straight from the airport and accommodated us even though we were a few minutes late for our reservation. The food was sooooo delicious, you must try the oysters, alligator bites, ribs and don't you dare leave there without having their grits! I don't even like grits but our server promised they would be the best I've ever had and she was right! The drinks were on point as well, the rosé and hurricane was great! If you live here and haven't been to Cochon, go there right now. If you are coming here on a trip, make your reservation now!!

We got the following:

1. Oysters- amazing; dip the bread in the sauce 
2. Craw fish pie- empanada filled with lots of craw fish; awesome 
3. Rabbit dumplings- essentially a pot pie; heaven of deliciousness
4. Cochon- it was kind of dry and not that exciting 

Great dinner!!
A great variety of menu items.  We had two varieties of the cochon,  both delicious.  Great service and good food.  We'll be back to try something else while we're here.

Went here a few weeks ago with my husband and kids while I was in NOLA for a conference. Food was some of the best we've ever had in our many visits to the city. We had the fried alligator, fried oyster sandwich (big enough for two people), catfish courtboullion (AMAZING), grits, mac' n' cheese, and spicy peanut butter chocolate pudding. Everything was good, even my kids were happy and that's saying something because they are picky eaters. Prices were a little on the high side, but it was worth it. We will be back next time we go to NOLA.

Yes! Yes!  This place is delicious!  So much good food to enjoy...

Started with the fried boudin balls.  They were excellent.

We then had The Cochon with Peaches and the ribs with pickled watermelon.  Added a side of mac n cheese, some delicious drinks from the amazing bar staff and ended with the pineapple upside down cake dessert.  All were amazing!  I kept trying to take pictures but it all was too delicious to wait!

Seriously check this place out for a great meal and outstanding service.

Hands-down the best mac & cheese I've ever had. And I've had some really good mac & cheese. I also got these wonderful little rice and sausage balls that are deep-fried and served with a really great grainy mustard sauce with pickled peppers. And they're soft bread rolls are to die for. No wonder this place ever has over 2000 ratings and is packed to the door. I got lucky and was able to get a A seat at the chefs counter. It's like dinner and a show. I watch another Siri food come out and I'm getting to watch them make it

Wow - I was with a group of 9 women and we literally ordered the menu - hands down everything was great! Oysters, cochon, brisket, brisket chili, allllll the sides, seriously have never been so satisfied, full and amazed!

We just had a wonderful meal at Cochon. Ribs and fried gator to start, everything was delicious and the watermelon pickle that came with the ribs was exceptionally tasty and crunchy. As main my husband had the rabbit and I selected the catfish courtbouillon. My fish was cooked to perfection and the dish was delicate and tasty. He loved the tender rabbit, the buttery, light and delicious dumplings, and the perfectly cooked vegetables. We managed to save some space for dessert: bread pudding ice cream for me, and blueberry trifle for him, both lovely. We will be back!

Please go! I don't really pork but I ventured in here with my coworkers during a work conference and literally everything we ordered was phenomenal. We had the chicken and andouille Mac and cheese and I have to say it's the BEST macaroni and cheese I've had. My coworker ordered a side for her after she tasted mine. I also had the chicken and andouille gumbo, we ordered the ribs, the collard greens , fried alligator and the Boudin starter . Amazing!!!!

Very friendly staff took good care of us. All of the food was great, with my coworker saying that the mac and cheese was the best he had ever had. Very clean and modern interior in a very old part of town.

Food ok to decent, ridiculous policy of no separate checks prevents any recommendation for a group larger than 2.

It's the 21st Century and they won't do what was available since the adding machine 3as invented.

Had the pleasure of eating at Cochon last week and it was absolutely delicious. We ordered the fried livers with pepper jelly & toast, smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickle, macaroni & cheese casserole, smothered greens, and smoked beef brisket with horseradish potato salad. The mac & cheese is a must - do not miss out on this bowl of heaven. The smoked pork ribs were mouthwatering. The service was attentive and friendly. I would definitely recommend anyone looking for a memorable meal to stop in and try a meal at Cochon.

Great lunch spot.  We were torn between the restaurant and the sandwich shoppe, selected the restaurant and was quite satisfied.  Hubby had the oyster sandwich and a side of popcorn alligator; I had the mac-n-cheese.   The popcorn alligator was just average; not much in the way of creative seasonings.  The texture was good, the coating was light and crisp and the drizzled sauce is what gave it a nice kick of flavor.  It was good enough to eat it all, but nothing to write home about.  The fried oyster and bacon sandwich was extremely delicious.  The sourdough bread was fresh and grilled to crunchy perfection.  The sandwich was filled with lightly fried oysters, bacon, lettuce, tomato and other goodness, including  a nice, tangy aioli sauce.  Unique, awesome BLOT (bacon, lettuce, oyster, tomato)!!  I opted for the mac-n-cheese, because it was raining outside and the mac-n-cheese photos looked so comforting...and it was indeed comforting, with a modern twist.  Tasted like a good amount of roasted garlic included in the bechamel sauce, along with a touch of cayenne and baked to a succulent internal creamy consistency, and browned on top to give a slight crunch. 
This is one of those places where there are so many uniquely prepared dishes that you want to return several times to try different things.  Another NOLA must...AND it is located in my favorite area of NOLA - the warehouse district...an all around win!!

Went to this place twice. The food is not bad but the service sucks. The first time I went I wanted to order something to go, they told me they do not have that option including that they do not have to-go boxes. I then asked if I have food left over where would I put it to rake with me. They then told me to go and order at the bar, eat one bite then get a to go box. I had the cheeks which was not too bad. The second time I went back as my wife wanted to try the food based on the reviews. They asked if we had a reservation, we did not, they told us the wait was 30 minutes. At almost 30 min we were seated at the back, we saw approximately 15 tables available along with an upstairs totally unoccupied. I guess they were trying to create a waiting line for people passing by. Our server was rude and inattentive. She failed or made it seem too difficult to explain the items on the menu when asked. The ham hook was not bad but was dry. The mac & cheese was good. My wife indicated the shrimp was a 3 out of 5. Not sure if I will return due to their poor service.
This was my second time eating here so amazing we sat at the chefs table amazing conversation amazing samplings best staff they could ask for 100% going again!!!
I had the brisket and the horseradish potato salad .. good meal but it wasn't anything to be excited about. The setup is cool and my waiter was great. Just #Blah

OMG. I don't even no where to start. Great atmosphere. Clean and friendly. Every description on the menu is better than the next. Went with my coworkers and we ordered a little bit of this and that. Fried gator - yum, pork ribs nice, greens, rolls, you name it. BUT the mac and cheese. Ahhhh!!!  Ordered another helping. We raved about the food all night!!   I'll be back!

The food was very good. My husband had the oysters for an appetizer. I had the ham shank, he had the rabbit dumplings and we shared the macaroni and cheese casserole. The ham shank was just okay. I wasn't crazy about the bed of cold quinoa that it sat on. I like quinoa but would have preferred something a little warmer and heartier. The mac and cheese was delicious. My husband likes his dumplings but didn't rave about them. We also had three different servers throughout our meal, which seemed odd. Non were particularly enthusiastic or attentive. We were envious of the treatment received by a couple next to us. They had one waiter who was friendly and helpful. Oh well. We did wish we had gone to Cochon Butcher next door instead.

It's been three years since eating here and I still think of the creamy grits and fried alligator. The grits don't even have cheese in them. I have no idea how they're so creamy. The best I've ever had. Excited to go back.

First, I think this is a very clean place. But I should have left after I saw the young lady at the table next to me pop-up and jook a cockroach off her leg. Cockroach #2 tried to tell me that this wasn't the experience I wanted to have. And I think we got on our waiter's nerves by asking him for straws and what chow chow was. Confirming my restaurant choice remorse is the fact that our food was just o-k.   Gumbo was okay. The grilled shrimp with chow chow was tasty. The mac & cheese was a good side for the shrimp. The catfish courtbouillion(?) was okay. Le sigh. I should have had a V-8.
This place was a find in New Orleans. Staff is really cool and the food was out of this world. Love the spice and all the different flavors. Definitely recommend!

We went while in town for a conference, on our first night, on the advice of a local. We decided to share small plates and everything we got was very good. Oysters, alligator, chicken livers. But what impressed us the most was their version of the Hurricane, and we didn't know it until the end of the week when we had tried Hurricanes at 4 other places including the one who claims to have invented it, and they were all "meh" but we were still talking about how good the one at Cochon was, probably because it did not taste anything like an actual Hurricane

Upscale comfort food concept. It mostly works, as the food really is quite good, but it isn't white tablecloth fare. There's almost nothing I dislike here, but nor is there anything that doesn't underwhelm, either. Much of what is on the menu is best made at home and hardly done better here (stews). There are much better options than this if you're visiting New Orleans.

Love love love!

Amazing restaurant, fun staff, awesome food, great drinks....can't go wrong here. 

We had a small group of 6 and were seated right away with a reservation...that's the key! Make a reservation. 

Our servers were super fun and laid back. They gave us a great recommendations and were fun to chat with though the night. 

For apps, I would go with the roasted oysters and alligator. These were awesome and perfectly cooked. 

For main course, you can't go wrong with the namesake Cochon. The pork is super tender and juicy. Loved this. 

Finally, their hummingbird cake and sorbets were to die for. 

Overall, I would highly recommend making a stop here for your NOLA dining fix.

Nice, chic ambience.  The cochon was cold and dry. The rabbit was flavorful and tender, but sauce lacked any memorable flavor.  Surprisingly, the food came out three minutes after we ordered; however, the table next to us ordered 10 minutes before we did and their rabbit came out 10 minutes after ours.  We did not get bread and butter until we were almost done with our entrées, meanwhile other tables got it when supposed to. The bread, however, was flaky and flavorful. We went on July 4th, so perhaps the better staff had the day off.

Cochon came highly recommended by my fellow Yelp friends. We stopped here on our first night in New Orleans as it was walking distance from our hotel room. I love the location in the Industrial/Warehouse/Arts District with all the old-world New Orleans charm and character. There are many wonderful museums in the area too, including the WWII Museum. 

Heading up the kitchen is the highly decorated chef, Donald Link, who brings Cajun comforts and house-cured artisan pork and meats to the denizens and visitors of New Orleans. While the menu is pork-focused there is a nice selection of salads, fish, shrimp and oysters to feast upon. 

I had my first foray into fried alligator here at Cochon. As the saying goes, the alligator to me "tasted just like chicken," except it was quite a bit chewier. I must say it was much better than I anticipated and fun to experience but it wasn't something I would need to order again. The chili garlic mayonnaise helped moisten the meat and lend a nice fiery flavor. 

The Louisiana Cochon (French for pig) dish was really something else. This one was a real crowd pleaser. The flavors complement each other perfectly. The meat is so fall-apart tender and the addition of the turnips, cabbage, cracklins and pickled peach just made the pork all that more enticing. The cochon was one of the standout dishes on my trip...the ultimate comfort food! 

We didn't like the Shrimp & Eggplant Dressing. We thought this one would be a showstopper because my dining partner loves eggplant, shrimp and dressing. It was really mushy and lackluster and didn't excite either of us. I focused on the Macaroni 'n Cheese Casserole which was ultra rich withl the right mix of cheese, cream and butter. Normally I would finish all the mac but there was so much food I didn't stand a chance, plus I wanted to make it to my first day of training the next day lol. 

We definitely had a great time at Cochon. This is the perfect place to nosh and drink authentic tantilzing New Orleans food in a lively rustic setting. Head next door to Cochon's spinoff, Cochon Butcher, for a hearty handcrafted sandwich, cheese plate, deli meats and some wine or beer.

Cochon is a cute, trendy little corner bistro whose menu drew us in right away,  I decided right then that we would return for lunch. On return we were excited about being sat right away,  less exciting was the hipster waiter who was clearly less than amused to wait on us.  He tried on friendly for size while answering our menu questions but realized it just didn't fit when we asked if he could bring bread to the table..... smug would be putting it mildly. 

We shrugged it off, it was a busy weekend so.... whatever!  Drinks always lighten the mood and ours were damn tasty, our  waiter sucks but the 'porch swings' were a hit! We placed our order with little help from the hipster but again... the drinks ... 

So, when I felt wings a fluttering under the table and jumped from my seat with Holy Ghost gusto.......there was a huge Cockroach beating a hasty retreat;  our waiters' , hell, the entire establishments nonplussed reaction was disheartening and ... honestly,  suspect! 

Suspect because no one moved, no one responded, no one  reacted;  I was seated at a table so close to the food prep station that to miss the commotion would be a dereliction of duty of both the front and back of the house.  

My waiter, in the immediate moments following my ankles molestation by the hissing cockroach, DID NOTHING!! He scampered away as quickly as his freeloading friend la CockaRoacha.  

At no point did our waiter offer up empathy nor sympathy for what was happening to a guest at their establishment. I sat there for several seconds expecting a member of management to provide me with the usual song and dance that comes subsequent to episodes of horror in business such as this.  My background in corporate salon management taught me to perform that song and dance with Motown efficiency...this team could use some Berry Gordy training because they dropped the Mic on this ... big time.. and not in a good way!

Unfortunately an apology never escaped the lips of my waiter... WHY? Are roaches such a regular occurrence in this place that they don't register a reaction or was I a deplorable... as an African-American female.... the wrong demographic??


It took an eternity for management to acknowledge the incident even as they witnessed it happening and immediately removed the traveler's carcass from the dining room floor.  

When the 'official' apology finally did come, it came in the form of 'I've been here for three years and this has never happened before' not 'I'm sorry this happened to you, what can we do?' Sadly, as a consolation prize, the manager offered up the food we'd ordered to take home since it was in the window waiting.... well what the hell else could they do with it? Smh, I declined that offer... too little too late;   I believe there was a second roach citing while I was using the facilities.  Thanks, but no thanks!

Listen, shit like this happens in businesses all the time;  it's not the offense that rankles ....mostly, it's the lack of acknowledgment and reconciliation.  A simple human exchange, not gratuitous,  but a display of genuine humility that demonstrates a remorse for your experience and restores the trust that makes me, the patron, feel good about spending my two very limited resources in your business; TIME & MONEY!!!

Cochon may have been voted the Best in New Orleans but the way they made me feel was the worst part of my trip! 
#EssenceFest #NolaFood #pighouse #warehousedistrict #gardendistrict #butchershop 

;

The was our second visit, and this time we brought friends along. Everyone loved the food and drinks. My only complaint, and not worth deducting a star was the pushy waiter. He suggested that we get 6 or 7 appetizers for a party of 6 and to order 6 entrees. Their appetizers were big enough to share. We left stuffed.

This is a nice fine dining experience if you are in the area near the WWII museum. It's very trendy and has more of a modern, fusion vibe than your authentic creole or cajun feel. I recall having a rabbit dish that was tasty and the cocktails were complex and flavorful. It is quite pricy  and an outlier compared to other places in the area. Definitely worth the visit if you want a more modern vibe.

The meat is very good, but I do wish there were more vegetables to compliment the meals! The limited veggies they did have, they were out of. Obviously the people want more veggies! You usually need reservations to come here because they get quite busy. The atmosphere is very sophisticated. We were given three different waiters during our time here (and we weren't even there an hour) so that was pretty odd. The presentation of the food was stunningly beautiful.
I would definitely recommend Couchon. They have consistently delicious food with great service. The ribs were fantastic. I have never been disappointed.
Delicious!!! We had the redfish fisherman's style, crawfish pie, boudin balls, BBQ shrimp, mac & cheese casserole, and twice baked potato.  All was amazing!!

My hubby and I enjoyed our dinner and cocktails here.  Great flavors and textures.  I highly recommend making reservations.  Although the ambience was a little hipster, which was cool, the seating was too close for my liking.

5-stars all around, y'all! I can't believe I've lived in Nola since 2009 and haven't dined at this Food Network feature--but better late than never! 

We were meeting some friends and their out-of-town guests on Monday night after a big weekend (Essence Fest/4th of July) and didn't have reservations. I was nervous that our party of 6 may not get a table but it was no problem for the host. In fact, she was wiling to seat us without our entire party present but my hubby and I opted to sit at the bar until the rest of our party joined us. I had a delicious glass of rose and he had the Porch Swing which he enjoyed. 

Once our party arrived, we were greeted by our server Jacob, who politely took our drink orders and gave us the rundown of the specials. He helped with drink choices and immediately let us know what the house was out of (no prob for us).  We started off with the oysters which were divine. As a not-a-huge-oyster fan, I highly endorse these! Also, please please please ask for the bread basket--it is filled with heavenly pillows of buttery goodness. Seriously, the rolls kicked my keto diet's ass! 

Jacob kept the drinks flowing and we ended up ordering a couple of bowls of gumbo, another order of the oysters, the crawfish pie, the mac-and-cheese, and the ribs. Y'all, everything was ahhh-mazinggggg! The gumbo (which is how we actually ended up here..if you google Gumbo, Cochon nails the ranked list!) features a thick roux; I can't recall if it was seafood or sausage gumbo but it definitely was a hit with everyone. The $13 (!) crawfish pie was jumbo sized with a flaky crust and abundantly filled crawfish which totally made it worth the price. Mac and cheese was definitely more of a "a little mac with all the cheese" not that we were opposed to at all, very rich and delicious! I didn't try the ribs but there weren't any left overs so I suspect they were delicious. We finished off with the peach dessert--can't quite recall the name of it as (I was 3 glasses in at this point!). 

Our bill came out to about $50/person but we all felt the food and ambiance was totally worth it. Jacob's service was casual and consistent with the ambiance of the restaurant which I'd describe as casual but the food is definitely gourmet. No suit jackets or LBDs required here, just your appetite and good company to make for a pleasurable experience!

Fried Alligator
Fried Boudin Balls
Chicken & Andouille Gumbo
Pork Ribs and Watermelon Pickle
Louisiana Cochon
Mac & Cheese
Pineapple Upside Cake
Chocolate Pudding
Porch Swing (Cocktail)

5 of us ordered SO MUCH FOOD and shared it all so we could try everything. This place did NOT disappoint! Every single thing we got was AMAZING. Friendly staff, cool vibe, AMAZING NOMS!  Definitely worth a visit while you're in town (or 2... or 3...)

First time here, sat at the food bar and watched chef Kyle and his crew work there magic! Strawberry Cream Ale was excellent as my drink of choice. Wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter, chicken & andouille gumbo, and the crawfish pie were my appetizers and/or meal.  Excellent, excellent, excellent!  Sitting up by the kitchen adds to the experience for sure and is recommended!

I gave 4 stars for the service and the attempt at good food. This place is overpriced and the food is good but not great. The service is amazing tho. Unfortunately good service isn't enough for me to come back here.

A relative recommended me to eat at Cochon during my visit in NOLA. She said it was a MUST-TRY, and she was right. The food was amazing! For two, we shared: 

Fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise
Louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklins & pickled peaches 
Rabbit & dumplings
Macaroni & cheese casserole

I have nothing bad to say about the food. The meats were tender and the flavors were bursting. Cochon was a great getaway from the busy French Quarter touristy restaurants. However, it does get busy here too. Just to be safe, make a reservation for dinners. Ask a waiter to see the huge smoker--some times the chefs will be glad to show you how they cook their meats! 

I will definitely come back here when I find myself in NOLA again.
Good Food. Aligator appetizer and cochon were delicious. Austin and Ashley were terrific. Just a bit pricey for the amount of food, but not surprisingly.

Cochon was a recommendation that my food journalism teacher gave to me when I told him about my weekend trip to New Orleans, and turned out to be the best meal I had in the city. We wanted to make sure to get in the restaurant, so we were careful and made reservations ahead of time. 

This restaurant has a beautiful interior. Great wooden tables and booths make it a good atmosphere for younger people. 
The staff is super friendly and helpful, making it a more positive experience.

My group of 4 ended up sharing small plates. Most things that we tried were small, but packed with good flavor. 

Food:
Wood-fired oysters - Amazing, as most oysters are in New Orleans. I liked them a bit more than the chargrilled ones at ACME because they weren't as heavy or buttered. More of a smoky flavor and you get to mop up the extra sauce with some bread. 

Fried Alligator - Delicious bites of fried goodness with the chili garlic mayo sauce.

Boucherie Plate - Pretty different. Having had charcuterie plates here and there, this was pretty unique from many I've had before. The smoked meats were amazing, even some of the ones you have to spread. I really liked the mustard too and the little crisps were great. A good platter to share with a group. 

Mixed green salad - Basic salad with greens, not too big. 

Mac & cheese - Damn good mac and cheese. 

Gumbo - Would pass on this. I think it had a twist from the usual bowl of gumbo, and I wasn't really a fan of it. Very smoky in an interesting way. 

Though we only shared small plates, this place lived up to the hype that my professor was telling me about. Definitely make a reservation for the night time. Next time I am in New Orleans, I would definitely come again.

Everything was amazing including our server, Terry. Please do yourself a favor and ask for him. He is very knowledgeable, friendly, and happy to steer you in the right direction. He's also very knowledgeable about the wine menu and happy to suggest a pairing.

Cochon is one of those restaurants that has something for everything and your eyes end up being bigger than your stomach. We arrived on Sunday morning around 11:30 AM with a group of 7 and were immediately seated. Our orders included: several orders of gumbo, the rabbit and dumplings, a few orders of the mac and cheese casserole, a twice baked potato and a few orders of the poached egg (a take on eggs Benedict). It was all delicious and cooked perfectly, plus they're the perfect portion sizes. Our waiters were so great - no sweet tea or water ever went empty. 

Tip: They can't split checks for large groups so be prepared.

Fantastic food. I was so glad I went here. It was great NOLA food. I was on a business trip and sat at the bar by myself and the bartender was kind and attentive. I had a glass of wine and Louisiana Cochon with cabbage. Yum it was sinfully delicious. It is a nice causal place that was busy when I arrived. There was a bit of a wait but the bar was not crowded at all. GO HERE!
Food and service were SUPERB! Wish I had enough room to eat everything on the menu at once!

This place is awesome! Definitely take some time to visit while in Nola! The local cuisine was unbelievable, if you make it here, please do your self a favor and try the Cochon, it's spectacular! Also, if you love oysters like I do, treat yourself to the oysters at Cochon! the sauce accentuates the oysters so well you'll have to tell everyone you know  about it. I'm already planning my next visit...
Amazing food, drinks and service. We couldn't be happier with our decision to go to Cochon for dinner.

This is one of the best restaurant that We tried while visiting New Orleans. It has a unique menu combination, a warming atmosphere, and knowledgeable service. It's a bit pricey and everything is a la carte, but it is well worth it. Will definitely go again.

First time here, the dry rubbed ham hock with quinoa, herbs, and goat yogurt was a sure fire win! This was actually my most favorite meal of the week if not longer. The dry rub was thick & crispy on the outside, the meatjuicy and tender on the inside. The bone pulled right out clean. The seasoning and salt on the ham hock was complemented excellently by the sweet yogurt mixed in with the quinoa and cherry tomatoes that it sat on top of it. The waitress was more than knowledgeable and able to answer any question without hesitation however for being such a slow Saturday the service was in somewhat of a disarray. We had to ask twice for a missing a place setting and our order didn't come out all together, so we had to ask where the missing entree was as well.

I can't understand the five star reviews. If you want portion controlled food at top dollar this is the place for you. While the flavor was good, $28 for four thin slices of brisket in the south is high. The horseradish potato salad might go well as a lunch side, but completely overpowers the brisket. Service was friendly and attentive, and they will emphasize everything is a small dish, even the entrees. This type of eatery has been done well and with class in places like Chicago, but it's not New Orleans. I can't imagine locals eating here.
Loud, crowded, with slow service. Perhaps I am a picky eater but I was not fan the food, tho the wine list was on point. Perhaps I will try again during a less crowded time.

I can't say enough about Cochon. It truly was one of our favorite restaurant for late afternoon dinner and this review will not do justice to the amazing food at this restaurant. Service was excellent, good bourbon selection. We ordered the old fashioned, strange situation, and hurricane ophelia. 

We started with the wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter, fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise, and fried boudin with pickled peppers. We loved every bite. The oysters were out of this world. I could have dined on just them all night and been blissfully happy.

I loved every bite of food at Cochon, the service was top notch, the atmosphere was comfortable. We will definitely be back next time we are in New Orleans.

Being pescatarian I was very hesitant to eat here. All they have is pork what could I possibly eat?! Our server was so helpful and had so many great suggestions. The chef made me a vegetarian plate which was incredible! Our seafood appetizers were delicious as well! I can't wait to come back!!

Parking costs money - the food is pretty expensive compared to the amount it gave us. It's a very nice restaurant to celebrate (adult) birthday or anniversaries. Not a place to bring little kids. Overall the waiters/waitresses were very kind and friendly!

Some fun different Cajun food. My husband got the cochon which is their specialty dish and my black drum was absolutely fabulous. The eggplant shrimp casserole was very pepper heavy but that was my only complaint. We will be back.

Fantastic! The service was wonderful and they have very friendly staff. I had the heirloom tomatoes with buttermilk and crab vinaigrette, and the pork cheek with corn, fresh chilies, tomatoes, and dill vinaigrette. Delicious and a short walk from the WW II museum.

Been wanting to eat at Cochon for several years since seeing it on a show. Went this weekend and it was excellent. The atmosphere was fun and the people were really friendly. The food was great really comfortable dishes with a little different ingredients to help you explore flavors. We had the amazing oysters, pork cheeks, chicken liver toast, and ribs all were on point! I am looking forward to trying cochon again!

Ok... this is seriously the BEST restaurant and dining experience I have EVER had... that means a lot coming from someone who is constantly trying new restaurants, haha. 

Nothing I say will do this place justice, but I will try my best! 

Location:
Cochon is located in the Warehouse District so it's way away from the craziness of areas such as Bourbon St. We took an Uber and got there in around 15 mins. 

Menu:
This is Cajun Southern cooking at its best, y'all. You're going to find whatever it is that you're craving! Small plates, salads, soups, fish, meat, everything! 

Food/What we ordered- we order 4 small plates and 2 side dishes and we all shared.. split four ways we each only paid $20 and we were STUFFED! 

- Wood Fired Oysters with Chili Garlic Butter $14
- Fried Alligator with Chili Garlic Mayonnaise $12
- Smoked Pork Ribs with Watermelon Pickle $14
- Pork Cheek with Turnips and Almonds $12
- Mac & Cheese Casserole $7
- Creamy Grits $7 

Ok........ even typing that out made my mouth water. I've never been to a restaurant that blew me away like this place did.. we were all SPEECHLESS. 

- The oysters were huge and that spicy sauce was to die for. 
- The alligator was crunchy and kind of reminded me of Chinese orange chicken lol. 
- The ribs were HUGE, I couldn't believe it only cost $14... they were juicy and perfectly seasoned and cooked; loved the watermelon. 
- The pork cheek melted in my mouth immediately, and the corn relish it came with was unreal. We almost asked for more of it on the side lol.
- Mac and cheese casserole? Cmon, you already KNOW that was delicious. 
- The grits were the best thing I ate during my ENTIRE TRIP... I'm serious.... in 3 days I ate a lot of things, but this was the best part. SO CREAMY YOU'LL WANNA CRY lol

My male spouse and I were so insulted and unsatisfied with the service we vowed never to return despite some outstanding appetizers and entrées. Our waitress was surly and rude and was obviously prejudiced against gay clientele. Her tattoos were the only thing she wanted to show the people at the next table. I observed other wait persons and staff who were doing their job but she just dragged herself as if she was waiting for a call from Broadway in New York. I'm sure she's not there any longer. And I'm sure we weren't the first or last people to complain. If you're straight go and enjoy their culinary delights, but I would recommend the Charcuterie on Rampart Street where the chef and owner is the chef who opened Cochon after his stint in San Francisco, our home town. 4 1/2 * for food and presentation and 1/2 * for service. The waitress asked another wait person to step in for her and we were reasonably satisfied with his service.

I've been looking forward to my dinner at Cochon for sometime now, but unfortunately it was a great disappointment.  I'm positive that if any of the restaurant staff reads this review, they will most likely write it off as a typical angry Yelper.  That assumption would be far from the truth.  We love dinning out, especially at restaurants with great reviews, but tonight fell short of the considerable hype Cochon has received.

Our meal began with a server who spoke so softly we had no chance of understanding.  We were dining with our daughter and inquired if they had a children's menu or children's options.  In hushed tones we faintly heard our server's disdain for even asking about children's options.  She whispered that our daughter could have the macaroni and cheese or the alligator tossed in a spicy mayonnaise with mint (obviously our server understands deftly the palette of a child).  We settled on the macaroni.

Upon her next visit to the table, our quiet server asked if we were ready to order.  I asked if we could order our first of several courses and she informed us the chef prefers only full orders.  Instead of arguing, we ordered two courses instead of the four I had hoped for.  Before our first course we were served dinner rolls with a very dry/tough exterior - like the bread had been microwaved.  Our first course was the alligator, the special porchetta, and the ribs.  We had to send the alligator back because it was so tough it was impossible to chew.  The porchetta was served cold, which was a surprise, but it could have been explained that way in the near-silent-verse of our server.  The ribs were very good!  

The entree courses were the cochon and the brisket served with sides of greens and twice baked stuffed potato.  The brisket was fine (a little heavy with smoke, but that's a personal preference).  The cochon was disappointing at best.  The pork was very dry despite it's  wonderfully moist braised cabbage and turnip accompaniments.  The twice baked stuffed potato was also very dry.  It desperately needed butter and/or sour cream to bring the over cooked potato back to life.

We left a great deal of food on the table, something that is a first for a heavy set man like myself.  The fact is the food was for the most part very dry and lacking the panache that I've heard about from the likes of Alton Brown and Anthony Bourdain.  Our post-Nouvelle-Creole-Southern meal left us wishing for better sourced products, careful cooking, butter/fat/sauces, and outstanding, audible service.  I don't mind spending money on good food (we just dropped $800 at Per Se for two), but tonight I wasted $143 on a mediocre at best meal.

I would suggest skipping this restaurant and server 201 T (we never heard her name and this was how it was listed on the bill).  Enjoy one of the New Orleans classics instead.
I came to try the pig mac, wasn't impressed. I suppose pork patties aren't my thing. However, the mac-n-cheese was the best I'd ever experienced.

Had lunch at Cochon today with a friend. We both ordered a bowl of the chicken and andouille gumbo -- it was incredible. Easily one of the best gumbos that I have tried in New Orleans. It had a great smokey flavor from the andouille. We also tried several of the small plates. The fried alligator was tasty. We tried the wood-fired oysters too, which were good. We also shared the braised pork cheeks, which were also incredible. Cochon recently re-worked the pork cheeks to have a light summer salad, which was really nice.

Our waitress was fantastic. She had great recommendations and made it a fun dining experience. 

If you're looking for something fun and tasty in NOLA, I highly recommend Cochon.

This is an unfair rating because I Don't eat pork or seafood.  I was invited to attend by someone else so I'm rating the drinks and atmosphere.  Drinks were pricey and you can spend $100 before your blink.

Came here for lunch, and surprisingly, it was not crowded on a Wednesday.  It was my first time here.  My favorite was the chicken and andouille gumbo, which uses their own andouille in it.  Marvelously smokey, I plan to steal this idea for my own duck and andouille gumbo!  However, I should note, that the smokiness dominates the chicken a bit too much.  All that being said, some of the best gumbo I have ever had in a restaurant!  I usually don't order alligator in a restaurant, as every time I have done so, it has been underwhelming and chewy.  I have to say, this alligator was tender and tasty!  The charbrolled oysters were perfectly cooked, but I did not favor the sauce.  I think you can do much better elsewhere.  The eggplant shrimp side was very good as well.  Service was excellent.  Highly recommended.

This was my second time at Cochon. The first time was for a celebration and it exceeded my expectations. Tonight, we went in to show a visiting dallas chef a favorite restaurant of ours- the food was fine but the service was terrible. We tipped 20% which I instantly regretted. By 11pm we where essentially asked to leave our table. Our server reminded us of this by slamming water glasses, forcefully pulling napkins off the table, and made it very obvious he was ready for us to leave (we left by official closing hours at 11pm on a Friday night). 
While this used to be one of my recommended restaurants, the service has declined from the level upheld a couple of years ago. There are many other dining options in New Orleans that uphold not only quality of food, but also quality of service.

Where do I even begin!? This visit was so overdue that I went back two days in a row for lunch! Both days we had a wonderful waiter, Thomas! Like we say on NOLA "if the bread is good in a restaurant, you know the food will be too!" Awesome fluffy hot rolls! Gotta love them! I always love a restaurant that serves fresh, and I mean not canned greens. As in mustard, collard etc. Cochon hit the nail on the head with this one! A hint of vinegar, ham seasoning, and a little touch of their own hot sauce made them prefect! I also ordered the boudin balls. Very good, but I like my boudin with slightly more meat and spice. I didn't bring too much of an appetite on Saturday but my date ordered the whole fish and it was also cooked to perfection. I think it was red snapper. Came right off the skin and was perfectly juicy and flaky.

Sunday's lunch! Had to go back to get some fish of my own! Btw, I ordered the Bloody Mary and I didn't even have to ask for a spicy one! It was perfection! We both ordered the Wahoo and once again, cooked on the grill to perfection. I wasn't big on the tomatoes that were on the side bc they were cold. But the yellow sauce with the fish was really good. The last thing I ordered was the twice baked potato. Had to split it! My eyes were bigger than my stomach. 

Everything at Cochon was top notch and I will be returning and recommending it to all my friends in the future!

I had a very solid lunch. No fuss, very chill. Great service. Wonderful beat salad. Great gumbo. 
Dip next door yo the butcher shop and grab some decent mac and cheese whole you get your sausage wrapped up.

It's hard to decide where to go to eat in a place like New Orleans. Especially if you're here for a limited amount of time. But Cochon is a place you absolutely must go. I sat at the Kitchen Bar and got to see the masters at work. I started with the pork cheek and good lord, it was some of the best slices of meat I've ever tasted. For my entree, I had the oyster and bacon sandwich. This was essentially an oyster blt but really that's oversimplifying it. It wonderfully balanced the rich, salty and smokey flavors of the oysters/bacon with a great acidic aoli. Even the rolls and sweet cream butter were fantastic. An absolute must try if you're here in NOLA.

This review is for 4.5 stars.

Fantastic food.  Fresh bread and tasty gumbo.  The cochon was on mark and the catfish stew was unexpectedly flavorful and creole to the max.  Drinks were relatively limited, but they had a bunch of local beer options and a few wines that were affordable.  The restaurant venue was surprisingly large and even had an upstairs area so it seemed great for an outing or bachelor party.

Amazing food. Terrible service. The worst we had out of the 5 restaurants we hit up in New Orleans today. Honestly it's unfair to the chef to have him execute a brilliant menu and then have an untrained FOH staff ruin it. We left before we were done with dinner. Didn't even finish our drinks or wait for dessert.
Amazing meal with amazing service. Make sure to have a cocktail or two while you're there, the pink Ophelia is divine and so is the Chicken and Andouille gumbo.

Food was slightly above average depending on what you ate. Service was not good. Waitress got sassy. Slow service. Felt like a bother coming into the restaurant. Clearly cheap toilet paper. Couldn't split check.
Delicious food, terrible service!!!! Visited after a day at the WWII museum. We're very hungry and they were slow to sit us and our waiter was really rude and in a hurry. Will not be back!

Very very good! We ordered two desserts and macncheese, alligator bites and pork cheeks. Portions are small. BUT. Extremely delicious. We are planning to come back every day until we leave New Orleans on Wednesday.

Cochon has been on my radar for many years now.  Luckily I got a chance to grab some lunch there on a recent vacation with my family.  I have to say that everything exceeded my expectations and I'm wondering when the next time I will be able to come back.

To start, the entire staff was awesome.  Beyond great table service, a lovely girl (want to say her name was Hope, but my memory is bad) assisted me in selecting some whiskey and beer to accompany my food.  She was very knowledgeable and went as far to pour me a couple of tastings to help me make up my mind.  There was a gentleman, who I assumed was the floor manager, checked on us at least a couple of times.  Lastly, we were able to catch up with Chef Stephen in Cochon Butcher next door.  He was super cordial and took time out to take a picture with my daughter and talk food with me.  I've met many famous Chefs and not all of them are so accommodating let alone, genuinely sincere.

Getting back to beverages, they have a nice selection of bourbon, rye and other whiskeys.  They also do whiskey flights which would normally appeal to me, but I wanted to try something different and perhaps rare.  I ended up with some Weller 12 with a tasting of the Weller Special Reserve Cochon Selection and the Elijah Craig 12 Cochon Private Barrel.  All 3 did not disappoint.  My wife ordered to the Hurricane Ophelia to get in the spirit of New Orleans.  She said it was the tastiest Hurricane she's ever had with quality rum and fresh fruit juices.  My daughter was super excited that they offered Dang Butterscotch Root Beer which is very similar to Butter Beer in Harry Potter World and Universal Studios. 

We had a party of 4 including my 11 year old daughter and we decided to order a variety of plates and share family style, just so we could sample as much as we could in this one sitting.  I don't want to critique every dish, but there was nothing that wasn't very good.  If I had to pick a couple of favorites, it would be the pork cheeks with corn and chilies and the rabbit and dumplings.  These two dishes are seemingly simple, yet so perfectly executed.  I don't typically do dessert, but my daughter ordered the spicy chocolate pudding pie which didn't survive long.

At the end of the day, the meal was fantastic and the experience was even better.

We came because we are in ssearch of the beat gumbo in town and this place was recommended. My friend had the shrimp with chow chow and collard greens, while I had the gumbo.

The shrimp was excellent, all three of them, the greens were over seasoned and too expensive for greens.

The gumbo was way too salty and didn't have gumbo flavors. Filled with lots of chicken, but far from gumbo flair. This would make a great chicken 

While this place may be trendy, being tagged teamed by multiple servers and having them hover was more than I could stand, seemed like massive over kill.

Beer was cold and yummy.

If you want to drop $40 for lunch and get a snack on the way back to work, this place is for you. Three shrimp for lunch left me hungry.

We ordered grilled spicy oyster, pork cheek and beef brisket. Oyster was pretty good. Like the sauce and the tenderness. Pork cheek was great too but the amount was not good enough for me. Beef brisket was over cooked. Not recommend that.

For someone with a Gluten & Dairy allergy they were able to accommodate us. The server new which items we could alter and there were a fair amount of selections. They even offered us complimentary sweet chicharrónes (cracklins) that were delicious in place of their bread & butter basket.

Food

Fried Alligator - recommended. Great appetizer to start off with. Tastes a lot like fried popcorn chicken but a bit tougher. No unpleasant taste to gator meat for a first timer and the aoili sauce with chiles and parsley made for nice aromatics. Loved this dish

Rabbit and dumplings - 4 dumplings served in a cast iron skillet with slivers of shredded rabbit meat in a thick stew/gravy heavily seasoned with wine and scent of bay leaf to help cut away at the gaminess of the rabbit. A hearty stew but I'm not a huge fan of gamey meats.

Braised Pork cheeks - recommended. I love the tenderness of braised pork cheeks. Just get it.

Special Pork Porterhouse - recommended. Came to be about 60 dollars for the dish. Was expecting a large tomahawk sized piece of pork but received a presliced porterhouse steak with a great smokiness to it. Because the porter house has two different cuts of meat, the short loin and the tenderloin, there were two great textures. The tenderloin was more lean and still had the rich sweet smoky taste that reminded me of a very nice ham, but without the overly salty taste. The short loin portion had a nice rind of fat and pork skin over it, but I chose not to eat this as it was too tough for me. Came with cheesy scrambled eggs and crispy well cooked potatoes.

Louisiana Cochon with cracklins and cabbage - I ordered this because it seemed like a local dish and was named after the restaurant. I had to look up what cochon was because I thought it was the name of a new regional dish or something. I was surprised to see that it was a puck-sized lump of cajun seasoned pulled pork that was pan fried, resting on a bed of cabbage, jus, and topped with pork cracklings. The pulled pork was not my favorite but it was an interesting dish overall

Sauteed greens - recommended. I'm new to southern cooking but I have a soft spot for seasoned collard greens infused with pork belly bacon flavors.

Mac and cheese - recommended. the side of mac and cheese on a skillet was delicious. Richly cheesy. Not the Kraft or Velveeta type but a real high quality cheesy taste to it.

Price - reasonable for the quality of ingredients and food prepared with care. Appetizers are around 10-15 dollars, entrees between 20-60, and sides at 7

Service - Excellent. Can't complain. Received all our food at once though appetizers did come out first.

Overall - Interesting contemporary american take on classic southern fare. Love the vibe of the restaurant and the nice interior decor. Cochon butcher is right next door as well if you like sandwiches. Highly recommended stop.
The food and the service are good. I would however stay away from the gumbo. It was dark and smoky not very appetizing. The alligator is fantastic.

This restaurant was highly recommended by one of our friends & the yelp reviews were fantastic! This is our first stop in New Orleans to celebrate my birthday weekend!! The door hostess was friendly and we lucked out and got the last 2 seats at the bar. Our favorite place to sit, so we can get to know our bartenders. Our bartenders, Nick and Miles, took great care of us & the drinks were amazing! I tried the "strange situation", it was vodka muddled with all fresh ingredients, including blueberries and it was delicious. The food is great, I started out with the wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter and they melt in your mouth. Then they brought out homemade fresh baked rolls to sop up the butter!!! My husband tried the smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickled relish, the meat fell right off the bone! Delicious. The creamy grits were to die for! We also tried the pork cheek which is a local favorite. It was different, but 
the taste was not my favorite. But, there's plenty of dishes on the menu for everyone to try!! Loved this place!!

We were really excited to go to Cochon.  It was a disappointment.  The gumbo was too salty.  The grilled shrimp was burnt, and they tried to hide it.

Our waiters were poor.  We had to get another waiter to find ours.  We won't be back.  Not worth the price.

We accidentally walked into here instead of the Cochin Butcher next door
Should have walked out but there were some interesting things on the menu. Unfortunately my husband has an onion allergy and 85% of the items had onions. He got the boucheree (excuse the spelling) but it was some thinly sliced meats with some large looking croutons for $16 not enough for anyone to get full on. My son got the ribs that was too spicy for him so we sent it back and he got a grilled cheese. I got the meat pie which was good but small for $11.
Service was good because they made sure not to bring out anything with onions but is was extremely slow and the place was almost empty 
Not worth the time or money

New to New Orleans and was recommended this place by a local. It was so delicious. I got the Louisiana Cochon and it was amazing. Perfect pairing of flavors. We also got the gumbo and oysters. Loved the spice on the oysters and they were cooked perfectly. Ended it with the spicy chocolate pudding pie dessert that was delicious as well. If I lived here we would be back! It is pricey but the serving size of the entree is not lacking. So worth going!

This is my third time at Cochon, and each time it blows my mind. Going for lunch, I had no wait. I sat at the bar and had terrific service from the bartender, who was the perfect blend of friendly without being obnoxious. The cocktail I ordered (vodka rocks with a splash of cran) was a solid pour. I started with the chargrilled oysters and I don't know if there is anything I've eaten in life that was better. Coming from New England where the oysters are small and sweet, and having been to New Orleans many times where I know the oysters are big and succulent, I usually find them only good for being fried. My apologies on the assumption. These were phenomenal. Well seasoned, perfect heat, great charred flavor, with delicious light dinner rolls to sop up the extra butter sauce. I was worried the garlic chopped on top would be too aggressive, but the char grill cooked it perfectly. I then ordered the meat pie, which was like the hot pocket of your dreams. Stuffed with pork, rice, and trinity, with an etouffee-type gravy, it was heaven. I was slightly disappointed that it wasn't the crawfish pie I had read about, but deeply appreciate that they change items up seasonally. This restaurant is a treasure.
This was one of our favorite meals in NOLA. The fried gator was so delicious.  The atmosphere was great, the food was yummy, good service--we would go back for sure!
Definitely a unique spot if your looking for a cool environment with delicious, small dishes to choose from. One of my top 10 restaurants of all time !!!!

Got to watch the chefs in action and chat a bit. We shared wood-fired oysters, fried alligator, smoked ribs, gumbo and malted chocolate cake. Everything was delicious. Chef sent us corn fritters as well that were so good.

Amazing. Came here for my 30th birthday dinner and this girl loves her fried alligator, fried livers with jelly, their amazing melt in your mouth boucherie plate! It was perfect for me! Of course, I had to to it all off with their Mac n cheese. Thank you for the amazing birthday everyone! I won't forget it!

Good experience at Cochon. Service was impeccable. The attention to detail here is strong. Everything here is pretty much a Pork dish, has Pork in it or on it! A few dishes don't have Pork in them. I had the Louisiana Cochon and it was basically Pulled Pork baked into a patty placed on a bed of cabbage. It was garnished with cracklings and pickled peaches. The flavors were well balanced and the Pork was moist and tender. My only qualm was the saltiness of all the dishes!!

The food was absolute delicious! We were Avery large group and had almost all the sides. We even ordered the pig head special! It was fun watching the celebrant try to cut through it. It was a lot of work but we got a good amount of meat off of it. Also, their specialty drinks, very tasty. Some were a little too sweet but turned out really good to sip on throughout our dinner.

Great overall! After the National WWII museum, we came here with a party of 5 for our first time. I had the fried alligator with an amazing chili garlic mayonnaise sauce. My first time having alligator was an amazing experience. Others in the party had their favorite gumbo soup, a mac and cheese casserole, and the ribs with a perfect amount of spice and smoke. Amazing ambiance and service was nice and fast. Definitely would recommend!
In beautiful part of town. Very friendly hostess and waitstaff. Very helpful. Food is very delicious.

This is a must go to restaurant when you are in New Orleans. It is further from the french quarter but the walk was so worth it. We had such excellent service and their food is absolutely delicious. It was my favorite place in town! It is true.. you must have the alligator! My friends and I got different plates and we shared them. It was an excellent idea and we enjoyed every bit of it.
Crowded at lunch but delicious. Modem southern food. Quick and excellent service. Definitely requires a return trip

I had the chicken and andouille gumbo with a specialty salad that was basically a cobb salad with FRIED salami (yum!) - my girlfriend had the ribs and loved them. Service was amazing. Cute little spot.

I remember the charbroiled oysters as the first and best oysters of that nature I've had. And everything else being decent but not as impressive as them. It was an adorable establishment sorta in the middle of nowhere, so I'd be careful to go alone or on a late night. But do go with all your friends because this is delicious animal soul food as the name suggests.

Cochon is located in the upcoming Warehouse/Arts District, about five blocks south of Poydras Street. The space is open and inviting, and the smells of what you're about to eat greet you at the door. 

Food: We went with the small plates and sides. There doesn't seem to be anything you shouldn't get. We loved everything we ordered: wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter, pork cheek (!), macaroni and cheese, shrimp and eggplant dressing. The flavors were incredible. Light but with loads of depth and texture. Their homemade dinner rolls are delectable. 

Service: Attentive and friendly. Water is brought to you quickly, refilled consistently, and the food comes out in good time. 

Cost: Reasonable for what you're getting. Roughly $60 after tax and tip for one small plate, one boucherie, two sides, and two drinks. 

Overall: A must try. If you're into something less formal (which this wasn't at all), Cochon Butcher, their sister restaurant is next door.
the smell just walking in was enough to get me hooked.  great food. large space. i will definitely be back!

I've eaten here several years ago, was terrific then.  Took my family for lunch and was like a different restaurant, not in a good way.  Some of the food was so salty it was inedible.  I never send food back, but this time our party sent back food two times.  Such a great restaurant when it's working right, dog out those old recipes!
Eclectic menu,  friendly waitstaff. Mac and cheese was fantastic, livers were tasty and i typically dont like them.  Charcuterie board was good, no complaints.
It was okay. Macaroni was creamy and delicious. The grilled shrimp with chow chow was different.

Amazing service, food and wine!! My friend and I had a fabulous time when we went. The atmosphere is perfect for a date, but can get a bit noisy when there are big parties. The atmosphere is gorgeous. I would definitely recommend this place to the meat eaters in NOLA for a fancy night out.

One of the best meals that we had our entire time in New Orleans for a recent trip.

The chili garlic butter grilled oysters are outstanding - you only get five to an order, so consider getting a few. They were perfectly spicy and delicious. I am still dreaming about them.
