Our entrees were also wonderful. The rabbit and dumplings was creamy and well seasoned with lots of chunks of meat. The louisiana cochon was packed with interesting flavors and textures from the pickled peaches, cabbage, and cracklins. 

Service was attentive but very slow. We had reservations but still waited a while for a table and probably didn't get any food for close to half an hour. But it was worth it, and I would have no hesitations about coming back and recommending this place to everyone.

Convenient picked out this place for me. Ended up sitting at the bar facing the kitchen, which was kind of neat. Service was good, food was not impressive.

I wasn't a fan of the firegrilled oysters. There, I said it. First off you get 5 which means you always get to have the awkward conversation if you're sharing. They had more of a muscle-y texture to them. GF liked them a lot, maybe they just weren't my style. Drago's still holds the number one spot for me.

Wasn't really impressed with the gumbo either. Wasn't bad, but it didn't blow me away either.

Brisket: to quality this review, I should have known that ordering brisket outside of Texas was a mistake. They give you the lean cut, which was the first mistake, then they try to keep it moist with drippings, which doesn't work. There is no crust on the outside and the smokey flavor doesn't permeate the meat itself so you get a bite or 2 that tastes like roast beef. Best part of it was the horse radish potato salad, which was awesome.

Overall there is better food available at better prices. I do like the sandwiches at their butcher shop, but I wouldn't bother with the main restaurant. Maybe I ordered wrong, but it's a pricey place for some of their limited menu items to be sub par.

Cochon is a little more expensive than we usually go for, but I'm glad we ate here because our food was delicious! We stopped by at 6pm on a Saturday night, which was perfect because we were able to get seated before it got too busy. We shared the grilled eggplant special and ordered the catfish and Cochon with pickled peaches. Our waitress was very kind and we had an excellent meal.

Don't miss an opportunity to eat at this fantastic restaurant.  They make it an experience.  The management team is great! The waitstaff is unmatched.  And words can't describe the kitchen magicians.  Don't judge me! I had two appetizers, an entree, and dessert.  It was all fantastic!  I had the wood fired oysters with a chili garlic sauce and pork cheek with corn fresh chilies and a dill vinaigrette for the first course.  The entree was a LA cochon with cabbage, pickled peaches, and cracklins.  Dessert was a chef special: chocolate cake with Bavarian cream. Last but least a taste of the roasted eggplant with sesame and pumpkin seeds.  I believe the pics speak for themselves. Thanks for the great food NOLA.

I went to Cochon on September 16th for dinner with approximately 8 girlfriends-- the food was lovely, but the beverage service was horrible. Our server was so incredibly rude and disrespectful. I ordered a bottle of Chateauneuf du Pape and a bottle of Tempranillo for the table. The server came out and poured large glasses of each wine for each guest. Half the table got Tempranillo, and half got CDP, although I had specifically requested that each guest get a half glass of each so everyone could taste both wines.

When the beverage server came around a second time to freshen everyone's wine, he began to pour the Tempranillo into guests' glasses of Chateauneuf du Pape, and poured the CDP into the Tempranillo. I caught him on the first pour and asked him to stop pouring because he was mixing the glasses of wine that I paid for. He stared at me, continued to pour, and said "Well, I guess they're all a blend now."   He promptly walked away, refusing to reconcile the problem by freshening the glasses he ruined or offering to remove the bottles from our tab. It was the most inhospitable and careless wine service I had ever received, and I was so offended by his rudeness and refusal to fix the problem.

I don't even like Creole/Southern food, but this place is pretty good!! If I had to go anywhere for southern food, cochon would probably be it. The Mac and cheese is to die for! That was probably my favorite dish. The complimentary bread they give out is also so delicious - piping hot, fluffy, and buttery. I'd forgo the fried alligator nuggets since it tasted like dry chicken. Instead, I'd go for the rabbit and dumplings - a homey comforting dish that reminded me of chicken pot pie, but instead of pastry dough, you get flour dumplings on top. 

Interesting enough to the say least, dessert was the real stunner! The pineapple upside down cake was amazing, and I'd come back for just that in and of itself. The blueberry trifle in the jar was also yummy.

Cochon was good! The alligator and wood fired oysters and ribs - all must-have appetizers. The rabbit was good, but nothing to write home about. The Louisiana Cochon was excellent! Desserts were just okay to us, too.

This review is for appetizers of fried gator, mac n cheese, rabbit dumplings and Louisiana cochon on a Tuesday dinner.

Fried gator: delicious, order if you have a friend in town. You can compare or just flat out avoid random gator in other restaurants because this is a good standard for a delicious gator

Mac n cheese: meh. 'Twas decent but have had better. I should had listened to my waiter, Allison? Maybe go for one of the others

Rabbit Dumplings - rabbit was amazing. This dish is fire. Definitely recommend.

Louisanna cochon - weird. Ours was overdone. Looked different than the table next to us. Good but saw the potential to be better. Limiting factor for not 5 stars. 

Service- excellent. Made good recommendations and treated appropriately. She made recommendations for beer. Crispin is a excellent cider. They were out of royaltea that I wanted to try and were able to recommend another decent beer. Advise to have a plan b as wait maybe long. Place is close to convention center so lots of people come after. 

Parking- maybe be able to nab a spot without meters on the last left turn before cochon near the warehouse doors. No meters it seems. Otherwise free after 7 [2017]

Overall solid. Butcher is actually a fav in the city. Cochon namesake was not quite satisfying, so i am confused and a little reluctant to give this rating, but I did not explore cochon to the upper level of the menu to fully appreciate the potential. All the other food was delicious and therefore Botd and therefore, 4 stars. Between the two, I still prefer butcher in the back.

So the food was excellent. 

I had their fish which was very well prepared. It came with pickled onions which I thought did not match the dish at all. It was way to sour and not balanced with the dish. 

Their boucherie plate was delicious. Their mac and cheese was superb and their red chilly oyster was to die for. 

Why did I give them a 3 star overall was because of the service. 

We came to New Orleans for my best friends bachelor party. It was 9 of us. We are asian. And we were dressed casually. We were seated all the way in the back and upstairs with no one which at first I felt a bit awkward but it was kinda nice because we were secluded, felt like it was VIP. But what changed my mind was the service. Our staff wasn't really smiling our service was ok. It just felt like we were being rushed. I mean 9 people drinks included, the service was 42 mins. I have never in my entire life ate such a fast dinner. 

It's too bad. The restaurant is very nice the food is good. Maybe they don't like Asian people. But for southern hospitality experience I give them a 0. I will never come back to this restaurant.

So, saw on FB today an upcoming event at Calcasieu and decided to call and inquire about details. Spoke to Joe, who immediately radiated with kindness over the phone and gave me as much info as he could. I am raving because you can really tell when someone is passionate about what they do each and every day. We often frequent Butcher and have dined at Cochon as well....want to make it full circle to Calcasieu! Waiting for an email now to confirm some other details I wanted to know about....hope it wow's me even more!

My second time dining at Couchon and I would go again tomorrow.

We started with their cured meat board. There were things on there that turned my stomach upon hearing the names (e.g head cheese) but I was aware that they know their meats, so I gave it all a go. It was all incredible. Delicious house cured sausages and meats matched with some delicious bread. It was really really really good.

Then there were the mains. Having already had their friend alligator (ridiculously out of control tasty) and their rabbit dumplings (fluffy pillows of goodness resting in the stew of gods tears) we ventured out to try some seafood. 

Garlic oysters. Shit. They were bloody delicious. 
Catfish stew was also on point. I didn't know catfish could be so flavorful. 
We also had the couchon staple of pulled pork rolled in icing sugar, fried, and covered in cracklins, served on pickled cabbage and peaches. It was really a perfect dish.


The cocktails are also great. 

Do yourself a favor and bring someone to Couchon. It will make you look like you know shit about New Orleans and your belly will be singing it's praises for weeks to come.

This was our first dinner in NOLA and it was incredible. They accommodated our table of 13 with no issues and excellent service. Vibe is also casual, not stuffy. Must get the wood-fired oysters! I'd go back there for that alone.

This restaurant is part of the butcher that is behind it.  The Butcher is more of a deli/walk-up counter that you order and them sit and they bring it to you, whereas this is a full-service seated restaurant.
This restaurant offers many meat-based specialties, mostly due to being part of the butcher.  The chef here does a really nice job putting together a rather unique and tasty menu.  On the evening we went, the food execution was spot on.
Service was just OK.  Nothing special, perhaps it's a management issue regarding this chain, because the butcher next door has borderline bad service (skirting the line of passive aggressive and pretentious).  Seems these places are so popular and they offer an incredible menu that they can treat customers however they feel.  
The restaurant itself was beautiful; everything from the cool neon sign out front to the exposed kitchen and the flames were amazing and created an atmosphere you really want to dine in.
Wine list was decent and even though a little on the pricey side, we still found something really nice for $50.
Overall, we really enjoyed visiting the various restaurants in this chain on our trip and had perfectly prepared, unique dishes (we ate at one of their restaurants four times within a few days!), but really didn't appreciate the lack of empathetic service.  With all the amazing places to eat in NOLA, we'd be better off trying some other places on our next visit.

Maybe the best overall Cajun restaurant I've tried as they are creative and not afraid make their food they way they like it.  I liked their Cochon, pig meat, signature dish made with peaches and bacon and fried skin. 
Came with some toasty soft bread and a little free taste made with a liver mousse.  
Comfortable and classy both.

Overall a great experience at Cochon.  Fun vibe, vibrant and happening without any drunken college students :) We loved the oysters, which were meaty and spicy - definitely get those! - as well as the charcuterie platter.  Beet salad was an unexpected standout.  Loved the drink selection - I got a Japanese whisky flight and my husband a great local IPA.  Both were terrific.  My ham hock was good, but a little dry.  Husband liked the brisket better.  Good service and great food overall - I'd come back!
This place was top notch! Alagator so tasty, ribs tasty, and my dinner the brisket melted in my mouth.

Amazing food, lackluster service. Cocktails were also delicious, everything just took an inordinate amount of time and server was obviously uninterested in our table.  We got pushback when trying to order small plates and drinks prior to ordering our meals(the chef prefers if you order everything at the same time apparently) and the service declined from there. Recommend the Livonia cocktail, alligator bites, meat pie, rabbit, Cochon, and grasshopper dessert.

Wow what a treat! Heard about this place from Anthony bordains visit after Katrina. Ordered the lamb soup seasonal special, ham hoc, grits and Mac and cheese. They take some of the worst cuts of meat and turn them into treasures! 

Great place to go for lunch when attending a show at the convention center. Everyone else at the table was pleased as well.
Made reservations with only an hour notice. Showed up and we were seated 15 minutes early. The alligator bites were awesome. The ribs and the brisket were also great. Highly recommend this place.

Really good, not unbelievable good but solid. Very cool place, great presentation of food. Fried boudin balls were some of the best I've had. Ribs were ok, but so much glaze on them you could barely taste meat. Pork cheeks were a little tough but good. I'll be back though
Solid dinner spot. Mac and cheese is fantastic and the gumbo is the best I have ever had. Rabbit dumplings were also good.

Food was good. I had the beef brisket with horseradish potato salad. My wife and I shared Chicken Mushroom soup which was excellent. Had beer from the local brewery which was very good..
The server was informative about the menu, good service, food was served hot. I was disappointed with ambiance of this restaurant which was like eating in a old warehouse.  Not very romantic and had ambiance of garage..
Very small menu selection which was very pricey..

We waited 10 minutes for a hostess to appear during the beginning of a modestly populated lunch hour. The bartender had mercy on us and came to seat us.
The server seemed mildly interested in waiting on us. 
They offered hot roll basket with butter and glass of water to every table.
They don't  stock Splenda for yellow packet lovers so I opted for a Diet Coke which was flat.
Wood fired appetizers were ok. Some were chewy so I spit them out into my napkin. I know, gross.
The sausage appetizer with grits and egg was very tasty. I think it was a special not on regular menu.
The ham hocks were too salty but the quinoa and goat yogurt was very tasty. 
We did not get dessert because nothing reached out and grabbed us-even though we were still hungry as the portions are very small. The entree was the same size as the small plate sausage.

Very underwhelmed. Will try Butcher or Calcasieu next time-lines at both.

We sat at the chef's bar and watched the entire kitchen work it's magic. The chef and kitchen staff are a well oiled machine, the food runners are professional and kind, and everyone works hard to make sure each dish is perfectly presented and correct. The service staff is attentive, timely and friendly. And the food. We had the homemade chorizo, fried alligator, wood fired oysters, mac and cheese casserole, beet salad and beef brisket and everything was so. good. So so good. Not to mention, being at the chef's bar we were able to see every dish before it was served. It was so hard to choose because everything looked so good! I would say this is a must visit for the delicious food, super professional staff and les bons temps.

I was so impressed, I wanted to write Chef Kyle a note... so here it is!

We decided to try the place out. It was decent. Had the Louisiana pork with Turnips. Gumbo and meat pie. Food was good. Not great. Drinks were yummy. Our server was wonderful. Parking was really easy. The atmosphere was ok very open space. I'd definitely like to see more items added to the menu. I'd probably go back.
As usual - no disappointment here with the to-die-for beets, ribs, Mac and oysters. We'll be back -- again!

This was one of my favorite meals from my last trip to New Orleans. 

We started with the fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise and it was amazing. I would love to buy the chili garlic mayonnaise and use that on tons of other dishes. 

For my meal, I ordered the redfish (I believe this was the special so I'm not sure it's on the regular menu) and the macaroni & cheese casserole. The redfish was very good but the macaroni and cheese was amazing! Easily top 3 that I've ever had. 

Staff was friendly but the restaurant was pretty loud so it made it hard to talk at some points.

Make sure to make reservations or be prepared to wait if you go for dinner.

I was really looking forward to eating at Cochon after reading many great reviews and blogger recommendations.  Unfortunately, the meal was extremely underwhelming.  We came for lunch and the place was pretty empty.  We ordered Boucherie Plate which we liked and the rabbit and dumplings stew which we did not like at all.  For me it was really bland and boring.  I make a better rabbit stew at home.  My husband's plate barely had any rabbit, he sent it back and they brought out another one.  Overall, very pricey and not memorable food.  Skip, there are much better places in New Orleans.

This restaurant is on a somewhat strange corner away from the main French Quarter streets.  We walked from the trolley so we were glad we wore comfy shoes.  The wait staff was very professional.  They brought me a sample of the draft beer.  We had the Cobia collar which was a huge plate of very rich fish that could have been shared.  I ordered the Louisiana cochon which didn't look like a lot of food until I started eating.  It was rather a strange combo of cabbage, cracklings and pickled peaches, but it was tasty.  The shrimp and eggplant dressing was very good.  Reservations recommended.

This restaurant lives up to the hype! We ordered the boucherie plate which was amazing, the gumbo was just spicy enough, the pork cheeks were small but delicious!  The cucumber salad is great if you like dill.  For dinner, we enjoyed the ribs for 2.  It was 3 lbs and cooked to perfection!  We even brought some home.  We finished the night with the pineapple upside down cake which was an amazing mixture of fruit flavors and decadence.  

Service was on point the whole evening.  Only suggestion is to make a reservation.
This place is so amazing, we had a business dinner a party of 10 and everything was mouth watering, the service beyond excellent. CANNOT wait to go back this place is a HIGHLIGHT for NOLA.

Ate there last night. My husband and I arrived about 6:30pm on a Wednesday and it was packed. The only available seating was at the bar so we sat there. I ordered the pork ribs and the twice baked potato. Both were delicious, the ribs (4) had a spicy flavor but were not fall-off-the-bone tender (how I generally like them)but still yummy nonetheless. We shared a chocolate cake for dessert and it was huge. We didn't finish it all, it made a sweet treat later that night back at our hotel. Overall good portions, good flavors....a little more expensive than we usually eat but we are on vacation to why not. Our tab for the two of us came to $84, included our two meals, shared dessert, two beers for my husband and ginger ale for me. I give it a four because the hostesses were not really friendly and the seats were really uncomfortable.

The best part of my recent trip to New Orleans was eating at this restaurant. I love how they have alligator and rabbit dishes which can't be found at every restaurant. I first ordered the fried alligator which I really enjoyed. It's true what they say about gator, it tastes like chicken. Or maybe it's just because they breaded the meat pieces and put it in a sauce, that to me tasted similar to a buffalo sauce for chicken wings. I still enjoyed the dish, but would have liked an experience where you could really taste the meat itself instead of just the sauce. For my main entree, I had the rabbit & dumplings. This dish is what I'm giving the established five stars for. All of the vegetables included in the stew part of the dish were cooked perfectly and were seasoned to perfection. The dumplings were cooked to a firmness that I prefer where it is easily broken with a fork and able to be tasted by itself. There were also decent sized bits of rabbit so you can get a clearer taste of the meat. I would love to order this again, especially on a chilly evening when I can let the warmth of the dish warm me up. Also if you're looking for a restaurant that has some handsome waiters, there were quite a few on my recent visit. I particularly found the bartender to be quite handsome so make sure to get a seat with a view.

Cochon is a must go when you're in NOLA. Everything here is pretty much all small plates but they do offer larger plates entrees which you can get. We got their fried alligator with garlic chili mayonnaise which was good with good flavor. We also got their pork cheeks with corn, tomatoes, chilies and dill vinaigrette. I've never tried pork cheeks before and I would definitely get this dish again. Next on the list that we tried was their duck and andouille gumbo. The gumbo was slightly salty but flavorful with a kick to it which was a nice touch. Our big entree that we go was their Louisiana Cochon with cabbage, cracklins and pickled peaches. It was basically a large meat patty, crispy on the outside and soft and juicy on the inside. Everything that accompanied that dish works well together. Overall great food here!

The charcuterie is amazing, and the drink list is very impressive. Went family style and tasted many of the dishes. All stars were definitely smoked chop, garlic chili broiled oysters, greens, and boudin balls!

Absolutely horrible.  We had 7 people for dinner and ready to go, while a table was open for over 1 hr right in front of us and the other hostess stand.  We were told it would only be a few minutes for our table to be ready - once.  We ordered a couple of drinks, which were the most expensive in the city all week, and settled in for a wait.  

We had to inquire on our own for status, as the angry and pissy hostess was getting more so each time we asked.  Finally, after nearly 75 minutes waiting they placed us in a booth, which was clearly meant for 5-6 people, not 7, as one of us was sitting half onto the bench.

If you're busy, tell your patrons there is no room.  Don't have them waiting and stewing around, milking a bar tab.....never again.

Showed up with a group of friends last evening and was told by the hostess that a reservation had just cancelled. And our party would fill this spot. We were  told that the wait would approximately be 30 minutes which was reasonable for a Saturday evening. After a 75 minutes wait (and many open tables that we on hold for a 2.5 hour period for those who made reservations) the hostess seated our large party of seven into a booth made to accommodate 5-6. We asked for a chair to place at the end of the table and were told this was a fire hazard and we could not be accommodated. Meanwhile, a table that would have easily seated our party was seated with a smaller party. Instead of switching out our tables to accommodate both parties we were told this was the best they offer. We ended up leaving and having dinner elsewhere. Sad for the server as she lost a huge tip last night and sad that this restaurant is so poorly managed.

A delicious combination of Creole and modern tastes. With menu items like rabbit dumplings and fire grilled oysters there is something for everyone and everything is gourmet and freshly made. We had the great opportunity of sitting at the chef's counter where we got the watch action and see very plate freshly prepared. Must try for any local or tourist! Make a reservation ahead of time to unsure a spot!

Sucks to leave this.

1st Time there was great!

Went back for a 2nd time on our vacation and it blew.

The apps are ok but the actual food was quite bad. We had the Brisket and the Cochon. Both horrible.

Decent Oysters and Mac and Cheese still but the actual m all are bad.

Hands down the best alligator I've ever had. Crunchy on the outside but soft and delicious on the inside. The cream has just the right amount of spices and the mint garnish adds a hint of freshness. The waiter recommended a great beer to go along. Great service. Wonderful atmosphere. Definitely coming back again.

Came on a Thursday night and it was packed. Even with a reservation our party of 8 still had to wait a while outside before we could be seated. The appetizers were amazing; we shared the fried gator, gumbo and ribs. Gator was amazing, ribs had such an interesting taste with the pickled watermelon but wasn't fall off the bone. I ordered the conchon with pork grind for main course and personally found it really salty which was a letdown after the yummy apps. 
All in all a great place to try southern cooking with some unusual ingredients.

The food here is amazing.  Some of the best food I have ever had.  The service however is a joke.  The chef needs to take a serious look at who is running the front of the house.  We enjoyed the bread so much that we asked for a second helping and we were then asked by the waiter if it was really necessary?  We then asked to speak to the manager who walked over with a big smirk on her face and were told bread was a privilege.  It's not like we had tap water and split an entree.....we ordered bottles of wine, multiple appetizers, entrees and sides.  I am embarrassed for this establishment.  The chef is doing an amazing job however I will never step foot in this place ever again no matter how good that bread was.

Great modern space about a 10-15 minute ride from the French Quarters you will find Cochon.  The menu is not very big but offers a bunch of dishes you would love to try.

Appetizers: Wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter:  A M A Z I N G. 
                   Fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise: Never had Alligator?  This is how
                   you try it the first time.  You will fall in love.  

Entree's: My buddy had the rabbit & dumplings (Tender chucks of rabbit with perfectly baked dumplings and served in small cast iron skillet) Delicious. I had the ribs with mac & cheese. 
The Mac & Cheese is some of the best you'll find outside of home.  The ribs were flavored well but not tender enough which led to a 4 star review instead of 5. 

Our service was quick and on point.  No complaints there. 

I will return here because i also want to try the Brisket and Ham Hock.  Great for a group or romantic night out.  Dont sleep on Cochon!

I came here for a birthday dinner with a group on 8 on a Thursday night. The place was slammed. You can tell right away this is a hot spot. It's more on the upscale side and has a great ambiance. The food here is fantastic. Very flavorful and different from what you might normally try. We order the alligator bites, baked oysters, short rib and watermelon ribs. 

Our server was extremely rude and never bothered to check on us. Our starters arrived before we received our drinks and we had to beg for the free bread as we were starving and getting hangry. Towards the end of our meal I tried to discretely tell him about the birthday girl who was sitting right next to me. I asked if he could bring out the most popular dessert as she's not picky and has no allergies. He made it blatantly obvious I was trying to surprise her.

If I could give 10 stars I would for this place! Hands down one of the best restaurants I've been to and I've dined internationally. I sat at the bar which was perfect for me. Bartenders were knowledgeable quick and efficient for those dining at the bar (which was almost everyone). I started with the oysters and  they were some of the best oysters I've ever had. Nice flavor and kick! I also had the beet salad and fried alligator which were both bursting with flavor. I promised myself I was going to eat half of each dish but I just could not stop myself ! I ended it all with the pineapple upside down cake which was not too heavy but melt in your mouth goodness ! I truly felt like I was in heaven with every bite of these dishes. I would definitely recommend you try this place if ever in the area.
Every time I go to NOLA I make sure to get the ribs and mac & cheese (and a bourbon cocktail) at Cochon. Every. Single. Time. Make a reservation, take your friends. It's the best.

The rabbit and dumplings is to die for! Seriously so rich and filling. On the pricey end. 

The alligator bites were tasty.

The pork cheeks and oysters were meh.

Great service but get a reservation and be prepared to wait.

Cochon stands as a solid go to choice for out of town guests. The food and service are good, prices are reasonable and they offer a good selection of Cajun style country fare. 
The wait (even with reservations) is almost always long due to its reputation and proximity for convention goers and tourists.  I've enjoy the boudin, fried alligator, Cochon and Rabbit dumplings. Although there are other place I like more, it's still a valuable cuisine experience for those looking to explore local flavors. The desserts are always original and not too sweet, so I recommend saving room.

Food is amazing, which left me no time for pics. My fave is the rabbit and dumplings and cochon de lait. Desserts: this time around we tried the passion fruit angel food cake and it was delicious! The restaurant itself has nice decor, but it does get pretty loud (good food, drinks and company = noise).

I really wanted to love this place since there is a lot of hype around it, and while there were certainly some great aspects, I left feeling disappointed. 

First, the space is great.. very large, wooden tables, nice lighting, etc. The vibe was like... trendy casual? It was pretty packed on a Sunday night so definitely recommend a reservation.  We made one several weeks out. 

Next, the service was fantastic. I can't remember our servers name but she was super nice and cracked some funny jokes, gave some recos, etc. 

Now onto the consumables. 
- Cocktails were good. I had some spicy lemon thing. It was enjoyable! 
- Appetizers were the highlight. The charred oyster is as good as everyone says. This was the stand out of the night. Make sure you get some of the complimentary bread to soak up that buttery oyster sauce!! We also had the boudin ball... it came with this spicy mustard that made for a well balanced bite. 
- Sadly, it all fell apart with the entree. We decided to split a main and a side since we doubled down on apps. We did the brisket with horseradish potato salad and the shrimp/eggplant dressing. Both dishes were unbelievably salty. The brisket had this brown gravy that was so salty we honestly thought someone made a mistake. The old drop the salt shaker into the pot move?? And the dressing was a shrimp flavored salt bomb. I would not recommend this side. We wished we got the mac and cheese since that looked really tasty. 
- Dessert was redeeming.. we got the hummingbird cake which came with a delicious cream cheese icing... yummy. 

Overall, Cochon is a cool spot with some nice plates. The majority of reviews on here are overwhelmingly positive, so maybe we just came on an off night. In any case, I probably won't make it back just because I'm not local... and if I'm ever back in town I'd try other places first.

Very cozy decor and ambiance that's perfect for a date night / small group. I would definitely make a reservation even for a weeknight. We like that it's small plates so we can try a little of everything. The menu must be seasonal since I didn't see certain items on the menu that people recommended. The complimentary rolls were so fluffy and buttery in a good way. A little disappointed with the gumbo but the rest of the dishes we ordered was great (fried alligator, pork cheeks, and Louisiana cochon). The gumbo was salty and I didn't see much duck or andouille in our bowl.

The restaurant is amazing . I'm not a big fan of oysters . But when my husband ordered it - it was amazing with the garlic paste . 
Pork ribs were amazing and the eggplant and shrimp dressing too. 
I wish yelp had more star buttons. 
You guys rock ! Amazingly .

Don't be afraid of alligator, it won't bite. You bite them! 

Cochon is home to the best delicacies you will find in New Orleans. This is where you can find fried alligator bites, rabbit with dumplings, duck and andouille gumbo, as well as an extensive list of obscure liquors. 

I first came here earlier this year and tried the rabbit with dumplings and the alligator bites. I immediately became a fan of the alligator as it tasted more like chicken but sweeter. The sauce has the perfect amount of spice. 

Coming back this second time, I ordered the Duck Anduoille gumbo and alligator once again, along with an Arnold Palmer. Who would've thought the Arnold Palmer would accompany the meal so well?! The gumbo is my favorite in the city, and that's saying a lot! If I wasn't in such a rush, I would've ordered an old fashioned or another Bourbon style drink like I did the first time. It was amazing.

If in New Orleans, you have to go here. Check it out!

Came in on a Thursday night with a day-of reservation at the "senior special" time of 5:30p. Didn't realize it until we got there, but I had gone here years ago and this visit was just as good (maybe better) than the first time which is saying a lot.  The only reason I'm not giving this place 5 stars is because the hostess was really unfriendly and inflexible with a last minute +1 to our group. Thankfully we all made it work out in the end (without any help from the hostess). Ok back to the food: 

Apps we had - the special (crusted pork rib), broccoli salad, pork cheeks, shrimp and rice boulettes, wood-fired oysters, and fried alligator.

My fav apps - wood-fired oysters, fried alligator and pork cheeks (yes, I understand I chose half of the apps I listed as my fav but that's how good this restaurant is!)

I had the Louisiana cochon for my entree which was delicious! The pork was tender, the cracklings had a  great crunch to it and the flavors just blended in all the right ways.

Desserts we had - hummingbird cake, chocolate malted cake, and grasshopper pie. The grasshopper pie was hands down my fav (I love mint chip), but the chocolate malted cake was a group fav as well.

Yes, come here now! To top it off, the total bill came to ~$60 per person which is a deal considering all the food and alcohol we had. Would highly recommend!

We were able to make day of reservations for a group of 7 at 1pm. A few of the dishes were done very well! Some other were just okay. 

Favorites of most recommended to least: 
Rabbit and dumplings ($23). My favorite! Amazing flavor, unique, and just the right proportion of rabbit meat, veggies, and biscuits. 
Wood fired oysters ($14)-  delicious! With a unique Cajun flavor 
Pork cheek ($12) : tender, good flavor. I would have preferred the corn to be hot instead of cold. 
Porchetta ($45) huge portion, great for sharing: delicious texture and flavor 
Fried Alligator ($12): tender, good flavor
Roasted beet salad ($10): a refreshing light dish to contrast the other items

Others:
Louisiana Cochon ($24): for their signature dish, I was not impressed. The pork was pretty dry
Duck and andouille gumbo ($8): very salty
Collard greens side ($7): decent

The service was a bit slow. We all got very hungry waiting for the dishes to come out. 

Overall, a unique NOLA experience, but was not super impressed. I would definitely get the rabbit and dumplings and oysters again.

All the foods we order are all so Delish! 
Oven baked Gaul fish is so tender and juicy! A must order!
Food was good but horrible management ignored our concerns from the bad service we got from our waiter. The worst service we got at our stay.

The waitress with the alligator tattoo behind right arm, did not take our orders for my group of 8 for 45 min. Once we finally did order, we received our orders in 1 hour since arrival. We asked our food to be brought out all together at one time and it was brought in courses which is Not too bad except it wasNot explained why appetizers were not at least served first-Salad was last. We have many concerns and we brought it to the manager, but he refuses to sit down (rather stand up) and speak with us. He said a few things to cover her mistakes, he didn't ask if there was anything he can do to make it better... We are really sad about this because the food was good...we spent good money for this and even tipped the other servers. Just not this waitress.

Worst service I've ever encountered. 

We waited 45 minutes before they even asked to take our order. It took an hour before we got any of our food. 

We asked for our food to be brought all at once, but it was brought in "courses", as the very incompetent and snarky waitress called it. 

Also, speaking of courses... it went in this order:
Some appetizers - Main course - other appetizers - SALADS

THEY BROUGHT THE SALADS LAST. 
Since when do salads come out last?!?

We asked to talk to the manager. He was asked to sit with us and have a conversation with our concerns, but he simply said, "No. I'll just stand." 
By talking to the manager directly, they were given the opportunity to make it right and they chose not to. Instead, he tried to cover up for the waitress that brought our food in courses even though we SPECIFICALLY stated that we wanted them all at once. I also asked another waitress for her name, but they played dumb. 

Shoutout to the attentive gentleman who refilled our waters and coffee. We tipped him separately.

Cochon lives up to its critical press.  One of the three best meals I have had in 4 trips to New Orleans.  Went for lunch and three of us shared entrees, appetizers, sides and three desserts not one dished missed, the menu has no weak spots.  The hummingbird cake is dark and is a little like carrot cake.  Pineapple upside down cake also rocked.  Prices are reasonable for food of this caliber.  Service was polished.  How anyone rates this as only four stars is a mystery to me.

We made it shortly after the lunch rush and scored a table in under 20 mins. I basically just drooled over and shamelessly stared at the food the table next to us ordered and got what looked good. Who needs menus? Of course, you have to get the fried alligator. What really blew my mind was the dry rub ham hock. They don't use dry rub in the traditional sense though. They slow cook the hock (ankle) and then flash fry it (mmm crispy pork ) and then dash on the rub. They serve it over a bed of goat yogurt, cucumbers and quinoa, which balances out the salty /savory of the ham hock. Don't forget to use your knife or whatever instrument you can safely use to scrape out the bone marrow GOLD from inside the ham hock bone. Omg. It was like a bonus round of flavor. (10/10). (Don't know why my server didn't recommend this? Worries me that many delicious bone marrows have been*GASP* wasted.) Service was great. Drinks were good but not out of this world. Atmosphere was hipster/casual.

The prep and execution at Cochon has exceeded almost everything I've had in New Orleans. Although I'm a fan of chili, I'd trade it in for a bowl of their gumbo any day. The Boudin brought out a wild ride of flavors and textures. The dynamics of the oysters also took me by surprise. If you're in NoLa, this is a must, just make sure you have your blood pressure meds on hand. Things tend to be pretty salty.

We went on a Friday night for a reservation at 8pm. We got there and waited for our table. First impression was it is noisy. Seriously noisy. We were seated and the waitress came over in a timely manner. Ordered drinks and were Told they were out of one of the cocktails. Ok...strange but we ordered another.  Cocktails good but not great. Ordered dinner...waitress came back and they were out of one of the entrees...ok...food was good but the best part of the meals were the vegetables. Seriously yummy but the meats were very salty and on the dry side. Waitress did not come back over to check on us at all once plates were set down. Decided to order two desserts...they were out of one of them. Seriously????Ordered a different one...it was ok. And she forgot to bring the other...so would not go back.

This was a great choice for the last night I spent in New Orleans. It was a little dark inside, but a good atmosphere. Prices seemed reasonable for the offerings and weren't too outrageous. I got the alligator with the chili mayonnaise. The flavor unique- like a mix of chewy chicken and calamari but tender and just enough spice from the sauce. Although tempting, I opted out for dessert this time

Cochon is always a delight. Its walkable from bourbon street (probably 20 minutes) and a pleasant walk of the weather is nice. The menu here is diverse and the items are unique and carefully prepared. We ordered the following:

1. Buttermilk pancakes- omg. This was delicious. It was covered in stewed apples more like a dessert. It's two rather large and fluffy pancakes layered ontop of one another. 

2. Fried livers and pepper jelly toast- this is a small plate and also very good if you like pate. It's topped with fresh herbs that gives each bite a nice pop

3. Oyster and bacon sandwich- two thumbs up! Sandwich size is huge and shareable. It has fried oysters and bacon with lettuce and tomatoes and a side of coleslaw and pickle. When taken together the flavors really come together

4. Pork cheek with corn- pork was nice and tender on a light dill vinaigrette with corn. It was nicely composed and the ingredients were really complimentary, especially the corn. 

5. Pork tail and tomato gravy- not the best. The tomato gravy was very overpowering and the pork tail was a little too fatty. 

Prices are a little expensive but portions are quite large. I would recommend this place!

The food and drink lived up the the hype. The dining room is understated and unassuming, but what was most impressive was the staff. Hope and her team were absolutely incredible for every minute we were in the restaurant.

This place was awful . Me and my boyfriend found this place walking down the streets of New Orleans . The service was so terrible . Our waitress was so unfriendly and only came to our table once and was no where to be found when we wanted our check . We waited for so long to even have our order taken and it wasn't busy at all.

I was blown away. The whole experience was something very memorable. And the food was ON POINT! We got the shrimp rice balls and oysters for appetizers. I ordered the short rib and my husband ordered the rabbit and dumplings. We also had cocktails and sat along the kitchen. Very intimate and wonderful experience. Can't say enough good things. Every bite was better than the last.

I enjoyed the food here. Ordered the ham hock it is a bit small and delicate but the meat was tender and the flavors were bright and crisp it was a good balance with the yogurt. A must have is the alligator is debris sauce! It was really delicious and if you never had alligator it tastes like a combination of chicken and squid. Most reviews suggest making a reservation. When we arrived it did not seem very crowded at all so it's not absolutely essential but it is probably best to err on the safe side.

Great restaurant and great food. This was the first time I had cochon, and I was impressed. The cochon was a ball of pulled pork which was breaded and fried. The cochon was savory and filling. Goes well with the vegetables it's served over. We also had fried alligator bites which taste like gamey fish and is topped with onions and a tangy sauce. I would definitely go back!

This was my FAVORITE restaurant in New Orleans. So glad we got to stop by before we left. The restaurant itself is pretty spacious and were able to accommodate 10 people quickly. Service was great as well; our waiter did not mind that we kept asking for more complimentary bread. Couldn't help it though; the bread was like house rolls. It was warm, buttery and soft. Honestly, the portions of the food were smaller than expected and the bread is the real reason I was full after this meal.

Either way, I can't complain. My friend and I shared the fried alligators and the char grilled oysters. Both were amazing. Coming from New York, I didn't know what to expect for alligator meat but it ended up being really good here! The oysters looked like it was drowned with sauce, but this did not hide how fresh they were. I really wish we got more. I got the duck and andouille gumbo as my entree. While it was flavorful, I thought it was a little too heavy for me.
The food was pretty decent but nothing wowed me .. and it was expensive .. I had rabbit and boudin.. there are other places in New Orleans id rather have went to twice ..

This was by far my FAVORITE restaurant in New Orleans. Service was great as well because we kept asking our waiter for more complimentary bread. I have no idea what that bread is made out of but it was addicting as HECK! 

The fried alligator was too die for. The sauce that they used tasted like spicy mayo and having the fried alligator drenched in that was simply delicious. The oysters were also delicious and I used the bread to soak up all the juices/sauce the oysters were covered in. 

For my main dish I got the gumbo which was filling and flavorful. You MUST MUST MUST stop by Cochon before leaving New Orleans. Their food definitely does not disappoint!

Very good food and customer service. Sat at the bar at lunch time and everything was perfectly executed. Gumbo was fantastic as were the oysters. Would definitely come back and will recommend to folks in the area.

Omg! Where do I begin? We are visiting from California and had done some research on places to eat. But Sunday we realized many places closed early so we looked at our guide book and checked the hours on yelp...ta-da! Cochon was a 3 min walk and open! Score! We didn't have a reservation so waited about 20 min and grabbed a drink across the street. 

When we sat down we had the best view of the kitchen! They have bar style seating with a direct view and it was seriously the best seats in the house. The cooks said hello and the waiters were very friendly with recommendations. We had pork, Mac and cheese, and the twice baked potato. We also got a treat from chef! So awesome! The flavors were unreal! Everything was delicious. If we come back to New Orleans this place will be on the list. And I would love to try more items...we saw them cooking Asian green beans, fish, oysters..it all looked so good! Go here!

Absolutely amazing service.  The food is very unique and delicious.  The small plates are great for appetizers and sharing, as well as the larger dishes.  The Apple Pie Moonshine is an amazing dessert alternative!

Giving this 3 stars because service was subpar but the food was fantastic! Coming from California my husband and I are used to having suggestions and enthusiasm by waitstaff as well as superb hospitality. The wait staff should be enthusiastic to sell the chefs dishes and talk about them. It was like pulling teeth to get our sever to talk about the food and recommendations, needless to say he seemed uncomfortable and twitchy. Was odd. Thank goodness for the blond lady who backed him up otherwise we would have walked out. The staff was more occupied talking among themselves instead of checking on their customers and tending to their needs. 

Was an interesting menu and after ordering and sampling a few items we were pleasantly surprised at how flavorful the food was. Mixing mint with various menu items was a pleasant surprise! Loved it! Cheers to the chef! Fabulous dishes! Wonderful food! 

Suggestion....train the staff with educating them on better customer service, being attentive, offering recommendations with ENTHUSIASM!  Smile, it's not painful. :)

I was on my way to check out the WWII museum and wanted to grab a quick bite to eat and stumbled upon this place. After a quick glance on Yelp, I knew I had try this place out. So, I grabbed a seat at the bar and was promptly greeted by the bartender. It didn't take me long to decide to order the wood-fired oysters and pint to go along with it. The oysters were so delicious! Great recommendation by the bartender! I enjoyed that they had this smokey flavor to it but also had a little kick from the chili sauce. I was tempted to order more food but filled up on the yummy complimentary bread...oops. But I don't regret it as my lunch experience was wonderful and hit the spot! I was actually surprised how attentive the bartender was, given it was a later in the afternoon. The ambiance here is pretty contemporary. I don't know how they set the tables for dinner but they had white table clothes down for lunch which was a nice touch. 

I would definitely recommend folks give this place a try if you're looking for unique flavors. I had my eye on the fried gator which I'll definitely try next time.

The worst.  Took 10-15 minutes after being seated to be acknowledged.  Ribs were tough.  Mac and cheese had some funky flavoring and was too burnt on top.  Bloody Mary's tasted like straight tomato juice.  Crab claws had hardly any meat.  The boudin balls were the only decent thing.  I think we meant to go to the butcher shop/deli?  The place on the hard corner missed it by a long shot.  I was fooled when we sat down because the place looked so nice and I can tell the spent the extra money money on the finishes.  Definitely not a kid menu friendly place.  I hate writing bad reviews but all the stars and positive reviews were way way off in my honest opinion.

Believe the hype! This was my big splurge dinner in New Orleans, and it was worth every penny. I had the chili oysters, the pork ribs, and the mac & cheese. Every dish was excellent. I also had two excellent cocktails and really wanted to try dessert but I was so full by the end of it, I couldn't. It's also definitely affordable even as a splurge restaurant if you stick to the small plates instead of ordering a man - the portions are huge and that way you get to try a couple different things! Especially when each dish was so wonderful, it felt like a great life choice. I will definitely be back the next time I'm in New Orleans.

A Jig for This Pig

A good bar, interesting craft cocktails, pleasant staff and delicious food are the makings of a great restaurant.  Cochon has all that.  Our group tried several dishes and all were full of flavor, interesting and well-crafted.  I'm not sure what else we could ask for.
One of the best authentic NOLA restaurant!! Super delicious wild wood fire oyster, port entree is right on point!!! Highly recommended!

Great place, food and service, close to WWII museum

I had the roasted beet salad and the braised short rib
All incredibly tasty and well prepared
The Louisiana Cochon and Mac and cheese are also remarkable 
It is a must go place in New Orleans

Simply a terrific restaurant and experience. My wife and I ate at the bar facing directly into the kitchen featuring a wood burning oven. We ordered the alligator, chicken livers, cucumber salad, charcuterie, rabbit, Mac and cheese, pineapple upside down cake, and hummingbird cake.

Phenomenal service, brilliant food and outstanding menu. If you're looking for a southern meal cooked at the highest level this is your place.

Not great. Visiting from MN, we were eager to try this restaurant as it has such great reviews. Unfortunately, it was simply disappointing. Our waitress had no interest with us. She checked in with us more before we ordered than she did the rest of the night - we actually thought we had switched servers because someone else dropped off the small plates, cleared then, then dropped off the entree. We had been unhappy with the salad but there was no one for us to tell because she never asked us how it was going until we were halfway through our entrees. At this point we had an almost untouched salad sitting next to our entrees when she finally asked how it was. We said it was disappointing and too spicy - she made no effort to rectify the situation, just took it away. She didn't check on us again, just dropped off the bill and picked it up without asking any questions. Very unfriendly and not what we would expect. 

Additionally the food was disappointing. Out of our group of 5 we only had one entree and one side that we actually felt were above average. The rest of the food tasted like it came from a food supplier, frozen, then heated up in the microwave. It basically felt like we were at a southern themed Applebee's. Not the worst food I've ever had, but overpriced. I would not come back or recommend, even for the experience.
Smoked pork ribs with pickled watermelon was on point!  The tanginess of the bbq sauce made this the best ribs I've ever had.  Sat outside, weather was awesome.  All was good in life.

Finally get a break from the cajun and creole food and have some large chunk of meat! The bread tasted so great and ask for a refill. The pork cheek is amazing. For the entree we ordered ham hock and beef short rib. I like the ham hock better as it tasted great and looks healthy~The sauce in the short rib is too salty but the rib is good. The dessert is ok. Can skip that actually...

A lovely, lovely restaurant and meal. We started out with the oysters and then I got the rabbit and dumplings and my husband got the special of the day, the porkcetta sandwich and roasted brussel sprouts. Everything was seasoned perfectly and hit the spot. We went at 2:30 in the afternoon so it's equally impressive everything was so wonderful at an off time. I would definitely come back next time we're here!

I went to Cochon with a large party, for which they offer a tasting menu. I dreaded this party, because, as a vegetarian I'm use to eating badly made salads at restaurants in South Louisiana. I was shocked at how well treated I was! The restaurant allowed me to not only order off the group's menu, the chef made me the MOST delicious fried broccoli on a bed of quinoa and goat's cheese. I cannot tell you how amazing the food was, because words do not suffice, but the service was perfect. Cochon is expensive and worth every penny.

Great food and location, and fabulous service. I initially made a reservation here for Friday night but couldn't make it. When I called, Joe was kind enough to help change it to Saturday night. The ambiance here is pretty hip and gives a nice cabin / cozy vibe. We ordered a variety of popular items and our server was wonderful.

Wood-fried oysters (5/5): Oh my, GET THIS! the flavor was so delicious that I couldn't help but soak up all the juice with the delicious bread they provided. After one order (which comes with 5 oysters), we asked for another order because it was THAT GOOD.

Fried alligators (4/5): Delicious, but nothing too different from all the other fried alligators at other restaurants. The spicy mayo was interesting tho.

Pork Cheek (5/5): Tender bits of pork in a wonder braised sauce. The sweet potato "cake -like" side was interesting. Maybe not my favorite but the sweetness goes well with the pork.

Rabbit and Dumplings (4/5): This was kind of like a chicken-pot pie. The bottom is a rabbit stew with carrots and turnips, and it's topped with 4 "dumplings" which are essentially just pieces of thick bread/ pie crust. 

Do yourself a favor and give this place a try. It's near warehouse/ arts district so do some sightseeing around the area as well.

I went here based on the positive reviews and feedback from people. Plus, I wanted to try the wood fired oysters. It looked different from the other grilled oysters served in the French quarter like the ones served at Felix and Bourbon house. I have to say their wood fired oysters are definitely better than Felix and Bourbon house. We also tried the fried alligator and shrimp and rice boulettes. Fried alligator was alright, nothing spectacular, something to try once. The meat has a chewy texture to it which is not bad. The shrimp and rice boulettes were a bit on the salty side, not a fan of it. The service and atmosphere is good. Food is  okay only.  Portions are tapas size. Definitely try the wood fired oysters if you come here.

Some restaurants bring you in because of yelp reviews, and others make you immediate fans because they not only deliver, but exceed the expectations. 

We attempted to dine at this restaurant because the menu looked like a unique take on new American creole cookery, and the reviews were positive.  Were appalled with the atrocious attitude.  We were barely sat in a dining room at 25-30% capacity during a colder off season evening just after six.  We asked for a booth a little removed from the front door... No we can't seat you at the booth it's for 6.  Then we can't move you from a ridiculously located drafty front door but two rows down on a banquette. 

Unfortunately, the food may be exceptional, we'll never know. However the lack of consideration for the guests leaves this two top looking for another restaurant to patronize instead of being patronized by unwilling staff. 

Again it would be understandable if the host stand had a stacked wait list, but considering the circumstances, having two extremely grateful guests is better than being unyielding, waiting for the imaginary 4 top that's required to join them...sayonara as the Japanese would say, bon chance, as the French would say.

For pork lovers, Cochon must be heaven! Even for non pork lovers, this is surely one of the best restaurants in New Orleans, a city of tasty restaurants fit for foodies. 

We arrived on a freezing Friday night (who would think of New Orleans being 37 degrees?!) and were greeted warmly by the hostess. While a bit early we got a drink at the bar and by the time the drink arrived, our table was ready. We asked both the bartender and the servers about their fave dishes and they recommended the wood fire oysters, smoked ribs, ham hock and rabbit & dumplings, all of which we proceeded to order plus a side of roasted squash. Everything was done incredibly well except for 1 dish.

Bread - warm buttery dinner rolls that were as good as the reviews say. Perfect for soaking up excess juices from the wood fired oysters!

Wood fired oysters- seemingly the Star app and they did not disappoint. These oysters in Louisiana are HUGE!! And each oyster had two chunks of oysters on it. Such buttery goodness!

Smoked ribs with watermelon pickle - hands down the best ribs I've ever had! Great flavor, lots of meat, chunky and super tender. It had all the elements - sweet, savory, slightly spicy and sour from the pickled watermelon. I think I would have been happy to just eat this all night!

Ham hock - this was good but not the best thing ever ordered. The ham was quite lean and the goat yogurt as quinoa was a nice balanced complement to it. But after the ribs nothing compared...

Rabbit & dumplings- the only disappointment of the night. Really bland and the dumplings didn't taste as good as the bread rolls. My date said it tasted a bit like something you'd get out of a can. We noted to our server that it was a bit bland and he kindly took it off our bill. Great service!!

Roasted squash with seeds - amazingly good!! Should've ordered more!!!

Super yummy dinner! Now I understand why all the chefs and foodies come here!

I would have paid just for the privilege of sitting in front of the open fire stove to defrost and dry off on the frigid day that was yesterday.  The food was an added perk.  I was grateful for the rolls that the staff brought out, while the food was being prepared.  I would recommend the fried alligator.  It had a similar taste to chicken, but a more even flavor and texture.  Bon apetit and stuff.
Amazing food and Better Service!! Terin and Aaron were a great team. Terin was super friendly and knowledgeable about the food. Super stoked we found this place!

Freaking amazing! First off this place is a lot bigger than it looks from the outside, it is a warehouse that was transformed into a magical food heaven. There were no disappointments at this dinner. Everything we ordered was so good. I ordered the Cochon, cucumbers and Mac n cheese. Cochon is a form of pulled pork, seasoned more like Pernil. They pull it then put it back together for the presentation. It was so tasty! The servers were also attentive and helped us make great decisions on our meals. If you are ever in NOLA check this place out!
Loved the food, it was unique and very tasty. The liver small plate is great, absolutely recommended. The ribs small plate is also very good.
Sat at the bar and watched the snow come down (ish).  Had a great meal, great bartenders, great vibe.  I've heard only good things about this place and it lived up to it.

Wow. It's very hard to describe the experience in words. The restaurant itself is beautifully created and the ambiance is good for a date and family feel at the same time. I ordered the Louisiana Cochon with a side of grits and mac and cheese, and my friends ordered the Side portion of the short ribs, as well as the beef. All were amazing. The short ribs were the siZe of an entree. The service was amazing. We made a reservation because we knew there would be a wait. The dessert was to die for. We ordered the chocolate ganache but they ran out of it in the kitchen. They told us they would go next door to get some cake if we really wanted it and they wouldn't charge us. Such great service!
The food and atmosphere were great. The only negative experience was that we showed up for our reservation on time but weren't seated for half an hour.
I had the rabbit and dumplings which was quite good. They also have a great brown ale.
Made a reservation for Wednesday and got messed up to Friday. Long story short, ended up disappointed my party (my boss and colleagues) and they do not seem apologetic either.

I went here twice during my stay in New Orleans, and it was great both times.  The service is friendly and efficient, and the food is spectacular.  Definitely the best food I had in New Orleans.  The duck and andouille sausage gumbo is rich and savory.  We also tried the cochon, catfish courtboullion, and the rabbit & dumplings.  The pork cheeks were also extremely good.  Reservations are recommended because this place is also very popular.  If you are at a convention in NOLA, you should definitely find a place in your schedule for Cochon.

One of the best meals i had.
The oysters were AMAZING! And the alligator was good as well :)
It's a luttle bit pricy but worth it!

I have been to New Orleans three times and each time I made sure I visited Cochon.  This place is unbelievable and beats my favorite restaurants in the New York area where I live.  The meat here (and all kinds of meat) is delicious.  The last time I was there, I remember the ham hock, which was fabulous.  The oysters also are excellent.

If you are visiting NOLA, make sure this restaurant is on your list.

Cochon serves up authentic Cajun Southern cuisine coupled with excellent ambiance and service in the Arts/Warehouse District. The space has a warm rustic, but airy feel. There is indoor and outdoor table seating, bar seating, and a small chef's counter. 

We started off with the wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter and the duck & andouille gumbo, both of which I would highly recommend. These were followed by rabbit & dumplings and braised beef short rib. We really loved all of these dishes, but the rabbit & dumplings was our absolute favorite--one of the best dishes I've had this year.

Visited 2 times and each time they out did themselves. Enjoyed great wine paired with delicious small plates and entrees that really stand out. I enjoyed the rabbit and dumplings this time and will need it again for my soul before the winter is over.

This was not cheap but this meal was worth every single penny. The amuse bouche of head cheese on toast was yummy (despite knowing what headcheese is...). The broccoli cheddar soup was the best I've ever had. The bread service was crunchy and buttery. The high point of the meal was the meat. My pork ribs weren't even attached to the bone, they were so tender. My boyfriend's short rib was perfection. Sit at the chef's counter. We ended up there bc we didn't have a reservation but I wouldn't have it any other way. It was delicious and entertaining. Honestly, this was the best meal I've had in as long as I can remember!

A nice lunch. Didn't quite live up to the hype and some reviews here, but still very good. I liked the chochon and my 2 friends enjoyed the duck & dumplings. Glad we got there before the main lunch hour rush. We were seated promptly but the line was substantial when we left. Worth a return visit.
Food is good but highly overpriced. There are some good pork and fish dishes. Appetizers are way over priced and very small in proportions.

Highly rated in New Orleans - I knew I had to come, and it did not disappoint! 

We managed to snag seats the bar because we didn't make a lunchtime reservation (whoops!), and it's sister restaurant Butcher - had a line out the door! 

The highlight of the meal were the oysters. They were the best oysters I had in New Orleans, hands down! Very unique sauce and so tasty! 

The other two menu ideas we got were the rabbit and dumplings and the Louisiana cochon. Both very delicious the first few bites in - but were very salty as we ate on. I highly recommend sharing different entrees to add variety - eating solely one entree by oneself would be difficult without copious cups of water.

Living in California I am picky about the quality of my food! This restaurant was so good. Flavorful, fresh, high quality and great prices. Really loved our experience. Diego was our server and he was so helpful. Gave us great recommendations for the city and made us feel very welcomed. The food was sooo good. We had the alligator bites, eggplant and shrimp dressing, the oysters, and the broccoli salad. Can't wait to go back. Seriously sooo good!!! Check it out if you like smaller plates with the best delicious tastes!!!!

My girlfriend and I have been trying every restaurant that locals have been recommending us, and of course Cochon was mentioned.

I really didn't like this place. Our waitress was disinterested and not very caring.

The cocktails were by far the weakest drinks we've had of the past 15 of so places we've eaten at in the past week. Not only that but they just didn't taste very good. They're just trying too hard to be different without delivering on quality.

The biggest disappointment was the Cochon itself, apparently their signature meal. It was just a lump of pulled pork with fried pork rinds all over it. Really? 

The gator appetizer was delicious, but nothing else was good. It was doubly insulting at $100.

Disappointing and overpriced.  We really wanted to love our meal, but we left quite a bit uneaten and it wasn't even worth bringing home in a doggy bag.  Most of the dishes simply were not impressive enough to warrant a night out.  Two highlights were the short ribs and ham appetizers.  At the other end of the spectrum--The catfish entree was one of the worst we have ever tasted.  Mac and cheese was something I can make better at home.  Service was also lacking.

Sat two walk-ins immediately. Nice warm seats in front of the oven. We doubled up on small plates and split an entree. Perfectly satisfied our big appetites. The pork is this place's namesake, but we loved the oysters, the alligator, and the rabbit!!!
Liked braised pork cheek, pork ribs and pineapple upside down cake! Nice environment too.

Great service, clean, awesome food. 
Every time I'm in New Orleans I make sure I eat here. 
Try the porchetta is out of the word ( great for two) and the rabbit.

Great for date night and corporate meals

Was given the kitchen bar table and think that was the best seat in the house. Watching the chefs cook in that massive woodfire brick oven was like watching a dance. Just for that experience it's well worth it. Needless to say the food was ace.

Goodness all around. This place hit my fancy spot for the New Orleans. They serve a variety of dishes. We ordered cochon which is just pig, pig that is delicious! The meat melted in my mouth but the cracklings that came with it gave it a nice crisp. We also tried fried alligator. The fried alligator was OUTSTANDING. The sauce that covered the chunks of alligator was so good. It was like a mayo type of sauce with a nice spicy kick to it. If you never had alligator before, I would say get it here for sure. The crawfish pie that we ordered was tasty. The flavors were good and the outside of it is nice and flaky. I also ordered some ribs which came with a tasty pickled watermelon type of thing. Together it was heaven in your mouth. As you can see, a variety of types of dishes for any pallet and all super good. Only reason why I deducted a star was because the cocktail I ordered wasn't anything impressive. Go here for food and a great atmosphere and skip the cocktails, maybe stick to a glass of wine instead.
Great food! First meal in New Orleans and we were wildly impressed! Staff was kind and courteous.

I'm a big meat eater.  Something about this place I didn't like.  It was as if they tried to do too much with the food.
I won't go back.

Shared the wood-grilled oysters and pork cheek. Both dishes were excellent, a little small to share but kept our check within budget range. Service was excellent. Seems to get rather busy so reservations are usually required esp for parties 3+.

We always bring our out-of-town guests to Cochon. We love it! The board is always amazing. The pork cheeks are always amazing. The oysters are always amazing. The rabbit and dumplings....always amazing. You get the idea. The atmosphere is fun and has a good energy level for a night out with a group of friends or a more romantic night out. We will continue to frequent this spot...oh, and don't forget to try Butcher!

Overpriced, overrated. 

Was very much looking forward to Cochon as one could call me a cured meat and really all things pork connoisseur, but was very disappointed.

I had a sad little overpriced beet salad, which was way too salty, and the charcuterie platter tasted days old - the meats all had that hard, slightly stale feel when they start to develop crystals on the edges, the salami was tasteless, the pickled vegetables past their prime, and the pated meat or fish (I couldn't even tell) that was in a tureen was greasy. 

Major bummer.
The soup is bitter. The dishes are very salty. Have to drink water by every bite. The waiter's attitude are rude. A disappointing place for dinner

Meh.  This restaurant came highly recommended by a couple of (separate) foodie friends and it was unfortunately a disappointment.  Bread came out after we had finished eating, drink glasses stayed low/empty, the brisket was bland, and service indifferent. The pork cheeks were good and the collards were great.  Mac and cheese were just okay.

No. No. No. 

Overpriced for what you get. Either our dishes were  under seasoned or you felt like you were going to choke on pepper. I've eaten next door at Cochon Butcherie and it was delicious, so I assumed Cochon would be just as good. I was wrong. 

Our waitress was stretched so thin between tables that we were forgotten about. We ordered drinks and waited... and waited... and waited. We took bites of the Mac n cheese and French onion soup and sent them back. We were still charged for both. 

A waste of a lot of money. In a city filled with such good food, do not spend your time here.

Started with an impressive charcuterie plate, followed by the best cooked oysters I've ever had. Usually when I get cooked oysters, I regret that I didn't just order raw, but not this time. 
Service was just about perfect.

First time in New Orleans with families. Look forward foe the following days. Too bad that they don't drink. I need a hangover. BTW: the restaurant is located in a quite neighborhood with a lot of outside tables. White fish is a little bit dry and salty. Not pricey.

The food was amazing. The service was great as well. However, if you're in a group bring a calculator & your math skills because this place WILL NOT split your check. Preferably, bring an accountant.  Great way to ruin a fantastic dining experience...make me do math.

Our party of 3 loved this restaurant. It was our first dinner in town and it was terrific. The vibe is great (though the hard wooden seats are a bit tough after a while!). The staff was incredibly friendly and professional. I had made a reservation but because of the time change for us we were hungry early; we showed up 1 hour early but they kindly seated us anyway. We shared the alligator bites, shrimp balls and charcuterie platter for apps - all were delicious. For dinner we had the rabbit and dumplings and cochon (a pulled pork kind of dish) and the really delicious smothered greens. For dessert we shared the upside down pineapple cake with house made sorbet which was perfectly sized (smallish) to compliment dinner. Portions were perfect (for us), prices reasonable for the high quality; a 5 star place. Highly recommend.

I think this place is famous for its chili grill oyster and lots of piggy plates. We ordered the chili oyster which is great, and duck gumbo which is exceptional. We also ordered LA cochon and bbq rib, the cochon is good however the rib is kind too strong for us (the source)

My third time here. The food was really good. However, my experience was not up to par with my previous visits. I asked about a previous signature drink I had and the server didn't really acknowledge my inquiry. He recommended a few drinks but a bit too sweet for my liking- I tried 2 of the three. My order took much too long to get to the table. And when it did, my entree was not what I wanted. Then my server came to argue with me on what I ordered. I thought the customer was always right. Regardless, the food was delicious, but my service experience was not. I was there much too long for lunch- 90 minutes and the staff did not seem to care about my experience.

Our favorite place in NOLA! We have now had Cochon twice and both times it was incredible. My gf has a severe dairy allergy and they bent over backwards to accommodate her. Everything we have tried is fantastic and the service is top notch. The decor is upscale and modern but not stuffy at all. The tables are a little close and it can be loud, but it's a great social atmosphere. Be sure to try the Jucifer on tap, it's fantastic! We had the ribs as an app and they were among the best I've ever had. She had the Cochon, which I had last time and is incredible. I had a ham dish served over tabuleah and yogurt, also incredible. 

We won't take a trip to NOLA without eating at Cochon!

Spent a week in NOLA, eating at so many great places, but this was by far my fav... the town was packed for New Years and the Sugar Bowl, so we went for lunch. The very first thing on the menu might have been my favorite, the wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter- with some bread to sop up the juice... we also had the oyster & bacon sandwich, the macaroni & cheese casserole & the smothered greens.

Great service- can't wait to go back!

Went during my stay in New Orleans. There is another butcher next door which is for meat, and this one is for sea food. Their chargrilled oyster was pretty good! I also liked the fried alligator meat, juicy and chewy! Oh their bread was amazing. I somehow finished two plates lol. The only entree I tried was rabbit and dumpling, very cool but I recommend their small plates more.

First night in NOLA, this place was set up for us by local friends. This place did not disappoint. We only had appetizers as we were trying to save ourselves for the festivities that will go on later on the night. 

We had wood-fired oysters, fried alligator, smoked pork ribs, fried boudin balls, and pork cheeks.

Favorite: OYSTERS - so amazingly good drenched in the garlic butter. I would definitely come back for that item. If you were closer to Drago's then I would hit up Drago's instead (my all time favorite).

Fried alligator was also delicious, flavors were good and wasn't gamey.

Pork Cheeks were super duper tender and seasoning was just A-Ok.

Least favorite: Didn't care for the pork ribs, it was burnt and had average bbq taste

ghost pepper infused tequila - YIKES

Service - Food came fast for a Friday night, I felt service was just ok.

On my one day spontaneous trip to NOLA, I discovered this place (well actually I discovered Cochon Butcher and then decided to come here first). Yeah, I had two dinners back to back. 

I shared a bunch of small plates and drinks. 
Fried alligator with chili garlic mayo - This was amazing! My first time trying alligator and this is the way to do it. The mayo was really flavorful! 
Fried boudin with pickled peppers - The boudin with the mustard and the pickled peppers is a beautiful harmonious combination. 
Boucherie plate - This was the weakest dish we had but still good. The pickles were amazing though. 
Duck & andouille gumbo - Honestly, I expected a little more out of this with the other food being amazing! This was still good. The dark roux created a deep, rich flavor which was interesting for me as I don't normally have the opportunity to eat a legit gumbo. 

Dessert! 
Pineapple upside down cake is a MUST!!!! This cake is simply amazing. The pairing with the dulce de leche and pineapple compote or something was phenomenal! 

PS. The drinks are also good here! Get the canal streetcar if you like old fashions!

******* Spectacular ********

I two blocks from Cochon's and the place is rocking everyday of the week. Along with its next door spot " The Butcher ". 

Great good, great atmosphere and great service. It is a must while you are in Nola. 

Go! Go! Go!

One of my favorite meals in New Orleans. I ordered the ribs and Mac n' cheese, and while they were listed as a small plate & side dish respectively, combined were more than enough for the main course. The ribs were prepared "St. Louis-style" and I have to admit we're better than many a rib I've tried here in St. Louis. The mac'n'cheese was subtly spicy BAKED golden deliciousness. Delicious cocktails & thoughtful wine menu. Can't wait to go back!

So, a guy who does not eat pork is reviewing a restaurant named Cochon. Stop laughing and keep reading, for there is so much more to Cochon than cochon!

The thought of Cochon's wood-fire roasted oysters is a major stimulus for my salivary glands, and makes me want to fly from the Big Apple to the Big Easy just for a plate of these oysters. OK, I know you oyster snobs insist that oysters must only be eaten raw; go eat your raw oysters and leave these for me. The oysters are plump and juicy, and the chili garlic butter makes them deliciously fattening. 

The fried chicken livers are served on toast with a pepper jelly that has a splendid flavor profile combining the sweet, the savory, and the spicy. The crawfish pie here is a great rendition of the Louisiana classic. 

The rabbit and dumplings dish at Cochon is an interesting take on the traditional Southern chicken and dumplings, and the short ribs are tender as a fond young lover's dream (let's see who gets the reference to obscure poetry!). 

The most interesting small plate item I've had at Cochon was the fried poached egg.
