I don't know how they did it, but it literally was an egg that was poached and then deep fried, and it did not lose the consistency and runny yolk of the poached egg. I've been back several times, but this item has not been on the menu again. If it ever makes an appearance again on Cochon's ever-changing menu, I will have to undertake a trip to NOLA just for a chance to enjoy this rare treat. 

The menu changes frequently, but if you find the butterscotch pudding on the dessert menu, don't miss it. The pineapple upside down cake, served with a scoop of sorbet, is another great dessert. 

When I dine solo, I take a seat at the chef's counter; it's a great opportunity to watch them prepare and plate the dishes.
Large group and bachelor(ette) party staple.  Great drinks too -

Accidentally bumped into this restaurant...in our hotel room we were glancing at photos of delicious food...little did we know...it was the place next door.    We didn't realize this mistake until we sat down.  

Since we were sitting...we might as well try the food.  I'm glad we did.  Food was delicious!  I had pork cheeks and it was awesome.  So tasty and well cooked!  Also had some baked oysters....Lima beans and sweet potato.  All were so yummy!

Service was great...waitress was kind and friendly.  Atmosphere was lively.  When we got there...we didn't have to wait but there were plenty of people already there.  By the time we were done...there was a waiting line.  Not a quiet place at all...when you talk amongst friends...you'll probably have to speak up.

Street parking...but in this area...it kind of sucks.  Unless you get lucky and find something close...Not much space.  More than likely you will have to walk.

Overall great place...it was a happy accident for me. =)
This is a must if you are in New Orleans, especialy in the warehouse district. The food is amazing. Lots of flavors that do not disappoint.

Just flew into Nola this evening; had heard so much about this restaurant that I knew this had to be our first meal in this magical city!! The food is absolutely exquisite!! Starters of fried alligator with chili aioli mayonnaise and topped with fresh mint! fried livers in toast with pepper jelly and a sprinkle of fresh mint and pork cheeks with sweet potato gratin!! All little tastes that delighted the palette! We were so full by then but wanted to share the short ribs... oh my, this dish did not disappoint! Succulent and rich in flavor placed in a pool of a delicate mushroom sauce! Can't wait to come back to try some of the other enticing dishes!!!

I had a friend take us to this restaurant during our stay in New Orleans. They raved about it and said that their time in NO they have not been able to get reservations to Cochon. The atmosphere and design of this restaurant is absolutely awesome! The only downside is we sat by the door and it was very cold. There also isn't too much standing space if you are just waiting to be seated. Also found out that Cochon, in French means (Pig/Pork). So you can imagine this is a pork based menu with some seafood. The menu is a little pricey, but you are definitely in for a quality meal. 

We went with a big group of people so we ordered a ton of different small plates (Wood-fired Oysters With Chili Garlic Butter, Fried Livers With Pepper Jelly & Toast, Fried Alligator With chili garlic mayonnaise, Fried Boudin With pickled peppers). These were all phenomenal, if you like oysters I would suggest the "Wood-fired Oysters". Our appetizers consisted of (lima beans, macaroni & cheese casserole, and smothered greens)

For our entrees, my father in law and I split two different entrees. We ordered the (Braised Beef Short Rib with Rice Pilaf & Mushroom Gravy & the Catfish Courtbouillon). Both very awesome dishes.
The oysters.... holy hell. Order the oysters. Also love the mac and cheese and almost every entree I've ever ordered.

This is like a newer trendy type of place not far from the convention center. Not too bad. Gets a little crowded sometimes. I wouldn't say the most authentic cajun / creole food, more fusiony I would say, but good. I had the cochon dish and it was good.

Great location, merely 2 blocks away from the WW2 Museum.  

I enjoyed the service more than the food. Wasn't all that impressed with the food. I had high expectations, but the dishes came out kinda with tired flavors.  It simply did not have that wow factor. Lunch was pretty pricey, and I did not think it delivered equivalent value.  Service was very attentive and prompt. 

I walked away thinking I made a bad choice. But how could that be with all the positive reviews on Yelp?

Stopped in here for lunch around 1pm on a weekday. Seating was not a problem. Everything on the menu sounded delicious. We ordered the Boudin balls as an appetizer. They were pretty good. Wife had the beet salad (which I won't comment on, as I think beets are awful). However! The Catfish Courtbouillon. My lord. Out of almost five days in New Orleans, this was, by far, the best thing I had eaten. The catfish was fried nicely, but the courtbouillon was just an explosion of flavor. It wasn't overwhelming. None of the flavors fought with each other. It also wasn't a ridiculous sized portion either. I was full but not ashamed of myself. If you're looking for something different beyond the standard fare, definitely check it out

My absolute favorite place!!! Excellent, excellent food, great atmosphere, and great service! The humming bird cake is to die for! All their food is great, but you need to order the wood fire oysters!

The alligator dumplings with sauce were excellent. All the dishes had distinct flavors that really popped. Next door at The Butcher, they make a pastrami sandwich that really stands out. This is one of my favorite restaurants in the city.
very good food, kind pricey.  You have to demand good service but if you do they come through.  Eat UPSTAIRS if possible

This was one of the first places I came to eat to New Orleans. I had heard amazing things so my expectations were high. We did the very touristy thing and got the fried gator, which was delicious. My personal favorite of the night was the rabbit stew with dumplings, such and incredibly deep flavor. Service was attentive and charming. I wish there was a more interesting list of bourbon, but I suppose that would only distract from the food.

This was a very short walk away from the Museum and offered lots of creative and delicious choices. We easily made reservations for 6 last second. The place is pretty big and airy.
We really liked the ribs, mac n cheese, soup, and rabbit stew and biscuits.
Good choices of drinks and pretty fast service.

Went there on Valentine's Day. Reservation for 8:30, didn't get seated until 9:20. Yikes...

Server was very knowledgeable and friendly, which lessened the bad taste in my mouth from the late seating. Food was flavorful and the menu was definitely unique and deep. While I thought the drinks were decent, the drink menu seemed a little too funky and unnecessarily out there.

Good meal overall, just wasn't pleased with the delayed seating. Probably just a Valentine's Day issue...I hope other have a good experience there, though!

This is one of my favorite NOLA restaurants. 

Service: (at the bar) Outstanding! 

Food: Outstanding! 

The best smoked pork ribs I've ever had....crispy and flavorful! The beet salad was also delicious. I ordered a margarita and both bartenders made equally delicious cocktails. I'm happy....what a great way to start game day! GEAUX SAINTS!

OUT. OF. THIS. WORLD! Had to try this place and it lived up to the hype. There were so many things I wanted to try. We started with the fried alligator and wood fired oysters. I also had a cocktail with chocolate, but it was not creamy. All three were delicious! The gator was perfection and chili butter on the oysters was divine. I wanted to eat the shell!!!! I ended up having their house specialty, the Cochon and it did not disappoint. Pork on pork on pork. I could feel my butt getting wider. We did order the malt chocolate cake for dessert which was not that exciting, after an amazing meal that was kind of eh. Would go back in a heartbeat!

My favorite restaurant in New Orleans (out of the handful I tried while visiting over a long weekend). Delicious short rib and ham. Staff is exceptional. We had to wait a couple of extra minutes for our food and they brought us complimentary wine, mac and cheese, and dessert. A really great place. Highly recommend. Make sure to get the oysters.

The food was above average but the poor service made the experience mediocre. We were seated at a table that was sticky and had crumbs from the previous guests. Our server forgot to bring us our drink order and our bread and left us unattended between each course for much too long. Many items on the menu were out by the time we were seated mid-evening, so that was a bit of a bummer, too. It wasn't a terrible meal, but I'd probably not come back the next time we're in town.

Definitively fresh ingredients tactfully incorporated into modern southern upscale comfort food that reaches back in time for inspiration and culminates into a transcendent culinary experience that left us brimming with joy.  Excellent beverages, try their wellers bourbon as an old fashion.

I made a reservation here for Saturday night at 5:30pm. We were a little late, but they still had our table ready for us. This restaurant is huge! There is a second floor in the back of the restaurant. I loved the ambiance there, with the muted lights, wooden tables/chairs, decorative bar with drinks lined up against the wall, it definitely reminded me a bit of the restaurants you can find in Los Angeles.

To me their menu is a mix of the traditional southern dishes with a twist. All together we ordered:

Fried Alligator 3/5
Pork Cheek 4/5
Pork Belly 5/5
Duck & Andouille Gumbo 5/5 (perfectly seasoned and flavorful)
3 lb Pork Shank 4/5
Roasted Beet Salad 5/5 (people that don't like beets, liked this dish)
Rabbit & Dumpling 2/5
Mac and Cheese Casserole 5/5 (creamy with a kick)
Smothered Greens 3/5

So to recap on the lower ranked dishes: the fried alligator had too much breading in it. I could not differentiate from the breading and the actual meat. The rabbit and dumpling was probably the hugest disappointment out of the batch because the flavors were just lacking. It reminded me of a pot pie but the flavors were muddled and nothing stood out about that dish. The smothered greens were a bit too salty/citrusy for me. That is saying something because I love both very much. 

With the pork cheek, it was very tender but it also tasted a bit gamey to me. I don't think I've ever eaten pork cheek, so I am not sure if that's normal but everyone else seemed to like the dish. The 3lb pork shank came with this sweet potato souffle that was to die for. There was definitely a hint of butter in there and it was whipped to a smooth and fluffy texture. It was delicious. The pork shank was fall off the bone, but for 6 hungry people, there definitely was not enough meat in it. 

With the higher ratings, you'll just have to trust me that they are pretty damn good. My husband also loved his drink, and said it's his favorite drink now. I can't remember what it's called but it has moonshine, salt & pepper, and root beer in it. If that's your thing, you should try it.

One of the best restaurants in Nola. A must to visit when in our city. 

Simple, but tasty. Delicious food without the high end cost. You enjoy yourself here 

The place is always full. Enough said!

The food and experience was over all enjoyable. Chris was particularly engaging and attentive. All key points of service were met by entire team, but as far as enthusiasm and interest in guests, he definitely excelled. However, we mostly came for eggplant dressing which was burned a hair and a bit dry. Wine would be better chilled a bit more. A thousand percent amazed with oysters and radish salad. I found the short rib poorly matched with the rice. It just seems wrong to put such a fine meat haphazardly on rice that way, but otherwise the flavor was amazing. Pork cheeks, as always, sing. In closing, we had a lovely meal but there are a few areas in service and plating that could be improved.

Don't go here! I'm serious -- I don't like having to wait so often and so long for a table!

Seriously though, that's the only downside. If you are in the crescent city and want an amazing gastronomic experience, do not miss this place.

Everything we've had here has simply melted in the mouth. 

Make reservations. If you are budget conscious make them for lunch.

Had a nice dinner here. Enjoyed the ambiance and trying dishes I can't get my hands on in Los Angeles. Unfortunately our service kind of fell short. The staff was friendly but not attentive.  After our opening round of cocktails we were never asked if we would like to order wine or whatever to go with our meal. We were able to flag our waiter down after a few minutes after getting our food, but it's still a detail that affects the overall experience.

We've been in town for a few days and have been there twice.  The oysters on the small plate menu were great, very fresh and served with a bit of heat on a bed of sea salt.  We also ordered a plate of ribs.  The sauce was sticky and had a bit of heat and were fantastic.  If your in town check this place out.

For obvious reasons, the vegetarian/vegan options are limited, so don't be surprised by their small menus. If you are new to the cuisine, keep an open mind because chances are you will be pleasantly surprised! I still think about the bread they serve prior to the meals!

My cousin is a local and works in a restaurant. so, when he suggested this place I knew we were going to be OK. It was just a few minutes walk from our hotel which was a nice plus. We had excellent service, good solid drink pours and very good food. The place is rather small so reservations will assure you a table. This will go on my list of NOLA favorites, but there are so many great places to choose from. You will not be disappointed with a dinner here! Check it out!

Had a lot of people recommend this place to eat and it didn't disappoint. My only complaint is they tried to put us in front of the kitchen seating. Which would've been cool but the stools are uncomfortable and they put me on the corner end and we had I ask to move because it was terrible. Staff was decently friendly but you could tell our waiter didn't want to be working last night. Got the pork ribs for app and beef short ribs for meal. Not my best meal in NOLA but pretty good

Holy crap, Cochon is so dang good! We wanted to have a great meal on our last night in New Orleans and Cochon delivered. From the atmosphere, to the food and drinks, everything about this place was amazing.

We started with the wood-fire roasted oysters. This was one of the best single bites of food I have had in a while. The oysters were meaty and plump, and the garlic chili butter was to die for. I'm pretty sure it would make a shoe taste good. There are 5 in an order, so it's a difficult dish to share with two people. Who gets the last one? I would have been willing to fight for it, but my fiancé is an angel and let me have the last one willingly. I chose well.

We also had the fried alligator. The alligator was tender and the chili mayo was flavorful, but I would have liked more heat. Overall, this was also a solid choice.

We decided to split the cochon for our entrée. The pork was moist and so delicious. I also really enjoyed the cabbage. I don't know how, but it had a nice smoky flavor. We got the mac and cheese as a side. It was creamy and cheesy without being too heavy. It is also a must.

We finished everything with the malted chocolate cake. It was very good, but not a standout like the rest of the meal. I did enjoy the cookie crumble topping. It offered a nice balance to the chocolate.

The staff was friendly and attentive throughout our meal without being overbearing. They offered some great recommendations. The restaurant is inviting and has great southern charm. It is no surprise that Cochon has done so well for over 10 years. It is a must try when you are in New Orleans.

This is a super late review but all important details are still fresh in my brain.

I came here back in Oct of 2017 with my best friend and it was a late dinner as well. We Uber'ed it here with an hour to spare before they locked their doors but when we walked in, we were warmly greeted and felt super welcome to be there. This place is kinda sexy with its dim lights, rustic, industrial vibe. I was totally feeling this place.

Our waiters were AWESOME!!! They were very thorough with the menu, made recommendations, advised us of what they were out of, and what to expect within each dish. They even made us feel great and confident about our choices.

Their wood-fired grilled oysters is.the.jam, ya'll. I wish VA would get down on some grilled oysters served this way. But whatever, it's what separates the two among a million other things!

Come here if you are on a first date, anniversary date, for your birthday celebration, or if you just want to get together with your friends. Laid back, relaxed, cozy, and like I said, sexy. It's like, fancy-casual. Come dressed up. Come dressed down. Just come ready to enjoy yourself. 

Highly recommend and will definitely go back.

The menu was a little small which isn't necessarily a bad thing. There wasn't anything on the menu that I "had to have." They had a different take on the Oyster with chili sauce, which was good. 

The dinner rolls were good and the ambience was nice.

Our second visit was as good or better than our first.

We were seated immediately and settled in quickly before our drink orders were happily and eagerly taken.  They have a very nice selection of Bourbon and whiskey that may take a minute to review.  Whatever you choose, know that the bartenders are artists who enjoy their craft. The drinks show it.

Starters: Smoked pork ribs: tender and tart; Shrimp and rice boulettes: could have eaten twice as many; Beet salad: refreshing and satisfyingly crisp and delicious.

Entrees: Gulf fish: seasoned liberally and broiled perfectly; Catfish: mild and also cooked perfectly, infused with a wonderful courtboullion and rice; Cochon with cabbage, cracklins, and pickled turnips hit all the right buttons: flavorful pulled pork, crispy smoky cracklins went perfectly with the tart but creamy turnips. Yum.  The short rib in mushroom gravy was also a hit and went very well with a side of creamy grits (over the rice pilaf in our humble opinion).

Dessert: Hummingbird Cake: Lightly spiced cake with orange and banana was so good.  But, the Chocolate Malt cake was the hands-down winner, combining rich chocolate cake layers with sweet dark chocolate ganache and crumbled malt cookie crumbles.  You must try it along with the recommended Port.

We washed it all down with two bottles of California Pinot Noir.

Overall, this was an excellent meal very competently served.  We all felt that it was a great value and we look forward to our next visit.

I've been here twice now - once almost ten years ago and once more recently on a business trip and I was very impressed both times. They clearly know their way around a pig and had some delicious vegetable sides with pig enhancements. The ambience is more and inviting and the drink list compliments all that fatty goodness quite nicely. It's now a permanent fixture on my list of stops in NOLA.

We had a party of 18 people, so we didn't order from the menu but rather we enjoyed a fixed menu where our group was able to sample many different items.  All of them were great!  Highlights were the baked oysters and the short rib.  The wine was spectacular as well.  Awesome service too!
I was super impressed with the combination of flavors. The service was also impeccable. Great energy and tasty food.

My second least favorite dinning experience in NOLa- least favorite would have to be the Butcher Cochon- 
Food at Cochon was O-k
We got thin sliced Cochon as an appetizer and we got 3 tiny pieces for $16
We also got the alligator which was chewy and the ribs which were fatty. 
I think it was over priced.  I heard great reviews from my friends and have to say- I was every  disappointed with food and service.

Came by after visiting the WWII museum for an early dinner. Food was okay but they added a 20% post-tax gratuity that was not on the itemized receipt (we were a party of 2 by the way). We found it an incredibly rude an deceptive way to encourage double-tipping.

I was not too impressed with this place. Not into fried gator, pork or Gulf Fish.  The sauce they served on the gulf fish was good, but the gulf fish tasted a bit like mud. Probably not a good idea to eat seafood from the Gulf. I'd choose Commanders Palace over this place, better food and better service.
love the small portion, got to try a larger variety of food, recommend pork cheek, fried boudin and roasted beet salad, plus the pineapple up-down
This was the best place to have our last dinner in NOLA before heading back home from our vacation. The mac&cheese and oysters were to die for! Will definitely come here again if I can!

We visited Cochon after a visit to the World War II museum. The restaurant was highly recommended by family members from New Orleans.  It was the LEAST FAVORITE restaurant experience during the week-long stay in New Orleans.  The server was condescending and lacking in attention and courtesy.  She disliked the fact that we failed to order a bottle of wine.  Southern hospitality that evident at all of other restaurants was missing. The brisket was bland and little in quantity for the price.  Portions of other dishes were small but a bit more tasty.  We spent approximately $90 for a horrible late lunch. Obviously Cochon is surviving on its past reputation and not providing good service and good quality food. New Orleans is home to great restaurants and we will not return to Cochon.

Could not have been more pleased with my experience at Cochon. I visited this restaurant on a recommendation by friends and yelpers and our visit was well worth our time. The oysters, boundin balls and alligator were excellent and the rabbit and dumplings were outstanding. Highly recommend anyone to visit this quality spot

I was disappointed with Cochon. We met friends who live in New Orleans there because it was close to our hotel.  The space was nice and also comfortable but the menu was to put it simply, strange. I don't know how to describe this food other than "different" but there were a lot of weird options like Rabbit and Dumplings, Pork Cheeks, etc. Small plates are just what they say, very small and not much of a value. I ordered the ribs and I like heat but could only eat two of them because they were so hot. Lemonade was so tart it left me with a puckered feeling in my mouth. Of the four of us, nobody liked their food very much. The restaurant was busy so somebody apparently likes it but I wouldn't return. If you go remember small means tiny at Cochon.

Amazing food...everything else was mediocre. Made a reservation for party of 8 at 8pm and wasn't seated until 8:40 with no apology from hostess or wait staff. A comped appetizer or drink would have been nice given that the whole party had to stand outside in light rain because the bar was too full to fit us all. I've been told this was a good place for groups but given the start and the subsequent impatient and lukewarm service by our waitress, that was not my experience this night. The chili oysters and fried alligator are the highlights...delicious! I also ordered the mac and cheese and the rabbit and dumplings which were above average but if I return (with a smaller party) I'm gonna definitely reorder the alligator and oysters

Toast with livers was so delicious as an appetizer.

Highly recommend the rabbit and dumplings.

Catch of the day was perfectly cooked and seasoned, it was light and rich in flavor at the same time.

Highly recommend Cochon for dinner. Leave lots of room because those dinner rolls are hard to stop eating.

BEST DINNER ROLLS.

Solid renditions of Cajun / southern food. This kind of food usually isn't my favorite, because it leans on the heavy side, but the renditions here were very good.

Wood-fired oysters - Reason enough to come here. I don't think I've ever tried oysters this delicious before - the oysters literally melted in my mouth. 

Fried alligator with chili garlic mayo - Don't be offput by the alligator because as it turns out, alligator doesn't taste actually like anything - for all I know I could have been eating chicken. It's all about the chili garlic mayo sauce in this, which my friends were a huge fan of (it's not exactly to my taste). 

Pork cheek - Quite tender meat. 

Roasted beet salad - I'd probably skip this unless you just want something lighter to cut the heavier dishes, because the rendition here was fine but nothing noteworthy. 

Wood fired cauliflower - Very yummy and flavorful. Nice use of vinaigrette and pork to add flavor and a pop to the dish. 

Rabbit and dumplings - I was worried I wouldn't like this because everyone kept describing it as a riff of chicken pot pie, which I dislike. But I was pleasantly surprised. The dumplings were more like large chunks of dough and the rabbit was strips of rabbit in the gravy. I liked that there wasn't pepper, which I think is one of the main things I dislike about chicken pot pie. Was it my favorite dish? No. Am I glad I tried it? Yes. 

Dry rubbed ham hock with quinoa, herbs & goat yogurt - The ham was nice and smoky and tender, and actually came on the bone which was a surprise. Favorite dish for one of my dining companions.

At the end of the day, none of this is food I necessarily crave / would be dying to eat again, except the wood fired oysters, but that's because I'm not generally a huge fan of heavy foods. But everything here was solid and I enjoyed my meal, and would definitely recommend any visitor to Nola to make a stop here.

The food was okay, not as good as we expected. However, the oysters was very good although other dishes was okay only. The customer service was very good, maybe just our server only. 
It was a nice a location to dine during Mardi Gras, we had a lot of fun before and after the dinner.

The oysters here were really good, and so was the mac n cheese. My SO had some sort of ham bone thing that he liked too. Overall everything was really good. 

I agree with Rachel C. the vinegar that they have on the tables is magical, and they have their own brand of hot sauce that is really good too.

We tried a variety of dishes and the best dish we had was the pig cheeks. The Gumbo was so salty that it took away from any flavor the dish had. The tuna tartare was very plain and lacked flavor as if the crumbled egg and raw tuna canceled each other out. It would have benefited from being served with a whole grain mustard or something to enhance the fish. The alligator was very chewy and smothered in a bang bang sauce. The pig cheeks were very tender and the flavor was very good in comparison to our other dishes. 

Brunch was not worth the cost as we left hungry and the food was less than spectacular.

Highly recommended. We went during mardi gras and the parade was in front of the restaurant. Our favourite dish is the ham hock with goat yogurt and quinoa, they go so well together. The ham hock is so tender, the saltiness matches so well with the yogurt. Must have. The other dish we also liked is the daily feature, the sheephead. It is a type of fish, so fresh and tasty. The smoke rib appertizer is also very good, the smoke favour is marinated in the meat. As for the charboiled oyster, I found the sauce is too strong, overpowered the taste of the oyster. Overall, this is one of our favourite restaurant in New Orleans.

Sat outside. Service was poor. One sausage board, one soup, one side of Mac n cheese and one side of greens and one beer = $55. Waiter didnt refill water and he didn't return credit card. The other Donald link restaurant is much better.  The manager knew about this but instead of coming and apologizing, she ignored us. For shame.

Underwhelming experience to say the least. Don't let the 4 or 5 star reviews here fool you...

An intimate setting set aside in NOLA with plenty of table space in a rather big restaurant. On a Friday night I expected it to be busy but there were just enough people for 7pm dinner to create a low hum. Warning sign #1 that this restaurant isn't what I thought it to be. I ordered a few dishes, none of which I remember besides the alligator bites and salad because they were that disappointing. Salty and small, over priced, and not delicious enough to finish more than 3/4s. If we weren't hungry we wouldn't have finished 1/2 probably.

The alligator bites are as good as everybody makes it sounds. It's like chicken nuggets but lighter because the pieces of meat are smaller. The sauce they put on top was tart and creamy and I wish Mcdonalds could serve this in their dollar menu. We also had the salad which was light, refreshing, and well presented with spring time colors. However, I would not recommend coming just for these 2 dishes alone.

Bread: 4 stars
warm, buttery soft rolls

Oysters: 3.5 stars
Garlic butter is delicious but the oysters taste pretty average 

Alligator: 4 stars
Delicious and tender, battered just the right amount. Chili mayo is a great complement. 

Smoked pork ribs: 3.5
A bit overwhelming with the vinegar rich sauce and could be more tender

Shrimp and deviled egg gumbo: 4 stars
Deep seafood flavor, the egg and shrimp stand out well. 

Pork cheek: 4
Tender, good sauce with green chilis and the sweet potato gratin had a delicately caramelized flavor

Ham hock: 3
Tender but too salty, I found the quinoa and yogurt side underwhelming as well

Lemon Meyer pie: 3
I'm sad the crust wasn't crusty. Filling was nice and tart but without a good crust it fell flat as a whole pie. 

Chocolate beignets: 4
The bitter chocolate filling was the highlight, we loved the richness. It wasn't overly sweet and the Vietnamese coffee ice cream paired well 

We avoided the cochon, their signature dish, because my sister said it was very salty and we didn't feel like having it.

Ate with Gabe L. but my ratings are a little different! Ambience was very clean and tastefully done. This would be great for dinner with friends though it's a little noisy and it might be hard to hear your dinner partners.

Bread - 5 stars
Pull-apart brioche that reminded me of the kaya/red bean buns you get in convenience stores in Singapore but fresh, soft and tastes like real bread/yeast.

Oysters - 3.5 stars
Garlic butter is delicious but the oysters taste pretty average 

Alligator - 4 stars
Great but the idea of eating alligator made a little queasy.

Smoked pork ribs - 2 stars
Really disappointed by this one because I love tender fall-off-the-bone ribs! The flavour was good but the meat was tough.

Shrimp and deviled egg gumbo - 4 stars
Good, rich flavour (I think it's the sausage) but a bit salty.

Pork cheek - 4 stars
Loved the sauce on this! With the pork ribs and the ham hock this was a bit too much meat for me but it was a good dish.

Ham hock - 4 stars
A bit salty on the top/crust but I thought it was cooked just right.

Meyer lemon pie - 2.5 stars
Very average, but it was nicely tart and not too sweet.

Chocolate beignets - 4 stars
Filled with a dark, bitter chocolate sauce, which was divine. It was a little dry so it would be delicious with vanilla ice cream! It came with Vietnamese coffee ice cream but I didn't have any because the caffeine would keep me up.

We didn't have reservations so we just arrived early around 5ish to get a seat at the bar. Although we originally wanted to go to the butcher next door as it was recommended to us, I really wanted friend alligator so we stayed at conchon. Great wine, great service, great vibe. Thanks for an enjoyable time.

From the moment I walked into Cochon, everything was perfect! The host was warm and welcoming. Our booth looked like it was made from reclaimed wood, it was amazing! Our server was so kind, and was happy to take our order as a whole and bring extra plates so we could all share the spread (party of 6). The atmosphere was fun, and we met a guest at another table through a funny IPhone airdrop exchange! Perfect place make new friends! The food melted in my mouth, and was tasty and exciting! We must have ordered more than half the menu, so I got a bite of pretty much everything! Rabbit with dumplings and the meat pie were my favorites. I will definitely be returning to Cochon when I come back to New Orleans in the future!

I've gone to Cochon a dozen times and up until today I had nothing negative to say but the service tonight was awful. The food was great as always but our two servers were terrible. We were ignored a lot and from the looks of it we were overlooked numerous times because the other tables in their section were ordering bottles. We would've ordered at least 2 more rounds of drinks and more food after we finished but they walked past us over and over again to get to the tables their other table. I will be back of course but what a bummer tonight was.
Had a creature in my alligator appetizer so nasty worst thing that has ever happen to me in a restaurant
Awesome form service was personable and excellent they made great suggestions. Eat at chefs counter if you can doubles the experience. Excellent in every way.

So good I went back on another business trip.  From cocktails to appetizers to entrees to service, everything was great.  I was there with good friends and colleagues so the ambient noise level didn't bother us, but for an intimate romantic dinner or with someone hard of hearing it may have been a challenge.
Depends what you get. I had the oyster sandwich (dense but great!), gumbo (nice and dark and delicious), Mac and cheese (not good- very over cooked pasta with a gritty sauce)

It was not the best choice for someone that does not eat a lot of red meat but were with a group of friends so wanted to be easy and try it. Definitely nice place and decor. We had the concierge at our hotel get us a reservation. 
I was a bit sick to my stomach from another meal somewhere else and a lot of partying, so i was a bit afraid i was going to get sick again since the menu all looked rather heavy.
However i was happy to see there were a few dish specials with fish and i went with their special grouper they had that night. It was delicious! over a bed of petit peas and pesto sauce, very yummy.
My friends all loved their food and appetizers as well. They tried the alligator bites (i did not) and said they were good but that the oysters were amazing.
2 of our group had the cochon and liked it, although one person said it was a bit on the salty side.
Overall pretty good.

Poor service, mostly underwhelming food.  Dinner started by seating us at the wrong table, and making us relocate.  The new table was actually far better, so we were very glad for the move, Im only mentioning this as an indication of their service.  They were very apologetic and had this been the only service issue I wouldnt mention it.  But this was followed by a dirty glass with lipstick, straws that were carried by hand and plopped into our glasses, needing to leave the table to find replacement flatware after clearing our appetizer utensils, no hand towels in lav, and an overall lackluster, unattentive wait staff.  

The recommended shrimp boulettes were deep fried rice and shrimp balls, which is likely similar to what fried cardboard would taste like. 

Alligator was better but still not what you'd expect from such a highly rated place.  My hamhock was good though a bit salty, and the quinoa concoction it was plateted on was bland and left uneaten.  My cuke salad was excellent and enjoyed far more than my entree.  

The jumbo shrimp and soybean dish came with 3 small 30ct shrimp with heads on, floating in a soybean mixture that was mostly untouched.  This was served in a small 6ish inch oval dish and looked more like an appetizer than an entree.  

The only comment heard on the rabbit was, "it's good",  again not what one would expect from here.  There was one dish that recieved very high comments from my friend whose family lives on the NC coast and eats plenty of uber fresh fish.  "This is the best fish I've ever tasted!"  With five diners, at least one of us had an amazing entree.  

All desserts were only partially eaten.  

After several farm to forkish meals in NOLA, I think i need to lower my service expectations.  Even though the prices are similar to far more formal restauarants, they all lacked in good service.  But unlike the others, Cochon did not make up for it in wonderful food.  We did take lunch at Cochon's Butcher and the food we had there was amazing!

Had 10p reservations because that was all that they had available. Walked 0.8 miles to get here and it was not worth it. Waiter didn't introduce himself but according to the tab, he is 203 T. He never checked on us or offered refill. We wanted to start with appetizers before diving into our meals but it never got to that point. We ordered the wood fire oysters 4/5, mac and cheese 3/5 (very small with a strong cheddar taste), and fried alligator bites 2/5 (very dry and gamey taste but the bf liked it). We had to ask for our bread 3 times before it finally came. I had the canal street car drink and it was horrible. The bf didn't like his drink either, it was worth remembering what it was. Dropped $70 for 3 appetizers and two drinks for a waiter that would rather chit chat with his friends (group of 4 girls celebrating a bday) and eat with them during his shift than do his job. Yes I saw him sit down for a few seconds and take a few bites from one of their dishes. I was irritated and hungry so I asked for the check and we went to look for whatever was still open cause it was already past 11p. Not sure why this place has such good reviews but I won't be coming back or recommending to anyone else.

Total segregation. Black sit outside , white inside. We waited 2 hrs from NYC , just to be seated outside .. totally ridiculous! Very terrible based in this areas  history, but very appro secondary to gentrification

Tonight I had to get to a restaurant quickly I was getting hungry.  I was suppose to go to Cochon Butcher but accidentally accidentally came here.  I assume they are both the same company.  I ate the oyster bacon sandwich with lettuce and tomato and come with chipotle tartar sauce.  I had the sauce on the side.  Yum!  The oysters were fried.  As soon as you bite into the sandwich all the flavors start crunching in your mouth.  The bread is toasted so it adds to the crunch.  I highly recommend it.

Went here by recommendation and reservations are the way to go. It was quite busy and moderately loud. The servers were certainly hustling and were as attentive as to be expected during such a busy dinner rush. We sampled a bunch of plates and REALLY enjoyed them all: butternut squash soup (of the day) with chili cream, spicy herb cucumber with vinegar, smoked pork ribs, meat pie (the most flavorful I have ever tasted), and mac n' cheese. They were all so tasty and actually worked really well together. All in all a super tasty meal and positive experience.

Just the facts, 
Recommended by a couple of foodie friends. 
Made reservations a couple of days in advance on open table only 5.30 and 9.30 pm reservations available. Took the 5.30 pm 
Arrived at Cochon at 5.30 and was seated in the back room of the large restaurant. Beautiful simple decor with large tables. Plenty of empty tables through out our meal. Promptly ordered our drinks and food. Drinks came out with dinner rolls right away. 6.30 pm no food not one dish. Asked our server "oh its coming right out". No apologies,  6.40 my wife spoke to maybe a manager in red. 6.50 our table was discussing about when we were going to get up and leave. 5 minutes later the food came. 

Alligator 
Pork cheeks 
Louisiana Cochon
Lima beans
Redfish 
Boucherie plate 
Beets
Fried livers 

Two items we ordered did not make our table, the ribs and the collard greens. However, at this point we did not want them anymore. The food wad decent but not memorable.  Just the facts $190 before the tip No Apologies just the truth.
We had an excellent meal here. The fish, alligator appetizer, and duck specials were stand outs

This place was so good I went again on a second trip to New Orleans! The food is locally sourced, and has a rotating menu. The crab balls were delicious. In the late summer they serve boar's heads! The reason it was four stars is they don't split checks- else a great dining experience!
Another NOLA Jewel! Don't miss this please, you'll be mad. The ribs, the sausage, greens and chicken collard greens soup. We'll be back!

The short: damn good meal in a really nice ambience. Highly recommend! 

The longer: we came for dinner on a Saturday night. I was pretty glad we were able to make a reservation online (book in advance!). We had mezzanine seating & 2 very lovely folks helping us. 

We started with alligator bites (dreamy perfection), grilled oysters & the beef cheeks with sweet potato. The flavors are amazing. The alligator is perfectly crispy on the outside & tender on the inside-- the bite with the sauce & mint made us pretttty damn happy. It seemed like every single person in the restaurant had an order of the oysters (5 per order), so we decided to see if they lived up to the hype: they did. 

For dinner, I wanted a simple piece of fish, so I got the fire roasted fisherman's special with a side of collared greens and bacon. The fish was perfectly cooked, and I was SO impressed that I didn't have any bones in the fish. I could bathe in the collared greens. 

For dessert, we shared beignets. They were also delish. We enjoyed every bite of this meal! Would highly recommend this spot!!
Excellent. Friendly and fun staff, incredible food. Loved it!!! Sit at the kitchen bar, warm and inviting!

Man this place is popular, but it's worth the wait. Don't worry about making a reservation so close to closing (we could only do 930pm), once your seated they don't rush you at all. Chili oysters, ribs, alligator, beef short rib, and Mac n cheese were more than enough for two. All had good flavor. The Mac is baked, but is in a heavy cheese sauce (not my wife's favorite style). The sauce has great flavor though. The ribs were tender and the sauce had a little kick. The alligator was pretty good. Might as well try it but almost like tougher chicken nuggets in a heavy aioli. My wife lover her short rib. After hating oysters my whole life (only had raw) I tried the grilled chili oysters. Totally different and totally delicious. Had an excellent whisky/bourbon selection and made tasty drinks.

Cochon was the last place we went to for a lunch before our flight and it was the most memorable restaurant for me. It wasn't too busy when we arrived so we were seated right away. When we we got seated, the sun was blinding some of us so the servers were nice enough to put up the blinds to ensure we had a pleasant meal. I had the oyster and bacon sandwich and it was literally one of the best sandwiches I have ever had. The oysters were fried to perfection and it was quite a hefty meal. I tried some of my friend's fried alligator as well and that was also so so so so good. The food came out quickly and hot and this place is a must for anybody visiting NOLA

Food was pretty good- I got the rabbit with dumplings and also the alligator with the mayo.  The complimentary bread was superb and went so well with the rabbit dish, which was a bit salty.  The dumplings were okay - kinda tasted like chewy doughy biscuit.  I felt like this was a hyped up tourist trap - there's many similar in quality restaurants back in Orange County.  Wait took an hour for a Sunday night and they kindly text you when your table's ready.  We killed the wait time by having a beer across the street.

The food was pretty good especially the fried livers in pepper jelly and the wood-fired oysters. I had the oyster and bacon sandwich - even the bacon was burnt and oysters overdone.

Unfortunately, this place is like a frat house party.  Many tables of 20 or more out of control young people screaming - bachelor and bachelorette parties and birthday parties too.  I guess it's that kind of place and that how the make their money.  But deafening and extremely disturbing to other diners.  I'm hoarse today from trying to converse with table.  I would not go back.
Definitely get the oysters and the alligator nuggets. The cocktails are off the hook be aware they are stronger than expected. Macaroni and cheese is amazing however fattening

Had the smoked ribs starter which were fantastic. The creamy grits were to die for. The red fish Fisherman's style, too, was also delicious. I'm not an oyster fan, and New Orleans is full of oysters, but friends in my party loved their version too. Terrific food all around!
The wood fired oysters were delicious. Its perfectly fired to melt in your mouth. The alligator were tender and not too chewy. I would come again.
The fried alligator and mac n' cheese were both really delicious. Portions were kind of small given what you pay for, however good service and excellent ambiance. Outdoor seating as well, huge plus.

I was a little disappointed with the amount of reviews and rave I've heard. 

We ordered a ton of stuff for three: the mac and cheese (yum! Get this, nicely crusted), the short ribs, the pork cheeks, the fried alligator, the boudin balls. They gave us a complimentary pate dish, but it was underwhelming as well. Everything was either overly salty, heavy and/or tasteless. I'd honestly just go to Cochon Butcher! It's friendlier on the wallet and stomach! 

All in all, it was a pretty expensive meal too with how small the plates were.
Service and food was meh.  Wouldn't go back.  And the ribs were dry and had equity too much vinegar.

This place is extremely hyped up and I've been here on 2 different occasions, once for dinner with a large party and another time for lunch with my husband. 

Both times the derives was okay. Meaning the food arrived promptly and the waitstaff was attentive but I have noticed that both times, the servers aren't very friendly and borderline hungover.

The atmosphere is cool! It does get a decent crowd for lunch and make sure you have reservations for dinner, cause it gets packed! 

As far as food, it's awesome that you can see the kitchen staff doing their thing from the dining space. They have their stuff together and the head guy is calling out the orders as they come in. To me that's pretty cool! The food entrees are okay, the appetizers are superb! 

Started off with the fresh rolls!! Always a win with fresh bread and butter! 

Fire roasted oysters - best thing in the menu! Had so much flavor but has a fresh, clean & light taste. They don't overpower it with butter or cheese. It's cooked to perfection. 

Crawfish pie - more like a crawfish empanada. This is really good too, had an etoufee inside with the crust on the outside.

Entrees:
ham hock with quinoa and yogurt. I like the freshness of the yogurt but the ham hock was ok. Just a big chunk of meat with a rub on the outside. It was cooked mediocre, the meat was a little on the dry side but I'm not sure now it should have been cooked. I was hoping for it to be a little juicier. 

and rabbit dumplings - thick and hearty, good flavor but nothing spectacular. 

$90 for everything we ordered. I would probably get more of the appetizers and share vs getting an entree. I also tried the Louisiana entree last time and walked away thinking it was just ok.

Cochon was the first reservation I made once we had booked our first trip to New Orleans. Even upon checking into our hotel and speaking with the concierge, they were enthusiastic when I told them of our one and only "set plan"- Cochon. 

We went on a Sunday night and I don't think we realized where it was in relation to the French Quarter- to us New Yorkers, it was off the beaten path. The place was jammed! Space for outdoor seating and a beautiful large space indoor that seemed to go on for miles. The space is gorgeous and exactly what you picture when you think of a butchery. 

Food- 

For starters we got the fried alligator (when in Rome, right?) and the pork cheeks with sweet potato gratin. Both delicious. Alligator was kinda like rock shrimp- is that a good thing? Yeah? I just was hoping for a different, more unique flavor. The pork cheeks was my favorite dish of the night I'd say. 

We shared two entrees: the Louisiana Cochon and the braised short rib. Both absolutely delicious. The Cochon has a pork sauce that, believe it or not, was a little too porky! I know that seems silly to say in a restaurant that oozes pork but- the dish could have used a slight contrast in flavor. But again, amazing. 

Oh and the Mac and cheese. Yes!

Overall, another great meal in Nawlin's. Looking forward to trying Cochon Butchery the next time we're in town!

Hmm... 

This will be a bit of a very personal review for Cochon. 

This was my first time in Nola & some of my friends did research and recommended Cochon as a great restaurant to try when Im in the city. 

1st. The restaurant takes reservations - YESS, finally I wont have to wait in line. That's a great perk for a SF resident like myself. 

Make reservation a couple of weeks in advance to grab a good time slot - mine was 9pm, I was starving when I got there. 

The food menu looks good, we were splitting dishes so we can try a bit of everything. 

What I love: 
- Fried Alligator : it was sooo soo delish 
- Oysters: BEST DISH THEY HAVE (and they are famous for their pork - I know) 

My take on their signature dish? - Cochon something something ? MEH and also for the pork cheeks. MEH. I am sure people are crazy over these dishes, I think Nola people eat hella salty (probably the way they prepare the food) but I felt like I didnt enjoy these 2 because it was too salty for me - So for those who are aware of sodium intake, prepare yourself. 
But the way they prepare it, I think it's very well crafted. 

Pricing is reasonable, I need to give a non biased review on this despite my experience. :) it is worth the experience & food quality. 

If I come back, I would try the prosciutto plate & cheese of theirs

Amazing oysters! First trip to NOLA and went here twice! Great service, making a reservation was helpful for the wait, and fantastic drinks! Smoked mezcal cocktail was fantastic! Licked the sauce off the oysters. The hype is well worth it. The fish and BBQ and alligator were all delicious as well. Would go back in a heartbeat :)

This is literally the best meal I have ever had. From Bangkok to Barcelona to Manhattan, this establishment has beat all competition. Every single dish I had was outstanding! Even the bread and butter was a culinary experience. I can now see why there was a line out of the door on a Thursday night. Well worth the wait! This was my last meal in NOLA for this trip, and Cochon made it count. I will 100% be returning to this restaurant and to the city to which it belongs.

Oh yeah! Best meal I had in new orleans. Got the ham hock on a bed of quinoa and some other ham dish that was a fried ball of pulled ham on onions. They were the two most expensive dishes on the menu and they were very much worth it. Got sides of collard greens and Mac n cheese.

I hate Mac n cheese. Theirs however was the absolute best I've ever had and I wanted more. 

Collard greens were really good.

All around highly recommend and suggest people go again!

This is worthy of your dinner plans....their signature plate will not disappoint! The atmosphere, service and food make for a great evening. Portions are large enough for lunch tomorrow and creative & fresh enough to make you plan another trip here! Do make plans for here!!

The food was good but the service not so much. I had two servers assigned to me and the one lady was great but the other guy was terrible. I don't know why I had to be stuck with the guy during the latter half of my meal but he gave off the air that everything I asked for was an inconvenience. I asked at the end of my (very filling) lunch to pack up my key lime dessert and he basically rolled his eyes. Then when I opened it up to eat it later that evening it was missing the entire shortbread on the bottom and the sauce was omitted from the box. Super depressing. I'm just glad he has to split my tip with the gal who actually seemed nice. 

The food was not bad but don't be fooled-despite the name, I think that their Cochon dish is not the best thing on their menu. Order something else. Their gumbo was not bad either but I think I should have chosen something else to eat.

The other thing was that the demeanor of their cooks wasn't really great. There was some cool who seemed to be training another cook and they didn't seem to get along very well and that one guy was not being very polite to the one he was training.

Oh well, I'll try them again next time I'm in town and we'll see how it goes.

I was slighted disappointed from the high reviews this restaurant has. The boucherie plate and catfish courtbullion were not bad, but the fried alligator was too chewy, the beet salad was very small and the braised beef short rib was too salty. Maybe I set my expectation too high before entering the restaurant. But the bread they served before meal was truly delicious!

Came here for dinner and good god I will be dreaming about this place for a very long time. Had dinner upstairs in a nice, secluded area with a group of 10. Definitely nice to have a quiet space to enjoy dinner and each others' company. Only downside? No restrooms upstairs. They do take reservations on the weekends which is nice.

Service was top notch. Food came out in a timely manner and our waiter was really great. Handling our party mostly on his own, he did an outstanding job with our requests and not forgetting things. 

One menu item in particular will stay with me forever. The woodfired oysters with garlic chili oil. So good I ordered another. Without a doubt, the best bite I had during my entire stay in NOLA. The braised short ribs were just alright.Definitely don't think they pushed enough flavor into the actual meat itself when they were braising it. The mushroom pilaf was a nice accompaniment to the meat. Not salty which I was pleased with. Twice baked potates were okay. A little drier than I would've like. Shortbread cake was good and light. Chocolate beignets were a pass for me.

This place was recommended to me by a bunch of locals and for good reason. Make sure you call for a dinner reservation because it will be packed!
The food is amazing and based around meat and seafood. We got the salad and pork boucherie plate to start. The salad, though we got it to help our consciences about not eat healthy, was delicious and perfectly dressed. The pork plate had a variety of cured meats and a pâté style pork spread which was AMAZING. 
for dinner I got the special pork tail stew and a side of Mac and cheese. I can easily say I kept stuffing myself although I was full because the food was so flavorful and amazing. The pork tail was fork tender and melted in my mouth, and the Mac and cheese was perfectly baked with an ideal pasta/ cheese ratio . The only thing I can say about this place is that I wish I had another stomach so I could try more of their food. I definitely hope to be back here the next time I'm in NOLA!

So much fun here! Pork shoulder was so great, the pork rinds on top were an unexpected treat! The waitresses were super attentive and the chocolate cake was sooooo good! Thanks to the staff for the glass of milk!
There isn't a more reliable spot for an excellent lunch in this pork-centric spot.  Terrific!

I came here with a group of friends for a bachelorette dinner.  The setting is nice and the service was good.  The food itself was very heavy and salty and I would not recommend this for this type of event.

Amazing food! We accidentally went here instead of
The Cochon Butcher but we were very pleased. Everything we ordered was amazing. Great flavors! We loved the hot pepper vinegar on the table. Service was great and food was quick!

We had lunch here on a Sat. The place was packed and we didn't have a reservation. There were two of us and we got seated at the bar, which was a fun experience. The soup was excellent. I have had better fried oysters in other places. There was a bit of a wait for the food, but it was a good experience overall.
We ate here on Friday afternoon the oysters were great the beef cheeks were great and we had only small plates and local beer very impressive tomorrow we will try butcher next door

We loved our meal.  Made a reservation and there was no wait during a busy Nola weekend.   THE OYSTERS!!!! I will forever dream of this dish.  The eggplant and shrimp dressing! Great drinks.  The Redfish was also delicious, but the other two dishes were stand out and memorable.  Collard greens were also delish! With so many amazing choices, I am so happy I chose Cochon . We will definitely go back.

It was on the everyone's recommendation list so I thought we have to try it on our first visit to NOLA.  There were 3 of us and we ordered quite a bit: 5 drinks, 4 appetizers, 3 entrees and 3 desserts.  Being underwhelmed is an understatement.

I always keep fairness in mind and I truly hope that our experience is not the norm at Cochon.  Cocktails were solid.  Well balanced and spirit forward but not overwhelming.  Wood fired oysters were the best food we had that night.  Plump and juicy oysters, baked to perfection, with just the right amount of toppings.  But food overall was over seasoned and overcooked.  Ribs weren't tender, and they were soaked in heavy bbq sauce.  Vegetables were cooked to death and very salty.  Other meat dishes were all pretty much along the same profile.  Desserts were nothing special.  Similar to what you can get from a decent deli.  Fried alligators were ok.  I've had it few times before.  It always tasted like leaner meatier fried chicken to me.  it's not bad if that's what you are craving but I could get the same thing in NY. 

Another thing that threw me off was the service.  Southern hospitality didn't exist here.  Or did it only exist if you looked Caucasian?  Dare I wonder the fact that we were the only non-white party at the time had something to do with how our service was given?  I couldn't help not to notice that other patrons received warm greetings and farewells.  We got none of that.  I couldn't overhear the interactions between other servers and their tables but our waitress didn't seem to want to speak more than she had to and was not attentive.  She had the persona of a crass diner waitress.  

Sure, price wasn't bad for someone who is used to coastal living cost.  But it is on the higher end in the NOLA spectrum.  We had way better food and more thoughtful services at cheaper prices.  Maybe I'm actually being lenient for giving the experience 2 stars instead of 1.  Good cocktails & oysters could do that to you.

Came to Cochon for a nice dinner, plus our Uber driver spoke to how popular this place was.

The restaurant had a dimly lit, bar vibe. However, it was classy and it had a slight hipster ambiance. 

We ordered the fried alligator and mac and cheese on the menu, and an aged pork and fish from their menu of the day. The food was delicious! However, while it was very good, it seemed to miss anything special about it. I came to Nola expecting unique and exquisite food. However, most of these items I felt could be replicated anywhere else (outside the alligator.) 

The bathroom was clean and organized, as I expected somewhere this classy to be.

We were there for lunch. it's a lovely and lively atmosphere. the smells are awesome. the service is gorgeous. 
We ordered, as per the suggestion of the waitperson, the cuchon and the oysters.
Oysters were glorious!!! just do it. the only problem was there is no baguette to soak up the liquor. they do have cornbread-which we had to ask for-but i think french baquette would have been better. 
the couchon is served unadulterated. Pork-3 ways. a small amount o pickled watermelon, and some small bits of cabbage. Flavors, once again, fabulous, however, not accompanied by anything that you can scoop it onto or combine with. 
overall, a nice experience, but lacking in completion of culinary thought.
Bad people and okay food. Not worth the price. The place is obviously mismanaged and they messed up the reservation we had gotten 2 months in advance. Very disappointed.
I drove 10 hours to eat here and I'm glad I did ! The braised cheeks and hominy grit cake is to die for! The Louisiana cochon is great along with the wood fired oysters !

I came here for lunch while at a conference at the convention center. Although not noted on the menu, there are gluten-free options. My server was knowledgeable about the menu and kitchen cross contamination possibilities. I had the dry rubbed ham hock with quinoa, herbs & goat yogurt. (I was advised that there is a cross contamination issue, but I haven't had issues with other restaurants of this caliber; FYI-I had no problems] I sat at the chef's table and got to see the action live! Great restaurant.

Can we please teach people how to cook pork like this in the Northeast? Damn! Loved all the meat we had - ham hock, such smoky flavor!! Ribs were amazing, beef short rib was yummy, fried alligator was great. Rabbit and dumplings turned out to be like a pot pie, FYI. Only thing not fantastic was the gumbo, which was much too salty - somebody probably tripped while holding the salt shaker that day. And that house made lemonade makes a great Arnold Palmer.

This place was fabulously classy and lived up to the hype!  MAKE RESERVATIONS.  We came here on a Tuesday night and wouldn't have been able to get in without reservations.  Here's my only beef with this place, and it's not just here, it's the reservation system in general.  But when I make a reservation for 8:30, such as I had here, I expect to be seated within 10-15 minutes of my reservation.  My husband and I got there promptly at 8:30 for our reservation after have drinks & apps next door at Cochon Butcher, and we weren't seated for another half hour.  They clearly over reserve this restaurant so you're just seated whenever something happens to become available and as long as there aren't other people waiting for their reservation ahead of you.  The food was delicious.  I had the catfish courtbouillon and my husband had the oyster and bacon sandwich.  Both were absolutely incredible and the sandwich was rather large!  We didn't have dessert because we were so full afterwards and from our apps before.  I will say, I did leave thinking how salty the food was, which isn't necessarily the best last impression.  However I would still return again for the food and to try more off the menu.

The bar, the drinks, and service deserve at least 4.5 stars. The food on the other hand is a different story. I came here because of recommendations and reviews. Place was packed and had a nice atmosphere. The bartenders were amazing. We ordered alligator appetizer which was just underwhelming and forgettable. The main course, oyster bacon sandwich entree was very very salty. The Louisiana cochon was superduper salty. The way the food was seasoned and cooked resulted in an overall lack of balance. I was disappointed.

When you first walk into the restaurant and hit by an amazing smell of pork, you know you've made the right decision. We shared the hock ham and charcuterie board. The hock ham was tender and delicious, and the charcuterie board had a good variety of meats. The service was friendly and professional.

Great local spot for dining. Wood-fired oysters and fried gator was excellent. Catfish was decent. Great ambience, and the staff was very attentive. Chocolate beignets for dessert. They have a lot of pork dishes but we didn't quite feel in the mood for them (preferred seafood). Would definitely go and visit again.

I had high expectations that were unfortunately not met tonight.

Overall the food was underwhelming.  Certainly not the food that so many have raved about, both friends and critics.

Fried alligator?  Really not very good at all.  We didn't finish. Chewy. 

Bread?  Soft and warm. Probably the best part of the meal.

Oysters? Meh

Braised beef? - Meh.  Bland.  On a bed of rice that could have been at a taco bell. 

Cochon pork - again. Bland. Dry. 

Sides! Stick with sides! 

Mac and cheese - good.
Lima beans - yummy

The best part was the lime sorbet dessert.

Service was fine... But probably won't be back.

If the food wasn't as satisfying, this review would have been 1 star. The hostesses was not at all accommodating to me and my friends. They told us there wasn't any more seating for us, but can wait for a spot to open at the bar. Okay. We arrived at 9:15pm on a Wednesday night. This would have been cool, but they were seating parties that came in after us. And no - they did NOT have reservation. I do believe it had something to do with how we looked or the way we were casually dressed. It was quite odd. 

We ended up waiting it out for 45 minutes and finally snagged a seat at the bar. The cocktails and food were great. We had the chargrilled oysters, alligator, rabbit dumplings, and the ribs. All were made quickly and tasted amazing. The gator and oysters were spicy, so take it easy if you're not about that life. I would give the food 4.5 stars. 

As we left, I looked back through the window and the hostesses were looking directly at us and snickering among each other. I'm not a professional at reading faces or body language, but I'm not naive either. Let's just say we did not feel welcomed at this restaurant one bit. Rest assured, I won't be back.

This was a great dining experience. Ordered the gumbo, and one of the fish specials. I came in towards the end of dinner service, and was lucky enough to be seared by the kitchen facing bar. Watching and hearing the team cook was a highly entertaining experience. Orders were constantly flooding in. The kitchen manager was doing a great job coordinating dish delivery for each table. The staff was highly coordinated, and kept their energy up despite the deluge of orders. It felt like watching a top notch team cooking competition. The food was delicious as well.

My first time visiting New Orleans and this was on my to eat list. After reading all these great reviews about Cochon I had high expectations for this restaurant. Unfortunately it was just ok. The ambience was great, the servers were knowledgable and helpful but the food was a miss. We got the oysters with chili garlic butter was absolutely delicious (which is really why I'm giving this 3 stars)! The cocktails were also strong and pretty decent. That's where the good really ended for me. I got the cochon with cabbage and it was extremely salty. It was not really balanced out well. Had a few other side dishes and they were all blah. Portions were also small and I left feeling like...did I really even eat? Overall not memorable and lacking.

Came here for lunch and I feel like I ordered the wrong thing. I got the Louisiana Cochin which was basically pork with fried pork skins and cabbage. The plate needed more freshness than the little cubes that were sprinkled around and was just way too heavy for a lunch offering. The oysters looked like they were a better bet...

Amazing. Simply amazing. We sat at the Chef's Table bar and saw everything being made. We had the oysters, gumbo, rabbit dumplings, and ham hock. They also have some custom bourbons and bourbon flights that are worth checking out.

Delicious pork, liver and seafood with upscale composition and plating in a semi-casual ambiance.

I got the titular cochón. Imagine a warm dinner roll made out of tender shredded pork. Came on a spare bed of cabbage paper and pickled turnips (which turned out to be a strong synergy), and topped with chicharrón, referred to as "crunchies" on the menu for some reason. Possibly to avoid the Mexican-street-food connotation. I cleaned my plate. At a price point of $40 per, I expected no less.

A waiter delivered a "gift from the kitchen," a cured-meat-on-toast item that was inoffensive but not quite as good as the fried liver with pepper jelly I enjoyed as an appetizer.

Recommended, although I don't make enough to eat here with impunity, and the fare doesn't demand so much attention that I'd detour for it.

Short Review:

Best meal I've had in a long time.

Long Review:

Just arrived in New Orleans for the first time. It was a Wednesday around 3pm. Had to be back by 6pm to do some work so we decided to get a quick bite. Not sure how long we would be able to stay in NOLA since we were only able to reserve the RV park we were at for 2 days. So I did not want to waste the meal. 

Logged in to Yelp and saw Cochon was highly rated so we hit the road. Was able to find some street parking fairly easily around 4pm, not sure how the parking situation may be during busier times.

Service was great, we were sat quickly and everything came out promptly as it should. I'm not big on uppity fine dining type places. One thing I liked about Cochon is that it was almost like being at a fine dining restaurant without the fine dining uppity atmosphere. It was very casual.

We started with the baked oysters... amazing. Perfectly cooked and the sauce/seasoning was so good. Their bread was also very good.

For our main course I had the short rib which was one of the best things I've eaten in a while. The flavor was insane, the sauce, the mushrooms the fried onions all worked perfectly together. My girlfriend had the Cochon which while not as "intense" as my short rib was also very good.

So happy with the food we had so far we decided we had to try the dessert and what else could we choose on our first day in NOLA but the chocolate beignets. Now I've never had beignets so I honestly can't compare it to any other beignet. What I can compare it to is other desserts I've had and this was by far one of the best. The beignets were very sweet and you put that together with the amazing coffee ice cream which has a very good coffee flavor but is not overly sweet and it was a perfect match.

Two entrees, one appetizer, dessert and two drinks came out to just under $100. Rarely have I had a meal that lived up to a $100 bill, this one was totally worth it!
Great food! Loved Mac and cheese, pork cheeks and fried alligator. Strongly recommend it. Probably good idea to get a reservation. Malted chocolate cake is bigger than expected (and delicious!)

My sister and I were told by multiple people to go to Cochon when we got to New Orleans. We made a reservation and went last night and it was very good. We got the alligator, shirt ribs, oysters, and the mushroom salad. Everything was really delicious but my favorite were the oysters. The ribs were also insane especially with the pickled watermelon on top but they were very filling. I would definitely recommend this eatery. It had a nice vibe and it smelled amazing when you walk through the door. We left very full.

Currently my #1 favorite restaurant in New Orleans.  I have been to Cochon several times and have sampled a decent portion of their menu - though it is seasonal.  I've yet to taste something there that I don't love.  Just wish it was maybe a bit quieter.

It's hard to know where to start; with the efficient yet friendly service with a laid-back vibe, or with the creative menu grounded in the local tradition of excellence?

Either way, Cochon is a win.

We started with the boucherie plate.  Everything (including the "weird" stuff like head cheese and country pate and pork rillette) was a headliner...a real star.  The only complaint is that there weren't enough toasts included for the rillette.  But the flavors were all balanced, and the house-made pickles (cucumbers and tomatoes) were a great balance, as well as the whole grain mustard.

The next course saw the crawfish pie (HUGE and packed with mudbugs in a great sauce with a slight kick), fried alligator (good flavor and texture with a punchy sauce), fried boudin (sausage arancini, if you will, that were perhaps the best part of this course), the ribs (super meaty pork spare ribs) and the rabbit & dumplings (an excellent rendition...killer dumplings and lots of bunny).  Rounded out with twice-baked potato and the mac & cheese casserole...well, it was one for the record books.

As you can probably guess, there was no room for dessert, but we did our best to clean our plates.  While this isn't really a "mom & pop" locals joint (it is part of a "restaurant group") it really ended up being one of the culinary highlights of our trip.  

The service was spot-on; our group of 5 got seated right away as walk-ins, and the waitstaff was right on the money with recommendations and smiles.  

Total A+.

Great ambiance and staff....but a very disappointing final meal to end a excellent trip to the crescent city.

The garlic butter chili roasted oysters were amazing!...but it went down hill from there starting with the gator. The breading was light and crispy and the chili mayo waa really good, but I wasn't a fan of the flavor and texture of the gator.

I sent back the gator and got the ribs...ribs were not good. They were tough and I found the bbq sauce to be too over powering. Next came the Louisiana cochon which was unimpressive a well, a soggy flavorless mess...tho the cracklin was good.

Over all I was really disappointed. One potential  bright note is theey carry Pappy...tho they were sold out. I would definitely come back again for the oysters and a shot of pappy, but wouldn't dine again.

This was our best meal in New Orleans.  After getting a recommendation from our Street Food tour guide, we decided to dine here on our last night in New Orleans.  I couldn't get last minute reservations, but from others' reviews, bar seating was available for walk ins and we were lucky enough to snag the last to seats.  

We ordered the Short Rib over rice and mushroom gravy, Gulf fish cooked Fisherman Style, and Mac and Cheese casserole.  I was going to order a 4th dish, but I was glad I didn't.  3 was more than enough for 2 people to share.  

The short rib was cooked perfectly.  It was tender and full of flavor.  It was my favorite dish out of the three. The fish was my husband's favorite.  The skin was crispy and the fish was still moist and flaky.  The portion was large and could easily split for 2.  

Service was on point also, friendly and attentitive.  If we visit New Orleans again, this would be my first stop.
There's not a lot to say. If you like great food, great drinks and great service, this is the spot. Everything hit the mark.
We had lunch during a show at the convention center.  We sat at the kitchen bar.   Great show by the chefs.  Loved all the food

Delicious food, one of those places where the appetizers definitely outshine the entrees. I would highly recommend the oysters--the sauce is delicious with a kick. The fried liver with jelly sauce was also delicious a good combination of flavor and texture.
Amazing service and food!  I love this restaurant. Every dish is thrilling and an adventure of culinary tastes. Great personal service and attentiveness. I feel so happy with our party of 6!
This is a great place has awesome  employees and the food is delicious .  We walked in five minutes before closing and we're still treated amazing.  I highly recommend eating here.

Went here for my cousin's birthday dinner, it was a hit all around.  Good whiskey menu, extensive wine menu, and decent beers.  I had the mac and cheese and alligator as my meal - I thought it was fantastic - great sauce and the mac was super cheesy deliciousness. Would recommend
This place was stellar. I was in New Orleans for business and came as a single diner during rush. I had the duck stew and oysters appetizer and loved every second. Strongly recommended.

Ugly Delicious done right. 

Great service, each plate we tried was done with love and care. We tried the Rabbit n Dumplings, Oyster n Bacon Sandwich, Ham Hock, Mac n Cheese, Geens and Boudin. All were excellent! 

On my list for my next visit.

Everything about the food was excellent. We had the rabbit and dumplings which were outstanding. The Cochon was also excellent and unique. The wood fired oysters were incredible. Overall excellent meal. 

Our server was incredibly rude. My girlfriend does not drink often, but she inquired about one of the beers. We were also considering a bottle of wine. Our server said he didn't know and would go check and seemed upset about having to go check, he never came back with our answer. That wasn't a big deal. She likes iced tea as much as beer anyways. Next, we were deciding about what we wanted to eat. We put in an order for the wood fired oysters. Then chose two of the bigger plates. Our server retorted that we would need more food and should pick a side. I said "Okay, can we have another minute to decide I didn't even look at those." He replied, "It's not life or death, just pick one." So I replied, "I think we will be good with just the two dishes we first asked for." I was shocked! This was a celebration dinner, where we were coming in thinking we would spend whatever we wanted on our meal, we were only in New Orleans for a few days. He lost out on a significant amount of money because we would have ordered more food, probably desert, possibly a bottle of wine. I'm from Chicago, I guess I had a different idea of what Southern Hospitality is. Complements to the chef.

I would absolutely recommend this fantastic establishment to anyone! I was thoroughly impressed as soon as we walked through the door. Our cocktails were both exceptionally crafted and delicious, and then there's the food. 
The FOOD IS AMAZING! We ordered starters and meals and filled our table with cocktails and food! Probably too much for just the two of us but it was an excellent decision. Everything was delicious! I'm definitely coming back and I tell everyone who is going to New Orleans that they must go!

Don't confuse this place with Cochon Butcher which is a sandwich place in the same space on the other side of the building (like I did). Anyway, the appetizers were the stars here. The mushroom salad was fantastic. The oysters were also great. The ribs were decent.

I had their lechon entree and it was just ok to me. Nothing amazing. My wife got their rabbit dish which they forgot to give her, so she didn't get it until everyone else was almost done with their meals. Also, she was convinced they used chicken & not rabbit, but who knows haha.  Their gumbo is decent but certainly not the best around. Service was a little spotty and prices were high. This is a hipster place so you also have that going on. I don't think I'd rush back, but if I did, I'd definitely get the mushroom salad.

Our last night in New Orleans was ruined by Cochon .
This place came highly recommended and I don't see why . We ate at commanders palace last night , and that place lives up to the hype. Cochon was the opposite . 
Service was one star 
Our waitress, man , no greeting , no smile, no nothing...
Asked for a sample of soup as it sounded like it could be really good or really bad, Sorry , we can't but I will ask.
