She never gave us a answer , just decided to skip it.
Ordered all of our food at once , and everything came at once , over a hour later , 
Entrees were set down , then appetizers , then their complimentary bread , then our salads .
I guess they don't Believe in spacing things out ,
Food was  meh 
Ordered desserts for some sort of redemption ,
But those too were sub par. 
I would skip this place and hit up all the others that will deliver to your expectations. 
I guess when they find out your not a local ,
They don't give a shit .

I normally don't write reviews for places but will take the time out to do one if the restaurant was out of this world amazing, or a complete utter failure. I was extremely disappointed in this place last night. We were visiting NOLA for a few days and had very limited time, so I had a specific list of restaurants scheduled for my family to try out. Unfortunately this was the worse experience we've ever had. From the moment we were seated, our server was rude and not friendly it all. She made us feel like we were a burden to the point that we didn't want to ask her for anything. We sat there with only water for over an hour. We didn't even get any bread until we asked for it since my family was starving after an hour. All of our food came out at the same time. Appetizers, soups, entrees, and the food was lukewarm. I think service was so bad that it ruined the food experience for us. I felt really bad because I hyped this place up for my family for awhile and the expectation was very high. The only thing that was good was that the manager was very nice. After we voiced our concerns about our server, he was very attentive and said he will address the issue with the server. This place gets 1 star from me because that's the lowest I can select on Yelp. If it were my choice, it would get no stars.
Amazing.  The pate and smoked salamis are excellent -- pulled pork was top notch.  Any restaurant that serves Mexican Coke always deserves high ratings in my book!

My friends and I went here for lunch after a trip to the WWII museum - We had just missed the lunch crowd so had no problem getting a table.  

We were in town for vacation, so after a few days of eating mostly bar food and drinking watered-down beer and super-sugary drinks, this place was a much needed change of pace. 

The Alligator appetizer was absolutely amazing, and the Gulf Fish was delicious. The staff was also super friendly and was happy to share tips about their favorite dishes and share their favorite places for us to visit while in town. 

If you're looking for elevated southern food, this is the place to go!

Jay Z said, "don't argue with fools, cause from a distance you can't tell who's who." Words to live by from The Black Album circa 2003. That's also the last good album he's released, so its been a good 15 years since he's dropped any real knowledge. I like to throw random shots at Nas' biggest fan from time to time to rile up his "Stans," so here's the obligatory But I Digress...

I bring up the aforementioned gem because I argue with a friend about pork all the time. For some reason he doesn't partake in the beast for archaic reasons. He thinks pigs are filthy animals, and I hope he didn't get that reasoning from Jule's in Pulp Fiction. He's not a religious fellow so I can't surmise that's his reasoning either. Not that eating pork would have kept us from passing through the Pearly Gates...we both led seedy lives in our youth, and the shenanigans of 2001 could solely keep us out #neverforget. 

Regardless, I don't argue with him anymore about it. I just tag him in every picture I post on social media that includes pork. Hey, I'm petty like that.

I bookmarked Cochon via recommendations online. I'd say I got it from Eater, but then I wouldn't be a company man...and, I want another Review of the Day, so let's just say I used Yelp.

Cochon is a french word for pig, dirty swine, or something along those lines (maybe my friend was right). You didn't think your boy was cultured huh? I learned that in France, as boucherie plates are my thing, and if you hang out in butcher shops long enough you pick up a few things here, and there. You're welcome.

I got here right as it opened at 11am on a Sunday, and a line was already forming. I'm not sure that's a good sign or not as people line up those for highly overrated beignets on Bourbon Street. Give me savory over sweet any day.

The first thing that was ordered were the wood fired oysters with garlic chill butter, and boucherie board. The clams came out first, and they were smokey, and as advertised, a bit spicy. Definitely good, but I think I prefer my mollusks al natural. The board had pickled veggies, pate, head cheese, sliced pork/hams, and toasted bread to put them on. This is what I came here for. It was all excellent, especially the head cheese.

Lastly the Cochon was ordered. I didn't know what it was at first, so I had to ask the waiter. He told me it was shredded pork rolled up into a ball, and lightly pan fried. It was accompanied with cracklins, pickled turnips, and cabbage. Cracklin's are like upscale pork rinds, and mixed with the meat were great. The cabbage was flavorful, and also complemented the pork well. I can't say I've had something like this being a gringo from Alaska, but I am now a fan. 

You know, I'm not sure my friend is on Yelp. I might have to ask him to join, and follow me (as you should all be doing), so he can see pork is a thing of beauty. While I do that, get the boucherie board, and check out my other reviews of New Orleans cause I got a few coming people. Until next time, salute!

Excellent! Superb! Decadent! I absolutely loved it here. Not to mention this place was incredibly trendy, hot and happening. I loved the vibes, from groups celebrating birthdays, to groups of girls dressed up in sparkles for a bachelorette, to our little casual group of 6. I absolutely loved it. Felt very welcome and at home here. 

The Wood-Fired Oysters with Chili Garlic Butter are an absolute must!!! 
I mean even if oysters aren't your thing, the flavor, the texture, the tast will definitely change your mind. I was so sad when I was done with my appetizer that I wished I had ordered a second plate. (Yes, they are that good). Also the shrimp and deviled egg gumbo is a must too. Just add that to the list. 

I'd say skip the Cochon plate, it had a unique particular flavor to it, and stick with the small plates and boucherie to share with someone. We had the Smoked Pork Ribs with Watermelon Pickle and these were pretty tasty, flavorful, messy, definitely going to see some hand wipes later on, which they actually give you after!

We also tried the Boucherie Plate, which was filled with crouton crackers, pickles, and prosciutto like meats. Excellent Plate to Share!

I also want to make sure that if you haven't already guessed that this restaurant is called COCHON, so plan on a lot of pork dishes. So full disclosure.

Now for dessert. THE CHOCOLATE BEIGNETS will help you recover from the itis and get you on to your next destination in New Orleans. The vietnamese coffee flavored ice cream mixed with it is absolutely delicious.

We had dinner here on Easter Sunday. Many cocktails choices, we ordered black magic woman and gin lime. The drinks are strong!! We love the small plates, aligator- so good, ribs, salads - the only disappointing dish was the shrimp salad. Love the atmosphere. We sat at the counter so we got a show of how the cooks work. Kind of like at Benihana. Plus we get to see how the dishes are presented. Highly recommended!

Quite frankly I was a bit underwhelmed overall.  The Oysters to start were outstanding and the flavor unmatched.  But the Shrimp appetizer was very basic, as was the main fish dish my friend ordered.  The Duck and dumplings I was happy with.  Nothing was bad, but only one item truly stood out.  In New Orleans where the competition is thick, I expected more.

A Cajun restaurant with a classy feel!  

We came for an early lunch on a Monday & was seated immediately.  Such friendly, attentive customer service, & even better food!

Fried Alligator with Chili Garlic Mayonnaise:  This restaurant has, by far, the best fried alligator I have ever tasted!  Crunchy outside, juicy inside, but what takes the cake is the savory, delectable sauce!
Pork Cheek Sauce Piquant with Hominy Grit Cake:  Tender, tasty pork cheek.  Loved the pairing with the grit cake.
Wood-Fired Ousters with Chili Garlic Butter:  Yummy sauce & scrumptious oysters!

This is going to be a divisive review.

I personally, would never return to Cochon. The honey? Loved it and put it in his top three restaurants in NOLA.

My personal feeling is that the dishes during our visit were not flavored with a subtle hand or by a chef with a defined palate. They do not sing together as one, they overpower and attempt to one up the others leaving you slightly nauseous.

To start off our experience we tried the fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise. The alligator was delicious, but the mayo felt cheap and used far to liberally. I wanted to wash it off.

Next up came the poached shrimp. Not to mince words, it was straight up terrible. One bite and I refused to go back to it. Since the cucumber was overpowering and bitter the honey and I then discussed the fact I have the PTC gene and he does not, so things by nature do not taste similarly to us.

Finally, and thankfully my rabbit and dumplings (which were overpriced for the size) ended up being the saving grace of the meal. Had I stuck with just that plate and not tried any other dishes I would have probably had a higher review. While the dish was overseasoned and very rich, with the right type of bread (not served) it could have been a winning dish. As it was I enjoyed it and it saved a very poor dining experience overall.

Again, I wouldn't return - but it's definitely to some people tastes more than others.

Was recommended by a few Uber drivers not being from around here that it is a must visit.
Worried that it may be over hyped, I have to say Cochon definitely delivered from atmosphere to tingly tastebuds by their unique food options . Would def recommend for anyone  heading to NOLA.

What else can I say that hasn't already been said? Cochon was amazing. Not without a few faults, but a thoroughly delightful meal. 

We started with the chili butter oysters, and believe me when I say you want to your order, do not share with your tablemates! The chili was delicious, enough flavor without being overwhelming and I didn't find the oysters gritty like I've had at some other NOLA establishments. We also tried the boudin balls which were light and fluffy and tasty! My entree was the short ribs, and it was perfectly cooked, great flavor, no complaints. I would have liked the greens to be a bit for seasoned, but I like my greens on the salty side. I probably wouldn't order the specialty ice cream again, but they comped us due to a delay in getting it out to us so it was fine. 

We made a reservation (Tuesday evening at 7:30) but probably would have had to wait if we were a walk-in around that time. Service was great, I appreciate that they had 2 servers on each table. Overall, great meal, great experience!

Cochon is more modern and updated compared to the typical French Quarter fair. The food, drinks and service were all excellent. I would describe the food as "elevated cajun". We enjoyed all of the dishes that we tried. My husband and I got a bunch of small plates to share. I would absolutely make a point to eat here if you are in the big easy! It is a nice change from the touristy places in the quarter.

Seen Cochon on a few food shows and knew we had to try it when we came to visit NOLA. Has reservations for Saturday night which was a good thing because the place gets packed. We ordered the braised beef ribs, Louisiana Cochon plate, Mac and cheese, smothered greens, friend livers on toast, and last but not least, the grilled oysters with chili garlic butter. Those oysters we're one of the best things that I have ever eaten in my life. So good. I wanted to drink the sauce on them but our waiter brought us more bread so we can sop it all up. I will be dreaming about those oysters in years to come.

Yummy.  The hardest part of this restaurant is making a decision of what to eat.  If you're dining with friends, I suggest ordering multiple different sandwiches and sharing halves.  Too many you will want to try.  Good cold beers and delicious sandwiches, walking distance to the WWII museum.
We have the corn and crab soup. I had the shrimp platter and my wife had the same. It was so good we eat there the next day for lunch

Most impressive dinner I've had in a while. The oysters are a must. Everything about this place is on par. We are from California and stumbled onto this place by a Lyft drivers recommendation. It did not disappoint.

Hey yo.

I've wanted to come here since Phil from Somebody Feed Phil dined next door. After attending WWE Axxess nearby, I decided to take my friends here to dine on some legit southern food. If you've ever seen the Netflix show, you can say I was making the same faces that Phil makes when chomping. 

Chomped:
1. Fried Alligator - tasted like chicken.

2. Boucherie Plate - came with an assortment of ham, head cheese and paté. I didn't figure out how to properly chomp this to balance out the flavors until I combined everything and stacked them on the crouton crackers. The saltiness from the prosciutto was balanced by the bitterness from the mustard and sweetness from the pickled veggies. 

3. Smoked Pork Ribs - smoky and tender af. 

4. Louisiana Cochon - a pulled pork dish. Overall, I thought this dish was on the salty side. 

5. Rabbit & Dumplings - rabbit also tasted like chicken. Make sure to soak this up with some bread (other than the dumplings). 

*Notable mention - sliders; this reminded me of the bread they sell in the Chinatown bakeries (奶油餐包). So soft and buttery!

Otherwise, the decor was hip and trendy, and they even had a wood oven in the back with an open kitchen! Overall, I would come here again when I come back to NOLA to try all the other offerings. I saw the cooks making wood-fired oysters which looked absolutely mouthwatering.

Made a reservation for 12pm and they did not disappoint. Started off with the charbroiled Oysters which was surprisingly better than the one at Dracos due to its chili flavor. 

For our main we sampled on the house special Cochon which reminded me of a dish from back home called Kalua pig with a NOLA flare. Loved the crispy pig skin that complemented the pulled pork centerpiece. 

For a side we got the double baked potatoe which was covered in baked cheese for a crust. To finish off we went with the strawberry shortcake which had the right amount of cream and cut strawberries. 
Overall, it was a great way to start our day in NOLA!
Ended up here accidentally - I meant to go to their sandwich place. No regrets. Yummy great service, great oysters, delish pineapple desert.
Had the Cochon and it was great, but the best thing is definitely the Mac and Cheese.

I have been next door to The Butcher and equally love Cochon. I can spend hours upon hours at both because of the impeccable service. You immediately feel welcomed, at home and they are on point with recommendations with pairing drinks for each course. I think my server could even recommend something to pair with a napkin that's how good he was. Lol seriously do your sel a favor and get the fried chicken liver with the pepper jelly. I thought I was done after that....for life. On a deserted island last thing in my mouth...yes. I had to wait and wait. I hadn't eaten all day either. They were so sweet and kind with me and eventually I moved to the next course pairing with wine then finishing with a cocktail. Everything was heaven. But seriously. Chicken livers!

I had to come here since Nicholas Cage raves about their wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter (B+). It didn't live up to the hype for me. It was good but wasn't comparable to Felix chargrilled oysters. Granted they are both made differently but there was no wow factor. 

What we ordered:

poached shrimp with grilled cucumbers, basil, chilies & clam broth (A-)
- refreshing and light, best dish of our entire meal

louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklins & pickled turnips (C)
- not enough flavor and punch, not memorable 

Our waiter seemed grumpy which added to our undesirable experience. While I was eating I was hoping another waiter swapped with us but nope we had to endure the pain of ours. Was watching his mannerisms with other patrons and he definitely was someplace else in his mind. Negative vibes suck.

The restaurant is definitely a hipster joint. I don't particular care for the pretentiousness. The tables by the wall are placed TOO close together which creates an uncomfortable ambience. 

We couldn't wait to get out of there and walk over to Felix for chargrilled oysters where the service is unpretentious and the smiles are plentiful. Skip.

Upscale modern fusiony place with lots of unique dishes.  Most dishes were decent.  

The best items for the group was ribs and fried livers.  There were double orders of those.  

Fried alligator was decent.  Tasted like chicken.

Crawfish pie was on the bland side but crawfish was tender.

Fried boudin was ok.  Not my type of sausage.

Rabbit & dumplings was not good.  Rabbit wasn't tender enough.  Dumplings was bland.  Tasted like dough.

But had an amazing variety of unique and some decent dishes.  Good for visitors to New Orleans.

Read all the accolades about this restaurant so decided to give it a try, plus it was open until 10 on Sunday.  My reservation was for 9 PM, but they kept saying 9:30 and seating others.  Fortunately I had the confirmation on my phone to show them.  Still had to wait extra time until we were seated.
Much improved after that. Our server was busy but very good.  The food was tasty, but really, $7 for the loaded stuffed potato???
Be prepared to wait to be seated and bring earplugs if noise bothers you, but you'll have a good meal.

Been to this place several times. In fact, Kyle Maclachlan just dined there two nights ago and put it on his insta! Everything you get here from any food item to any drink is perfection. (Well there was the one exception of the dry- super tiny and flavorless strawberry shortcake) Everything else has been great. This was the only place in my life that made oysters appealing enough to actually try and they were delicious. I will probably never say that again about them anywhere else! Great gastropub vibe and wonderful service. $$$$ Make a reservation FOR SURE.

James Beard Award Winning

That being said, the food and the service should get different ratings.

Food was a 5/5. I am sitting here, in snowy Pennsylvania and my mouth is salivating at the idea of their chili garlic butter oysters and catfish courtbouillon. I wish I had multiple stomachs so I could have kept eating. My friends also got the porchetta, cochon, mac n cheese, grits, braised short rib, and rib appetizer. I only heard positive things. We were scarfing the food down.

The other side was the service. This is partially on us because we had 9:30pm reservations and maybe they were in a hurry to be done. However, at a restaurant of this caliber, I expect more from the service. They did not communicate with each other. This led to multiple visits where they seemed confused. Then one of our orders was forgotten. All in all, I think the food made up for the service, but I think this should e acknowledged.

Like the other 2K reviews I concur that the food here is amazing! We started with the oysters and it was divine where it had the perfect balance of buttery, tangy and a hint of spiciness. Please make sure you order at least 3 oysters per person (comes as 5 oysters/order). The shrimp with black bean was also tasty but the winner is definitely the oysters

This was our second time dining at Cochon. It was spectacular! Servers are well trained and were very accommodating to our one year old. This is what I wish every dining experience was like! Delicious food, great service and a wonderful atmosphere!

This place was OK. Saw the hype and all the reviews on yelp but after eating there, didn't taste anything special. The grilled oysters and fried alligator were probably the best things we ordered. 2 people from our group don't really like oysters but they really enjoyed these. As entrees we ordered the catfish and the cochon. Nothing too special about either from what I could tell. Ambience and eerie seemed fine, though they did forget our oysters until we reminded them.

Incredible restaurant! I recommend the alligator and the chargrilled oysters to start. Both a little spicy and incredible. Best oysters I've had in NOLA. Tangy and spicy and perfectly cooked. The alligator is battered and fried, crunchy on the outside, in a Buffalo type of sauce with mayo. Excellent!

We also had the mixed green salad with the goat cheese. We had to order the Louisiana Cochon (their signature dish). We liked it but didn't love it. We also got a side of the Mac and cheese (which was amazing!). Their collard greens were ok, a bit salty. Overall we enjoyed the apps better than the main course.

Service was very good.

We had dinner here and it was amazing! Service was on point, the food cooked perfectly, and a good drink selection.  I would recommend two three things: Cochon, oyster appetizer, and the boucherie.  Especially the boucherie.

New Orleans is a unique place. It's a melting pot of various cultures and styles of cooking that contributed to the  fabrics of the society. The narrow old streets , the musics and creole cooking smells everywhere. All cultures, songs and different styles of cooking were intertwined here in NOLA . It was a nice breezy day I decided to take a walk. I was looking for something different, found this place to have dinner. The place was very simple. Even half of the tables were empty I was given a seat next to kitchen. The whole place was noisy. Informal atmosphere. Small menu. The service was great. Grill oysters with butter chili was very tasty. Love it. The shrimp was refreshing with cucumber and basil leaves. The whole Grilled Red Snapper made my day. I was too full to have desserts. Price was $$$. Parking on the street, hard to find. Good place to have lunch and dinner.
Oyster and ribs = awesome. So good. This place is awesome and close to convention center. You need to come check this place out. You won't be disappointed.

I came here while in town in New Orleans because of the great review and I wanted to try some true New Orleans food.  I made reservations online and requested a booth as well.  I checked in 30 minutes prior and was told that the table wasn't ready.  I came back 30 min later and was told that the thing available was a half booth that was right next to other people.  I was ugh.  Seriously?!

    Other than the seating,  I was ready to eat some food Cajun Creole food from Louisiana. There was complementary rolls which was very tasty woI ordered the alligator and oyster appetizers.  I also ordered the Louisiana Cochon with cabbage and a side of Shrimp and Eggplant dressing. 

     Omg, the alligator and oysters were perfect and off tha chain.  It's amazing as everybody on here has said it was.  The Cochon was very good as well.  The Shrimp and Eggplant was just awesome.  I wanted more when it was all done. lol.  I highly recommend this place if your in the area.  Total bill was approximately $63 and well worth it.

I nearly called the po-lice to have these people arrested. Such good food CAN'T be right! The crowning touch to the unbelievable food and incredible staff was watching the sun go down and the curtains come off through the windows. A magical place

Came here after work one day and snagged a spot at the bar. I ordered two apps: the grilled oysters (garlic chili) and the fried alligator.

It was my first time having alligator so i didnt really know what to look for flavor- or texture-wise but it was solid esp if you include the mint in your bite (major key alert).

The oysters were very intense but delicious. Super buttery, garlicy, and a little spicy (not hot) for five amazing oysters. I looked like a fool eating them and scraping tiny pieces on the inside -- so worth it though.

The food is very nice with good flavors. Had the gumbo and the wood fired chili garlic oysterd for a late lunch. No crowd, relaxed atmosphere and the restaurant is open and airy. I'm sure it's different at dinner but it was a great experience.
Food fried oysters and fried alligator a must. Great atmosphere and food! Definitely will visit again just for the fried oyster!

Absolutely delicious with a great, casual atmosphere, and the pricing is good. I had the rabbit and dumplings, which was perfectly cooked and an excellent portion size.

I would love to come back and try more of their dishes!
Had the most amazing ribs and shrimp and eggplant dressing. Friends had the short rib also amazing

Went on the recommendation of my tour guide and was initially excited when I could get a reservation. We walked there from Bourbon Street this place was only 1/4 mile from our hotel in the garden district. A little deceiving from the outside but we were told they had expanded and we sat in that section with high ceilings and light wood everywhere. The menu is quite limited and I since my friend was getting the oyster sandwich I got an order of the boudin balls that came with a pickled peppers (almost like a sweet pepper you would put on a sandwich) and grain mustard(my fave) the rolls they give you are mini sweet rolls - if you have ever been the Quincy's or Ryan's you would know it when you taste it. I got the rabbit and duck dumplings and my friend got the fried oyster and bacon sandwich that came with slaw on the side.

Regarding my dumplings - even though the cast iron is not particularly huge the meal is dense and heavy. The rabbit was well cooked but the overall plate had a sweetness to it that I was not expecting. I had to salt my plate a couple times (I'm not looking for a dessert dinner) the dumplings where doughy and looked to almost be biscuits on top and the carrots and potatoes were the perfect size. I didn't finish my meal - it felt heavy almost instantaneously but my friend powered through. Regarding the sandwich - it was huge and he loved it. No complaints there. 

Drink wise I got a glass of sauvignon blanc and my friend got Smoke on the Water. I enjoyed mine but they stated there drink wasn't that strong.

Service was great and I can see why people like the place but I'm okay never going back.
Best Smothered Greens I've had.  Mushroom salad was interesting with mix of herbs and fried beef jerky.  BBQ sauce on ribs with watermelon pickles was great.

Cochon means pig in French so if you're going to check out this NOLA-unique joint, don't skip out on some delicious pork. The service here during my visit was perfect--southern hospitality at its best! It's almost like we had 2 servers who were very attentive to all our needs. I even brought my 3-month old who was being extra fussy and difficult.

I wanted to give this place 3 stars but the service was too good. I'd say it's a solid 3.5 and rounded up, mainly losing points because of saltiness. I ordered the cocktail, Smoke On The Water, and it was too salty (salt on rim of cup). I got a different cocktail and didn't like that either. I also ordered the Louisiana Cochon and it was too salty (needed some rice or something on the side to balance it out). The only thing I really enjoyed was the braised pork cheek (appetizer).

I'd say anyone who is looking for a higher price point of yummy N'awlins grub, then check out Cochon! Maybe skip on the cocktails and get an Abita beer.
I sat at bar bc wait was long. But Dionna was my server/bartender and service was great! I had the lamb sandwich, which I recommend. But then again I would recommend ANY meat from Cochon!

Have you ever had food so good it makes you cuss? Let me first say that I am not a fan of small plates. So it goes a long way when I tell you that Cochon, despite its small plate offerings, was delightful. I was visiting New Orleans for work and cozied up to the bar for a solo dinner. I had the oysters and ribs, which was plenty of food for one and didn't feel like small plates at all. The oysters were drenched in a garlic butter sauce that I couldn't get enough of, and the ribs were rich and meaty. When the ribs came out, multiple people at the bar remarked at how good they looked and smelled. Strong whiskey cocktails as well that are unique plays on traditional drinks.

We loved everything...atmosphere, service, menu, drinks. The rabbit dumplings did not disappoint and might have been the most delicious meal I ate during our stay in NOLA. Get a side order of the cracklings. Yum!

Cochon was on my list from the moment I knew I was going to New Orleans. I was so excited to be there, and I really wish that it had lived up to the hype, but it did not.
Items Ordered:
Fried Alligator - The chunks of alligator were a good size, and the batter was decent, but the sauce was honestly kind of gross. I usually love sauces like this, but this tasted like under-seasoned warm mayo. The pickled onions and mint in the sauce were barely perceptible. I ended up removing the actual alligator meat from the breading and enjoying that on its own. 
Boucherie - The meats themselves were bland. I expected an array of salty pork goodness and received a variety of things that somehow all had a similar flavor, just with different textures. Paired with the toast points (which were delicious), the mustard, and the pickled vegetables (house made bread and butter pickles were the best), it was just okay.
Smothered Greens - Delicious. The second best item we had. They had just the right amount of bacon, vinegar, and kick. 
Rabbit and Dumplings - served in a small skillet, but definitely heavy enough to be a main course. Comes with four dumplings each about the size of an egg. The dumplings had excellent texture. Unfortunately, my serving only had one piece of rabbit that was about half the size of one of the dumplings. The texture of the rabbit was also excellent, I just wish that there had been more of it. Also, although the gravy had a silky mouth feel and was well salted, the herbs in it were so overpowering that you could not actually taste the rabbit, dumplings, or root vegetables.
House Lemonade - tart and refreshing, just a tad on the sour side, mellowed as the ice melted. Did a good job of cutting through the richness of the dishes and working as a pallet cleanser between plates.
Blueberry Buttermilk Sorbet - The highlight of my meal. Amazing blueberry flavor with an ever so slight tanginess from the buttermilk, sweet but not overly sweet, and great texture. A perfect dessert.
The service was great. You have two servers in your section so there is always someone available if you need anything. Both of our servers were extremely pleasant and helpful. 
Final thoughts, I was really hoping for an amazing meal here and, though it wasn't awful by any means, it wasn't $100 good.

By far one of the best meals I've ever had! The oven grilled oysters were cooked to perfection with a delicious sauce. Gator tail had some kind of spicy mayo sauce that was very tasty. Ham Hock delicious! Chicken livers the best I've ever had. I would have preferred them with out the pepper jelly as they needed nothing extra since they were perfect! Lima beans delicious, fennel special spectacular!  This place was so good that this is my first time ever posting a review on Yelp. If you go to New Orleans and do t eat here you are missing out!

To start the day of my favorite girl's bachelorette party, we went to Cochon! The atmosphere of the restaurant was great for us girls to chit chat over delicious food. Flavorful and fresh. Highly recommend their small plates/appetizers. Everything we ordered off the menu did not disappoint. Last but not least, what's a decent brunch in New Orleans without some fried alligator meat! Chomp chomp

New Orleans never ceased to amaze this Houstonian boy! I really liked my dinner visit at Cochon yesterday, it really made my second one-day trip in New Orleans complete.

We were very lucky to get a table without reservation at Cochon at around 8. The restaurant has a huge dining area, so it really has higher seating capacity than other venues in NOLA. Our waitress was extremely friendly as well! 

For starter, my friends and I had the wood-fired oysters and the fried alligator. The oysters were sooo good! I have to say these beat Acme for sure. They were succulent, juicy, and so flavorful with the garlic butter topping. The fried alligator was also tactfully done, though the sauce made it a little heavy. 

For entree, our group fell in love with the short rib. It was so moist and tender, YOU MUST TRY IT! The rice was also served with a flavor-pact sauce as well. Nothing I would ask to change the way it is! The ham mock, ok the other hand, was a bit too tough and dry for my taste. I wouldn't order that again. 

Tl;dr: order the wood-fired oysters and the braised short rib, you won't be disappointed!

We ordered 2 appetizers: the fried alligator and wood-fire oysters with chili butter garlic sauce.  The fried alligator was good and tasted like chicken. We absolutely loved the wood-fire oysters.  The chili  garlic sauce on the oysters was unique and quite different from the regular chargrilled oysters that's normally associated with New Orleans. The sauce didn't overpower the oysters and allowed us to still taste the freshness of the oysters. The oysters were well cleaned, plump and not gritty. For our entrees, we  ordered the ham hock and beef short ribs.  The ham hock had some sort of yogurt dressing on it with quinoa.  The ham hock was a little bit too salty for my taste but that may because I'm generally not a fan of ham.  I loved the beef short ribs with rice and mushrooms. It was extremely tender and fall-off-the-bones.

What a great recommendation! We were only in town for 1 day, and a close friend suggested I check this place out before heading out. We visited on a Tuesday afternoon just before the lunch rush. We opted to sit outside because it was such a beautiful day, which was a bit noisy because of the street traffic, but it was still quite enjoyable. We started off with cocktails, the "Black Magic Woman" and a local beer. Both great options and the cocktail was made to perfection. For entrees I went with the Rabbit & Dumplings $23, which was my first time trying rabbit. It was absolutely delicious! The flavor of the dish was very impressive, and the rabbit taste very similar to chicken in my opinion. We also ordered the fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise. Also my first experience. The sauce was not a great as we expected, but the gator itself wasn't bad at all. The service was absolutely incredible! From the moment we walked in until the time we left, the staff were all very friendly and helpful, not only to us, but to surrounding guests as well. I would certainly recommend this place to anyone visiting the area.

We love Cochon and Butcher. Everything on the menu is really tasty. Great smoked meats, fish and clever oyster concoctions at Cochon. The catfish courtbouillon is one of my favorites. Next door at Butcher, we always stock up on their terrine, pastrami and cheeses when we go to New Orleans for or bi-annual food fest. This is a classic southern experience. Don't miss it.

Reservation is a must at this trendy location. The food is inventive and cooked in a thoughtful manner. Service was prompt and portion sizes will not disappoint. The ribs were the only minus because they were too sweet. But overall the menu was fantastic.

Exceptional food, friendly service and all around great vibe. I had the oysters (best I've had so far), liver, shrimo and alligator - the flavor of the meat with the accompanying sauce were delicious and memorable.

Wow wow wow!!! 
This place was absolutely the highlight of my 3 days in New Orleans. 
Fresh tear and share bread which was still warm. 
For starters I had the special which was shrimp and rice boulettes which came with a mustard tartar sauce. They were fantastic! 
I then got the dry rubbed ham hock with quinoa, herb and goat yogurt. The smell was incredible. The ham was so tender and just fell off the bone. We shared sides of mac n cheese casserole and smothered greens. 
For dessert I chose the chocolate beignets which were filled with chocolate sauce and cake with iced coffee ice-cream. Amazing

Here's a tip, from the hostess to me to you: the menu is the same all day, so instead of climbing over people during a 2-hour wait at night, just come during the day with an open mind and mouth!

We returned for Saturday brunch after being turned away Friday night because we showed up too late for dinner.  So glad we did, y'all.  So glad we did.

Now, because it was a girls' weekend, no food item was off-limits.  The Blanche Devereaux (what you know about that?!) was an instant thumbs-up, while the Smoke on the Water and Black Magic Woman cocktails require a more refined palate.  Tasty, but He-man-strength flavors!

So then we had sourdough pancakes and pork ribs and mac and cheese.  Oh yeah, and roasted fish.  Like I said, we're No-Limit Soldiers.

Yumyumyumyumyumyum and yum.  Literally finger-licking good.  The barbecue sauce on the ribs squeezed a little body roll out of me, but everything that hit the table, including the yeast rolls to start, was delectable.  

Special thanks to our waiter, who had a lovely sense of humor.  Great service makes the food taste even better!

I have traveled to 5 continents and have had the opportunity to have eaten in some of the best restaurants. New Orleans food is my personnel favorite. 
I have spent a lot of time in the back bayous of Louisiana , Cochon captures the flavors of true southern cooking.  Nola is the true eating capital of the world hands down. Forget Paris, come to Nola for a true eating experience
Must have when down in New Orleans. The chili chargrilled oysters are a must. Louisiana Cochon was delicious. Excellent service. Will return if I'm ever back in Nola.

Cochon is French for domestic pig; and the food revolves around pork.  So you better really like pork if you come to Cochon.   I was with a large group at the convention center and got a chance to try quite a bit of the food at Cochon on a limited menu served family style.   This location is perfect for groups and people wanting a high end meal close to the convention center.

I found the food to be really good and well executed, but nothing really stood out saying this is one of the top tier restaurants in New Orleans.  That said, the service is great and they can accommodate large groups with a cross section of different starters and entrees.

That said, their companion restaurant, Cochon Butcher is really good and stood out in my mind above this location for lunch and carry out.

I've been trying to get to this spot for a few years when I'm down for Jazzfest and finally made it out for lunch. My crew and I were not disappointed as everything was top notch. Starting with a Bloody Mary, was a solid move. We then shared the boudin balls, Mac & cheese and chicken livers with pepper jelly. The chicken livers are probably not at the top of most people's list but it should be - delicious! We then shared the Cochon which was amazing and cooked to perfection. For the finale we share the pineapple cake and left full and happy to be at a wonderful spot in such an energetic city!

This is one of the few 5 star reviews that I've written.  

I hadn't visited New Orleans for a long time.   I decided to go to this restaurant because I was looking for some true local flavor and it was relatively close to where I was.

The staff were all very attentive and friendly - We were greeted by the Maitre D and assistant when we walked in and asked for some recommendations - They were super friendly, authentic and sincere.   The M-D said that he never liked pork ribs, but finally caved and tried them here.

Our server was really nice, described the various local brews that we were considering and described them aptly - brought us over some samples so that we could decide.    

We opted for a local dish - Fried alligator with chili garlic mayonaise -  - tender, slightly spicy, and delicious.  (I'd never had alligator, so no basis for comparison.)     I also ordered the Smoked pork ribs with watermelon pickle.   They were truly amazing!    We also split the Braised beef short rib which was also very good, but the pork ribs - OMG!

The decor is great too.

PS  I'm a hyper critical eater, wine maker, and my wife is a chef -  This place is really good.

Came here for dinner with a bunch of girls on our trip to New Orleans. The service was great and the food was good. Unfortunately i don't remember what everything we ordered was called but everything was great! The only  thing we ordered that wasn't as great was the T-bone pork steak. I found the meat a little dry. We ordered two fish options that was so good! Overall a nice place to have a great dinner!
One of the best meals Ive had in new orleans. An awesome menu of Pig. Cant go wrong.

Cochon is Creole/Cajun restaurant in NOLA. The service is solid, the food ranges from average to very very good, and the drinks are good. Good dessert. 

The restaurant is spacious and looks a cleaned repurposed warehouse. Cochon is next door to a Cochon Butcher that supplies most of the meat products.

We had a reservation 2 days ahead of time because this place looked very popular. 
We showed up to our reservation half an hour early and due to the volume and number of tables, we still waited until 7pm sharp before we were seated.

Food and Drinks:
The four of us started with hot ginger ale and root beer for drinks. We had wood-fired oysters with garlic chili sauce (2), fried alligator, poached shrimp, Louisiana cochon, fried boudin, Mac and Cheese and chocolate beignets. 

The Best:

The Hot Ginger Ale was very refreshing and palate cleansing. It was great after walking all day. And great with all the dishes. 

The Cochon came with cabbage, cracklings & pickled turnips. The pork was perfectly roasted, tender and juicy and the cracklings were so crispy and savory. I wanted a whole bag of cracklings! 

The wood-fired oysters were buttery, slightly spicy and very good.

The pouched shrimp was so simply done. It was clam broth with cucumbers and it was so clean tasting and refreshing. It was so different than everything else we ordered. And different from everything else we had eaten in NOLA for 5 days.

The good:
Chocolate beignets. This was a good take on a classic beignets. There was chocolate inside the beignets. And chocolate dust on top. It was very appealing.

The ok:
Mac and Cheese - it was simple and cheesy. I liked broiled crunchy cheesy top. It was not very different or unique. 

Fried alligator- it tasted like fried chicken nuggets with a mayo Sriracha sauce. 

Fried boudin- it was not very flavorful. It tasted like arancini with small tiny bits of sausage. But I wanted more of the boudin (blood sausage). I  would have ordered this dish from Cochon Butcher instead.

The service was very prompt and friendly. We weren't really rushed but could tell that they needed the table. 
Overall, the food was solid. It's hard to say if I would return if given a choice since there are so many excellent choices in this city.

instagram.com/snackchatnyc

Here's a restaurant where their popularity has gotten in the way of good service. After being seated, it took an hour and fifteen minutes for appetizers. When I asked the waiter about it, he seemed pretty annoyed about me even asking.

Sorry man, I came here to eat. Not watch 4 other tables get their whole service in the time it took to get appetizers.

I hope the main course is good, the appetizers were good, but at this point I'd rather have Jimmy Johns and come here for dessert.

Ok ok the entree was great. Like really great. 

So perhaps I'd offer this. Eat here, but only if you aren't super hungry. You'll enjoy the food, but it will be at the pace that they want, not what you want.

Wow wow wow!!! 
This place was absolutely the highlight of my 3 days in New Orleans. 
Fresh tear and share bread which was still warm. 
For starters I had the special which was shrimp and rice boulettes which came with a mustard tartar sauce. They were fantastic! 
I then got the dry rubbed ham hock with quinoa, herb and goat yogurt. The smell was incredible. The ham was so tender and just fell off the bone. We shared sides of mac n cheese casserole and smothered greens. 
For dessert I chose the chocolate beignets which were filled with chocolate sauce and cake with iced coffee ice-cream. Amazing

Fried alligators- kind of chewy and very heavy with the sauce. Didn't really enjoy it
Ham hock- a little dry
Louisiana cochon- pickled cabbages were pretty good and the meat was tender. The chicharron was not very good.
Service was very friendly.

I decided to come here prior to going next door to Cochon Butcher have a bowl of Gumbo and a glass of wine. The gumbo was deep, smokey and rich with chunks of chicken and andouille sausage. Out of the two Gumbo's I had I would say this was my favorite, but honestly it was a tough call to make. I sat at the bar and the bartenders were still busy given that it was 2pm and the restaurant wasn't full, so there was little time for chit chat and local wisdoms from the two bartenders. Next time when I am in town I will return for the gumbo and more. Much more.

I'm a 40 yr native transplanted to SoCal since 2005. This restaurant was one of the first restaurants to open post Hurricane Katrina. Boy, have I utilized it while trying to rebuild my life flying back and forth from LA to La...Los Angelas to Louisiana. It's stayed consistent over the years as being a great place for small plates to share with friends.  It's nice to enjoy many different flavors during your dining experience. Fried alligator, boudin balls, are just some of the tempting appetizers. This is more of a Cajun/Southern type of fare. Come hungry and stay a while. Be adventurous! If I buy a chefs cookbook then it's definitely kudos to the chef! I own two! I live in California since the storm and the cookbooks are a go to for me to spark my southern/Cajun roots s cookin' to the delight of all my SoCal friends. Many who have toured NOLA with me over the years since the hurricane. It's one of my go to spots.

The grilled oysters here are to die for. We ordered one for appetizer and one for dessert. That's how good it was. Loved the music and ambiance. Loved the food and the drinks. The service was awesome. What more can you ask for?

My first meal in New Orleans and it set the bar pretty high. Staff was very friendly and even attentive as well. Our waitress gave us great tips about the area and suggestions on things to see. 

Alligator appetizer
Just had to try it. Did have a weird texture but the flavor was amazing. This spiciness that kept kicking

Pig cheeks
Really good...weird but really good. 

Rabbit and dumplings
Probably my favorite...the dumplings with the rabbit was an amazing taste together

Cochon 
Sooo good. They inclusion of chicharones played really well with the tender meat and crisp Ines of the chicharon

Hamhock
Had never seen one that big. Amazing flavor and soft meat. Would have never guessed to pair it with quinoa but it was delicious. 

Fish
Soft and meaty. The seasoning again was on point. 

An amazing meal.

Wow! I am definitely not typically a red meat eater, but I saw this place as a must-try from the recommendations. It did not disappoint. I was a little hesitant about a wait but coming a little later around 8:15 there wasn't any during the week. The menu isn't all that large, but the choices were hard to pick! I went with the recommendation from the bartender and did the salad and the pork cheeks. All I can say was the salad was delicious and flavorful with generous dressing, which for me is fine but if you like it light ask for it on the side. The pork cheeks were completely tender and delicious. 

The atmosphere is laid back and a good setting. Service was attentive and friendly as well.

If you're a foodie don't miss this spot!

Traveling on business I always like to sample the local fare. Cochon seemed the perfect choice and it was also easy walking distance from my hotel. If you're into alcohol, they have an excellent selection of beer, wine and whiskeys. I had the Devil's Harvest Breakfast IPA that had a strong citrus flavor and would be a fine choice for sitting by the pool or at the beach. 

I started with the alligator appetizer because when will I ever have it outside of Louisiana?  It is served in nuggets that are deep fried in a spicy sauce. Very tasty! The IPA goes well with it. 

Louisiana Gulf Fish was my entree and the fish of the day was Red Fish, although I wasn't sure what that was. It was grilled perfectly with light seasoning. Flaky and delicious!

Make sure you go early since it seemed to get busy after 8.

Had a wonderful experience here. We chose 2 dinner restaurants to go to while visiting NOLA and this was the first (and way better) place. The interior is very spacious and smells great because of the wood fire they use to smoke. 
I was with a group of 5 and we sat upstairs. Immediately service was great, everyone was friendly, the runners were especially jovial and even helpful with suggestions. 
Me and 3 others decided to get a few small plates and an entree so we could try several things. The food came so fast! The cucumbers in vinegar were sooo amazing, and my friend really enjoyed the liver, while a little smokier than I like it, the ribs were also delicious and the pickled watermelon on top added something extra. Honestly the bites were all great, but we were actually less impressed with the cochon entree, it tasted like dry pulled pork, but the cabbage that came with it was the real winner. Wish we had gone with the rabbit.
The only disappointment was the dessert menu. Nothing on there intrigued me or made me want to "make room for more". Maybe they can get a little more creative with their pastry offerings...

But, with the tasty bites and great service I would go here again!

The reality is that it sits around a 3.5.

The food was excellent and they have a decent selection of craft beers on tap along with a good wine selection by glass.  We booked a table ahead of time and I would recommend this for all.  The place is big and gets very busy.

The staff were not very engaging nor were they overly friendly and I guess given hos busy they were they were removing plates quickly.  A plate was removed and hadn't even finished.

The removing plates and glasses while still in the midst of dinner is something that would normally cause me to give this place a 2 but the food pulled it back.

The bill was over 200$ and add 18% tip with that then it was a chunk of change that you would expect more from a service point of view.  

Please - do something with the service and a good bye and thank you would be nice.

Excellent dinner, we did not have reservations, walked around and were paged when the kitchen bar seats opened up. We were sitting right in front of the wood burning stove. I don't know what I enjoyed more - alligator appetizer, fire roasted oysters or watching chefs with "propellers" prepare dinner - these guys did everting but fly - it was nothing short of spectacular. Food was excellent!

Cochon was pretty tasty if you have a craving for pig!  The fusion of traditional southern comfort was refreshing to have in New Orleans since all you can typically find is the New Orleans staples (seafood and whatnot).  The tables were a little cramped; not a good place to people watch and talk a little smack! :) The food was great!

We stopped in for lunch after visiting the National WW2 museum.  The food is fabulous.  We had the pork rib small plate, which may have been the best pork ribs I have ever had.  The crawfish pie was great, and the wood fired oysters were one of the best things I have ever eaten.  Just fantastic.

Although the food was good (though not great), the service was abysmal. Admittedly we had a late reservation (a reservation nonetheless), but the staff essentially shooed us out midway through the main course. When we ordered dessert, the thought was met with utter disgust from the staff, who, at this point, were standing around waiting for our larger party of 7 to leave.  While I'm sympathetic to wanting to head home for the night, it felt very uncomfortable to have the restaurant chasing away paying customers. In addition, the servers' attitudes were condescending and not at all welcoming or warm.  New Orleans is a terrific food town, and service like this with less than outstanding food does not make for a long-standing establishment. None of the seven of us would return. Instead, go around the corner to the butcher shop -- excellent food, casual, fun, and a friendly staff.  That's where Cochon seemed to shine.

Interesting menu with delicious dishes. The small plates are not really small. The oyster and bacon sandwich was the highlight, but everything we ordered was a near match. I recommend  this place whole heartedly!

After having so many wonderful meals in NOLA we were exceptionally disappointed with what was supposed to be the most memorable meal. We ordered:

1. Fried alligator: a bit overcooked and smothered with way too much aioli. 

2. Rabbit and Dumplings: way over seasoned and the rabbit seemed like an afterthought with just a few small pieces. The dumplings were good but as a whole the dish was nothing to write home about. 

3. Grilled oysters: These were good but again, nothing special. We had similar oysters in two other restaurants for less money. 

4. Smoked pork ribs: these were cooked really well, but the smoke was so overpowering you could not tell these were pork ribs.

5. Fennel appetizer which was completely inedible. However, they did remove it from our bill. 

All in all, we would not return, as there are sooo many other wonderful places to eat in NOLA.

This is a "treat" spot for me, as my budget won't always allow for it.. but it's worth the cost every time! The specials change constantly, but there is also a permanent menu. There are honestly no wrong choices here. The bourbon selection alone is a draw for me, but don't miss out on the food. 

The ribs will leave you with sticky fingers and a saucy grin. Rabbit and dumplings has a hearty body and keeps me comforted and full. The stock and cream have a down-home Southern feel. At the very least, the Mac n cheese (also served at the Cochon Buthcer, next door) will bowl you over. It is perfectly baked for a crispy top and warm gooey core!

Last time I visited, they had a soft shell crab special. They added an egg wash, which isn't the way I enjoy crab (I prefer tossed in flour), but the flavors were buttery and unbeatable. Be sure to come early... this place fills up FAST!

Had a lovely dinner here tonight.  My server, Ryan, was super helpful and friendly. My food was perfectly prepared, with superb taste.  I can't wait to come back and try more great food!!  I had the crawfish pie followed by the ham hock.  Yum.  For dessert ai had the chocolate cake.  Also yummy.  If you need/want great food served by friendly folks, make your reservation!
Great vibe and good food, service was attentive. Enjoyed a solo dinner here at the bar facing the kitchen. Solid destination.

All things pork related! Service was spotty. We had to ask for the complimentary bread at the end of dinner, since they forgot to give it to us. Cocktail list was diverse and unique. Wine list was extensive thus able to pair with your food. Appetizers and dinner were unique to each own - Delicious!

Had a great lunch here before leaving New Orleans. Wish I knew about it earlier in my visit. We had fried alligator as appetizer, Louisiana cochon and wood fired oysters with chili garlic butter. Wish we could have tried the crawfish pie, braised beef short ribs and oyster bacon sandwich. Those last three were at the table next to us and looked great. Great service too. If you visit NO u have to try this restaurant.
I look forward to coming to this restaurant every time I visit new Orleans. I love it, fantastic food! Its a must you try it.

This was a stumbler for me as we where meant to end up at the butcher location next door. I choose the wrong door, haha! Beautiful restaurant with a relaxing but elegant feel. Bar was inviting in the large dinning area. Prices where spendy a bit but considering the menu they are slated as they should be. The drink price spendy as well for the size but again that falls to the more elegant side of the menu. Our server and all the staff was very friendly as informative. I ordered the braised rabbit dumplings served in a small cast iron skillet, the rabbit was tender but I did expect more of a flavor from the dish. My pallet is broad so the flavor was good but I expected a bit more (don't let that discourage you as it is a good thing to order tender vegetables and beautifully cooked dumplings on top) I also ordered collared greens with bacon they are DYNAMITE! Dessert was the chocolate cake. It was very moist and fresh. Great location, Clean, friendly a must go to have a more casual but Elegant evening on a NOLA night out! (Did I mention the rolls brought before dinner? I must of been busy licking my fingers to type that out, I LOVED THEM)

We were a large group of 12 and we ordered a variety of items from the menu. We went there during the lunch hour and the prices were very reasonable. Service was great and the food was amazing especially the pork and beef ribs and also the alligator. The gumbo was delicious as well. I highly recommend this place.
So good! Uber driver recommended it everything was unique and flavorful and just divine. Oysters were spectacular. Must add to your Nola trip especially if you're in the area.

Best meal I've had in New Orleans.  Doesn't have a dedicated gluten free menu but the staff was extremely knowledgeable. They physically marked all the gluten free options in pen for me on my menu. At least half of the menu was GF.  I got the wood fired oysters (best oysters ever!), roasted fennel, and the Louisiana Cochon which was incredible!

This place is awesome food 5 star restaurant, food was to die for elevated flavors, chili sauce oysters was so good we had a Second order.  Very nice and clean place, with great service. We loved it so much my wife and I kept ordering from the menu and left very happy. We can't wait to come back. Good job Cochon!!

This was my second visit to Cochon with several years in between.  The memory of how amazing the food is matched the reality of my second visit.  I absolutely love this place- I think it's the best restaurant in New Orleans.  Because people tell me, oh, there's so many good places- Cochon is just one of them, I tried other notable restaurants and let me tell you they don't even come close. Not even close.  I'm still dreaming of the whole roasted snapper topped with pickled onions and green beans.  The oysters- and I love oysters cooked in all sorts of ways - are so damn good.  Next visit to NOLA, I'm going to Cochon every night for dinner.  Forget other people's recommendations- I know what's good.

Ate lunch at Cochon while in town for a conference.  The food was unique and very good.  The way the tables for 2 are positioned, you have no choice but to engage those seated next to you...which is interesting...worked out OK this time...but that can be risky.  Price point was a little high in my opinion.
The fire grilled oysters were awesome!!! had the Short ribs and the wife had the Cochon (pork) both were excellent!!! Definite Go To.

We had the best meal of our vacation at Cochon.  At the point we plan to return to NOLA, one of the first things I'll be doing is making our reservation for dinner (maybe more than one).

Cochon serves Cajun/Creole and seafood dishes.  The word, cochon, is French for domestic pig, so as you'd expect, pork is featured throughout the menu.  They also have pig images interwoven throughout the space and dinner experience.  The space is a bit trendy and suitable for date night.

Reservations are highly recommended.  This is a popular venue and they get very busy.  We were seated at the chef's bar and had a front row seat to the high-energy effort being put forth in the kitchen.  It also made me realize that I MUST try the ribs the next time we dine here.  They looked amazing.

Having said that, the thing that has me day-dreaming about Cochon and making me want to return to NOLA are the wood-fired oysters.  GET THE WOOD-FIRED OYSTERS!  They are the best thing I've eaten all year - maybe longer.

That statement requires a bit of backstory.  I've never really been thrilled by oysters.  It's true.  I've tried them from time to time, maybe once every other year and they've always fallen into the A-okay zone.  I tend to migrate to scallops and snow crab first with lobster and shrimp ordered often.  Oysters typically don't hit my radar.  The wood-fired oysters at Cochon changed that.

They're so popular, I saw the chef responsible for that station putting them into the oven in trays of several dozen.  They're topped with an amazing chili-garlic butter.  HIGHLIGHT OF OUR TRIP - not an exaggeration.

We enjoyed the Rabbit and Dumplings for our entrée.  It comes in cast iron and had plentifully chunks of tender rabbit with potato, carrots and onion.  The dumplings were soft and absorbed the rich, savory stew broth nicely.  Altogether, an awesome comfort-food experience.

We passed up some of the richer desserts for ice cream to finish.  Then again, I'm an ice cream fiend and that tends to happen.  The ice cream was very good and came with a sugar-cookie garnish in the shape of a pig.

Final Assessment:  Excellent food!  Ingredients locally sourced.  Friendly, professional, service (our drinks were refilled regularly).  It took a bit of time for our food to come out but it was totally worth it.  We're mega-fans and we want more oysters!  5 stars all day long.  

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED
Cochon is salty and overpriced. Service is arrogant. Main courses are small portions and not worthy.
The food and service are excellent! The oven fire oysters are a must. chicken liver are also very good. The braised short ribs are delicious. We liked so much that came back the next day
Sit by the fire grill bar. This place is amazing. I highly recommend the grilled oysters!

I came in thinking this was Cochon Butcher. It's not! But I don't regret the choice since my partner and I had a nice, air conditioned, sit down lunch at Cochon. The food is very good. Oysters are amazing. 
I forgot to take a pic of the short ribs and the gumbo that we ordered. They were so good. The gumbo was the best I've had in NOLA. The servers were also friendly and accomodating. However, there's a bit of a wait 30mins for 2 people during lunch time. I suggest that you make a reservation prior to going.
Worst service in NO 20 minutes to get a drink and got my entree before my soup. All for over priced fair at best.

I would highly recommend this place in New Orleans for an upscale, dining experience. I was in town visiting for a conference, and a friend had recommended this place to me. I was a bit surprised - it was definitely more upscale (and more expensive) than the typical New Orleans spot that I was used to. I felt like I was eating at a five-star restaurant. The waitstaff was incredibly attentive, the menu was small but still offered a variety of dining options. The presentation of each dish was beautiful - and true compliments to the chef on this one! I tried to ham hock with quinoa and goat yogurt (which was recommend as a staff favorite). The ham was cooked perfectly, and the goat yogurt really added a nice flavor to balance out the saltiness of the ham. It is a bit expensive, but for the experience and the quality, I would recommend.

We came here for a date, hoping that we'd get a decent table until we went in a full house with a 45 minutes wait. We opted to be seated at the bar cos it allowed us to be closer. ;) 

Took a while to figure out what we wanted and we went for fried alligator with chili garlic mayo as our starter, Louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklin and pickled turnips and catfish courtbouillon. 

They were all amazing and delicious! We kept talking about all of the food the next day and how we wanted to come back before we went back home (and we never did). 

I would highly recommend the cochon - the best.
We had a delicious lunch and cocktail here on a rainy day while in town for a conference and sight-seeing. Great service and delicious food! Wasn't too crowded either, which was nice.

Worth the long walk from my hotel! Please make a reservation! We dropped in for lunch & got lucky that there was room at the bar. When in NOLA, please have their Alligator, which to me, tasted like battered fried chicken that was a little chewier & is topped with an amazing sauce. Then, the chargrilled oysters. I slurped a whole order by myself-also with a cajun sauce. Next, the gumbo-chicken, andouille, rice, just plain delicious. I could barely walk leaving but may I add to share their twice baked potato? Unlike any other. Crispy on the outside, smothered goodness on inside. Their butcher deli shop is also out of this world.

I will be dreaming of this place for awhile! 

The drinks are amazing here and pretty strong and the service was GREAT! 

I got the soft-shell crab which was the special and I must say, it was BOMB. My friend got the braised grilled beef and I tried some of hers and it was so good! I would definitely recommend! 

My favorite was the wood-fire oysters. OMMMGGG! Its a must get! I'm just drooling just thinking about it! The fried liver was amazing too. My friends told me it was probably the best liver they have ever had. I guess that says a lot.

I would definitely recommend this place!
Came here tonight for dinner and drinks and everything was excellent. Cocktails were fun. All the food we had was excellent especially the wood fired oysters.

Everything was great here, the service our waiter Ryan was very friendly and funny!!!! The food my Lord, in town from California and real food is in the South and here. You will not go wrong with ordering anything.

Went to Cochon in a group with mixed reviews from everyone. Here's my perspective. This place is attached to their butcher shop. This tells me they must be skilled with meat. So I ordered ribs with a side of Mac n cheese. The others in my group ordered fish. Guess who didn't like their meal?  The pescatarians. 

I'd definitely recommend the smoked ribs. Fried alligator was a treat. The braised beef bowl looks awesome. Mac n Cheese was on point too!

The short rib with rice pilaf was so good! The meat was tender, juicy and perfectly cooked. I also ordered the smothered greens. You can't go wrong with greens covered in bacon. The service was great and our server was very attentive! Highly recommend coming here if you are looking for a great meal.

You cannot have a bad meal here.  I have eaten here several times.  The grilled oysters are amazing.  Any pork dish you have is tremendous.  Pork cracklins are another level.  They have great bourbons, nice wines, and a creative drink menu.  The thing I love about Cochon is they were on the forefront of the farm to table movement and take that leadership seriously.  It is one of my top ten restaurants in New Orleans.  Plus, it's close to the National World War Two Museum.  You can walk off your lunch there!

Ya know, I wasn't too thrilled about this place when I walked in, because it looked really fancy and I'm more of a mom and pop sorta guy when it comes to local cuisine.  But I walked by the kitchen and I thought I was going to drool constantly.

So I didn't see what everyone else ordered but I'll start with the first.

1) we ordered the fried gator, which wasn't TOO much of a thrill.  But man, if you mix it with the mint its REALLY good, oh and of course the hot sauce

2) fried liver of whatever - pass

3) I had the catfish courtbullion.  It was like a stew, it was pretty good and it was just the right amount not to feel super bloated

4) but the main course, the FRIGGIN' Fried Oyster/Bacon sandwich.  MY GAWD, that was delicious, my buddy ordered it and I had a couple bites but holy smokes that thing was outta control good!!! WOOOO WEEEEE!!!

Great service, very clean venue, good place for a nice sit down meal.

Service was excellent here and the food was really good. I had the smoked pork ribs which were tasty. The gumbo was delicious. I did try the poached shrimp and that was good as well.  For dessert I had the chocolate beignet; It was really sweet but if you're a fan of chocolate, you'll like it.

Came here on a recommendation from a friend. The place is full/crowded so if it's dinner time(7:30 on a Monday for us), make sure you have a reservation or you'll wait much longer than we did WITH a reservation(20 minute wait). The air conditioner is WAY too high. Every woman around our table was VERY cold. Asked our server about it and her explanation was that it needs to be because of the kitchen. We were at least 20 feet from the kitchen against the wall (about middle of the restaurant). I switched seats with my girlfriend to try to give her LESS of the cold draft. Sitting in her spot was cold for me and I prefer temperatures of 60 degrees normally. Our server came off as snooty and a little too cool for school. Her assistant or partner should be the server. Much more friendly and aware. Now on to the food... I wasn't impressed. What I read on their Yelp menu WASN'T on the menu when we got there and the server was like "oh well" and corrected me when I pointed out the things that were missing by snipping at me that they were... until I pointed it out and showed her. I suggest a HUUUUUGE attitude adjustment!

Not worth the $90 I spent for two people. I went in with my girlfriend around 4pm they weren't even busy we go seated almost immediately and that's about as positive as my experience was, from there it was all down hill, it took 15min to get our drinks and another 10min after we got our drinks to get our order taken. We started off with the fried alligator and I order the oyster and bacon sandwich and my girlfriend ordered the louisanna cochon and the alligator was probably the best part. My sandwich in particular was very dry but my biggest issue was that I found pieces of shell in my sandwich which I had biten into twice, my girlfriends dish was equally as dry and lacked any flavor to add more to it took an additional 30min just to get our tab and get it paid. All in all very unpleasant dinning experience

Cochon was among my must-visit restaurants during our five days in New Orleans. I had long been a fan of Donald Link and have made many dishes from his cookbook. I also liked the idea of a chef from Cajun country making it in the big city.

That said, I was a little underwhelmed by our experience at Cochon. I was surprised to find the boudin, a Cajun specialty, wasn't links but boudin balls. They were ok, but I much prefer links and I was confused on why the menu didn't reflect they were balls. The menus at other places we visited, including Lafayette and Scott in Cajun country made the distinction clear. 

The namesake cochon dish was good, but wasn't anything that wowed me like the dishes we ate at Commander's Palace, Antoine's, Brennan's and Gabrielle, among other places that we dined. 

The service, while friendly, was more like I would expect from a more casual place than Cochon, which carried prices more apt for the fine dining spots we went to. 

Again, I was happy with what we ate. It just didn't match my expectations for a place that has gotten so many accolades.

I remember wanting to try this place five years ago when my friend and I stumbled across it. But to be a new (more cost conscious) 20-something then we didn't splurge.

Here I am back in NOLA this time with my husband and a more spoiled palate and looser wallet I had my opportunity. That's not to say this place is expensive. It really isn't in hindsight now. 

I made last minute reservations on the day of for 9:30pm.

We arrived around 9:20pm and the place was PACKED. On a Sunday. We weren't seated until 9:50pm and many others weren't seated until past their reservation times made either. The place was CRACKING.

But I wasn't starving and 20 mins wasn't terrible so I'm ok with that. If I was hungry I'm pretty sure I would've gotten hangry quick.

Between my husband and I we ordered the following:

- wood fired oysters: the freaking bomb! It was so great I can't stand it. Super highlight. At first I only saw 5 shells then realized that each shell was stuffed with like 4-5 oysters. 

- boucherie plate: we really enjoyed it! I especially liked the pickled accompaniment and the head cheese. It was a decent assortment.

- pork cheeks: didn't blow my mind. It was tasty enough but not the best I've ever had. I'm sure I'll forget about this fish soon.

- Mac and cheese casserole: very good! Cheesy, gooey, goodness.

- Louisiana cochon. Not sure how it's Louisiana. Felt more Asian influence with the radish and daikon. The crackling pieces and cabbage was probably my favorite part of the dish. The pork itself was a bit dry.

Service was fine.

As mentioned, prices are pretty reasonable now in hindsight. I would definitely return for those oysters!

Food is amazing. In NOLA for four days and ate dinner here twice! Customer service and ambiance outstanding. Drink selection out of this world. My husband ate the rabbit  twice.....definitely our new favorite. Wished I could have gone next door to the Butcher as well.

Beautiful restaurant, love the atmosphere and decor. Such a relaxing environment, love the wait staffs here and host. Came in on a Saturday, we rsvp ahead of time cause we have a party of 7 people. We basically ordered half of the menu and shared among everyone. Hahahaha. So let's start: 
1. Half dozen oysters wood fired- very delicious and a little spicy. 
2. Fried alligator- first time having it, taste just like chicken lol I would recommend to get to just so you can try it. 
3. Mix green- delicious salad, very fulfilling. 
4. Oven roasted gulf fish- big size and super fresh. A little spicy. 
5. Mac & cheese- always a great choice. 
6. Ribs- very good, like 3 pieces in a order 
7. Smoked greens- it was okay. 
8. Crawfish pie- I would recommend this!! Very delicious 
9. Grilled beef ribs- so good, melts in your mouth!! 
10. Fried soft crab- very good as well.

Ambiance 4/5: classic dining environment, high ceiling and large windows, soft lighting and comfortable seats

Service 0/5: ignorant and disrespectful, hostile body language and arrogant tone, unknowledgeable about their food, lack of hospitality, for example, while other table was served the hot bread right away and we've been seated for a while and got ignored so we asked for it, the waitress was so impatient and just told us to wait, no apology at all, by the time finally the bread came, we almost finished everything else, after we checked the desserts menu, we decided not order more since we were already disappointed about their food, she seemed like have the face showing she knew it, almost threw the bill on our table in the end, another waiter who occasionally helped our table was nice and friendly, but the waitress who mainly served our table was like the worst server I've ever experienced during my entire trip

Food 3/5: limited choices on their menu and so so taste
  wood-fired oysters with chili garlic butter - *** average taste
  fried alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise - *** deep fried
  pork cheek sauce piquant with hominy grit cake - *** chewy meat
  louisiana cochon with cabbage, cracklins & pickled turnips - *** it's supposed to be the signature dish here, very dry and salty, high expectation turned out to be a big disappointment 
  freshly baked bread - **** ironically the only food I like here is the bread, which we were supposed to get at the beginning but served in the end

Price 2/5: extremely small portions and overpriced for the quality, spend almost $30 per person, still left with empty stomach

Wow so disappointing. We were so excited to go here. We got a reservation. Seated and served quickly. Almost too quickly as if we were being rushed. Ordered the oysters, ribs, mac and cheese, rib roast, greens. ALL of it was SUPER salty. We barely touched the food and even sent the rib roast back. Not eatable! Wait staff is pretentious. The wine by the glass wasn't even gulp able. Terrible dinner!

Ate here with a girlfriend for first time yesterday evening. We were both disappointed. Had to send back the fried alligator appetizer as was TOO salty to eat. I had the Louisiana cochon with cabbage dish, a bit salty, thought fried cracklin with fried pork shoulder too much fried food on same plate. Girlfriend had rabbit and dumplings, more like a rabbit pot pie. Service was OK, we were seated in a louder part of the restaurant and had to ask waiter to repeat himself to hear him. Won't be returning anytime soon, many. I do say 'thank you' to restaurant for accepting my Emotional Support Service Dog in her carrier.

This place is architecturally gorgeous and the food is sumptuously delicious. The menu has some very original offerings that must not be passed over. The desert if pineapple upside down cake was divine

Fantastic as always. Just not a trip to Nola without a stop here. Everything was great from start to finish.  We actually weren't going to make it but squeezed in a Sunday afternoon stop on the way tot he airport to complete the JazzFest Weekend.

I do love me a good all around package and this was it! I just picked from yelp food closest one. Alright let's go to it! First the place has a nice atmosphere good music and good vibes from all their staff. The drink options was diverse and had good options for a fair price. The appetizers, well I had the Woodfire oysters which were amazing, right after the hot soft bread buns. Had a local beer that had a flamingo on the Handel it was urban South Park lager or something. Anyways so far everything was coming out fast and just perfect, great presentation and great taste.... (dreaming about more oysters). Then I order their famous plate Louisiana concho which was pulled pork, then after oven roasted with a bunch of goodies. The list was long and I wanted it all. After I chose to get desert which their blueberry tart was great, even though I am a chocolate lover and just tried to come out of the box and try something different. I think it was a great place and will come again. Deliciousness!!!!!

Food was delicious. Their fried red fish was rich with tangy flavors and the crusting added another level of texture. The atmosphere is modern and warm, with lots of wood textures and relaxing dim lighting.
The staff, however, was not all that friendly. I did not feel welcome and they were lacking the "service with a smile attitude." Granted, if this isn't a big deal for you, I would still recommend eating at this restaurant.

This is a 2.5 star review:
