The rabbit & dumplings tasted like a bland stew. It was apparent that everything was very fresh. The mix of flavors just wasn't quite right and needed more seasoning. 

I had a rum cocktail with rum, lemon verbena, lime and ginger beer. It was excellent. The rest of my party had beer. 

You'd think with all of the above, we'd be full. We weren't, so we ordered the pineapple upside down cake, the chocolate chip cake and the banana bread pudding'y thing. The pineapple upside down cake was the best of the bunch and it was good-to-excellent. even if it was the size of an ice-cream scoop. The chocolate chip cake was good and had a nice, light texture. The bready thing with the whipped cream was probably the biggest disappointment of the evening. It tasted like a bun with whipped cream on the top and doused in rum. The bread itself wasn't sweet, so it wasn't good.

I really wanted to like this place, especially since the service was stellar (barring the bread issue). But it just didn't work for my family.

Ambience is nice. Restaurant is clean. Service was excellent. Food was LACKING! Flavors were off and the food needed seasoning. The rabbit and dumplings came highly recommended. It was a very average, and bland. It would be fine for $8-$10, but for $23 on that one dish, I expect a lot more. At least something unique in the flavor, or a bit of seasoning. The alligator just taste like it was fried and tossed in thousand island dressing. A bit weird for me, I usually LOvE the taste of alligator, but not here. Not a fan of the chili seasoning used on the oysters, didn't pair well. The crab "salad" is just crab meat in the crab shell and once again, the crab lacked seasoning. The ribeye sandwich had hope. The meat taste good, but the sauce over powered the meat and did not compliment the flavor of the meat at all. Each bite felt like a battle between the meat and the sauce. Overall disappointing. I would expect the food to at least taste flavorful. But hey, the server was AMAZING! So it wasn't all bad.

The food in New Orleans is repetitious and boring. We are from Los Angeles, so we are used to have a huge selection to choose from. We were so happy to uncover this gem of a restaurant, which wasn't too far from the hotel we were staying at. We were slightly inconvenienced, having to find a spot at the bar because the wait for a table was too long and they were closing soon. No worries, we found a spot and the bartender took our orders and everything turned out amazing afterwards. It was a while ago, so I can't remember what we ordered unfortunately, just completing a review I started the night we ate here. If you are ever in New Orleans and you are disappointed in other food options like we were, go here. You won't be disappointed.

Overall, I enjoyed Cochon. But there were a few mostly "service" issues that occurred. 1. It took a very long time to order. 2. My partner waited at least 15 minutes for his beer. In fact, I ordered my wine after him (yet received it before him). We asked where it was twice before it was delivered. I suspect they forgot about it, but that was not acknowledged. 3. We received our bread (for the first time) after asking for the dessert menu. Off timing. 

In terms of food, the oysters were good. But nothing that I will crave afterwards. The Mac and cheese were delicious, and the Brussels sprouts were delicious too!

This place was great. Service was mediocre at best and they definitely need to work on being more welcoming and friendly BUT the food outshined the service. We had some great appetizers but the alligator was by far my favorite. I would also recommend getting the oysters...WOW. My Brussel Sprout salad was also awesome. Again, just be friendlier when your customers ask questions about the menu! You are in an industry that depends on customer service! If I didn't own two restaurants myself my review would be completely different.

Absolutely worth a stop. All the dishes were flavorful and in all honesty they all had individual highlights. A bit small in size but fortunately we were with six people so we covered about half the menu. I'd go back to try more.

This was one of the worst dining experiences we have EVER had. We ordered shrimp and grits, wood fried grilled oysters, a Boucherie plate, and rabbit and dumplings.
The shrimp was non existent in the shrimp and grits. There was shell all throughout the grilled oysters and they were over cooked. There was so much pepper in the rabbit that it was inedible. The worst of all was the rancid and slimy meats on the boucherie plate 
The tea and complimentary bread and butter were wonderful!!!
NEVER AGAIN will  we darken the door of this establishment or recommend it to family or friends.

Went for lunch. We were recommended this place by some friends. We got it confused with Cochon Butcher, the more casual and affordable sister restaurant located about 150 feet away with a much smaller sign. By the time we realized we were in the wrong place, we had already ordered an appetizer and drinks. 
I had the charcuterie plate and the dirty rice meat pie and a glass of wine. The plate had good flavor, and the dirty rice was excellent. This is a very upscale place and the prices reflect that. It's far more suited to take a lady to impress her with ambiance and a pocket book.
Still it was a upscale place with really good food. I wished it had a more diverse menu.

We were thrilled to be able to get a table for nine in such a season!   Service was excellent.  Our waitress was friendly, obliging and attentive.  Having dined here before, I expected better.  But we were disappointed.  The spare ribs were over cooked and the sauce inedible.  Plus they were served in such a small plate, you'd think I child plated them. Some of the dishes my party ordered were alright. Only one was outstanding.  Maybe you'll have more luck.

THE BEST OYSTERS I HAVE EVER HAD.

That garlicky, sriracha, whatever the hell that sauce is. Hohhhhmygod it's so good. Get them. Everything is family style here, or at least that's what they recommend. So get sides and whatnot. Share. We also had the pork ribs, mac and cheese, turkey neck gumbo, Lima beans (so good) and the shrimp and grits. All of it was delicious but the turkey neck gumbo wasn't all that great. Shrimp and grits are mostly just grits served with this really thin delicious bread idk it was delicious. All of it. 

My ONLY complaint were that the pork ribs were cold when we got them. Still ate em because I ain't no punk and they were great. Just saying. Wished they were warm haha.

It's hard to say whether my tastes of changed, whether things have just gotten less creative here, or whether a week of eating in New Orleans just elevated my standards, but on a return trip this place wasn't nearly as transcendent as it was my first time through. The very best and most interesting work seems to be in the appetizers and small plates. The bigger stuff, like the smoked pork chop, gets boring after a while, and I wonder if it is on the menu more out of a sense of obligation than culinary excitement. Still very good, but not one of the the four best meals I ate in New Orleans.

Took the whole family. Three kids and five adults. All left happy. Red fish grilled perfectly. Mac n Cheese was the bomb. All sides were great. Pork Cochon was great. Did I tell you the Old Fashoineds were perfect.

Service: it wasn't personable at times however  I ordered the braised chuck roll and the Mac n cheese. 

The bread and butter was awesome and the cocktail selection is phenomenal. The service was semi prompt.

The chuck roll was absolutely tender and tasty. The yam taste like only nutmeg no real sweet taste. But it was cute. However, it wasn't the best but it was good!!

Let me tell you right now whoever made this Mac n cheese put their whole leg in it. It was pleasantly cheesy with a spice to it. Cheese and spice doesn't go together right? Wrong! This was amazing! This is by far the best I've had. It was a soul food and Cajun mix that I'm going to try to recreate. ;)

I'm coming back to try the oysters out.

It's a New Orleans thing to force one check.

This spot was really great! 

I came in a busy thurs evening solo and the hostess (who was really super lovely) places me at the back bar overlooking the open kitchen. I loved watching the kitchen and I recommend sitting up there but be warned it can get warm (as the nature of a kitchen). 

I had the alligator and the ribs. The mint on the alligator was great and the wings had an amazing flavor. The warm, wet towels were super appreciated for a messy dish.

The place is very clean and nice. The food is awesome, we tried the head cheese and the boudin, both very well made and the sides were really good too, I could eat a whole jar of their bread and butter pickles by myself. Our favorite was the Pig Mac, wow!! Super juicy, perfectly balanced with the sauce and veggies, delicious!!

We love this restaurant! The menu was very interesting and we took a chance with many of the things we ordered. Everything was delicious, the flavors were amazing. They make a good Mojito and the service was the best we've experienced all over New Orleans. We had two servers who were very attentive to us and shared their opinions of the menu and made recommendations which we took. The ambience of the restaurant was very pleasant in their lighting and architecture, and we liked that it was fairly casual as we have been walking around all day in jeans. Their choice in music was funny and I wish it had been different that night. It was a throwback to some 90s and early 2000's pop & rap, kind of interesting and not my taste to listen to during dinner. We definitely recommend!

Super pricey, really expensive 
But the foods good. they are really busy so definitely don't go without a reservation. 

Things to try: 
Fried alligator 
Mac and cheese
Boudin 

Nothing else was really noteworthy 
Portions are kind of small. I tried the rabbit and dumplings and it was 1 really small piece of rabbit and the rest was bread dumplings

We shared 5 dishes, hard to choose, everything sounded great. And it was! Service was very professional and friendly.
I'd go back in a minute if I wasn't so full

This place has great food! bar tender is really nice and knows their cocktails. service was great. i would give this a 4 star but i have to knock down 1 star because of the host. We walked in with no greetings from the host. she had really short blonde hair and was not helping anyone. I asked her if she can put our name down for 2. she said in a firm voice, "well, we're super busy and it will be about 3 hours." I responded with "ok, please put our names down anyway and let us know."
 she again said "you'll wait til 10:30 for a table? it will be 3 hours from now" in a firm mean tone. I said "ok, please put our name down." i asked her if they only have that bar behind her so we can go grab a drink. she rolled her eyes and nodded. well, luckily we got a seat at the bar and what do you know, 30 min later we received a message telling us a table is ready for us. really? ok, managers if you're reading this you need to educate your hosts on time expectations. I understand that your a busy restaurant that was why we went early so we can grab a drink at your bar, eat a bit of apps and then have a full dinner. the longer a customer stays at the restaurant the larger the bill will be. Great food though.

So many people recommended this place for my first time in NOLA, and it did not disappoint! Every dish was perfectly cooked with interesting components and multiple layers of flavor.

We got the fried alligator, woodfire oysters, mac & cheese, smoked ham hock, cochon, and rabbit & dumplings. 

This was my first time trying alligator and it pretty much tastes like really chewy chicken. 

The oysters are a must! It's buttery and has a hint of lemon I think? The chili gives it a kick but not too spicy.

The meat dishes were so delicious. My favorite was the ham hock. It's fall-off-the-bone type of tender. 

Minus one star for the service. We had a reservation but still waited 15 min to be seated and another 15 until our waitress finally remembered our existence and took our order.

This was one of our favorite meals and restaurants while visiting New Orleans! My husband and I shared some appetizers and each got our own meal. Beet salad, oysters, pork ribs, mac and cheese, and beef roll. All amazing! Highly recommend!
Fannnntastic dining experience! I'm making this review late, so I can't recall what exactly I ordered, but judging by how tasty each dish was on my group's table, you can't go wrong!

I've had the roasted oysters twice now - first time out of this world, second time only ok.  The meat selections are usually safe but have not blown me away - got the pork chop special and it was okay..  the ambiance leaves A LOT to be desired.  I prefer the ambiance of the butcher shop for the price point.

So as a pescatarian I've avoided Cochon, but I was in the are for Luna Fête and decided to try it. We sat at the bar and the staff was attentive but not overly so, not in an awkward way! They answered our random questions and I decided on the gator bites (the Catholic Church of Louisiana deemed gator a fish so people can eat it during lent and who am I to argue that logic??) the gator was DELISH! They also did a very surprising flavor combination of adding fresh mint leaves on top of the semi spicy gator bites. So good ! 

Try it you'll not be disappointed!

Me and my husband ate here for our anniversary. It is quite possibly one of the best meals we have ever had! Everything was so delicious. This place is so unique. I had the rabbit dumplings and he had the short rib. Both were amazing! We will be back for sure.

I was debating over whether to go to the restaurant or the butcher first, but I'm glad I went to the restaurant first. ( Now they I think about it, it doesn't really matter which one you go to first as long as you go to both ) I was asked if I had a reservation at first, which I didn't, but they found me a seat within a minute anyway and this was on a Saturday evening. I order their fried alligator, shrimp and grits, and the brussel sprout casserole. All of the food was delicious, even the bread that comes on the side. The alligator actually tastes like chicken. No kidding. I love grits and the shrimp and grits was very satisfying to each with the added buttered bread on the side. And the brussel sprouts were very tasty as well.
The restaurant is very spacious and the service is quick and attentive. Unrelated to the restaurant, but a cherry on top of my experience was this very sweet couple who sat next to me and made conversation. They ended up giving us a plate of their BBQ ribs, because they had too much to eat, and I gladly accepted it. Ribs, excellent. Sweet and tender and the meat fell right off the bone. What a great time. Would come to again.

Go go go! This is a must-visit when you are in NOLA. The food and service and atmosphere are all incredible. My partner and I came here for lunch during our stay in NOLA and it was phe-nom-e-nal!

To eat we shared: fried alligator, fried sausage balls, mac n cheese, and oven baked oysters. As two non-oyster lovers, they were incredible. If you can take a food I am quick to avoid and make me go back for seconds, you deserve all of the kudos. The alligator was my favorite thing I ate all week - well seasoned and not greasy from the frying. The fried sausage balls were similar to the arancini balls you get at italian places but with a more meaty southern kick. Finally, the mac and cheese was so creamy and delicious. It was the perfect amount of food for the two of us for lunch.

We also got two vodka lemonades (they make the lemonade in house, big win!!!) and lunch came to around $60.

Love love love their boudin balls. I've tried boudin balls from so many other restaurants around here but these beat em all. They're so crispy on the outside but are really flavorful on the inside and seem to have a lot more meat than most. I've actually just ordered these without any other food before because they're that good

Pricey but absolutely delicious. I highly recommend the ribs and the fried alligator. The rabbit was pretty good too.

Why 4 stars? I strongly feel that the appetizers surpassed the main course in taste.
Great restaurant to try and wonderful kitchen to look at. Food is special and sure need to try.

Although the food was delicious, I am giving them 4 stars and not 5 because of the service. We arrived on time for our reservation and we're seated right away. When the waitress came by she immediately said "Are you ready to order?" We said we would like to order drinks first. She didn't seem thrilled. My husband ordered one of their drink specials off the menu and I asked if they had a Milk Punch (which is a very a common drink in New Orleans) or a Brandy Alexander. She seemed confused and said no milk punch, so I ordered the Brandy Alexander. They have a large full Bar. This should not have been a problem. She came back and said they didn't have the ingredients and couldn't make it. Brandy, Creme de Cocoa and cream. I ordered a White Russian, which is basically the same thing only made with Kahlua. She came back with the drinks and asked if we were ready to order. We asked several questions about items on the menu, she seemed to be rushed and then said she'd come back when we were ready, instead of giving us a few minutes to think about the info she gave us. She never told us the soup or the fish special. We only found out about them by hearing a different server tell another table. For appetizers we ordered the fried alligator and the smoked grilled oysters. They were very good. For main course we had the Crispy Pork Shoulder and the smoked BBQ Ribs. Also, excellent. We finished and she took the dishes away, then returned and placed the check on the table. Did not offer us dessert, coffee or an after dinner drink. We asked for a dessert menu and she took the check away and had someone else bring the menu over. When she came back we ordered the Meyer Lemon pie, also yummy. Again she didn't ask us if we wanted coffee or any drinks. We got the feeling from her that she was not interested in serving us, felt we were a bother and want to get us out as soon as possible. When the service is bad, it really takes away from the enjoyment of the meal. We travel a lot and eat at fine restaurants often. We have friends that are restaurant owners and friends that are servers. We know how hard they work and always tip between 20-25%. We left her a 15% tip. We also stopped on the way out to inform the Manager of our experience. We believe that if you don't let the Management know about the problems, they can't correct them. As the food was delicious, we will go back. Hopefully, the service will be equal to the food.

Date of visit: January 2019

I'm so glad we decided to have our last meal in New Orleans at Cochon! The fried oysters were delicious. I also had the red fish and the chocolate mousse for dessert, all were so yummy. My boyfriend had the pasta and we shared the mac and cheese. Service was excellent. Loved the ambiance too, and sitting at the counter you can see how hard and fast the cooks are working. It's amazing how coordinated they were in kitchen. There was a bit of a wait but the bar at the front of the restaurant made the wait go by quickly. Definitely a must eat restaurant (and must return!) if you're ever in New Orleans!

The starters they have are really good. But the main entree are not really as good as you expect it to be. Also the service is really bad, our server never checked on us, instead the runner was the one who checked on us. They gave us bread service with no butter. The food took too long to get to our table and it wasnt that hot anymore.  I was just disappointed on how my experience went. But ill still recommend for people to try the fried alligator and the oysters.
Had a delicious dinner at the bar. The wait staff was very attentive and the atmosphere was fun. Casual yet serious for eating. The small plates hit the spot and the dessert was awesome.

Excellent food, prepared in an interesting way. I recommend getting a round of small plates and sharing. My favorite is the oysters with chili sauce and the ribs. They also have a few fish selections on the menu as well as meats. The service is very good as well. My only issues are that its really, really loud here, like you need to yell across the table to your companions and the other tables are pretty tightly packed in. Reservations strongly recommended. Be warned, its not inexpensive and the on line menu is usually not up to date.

I was really excited about this place after the yelp reviews, but our food was mediocre. To start we had the alligator, which was very bland and tough. We had to order more sauce just to give it flavor. Then we had the soup of the day (which the waitress didn't really know at first) and the Brussel sprouts, which were fine. The Mac and cheese casserole was ok, the noodles were soft and it felt more like mush. 

The waitress was nice, but wasn't as attentive as you'd hope for a restaurant that isn't very busy.

Small menu compared to other establishment. But the restaurant itself was large, more rooms than meets the eye. 

Starting off they gave you warm bread which reminded me of the ones you get at bakeries, very nice touch.
I thought their fried alligator with chili garlic mayo was excellent. This was my second time ordering a plate like this here in New Orleans and this one was the best I tasted so far! 

As for the main entrees, I think some dishes were very salty. The Asian in me wanted to order a side of rice but I think that would be frowned upon. I wasn't a huge fan of the catfish courtboullion (again, too salty). But I did enjoy the braised chuck roll with sweet potato pudding and onion gravy. I do believe they change their menus quite often so definitely come back to see what's new!

We were sorely disappointed here... service was NOT welcoming which led to us not wanting anything past our first appetizer; the drinks were ok but pricey for what they were; the food was tasty though we discovered we aren't alligator meat fans... it's tough!)  We both wished we'd started next door at the Butcher...
Small and large plate. Good season but need to lower salt. Great cocktails. Excellent serving staffs. Such a great team work.

Cochon was my very first stop in NOLA. I've been wanting to try this space since Anthony Bourdain came during his layover in 2013. 

Grabbed a few plates per the server's recommendations. Wood fired oysters, obviously. Fried crawfish, sure! Boudin meatballs, duh. Alligator?... Maybe? 

We enjoyed all of our dishes, especially the oysters and the boudin. I love that the fried alligator was paired with mint, which gave it an amazing freshness, but I found myself wishing it was chicken. :p 

Definitely a great place to grab a bite in Nola.

Great environment. Came in no rsvp and got a seat in front of the kitchen. Great to watch them at work and great communication and prompt. Very well
Run kitchen.
Got the gator as that was what many of the reviews said and they weren't wrong. Excellent. Chef also gave a sample of the fried oyster and was awesome. As the main, I opted for jumbalaya. When In New Orleans right? It was pork and sausage and came with plenty of meat. Was a bit dry and was much better with hot sauce. Wasn't too filling which is good when you have gator to start. Drinks are good but odd options. No Tito's, no capt Morgan. Waiter was very prompt and good suggestions. The 4 was the dryness and also lack of name brand even though they say they are close offerings

OH MY GAWD! We may have food orgasmed a bit, and went home to sleep off our food coma. EVERYTHING was great & well seasoned. The duck sliders and the lamb gyro we voted were the best. But don't pass the bacon pralines!

Damn.  I want to eat boudin balls from HERE every week.  They are effing amazing.  Levin was out waiter and we let him run the show and recommend must haves.  He didnt fail us.  The mac n cheese is amazing, the lima beans (which i laughed at spending $7 for) were rather good, but did I mention the BOUDIN BALLS??????  I wanted to go back the next day for more.  NOM.

My know that New Orleans is known for spicy, singular cuisine reflecting its history as a melting pot of French, African and American cultures. The first evening we decided to go to Cohon restaurant and it was a right decision! 

There was a line and we had to wait about an hour but as we did not make a reservation it was a good sign. We were sited at the bar table near the stove. It was nice, warm and cosy.

We had wood-fired oesters, roasted brussels sprout salad, fried alligator with chilli garlic mayonnasie, catfish courtbouillion. All was amazing, tasty and prepared in a delicious way. I personally prefer hot brussels sprout but they were still a good choice.

In short, very good food, reasonable prices. We will definitely come back when next time in NO.

Although human beings aren't obligate carnivores, doesn't mean I'm not going to stop by Cochon for their gator. Cochon came highly recommended to me and rightfully so. Definitely grab a reservation here! There was a wait Saturday 7pm night when I arrived.

Fried Alligator appetizer (5/5): I hate that alligator is so rare in California but I'm glad I got some while at Cochon. Fried to perfection. Perfect amount of sauce for flavor. VERY recommended!

Cochon (4/5): Of course I had to try the house specialty and wow, I've never had pork that way in my life before. Perfectly cooked. I loved adding the house hot sauce for an extra touch. Alligator overshadowed this dish, however.

Service was A+. Everyone was nice and attentive. The decor and ambiance was also on-point. Next time I come back I hope they have the turtle soup!

As a local one of my fave places!!! 
Service and food is always spot on!!
Must visit when in New Orleans!!!

This is my second visit to Cochon. I love this place! We went in last night and were lucky to get a table with no wait. I had the Rum the Mules which had all of my favorite flavors for a drink and was similar to a Moscow Mule just with rum instead. We ordered the smoked ribs and shrimp toast for our appetizers. The ribs had a great crust on them but the pickled watermelon stole the show with its sour and sweet addition. The shrimp toast with grits was really tasty and some of the best grits I've ever had. We split the hamhock which was tasty and the hoppin john was really flavorful. We split an entree so we could justify getting dessert. We ordered the lemon Meyer chess pie which was really tart and sweet, so good. I highly recommend coming here!
service terrible.  lack of experience and little knowledge about menu. was given another sever (levin) who was more knowledgeable, but "prickly".   shame

We tried going to Cochon on Sunday before MLK day and the wait was 2 and a half hours long. Many people recommended to us before our trip to NoLA so we were torn about whether to make the wait. We chose to make reservations for the following day instead. When we came came Monday, we were seated right away. We were so glad we did. Everything about Cochon was exceptional. My boyfriend and i shared the ribs, beet salad, octopus, mac and cheese and cochon. Everything was flavorful and perfectly seasoned. We finished our meal with the pineapple upside down cake, which I never had before and I was sad that it ended.

Friendly staff and 5-stars worth food.
Top 3: jambalaya, fried alligator, fried livers
Fantastic food and atmosphere. Wait staff could be a little nicer. The food was full of flavor and presented perfectly. The charred oysters were to die for!!!
Fantastic. Reality please with choice and quality of food.   Had the boudan stuffed chicken with local grown airloom carrots and cabage, killer good

Visiting NOLA from the Bay Area and stopped by here for the great reviews. Ordered the oysters, Cochon, catfish, Mac and cheese, and jambalaya and all were incredibly tasty!! 

Service was also great - there was a mixup in the kitchen and we had a long wait for our main entree's, but the manager came by, personally, to apologize and explain this doesn't usually happen. He took 50% off of our bill as a courtesy and we hadn't even asked.

100% recommend for taste and service. Will be back again!

I took co-workers here from San Francisco.  They loved it.  We started with a bourbon cocktail.  We ordered the rabbit and dumplings as well as greens and macaroni & cheese.  When will we have rabbit again?  Never.  Only at Cochon...they know what they are doing.  Everything was delicious.  The rabbit was smothered to perfection.  So filling and seasoned with all the holy trinity.

I had just arrived to New Orleans, and at the suggestion of my realtor, decided to explore the area around my new apartment. After driving for two days i wanted a good, satisfying meal. 

I came upon Cochon since i can literally see it from the door of my new place. The menu, the reviews, the location all looked promising. 

We were seated at the chefs table, right on the kitchen line where all the action was taking place! It was a lively Friday night, so they were quite busy, however you could never tell. Our service was attentive and informative without being pushy or overbearing. 

The meal lived up to all the reviews! The drinks were well balanced and beautiful. The wood fired oysters are an absolute must and my first alligator experience has left me craving more! The ribs were perfectly cooked and mouth wateringly delicious. 

It is so dangerous that this place is a stones throw from my front door. I cannot wait to get back to explore the greater depths of this menu. Everything was beyond my expectations; the service, the ambiance, the drinks and food are all superb.

I really liked this restaurant, the food is excellent. The only downside is that it's expensive and small portions. We went here because it was 2/5 dollar signs for price on Yelp. Both of our dishes were over $20 dollars and we were still hungry after we finished our meal.

Hats off to Cochon for a stand out menu. In a world of boring, cookie cutter selections Cochon knocks the dust off with a great twist on down home. Nice atmosphere, great staff and good luck getting in on the weekend. I had to come back at lunch
Place is bomb. Great food. Would eat here again if I had the chance. Amazing experience.

My party and I dined at Cochon's tonight at the recommendation of several natives and we are SO glad we did. We made reservations online and were sat promptly. The service was impeccable from start to finish as well as our food and drinks.

We had the pleasure of having Levin as one of our wait staff, who made us feel like we were the only table there. He was so attentive, patient, and informative. We really enjoyed meeting and talking with him. 

Our table ordered the fried alligator dish, the cucumber and herbs, rabbit and dumplings, the Louisiana Cochon, a twice-baked stuffed potato, and a surprise vegetarian dish! All of which were amazing with so much flavor. The vegetarian dish was a nice surprise and may have been vegan as well. They don't tell you what you are getting other than to say the chefs will make you something they assure you will be delicious and it really was. It was such a unique and enjoyable experience. We were all so glad we came to Cochon's! Thanks again!

Made reservations for a large group in advance. When we got there, some of us went in first and the rest of the group showed up a little later. The host told the second half that there was no reservation under our name. Although the food was tasty, the service was ok. (maybe because it was a busy night, big crowd?) We shared many little dishes and even though some of us ordered before others, lots of us were waiting for our dishes to come when part of the group was already on their third or fourth dish. It was very inconsistent. Maybe next time I would go with a smaller group (there were about 10 of us)

I haven't been here in over a year - and I find myself in this city once agin, and yet...I still can't stop talking about how deliciously wonderful my meal was.

The staff was extremely welcoming & sweet, the "sneak peak" kitchen window in the back left me wanting to see (& know more). 

I loved the family style menu, but what I remember most is the encouragement from our waiter. He helped us select the best dishes for our tastes and made sure that we ate them in the most perfect order.

You won't regret adding this spot to your New Orleans restaurant tour. You'll be thinking about your meal the next time you visit, just like I do.

Finally a great place to eat at. Besides the fresh food with amazing ingredients our server Levin was one of the best we've ever had anywhere in the world we travel. 
Wood fire oysters and Fried Alligators were just some of the apps we had. We went with 6 people and almost ordered the entire app menu. 
Will definitely come back and when in NO this is a must place to visit.
Great NOLA food in a clean modern atmosphere! Highly recommended. Ordered the alligator bites, oysters, rabbit stew, and catfish gumbo. Was delicious!

I went to Cochon many years ago and I remember it being better; this review is based on lunch last week. I ordered the Catfish Courtbouillion because I was fascinated by the name. It was a disappointment. The catfish was fine, no complaints with how it was cooked though nothing special either. The courtbouillon is a tomato-based sort-of stew that didn't have much flavor but pepper. It was spicy without being very flavorful. I did enjoy the creamy grits and toast (extremely thinly-sliced bread toasted and buttered). It was slightly odd to dip bread into grits but both were good on their own, and could have been eaten that way, so I won't complain about that. The bread basket was good but not great. And the amount of butter served was stingy, which was odd. Are they trying to save money on butter? Hope that works out and they reach their profit target.
The food here was unique. I had the pork Cochon. The pork was a little dry but the cracklings on top were delicious. My friend had the rabbit and biscuits. It was pretty good.

Came in with a bigger party and we were seated rather quickly. Started off with some appetizers of  fried alligator and oysters. Both of these were very good. I ordered the shrimp grits and they were just okay. The best thing I tasted at the table was the ribs, they were very tender and flavorful.  The dirty rice meat pie was also very good. Being with a party of 9 we all sampled each other dishes. Another standout dish was the macaroni and cheese casserole. Some of the best macaroni I have had in a restaurant.

My husband and I went to Cochon while in New Orleans. The interior was very modern and you could see the kitchen staff at work although you couldn't tell what they were doing. We were seated and a server drifted over. We placed our order - an appetizer and drinks. Eventually the drinks arrived and a little later the appetizer. 

Because the tables for two are very close together we struck up a conversation with the two guys next to us and even shared our appetizer. 

Our entrees took a pretty good while to appear. The restaurant was nowhere near full and occasionally you'd see plates stacking up at the pass through and a huddle of servers standing there talking. I don't know if they serve slow food so you can enjoy and anticipate your next dish or if they're just slow as Christmas. 

My husband ordered the Ham Hock with HoppingJohn. It was pretty good. I had a roast beef dish that has replaced the short ribs you'll find on their website menu. It was really good. I asked if I could have rice instead of whatever they served it with because who doesn't like rice and roast beef gravy? The server had to go ask and cane back looking very down cast. Apparently I could have it for a $6 surcharge.  My entree ended up coming not only with the rice instead of whatever, but it also included an extra side of rice. There wasn't enough gravy for the extra rice and I'm not a big eater so that was a fail. It really didn't make sense either. Oh well, my roast beef made up for it although my husband was a shade disappointed in his meal. 

I can't say I'll want to go back next time we're in NOLA. There are far too many other great restaurants to try.

My diligent yelping led me right to Cochon's door my first night here in NO. So happy it did! We arrived at about 7:45 or so on a Friday night and we were quoted an hour wait.  Due to a reservation canceling, we were seated in 15 minutes. I'll start with the cocktail menu. While the choices were plentiful and it was difficult to pick between exotic-sounding ingredients such as butterfly pea flower tea and old favorites (mezcal), the smoke on the water won out. Twice. One of the best cocktails I've ever tasted, actually. At the risk of incurring judgement I'll admit to having a rum the mules, too, which was very good and the sweet "dessert" I was looking for. 
We split fried alligator, boudin, and the pork cheek with andouille jambalaya to start. We cannot get andouille like that in WI so that dish won out for us. The alligator was good; I wanted to try it because it was alligator and I'm from WI but frankly it was all spicy sauce over a meat that was essentially a rubbery chicken. I don't feel qualified to judge how it was cooked or prepared so I won't. But fellow midwesterners... don't be scared. The Boudin was good; the pickled peppers (onions in reality I believe) were a wonderful accompaniment. 
Smoked ham hock with Hoppin' John. I can't say enough about how good this was. I scraped up every last grain of rice, sopped up the sauce with my leftover bread....and still wanted more. We had also ordered the Mac n cheese casserole and the loaded baked potato. Those two were essentially fillers. I felt the noodles were over cooked but the flavor was good. We both agreed we would have rather had our own ham hock and Hoppin' John plates. As we surveyed the mostly empty dishes, we realized the combination of the latter three dishes was a bit salty. Consider a fresh salad on the menu; betting that would be the perfect complement. 
Service was on the slow side, but friendly. The vibe is casual and fun, a bit loud with tables too close together to be intimate.

First, let me say that I have talked about eating at Cochon for a couple of years now. For some reason, I always chose another restaurant over it. Well, today was finally the day and I'm glad that it was. I needed a delicious comforting meal and that is exactly what I got.

For starters, we had the gator bites and fried chicken livers. These were ok. They weren't to die for but they were tasty and a good pre-meal snack. We were starving. So, let's get to the good stuff. I ordered the ham hock with hoppin John, my husband had the rabbit and dumplings and my son had the Louisiana  cochon on cabbage. All of our dishes were A-M-A-Z-I-N-G! They were all so flavorful and seasoned to perfection. The food was hot and fresh and I just drooled a little reliving that dining experience. It was a flavor party on my tongue. My sixteen year old son said that it was one of the best restaurant meals he has ever had, and we eat out a lot. 

If you are having second or third thoughts about this place, don't.  It is worth the money, the service  was great and the atmosphere was casual and comfortable.  Parking was also easier than we thought. There is ample metered parking and a couple of lots near by. If you are up to it, you could even walk to the riverwalk if you need to walk off all the cochon you just put down. Either way, this place is now on my list for a return visit.

If your looking for good southern comfort  Cajun food, then you will
Enjoy this eatery.located in the warehouse district.  A trendy location offering  fish and pork creations  that are delicious.  The entrees are generous portions and with the addition of the different sides and appetizers you will have a filling meal.
WOW!  Food was phenomenal and service was above and beyond.  Highly recommended as a 'must-go' place to eat while visiting NOLA.

Amazing food - great tastes.ine of my favorite on this last trip. Had Alligator - very tasty!  The cucumber salad was good - and lite.  The grilled oysters were AMAZING - my wife could not get enough. Just suggestion - serve 6 not 5 - we fought over the last one. Signature drinks were tasty too. Our server - Darwin - was amazing - he was LOVELY (inside joke). Lots of character and glad we went here!
Amazing. Favorite restaurant in all of NOLA!  You must try the fried alligator and the rabbit dumplings. Everything was delicious from the appetizers to the dessert. Truly worth every penny spent.

Amazing!!!!  Take your Stacie BEFORE you go... but... so good.  Had the alligator appetizer, mac&cheese and red snapper!  Every bite was like a  25 year high school reunion with the woman of your dreams!

Man, the food here is life! I ordered the oysters and the dirty rice pie. Amazing, particularly the dirty rice pie. I could eat that all day. We also ordered the alligator bites, Mac and cheese and the jambalaya, all of which were good too.
Delicious!  Went there our first day in town and it was great. Cucumber salad has delicious chili flakes and the ribs were perfect. Great meal!

As a local and a foodie I'm always looking to try new and great spots. I was in the vicinity of the convention center and after paying $25 for 4 hours of parking I needed to use up every bit of my time. A normal pescatarian doesn't venture into places called Pig but I'm far from normal so let's do this. Although it was lunch time there was absolutely no availability but there were seats at the bar, so we took them. I initially informed the bartender of my food shortcomings and he told me everything that was available to accommodate and the list was long enough for a second comeback if needed (which by the way is so needed) 
I had the oyster and bacon sandwich minus the bacon and a side of Mac and cheese and OMG I want more. The Mac and cheese was not boxed and was baked just right with just the right amount of cheese and flavor..this absolutely didn't taste like restaurant Mac and Cheese...now let's talk about this oyster sandwich that is topped with a homemade slaw and green tomatoes on a thin and crispy amazement of bread - first the sandwich is bigger than me but the consistency and flavor gave me all of my Saturday life and I mean all of it. My spouse had the shrimp and grits, which doesn't have actual shrimp it's a shrimp sauce on top of grits but it's absolutely delicious. Although the shrimp is grounded into some type of paste sauce you can absolutely taste it and it's lacking NOTHING - I will definitely be eating my leftovers and absolutely will be returning 
P.S 
There is a second side of the restaurant called Butcher and although they are one in the same they are different and each has a different vibe. The butcher is more of a chilled side
This place surprisingly has the best Mac n' cheese of our lives, and the oyster sandwich is awesome. The cocktail Black Magic Woman is fantastic and pretty strong even if a little small.
The food is phenomenal! We had the ribs, boudin and the jambalaya with the mac and cheese on the side. We loved them all! Will definitely come back when we are back in town.

David, what do you think about this drink vs. that drink -
"Honestly that drink, I don't even like selling it. Get the Scarlet Letter." 
David, what do you think I should get between the Rabbit and Dumplings and the smoked hock - 
"If you don't mind a little sage, get the rabbit and dumplings. It's my favorite dish. You'll like it."

We like David. Such confidently proffered suggestions, and right on every instance. I loved the Scarlet Letter (where does one get Punt e Mes these days!? The other place I know that has it is the Milk Room in Chicago) and really liked the Rabbit and Dumplings (sorry, Thumper) - as another Yelper had said, it's reminiscent of a deconstructed pot pie, but in no way is it bland like a couple people have said. 

The Cochon, as he said, was salty and so were the cracklins, but the cabbage in it was delicious - the dish was balanced out with the bread and the dumplings from our other dish (we shared everything). We also got the Mac and Cheese and that was good too! As were the boudin balls. The smoked oysters, which were the only things I had gotten last time, were still delicious. Maybe we'll leave room for dessert next time. Or maybe we'll stuff ourselves again. Quote, "I can't wait to loosen my belt. I can't even keep my jacket buttoned anymore."  Before we walked around the Garden District and Marigny for 2 hours discussing commonalities and differences between Nazi Germany and Japanese imperialism. :) 

Anyway, I digress. 4.5 for the food/drink this time around and 5 for the ambiance and service :) got lucky with street parking so even better! It was just a lovely night overall. Happy to recollect such good meals of such good company, and yes, including David's.

We were walking around New Orleans wondering where to eat when our brother dropped us a random text recommending a great restaurant in the area he knew we were visiting.  He said Cochan was a great place to get great food.  We looked up and we happened to be headed right for it on foot.  So we dropped in.  It was one of the best meals we have ever tasted!  Our waiter was great and he led us to his favorite choices on the menu.  We ended up sharing fried white boudin and pickles, shrimp grits and a beet salad.  It was just the right amount of food for us and we savored every bite.  If you are in the warehouse district of New Orleans, don't miss it! I'll never forget it!

We tried this place on our last night in New Orleans after the suggestion from a fellow Yelp elite member/friend. And we were certainly not disappointed. 

We opted for the jambalaya to start. My husband ordered the Louisiana Cochon and I ordered the Ham hock with beans. We also opted for a side order of grits. Everything was delicious. Our server was very attentive and all the food was hot, fresh and flavorful. 

I honestly was disappointed I did not have room for dessert because I heard the pineapple upside cake was delicious.

Give this place a try

Tried this place during my visit to New Orleans for the first time, and it did not disappoint. I had the bbq ribs as an appetizer, followed by the cochon with cabbage as my entree, both were excellent!

We got the Fried alligator with chili garlic sauce, wood-fires oysters with chili garlic butter, pork cheek & andouille jambalaya, catfish courtbouillin and Meyer lemon chess pie. Everything was very good but my favorite was the catfish because it was bursting with so many wonderful flavors. The Meyer Lemon Chess Pie was so light and refreshing. Would do it again! Say Hello to Alex, our secondary waiter! He was awesome!

This restaurant hands down is one of the best restaurants in New Orleans. I checked in at the counter about 1pm on a Saturday and it was busy. There were no seats available in the restaurant, so they offered me up the chefs table. Uh! Yes, please... I love watching the chefs in the kitchen.

The waiter came immediately to serve me and he said I would receive a starter on the house. This was the head cheese with mustard on a crostini. I do not normally eat head cheese, but this combo was amazing.

I let the waiter pick my dishes. He recommended the grilled oysters, ribs, Brüssel sprout casserole. Herr are my thoughts 

Ribs- amazing, smoky and tender
Brüssel spouts: reminded me of a green bean casserole, creamy, tender and amazing 
Oysters- these were good, but hard to competed with so many other oyster places in town. I would recommend the other dishes over this.

The overall food coming out looked great, just could not eat it all. Next time for sure!

Underwhelmed and disappointed. Picked this place over the hundreds of good restaurants in NOLA and went 20min our if the way to get here. 

Service was mediocre even with two wait stuff overseeing the table and it wasn't pack as the restaurant was 1/2 full. On two different occasions, the glasses were empty. I would give service as average to below average

Food was a disappointment. We had the ribs for appetizer came out dry and lack of taste after you bite in. I have no idea how you could do wrong with ribs. Rabbit dumplings was over seasoned with salt and could be paired with some bread, but it didn't come with it.

Wish it lived to it's Yelp reviews, or maybe it was just a bad day and I was unlucky. Better satisfaction if I tried my luck at Harrah's casino
GREAT .......VERY  good service and great tasting food...gotta dip the bread in the oyster sauce.

What can I say about this place that hasn't already been said? We were seated within in a few minutes despite the fact we walked in off the street during  a busy lunch service.  Great service! The Cochon, their signature dish was the best piece of pork I have ever eaten. Don't leave without trying the Meyer Lemon! Amazing!
It was good if you like the more exotic foods (rabbit, alligator, etc). Not much to choose from if you are less adventurous but I'd probably go back again. The side of Mac n cheese was divine.
Delicious food.  Manager was rude when a friend stopped in and jumped on our table After we told our waitress he was on the way if it were not for that. 5 star

Great food and service with a cool, casual vibe . Only ate a little bite with the shrimp and grits with toast but it was pretty damn good ( as well as the bread ) . Definitely will be back for more !!

Perfect for dinner after the WWII Museum experience. The only negative was that since it is a big warehouse like restaurant in the back and it was rainy we were cold. The Zinfandel made it better though.
The oysters and friend alligator were the best thing we had. Great selection of whiskey and great service. I would highly recommend.

Delicious southern comfort food.  Sometimes good restaurants can be stuff & intimidating but Cochon was Mellow, nice environment with excellent food and service.  So happy we chose to eat here.  All 3 generations LOVED their dishes.
Rabbit, pork chop and the whole red fish & the pineapple upside down cake were the highlights.
We loved this restaurant!  They seated my family of five in a cozy nook. We each enjoyed a sampling from all categories of their menu and none of us were disappointed!  Highly recommend!

The food was amazing!!! Mac and cheese casserole was to die for!!! Ribs were great, and had a good Smokey taste. First time having alligator and it was pretty good. As for dessert, you MUST have the CHOCOLATE MOUSSE!!!! My girlfriend and I were amazed at how delicious it was!!

This was a restaurant recommended by a friend & so we stopped by for lunch one day.  Their food was delicious from start to finish!  I started off with a Canal Streetcar, which was excellent.  As an appetizer, we ordered the fried gator bites, which were very yummy.  For lunch, I ordered the gumbo.  Paired with the buttered rolls, it was so tasty.  My friends ordered the Mac & cheese, smothered greens, oysters and the thrice baked potato.  All of them were absolutely delicious!  When in New Orleans, I recommend stopping by because their food does not disappoint!

This is the number one restaurant in New Orleans.  Once you go, you know.  We tried every appetizer on the menu!  OMG!  Foodie heaven.  We visited on Saturday, February 16 with our children and their spouses.  It was a beautiful night and we were lucky to sit outside.  
We started with a great bottle of wine and some small plates.  The wood-fired oysters with chili sauce was delicious and the fried alligator was heavenly!  That was a nice surprise.  The chanterelle pie was so full-flavored and the poached shrimp salad was refreshing and light!  The entrees we enjoyed were unlike anything we have ever enjoyed in a restaurant setting.  The cochon with cracklins, turnip and cabbage was a party in our mouths!  The rabbit with dumplings were insane!  We finished off dinner with the blueberry tart and the malted chocolate cake which were a delicious ending to a perfect night out!  This is a must-try establishment!!

To be to the point: Cochon was the best restaurant that we tried during our week in New Orleans. 

I first heard of Cochon on an episode of Anthony Bourdain and after seeing its rating on Yelp, I knew that it was a place I wanted to visit. It was a 20-30 minute walk from our hotel and it was worth it. Honestly, we wished we went more than once. 

We arrived just before the dinner rush, at about 4:30, and by the time we left at 5:30 it was filling up. So, try and get there just before dinner if you can.

We shared the Mac and Cheese, Smoked Pork Ribs and the Jambalaya. 

The Mac and Cheese was really, really good. Honestly, I'm not the biggest fan of Mac and Cheese, but I had to admit this was great. There is a nice crust atop, which adds a nice textural contrast between the creaminess of the casserole. Honestly, the only thing that I think that could've made it better was if there was a smoked meat product added too, just to add a nice texture and flavor layer. It's creamy, rich, and cheesy. Really good. 

The Smoked Pork Ribs has a very good smokey flavor and the watermelon pickle was a really nice acidic and sweet contrast to the smokiness of the ribs. The only critique I have is I wish the ribs were a little bit more tender/fall-off-the-bone. But if that meant sacrificing flavor, then never mind, because I loved the smokiness.

Our favorite thing though was the Jambalaya. There was a nice blend of spices and textures. I wish that it would've came in a entree size. There was a slightly crispy exterior to it, almost like a fried rice, but the interior of the dish was moist. The meat was crispy but tender - has great flavor. There was a nice spice to it as well. Easily the best starting jambalaya that we had. 

Also, the rolls were really good too. (Haha). They were light and fluffy and the butter was smooth. I could've eaten as many rolls as they would've been willing to bring me. Too good.

Hip place! Went here for a galentine's dinner on Valentine's day during our work conference. Service was prompt and attentive. I went with what most reviewers recommended and got the rabbit and dumplings. It was seriously the least gamiest rabbit and also surprisingly tender. It was pretty rich tasting but I kind of expected it. My friends got the cochon and I got to sample some of that crispy goodness. The rest of my party wished they had ordered what I did, so I must say to definitely trying the rabbit and dumplings! This was my first restaurant stop in New Orleans and it did not disappoint.

Came here for dinner on my first night in New Orleans. It was just me, and the hostess said I could eat standing at the bar, or it'd be about an hour wait. I was starving, so standing at the bar it was. I was helped quickly, and my food came out very quickly as well, which I was surprised by considering how busy they were. I got the fried alligator bite with garlic chili mayo, and the pork cheek jambalaya. They were both amazing, but the pork cheek is one of the best things I can remember tasting in a very long time. Cost me $27, and was worth every penny.

One of my favorite dining experiences in New Orleans. 

Yes, much of the food is far from light, but mostly totally worth the calories. Fried alligator and wood fired oysters were highlights.

Service was excellent, despite it being picked and a bit chaotic. 

Looking forward to trying more of the menu when I'm back in town.

The roasted oysters were hands down the best oysters I've ever had! I'm from Seattle and to say that l think it means a lot haha. The overall experience was great-sat at the bar top and both bartenders were tentative and quick with their service. I was pleased at my experience

Very delicious oysters. They are seasoned nicely and grilled. Only 5 come in the serving, but they're a good size. The service is great and the only regret  I have is not trying more of the menu.


They don't serve the sandwiches here, that's next door. I can't say much more because all I had were oyesters.
Nice ambiance and music. Decent wine selections and the food was tasty Wood Fired Oysters are on point. The hush puppies might be the best I've had. Fried gator was another great appetizer.

Food was sooo good. We had the fried alligator, oysters (sauce is amazing!!), Mac n cheese and smothered greens. Excellent wine recommendation by the server as well. Everything from the decor to the ambiance was spot on. Overall great experience. Will most definitely return when in town again. Thank you Cochon!
Bleh... Food expectations didn't meet all the hype. Food ok, but server was beyond comprehension....arrogant...detached...really???!!! game over Bro

Not as impressed as many Yelpers. Oysters were tasty as was the $32 Red Fish entree we shared. All in all a very pricey lunch once a few drafts which were added which were overpriced in my opinion. Will try another spot next time.  Not much value here in my opinion.

Chili oysters were actually very very good and I love the rabbit dumplings stew. Overall the flavors were not my favorite but I could definitely see myself coming back here and bringing friends I loved talking to my waiter about the different options and my waiter was very helpful; everything was great. Everything cooked perfectly and unique. I'm not a fan of oysters but I really did like the chili oysters but I had them cooked a little more. Casual atmosphere inside. One of the better restaurants in New Orleans, they actually care. Very popular and gets busy it's also in a really nice neighborhood there lots of restaurants nearby. It got really busy in area after 7pm. Parking on street.

First time in NOLA and first time at this fine establishment! Didn't expect to try something I never had before but I'm glad I did. The fried alligator was sooooo good & the red fish entree was cooked perfectly.

We saw this on a food network list of places to eat while in New Orleans and are SO glad we made it in.  I was feeling like sampling everything so I got the wood fried oysters, fried alligator, ribs, hush puppies (apart of today's special) while my hubby got the hamhock entree. OMG. We almost bit our fingers off. SO good. The entree was fall off the bone tender with flavor throughout (they marinate it for 6 days!!). Out of all my small plates (if I have to pick)...not sure since they were all good but the alligator is notable for how tender it was. My hubby said it was the best he ever had).  And to top it off they gave us warm, lightly toasted bread rolls at the beginning of the meal.  In addition I didn't finish my cocktail (it was stronger than I liked) and they didn't charge us for it. They won us over. Lovely spot. Great food.
Excellent ribs, excellent staff. I loved the back room where we sat but it was a tad loud so beware if your looking for a chat. Will go again!

This dish was undercooked. I arrived at the restaurant maybe an hour before closing, which could have been a factor. I was not drunk, nor had I had much too drink. But I attempted to eat it because I didn't want to be rude. Soon after I ran to the bathroom and threw up my food. I will say that the gentleman who handled us though was extremely courteous, friendly, and most of all understanding. He took the dish off the bill without hesitation. Just because of this, I would go back. But I won't be ordering that dish again.

Not our first choice but we decided to give it a try. I'm glad we did! I had my first fried alligator and it was delicious! Wood-fire oysters were sooo good too! Best ever! I didn't like the Smoked Hamhock, for me the meat was dry. Service was okay. I'll recommend this place to a friend.

Their rolls are amazing!! They are so soft and sweet. The alligator bites are tender and they are tossed in chilli garlic mayonnaise. We also ordered the Mac and cheese casserole which was great! Very creamy and it had a little kick to it. I would definitely come back and visit again.
I received poor treatment at this establishment because they didn't like the color of my skin #boycott

Starting with the bourbon flights, the information presented about each type of bourbon was very interesting to read and let you know what to expect before diving in. The variety available is great, as they have bourbons from both local distilleries and across the United States.

The fried alligator was one of the best I've had in the city. The remoulade sauce compliments it wonderfully. The dinner rolls that came with our meal were warm and steaming on arrival. They are extraordinarily fluffy, and they went along great with all appetizers. The oysters came out piping hot. They are large and come in a beautiful chili garlic sauce. The oysters were the standout of the meal.

The cochon was perfectly tender. It comes in a side of cabbage and radish, which compliments the flavor well, as well as cracklings to add the right amount of crunch. 

The jambalaya was made with delicious meats. It had strong flavor and is cooked in a way that allows for a crisp crust over the outer portion of the rice. 

Other sides included Brussels sprouts and Mac and cheese. The Brussels sprouts were probably the least healthy you can find, but absolutely delicious with crispy fried onions to boot. The Mac and cheese was creamy and perfectly cooked as well.

The food isn't the only highlight. The staff is very polite and attentive. We did not have to wait for a 12:30 lunch either. The food all comes out quickly, and the decor is lovely. Exposed brick walls and lots of natural lighting in a rustic setting with wooden tables and comfy wooden chairs. 

If you are in the area, I would definitely recommend this place for a meal.

After spending a month in New Orleans I've finally decided. This is my favorite restaurant in the city. It's just so damn dependable, and always satisfying. The grilled oysters are a must, as are the alligator bites. If you need more meat I'd recommend the boudin balls. Oh and yeah, you've got to get the boucherie plate to try all their amazing made-in-house meats. The pickles that come with that meat board almost steal the show, by the way. 

Meat, in general, is something they just do super stinking well, but they're also REALLY good at vegetables (kinda surprising for NOLA, a place where vegetables are as rare as gold). The beet salad I had recently was shockingly flavorful and fresh tasting, and last time I came in for dinner I ordered a pork special which came with a pile of roast broccoli that was almost better than the pig. The pineapple cake that's been on the menu for ages is solid, but maybe not SUPER memorable. But that's forgivable when the rest of the meal is so good.

The service I've had has been good, but perhaps a bit uneven. Sometimes I come in and they're super on point, and other times I've been there and it takes five trips to the table for them to remember I ordered a soda.  Still, they're friendly and attentive when you really need them to be.

We like Cochon Butcher so we were excited to dine at Cochon for dinner. The restaurant was busy as the parade on Canal Street was winding down. The restaurant does have a fun vibe to it and that was nice. Love the interiors -bar design, brick walls and wood accents. We had reservations so we were sat almost immediately. It took about 10 minutes before our server came and greeted our table. Okay, it was a busy night. We ordered our drinks and that took another 10-12 minutes. Knowing this would probably be the trend for the rest of the evening, we placed our appetizer order along with our entrees. We started with Wood-fired Oysters with Chili Garlic Butter, Fried Alligator with Chili Garlic Mayonnaise, Smoked Pork Ribs with Watermelon Pickle and Pork Cheek and Andouille Jambalaya. We loved the oysters (the dinner rolls came in handy for dipping into that sauce) along with the fried alligator (nicely battered and fried - meat is tender and sauce has a nice kick). Pork ribs had a bit too much sauce (for my taste), again with a kick and the jambalaya had good flavor with crispy rice. I had the Louisiana Cochon with cabbage, cracklins and pickled turnips. The meat was tender, but way too salty. I did enjoy our side dishes of Mac n Cheese Casserole and Creamy Grits. The best part of our dinner were the desserts - Milk Chocolate Mousse with Salty Caramel Custard and Chocolate Peanut Crumble, Pineapple Upside-down Cake with Coconut Lime Sherbet and Lemon Chess Pie (we asked our server what "chess pie" meant, but he didn't know). All items on the menu except for the entrees are small plates and meant to be shared. Nothing really stood out for us and the lack of service really left us wanting for more.

DISAPPOINTED ... came here yesterday and I will say service sucked .. hushpuppies were good and the pork ribs but that's it ... the fried livers was ok, our pork hock was not tender... sad, we had high expectations .... I was excited but this place just didn't deliver ... over $100 I paid and wasn't satisfied? That sucks .... go to Johnny Sanchez it was super awesome and half the prize ....

I want to like this place more than I do.
Nothing is bad, but nothing blows me away.

I have gotten the Cuban and the Pig Mac and both were ok.

Fantastic Louisiana food in a casual setting. Wood fired oysters, alligator, pork cheek jambalaya, cochon, and rabbit and dumplings were amazing. Local beers paired great with the food. Service was efficient and friendly. Another go-to fave in NOLA.
Definitely a unique spot if your looking for a cool environment with delicious, small dishes to choose from. One of my top 10 restaurants of all time !!!!

Amazing food. Great ambiance and fantastic service. Must taste while in NOLA. Also as an added bonus they have a limitless Bourbon menu as well. Highly recommend this NOLA fixture for a fun and delicious night out.

Very creative dishes. Cochon is more focused on meat dishes rather than seafood, though they had quite a few fish dishes we were more looking for shellfish which they only had wood grilled oyster (4 stars quite unique). 

My favorite would be the Cochon (very tender and unique), braised chuck (unique flavor), 4 stars. The rabbit and jambalaya, hush puppy, boucherie were good but not outstanding (3.5 stars). The best was surprisingly delightful fried livers (and creamy livers in the boucherie), 5 stars.

The dining experience was quite pleasant too, like the setting, decor, and causal yet comfy sitting. Quite a nice location too as we watched the Mardi Gras parade from the restaurant. One thing I wasn't happy about was that the waiters weren't attentive enough, takes a few tries to get attention, after several having blank stares of me waiving, come on you think I accept that you simply don't see me?

Wow! That's all I can say after trying these amazing Wood-Fired Oysters. My Lyft driver recommended Cochon last night and I was leaving New Orleans to get back to Houston and I pulled up to a gas station and looked across the street and there it was, Cochon in all its glory! Of the Oysters and Alligator, I liked the Oysters the best, probably the best tasting I've ever had. The fresh bread and butter was a great touch. I was eating alone, but this would be a great place to come with friends. Can't wait to try those Oysters again! On to Houston!
Oops We should have brought our food scale to check the small portions.. Rice in jambalaya was over cooked.
Every part of our meal was incredible. We swooned over 4 of the signature cocktails. The small plates of alligator and fried livers were both tender and I'm still talking about them 4 months later!

Got the soul food here and it did not fail! Finally good Mac and cheese and some bomb food all around!

Got the smoked ribs with watermelon pickle and it was fall off the bones melt in my mouth goodness! And the pickled watermelon was a nice touch to the dish! Give it a try!

Tried the fried alligator they're known for, and it was quite interesting. Tbh, it tasted like fried chicken! So give it a try if you're adventurous!

Next time I'll also try their famous chili garlic oysters with a different twist; so if you like to try oysters a new way, quite a different touch. But sounds bomb!
Best restaurant in our visit to New Orleans. Every meal was so tasty and paired well with your drink of choice. I had a whiskey flight which went well with my Cochon (pork) dinner.

To be honest I liked this place but it was quite expensive. The fish was good as well as the chocolate mousse. The rabbit and dumplings was my least favorite , it was like a stew. It would recommend the fried alligator and the red fish .

Service was topnotch. I had to catch a flight later, and server made sure food was on time and we left with literally 1 minute to spare. The flight was literally boarding when we got to the airport.  Drink selection was good, extra bread always wins brownie points

A couple blocks down the road from the National WWII Museum, Cochon is a good place to have a nice meal at with creative takes on New Orleans classics. 

We stopped by after checking out the National WWII Museum for an early dinner, and their menu offered a range of choices but nicely fit on to the front side of one page. They offer nicely plated (and somewhat more expensive) versions of many Cajun staples, and as someone who loves pork, I tried their pork cheek and sausage jambalaya and their namesake cochon. The jambalaya was pleasantly smoky, with plenty of sausage and pork cheek, although the slightly tough cheek seemed to be a waste of a very delicate cut. The cochon was an interesting ball of smoky pork that was tender but a little dry. This dishes were seasoned well, but could have used a touch more spiciness (easily fixed by their pleasant but otherwise unmemorable hot sauce). I had a refreshing gnarly barley IPA that paired well with the meal.

Severs were very nice. The recommended fried alligator and oysters were good but honestly passable. They serve this delicious bread at the beginning of the meal, delicate but not sweet like brioche. While I feel that this place is a bit more expensive than it needs to be, everything on the menu sounded amazing and everything I tried tasted pretty good. Would consider returning if I was in town again. 4 stars.

Went here on the recommendation of a friend and it did not disappoint. Cochon's porky menu deeply satisfied me and my entire group of touristy friends. I love the reimagining of Creole food into something more akin to upscale dining without crossing the border into high falutin or pretentious. Because we were a large party, we had a fixed menu but it had all the delicious favorites, so we got to experience what I feel is the perfect survey of the menu: fried alligator bites with the perfect dipping sauce that disappeared the most quickly from our table; mac & cheese so creamy it nearly sent me into blissful sleep; the most AMAZING fish!! preparation I have ever had, and this is coming from someone who rarely, if ever, orders the fish entree at a restaurant; plus other delicious things I can't remember. Seriously, I was shocked at how good the fish was & if you are going to get anything, please try that and be as surprised as I was at the most excellent, savory preparation. 

It was a good, solid meal in a perfect setting for convivial conversation, friends & drinks. If you're looking for a nice dinner while in New Orleans, this is a dependable choice!

Unexpected treasure that straddles the French Quarter and Warehouse district.  Perfect entrance into New Orleans hospitality and Creole cooking.  Accommodated our vegan side with a special surprise entree!!  Great specialty drinks and micro brews.   Omg. Best ever Brussels sprouts casserole.  Oysters to die for.  Spicy and savory.  Amazing taste sensations.  Great service.   Don't hesitate to walk thru this door!
First time at this restaurant and it was great. We ordered a lot of food. The pork ribs were amazing, meat falling of the bone! And the ouster were delicious.

What a fine introduction to New Orleans. Recommended by a friend we decided to try Cochon in the warehouse district just for fun. We ordered several of the smaller plates to share because everything looked so good. We started with a strawberry salad, usually a California type dish, this one had the southern addition of candies peanuts and mustard greens. Great way to start the dinner. My husband ordered the smoked ribs with watermelon pickle. They were melt in your mouth tender with just a little spice and the contrast with the sweet/sour crunchy watermelon pickle was wonderful. I had the fried boudin with pickled  peppers. Again the pickled peppers were a great contrast to the richness of the fried boudin. 

The restaurant is deceiving, you walk into the bar area with a few 4 tops and then turn a corner to a huge area in the back. It is in a warehouse with the kitchen and the smoker off of either side in the middle. Ambience was fun, not too noisy and obviously a choice for families, tourists and locals. Love it

This was the best lunch in months
 Fried alligator is from outside of this world. Chocolate mousse was really good as well. Really fast and very nice service. Overall, outstanding

Amazing food and service in a challenging evening.  Had a large group during Bacchus parade and we were treated very well.  Restaurant was flexible w our reservation time and the service was flawless.  Food matched the level of service.

We were well behaved, but drunk, and they made it extremely easy for us.

One of the best meals we've eaten in 20+ years of NOLA visits
Omg! So good! The fried livers with pepper jelly was everything!!! Can't wait to come back!

First visit. In town for meeting. This place was walking distance to my hotel. Very busy, but very accommodating staff got me (as a walk-in) a table within 30 min. Food was good, but not great. The Yelp photos, and the creative descriptions, far outpace the reality of the food presented. I don't understand the rave reviews for the baked oyster appetizer. They looked great on the plate (and in the Yelp photo), but simply put, they were bland. Jalapeño hushpuppies good, but could't find the jalapeños. Catfish - good, but nothing special; sort of a stew.  Decided to try the strawberry mouse for desert. Gawd! Had the texture of jello.  Best part of this meal was not the food, but the pleasant ambiance and the stellar service.

Last restaurant of our NOLA trip and worth it.
Oir group shared jambalaya, louisiana cochon, smothered greens, shrimp grits, gator, beet salad, boudin. 

Of those, best were shrimp grits, gator, jamabalaya, beet salad. If I had to complqin about anything, it's that the cochon was on the saltier side but everything was fantastic and service was amazing.

Probably the best meal that we had in New Orleans. Casual and open environment. Like all the other reviews, I would say that the wood fired oyster and fried alligator starters are not to be missed. The cochon plate was good but the redfish, great.

This is the place to try great food in casual atmosphere- the alligator bites were so good, we ate them before I took pictures!  You also have to try the macaroni & cheese - everything was delicious, including the warm rolls - if I come back to New Orleans, i will definitely stop by Cochon!!

Loved this place. I sat at the bar and had great conversation with the bartenders and other patrons. It's just a comfortable vibe. I had the Deviled Egg Gumbo and Jambalaya; both were filled with great flavor. The gumbo was my favorite because of its depth of flavor. My food came out within minutes of me ordering it which was an added perk. I would recommend reservations as this place is very highly rated.
Very solid spot. The alligator was a bit disappointing but the Mac & cheese, stuffed potatoes, rabbit, greens, all was absolutely excellent!

Great find for a good price. The seating is a little crazy! We ended up eating standing up at the bar to skip a 2.5 hour wait. The food is on point and the sides are delish. Had the Mac and cheese and jambalaya ... both good but not the best. The Louisiana Cochon w cabbage and turnips were the main! Def a goto if in New Orleans!

We came here for dinner and managed to get a table without much wait even though we didn't have reservations. We started with the fried alligator then shared the rabbit and dumplings and the Louisiana cochon. The food is definitely on the heavy side but everything was really delicious. The price point is slightly on the expensive side which isn't a surprise given the name recognition of the chef.

The. Best. Place. To. Eat. Ever. 

Delicious, savory and SMOKEY. Not a tourist trap like some other places people maybe tell you to head to if your from out of town. Must go here to enjoy the drinks and the delicious specials. The meats are perfectly tender juicy and Smokey. The chefs here are super talented. This will be the first place I return to eat when I come back to NOLA.

Cool place. I got to sit by the kitchen and watch the line cools work hard. I would give this place a 3.5 stars. First, the service was great. I had the oysters. They weren't nearly as good as the ones you get on Bourbon Street. So if you have a first timer to oysters don't let it be at this place. I will say they were clean. I can't stand to bite into a gritty oyster. Just not too flavorful. Then I tried the gumbo. It was good but I like mine spicy so I added their hot sauce in it and it didn't do much to take it up a few notches. Not a bad thing if you like your gumbo mild. Then I got the ribs. Man!!! They where almost perfect. Unfortunately I mine came out cold!? How is that possible when they are in the fire for a while. Unless they sat underneath the heat lamp, too long. I wish I would have looked because I remember see some setting there for a while. Even before I order mine and mine came out pretty fast so it's possible they gave me the ones setting there for a while. The second thing about these ribs was that they were not "fall off the bone" tender. They needed some time. That takes me to my third point this ribs had the potential to be perfect. The sauce is an amazing blend of sweet and spicy. I'm a Texas girl and over here if you need sauce you didn't do it right. So I generally do not like sauce, but this sauce I would ask for more. Finally, I love pecan BBQ so they got that right for me. If you're use to mesquite, pecan is different but it's better in my opinion. But who am I?

Oh yeah the Mac and cheese nearly made me cry it was so damn good! Don't leave this place without trying it.

Very artsy decor. It is spacious and doesn't look so from the outside! There is also outdoor seating. The food is really really good! We chose the fried alligator. The sauce was very tasty. I think they add mint to it, which I enjoyed! We also chose the roasted cauliflower which was one of their small plates. It was lemony and on the dryer side. Took me a few bites to enjoy it, but loved it after. The catfish courtbouillon was our entre. That was a hit! The catfish was juicy, soft, the rice well made and the curry seeped into the rice and fish really well. We also got a side of Mac and cheese, which was fantastic! And I don't really eat Mac and cheese.
