A creative and upscale restaurant doing inventive things with southern food and pork. This place was pretty acclaimed and regularly busy so we made a reservation a few days ahead of time. We sat outside on the patio. Service was helpful and accommodating with questions, but seemed like they were spread a little thin so had to wait a little longer to get our order in. The pre-meal cornbread is pretty solid and has a nice crusty texture, and it comes with a salted butter that pairs nicely. The wood fired oysters comes with an absolutely killer chili garlic sauce, which is also amazing to dip with the cornbread. Definitely get more bread to mop it all up. The fried alligator bites are really interesting. It's kind of like popcorn chicken, but the sauce and breading elevate it up. The alligator itself is very chewy and overall definitely a really unique dish. The crawfish pie is basically like an empanada. The crawfish itself was not too crazy but the texture of the pie was perfectly flaky and crispy. Three really good dishes for sure. 

We got the cochon special, which for that day was basically a huge piece of pork cooked at different parts - pork belly and skin and chops. It was kind of like a big pork steak, topped with some roasted Brussel sprouts. This thing was really good and unlike any pork I've had. The pork was cooked immaculately, every bite was perfectly juicy and rich. The combination of textures between the crispy skin, gelatinous fat, and juicy meat was like a perfect harmony of pork. This feels like the upper limits of what you can get out of pork. This isn't really necessarily a "flavor" or "seasoning" type of dish - it's more like a steak in that what makes it good is the quality of the meat and how it's cooked to bring out the taste inherent to the meat itself. "Let the meat talk." This dish didn't blow me away in terms of bite-to-bite flavor but was a very interesting dish in its own right. I just wish it was served or presented in a more accessible way so that it's easier to tackle and eat the different parts more evenly. 

We had the pineapple upside down cake for dessert. The cream on the side is pretty light and tasty, and the sauce is really good. The cake itself is solid as well, with a nice warmth, texture, and balance of lighter sweet flavors. Not terribly memorable but a good dessert for sure. 

I don't think I ended up being as floored as Cochon as I was expecting to be but I came away still very full and satisfied. This probably wasn't my favorite meal of our NOLA trip but I think it was the most interesting and inventive. This definitely a memorable meal and certainly worth the visit.

Lunch here was great!  My friend and I shared the Fried Pork Shank and it was AMAZING!  The outside was crispy delicious skin and the inside meat was moist and juicy.  The sauce seemed to be a honey glaze served with fresh Cilantro and Mint.  The mix of the herbs with the honey were perfect with the pork.  So glad we decided to stop here for lunch.  Service was great too, Nakala took care of us and made sure we were enjoying our food and kept our beverages filled throughout the meal.

Our experience at Cochon was pleasant. Service was quick and food was delicious. Drinks are also well crafted. The oysters on garlic chili oil was a winner

The alligator was different. If you don't mind eating alligator then it's probably good.  Just not for me.

The pork neck meal was well made according to my friend as i don't eat pork.

Will definitely be back to try more things in the menu.

In the industry we call this a OYRU!  (official yelp review update)

So back in the day this place was all that...  2013-2015 era...  It was on Anthony Bourdain... you couldn't get in the place.  I initially visited there in 2014 I think...

I remember having a good experience, not great.  But wanted to go back and give myself another opinion.

Came here with my ole lady recently, and it was ayight not great.

I think its one of those places that is super popular at first and everyone wants to go there, then they step it down after a year or two and its just not as good.  My ole lady had the rabbit which she says was pretty good.  I had the pork belly - same.

Honestly I think the food is better at Cochon the Butcher next door.

First stop in New Orleans and it was a pretty good one. Oysters were amazing and that sauce it comes in is heavenly. It's a garlic butter sauce that goes along well with the bread. Also got the pork belly, but at that point it was getting a little too savory for me. The fattiness of the pork belly really needed something sour or fresh to cut though it's richness, but sadly it didn't have enough on the side like a bigger salad to do so. I would say the skin was really crunchy though and that made it a little better by adding texture. Not sure if I would be back but it was for sure a great experience.

Excellent customer service. They are social distancing the tables which is a nice change compared to other restaurants. The food was delicious. We ordered the wood fired oysters which were absolutely delicious and the Louisiana Cochonwhich was tender, juicy  and flavorful. The service was friendly prompt and attentive.

Delicious food and cocktails. We enjoyed a very nice, leisurely dinner. 
However, the unpadded wood chairs proved uncomfortable.

My grandsons and I had lunch here the other day and I was pleasantly surprised with one of the best gumbos I have ever had. It was chicken and sausage with a dark Cajun road just the way I like it. Their take on a crawfish pie was also really good but the star of the show where the free mini buns how out of the oven that they bring to every table.
Great environment. Great, unique food. Only downside is small volume cocktails for the cost of them.

There is a reason Cochon is on every list of top places in NOLA. I started with the whiskey flight which was only 25 dollars! Great price. The wood fired oysters was a great choice for appetizer, the garlic sauce it came with was amazing for also dipping bread. My wife had the smoked porkchop which was the best pork dish I have ever had in my life, it was smoky, juicy and soft which is not typical in pork chops. I would love to go again to try out different things on the menu and the pork chop again. Excellent service as well, staff was very kind

We came here and the first thing we were asked was,"Do you have a reservation?" We didn't abut they had just opened for they day and they were kind enough to make one for us. For appetizers we ordered the fries alligator with was interesting. I had never had it before and the best thing I could say is it tasted like calamari which I like. Also had their gumbo which was really tasty. As an entree we had the braised short ribs with squash and it was delicious. This is of course too much for me to eat so I had to take most of it to go including the cornbread muffin and carrot cake we had for dessert. All of which where gone by the end of the night. 
Waiter was decent he filled our glasses and gave recommendations on the menu.
Awesome food. Boudin and wood fired oysters on point. Especially dipping house made bread into chili butter. Braised short ribs were amazing

From start to finish a 5/5 experience. Brandy and the other hostess were friendly and accommodating at the door. Our server, Anastasia, was friendly, attentive, knowledgeable. 

Brandy made this dining experience a truly special one with her anecdotes of New Orleans, the history of Cochon and the restaurant group as a whole. 

We came in as strangers on a weekend getaway and left as friends of the many staff we engaged with. 

Great job to chef and FOH staff.

This is one of our go-to restaurants in NOLA (from LA).  Love love love!!  Coincidentally, a special client of mine was having a pre-wedding event here so I asked Cochon to assist me in surprising her with a nice bottle of wine.  Every time I called to coordinate this the front of the house staff was SO SO nice and helpful and went the extra mile.  I will always recommend this place.  Thank you so much!!

Not a friendly or helpful business. The hostess rudely told us leave and go across the street to a more family friendly restaurant. Maybe I'm seeing things wrongly but that to me is considered DISCRIMINATION towards me and my family. But it's probably my mistake for thinking they were a business trying to make money.
Awesome seafood and fresh water cuisine available, it's heaven for pescatarians like me

Get a reservation before you read the rest of my review.

Cochon was a restaurant suggested to my boyfriend and I by a few friends, a few travel books, and a few locals we talked to while we were visiting New Orleans. It's clear why... this was one of the best dining experiences I've had in a long while! This restaurant advertises itself as cajun and southern cooking, so my second tip after "make a reservation" is come hungry! I was definitely nervous when we arrived and saw the upscale atmosphere that the portion size would be small, but was VERY happy with what we were served.

We were lucky enough to be in NOLA during "crawfish time," and had the opportunity to enjoy a few additional menu items while we were dining at Cochon. My boyfriend chose the crawfish etouffee with Louisiana popcorn rice for his main course. It was rich, and flavorful. There was so much crawfish meat swimming around in the hearty etouffee broth. He was basically licking the bowl at the end because he enjoyed it so much. For my meal, I chose the rabbit and dumplings. I did have to ask our waiter what it was because there was no description on the menu. As soon as he said it's their version of a pot pie, I was sold. The dumplings were perched atop the most flavorful gravy I've ever tried. The meat was tender and paired perfectly with the mouthwatering veggies in the dish. 

Even though you are served a TON of food, do yourself a solid and order the mac and cheese casserole. That was the most memorable part of the meal. The crunchy cheese top was like breaking into a creme brulee. The mac and cheese had an awesome cheese blend and tasted like it had four or five pounds of butter in it. It was the perfect side dish. 

The cocktail menu was very long. They had so many different drinks to choose from. It was a tad overwhelming. The bar also featured tons of craft whiskeys. It is definitely easy to rack up a big tab when you're dining at Cochon.
Great casual dining restaurant. The food was delicious. Pork was cooked to perfection and just as ordered. The menu was a bit limited. But I would come back again.
Scrumptious food, amazing service and comfortable atmosphere!!! Order the cracklings, ratatouille and fried alligator  delicious
See Matt C's review, which I've attached to this one. He is spot on. Good, but nothing special.

Omg sooo freaking good. Had the New York strip (gluten free) and it was wonderful. Almost licked the plate too bad people were watching so had to control myself. Hubby got the ham steak with succotash and it was awesome (gluten free also), I did finish his. Great selection of whiskey and bourbon, had a great old fashion. Service was awesome! Must go to restaurant in NOLA, we go every time we are in town.

Cochon has become our go to! We love the service and the food, We feel comfortable there and always have a good evening under their roof! Can't say enough about the dishes they serve and the service!:)

We came here to try the fried alligator which we haven't had before. It literally just tastes like chicken. The gumbo was good but the mac and cheese was the best dish, along with the greens coming in second. Our experience was true when it comes to the server can make or break your restaurant. 

When we asked our server Rebecca what cheese was in the mac and cheese, she had to go find out. Then she came back with a generic answer of it being a blend of cheddar cheeses. HAHA, ok. You might as well just tell us you don't want to tell us, or you couldn't find out. Later on near the end of our meal when we asked her two more questions, she was slowly walking away from our table while giving us the answer. It seemed like she just wanted us out of there or didn't have time for us, a table of 2.
Fantastic dinner with a wonderful twist on Creole dishes.  Ensure you try the Wood-Fried Oysters With Chili GarlIc...go ahead and order extra bread...trust me.... Friendly staff and great service!

Cochon was a tasty and unique take on NOLA food. We enjoyed sampling Cajun staples (such as gumbo and catfish) as well as trying some funky Louisiana dishes, such as fried alligator. Service was incredible. 

An additional star would have been given for better atomosphere and some healthier options on the menu. Overall, very good experience.
The bread is delicious, it is given when asked.  Everything is a la carte, servings are small not enough to satisfy wish they were not just a taste.  Very expensive!
Beautiful place and great staff. I had a steak that was perfect and Gumbo was delicious. Make reservation they fill up quick

It's New Orleans so it's no surprise that everything was full flavor. I would recommend the rabbit and dumplings, delicious!
I also tried the boudin balls and pork & bacon pie. Just lovely! I'll definitely be back. 
If you're diving, there are nearby paid parking lots and there's street parking.

Such an amazing time last night. Jeff, Mike, and Aaron--the bartenders-were quite efficient. Jeff was my main bartender and he was so friendly. Sit at the bar, if you can. This is where the magic is! One of the managers Jacob came to check on me as I had made a reservation. It was a very thoughtful touch and it didn't hurt that he was both friendly and fortunate looking. I ate alligator bites--yummy. I had the wood fired oysters--yummy yummy. Then, the drinks were all amazing and fresh. Thanks for a wonderful time!

I thought I was out of luck without a reservation for lunch, but I made a phone call and the waitress just wrote me in. I entered and it was pretty empty on the weekday.

I ordered the alligator bites and fried boudin balls, loved both. The alligator bites I guess can be demeaned to better versions of orange chicken, but the orange sauce on this was much more sophisticated and complex. I ate every single bit, with the garnishes too, in between a split complimentary Hawaiian roll (amazing choice for bread basket). Delicious. One of my favorite dishes. 

The boudin balls came with three, side of some mustard and pickled vegetables. Delicious! The two were filling enough for me, but I wish I could have tried their other offerings.

Their rotating entree of chef's choice pork specialty never fails to impress. The brined, smoked, and grilled ham steak on offer when we were last there was the most delicious, outstandingly prepared cut of pork I've ever tasted. This is not a kiddie, quick-eats sort of place. Plan to slow down a bit, put down the phones and actually have a conversation with your dinner party, and savor a freshly prepared meal of exceptional pork dishes. Note: Some of the tags or reviews say "Vegetarian-friendly." That has got to be a joke - There are good options, to be fair, but they will not be pleased with the smokehouse aroma and most of the menu. Carnivores, though, will experience a bit of dining bliss.

Perfect dining in New orleans. Wood fire kitchen is super great. That make everything delicious. 

For Gulf fish, well seasoned and perfectly cooked. Also, tody's cochon, Porkbelly was amazing. Crispy outside and juicy inside and summer corn. 

They have good wine lists and hard liquors.

I should come back again.

Drove a couple hours to try this place and they wouldn't let me eat here because I was a party of 1.  Plenty of open seats indoor and out.  Don't go here solo.  They did nothing to accommodate.

Update: I went back to see if they do takeout (which was never offered), and they did so I went to the bar to order takeout and a seat opened at the bar.  I sat there and was treated like garbage by the bartender.  Not sure if the hostess told him about me leaving upset, but he had a bad attitude with me but was very pleasant with the other guests.  At the end he gave me a bill that wasn't mine.  The pork Belly was $38 way overpriced.  This morning I have been sick to my stomach something fierce.  Do not recommend this place at all.

Service was amazing, decor was pleasant and omg the drink names were so creative! My partner and I visited the gem before hitting the road back to FL. From the moment you walk in you can smell the savory smells of meat. I enjoyed everything but especially the oysters and corn salad. I can definitely see myself visiting when in town but for dinner.

I started with the Huckleberry beer (Trail Dog Tangerine Wheat). This was a heavier style, and I would say better tasting, of a tradition Blue Moon beer. 

For dinner I chose the fried catfish  with grits, sweet pepper salad, cured pork, and chili sauce. Who would've thought that mint leaves would've been good is something like this?! It was great though. The veggies were not overdone or too oily, they were just right. Catfish was flaky and lightly breaded. The grits were great as well, not overly done. The portion was a little smaller than expected, but for the quality it was worth the price. 

The venue has a wide open feel with a modern look. It is on the corner of the street so there are windows all around allowing natural light in. 

The staff was helpful, knowledgeable, and attentive.

Absolutely outstanding service and food!  Delicious cocktails.  The grilled oysters and their pot liquor were incredibly tasty.  The fried boudin is perfect.  The ham steak has a smokey depth of flavor that is a whole new experience in eating pork. These guys know what they are doing!

We went to eat at Cochon our first day visiting New Orleans. It was the perfect introduction to all the delicious creole food! All the dishes we tried were so flavorful and delicious. The wood fired oysters were incredible, I had never had oysters like that! Also, it was my first time trying fried alligator, and  I thought it was very yummy as well. But the star of the show was the cake at the end! It was a special corn pudding cake! Best of my life for sure! The service was outstanding as well, I can't wait to go back to Nee Orleans to visit this restaurant again.

What a great choice for lunch. Walking distance from my hotel in the warehouse district.  Sat at the bar sampled the grilled oysters (amazing) with the best fresh baked rolls. Gumbo was delicious.  Had the chili dusted Cracklin and the a great piece of carrot cake. A touch pricey but worthy of the pricing.

Food here was only so-so... we got gumbo, which was decent. Alligator for appetizer which was also okay. But the fish plate was not good- it was so salty and soggy for some reason. We had to send it back. But the manager came by and apologized and offered to remove it to make things right. That was nice and appreciated. We also ordered dessert, a peach ice cream on cornbread or something - that was probably the best thing we had. Overall experience was fine. Nice restaurant and good vibes. But yeah, a bit underwhelmed with the food.

Probably the best restaurant I went to during my brief visit to New Orleans, which I maintain, is a terrific food city, one that rivals or sometimes tops New York City. We had dinner here during my brother's bachelor party weekend, and I think the entire group of like, a dozen of us guys ordered pretty much everything on the menu. And everything on the menu was really, REALLY good. It was one of the best meals of my life. Plus, we kind of had a little competition going with the bachelorette party at the table next to us.
All of the food, wine, and dessert was amazing! The fried alligator was a must-have. Our waitress was nice too. Would definitely recommend!

Absolutely amazing food. Seated quickly although it was not busy when we arrived. Waiter was amazing, I wish I remembered his name but even as the place grew busy he didn't slow his service to us. Food was incredible, pork belly was perfectly done and the skin was absolutely delightful and crispy. Over all, this is probably one of the most delicious meals I've had in months and for a price you cannot beat. The kitchen also looks amazing and I wish I could tour it and see how they make their food.
Literally the best meal we had in New Orleans. Their gumbo is so rich with such an abundant amount of flavor that it makes you stop and say "oh, damn!"

Came for a birthday dinner! The best part of the evening was the service - everyone was nice and professional! We had higher expectations about the drinks and food however we were a bit disappointed wishing there was a nicer twist of flavor and presentation. We tried the 1lb Cochon, cucumber salad, alligator bites (must try), oyster and pineapple cakes and chocolate mousse for deserts - all was just fine! My favorite was the complimentary freshly baked bread. Overall good experience - Cochon is definitely a place I would recommend to friends;)
Yassssssss everything was so flavorful!!!! The alligator was interesting- my first time having that and I would try it again. The Rabbit and dumplings was sooooo good !

Ratings
Food 10/10
Service 10/10

Everything about this place was excellent, had a unique flavor, and provided the best Gumbo in New Orleans we have tasted.

I visited this place with 3 others for the first time.  The restaurant itself is really nice. The menu is compact and initially I wasn't sure I was going to like it. I ordered the Woodfire Oysters, the Oyster Sandwich and the pineapple upside down cake. The Woodfire Oysters were delicious. I just wish there were more of them for the price. The Oyster sandwich was HUGE but it was also delicious. The slaw paired with it was good too. However, I wasn't a fan of the Pineapple Upside Down cake. It tasted like it was made with cornbread or some sort of grainy bread... I also like that I was able to pay and tip really easily by scanning a code on my phone.  Overall though, it was a good experience. I'd go back.
Delicious food. The rabbit and dumplings was perfect. Filet was well seasoned and tasty. Boudin balls were delicious too. Nice pour on cocktails. We didn't try dessert.

On every trip to New Orleans, we try to avoid all touristy restaurants and focus on simple, great food. Cochon has a very cute, woody vibe. The customer service is great, our waiter was very attentive without being overbearing. 

Food review: 

Complimentary bread: nice crust on top, soft underside, served with a light butter

Fried alligator: good but just not our cup of tea. If you like gator, try it out

Wood fired oysters: served with a very tasty sauce. We personally prefer thinner oysters. These were very plump 

Cracklings: best I have ever add

Sweet tea: the bomb! 

Cucumber salad: light and refreshing with a tad kick

Pork belly, shishito peppers, and Mac and cheese are MUST HAVES!
Second time here from an out of town, and this should be a go to for everyone. I wish they still had their charcuterie plate option, but quality and taste is tip top!

My boyfriend and I went here on my last night in New Orleans and I was upset he didn't take me sooner! I had the tuna steaks and he had the beef short ribs (highly recommend!) The cuts were perfect and deliciously cooked. I have a shellfish allergy and the waiter was kind enough to tick off all the things on the menu that would safe from cross contamination from shellfish! The service was excellent and the restaurant left a wonderful taste and dining experience memory of my last night in the culture-rich New Orleans

Best place we ate at in New Orleans. 

Alligator was great. Pineapple upside down cake was great. Oysters were great. Wish we had room to eat more pork. 

Good cocktail menu. Really friendly fun staff. Nice decor and cool clientele. Very reasonable priced for the quality and amount of food. 

I had been having a battle to pay for meals with my friends. The server for my table let me sneak my credit card to her well before the meal was over to make sure I could pay for it. Thanks for that!!!

Would definitely make an effort to visit again next time I'm here, and I want to try the butcher too!

Unfortunately I was underwhelmed by my dining experience here. I was expecting it to be good from the high reviews but really just mediocre. They also hold a card for reservations ($25 penalty for no shows/late cancellations).

The cochon came lukewarm, the corn on top was cold. The meat was pretty tough and hard to chew. The flavor was smoky enough and decent. The corn cobs were very dill forward but also came cold and texture wise wasn't a very good corn. The kernels were soft and the corn wasn't sweet. 

The oysters were actually delicious but I'm confused as to why they plated it like this. They could have placed the oysters back in the shell. 

Overall, there are better restaurants in the area.

This was one of my favorite meals while visiting New Orleans, so much so, that I decided to go back again just before my flight home.   They followed all COVID protocols, staff were friendly, provided great service, and food was delicious. Can't ask for much more.  My favorite dishes were the Bacon and Pork Pie, Wood-fired Oysters, and Chili Dusted Cracklin's, and Fried Boudin.  I don't drink but my friends said their drinks are solid and that their gumbo and pork neck special are must try
Nice leisure atmosphere, wait staff friendly and helpful, main course underwhelming for the price, the Cochon was lukewarm in center, maybe I ate too slow, bourbon flight was nice though.
Best charbroiled oysters!! You can dip the bread in the sauce for a little extra. Love the smell of smoke in this restaurant. It's a must when you're in NOLA!

Definitely a must for Nola! The food was very, very delicious but unfortunately the service was terrible that evening! Super slow and our server was confused and inattentive. We ordered the pig's head and obviously weren't nearly close to finishing it but wanted to pack it and bring it back for later. We waited, and waited for a good 30 minutes and we discovered they discarded it! The manager was nice enough to comp our drinks and gave us dessert to go but the server didn't even apologize nor  check on us...?

Otherwise everything else was amazing. Loved the oysters, rabbit dumplings... but next time I wouldn't order the pig's head.

Cochon (not to be mistaken for Cochon Butcher next door) is a solid place to grab dinner.  The ambiance is fun.  The staff is friendly.  The food is generally tasty but not everything on the menu is a solid base hit.  And IMHO, no home runs to be had for the entrée section.

The menu changes, so I cannot say that I've drilled down on anything I love or hate at Cochon.  The menu tends to be very protein heavy, which I like.  In general, the food is seasoned well and occasionally, the cooks are too heavy handed with the salt.  

The gumbo is ok.  I usually order a bowel but it doesn't rank in my top 5 for NOLA.
I am not a fan of their boudin or cracklins.
I have liked their catfish and few cuts of meat.  
I believe I've had the rabbit and dumplings and it was solid but I doubt I would repeat.

All in all, Cochon is pretty good.  It's one of those restaurants for me that could be better and sometimes is depending on the menu.  Before I book a reservation, I will check their menu to confirm they have a few entrees that are particularly enticing.

We were referred to Cochon by a friend and very excited to try this place after our excursion to the WWII museum. 

We came rather early in the evening, around 5pm, and the place was about 1/5 full. By the end of the evening it was packed. 

We perused the menu and instantly went for the Wood Fired Oysters  with chili garlic butter sauce. They were amazing and something I would most certainly order again. About half way through we were offered bread - definitely make sure to ask for the bread first as that garlic butter sauce needs to sopped up with some carby goodness. 

With a changing menu, you'll find a variety of dishes at Cochon throughout the year. When we visited the menu was unfortunately slim pickings for our liking. I opted for the Cochon special while my partner choice the beef. What arrived was a rather large portion of ham steak - which was impressive. But that was really about it. Maybe I'm not a meat connoisseur to know the difference but it didn't impress me any more than a Boston Market ham steak, unfortunately. 

Service was lacking and slow. It took a good 45 minutes from ordering to receive our food. The table we received was incredibly tight and we found ourselves looking to the floor for placing items - which isn't great. 

I'd be interested to return if the menu was something to our liking, but not being from the area it'll remain to be seen if we can.

Love this place. Whether you go to the Butcher or the full restaurant its always been a good meal and great atmosphere. It's a stop every time
I'm in NOLA!

Great atmosphere and bourbon selection was excellent.  

Had the Cochin special. Pork was over cooked and serving size small and not lean. The Hopping John was cold.   Gator appetizer was good.  Our server was great and service was good. 

For the price , it not deliver

Cochon restaurant is nice with a friendly atmosphere. We ordered the catfish with collard greens and grits, sirloin with red potatoes with mushroom slices. Both dishes had an excellent presentation. The portions are adequate and the prices are high for the portion. The food is fresh and flavorful. The sirloin was tender, I got it medium since my past experiences with well done sirloin has ended in tough meat. I did send my plate back because they brought it out and the steak was lukewarm and the butter wasn't melted. When it returned everything was perfect. The current menu is limited with choices but definitely something that will soothe your tastebuds. The carrot cake was delicious and the portion was enough for two.

We went there the other night, based on a referral from my work counterparts daughter. I had the blackened redfish and although I have an eaten a lot of redfish, this dish was not my favorite. It definitely had a fishy taste almost as if it was a couple of days old. A good piece of fish is not supposed to taste like this and it's hard to describe. But all I can say is after every bite of fish, I was cringing having another one I probably ate about 3/4 of it. I think there are better choices in town. Nice atmosphere, and a great wait staff that's the only reason why I gave it a three. I will not be back but that's just me.

We came closer to closing time so it was obvious they were trying to get us to dine relatively quickly. The portion size was good and the flavors were also very good. Definitely recommend making a reservation prior to going!

Tried Cochon for the first time on a Friday night and not disappointed. Snagged a last-second reservation and was seated in the large back dining room. Pretty noisy with two big parties near our table, but all that faded away when the food arrived. Porterhouse was HUGE (and delicious) but I think we actually enjoyed the Mac & Cheese casserole more. Pineapple upside-down cake was a sweet end to the meal. Prices are definitely in the higher range, but hard to complain too much when the product is this good. Service was excellent.

This place is incredible!  I had a wedding rehearsal dinner here for 80 people.
I worked with Jessica Jackson, Jeanette Stansbury and Matt. They were all so professional and nice to work with.They made it easy for me to plan this event.  I met with them the day before and tasted some incredible wines that were served with the dinner.   I live in San Francisco so the menu was all chosen remotely.
Now about the food!!  Everything was delicious and beautifully prepared.  I had passed hors d'oeuvres. The fried oysters were one of the best things I've every tasted.  We then moved on to a four course dinner.  The only problem was I wished we had a 10 course dinner.  Each course was so delicious and served by an amazing staff that was friendly and very competent. 
Thank you to Jessica, Jeanette and Matt for organizing my rehearsal dinner.
The bride and groom and both families were beyond impressed with Cochon.
The Alligator, the catfish, the grits, Delicious!!! I can't wait to explore the rest of the deliciousness on the menu!

If you go to the WW II Museum, this nearby restaurant (2 blocks away) is a must. We had lunch there and it was delicious: fried oyster & bacon sandwich (unimaginably tasty) and a green salad. Reasonably priced, good service, excellent fare.
Been here multiple times over the years. With the amount of good food in NOLA, that says something. Inventive and fresh.

We ordered almost every appetizer on the menu and everything was fabulous. Other people in our party ordered the red fish and they said it was great. Would definitely return here when we are in the Big Easy.  Great staff too.

MAN OH MAN DO I HAVE A LOT TO SAY!!! This was my 2nd time trying it and BOTH times it was phenomenal. I'll start off by saying it is slightly pricey but you honestly get what you pay for! I paid around a total of $117 (not including the tip) for this so I'm yeah lol anyways! Located in the heart area of New Orleans. 
The gumbo 5/5: The flavor is just so savory and delicious. The chicken and sausage is super tender and mind you, I am not a fan of okra but this one in particular is super soft and BARELY noticeable. The flavor is delicious and I never leave a single drop when I order! Definitely a must! 
The fried boudin 5/5: This is honestly a New Orleans staple but these are the best dang boudin balls I've ever had. The texture of the ball is so crispy but the middle is super soft. The meat and the rice are perfectly seasoned it's hard to find anything to compare it with and the Dijon mustard dip I believe they give with it adds a nice sour flavor to it.
The mac and cheese casserole 5/5: I believe it has onions in it? And I am honestly not a fan of onions but I barely even noticed it was in there! And I have some pretty strong taste buds. The macaroni is nice and soft while the top is nice and crispy and hits you with a sharp cheddar flavor. It's enough to honestly get as an entree! 
Lastly we have the smoked porterhouse 2lb pork 5/5: I didn't eat this myself although I think I could considering how delicious it was. The pork has a nice smokey flavor to it and the sauce that comes on top of it has a smokey almost faint wine taste to it? But it isn't anything crazy that takes away the taste of the pork. It really makes the pork even juicer. The pork itself reminded me of a Christmas ham. Except it was super tender and not dry at all. It felt lean honestly. I'm a person who tends to fear too much pork since it usually gives me chest pain if I eat too greasy but this was on point. I didn't even feel full afterwards because I was still down to get some beignets! 
Anyways, if you're visiting New Orleans I definitely recommend trying this place at least once, you will not regret it!

Great food in a relaxed, modern location. Prices seem to be on the higher side by NOLA standards, but being from the Boston area, these prices are more what I am used to.

For food, I had the gumbo, fried gator, and wood-fired oysters. For drinks: the Ramblin Rose and the Elevation.

The gumbo was pleasant and well-balanced. It had good flavor and spice without overdoing it. Some of the rice felt a little undercooked, but I'm not sure if that's intentional. There was also a small bone in the gumbo (oops). 

The fried gator was a tasty dish as well. It was breaded nicely, and I liked the chili-garlic mayonnaise sauce and other garnishes.  I want to note that some pieces were a little less tender than others, but full disclosure, I'm not sure if that is the nature of gator meat.

The wood-fired oysters were solid. These were cooked oysters in a buttery and slightly spicy sauce. Not at all bad as far as cooked oysters go. 

As for the drinks:

The Ramblin Rose was light and refreshing. I could feel the alcohol within, but this drink is not at all spirit-forward. The Elevation, meanwhile, brought some of those spirits closer forward, as well as some smokey and spicy notes!

The food came out quickly, and the service was kind.

A pleasant surprise of a place after a day at the museum; an easy five minute walk.  Great bar area in a modern atmosphere of a fine, fun dining experience.  Service was good. Braised short ribs were delicious with just a bit of spice and two potatoes with finely diced vegetables. Really good and recommended.  Mac-n-cheese was also good and had some great taste too. I wanted to do the oysters but I felt they were a little pricey on my budget. Great place. Try it!
Fantastic lunch spot. Great service and wine selection. Gumbo was incredible, squash was perfection.

Making reservations is easy with the app.  Anastasia (sp?) was our server and she is very courteous.  There are so many great appetizers I had to order three!  None of them disappointed. I had the pork pie, boudin balls, and fried alligator.  The fried alligator is served with a mint garnish - excellent.  As an entree I had the rabbit & dumplings which was peppery, velvety, rustic, and filling! I enjoyed it.  It did not taste "gamey" at all.

4.5 stars here. our dinner with friends on arrival in New Orleans. Highly regarded Cajun cuisine that works with local farms for a large amount of their ingredients. Menu, though not extensive, looked great before our arrival so was looking very forward to our meal. I would consider it on the pricy side, though maybe not for New Orleans. Very personable service throughout our time here. Once seated we ordered drinks and perused the menu. A bowl of delicious rolls with butter arrived shortly. Having just gotten off a plane and not being all that hungry, along with being budget conscious, we chose to order light. Wife ordered the bacon and pork pie and the cucumbers and herbs in vinegar salad. My choices were the chicken & andouille sausage gumbo along with fried alligator with chili garlic mayo. The pork pie was a bit light on flavor-lacking any discernible seasoning or bacon flavor. More bacon would add a lot. The crust was well made and it was cooked perfectly. Cucumber salad had a large amount, IMO, of red chili flakes not listed on the menu. Avoiding them was difficult but she powered through it, pronouncing it "fine". My gator was delicious, tasting very fresh and lightly breaded. But for me, as I was expecting, the chili mayo was too much for my palate. Very small bits of sauce added to the flavor but it was easy to add too much. The gumbo was the star of the show for me. Deep, rich flavor profile along with tender veggies and sausage that was flavorful without being too hot. I should really have ordered more of this.

I didn't pay as much attention to our companions' meals as I should have but I did try a bite of the wood fired gulf fish served "fishermen's" style that on our visit was redfish. Requested grilled, it had a great seasoning and was very reminiscent, IMO, of a fresh trout, though the person who ordered it compared it to halibut. I didn't think so.  Desserts were a German Chocolate Pie and an Apple Cider donut. The donut was pronounced flavorful by our fellow diners but I never tried it as I was fully involved in our pie. I will say it was not really like a pie IMO as the texture was very firm, not soft and moist like a traditional pie. It resembled to me more of a pecan pie with chocolate and coconut or a 7-layer bar for those who know what those are. Very very good. A really enjoyable meal. I'd come back again for sure.
Sheesh.....get the damn pigs feet. Get the damn catfish. Get the damn rabbit. So damn awesime.

Hands down the best food in Nola. So good, went back a second night. The rabbit and dumplings has to be number 1 item, followed closely by the spare ribs. Was part of a group and we all did family style so we could taste everything. Honestly, you can't go wrong with any of the dishes.

I came for lunch with a group of 8 for lunch.  The space itself was great and had a nice warm/homey feel to it.  We started off with bacon/pork pie and fried boudin. Fried boudin is a cajun meatball with rice and pork in it. Both starters were so delicious.  We were fighting over the leftovers and debated ordering more.  I had the cucumber salad.  It was nice to have that to brighten up my palate before the next course.  The entrée I had was a grilled flank steak with potatoes and mushrooms.  The steak was cooked to perfection and very tender.  The potatoes and mushrooms were a perfect addition to the steak.  My husband had the cochon of the day which was a fried pork chop.  Oh my lord!  It was soo good and I kept getting bites of his. 

The staff were very attentive and friendly.  This is a must-do in NO.  I can't wait to go back!

Out of all the restaurants I've tried during my week in New Orleans, Cochon was the best.  I should have gone back to try the rest of the menu.  For my drink, I got a lemonade.   It was house made and refreshing.

To start, we had beautiful warm bread rolls with butter.  They were like King's Hawaiian sweet rolls, but to the next level.  The wood fired oysters with chili garlic butter were incredible!  I've never had oysters served like this.    They came in a hexagon cast iron and you could taste how fresh the oysters were.  I should have ordered one more.  

Fried Alligator with chili garlic mayonnaise.  The alligator had a nice fried coating that was dressed with delectable mayo.  I order alligator whenever I see it on the menu and I would definitely come back for more.

I agree with a previous review that stated nothing was wrong but nothing was great. In a place where so many places to eat are outstanding this isn't one I would repeat or recommend if you have one night in NOLA.

That being said, excellent service. The stand outs food wise where the wood fired oysters and the rabbit & dumplings, the boudin, Cochon, and short ribs where as described but not inspiring, the alligator and dessert was not great.

Wonderful food, great service, chef is an awesome person too. We've been coming here for years, whenever we are in town. Often have my birthday dinner here with a large group. Never a disappointment, always a pleasure. Can't wait to return!
Good, but not great. We enjoyed the dishes but nothing was a wow. Seemed to be coasting and not trying for fresh ideas and imaginative.

Unfortunately Cochon has definitely gone downhill since we last ate here. For what you pay, the service is quite sloppy, and the food is somewhat lacking.

For example, our server forgot to review the beef/fish/pork options on the menu when she was taking our drink order; we didn't get bread until long after our appetizers arrived; we ordered a dessert wine with our dessert and were told they couldn't find it after we had already finished the food...

In terms of the main courses: the Cochon tasted good, but there was more fat than actual meat on the portion. My meal partners kept cutting and digging for an inordinate amount of time to actually find bits of meat to eat. We also ordered the gulf fish dish, and it was rather overcooked, the skin was unscaled (and therefore inedible), and it was strangely under-seasoned and flavorless.

All in all, it was pretty disappointing for such an expensive meal. It was the worst meal of our trip to New Orleans.

Service was awesome, great drinks, the grilled oysters were wow!!!!! The sauce it's self could be drank. The shrimp app was amazing!!!!! Oyster Poe boy was so so but the rest of our meals were to die for. Great spot must go, best experience while in town, did not lack staffing and if so did a great job.
Loved the food!! Catfish and grits was delicious, pork good. Only reason for the one less star is we didn't get the app we ordered.
The food was excellent but pricey. The wait staff, Nick, was attentive without being overly intrusive.

Went there December 23 2021. Service was awesome and food was delicious. We were waited on by Juan and Stephanie. They were so knowledgeable about the food. I had the pork chop and was the best I've ever eaten. Highly recommend this cozy place

This restaurant presented the oldest dilemma regarding a restaurant:
What's more important the food or the service?
Even though the food was really excellent I would not go back because of how we were treated.
Let's start with the host. After waiting by the entrance for a while (even though the restaurant was barely at half capacity), the host "found the time" to greet us. We pointed out that there was another group in front of us he replied in the most sarcastic tone: "I know, I was just saying hi". We were really put off but decided to ignore anticipating a great meal.
Then came the waiter. One word to describe him: glacial.
Let's say he was less than enthusiastic to see us there, which strikes me as odd, since I would think servers at a restaurant would be really happy to see any customers on a Tuesday night, when there's a pandemic happening and restaurants are desperately suffering. But that's me.
Bottom line, it's too bad I had to spend the entire review talking about service and didn't even mention the food, which was great.

My friends and I have been to NoLa three times, and Cochon has always been a part of our trips. From a party of 8 to a party of 3, our groups always love coming here! The food is delicious and they have a great whiskey/bourbon list as well! The staff is incredibly kind and helpful. We've never had a bad meal from pork (cochon) to rabbit to gator bites to dessert! We are repeat customers!

Very disappointing small portions.

Ended up paying about $100 of disappointment. 

Pork belly is mostly fat.
Most dishes are essentially overpriced.

They need to work on the portions.

If you like fat and gristle and paying the equivalent of your monthly utility bills for a meal, knock yourself out. I'm sure it's easy to to dupe clueless tourists with this "elevated" Cajun/creole food, but if you've spent any time living in Louisiana you'd probably agree that charging $14 dollars for three slices of hoghead cheese and some stiff crackers is criminal.

I love, love, love this place and it's sister restaurant Peche. This is probably a top 5 meal I have ever had.
I just finished work late, the place was recommended to me. I sat alone at the bar and ordered alligator bites which were the tastiest. I literally can't wait to eat them again. 
The catfish with grits and charred greens blew my mind. Kudos to this amazing chef.

Order fried alligator and it was good but the chili garlic Mayo tasted just like regular Mayo. The bread was amazing!!!! I loved it and the butter but it came a little too late in my opinion. The service was average. Not going to complain but was far from impressed. As. For an entree I got the fried catfish. That was a mistake. It was so SOUR like someone had squeezed two full limes on top of a finished dish so that was all I tasted. It had zero balance and I even through it was $25+tax I couldn't eat it. I just filled up in bread instead. The greens were horseradish and again hit you straight in the nose. Horseradish and limes.... Gross. The grits were the best part but under seasoned. I mixed it with the bread butter to get it a bit better. I tried some of my friends Mac n cheese as well and thought the roux was gritty and the overall flavor could use a punch up. It was too mellow for me but everyone else loved it. 

TLDR: feels like I ate a meal that was A+ by design but was executed by the reserve squad. Great ideas but less than average execution. I should've stopped at the table bread

The atmosphere was cute, wooden chairs and tables, cozy enough. The rolls that came out were hot and delicious. We ordered the gumbo, which was very flavorful, but it came out room temperature. After 5 minutes, it was cold. Had to ask to have it reheated. Head cheese board was good, but an acquired taste. The pickles that come with it are sweet pickles for those who are picky about their pickles. Mac and cheese was good, but average. Overall a very average meal for high prices.

Definitely the least memorable dining experience I had during my trip to New Orleans. Nothing was actively bad but all of the food was resoundingly "meh". Given the price point and the wealth of other incredible options, I would not go back
